title: Vote to Recall Rizzo Is Barred by Court
Stage: A Peabody To the Music of Time
U.S. Uncovers Evidence Indicating An F.B.I. BreakIn in Upstate Town
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Justice Department prosecutors investigating illegal burglaries by Federal agents have found evidence of a breakin at an upstate New York home occupied by Stewart Albert, a longtime radical believed to have connections to the terrorist Weather Underground organization.

title: Art People
description: IT WAS 10 DAYS that shook Larry Rivers, says Larry Rivers, art American cultural asset recently circulated by the State Department and the Soviet Artists' Union on a strenuous tour of Russia. They had something arranged for us [Mr. Rivers was accompanied by his son Steven] from the time we opened our eyes in the morning until we closed them at night. And all the while, we were recording everything on videotape.

title: NIXON SPOKESMAN TERMS MEMOIRS REPORT FALSE
description: A spokesman for Richard M. Nixon said Wednesday that a published report about details of the former President's memoirs was false.

title: Yanks' Nettles Declines Offer of Rest In Order to Get Ready for Playoffs
description: This is the time division champions rest weary legs and tired backs, let aching muscles heal and generally get players ready for the pennant playoffs. This is a new time for these Yankees and they are using it in different ways.

title: Upbeat on Africa
description: It was a thoroughly upbeat analysis of the situation in southern Africa that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger gave the United Nations General Assembly yesterday on the basis of his recent shuttle diplomacy. He hoped for the independence of Namibia (SouthWest Africa) within a fixed, short time limit, hailed a historic break from the past that could ease Rhodesia's transition to black majority rule, and flatly if cautiously predicted the end of apartheid in South Africa.

title: 4 LEFKOWITZ AIDES INDICTED ON BRIBERY; Attorney General Recalls a Meeting in 74 on Loans to Staff
description: Three members of the staff of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, including his personal secretary, were charged yesterday with perjury and accepting bribes to favor New York State construction contractors.

title: TROY RESIGNS AS HEAD OF FINANCE PANEL
description: City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., who was sentenced Wednesday to two months in jail on his plea of guilty to filing a false income tax return, resigned yesterday as chairman of the Council's powerful Finance Committee.

title: U.S. Oil Family Finds Libya Like Home
description: TRIPOLI, LibyaLife in Libya is like the Bible Belt in Oklahomavery puritanical. accordine to the Ivey family.

title: A Museum's Contrast in Crafts
2 Plead Guilty on Falsifying Data For Bank Loans to Adlay Jewelry
description: A businessman and an accountant have pleaded guilty to charges of submitting false financial statements to obtain $3 million in bank loans for a Manhattan jewelry company that later went bankrupt.

title: Art: Daniel Buren Surprises Again
Weekend Gardening: Frost Warning
description: Autumn has slipped in. but all is not quiet in the vegetable garden yet. On the long list of puttering to be done before the black frost withers the green are such tasks as potting up some parsley, chives and mint from the outdoor herb patch to tide the chef over the winter.

title: SPECIAL PROSECUTOR ENDING FORD INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The Watergate special prosecutor is winding up his inquiry into President Ford's campaign finances and there is a growing indication that no criminal prosecution of Mr. Ford is contemplated, according to interviews with officials in Grand Rapids, Mich., and with Government sources here.

title: Film Festival: Truffaut Kids
PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Tragedy can seem more tragic to those who don't suffer it than to those who do. Just notice how the ablebodied cringe when they talk about the handicapped.

title: Geraldine van der Kwast Wed to G.F. Thomas
description: St. James's Episcopal Church here was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Geraldine van der Kwast to George Francis Maitland Thomas.

title: Lawyer Given 7 Years for Embezzling From Clients
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 30A Westchester lawyer who admitted embezzling $336,000 from the estate of his priest and other clients was sentenced today in County Court to seven years in prison. He will be eligible for parole in one year.

title: New York May Start Flu Shots on Oct. 12
description: New York City residents will have to wait at least until Oct. 12 before they can get vaccinations against swine flu, while residents of Connecticut, New Jersey, upstate New York and Long Island are expected to begin receiving their injections anytime from the next few days to several weeks.

title: Dance: Whirl From the West
description: WELL, my oh my, oh golly! What was the fuss all about? The Utah Repertory Dance Theater, now in its 10thanniversary season, had planned to come to New York for its fourth local season. Sensibly enough, it had planned to appear at the Marymount Manhattan College, which has one of the best small dance auditoriums in town.

title: Ford's Dealers Devise Strategy To Offset Strike
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 30Frank Kistler considers himself one of this city's best salesmen. And in the next few weeks he will get a real chance to prove it.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times last Saturday reported incorrectly that Jimmy Carter had erred, in debating President Ford, when he stated that there were now fewer people working in private, nonfarm jobs than there were when Mr. Ford became President. The figures cited in The Times were provided by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which did not subtract government employees in making its compilation. As of last month, there were 298,000 fewer persons in nonfarm, nongovernment employment than there were in August, 1974.

title: Photos of 48 Fall of Old Jerusalem Evoke Tears of Israeli Survivors
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 30The invited guests moved quietly and thoughtfully past the exhibition of photographs chronicling May 28, 1948, when the Jewish quarter of the Old City of Jerusalem fell into the hands of Jordanian troops.

title: Article 2  No Title
Guerrilla Group Rejects Plan
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, Sept. 30 (Reuters)A statement rejecting the BritishAmerican proposals on Rhodesia put forward by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger was issued here today in the name of the Rhodesian African Nationalist Guerrilla Army.

title: Nationalists in Conflict
description: GABORONE, Botswana, $ept. 30Conflicts among Rhodesia's black nationalists emerged today as a major obstacle in the path of the conference that Britain has called to set up an interim multiracial government in the whiteruled territory

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up 4.7%
description: Special to The New York Times

title: At the Movies
description: I HEARD ABOUT the audition the day before it took place, said Andrea Marcovicci. I didn't know what the story was about, who was in it, or anything, and when I walked in the door, there was Woody Allen, waiting to read with me.

title: China PostMao
description: Mao Tsetung has been dead less than a month but he is still being glorified almost as if he were still living. Those who today hold power in Peking, are such a relatively unknown group that their first priority has been, understandably, to stress the theme of continuity, to call for unity, and above all to try to keep daily life on an even keel during this potentially dangerous transition period.

title: Chrysler to Raise Prices by 5.8% On 77's, Following G.M. and Ford
HEALEY ASKS SUPPORT OF WEAKENING POUND FROM LABOR PARTY
description: BLACKPOOL. Sept. 30  British Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey rushed here unexpectedly today to ask support for the pound from his own Labor Party.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
Chinese Conflicts Are Persisting After Mao's Death
description: HONG KONG, Friday, Oct 1China marks its national day today, three weeks after the death of Chairman Mao Tsetung, amid contradictory signals that appear to indicate that the conflict among Peking's leaders is as it was before Mao's passing, with the basic issues of succession and future policy still unresolved.

title: How Chrysler Steered Out of a Rut
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich.Exactly one year ago today, a new driver moved to the wheel of the nation's third largest automotive company to steer it out of a deep financial rut. Together with his predecessor, he had made a number of moves earlier to try to facilitate a ride to smoother ground, and then added several more himself during the last 12 months. It is clear now that John J. Riccardo, the 52yearold former accountant who was invested with the title of chairman and chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation last fall, has succeeded in steering the big automotive company out of its morass and back to a freewheeling highway. He has made the operation a team effort with his partner, Eugene A. Cafiero, president, instead of the oneman rule in the Lynn Townsend regime.

title: Books of The Times
description: WE put up with our lives, Sheila Redden said to her friend Peg Conway on page 153 of The Doctor's Wife, and this is about the first characteristic Brian Moore line in the book. Until then, this could have been a conventional romance written by just about any competent writer.

title: Rhodesian Catholic Commission Charges Mistreatment of Blacks
description: LONDON, Sept. 30 (Reuters)A Roman Catholic commission in Rhodesia today accused the Government of using abduction, torture and murder against the country's black population.

title: Hockey Club Changes Opener
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 30 (AP)The World Hockey Association opener for the Indianapolis Racers has been moved up a day, from Oct. 9 to Oct. 8, the club said today. The change, made with the approval of the visiting Minnesota Fighting Saints, was to accommodate fans who didn't want to miss the first game of baseball's National League playoffs, between Philadelphia and Cincinnati, or the Indiana University homecoming.

title: Carter Campaigns With Moynihan
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 30Jimmy Carter and Daniel P. Moynihan campaigned together here today in search of votes as a poll showed that both Democrats were trailing their opponents in Erie County, where Democrats outnumber Republicans, and even in this heavily Democratic city.

title: Ford's Brother Aids Buckley Effort
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 30President Ford's brother Tom urged Westchester Republicans today to work harder to get the President and Senator James L. Buckley elected, warning that Republicans alone probably couldn't elect a dogcatcher.

title: Schlesinger, Back in U.S., Favors Selling Weapons to Peking Regime
description: James R. Schlesinger, the former Secretary of Defense, said yesterday that he had discussed Chinese defense problems with leaders in Peking, and he reiterated that he thought the United States might consider selling weapons to the Chinese.

title: General Strike Urged in Madrid
description: MADRID, Sept. 30 (Reuters)Opposition groups have called for a general strike in Madrid tomorrow to protest the killing of a 21yearold student during an antiGovernment demonstration this week.

title: Restaurants
description: Anyone who appreciates a really elegant interpretation of Italian cooking will understand why San Marco has held on to its loyal coterie for the last 14 years, 12 of which were spent at its first home on West 55th Street, and the last two in its present site on West 52d Street, just opposite the 21 Club. This newer setting is far more spacious and comfortable than the old, far less likely to bring out latent traces of claustrophobia.

title: Article 1  No Title
Buffalo Philharmonic To Open at Carnegie
description: There is an unkind wisecrack in A Chorus Line about Buffalo being a place where committing suicide is redundant. But a city that has such cultural institutions as the innovative Center for Creative and Performing Arts at the State University, the excellent Albright Knox Art Gallery and the progressiveminded Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, can't be all that bad.

title: Protesting Boaters in Auckland Block a U.S. Cruiser Briefly
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Friday, Oct. 1A flotilla of 80 to 100 small craft forced the United States nuclear cruiser Long Beach to halt for half an hour at the entrance to Auckland harbor early this morning.

title: NIGHT COURT IS DISRUPTED AS BOMB DESTROYS DOOR
description: An explosive device was detonated late last night behind the Criminal Court building in lower Manhattan, destroying a door and disrupting night court. The police reported there were no injuries.

title: A Dugout Explores Indian Country of the Bronx
description: The river was still. Like a mirror it gave back to the sky a shimmering picture of clouds crossed by gulls equally friendly with water and air. The hazy veil of the morning was lifting on this ancient Siwanoy Indian country.

title: Bryant's Burden: Stop Mel Gray
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y.. Sept. 30Two years ago, the Giants knew about William Bryant.

title: Quake Shakes Ionian Islands
description: ATHENS, Sept. 30 (AP)A sharp earthquake shook islands in the Ionian Sea off Greece's west, coast today but no casualties or damage were reported. the national seismological service said.

title: Tax Charge Against Davidoff Dropped on Agreement to Pay
description: A tax charge was dismissed here yesterday against Sidney Davidoff, a special assistant to former Mayor John V. Lindsay. Mr. Davidoff had been indicted earlier this year for failure to file withholding taxes for his employees at a midtown restaurant, Jimmy's, which is no longer in operation.

title: N.A.A.C.P. STILL FACES $1.2 MILLION PENALTY
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 30A Mississippi judge refused today to overturn or stay a $1.2 million judgment against the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, a judgment the moneyshort civil rights organization said would substantially and severely threaten its existence.

title: Rise of 19% in Medicare Payments By Recipients Set by U.S. Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)The Social Security Administration today ordered a 19 percent increase in the amount of money the nation's 25 million Medicare recipients must pay to cover their portion of hospital or nursing home costs.

title: Notes on People
description: Liberia's President, William R. Tolbert, was impressed with New York's harmonious mingling of races, he said at City Hall yesterday. The situation here, he said, contrasts with intolerable bigotry in southern Africa, where a minority suppresses the majority. After making President Tolbert an honorary New York citizen, Mayor Beame added a version of his most serviceable pleasantry: When I say that your honorary citizenship will enrich New York City, I don't mean that we're going to send you a tax bill.

title: A.T.&T. BILL IS CALLED COSTLY TO CONSUMER
Vacant S.I. Building Burns
description: A fouralarm fire swept through a vacant commercial building on the Staten Island waterfront yesterday, rapidly spreading to a barge docked on Kill Van Kull. No injuries were reported. The Fire Department said the blaze broke out shortly after 1:30 P.M. at the building formerly occupied by the Brewers Drydock Company, 2912 Richmond Terrace.

title: Memorial Services
description: GLICKMANRabbi Jack Stenley, Memorial Day is second day of Rosh Hashanah from 207579St. Brooklyn, N. Y. C.

title: GEN. W.H. ARNOLD, 75, W.W. II LEADER, DIES
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Sept. 30 (UPI)Lieut. Gen. William H. Arnold, who commanded the Americal Division in the South Pacific during World War II, died today at Lake Forest Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: RADIO
Pickets Protest High Drug Prices
description: NUTLEY, Sept. 30About 50 members of the North Jersey Federation of Senior Citizens demonstrated here today outside Hoffman La Roche Inc., the pharmaceutical company, to dramatize their support of an Assembly bill aimed at lowering the price of prescription drugs.

title: Pennsylvania Health Aide Announces Plan to Widen Hunt for Cause of Illness
description: HERSHEY. Pa., Sept. 30The Pennsylvania Secretary of Health announced today steps to broaden the search for the cause of a mysterious disease that killed 29 persons in July and August.

title: Yom Kippur Conflict Irks Owner of Rams
description: LOS ANGELES. Sept. 30 (UPI)Carroll Rosenbloom, owner of the Los Angeles Rams, strongly criticized Commissioner Pete Rozelle today for having scheduled Sunday's MiamiLos Angeles Rome in Miami several hours before the beginning of Yom Kippur, the Jewish high holy day.

title: VIDEOTAPE SHOWING DISTURBS KALLINGER
description: HACKENSACK. Sept. 30Joseph Kallinger watched himself closely today on television during his murder trial. What he saw apparently upset him. On sets placed in front of the jury, Judge Thomas F. Dalton of Superior Court and the defendant was a videotape of a police lineup in Harrisburg, Pa., on Jan. 27, 1975 19 days after the murder of Maria Fasching in Leonia.

title: PRICES FOR BONDS GAIN MODERATELY
description: Prices rose moderately in the credit markets yesterday in response to the record $2.8 billion decline in the basic money supply in the week ended Sept. 22. The response in the money and bond markets was much less pronounced than a week ago, when the money supply soared $4,5 billion in its biggest increase to date. Treasury notes and bonds rose  or  point during the first five or 10 minutes after the Federal Reserve's weekly money supply figures were published after 4 P.M. and then the credit markets reaction lost its force. Since most moneymarket economists had expected a large decline in the money supply, the figures had been largely discounted.

title: Nets, Without Erving, Crush Knicks in Preseason Opener
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Sept. 30Near the end of the seasonopening exhibition game tonight between the Nets and the Knicics, a cry came down from the Nassau Coliseum directed at Coach Red Holzman of the Knicks from one of the 8.421 fans on hand.

title: Plan for Resources Bank Will Be Pressed by U.S. At I.M.F. Manila Meeting
description: MANILA, Sept. 30The United States will ask the development committee of the World Bank to accept the concept of an international resources bank as part of its work and study program for the coming year.

title: Reserve Report
G.O.P. Allies of Lefkowitz Regard Him as Invulnerable
description: Through good times and bad, through periods when the political world was placid and when it was frenzied, Louis J. Lefkowitz, the people's lawyer, as he proclaims himself, has been returned by ever more lopsided votes as Attorney General of New York State.

title: CRC Investors Acquires 65% of the Shares of Crutcher
Shapiro Says DuPont Plans Cut in 77 Capital Spending
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company is deliberately slowing down its capital expenditures next year, according to Irving S. Shapiro, chairman of the company.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Army Secretary Martin R. Hoffmann told the New Jersey Congressional delegation that the Army would conskier alternatives presented by the delegation before deciding what to do with Fort Monmouth. Mr. Hoffmann commented after attending a briefing called by Representative James J. Howard, Democrat of the Third Congressional District, to discuss alternatives to an Army plan to relocate about 570 electronic's workers from Fort Monmouth to posts in Maryland and Virginia. Mr. Hoffmann was presented with an 11page document that recommended keeping most elements of the Army's electronics research and development work at Fort Monmouth.

title: Goodbody Is Found Guilty of Submitting False Finance Data
Norton's Loss Was the Dips Gain
description: Back when the Dodgers still played baseball in Ebbets Field, the big, bellicose umpire, George Magerkurth, called a close one against them and was set upon by a stocky character in a polo shirt who sprang from the stands and struck him repeated blows. Maje was mortified, especially when papers all over the land published a photograph showing him flat on his back with his assailant astride his bosom, but he declined to press charges. It turned out that the stocky guy had a record, and he went back in the slammer anyway as a parole violator. Years passed before Judge Sam Leibowitz came up with a sequel.

title: California Conflict
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept 30Senator Robert Dole, the Republican VicePresidential nominee, told a group of MexicanAmericans in Los Angeles on Sept. 24 that I have not taken a public stand on Proposition 14. That's the controversial ballot initiative to insure fair labor practices in California's striferiddled agricultural areas.

title: Composer, Aged 6, to Play an Original Song on TV
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, Sept. 30George Mark Appleyard of this Bergen County community is the youngest of 30,000 composers and lyricists registered with Broadcast Music Inc. He has just turned 6.

title: Beame Reports the City's Deficit Is Less Than Planners Predicted
description: Closing the books on the first year of its plan for New York City's fiscal recovery, Mayor Beame's office reported yesterday that the city spent $13.6 billion for the year ended last June 30, producing a deficit of nearly $1 billion, which, big as it was, still fell within the most recent expectations.

title: Art: Rodin's Homages To Balzac at Modern
description: RODIN AND BALZAC: These two great names, which still resound with the Promethean energies that made Paris the literary and artistic capital of the world in the 19th century, are the subject of a small, elegant and instructive exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. Rodin & Balzac is a small show based on a big storya story that takes us back to an era when even the greatest names in the arts were still subject to violent controversies of taste.

title: Incumbent Role A Boon to Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30One day after Jimmy Carter challenged him to 'face the news media for a change, President Ford did today, but on his own terms. In the process, the President demonstrated that he had discovered a central advantage in campaigning for the White House from the White House. He can largely control the political environment. That Mr. Ford mastered, somewhat belatedly, the knack of incumbency helps to explain why it is the Democratic challenger, rather than the Republican President, who is on the defensive with 33 days remaining in the election contest.

title: Kissinger, at U.N., Urges Africans To Resist Any Outside Interference
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger called on the loaders of Africa today to seize this moment to pull back from the brink of interracial war and to devise their own political future without the interference of outside powers.

title: DELEGATES OF P.B.A. REJECT AGREEMENT REACHED BY LEADERS
NASSAU SUPERVISORS REACH POLICE PACT
description: MINEOLA. LI., Sept. 30A tentative agreement was reached today between the Nassau County Board of Supervisors and the county's police union on a longstanding and controversial contract dispute.

title: Carey, Backing Commerce Chief, Assails Nyquist's Education Policies
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 30Governor Carey today not only endorsed the attacks by his Commerce Commissioner, John S. Dyson, on the policies of Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist, but also added some strong criticisms of his own.

title: Lisbon and Luanda Agree to Restore Diplomatic Links
description: LISBON, Sept. 20Portugal and Angola decided tonight to reestablish diplomatic relations at the ambassadorial level.

title: JULIAN L. DEANE IS DEAD
description: Julian L. Deane, a retired New York advertising executive, died Wednesday after a long illness at White Plains Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: 4 LEFKOWITZ AIDES INDICTED ON BRIBERY
Wheat Futures Decline But Soybeans Move Up
description: Wheat prices slid and soybean prices moved up yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: NEW ECOLOGICAL DISASTER FEARED IN ITALIAN BLAST
description: MANFREDONIA, Italy, Sept. 30 (AP)A chemical plant explosion that showered part of this Adriatic town with arsenic could set off an ecological disaster as bad as that in Seveso, a government pollution expert said today.

title: Bridge:
description: Many players are rather vague about the meaning of a one notrump bid when partner has made an overcall or a takeout double.

title: Allied Chemical Cleared by Judge
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 30 (AP)A Federal judge today acquitted the Allied Chemical Corporation of a charge of participating with the Life Science Products Company in polluting the ,James River with the toxic insecticide ingredient Kepone.

title: Retail Store Sales Increase 11%
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Police Command ShakeUp Expected as Result of Incidents at Stadium
Police Stress Unity at Meeting
10 Cities to Get Grants
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)  The Ford Administration announced today that it would give 10 cities grants tataling $4.8 million over the next two years to develop new ways to deal with unemployment and other urban problems. The cities are Albuquerque, N.M.; Baltimore; Bridgeport, Conn.; Buffalo; Chicago; Dayton, Ohio; Kansas City, Mo.; Oakland, Calif.; Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, Pa.

title: Strike Crippling City Services in Youngstown, Ohio
RamsDolphins Contest Is Sunday's TV Treat
Braves Rehire Bristol
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 30 (AP)  Dave Bristol was rehired today as manager of the Atlanta Braves. Ted Turner, president of the National League club, said Bristol had signed a twoyear contract, the terms of which were not disclosed.

title: Are You Going to Danbury Fair?
description: The Great Danbury State Fair opens tomorrow for its 107th year, a little bigger, a mite louder and unashamedly gaudier than ever before.

title: Screen: Woody Allen Is Serious in Front
New Restaurant: A Lot of Green Is Changing Hands
description: If Bruce Zenkel has his way, salads are about to give Ronald McDonald a run for his money.

title: Bronx Policeman Is Shot And Seriously Wounded
description: A Bronx policeman was shot and critically wounded early yesterday morning as he sought to investigate a complaint at a social club in the Morrisania section of the Bronx.

title: Change in Two Debates Is Urged To Bar Jewish Sabbath Conflicts
description: Jimmy Carter and President Ford have been asked to reschedule their final television debate, set for Oct. 22, as well as the Oct. 15 discussion between their two running mates to avoid conflict with the Jewish Sabbath and a religious holiday.

title: Vote to Recall Rizzo Is Barred by Court
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30The Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruled today that Mayor Frank L. Rizzo does not have to face a special recall election in November.

title: In Memoriam
description: WHITTINGHAM, VICENTE JACK. To live in the hearts we leave behind is not to die. Thelma and children.

title: CONGRESS OVERRIDES FORD'S VETO OF BILL ON SOCIAL SERVICES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  Congress easily overrode President Ford's veto of the $56 billion appropriations bill for social services today, with conservatives of both parties joining liberal Democrats in the rebuff to the White House.

title: Palmieri and Gillespie Are Having a Fiesta
description: Eddie Palmieri, whose fans call him the sun of Latin music, and Dizzy Gillespie, the selfdescribed Latinophile of modern jazz, will be performing individually and together tomorrow night at City Center. The concert, which begins at 8 P.M., is their first joint venture, but the tastes and accomplishMents of the two men give the meeting an air of inevitability.

title: SouthWest Africans at U.N. Are Critical of Kissinger
description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., Sept. 30Representatives from the SouthWest African People's Organization s.lid today that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger had been unable to obtain any meaningful commitment from South Africa regarding independence for Namibia, also called SouthWest Africa.

title: 3 Nations Act to Prop Economies As Monetary Ills Menace Europe
description: PARIS, Sept, 30  Monetary storm clouds are hovering once again over Europe as Britain, Italy and France seek to prop up inflationdebilitated economies.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Friday

title: Management
New SyrianSupported Military Force Gains Key Role in Lebanon
description: AIN TURA. Lebanon, Sept. 30The Vanguard of the Lebanese Arab Army, formed four months ago and generally ignored as another military splinter unit in this land of many armies, began to emerge today as the nucleus of the new national armed forces that Syria apparently wants established in Lebanon.

title: United to Order 28 Boeing 727's But Defers a Decision on DC10's
Publishing: Irving Wallace And His Writeon Family
description: DOES THE FAMILY that writes together stay together? Judging by the Wallace family (Irving, Sylvia and the two children, David and Amy), perhaps the most closely knit literary enterprise since the Bront sisters set up shop in Victorian England, the answer would have to he yes. And all four, as they say in Hollywood, are in production.

title: Advertising
NUMBER OF JOBS FELL SHARPLY IN NEW YORK
description: New evidence of deep trouble in New York City's economy was made public yesterday by the State Labor Department as it reported that the number of jobs in the city and the number of its residents at work fell in August to the lowest levels on record for that month.

title: Samuel Blecher Is Dead at 66
description: Samuel Blecher, former regional counsel here for the United States Customs Service died Thursday at his home here. He was 66 years old and lived at 155 East 38th Street.

title: Nation's Air and Water Improving
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The nation's air and water quality are steadily improving, and most of the country can look forward to clean air by the early 1980's, the Council on Environmental Quality reported today.

title: Around the Nation
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.m Sept. 30 (AP)A District Court judge dismissed charges against three persons accused of plotting to kill Senator Edward M. Kennedy and ordered the trio freed today because he said there was no probable cause for prosecution.

title: Music: A Century In Polish Perspective
SUBPOENA IS ISSUED FOR A MEDICAID AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30A Senate subcommittee issued a subpoena today for a Federal official who is charged with taking thousands of dollars in payments from private computer companies that were seeking antifraud contracts with the Medicaid program.

title: J.L. Tribuno, 65, Vermouth Maker
description: John L. Tribuno, head of the largest American producers of vermouth, died yesterday at his Bronxville, N.Y. home. He was 65 years old.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET UNION RESUME ARMS TALKS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30The United States and the Soviet Union have resumed highlevel discussions on a new agreement to curb strategic arms, although American officials doubt that a breakthrough can occur before next year.

title: Gura, ExYank, Is Man of Hour For the Royals
Haiti Announces an Amnesty
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Sept.30 (AP) President JeanClaude Duvalier announced an amnesty for 261 prisoners today. The 23yearold President said that political offenders would be among those released on Nov.17. No names were immediately available.

title: Navy Fails to Find F14
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (Reuters)The United States Navy has failed to find an F14 Tomcat fighter plane lost in the North Atlantic on Sept.14 when it fell from the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy, the Defense Department said today. The department spokesman, Alan Woods, said that the tug Shakori used sonar equipment in a weeklong search of the North Sea bed some 75 miles northwest of Scotland. Additional search areas are being plotted based on the speed and direction of the carrier when the F14 was lost, the spokesman said.

title: A.T.&T.'s 77 Annual Meeting Set
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company says it will hold its annual meeting next year at the H. Roe Bartle Exposition Hall in the Kansas City Convention Center. The meeting, set for April 20, will be the first ever held in Missouri and the 14th held outside New York by the company.

title: Cornfeld Is Sentenced to 3 Months And Fined for Telephonic Blue Box
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 (AP)Bernard Cornfeld, the millionaire financier, was sentenced today to three months in jail and fined $3,000 for his conviction on charges of defrauding the Pacific Telephone Company.

title: Gaullist Legislators Reluctantly Support Giscard's Program
description: ROCAMADOUR, France, Sept. 30New evidence of strain between President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and the Gaullist party surfaced here today at a meeting of Gaullist members of Parliament, the largest bloc supporting the Government.

title: The U.N. Today
The Complexities of a Sea Change
description: As the fifth session of the third Conference on the Law of the Sea ended, the news media reflected an atmosphere of gloom. They said that the proceedings were all but grounded. But there are a few aspects the public is not aware of, and the press has not stressed.

title: Lincoln Center at the Movies
Farmers' Prices Declined by 0.5% In Latest Month
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)Continued declines in returns on meat animals brought the overall average of prices American farmers receive for their raw agricultural products down onehalf of 1 percent between Aug. 15 and Sept. 15, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: New Met Galleries Portray Daily Life Of Ancient Egypt
description: Back! Retreat! Back Up, O Crocodile! Do Not Come After Me, For I Live on Magic! This spell to ward off crocodiles, and another for cockroaches, appear in a 72foot papyrus scroll, a sort of handy guide to the afterlife, found in the fourthcentury B.C. tomb of a priest of Horus Imhotep. It is one of the 45,000 objects in the Metropolitan Museum of Art's vast Egyptian collection, now emerging from storage for display in a dramatic new installation that opens to the public on Oct 16

title: CARTER SCORES FORD ON MISSILES SALE
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30Jimmy Carter denounced the Ford Administration today, saying that it had quelled Congressional opposition and had gone ahead with the sale of airtoground missiles to Saudi Arabia. He accused the Administration of moral bankruptcy and of bowing down to foreign blackmail.

title: 49ers, Under Clark, Are Rebuilding With More Success Than the Jets
description: Not all rebuilding clubs that had dismal records last season and new coaches have lost their first three games, as the Jets have. Case in point: the San Francisco 49ers, whom the. New Yorkers face on Sunday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The death of a 29yearold inmate in his cell on Rikers Island Wednesday night was the eighth suicide in the city's correctional institution this year, officials reported. Fernando Mota of 266 West 73d Street was found hanging from a bedsheet tied to the bars of his cell by a guard making a routine check at 11:30 P.M. He had been serving a 90day sentence for attempted grand larceny and was scheduled for release next Thursday.

title: American Geographical Society Votes to Leave New York for University of Wisconsin in Milwaukee
description: The American Geographical Society of New York, sponsor of famous polar expeditions, holder of a multimilliondollar library and map collection, and a landmark on upper Broadway since 1910, decided yesterday to move to the University of Wisconsin in Milwaukee.

title: Broadway
description: IT IS TIME to think once again about George Gershwin. For one thing, there is his opera Porgy and Bess, which is at the Uris, and for another there is his musical Oh, Kay! which Cyma Rubin wants to revive in the spring. Now there is also Tip Toes, which Benay Venuta wants to revive in a spring production, too. Miss Venuta has never produced a show before, although she has done virtually everything else in show business, and one of them was to be in the California production of Tip Toes in 1928. (Here I am, she says, holding up an old picture, the tall girl at the end.)

title: Pooh's at The Zoo, &
Velez Seeking to Clear My Name
description: Councilman Ramon S. Velez, already embroiled in investigations by the Internal Revenue Service, has volunteered to appear before the City Council's Committee on Standards and Ethics to clear his name of a variety of allegations that have been made against him in the last several months.

title: Orient Express Nears End of Line
description: BUDVA, Yugoslavia, Sept. 30 (Reu ters)The Orient Express, the train that in literature, films and legend was a luxurious and sinister setting for the adventures of aristocrats, spies, elegant women and others on journeys between Paris and Istanbul, will end service next May, a conference of European railway administrations has decided.

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Slip
description: Prices American farmers received for their products declined by onehalf of 1 percent from Aug. 15 to Sept. 15. Page D11.

title: At Coty Award Festivities, A Throng to See the Winners
Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Common Market Pushing Tariff Plan in Third World
description: BANGKOK, ThailandThe European Economic Community is selling its system of tariff preferences in the third world.

title: Southwestern Louisiana Ordered to Forfeit Games
description: LAFAYETTE, La., Sept. 30 (AP)The University of Southwestern Louisiana, cited for using an ineligible player, has been ordered to forfeit football victories over Fresno State and Cincinnati, and has been barred from competing for the Southland Conference championship.

title: Sears Is Suspended as a Lawyer For Transmitting 72 Vesco Gift
U.S. Election Panel Limits Sum Individuals Can Give Candidates
Indians Offer Robinson a Contract As Manager Only for 1977 Season
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 (UPI)Frank Robinson, the playermanager of the Cleveland Indians, confirmed tonight the ball club had offered him a oneyear. $80,000 contract to return only as a manager in the 1977 season.

title: Market Place
description: Athlone Industries, a diversified company that sprang from the ashes of the old Holland Furnace Company, has been buying its own shares aggressively for some time and has stepped up purchases this week on the continuing theory that at current prices the stock is a bargain.

title: Economics of The Times
description: A team effort at the Chrysler Corporation led by John J. Riccardo, the chairman, is pulling the big automotive concern cut of its financial rut and onto a smoother course. Page D3.

title: Fiscal Year Begins Under a Revised Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)The United States Government will start a new fiscal year at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

title: In Rejecting Pact, Delegates Show They Still Want Special Treatment
description: By rejecting a proposed agreement with New York City yesterday, delegates of the police officers union made it clear once again that they wanted and still hoped for special treatment and a pay increase that other unions agreed to defer in New York's fiscal crisis.

title: WILLIAM T. REID IS DEAD
Byrne's Nomination of Legislator For State Justice Is Ruled Illegal
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30Governor Byrne's nomination of State Senator Stephen B. Wiley as a New Jersey Supreme Court justice was rejected today by Judge George Y. Schoch of Superior Court on the ground that the nomination violated the State Constitution.

title: Swine Flu Shots Will Start Today For the Elderly and Ill in 2 Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The nation's largest, most intensive immunization program, the campaign against swine flu, begins tomorrow after serious delays, production problems and controversy.

title: Antiques
description: FROM one famous Madison Avenue specialist in period American furniture have now come two. Benjamin Ginsburg and Bernard Levy have not only parted company, but they have also completed the division of the stock of Ginsburg & Levy Inc.

title: 11 Entered in Marlboro
New Met Galleries Portray Daily Life Of Ancient Egypt
description: Back! Retreat! Back Up, O Crocodile! Do Not Come After Me, For I Live on Magic! This spell to ward off crocodiles, and another for cockroaches, appear in a 72foot papyrus scroll, a sort of handy guide to the afterlife, found in the fourthcentury B.C. tomb of a priest of Horus Imhotep. It is one of the 45,000 objects in the Metropolitan Museum of Art's vast Egyptian collection, now emerging from storage for display in a dramatic new installation that opens to the public on Oct. 16.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: A plan involving up to $107.5 million in a sale for cash of assets is contained in a restructuring of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company announced yesterday by Robert V. Tishman, its president.

title: HARRY SCHWARTZ
description: Harry Schwartz, a retired New York City undertaker who had been president since 1937 of the Gramercy Park Chapel at 152 Second Avenue, at Ninth Street, until his retirement five years ago, died yesterday at the Parkway General Hospital Medical Center in Miami Beach. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan and Miami Beach.

title: About Real Estate
description: For nine years Manuel Rivas has lived in a tenement that he owns at 459 East 135th Street in the Bronx. Seven years ago he had to give up his job as an pantryman in a restaurant because of failing eyesight. He is almost blind now, and most of his income comes from a disability pension of $300 a month.

title: Allen Apologizes to Feuding Phillies
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 (AP)The Philadelphia Phillies president, Ruly Carpenter, said tonight that his controversial first baseman, Dick Allen, had apologized for problems he may have created among team members.

title: The Pop Life
description: THEY MAY NOT RIVAL the Beatles in capturing the aspirations of their time. Or, more depressingly, maybe KC and the Sunshine Band do, if you choose to think of the mid 1970's as a time of jolly, mindless escapism.

title: CLARK TO BE RECEIVER FOR BERGMAN ASSETS
description: Ramsey Clark, former United States Attorney General, is expected to he appointed today as receiver for the assets that Bernard Bergman, convicted nursinghome promoter, has turned over to the state.

title: Novel by Liberal Is Talk of Prague
Economic Recovery Said to Slow More Than Expected in Quarter
description: A spot check of many private economists reflects the belief that the nation's rate of economic recovery slowed more than had been expected during the third quarter of this year.

title: Guerrilla Chiefs Meet in Lebanon To Weigh Their Defeat by Syria
A Fair Deal for Police and City
description: The delegates of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association who rejected a compromise contract settlement yesterday, and their militant factional followers, are acting under delusions that could bring great peril to this city and all its citizens, not excluding policemen.

title: Carter and Defense
Carter Margin In Gallup Poll Is Cut to 5042
description: The latest Gallup Poll on the Presidential contest shows that Jimmy Carter's lead over President Ford has been reduced from 18 percentage points to 8.

title: MONEY SUPPLY FALLS RECORD $2.8 BILLION AFTER UNUSUAL RISE
SMITH PLANNING ROLE IN RHODESIAN PARLEY
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 30 (Reuters)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith would lead the Rhodesian Government delegation to the proposed initial blackwhite talks on progress to black majority rule for Rhodesia, a spokesman for the Prime Minister's office said tonight.

title: Harvard Is Silent on Curry Case
description: Jim Curry, the split end on Harvard University's defending Ivy League football champions, has been dismissed from the team for the remainder of the season. Harvard officials will say only that Curry was dropped for personal reasons. University officials are bound to silence by The Family Education Rights and Privacy Act, authored by Senator James L. Buckley. Republican of New York, and enacted into Federal law on Nov. 19, 1974. Unless, under the law, Curry gives Harvard permission to divulge the reason for his dismissal from the squad, the university is bound to silence.

title: Kissinger's Farewell Addresses
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30There is a sad and even noble strain to Henry Kissinger's speeches these days. Despite his recent diplomatic successes, he seems increasingly aware of the menace and fragility of international life, and determined to express his hopes and fears before he leaves the world stage.

title: Mrs. Abzug Berates Colleagues For Lack of Support in Primary
Private Towaway Program Called Success
Commodity Price Index Declines 0.4 From WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials declined to 199.8 from 200.2 last week.

title: A Grateful Look at Containerships
description: Towering over the water of Elizabeth Channel yesterday was the 700foot containership Albert Maersk, her lightblue hull topped with containers stacked high, a giant crane swung out over her decks.

title: Bobick Waits Eagerly for the Day He Can Challenge for Ali's Crown
A Physician Gives His Colleagues a Bitter Pill to Swallow
description: Despite soaring medical costs and Medicare/Medicaid scandals, doctors still rank high on American's mosttrusted list. The image of the noble healer aside, the physician has, in the words of Dr. Edgar Berman, a stranglehold on patients even Rasputin couldn't get on the czarina. Dr. Berman is an apostate physician who has served on the faculty of Johns Hopkins, was president of MEDICO and doctored with Tom Dooley and Albert Schweitzer. In The Solid Gold Stethoscope, he takes scalpel in hand, with decidedly satirical intent; the, result is a cauterizing book that left me with a single complaint: It hurts when I laugh, doctor.

title: IranGrumman Conflict Sharpening
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept.30A controversy over Iran's order of 80 Grumman jet fighters for more than $2 billion has been deepened by recent statements of Iran's chief arm purchasing officer.

title: Rev. John McGinty, 63, ExNew York Provincial Of the Society of Jesus
description: The Rev. John J. McGinty, a former provincial of the 1,150man Province of the Society of Jesus, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 63 years old and a resident of Jersey City.

title: Vienna Talks Resume
description: VIENNA, Sept. 30The EastWest talks on mutual reduction of forces in Central Europe resumed here today after a 10 week recess without any sign of progress.

title: Ford Disclaims Diverting Funds To His Own Use
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30President Ford said today that he had never diverted any campaign funds for personal use and expressed confidence that the current investigation by the Watergate special prosecutor would show him to be free of any allegations.

title: Films Show Ali Was in Control In Final Round
description: Muhammad All landed three times as many punches as Ken Norton in the key 15th round of their heavyweight title fight last Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium.

title: Byrne Is Named to Head 6Man U.S. Chess Team At the Olympiad in Israel
A Dugout Explores Indian Country of the Bronx
Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30A State com mission with ultimate authority over gambling casinos in New Jersey was proposed today by legislative backers of casinos for Atlantic City.

title: 2 Former Sudan Cabinet Members Sentenced to Death in Absentia
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Sept. 30 (UPI) The Sudan's former Prime Minister and Finance Minister were sentenced to death in their absence today in a mass trial of alleged ringleaders in an abortive July coup, the official Sudan News Agency reported.

title: Dow Stock Average Drops a Point As Traders Await Money Report
description: Stock prices fell slightly yesterday in slow trading that analysts attributed to investor hesitation pending release of the weekly moneysupply figures by the Federal Reserve after the closing bell on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Report on Kosygin Prompts Talk That He May Resign
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30Speculation that Aleksei N. Kosygin may soon step down as Soviet Prime Minister has gained strength in some Soviet circles with the private circulation of a new account of the accident he is reported to have suffered last month.

title: Radio: Alec Wilder and the Art of Pop Song
description: Alec Wilder's book American Popular Song: The Great Innovators, 1900 1950, an acclaimed critical analysis of an element of our popular culture that is largely taken for granted, will form the basis for a series of 26 weekly onehour radio programs starting Sunday on WNYCFM (93.9) at 9:30 P.M.

title: Tenant Promotes Philadelphia Hotel
description: Apparently now is the time for all good tenants to come to the aid of the landlord. That's the attitude at least, of Mme Wellington who operates Wellington Jewels in the Bellevue Stratford Hotel, the Philadelphia hotel that has suffered financially in the wake of the mysterious Legionnaires disease.

title: Mintoff of Malta Is Turning to Many Countries for Help
description: VALLETTA, MaltaA group of Communist Chinese technicians and workers were resting on a barge in the dockyard's harbor where a small Soviet tanker carrying Georgian wine had pulled in for repairs.

title: Mobil Oil Will Pay a Refund to 3 Airlines And Penalty to F.E.A. in Guam Dispute
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation and three of its subsidiaries yesterday agreed to pay $1.9 million to three airlines and a $25.000 penalty payment to the Federal Energy Administration in the conclusion of an 11 month dispute over the pricing of jet fuel in Guam.

title: The 59th Veto
DELEGATES OF P.B.A. REJECT AGREEMENT REACHED BY LEADERS; PICKETING WILL RESUME TODAY Raises and Work Schedule at Issue Command ShakeUp Expected as Result of Stadium Incidents
description: Delegates of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday unanimously rejected an agreement that their leaders had reached with the city in the predawn hours, and they vowed to picket and demonstrate once again around New York City until their demands were met by the Beanie administration.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times last Saturday reported incorrectly that Jimmy Carter had erred, in debating President Ford, when he stated that there were now fewer people working in private, nonfarm jobs than there were when Mr. Ford became President. The figures cited in The Times were provided by the Bureau of Labor Statistics; which did not subtract government employees in making its compilation: As of last month, there were 298,000 fewer persons in nonfarm, nongovernment employment than there were in August, 1974.

title: St. Joe Minerals Corp. and NL Increase Their Prices on Lead
description: A new round of price increases was announced yesterday in the lead industry.

title: VIKING 2 TEST FINDS NO ORGANIC MATTER
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept 30The first organic chemistry test by the Viking 2 lander has failed to turn up any evidence of organic material in the soil of Mars, project scientists reported today.

title: Prisons: Input or Output
description: New York State's new Correction Commission chairman, Stephen J. Chinlund, has had sonic encouraging words for anyone who wants to see the state prison system move away from the bad old days of Attica. He has recently described the state's parole system as a shambles and its probation system as a worse shambles. He has properly identified the crucial role of executive leadership in any effort to reform the prison system, and lie has called, as others have before him, for greater public interest in and knowledge about the prison system.

title: Mime: Hakoshima Environments
description: Like many mime artists, Yass Hakoshima attempts to give an ancient art an uptodate twist. At his concert Thursday night in the New York University Theater, the Japaneseborn performer often sought to give his images a philosophical underpinning.

title: Ford and Gromyko Talk of Arms Curb But Snag Continues
F.B.I. Is Said to Find No Evidence Of Wrongdoing in Ford 72 Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun preparing a final report on its field investigation of an allegation of campaign financing irregularities involving President Ford and has uncovered no substantial evidence that would support criminal charges, well informed Government sources said today.

title: Time to Go Westway
description: After four years of study and debate, Mayor Beanie and Governor Carey have applied to Washington for funds to replace the defunct West Side Highway with a new interstate corridorWestwaywhich would run mostly below ground on made land beyond the existing shoreline, from the Battery to 42d Street. This project, to be financed with $990 million in Federal funds and $110 million in state funds, merits the approval that Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman Jr. indicated he favored in an address here last week.

title: An Average Fellow Is Accuser of Lefkowitz Aides
description: Bernard Landers, the Syracuse accountant who served as a key witness in the Manhattan grandjury investigation of alleged bribery of aides to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, described himself yesterday as just an average fellow who always tried to do a good job.

title: Royals Beaten by Twins But Clinch as A's Lose
Lots of Business to Be Done in Libya, but Doing it Isn't Easy
Watching Pickets in Rain at City Hall, an Officer Tells of Frustration
description: The drizzling rain had slickened Police Officer Frank Knazik's rubber raincoat and put a glistening fringe on his bushy mustache as he stood watching the offduty policemen and their wives demonitrating yesterday at City Hall.

title: U.S. Courts Bar Curb on Funding Some Abortions; Restraints Are Imposed on Medicaid Statute
description: Federal Judges in New York and Washington blocked implementation of a restriction on Federal Medicaid reimbursement for abortions yesterday, only hours after the new social service appropriations bill containing the restrictions became law.

title: First Swine Flu Shots Are Given In Massachusetts and Indianapolis
THE TIMES AND UNION SET NEGOTIATIONS FOR MONDAY
description: Negotiations between the paperhandlers union and The New York Times are scheduled for Monday on the eve of the newspaper's start of printing operations at its new automated offsetprinting plant in Carlstadt, N.J.

title: Hope Wins Title Bout
description: ROME, Oct. 1 (UPI)Maurice Hope of Britain won the European junior middleweight boxing title tonight with a 15thround technical knockout of the defending champion, Vito Antuofermo, of Brooklyn.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1976

title: California Grants Terminally Ill Right to Put an End to Treatment
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1California has become the first state in the nation to grant terminally ill persons the right to authorize the withdrawal of lifesustaining procedures when death is believed imminent.

title: Visconti's 'Ossessione,' at Tully Film Festival In First 35-mm. Version, Initiated Neo-Realism
description: Although there are almost as many definitions of Italian neo-Realism as there are Italian neo-Realist films, Luchino Visconti's first feature, "Ossessione," made in 1942, is generally accepted as having begun the movement whose name was later applied to the work of Antonioni, Rossellini, De Sica and others.The film, which will be presented today at 3 P.M. at the New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall and again on Tuesday at 6:15 P.M., is being shown here in a 35-mm. print for the first time. Earlier showings in the United States had been prohibited because Mr. Visconti had, without permission, helped himself to James M. Cain's novel, "The Postman Always Rings Twice," the rights to which were owned by M-G-M, the studio that later filmed it in 1946 with John Garfield and Lana Turner under Tay Garnett's direction.Comparing the Visconti "Ossessione" with the Garnett "Postman" is to stand a production of "Traviata" next to a McDonald's television commercial, which is not meant to underrate the American film that is as effectively steamy, tough and terse as the Hollywood law allowed in those days.Mr. Visconti follows with remarkable fidelity the Cain story about the handsome young drifter and the youngish wife who, driven by their sexual passion and greed, murder the woman's old husband to get his money and his business, a combination hamburger stand and filling station."Ossessione" today looks to be an extraordinarily majestic, elegant and romantic movie to have started anything labeled neo-Realism. There is even something grand about that bleakness of the Italiian landscapes, to say nothing of the mood. When the illicit lovers, Gino (Massimo Girotti) and Giovanna (Clara Calamai), are exchanging lustful glances at the dinner table, the soundtrack rumbles with the sounds of distant thunder and frantic cries of caged farm animals. Under these circumstances, one is disappointed that the characters don't sing."Ossessione," which also began the late Mr. Visconti's remarkable film career, may be slow-going to the uninitiated, but its historical importance is not to be denied.

title: MOTHER NINETT A IONATA, HEADED A TEACHING ORDER
description: Mother Ninetta Ionata, a former superior general of the Religious Teachers Filippini, a Roman Catholic women's teaching order, died Wednesday at Sao Paulo, Brazil. She was 88 years old and a resident of that city. Mother Ninetta, who became a member of the order in her native Italy in 1908, was sent to the United States in 1910 by Pope Pius X to open a parochial school for the children of Italian immigrants in St. Joachim Parish in Trenton.

title: RICHARD JOSEPH DEAD
description: Richard Joseph, writer of travel books and the travel editor of Esquire magazine, died Thursday aboard a plane on his way back to New York from a travel conference in St. Thomas, V. I. He was 66 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Goshen, Conn.

title: Defense Seeking a Shift in Trial In Murder of Arizona Reporter
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 1Lawyers for a 32 yearold man accused of the carbombing murder of Don Bolles, a reporter for The Arizona Republic, are seeking to have the trial moved out of Phoenix because of what they call massive, pervasive, and prejudicial publicity over the case.

title: Books of The Times
description: In recent years, as we staggered out of the mud and moral chaos of Vietnam and Watergate, many Americans have turned with eager nostalgia to a popular fantasy of England at the turn of the century, a lost world of grace, order and the thick, comforting social texture so evident in the television series Upstairs, Downstairs and a score of new books on Edwardian and Georgian life. There seems to be unending fascination with the elegant lassitude and lawnparty wit of the Bloomsbury set, with its sexual gossip and whiff of upperclass perversion.

title: Exxon Increases Prices Of Heavy Fuel Oil in East Up to 40 Cents a Barrel
description: Exxon U.S.A., the chief domestic affiliate of the Exxon Corporation, announced yesterday that it had increased prices for individual grades of heavy fuel oil sold on the East Coast by as much as 40 cents a barrel. A spokesman said this reflected competitive market conditions. However, the spokesman denied that there was any connection between the increase and a rise in the price of heavy crude oil announced earlier this week in Venezuela.

title: Miss Quinlan Still in Coma
description: MORRIS PLAINS, N.J., Oct. 1 (AP)Karen Anne Quinlan, her body emaciated after nearly 18 months in a coma, is alive without the help of a respirator that her parents had requested be shut off.

title: Reagan Sees Carter Lagging
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 1 (UP1)Ronald Reagan says that Jimmy Carter suffered a great loss of momentum in his drive for the presidency and one reason is his statement to Playboy magazine about adultery, Mr. Reagan, who narrowly lost the Republican Presidential nomination to President Ford, told newsmen yesterday that it appeared to him that Jimmy Carter can beat Jimmy Carter.

title: Nets Foil Bullets, 9492, After 76ers Rout Knicks
Bronfman Abduction Trial Open's
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 1The lawyer for one of the two men charged with kidnapping Samuel Bronfman 2d, heir to the Seagram liquor fortune, suggested today that the case might have homosexual overtones and that young Bronfman had helped stage his abduction to extort money from his wealthy father.

title: 12 Charged With Food Stamp Fraud
description: Eight men and four women were charged in Manhattan yesterday with defrauding the Federal Government of more than $2 million by cashing stolen food stamps.

title: Giants Planning First Lineup Change of the Season Not Due to Injury
Marlboro Casts Forego In Another Heavy Role
description: Unless more rain keeps the track muddy, Forego and Tommy Trotter will renew their battle of the scales today in the $283,700 Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park.

title: Hawaiians Are Choosing Nominees For Seat in the U.S. Senate Today
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 1The confrontation in tomorrow's Hawaii primary election between Representatives Patsy T. Mink and Spark M. Matsunaga for the Democratic nomination to the United States Senate has failed to produce the bloodbath that the Democrats feared and Republicans hoped to see.

title: EGYPT'S FOREIGN MINISTER ON SURPRISE PARIS VISIT
description: PARIS, Oct. 1Diplomatic sources said today a surprise visit here by Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt indicated that efforts were under way to start Paris peace talks to end the Lebanese civil war.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR, on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up the lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station.

title: West PointPepperell Posts 50.6% Rise In Quarter Net and 36.1% For the Year
James N. MacLean, Lawyer, 85
description: James N. MacLean, who was active in civic roles on Long Island and who retired as a partner in the law firm of Scheiman, Albert & MacLean in New York City in 1961, died Wednesday in Glen Cove Community Hospital. He was 85, years old,

title: U.S., IN MAJOR SHIFT, SETS 3YEAR SUPPLY IN STRATEGIC STOCKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The General Services Administration announced today a major policy change in the strategic stockpile program designed to assure a threeyear supply of critical materials in event of a major war.

title: Humphrey to Undergo Surgery
Strength of Red Apple Chain Lies in CountryStore Link
U.S. Bans Showing Of Festival Movie
description: United States Customs Service officers demanded yesterday that the Japanese film In the Realm of the Senses. which was scheduled to be shown tonight at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, be removed from the program and that it be turned over to its New York division of import compliance for being obscene.

title: Lisbon Decrees Labor Restrictions
description: LISBON, Oct. 1Portugal's Socialist Government moved today to curb Communist influence in trade unions and to restore order to labormanagement relations as a means of reviving the country's failing economy.

title: THOUSANDS OF POLICE PROTEST AT CITY HALL TO RENEW DEMANDS; RALLY IS RELATIVELY ORDERLY Department Filing Charges Against 6 Officers, Including One Accused of Jostling Operations Chief
description: Thousands of shouting offduty policeofficers marched around City Hall in the rain yesterday and then held an even more raucous rally nearby to protest what their leaders called the Beame administration's irresponsibility in deferring pay raises and lengthening the work schedules. for New York's 18,000 policemen.

title: President to Fly West on Monday On a 6Day Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)President Ford will leave on Monday for a sixday trip to California, Oklahoma and Texas, Ron Nessen, his press secretary, said today.

title: FACTORY ORDERS OFF BY 0.8% FOR AUGUST
description: New factory orders fell for the second consecutive month in August, declining by $804 million or 0.8 percent to seasonably adjusted $94 billion, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

title: NEW LAW EXPANDS GOVERNMENT POWER IN ANTITRUST FIELD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The antitrust bill that President Ford, heeding the recommendations of his political advisers above those of his businessoriented aides, signed into law last night will significantly expand the scope of the antitrust laws.

title: POUND, AT $1.6670, ENDS WORST WEEK
description: LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP)The pound moved erratically today and ended its worstever week at an exchange rate of $1.6670, almost unchanged from yesterday, as the British Government struggled with ways to halt inflation and revive the economy.

title: Labor Feuds and the Pound Sinks
description: BLACKPOOL England. Oct. 1  It wasn't Prime Minister James Callaghan's modest old Rover parked outside the main entrance to the Winter Gardens, where the British Labor Party ended its annual weeklong conference today. The only car allowed there was the black Bentley limousine of the ambassador from the Ivory Coast.

title: DISSIDENTS PRESS ESSEX DEMOCRATS
description: NEWARK, OCT. 1Dissident Essex County Democrats have decided to ask the Appellate Division of Superior Court to force Harry Lerner, the Essex County Democratic chairman, to give a detailed accounting of funds spent by the party in the last eight years.

title: Pierce Fills In On the Piano For Ill Basie
description: Count Basie's orchestra played at Pace University's Schimmel Center on Thursday evening, but Mr. Basie was not at his customary place at the piano. He is still recovering from a heart attack suffered earlier this month. His place at the keyboard was taken by Nat Pierce, one of the most accomplished Basieinfluenced pianists, while Clark Terry, a member of the Basie band from 1948 to 1951, appeared as guest soloist and front man for the band.

title: Bridge:
description: If the opponents open at the onelevel, almost any overcall up to the game level has an obvious useful meaning or can be assigned one by partnership agreement. The only exception that comes to mind is a bid of three notrump following an opposing opening bid of one notrump.

title: Burns's 65132 Leads by Shot At Las Vegas
Loft Jazzmen Move Uptown To Recital Hall
description: Loft jazz moved out of its customary lower Manhattan haunts and into Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday evening, when two of the moreinteresting improvisational ensembles, AIR and the Oliver Lake trio, presented a joint concert. The transition was not particularly smooth, but the concert's faults had more to do with the surroundings than with the music.

title: SYRIANS, CHRISTIANS RESUME OFFENSIVE AGAINST GUERRILLAS; P.L.O. REJECTS NEGOTIATIONS Fighting Focuses on Mountain Slope Vital to the Palestinians and the Leftist Moslems of Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct, 1Syrian and Lebanese Christian forces today resumed their offensive against the Palestinian guerrillas, seeking to drive them out of a mountain area directly overlooking Beirut.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LONG SHORT RUN Bobby Short starts his 10th season of tickling the keyboard and passing the nights in happy song at the Cafe Carlyle this weekend. Mr. Short, as much of an entertainment staple as our town can boast, spends each night, except Sunday and Monday, in the comfortable Upper East Side room in the Hotel Carlyle, 35 East 76th Street, at Madison Avenue.

title: Swift Closing Two Beef Plants
description: CHICAGO, Oct. I (UPI)The Swift Fresh Meats Company, a division of Swift & Company said today it was closing two of its 13 beefdressing plants due a narrowing marging between livecattle costs and dressedbeef prices. The closing of plants in Grand Island, Neb., and Tolleson, Ariz., the the layoff of 450 employes will he attractive until the price spread returns to acceptable levels, Swift added.

title: A Jury Proposes Major Changes In Court and Jail Security Facilities
description: A Manhattan grand jury yesterday recommended major changes in city courtroom and jail security facilities, including the reopening of the Tombs for prisoners awaiting trial and the installation of visual devices in cells for continuous monitoring of prisoners.

title: People in Sports
OneDay Protest Strike in Madrid Is Partial Success
description: MADRID, Oct. 1A leftist call for a day of struggle in Madrid evoked a spotty response today. Thousands of workers staged job actions or strikes, but life in most of the capital went on nor%mally.

title: Moscow Is Conciliatory In Greetings to Peking, But Makes No New Offer
description: MOSCOW, Oct.1The Soviet Union expressed its willingness today to normalize relations with China but offered no new proposals for winding down the cold war between the two countries.

title: 57,000 Ask Refunds of 3 Sued Stores

Ford Reallocates Military Raise
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI)President Ford reallocated today his recently ordered 4.83 percent pay increase for military personnel to reflect more fairly the cost of living in Government housing. He said onefourth of the higher pay by grade would be shifted to the basic allowance for living quarters, and unmarried personnel would get some of the allocation in cash.

title: LEONID BERMAN, PAINTER OF NEOROMANTIC SCENES
description: Leonid Berman, who painted over the signature of Leonid and who was a representative of the neoRomantic school, died at St. Luke's Hospital yesterday. He was 80 years old, and lived in New York City.

title: Cape Cod Sea Lab Now AllYear Effort
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass.The arrival of fall here used to signal the departure not only of thousands of tourists but also of the hundreds of scientists who come from all over the world to spend their summers at the Marine Biological Laboratory.

title: House Rejects Move To Expel Hinshaw
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)The House shouted down today an effort by a California Republican to expel another California Republican who is appealing a bribery conviction.

title: POSTPONEMENT WON ON CRIMEFUND CUTS
description: New York City won four weeks' time yesterday to try to alter a state plan that would substantially reduce the city's share of Federal anticrime money.

description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 1President Hafez alAssad has rejected a direct appeal from the Soviet leader, Leonid I Brezhnev, for the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon.

title: Carter Was Guest Twice At a Corporation Resort While Georgia Governor
Bill De Young Gives Dance Of Emptiness
description: Choreography without content and ceremony without circumstance met disastrously in Bill De Young's Ancient Rooms, Passing Ruins, Thursday evening at the American Theater Laboratory. The two were obviously meant for each other.

title: Beame and the Police: It All Boils Down to Fiscal Crisis
description: It is as if the events of the last week were designed to make a vicious mockery of the exuberant days of Operation Sail, the Democratic National Convention and the summertime spree in which city officials gleefully pinned Big Apple insignias on everybody's lapels. The incidents involving the police were telling a different story they illustrated the fact that the fiscal crisis is still calling the tune in New York City.

title: All Declares He Is Retiring To Assist the Islamic Cause Ali Says He's Retiring To Aid Islamic Cause
description: Muhammad Ali, a prophet of the unpredictable, scored again yesterday. Instead of confirming an expected final title defense against George Foreman, the 34yearold world heavyweight champion announced his retirement from boxing.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun preparing a final report on its field investigation of an allegation of campaign financing irregularities involving President Ford and has uncovered no substantial evidence that would support criminal charges, well informed Government sources said today.

description: WOODS HOLE, Mass.The arrival of fall here used to signal the departure not only of thousands of tourists but also of the hundreds of scientists who come from all over the world to spend their summers at the Marine Biological Laboratory.

title: Prospective Voters Warned to Register
description: New York City's Board of Elections reminded prospective voters yesterday that they might register at their local polling places today between 1 P.M. and 9 P.M. and during the same hours next Tuesday.

title: FORD REBUKES BUTZ FOR SLUR ON BLACKS; Agriculture Secretary Will Make Public Apology for Remarks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1In a rare public upbraiding of a Cabinet official, President Ford summoned Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz to the While House today and gave him a severe reprimand for making racist remarks that were highly offensive, a White House spokesman said.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Carey announced yesterday the appointment of a sevenmember task force to study the problems of housing developments built under the New York State MitchellLama Law. The law has authorized New York State and City financing for the construction of more than 250 middleincome apartment projectsmany now in financial troublethat house more than 100,000 families across the state. Appointment of the task force was part of a compromise agreement last summer that ended a long dispute between the state and residents of the 15,000family Coop City in the Bronx, a statefinanced MitchellLama project. The dispute involved a sharp increase sought in apartmentmaintenance charges. The task force will be headed by Joseph B. Goldman, Acting State Commissioner of Housing and Community Renewal.

title: U.S. WILL NOT OPPOSE G.E. BID FOR MERGER
description: The Justice Department announced yesterday that it did not intend to contest a proposed $2 billion acquisition of Utah International Inc. by the General Electric Company. The merger would be the largest ever in the nation's history.

title: On Carter's Amnesty and Pardon Views
description: HILLSBOROUGH, N. C.  For a Southerner and a Democrat, Jimmy Carter has a curious position on pardon and amnesty. He says there's a difference, and he's right about that anyway.

title: No Peace For Old Pharaoh
description: The mummy of Ramses II was flown from Egypt to Paris this week to undergo medical treatment for a fungus infection. An honor guard of the French Air Force and the Garde Republicaine presented arms as the crated pharaoh was transferred from the airplane to a truck. He is 3,000 years older than the United States and may have known Moses.

title: BUCKLEY IS FOCUSING ON ELDERLY VOTERS
description: Senator James L. Buckley is making a major effort to win the votes of older men and women in his campaign for reelection to the United States Senate.

title: Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod Is Torn by New Resignations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI)A fourth district president resigned from the strifetorn Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod today and mass resignations of officials were announced in another district.

description: United States Customs Service officers demanded yesterday that the Japanese film In the Realm of the Senses, which was scheduled to be shown tonight at the NOW York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, he removed from the program and turned over to its New York division of import compliance as allegedly obscene.

title: RANGASWAMY SATAKOPAN
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 1 (AP)Rangaswamy Satakopan, a newsman and photographer for The Associated Press in India for three decades, died today of a heart attack. His age was 66. Mr. Satakopan, who joined the news agency in 1945, covered many major stories on the Indian subcontinent until his retirement last year.

description: The Bank of America, the nation's largest banking institution, and four other California banks said yesterday they would cut their prime rate to 6 percent from 7 percent on Monday. The National Bank of Detroit also will make the change Monday.

He had already sat on and approved of the new modular seating designed by Ray Wilkes, which the concern is introducing.

description: Dr. Theodore G. Holzsager, a pediatrician and neurologist, died Thursday at Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 73 years old and lived in Great Neck. L.I.

description: An unemployed Bronx man charged with the attempted murder of a police officer critically wounded in a shotgun attack Thursday was released on $5.000 bail yesterday by a Criminal Court judge.

title: Notes on People
description: Jane Pauley, a 25yearold newscaster in Chicago who has been with the NBC station there for only a year, will join the regular cast of the network's Today program, probably as soon as Oct. 11. Officials of NBC News emphasized that she would not be joining as Barbara Walters's successor, although they conceded that Miss Pauley would probably be perceived in that role by the press and the public. They stressed that Tom Brokaw was now the star and host of Today and that he, more accurately, was the replacement for Miss Walters, who resigned from the program last spring to accept an offer of Si million a year from ABC News. Unlike Miss Walters, who was a cohost, Miss Pauley will have no title other than member of the cast.

He was 71 years old.

title: Chemical Industry Aide Denies Plants Are Major Cancer Cause
description: TRENTON, Oct. 1A Senate commission studying the high incidence of cancer in New Jersey was told today that chemical manufacturing was not the major cause of cancer in the state, and that it was time to end scare tactics that charged that living here could be unhealthy.

title: World Anglers Oust South Africa
description: VIENNA, Oct. 1 (Reuters)South Africa was expelled today from the International Angling Confederation because of its racial policies, the Bulgarian press agency reported. The agency said the decision had been made at the end of a twoday congress of the confederation at the Bulgarian Black Sea resort of Varna. The meeting was attended by angling organizations from 20 countries.

title: An Alas for the Career of Diplomacy
description: ANNANDALE, Va.Somewhere our nation lost a serious, sophisticated approach to diplomacy. This occurred, perhaps, about the time of the 1828 Presidential election, when the last of our great diplomats in the White House lost to a Tennessee frontiersman, horse racer, gambler and Indian fighter who derided diplomacy as mere gabble and glorified military action.
