description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP)Kentucky State University will make a final determination by next Tuesday on the eligibility of six football players dismissed from the team, the chairman of the university's athletic committee said today. The players will not be allowed to play against CarsonNewman. Dr. Rufus Barfield said Dr. William Butt, the president of the school, called a special meeting this morning and asked the athletic committee to determine what rule it is using to determine eligibility and who is responsible for determining eligibility.

The vote on Sunday is expected to be a tense and close finish between the Social Democratic Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, and his Christian Democratic challenger, Helmut Kohl.

Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party leader, conferred today with Raul Castro, Cuban First Deputy Prime Minister andDefense Minister, Tass, the official press agency, reported. Mr. Castro, brother of Prime Minister Fidel Castro, is a frequent visitor to Moscow.

title: Kuhn Fines Cardinals for Tampering With A's
description: Bowie Kuhn, baseball commissioner, has fined the St. Louis Cardinals for tampering with Oakland A's players, it was announced yesterday. A statement from the commissioner's office said the Cardinals had been found guilty of violating baseball's antitampering rule, Rule 3G. The amount of the fine was not disclosed officially, but United Press International reported that it was $5,000.

title: LEROY C. KELLY
description: Leroy C. Kelly, a retired vice president and copy director of Muir & Company, a financial advertising agency, died last night at his home in Bayville, L.I. at the age of 70. A founder of Muir in 1935, Mr. Kelly is survived by a daughter, Mrs. Joan Bruce, and five grandchildren.

title: Tanner's 'Jonah' a Cerebral Film
description: All but two of the characters in Alain Tanner's witty, cerebrally playful new Swiss film, "Jonah Who Will Be 25 in the Year 2000," are French-speaking Swiss. The other two are French citizens who live just over the border in France. Yet each of the characters is, in his or her own way, as surrounded as Switzerland, hemmed in, denied access to something essential.Max (Jean-Luc Bideau), a former political activist, no longer writes for his newspaper. Since 1968 he has worked as a proofreader. Marco (Jacques Denis) is a teacher of history, but his methods are so bizarre that he keeps getting bounced from one school after another. Marie (Miou-Miou) is a cashier in a Geneva supermarket who, being French, is not allowed to sleep in Switzerland. Mathieu (Rufus), fired from his job as a printer because of his union activities, returns to the land as a farm helper."Jonah Who Will Be 25 in the Year 2000" is less the story of nine friends and acquaintances than a highly comic, politicized accounting of their states of mind and their talk. They are surrounded and hemmed in, all right, but they have not been anesthetized by mediocrity into dreamless boredom. They rant and they carry on, like Charles (Raymond Bussires), the retired railroad engineer for whom Marie steals provisions from the supermarket.At one point, Charles recalls the difference between riding on a train and sitting in the engineer's cab. "When you are a passenger," he says, "the landscape slides past you. When you are the engineer, you are always entering it, approaching that point where the rails meet, but they always open up for you.""Jonah" is Mr. Tanner's fifth film to be released in this country, and like his two best films ("La Salamandre" and "The Middle of the World"), it has a screenplay written by him in collaboration with John Berger, the English novelist and critic. They make one of the most interesting film-making teams in Europe today.Their line is Marxist, but their method is exuberantly humane, always aware of the comic aspects to the accommodations being made by characters who, in Mr. Tanner's words, are "metaphors on two legs." That, I think, undercuts the compassion of the film.The characters may be metaphors, but they are also recognizable individuals, whether determinedly, hilariously steeped in Hindu mysticism, like the beautiful Madeleine (Myriam Mezire), who believes the mind can be fertilized by particular sex practices; or, like the lantern-jaw Mathieu, who is dedicated to shaping a better future for his new son, Jonah.Mr. Tanner's characters talk incessantly, sometimes, as in the case of Marco, they lecture, playing with theories of history, time, revolution, education and capitalism with such enthusiasm that the spirit of the talk has the effect of giving comic perspective to metaphors not of the first freshness ("the highway of capitalism is collapsing").The stories of the individual characters, which connect casually, gracefully, are punctuated by fantasies that, in contrast to the rest of the color film, are photographed in black and white. They are short, mischievous, sometimes sad, occasionally erotic, always informed, as in the entire film, by Mr. Tanner's awareness that these people, whether two-legged metaphors or not, inhabit a specific society in a particular time.The performances are so thoroughly integrated with the material that I'm not sure where performances begin and the work of the director and the writers leaves off. The entire cast is splendid."Jonah," which will be shown at the 14th New York Film Festival today at 6 P.M. and tomorrow at 9 P.M., will open here at the Fine Arts Theater within the next several weeks. It's a window on a European political-intellectual world seldom seen in filmsand never seen with such an appreciation of cinematic style.

description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Oct. 1 (UPI)An outbreak of the fishkilling microorganism commonly known as the red tide has been located in the Gulf of Mexico along a 25mile stretch from Venice to Sarasota, marine biologists reported today. A spokesman at the Marine Research Lab said small isolated fish kills had been reported, but none within five miles of shore.

title: Ballesteros Leads Belgian Golf
description: WATERLOO, Belgium, Oct. 1 (AP)Severiano Ballesteros of Spain carded a sixunderpar 67 today to take the lead after the first day of an international challenge golf tournament at the Waterloo Golf Club. Lee Elder and Curtis Strange of the United States were next. Elder at 69 and Strange at 71. Brian Huggett of Wales had a 73, while Tommy Aaron of the United States and Jean Garaialde of France were at 74.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The South Korean Central Intelligence Agency, President Park Chung Hee's strongest instrument for political action, has steadily extended its reach into the United States over the last five years just as it has expanded its power at home.

title: Element 107
description: Generations of high school and college students learned in their elementary chemistry lessons that there were 92 elements in the universe, from hydrogen (the lightest) to uranium (the heaviest). Persons so instructed in their youth may well be startled to learn that Soviet scientists announced the other day that they have synthesized element 107. Put another way, scientists have now produced 15 socalled transuranic elements, basic types of atoms which do not normally exist in nature but can be manufactured in laboratories.

title: California Grants Terminally Ill Right to Put an End to Treatment
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1California has become the first state in the nation to grant terminally ill persons the right to authorize the withdrawal of lifesustaining procedures when death is believed imminent.

title: A Plant Expert Selects His Favorites For Garden Display A Plant Expert's Favorites
description: WHEN I was asked to name my favorite woody plants that I was assured of having for my garden, I found this a difficult question. There are literally thousands to choose from, when considering all the possibilitiesevergreens, deciduous, flowering and fruiting species, those with good autumn color for specimen planting and the many fine dwarfs.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE backyard (the garden, if you're a highclass type) has just about had it for this year by now, but it really has paid its way. It's been the extra room for afternoon company, the playpen for the kids, the kitchen for steak dinners and the dining room. One friend of mine recently turned his into a wedding hall.

title: Home Clinic
Legislator Urges Rollback of AutoInsurance Rates
The Hite Report
description: One of the fascinating things about the seemingly copious literature of sex is its glaring omissions: although there are any number of books about female sexuality by men, there are virtually no books about male sexuality by women and relatively few books about male sexuality by men themselves. This would seem to indicate that women's sexuality is regarded as a problem whereas men's is not regarded at all (perhaps because it is seen as the norm). No woman I have ever met (or read about) would dare presume to tell a man what he feels during the sex act, how his orgasm is best obtained, whether he is feeling what he should be feelingyet men have been telling women all those things about their sexuality for centuries. As one character in Doris Lessing's The Golden Notebook remarks: Women of any sense know better, after all these centuries, than to interrupt when men start telling them how they feel about sex.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Numisma tically speaking. the Bicentennial celebration is winding down. The Government has just announced the impending completion of the last of its various series of official Bicentennial medals, The honor of being last but not least falls to the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration. It has opened the mailordering period for the fifth and final annual offering in its national commemorative medal series (authorized by Congress and launched in 1972). The ordering period began Oct. 1 and will end Oct. 31.

title: Margaret Mitchell's Gone With The Wind Letters 19361949
description: In one of Margaret Mitchell's early letters reproduced in this collection, she wrote: I cannot figure what makes the thing sell so enormously. This was a comment Miss Mitchell was to repeat many times and might still be repeating if she were alive. According to the editor of the present volume, total sales of the thing, that is, Gone With the Wind, have now run to over 20 million copies, and the book has been printed in 27 languages. The 40th anniversary this year of the original publication has sparked a new flareup of interest. Several books about Miss Mitchell, her book or the movie thereof have been or are about to be published, and there will be an official anniversary edition with an introduction by James Michener. Probably most important in stimulating interest, the movie will be shown for the first time on home television.

title: Greetings
description: FALKMr. and Mrs. Charles Falk of New York City, formerly of Lawrence, LI., and their family, Mr. and Mrs. Michael A Falk, Mr. and Mrs. Ronaid Green and Mr. and Mrs. Leonard N. Stern, wish their relatives and friends a Healthy And Peaceful New Year.

title: The Widow's Children
description: For most novelists, there is a special constellation of fiction elements that works best Alas, novelists are not born knowing what that constellation is. and the body of work of individual writers is often a series of trialanderror efforts, interesting because of the gifts that are seeking, like water, their true level. In Paula Fox's new novel, The Widow's Children, her special brand of unemphatic, perceptively detailed writing, along with her penchant for lifebenumbed, willless characters, struggles to make its mark.

The film's director, the radical Japanese film maker Nagi.sa Oshima, was cheerful, however. Its a shocking film, so I !mew there would be some reaction, he said, speaking through an interpreter.

description: TRENTON ECAUSE the average cost of a semiprivate room and other services in New Jersey hospitals has risen to $145 or so a day, a fierce debate is under way in the state over what, if anything, can be done to lower these costs or at least to stop the annual increases of 15 to 20 percent. One suggestion has been to let the state's Departnient of Health set all hospital rates in New Jersey, and by this require the hospitals to perform in an efficient manner.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2For President Kim II Sung of North Korea, the belligerence of summer has given way to the Quiet of autumn.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 3The spacious doors to this city's new Children's Museum were formally opened yesterday, offering youngsters of all ages a chance to see, touch and learn from exhibitions that fill the museum's five sprawing floors of galleries.

description: The Board of Higher Education, in a test of how independent it can be of Governor Carey, has put off the selection of a vice chairman he reportedly wanted.

These original ancesters of our modern garden tulips, although native to faroff places like Iran and mountainous areas along the Mediterranean, are fully hardy in New Jersey.

title: Point of View
description: Looking back on almost three years as Administrator (Temporary) of the Housing and Development Administration, I have the very strong impression that although my phrase Planned Shrinkage will run a poor second to Benign Neglect in the Unappreciated Phrases Derby, it will remain the most prominent label in the file of my government service.

title: For Portugal's Recovery
description: Prime Minister Mario Soares has finally launched a series of programs essential for an economic turnaround in Portugal but politically difficult for a Socialistand minorityGovernment to undertake. The measures are designed to break up Communist domination of the single national trade union federation, to restore worker discipline to the shops and factories, and to return illegally occupied farms to their owners.

description: The Beame administraton is negotiating with the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority to finance construction of a propsed convention center, an admiistration spokesman said yesterday.

title: Californians Disinterest Seems to Aid Ford
description: CONCORD, Calif., Oct. 2Rainsodden, still wrapped in rubber bands, a week's worth of daily newspapers lie untouched on the lawn at the Horn home here on Bonafacio Drive. It's not that the Horns are away, they're just too busy caring for six cats, two dogs and three quail, and living the good California life, to worry much about things like the Presidential race.

title: Education
description: In elementary school Dana Felt was always the best math student in her class. When she got to junior high school, though, her grades dropped sharply.

title: Of Things To Come
description: Although science fiction would seem to offer writers an unusual degree of freedomthe freedom to create entire worlds from scratch, to invent new technologies, to rearrange the anatomy of their characters  few s.f. writers venture outside the rather tightly defined conventions of the genre. At the core of these convention's is a commitment to rationality  or, to be more precise, reasonableness. Virtually anything can happen in an s.f. story as long as it does not seem totally arbitrary. The author does not have to explain everything; he need only hint that a reasonable explanation exists if the ,reader wants to take the time to search for it. In most cases, it is taken for granted that the search will follow the rules of evidence laid down by modern science. These rules are by no means as rigid as many laymen believe; after all, a scientific inquiry may lead to a consideration of black holes and the Principle of Uncertainty as well as Pavlovian conditioning and the periodic table.

title: Gunnar Myrdal: Fiery Defender Of the Swedes
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 26Gunnar Myrdal says that the recent Swedish elections are irrelevant. He insists that the Swedes are buoyant and happy people, that the welfare state has produced genuine contentment and that the nation's critics are often fools.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Amanda Cross writes mystery stories featuring a college professor (of English) named Kate Fansler. The dialogue in her books is supercivilized, in the drawing  room tradition, with long, resounding periods. In THE QUESTION OF MAX (Knopf, $6.95) we have a character who says things like: Most people, dear Kate, err by trying to be thought generous, an illconsidered aim. Once you are thought selfish, not only are you forgiven a life designed mainly to suit yourself, which in anyone else would appear monstrous, but if an impulse to generosity should by chance overpower you, you will get five times the credit of some poor selfless soul who has been oozing kindness for years. Human beings must be carefully trained in what they can expect from you.

title: Even Peter Frampton Can't Explain His Sudden Ascension
POLITICS
description: MOST Long Islanders have experienced the hazards pf election time: A lawabiding citizen comes out of a bakery on Sunday morning with the newspapers and some buns in his arms and, finds in his path an eager candidate trying to find a free hand to shake and stuff with campaign literature at the same time. The same kind of thing happens to the barely awake commuter at the Long Island Rail Road station many mornings in September and October.

title: Ancient Greek Fortifications Reported Excavated in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (AP)Fortifications believed built by Alexander the Great have been excavated at Samarkand in Soviet Central Asia, the official Soviet press aecncy Tass reported this week.

description: CAIRO, Oct. 2 (Reuters)Both Foreign Minister Ismail Falmy of Egypt and Kemal Juniblat, the leftist Lebanese leader, today called on France to help solve the Lebanese crisis.

Dolph Briscoe Jr. of Texas, the millionaire rancher from Uvalde, and Mrs. Briscoe of Austin. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles James Amis of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington. Her father is vice president of Allstate Insurance Companies for the metropolitan area.

description: When Forego won the Woodward Handicap two weeks ago under 135 pounds, even his staunchest fans wondered what the twotime Horse of the Year could do for an encore.

title: The Nation In Summary
description: In some respects, the 94th Congress has behaved as any election year Congress, with major business jammed into its final days to meet an adjournment schedule in order to campaign. But in some respects, this Congress was not typical. It sat in a period of severe economic dislocation, and was controlled by Democrats who are in the best position to recapture the White House that they have been in years.

title: The Man Who Knows All About Oil
description: In early 1974, a few months after the Arab oil embargo turned energy crisis into a household phrase, John Lichtblau, head of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, received a phone call from an Ivy League professor.

title: Ann Thompson Is Married to Samuel D. Ford
description: Ann Southam Thompson, daughter of Bethuel Phelps Thompson of Brightwaters, L.I., and the late Mrs. Thompson, was married in Great River, L.I., yesterday to Samuel Dennis Ford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Ford of Concord, Va. The Rev. Russell A. Bechtel performed the ceremony in Emmanuel Episcopal Church, scene of the marriage of the bride's narents in 1938.

title: Bank Women Step Out Front
description: The National Association of Bank Women, a group established to promote the interests of women in banking, has thrown open its membership roster to men. At their annual convention in New York last week, the bank women voted to admit men as affiliate members for the first time.

title: ARCHITECTURAL VIEW
description: After a 13year saga of abandonment and rescue, the CooperHewitt Museum of Design is reopening this week in the remodeled Carnegie Mansion at Fifth Avenue and 91st Street, its gardens abloom with chrysanthemums, its collections secure, its future a bright promise. The lengthy process has led from Cooper Union's decision in 1963 to dispose of one of the world's finest collections of decorative arts and design because it could no longer afford to maintain it, through the threat of public sale and absorption by other museums, to the creation of a totally new institution. It has required over $6 million in privately raised funds, the adoption of the collection by the Smithsonian Institution in 1967 as part of the national collections, the gift of the landmark Carnegie House in 1972 and the talent and ingenuity of the renovating architects, Hardy Holzman, Pfeiffer, the indomitable drive of the museum's steel and porcelain director, Lisa Taylor, and the sweat and tears of its dedicated staff.

BRIDGE
description: Declarers at the bridge table, like politicians in election battles, can often emerge victorious by encouraging the opposition to make an error. And there are some situations in which it takes a clever opponent to make the fatal error. In the diagramed deal from a New Jersey tournament South had a chance of making his slam only because West had a very clever thought.

title: What Really Happened To the Class of 65?
description: In January of 1965, Time magazine ran a cover story on Today's Teenagers and focused its attention on the senior class of Palisades High School, which is set on a bluff overlooking the Pacific in an affluent section of West Los Angeles. As these two young authors, both members of that class, recall:

title: Slapstick
description: Kurt Vonnegut is one of the most popular novelists in America, and his popularity seems to be increasing. His latest, Slapstick, or Lonesome No More! has a first printing of 150,000 copies for the hardcover edition and that may be close to a record. Unlike most extremely popular novelists, furthermore, Vonnegut attracts a following that includes serious people who take fiction seriously. Yet there has always been resistance to his popularity and, since one Vonnegut novel is very much like another, the resistance also is likely to increase. As one who resists, I must try to say why I find Slapstick flashy, clever and empty; I must also try to explain the popularity.

title: LessDeveloped Nations, Meeting in Manila, Drop Request for Special Relief on Their Huge Debts
description: MANILA. Oct. 2Finance Ministers representing nearly 100 lessdeveloped countries dropped all mention today of a moratorium on their huge debts and agreed that the industrial countries should give priority M their policies to fighting inflation rather than a quick return to full employment.

title: The Blacklist and The Cold War
description: Who would ever have dreamed, a generation ago, that the blacklist and the Hollywood Ten, the sordid proceedings of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee and the political vagaries of Joe McCarthy, would one day reemerge as a form of cultural chic? But this unlikely vicissitude, which would have strained the credulity of any intelligent observer of the Truman and Eisenhower era, is now decisively upon us.

title: Controversial Jewish Settlement at Hebron Illustrates the Challenges Israel Faces in Occupied Arab Lands
description: KIRYAT ARBA, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Sept. 30This rawlooking settlement of 1,500 Jews has become a microcosm of the problems facing Israel because of the territories it captured here on the West Bank of the Jordan during the 1967 war.

title: Poll Calls Race Tied
description: President Ford and Jimmy Carter are tied in their race for the Presidency, according to a survey completed late last week by the research firm of Yankelovich, Skelley & White for Time magazine. The survey indicates that each candidate has the support of 43 percent of the electorate, with 14 percent undecided.

description: PARIS, Oct. 2 Defense spending is starting to get some of the hard scrutiny in France that it has long had in the United States.

title: 2 Campaign Aides of Buckley Also on His Senate Payroll
MUSIC VIEW
description: When the New York Philharmonic released its 197677 programs last season, there was surprisingly little of Mahler's music listed. That was a shocker, for Mahler has become as one with Brahms and Beethoven, and much more than the once phenomenally popular Tchaikovsky. Could it be that the Mahler craze was beginning to recede? The explanation came a little later, with the announcement of the Mahler Month, in which the Philharmonic would be giving nine concerts of nothing but Mahler. So we currently are in the midst of that Mahler Month (it continues until Oct. 25, when Pierre Boulez brings things to a conclusion with the Third Symphony).

She lived in San Marcos, Tex., having moved there from Edison, N. J., when she retired in 1963.

description: The economy of West Germany is one of the strongest in the world; the country is politically and socially stable; its international diplomatic stature is assured. So West Germans. voting in a national election today, have the luxury of not worrying very much about who wins. Little is expected to change whether they reelect the ruling coalition of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt or replace it with the more conservative coalition headed by Helmut Kohl.

These men have conducted the affairs of a great nation with methods and in a spirit not consonant with the character and institutions of the American people.

description: Candidates: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, 57 years old, is asking 41.6 million West German voters to elect his coalition government to another fouryear term. His opponent is Helmut Kohl, 48, governor of the state of RhinelandPalatinate. Voters will elect 496 members of the four major political parties to the Bundestag, or Parliament. The parties with a majority will then formally elect their candidateMr. Kohl or Mr. Schmidtwhen Parliament convenes Dec.14.

title: Hackett Starts First Leg Of Long Haul to Moscow
Personality Often Could Be Equated With Power
description: WASHINGTONMore than any other institution of Government, Congress, and what happens in it. is shaped by the interplay of personalities. After the official record of hills and resolutions and debates and votes has been entered in the appropriate annals, among the enduring impressions of the 94th Congress, which finished its work last week, will be those of individuals, ones who arrived and ones who departed, ones who succeeded and ones who failed.

title: Michigan Is 310 Victor Over Wake Forest Team
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 2 (AP)Rob Lytle, a fullback, scored two touchdowns today and passed Tom Harmon on the Michigan career rushing list as the Wolverines trounced Wake Forest, 310.

title: Jobs: The Recession Still Has Not Ended
description: The report last week that New York City is continuing to lose jobs at an alarming rate is a reminder that despite the nation's economic recovery, the city and most of the metropolitan area remain depressed. The fact is this region never recovered from the recession of 1969; it fell when the rest of the country picked up in the 1970's, fell still more with the recession of 197475 and is still dropping. There has been a steady job decline for the better part of a decade.

title: University Plans Office Building
description: SADDLE BROOK, N. J., Oct. 2 (AP)Fairleigh Dickinson University plans to build a $5 million office building in Hackensack, which it hopes will earn $1.25 million a year in rents. At a meeting of the Northern New Jersey Advertising Club here yesterday, Samuel J. Silberman, a University trustee, said that the Prudential Insurance Company would finance the sixstory building.

title: Seeds Of Man
description: Woody Guthrie said somewhereor should have said, for I am much enchanted and influenced by the man, and am probably putting words in his magnificent dustbowlfilled mouththat the true sound of the American people is the sound of a guitar and a harmonica, played beside a railroad track at night. A fast freight goes by, and while them cars are rushin along, you can't hear the music. But when that train's gone, and you can just barely hear that lonesome whistle, you hear the music again. It ain't never stopped. It ain't never stop.,

title: Hunt, Miffed at Reversal, Assails the Grand Prix
description: The world driving championship has been devalued this season and turned into a farce, according to James Hunt, the Englishman, who likely will finish second to Niki Lauda of Austria in the Formula One point standing. Ferrariwanted the championship for Lauda and they went to great lengths to make sure that he won it, added Hunt. I think they have spoiled it for everyoneNiki, me, the two North American races, the fans, everyone. Hunt and Lauda and the rest of the Formula One circus are at Mosport for the Canadian Grand Prix today. Next Sunday, the entire entourage will be at Watkins Glen for the 18th annual United States Grand Prix.

title: If You Go ...
description: . . . to Olana, the quickest and easiest way to get there from New York City is to take the New York State Thruway to the Catskill Exit, No. 21. Follow the signs to the Rip Van Winkle Bridge. Across the bridge turn right, or south, on New York State Route 9G. The entrance to Olana is about one mile on the left. The drive takes from 2 to 2 hours, depending on traffic.

title: Marjorie Schulman And Bruce R. Kraus Planning Marriage
description: The engagement of Marjorie Schulman, a student at the New York University School of Medicine, to Bruce Robert Kraus, who is attending the Yale Law School. has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Schulman of Great Neck, L. I. Mr. Kraus is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kraus of Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Phillies Defeat Mets, 74, Gaining 100th Victory
DeRogatis Kicks the Pro Football Habit
description: Curt Gowdy will be the playbyplay announcer at the OaklandNew England game today in Foxboro. Mass., with John Brodie doing the color rather than Gowdy's former partner, Al DeRogatis. What happened to DeRogatis, one of the more pithy commentators about football and a great player in his brief New York Giants? Nothing happened. He quit with a year to go on his National Broadcasting Company contract, and for the first time in 35 years DeRogatis does not have viceral link with football. How is it to have kicked the habit?

title: A.C.L.U. CERTIFIES DISPUTED ELECTION
description: The national board of the American Civil Liberties Union voted yesterday to certify the election of nine new members of the hoard, despite reported irregularities in the way the election was conducted.

title: The Hamilton, A Sidewheeler Is Set for Sale
description: The Alexander Hamilton, the last sidewheel excursion steamer afloat east of the Mississippi, appears destined for her final voyage.

title: Dial R for Reform
Is Harvey Korman Ripe To Be a Top Banana?
description: For almost 15 years, Harvey Korman has made a career of being the most successful second banana in show business. While the stars held forth at stage center, Korman got his laughs by standing just a bit to one side. His characterizations of the ham actor sculpted from the purest pork and the manic hardware dealer with a cackle that shatters glass were some of the brightest spots on The Carol Burnett Show for a full decade. But he was not the power, the muscle that makes .a comedy show work. Now Korman is finally going to try climbing to the top of the bunch. Next season, after years of having traded pig bladders with the likes of Danny Kaye and Lucille Ball, Korman will star in his own comedy series on ABC.

title: Despite Successes, Rhodesian Army Is Displaying Strains
description: SALISBURY, RhodesiaThe only thing that Is obvious about the quickly changing Rhodesian situation is that the only alternative to some form of negotiated settlement is a continuing and intensifying war.

title: Ideas &
description: Echoes of the literary and political quarrels of the socalled McCarthy era are reverberating again through the publishing world. Little Brown & Company last week canceled its plans to publish a new book by critic Diana Trilling because the book contained remarks critical of another Little Brown author, playwright Lillian Hellman.

title: MORE APPLICATIONS FILED FOR POWER FROM STATE
What Tax Reform Means to Executives
description: Scattered through the labyrinthine Tax Reform Act of 1976 are important provisions affecting executives and how they are compensated. One of these items may actually put more dollars in some of their pockets, while two others could actually disgorge dollars from their pockets.

title: CAMERA VIEW
Starr Badger Wed to R. W. Shippee
description: Mariette Starr Badger and Robert Wright Shippee were married yesterday by the Rev. Bradford Hastings in Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. A reception was given at the Field Club in Greenwich.

title: PANEL ASSERTS FORD MISHANDLED CITY AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2A Congressional report released today asserted that the Ford Administration mishandled the New York City fiscal crisis last year, producing needless uncertainty and inadvertently contributing to increased costs of municipal borrowing around the nation by up to $1.4 billion.

title: Deere Talks Break Off
description: MOLINE, Ill., Oct 2 (UPI)  Talks between the United Auto Workers and Deere and Co. broke off abruptly today and no new bargaining sessions were scheduled in the strike of 27,000 workers against Deere's farmimplement plants and depots in six states.

title: Book Ends
description: Publishing West. Following literally in the projected footsteps of Harper & Row, which recently announced that its religious books department would move to San Francisco next January, we headed out to California to see if the grass was any greener. We found the state in the throes of a severe drought, so the usually golden hills of the Bay Area were a sere brown. Nonetheless, the Harper & Row move, which will involve general trade publishing as well as religious books, reaffirms the continuing, if fluctuating interest of New York publishers in the state. That interest peaked in the late 60's and early 70's during the fat period in Federal educational funds and the heyday of the counterculture, when such best sellers as The Whole Earth Cataloguewere discovered in California.

title: DANCE VIEW
Connecticut to Set Up More Radar Patrols
description: HARTFORD (UPI)Drivers on Connecticut highways will be clocked by more radar patrols in a major crackdown on speeders and reckless drivers, State Police Commissioner Edward P. Leonard said.

title: Class of 80 Steps Into 21st Century
description: IT startles men to think of it, but when the doors of Rutgers University opened to the members of the Class of 1980, the 21st century entered with them. When the century turns, these young men and women will be turning 40, and they will be taking up leadership in our state and nation. For their sake and for ours, it is an especially appropriate time to assess where the State University has been, where it is now and where it should be going.

title: Biting the Handgun Bullet
description: THE 21 County Prosecutors and the Attorney General have initiated an organized and rational effort to deal with the problem of violent crime. Their plan gives priority to the treatment of such crime and precribes a program to deal with the violent offender from arrest to sentence within 120 days.

title: The Almost Free Agents
description: Baltimore OriolesWayne Garland, pitcher; Bobby Grich, infielder; Reggie Jackson, outfielder; Royle Stillman, outfielder (contract in dispute).

title: Notes: NBC's $6Million Layaway Plan
Opposition to Marcos in Philippines Small but Active
description: MANILA, Oct. 2Four years after Ferdinand E. Marcos imposed martial law in the Phillippines and two weeks before the referendum that is expected overwhelmingly to reaffirm the mandate he seized, the small but active political opposition here is continuing its efforts to reveal the other side of martial law, and the truth about this election.

title: MANDEL TRIAL TOLD OF FRIENDS FAVORS
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 2The prosecution has described in the first two weeks of Gov. Marvin Mandel's corruption trial the secret benefits that he allegedly received from friends.

title: A World Of Light
Bridal for Catherine Moss
description: Catherine Casale Moss and James Donald Warner, 1974 graduates in landscape architecture of the University of Arizona, were married yesterday afternoon in Garrison, N. Y. The Rev. Blase Burniston, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in St. John's Chapel on the grounds of Graymoor, home of the Society of the Atonement. He was assisted by the Rev. William S. Reisman, rector of St. Philip's Episcopal Church, Garrison.

title: Stephanie J. Beard Bride of C.R. O'Neill
description: The marriage of Stephanie Jocelyn Beard to Christopher R. O'Neill took place yesterday afternoon in Potomac, Md. The bride is the daughter of Edward A. Beard, associate justice of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, and Mrs. Beard of Washington. Her husband is a son of Representative Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr., the House majority leader, and Mrs. O'Neill of Cambridge. Mass.

title: Design
Dorothy Noyes Becomes Bride
description: Mildred Dorothy Noyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jansen Noyes Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Jos Vidal Rodriguez, son of Sara Rodriguez of San Juan, Puerto Rico, and the late Jos Rodriguez.

title: The Art of Sneaking By Ushers
STAMPS
Hopes Ride High for the AmericanFlag Fleet
Population Drop Worries Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia. Oct. 2 (Reuters)White Australians, whose European ancestors sailed around the world 188 years ago to build a primitive convict settlement into a new nation, are being told they may be a dying race.

title: Battle Goes On To Free World From Smallpox
description: COMILLA. Bangladesh, Sept. 27P. T. Hargrove, a 33yearold public health worker from Grand Rapids, Mich., walked up to a group of barechested fishermen near here today holding a photograph of a baby covered with the hideous sores of smallpox.

title: Kurile Island Volcano Erupts
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (Reuters)The Sarychev volcano on Matua Island in the Soviet Union's Kurile chain has begun erupting after lying dormant for 16 years, Tass, the press agency, reported today. It said two streams of lava were flowing from the 4,744foothigh volcano toward the Sea of Okhotsk on the western side of the island.

title: Heartland
description: Some book nut in a dusty BuyOldVolumesbythePound warehouse on some obscure Fourth Avenue of the future, in say 40 years or so, will come across a battered copy of Heartland and, leafing through a few pages, will wonder just who the hell this Mort Sahl was.

title: Parks Cope With the Budget Blight
POINTS OF VIEW
Quotations of the Day
description: There is just no way we're going to budge.Douglas B. Weaving, pressdent of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, commenting on the current dispute with the city. [1:3.]

title: Hellas in the Hamptons
The Political AlsoRunnings
Wood, Field and Stream: Atlantic Salmon's Fate Depends on Pure Environment
description: Not long ago, I tried to tell a group of listeners, none of them conservationists or anglers, of the magnificent Atlantic salmon and why its survival is important to man.

title: Nini Giffuni Bride Of Bart Tiernan 3d, New York Lawyer
The Beaver
description: Ask any oldtimer who lives near North Carolina's Little Fiery Gizzard Creek, and he'll tell you that Glen Rounds has, been watching beavers there for a long time. Long before he wrote Beaver Business and Wild Orphan in the early 60's, Rounds had begun to spend entire days and nights drifting about the dammedup pond in a kayak, or sitting on the creek's bank, to learn what he could about beavers.

title: The Philippines At a Glance
description: Major exports include sugar, coconut oil, copper concentrates and timber products, although in recent years the country has made attempts to diversify into cement, clothing and textiles. Nearly half the labor force is in agriculture, a total that has dropped less than 7 percent in the last 15 years.

title: EAST GERMANS BUILD NEW BORDER BARRIER
description: FULDA, West Germany, Sept. 29East Germany has completed about twothirds of an elaborate new barrier system that will run along the West German frontier from the Baltic Sea in the north to Czechoslovakia in the south.

title: Reagan Joins Dole in New Haven and Praises the Republican Platform
Notes: Flying. Away For a Dollar a Day
Nightmares
description: I remember the last time I took a group of children on a picnic: Queen Anne's lace underfoot, goldfinches overhead, the sun over all, and the kids spent the afternoon hunting for monsters. In those Elysian fields none appeared, but on the way home we amused ourselves telling monster stories. Mine were not well received.

title: CONNECTICUT LOSES SUIT OVER MINORS ABORTIONS
In Bergen, Arts For the Young
description: PROJECT IMPACT, begun with Federal funds nine years ago to help support special arts and cultural programs in Bergen County schools, has become an independent foundation, the first of its kind in the nation.

title: Submarine Stirs Still Waters
The Bowling Clinic
description: With the pocket area 60 feet away, it's rather obvious that what you do on the approach is critical. There is a sizable area behind the foul line in which you set up your shot, and there are thousands of variables considering the width and length of the approach.

title: Women in Sports
description: Carole Smitten, a graduate of Hofstra University, is involved in a program run through the Alumni Association of her alma mater that is designed to attract women back to Hofstra.

title: NATURAL GAS SHORTAGE FEARED BY ENERGY CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI)The Federal Energy Administrator, Frank G. Zarb, said today that there could be serious shortages of natural gas in some areas if the nation has a cold winter.

title: Unacceptable Choice
description: The recovery of the United States economy has definitely slowed down. After rising for 17 consecutive months, the Government's key index of leading indicators dropped 1.5 percent in August. New construction contracts fell 15 percent the same month and reached their lowest level since last December; only residential building rose.

title: New HighYield Variety of Wheat Going Into Production in New York
description: ITHACA, N. Y. (AP)A new highyielding wheat variety developed by Cornell University goes into production in New York State this season.

title: Miss Krugman, Local Lawyer, Wed in Jersey
description: The marriage of Candace Lynn Krugman to Frederick William Beinecke 2d took place yesterday at Pleasantdale Farm in West Orange, N.J., Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer of Paterson, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: YOM KIPPUR STARTS AT SUNDOWN TODAY
description: On the eve of Yom Kippur, the most sacred holiday on the Hebrew religious calendar, secular and spiritual leaders called for a new vigor in the defense of liberty and freedom throughout the world.

title: 10,000 Indians Have Yet to Claim Funds Granted for Sale of Land
description: ANCHORAGE, Sept. 25 (UPI)  Ten thousand Indians who have not claimed their share of a billion dollars granted by Congress are the largest group of missing heirs in the history of the United States.

title: Margaret M. Grieve Bride of Jeffrey L. Liddle
description: Margaret Mary Grieve, a secondyear student at the New York University Law School, was married yesterday in Toledo, Ohio, to Jeffrey L. Liddle, an associate in the New York.law firm of Baer & Marks.

title: In a FrontLine Village in Lebanon, Only the Baroody Family Stays On Under Shell Bursts and Gunfire
description: BMEKINE, Lebanon, Oct. 2If the remaining inhabitants of this small frontline village could vote at the United Nations, all 11 of them would give their vote to Jamil Baroody, the delegate of Saudi Arabia, no matter what he did or said.

title: Press, Politics, Power
Pamela Birkins Is Bride on L.I.
description: Pamela Birkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Edwin Birkins of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Phelps Hoyt Swift Jr., son of Mrs. Gordon R. Wright of Cincinnati and Mr. Swift of Pinedale, Wyo. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church. in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: ART
Preserving the Ethnic Focus
Bethunes Lead Matawan to 22d
description: The Bethune brothers, T.R. and Steve, scored two touchdowns each yesterday as Matawan, winner of the Central Jersey Group 4 playoff championship last season, powered to its 22d consecutive victory, 357, at the expense of Middletown South in Matawan.

title: Neither Socialists Nor. Tories Stay Pure
description: LONDONAt the end of George Bernard Shaw's play, Heartbreak House, the prophetic Captain Shotover is asked what will happen to this ship . . we call England? he answers: The captain is in his bunk, drinking bottled ditchwater; and the crew is gambling in the forecastle. She will strike and sink and split.

title: U.S. Outlays Rising On Allied Missile
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The United States Army, which started off trying to standardize weapons with its West European allies, now plans to spend more than $250 million on Americanizing an air defense missile already in production in West Germany and France.

title: Mysteries Cloud Bronfman Kidnapping Trial
Westchester Democrats, In Welcoming Mondale, Predict a Tough Battle
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y.. Oct. 2Westchester Democrats gave Senator Walter F. Mondale, their candidate for Vice President, a cordial welcome during a campaign visit to this county today, but their leaders are only mildly hopeful of carrying the county for him and Jimmy Carter in November.

title: Nassau's Labor Woes Heat Up
The Governor and
description: WHEN Governor Byrne reached into the Legislalature last month for a State Supreme Court justice, a Commissioner of Labor and Industry, a president of the state's Civil Service Department and a member of the Board of Public Utility Commissioners, he was following a timehonored habit in New Jersey politics.

title: Levittown Division Beats Memorial, 180
description: The residents of Levittown, L.I., have put their school district on an austerity program, and yesterday Levittown Division put its neighborhood rival, Levittown Memorial, on an austerity program all its own, 180, in the Conference 6 opener for both teams.

title: Music in Review
description: Iris Gillon chose wisely for her debut piano recital last Sunday evening in Carnegie Recital Hall. Too many artists pick demanding virtuoso programs for which they simply aren't yet fully equipped, and listeners have to sit there passively, as artistry is swamped by unmet technical demands.

title: For a Sensible Transit Plan
description: OVER the past decade there have been several debates around the feasibility of increasing the use of mass transit or public transportation in the Long Island region. The recent energy crisis gave further impetus and urgency to the debate but but resulted in a minimum of action.

title: After 25 Years, Thomson's Shot Is Still Painful
description: Twentyfive years ago today, Brooklyn wept.

title: So Far, Carter and Ford Have Pushed the Trust Issue
description: Television viewers may well think that the images they are viewing in this fall's Presidential campaign are blander than ever before. But the importance of television in the campaign, and of the imagemakers it has fostered, is at least as great as it has ever been and, arguably, even greater.

title: DANCE MAILBAG
description: City Center Defends Itself: We're Still Alive and Kicking

title: Working the 100Hour Week and Loving It
Author's Query
description: For a biography of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd (1888 1957), polar explorer, I would appreciate any material including letters, photographs, manuscripts and reminiscences.

title: Yacht Race To Greene
description: MONTAUK, L.I., Oct. 2Under steelblue skies veiled by a constant drizzle, the 10 multihulls soared and plunged across the dark, stormy seas of Block Island Sound today. The country's first professional yacht race had started.

title: Law and Disorder
Dominator's 60th Best Sets Record
Quiet Man of Darrtown
description: There is a new book called A Year At A Time, by Walter Alston with an assist from Jack Tobin. A copy arrived in the mail recently and was opened for the first time yesterday. That was a curious accident of timing, for on Page 168 Alston says: I've got the best job in the world. The curious accident is that Walter doesn't have that job anymore. After working out 23 oneye ar contracts as manager of the Dodgers, he resigned the other day. There comes a time, he said, when you get enough of everything.

title: Therese Forsyth Is Married to John Hare
description: In the chapel of the Salisbury (Conn.) School at noon yesterday. Therese Hewitt Forsyth was married to John Edmund Hare by the Rev. William Campbell, pastor of the North Baptist Church in Corning, N.Y.

title: FORD TERMED READY TO LET BUTZ RESIGN IF DISPUTE WIDENS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2President Ford is prepared to accept the resignation of Earl L. Butz from his Cabinet if, as appears likely, the public controversy widens over racist remarks made by the Secretary of Agriculture, wellplaced White House officials said today.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Subway Cars Vetoed For LongDistance Runs

title: Arson!
description: In 1967 John Barracato was a fireman assigned to a ladder company in remote and peaceable Staten Island, where clouds of smoke indicate more often than not only that a householder is burning damp charcoal in his backyard barbecue. Chafed by boredom and ambition, rare afflictions indeed among municipal employes, Barracato got himself appointed as a fire marshalthat is, a department detective dealing exclusively with the crime of arson. For someone craving action, the timing was perfect. The firesetting that destroyed countless thousands of buildings, and continues to this day, was beginning in Brownsville and the South Bronx.

title: Federoff Star As Carteret Routs Iselin
description: Tom Federoff threw three touchdown passes, kicked five extra points and ran to another touchdown as powerful Carteret rolled to a 4114 victory over Iselin yesterday in Iselin.

title: Growers and Farm Union Are Competing for Votes On California Labor Law
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2With an eye on Election Day four weeks away, the United Farm Workers union and California growers are again battling for dominance of the rich and fertile land of central and southern California.

title: Bobick Stops Wepner At 1:12 of Sixth Round
description: UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 2 (AP)Undefeated Duane Bobick scared a sixthround technical knockout over a bloodied Chuck Wepner in a nationally televised heavyweight fight today.

title: Joining to Seek Jobs for the Region
description: A TOP Nassau County official who has spent most of his time worrying about the economic health of his own bailiwick has begun devoting a substantial part of his energy to a broader but related concernhow the core of the New York metropolitan area can work toward greater prosperity.

title: Beame Is Outraged At Suspect's Release
description: Mayor Beame expressed outrage yesterday after learning that a Bronx man, 20yearold Carlos Ruiz, who is accused of shooting Police Officer Roger Smith with a shotgun Thursday, has been released on $5,000 bail by a Criminal Court judge.

title: News Service in Harlem Is Forced to Shut Down Because of Lack of Funds
The Region/Continued
Environmentalists Propose Switching Expenditures From Narrow Interests to Entire Natural Groupings
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2An epochal change in the nation's approach to wildlife conservation is being proposed by leading environmentalists, with significant support from the Federal Government.

title: Backus Excels for Uniondale
description: With Berner and Massapequa, two perennial powers, having their problems yesterday, Uniondale moved into the role of Conference 2 favorite by mauling Mepham, 356, on the running of George Backus and the playcalling of Steve Arresto.

title: ELLIS JOHNSON, 84, TAUGHT MATHEMATICS AT ERASMUS
An Outbreak of Diversity
description: LEVITTOWN, L.I.In which single community are there homes designed to look like a Swiss chalet, a Dutch farmhouse, a halftimbered Tudor, and an East Hampton beachhouse? Why, here in Levittown. That symbol of suburban uniformity, where more than 17,000 nearly identical houses were massproduced from 1947 to 1951, is today a hotbed of contrasting architectural styles.

title: Stronger Teams Are Ready For Fifth W.H.A. Season
description: Despite the refusal of the National Hockey League to recognize the World Hockey Association as an equal or believe in its financial stability, the W.H.A. is ready for its fifth season. The rebel league has stronger franchises and a new, tighter division alignment that splits its 12 teams into East and West divisions.

title: James C. Auchincloss Dies at 91
description: James C. Auchincloss, who represented New Jersey's Third Congressional District in the House of Representatives for 11 terms from 1943 until his retirement in 1964, died yesterday at a nursing home in Alexandria, Va., at the age of 91. He was a resident of Washington.

title: A Lesson From the Past
description: IN the face of the swirling controversy over whether to inoculate for swine flu and if it, indeed, may be expected to threaten the populace, it is comforting to know that someone out there is concerned with public welfare.

title: EUROPE IS WATCHING GERMAN VOTE TODAY
description: BONN, Oct. 2An extremely close vote is expected tomorrow when West Germans choose a new government in an election in which the victory of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, a Social Democrat, or his defeat by his Christian Democratic challenger, Helmut Kohl, will be taken as en indication of whether the trend in Europe is to the left or the right.

title: Yankees Triumph, 65, 43

BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Can the American business community take another magazine aimed at management?

title: Argentine President Escapes Blast
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 2 (Reuters)President Jorge Rafael Videla of Argentina escaped death today when a bomb exploded beneath a stand he had just left after having reviewed troops at the country's biggest and most heavily guarded army hasp

title: Patricia Keegan, Editor, Wed to Kenneth C. Abels
description: Patricia Anne Keegan, city editor of The StandardStar in New Rochelle, N. Y., and Kenneth C. Abels, an account executive with DudleyAndersonYutzy, a New York publicrelations agency, were married yesterday in Passaic, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Daniel P. Noonan, who concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Ronald Sordillo in St. Nicholas Roman Catholic Church.

title: Canadiens Expected to Rule Again in National Hockey League
Vigorito Sparks DePaul
description: Tom Vigorito rushed 19 times for 131 yards, three touchdowns and a twopoint conversion as DePaul defeated Pequannock, 360, at Wayne yesterday for its third successive triumph. Vigorito, one of the state's top scorers last year, raised his season scoring total to 62 points. He got the touchdowns on runs of 3, 7 and 8 yards. Pequannock lost its second straight after an opening victory.

title: Tax Collector to Operate From Bed
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Oct.2 (AP)Litchfield's 71yearold tax collector refused to turn over the keys to her office or reveal the combination of her safe. So selectmen decided to allow her to collect taxes from her hospital room.

title: Trumbull Gains Its 3d Shutout
description: Trumbull High School is unscored upon in three games this season, having routed Andrew Warde by 400 yesterday.

title: New York City Taxi Fleets to Test Diesel Cabs in a 2Year Program
description: The fleettaxi industry in New York City, in its search for operating economies, has started a twoyear program of testing the performance of 66 taxicabs converted from gasoline to diesel operation.

title: Gottfried, Stewart Gain Coast Tennis Semifinal
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (AP)Brian Gottfried, trying for his second tournament championship of the year and second in two weeks, beat secondseeded Harold Solomon. 61, 36. 63, today to move into the semifinals of the $125,000 Fireman's Fund international open tennis tournament. He will oppose unseeded Sherwood Stewart from Goose Creek, Tex., who won his quarterfinal today, 64, 62, from 11thseeded Vijay Amritraj of India.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: IT only stands to reason. At least I think so. If you're exposed to serious literature, I feel, then you must take your literature seriously. And so it was rather warming to learn recently that not only are New Jerseyans taking their literature more seriously than ever, but they also are becoming more sophisticated in their reasons for banning it.

title: TwoYear FordCongress Struggle Viewed as a Draw by Both Parties
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The 94th Congress and President Ford slugged it out like two heavyweights, and when Congress finished business early today there was a consensus that the twoyear fight had ended in a draw.

title: Arab Goverments Cannot Entirely Turn Away From Arafat
description: BEIRUT, LebanonYasir Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization has suffered a crippling military defeat in Lebanon and has seen its political power curtailed. Its influence on events elsewhere in the Middle East has been sharply reduced.

title: Julia D. Rea Becomes Bride
description: Julia Dodge Rea, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Rea of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday at noon to James Edward Diamond Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Diamond of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. The Rev. Dr. James Blackwood, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Reas country home in Stahlstown, Pa.

title: Details Are Corrected On Mail Registration
The Evolving Constitution
description: WE have spent a good part of this year celebrating the success of the democratic experimentand by any standard of which I am aware, our celebration has been justified. We are the children of a nation of immigrants.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 10yearold girl was crushed to death last night when she put her head through a glassless window in an elevator door and a descending elevator struck her. The child, Shirley In was playing in the fifth floor hallway of the building she lives in with her family at 1273 Nelson Avenue in the High Bridge section of the Bronx when she stuck her head through the broken panel seconds before the elevator descended, the police reported. Children of other tenants in the sixstory building ran down the stairs and told her parents, who live on the second floor.

title: Baku, Houston Now Sister Cities
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (AP)The port city of Baku, an oil center, has decided to become a sister city of Houston, Tex., the Soviet press agency Tess reports. The decision came in response to a proposal from the municipal council of Houstort. Baku is the capital of the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan. With a population nearing 1,400,000, the Caspian Sea port is the Soviet Union's fifth largest city.

title: 65 Imprisoned in Philippines Begin Hunger Strike as a Protest
description: MANILA, Oct. 2 (AP)Sixtyfive people jailed under martial law said today that they had started a hunger strike as a protest against their imprisonment and to demand the release of at least 44 of their number.

description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in the Arts and Leisure Section:

title: Polishing Manila for the I.M.F.
Rockefeller, Off the Bandwagon, Walks Behind as a Team Player
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The retinue is gone. Throngs of reporters and photographers no longer surround him, the crowds are fewer and smaller. He seems to seek out hands to shake, elbows to clasp and shoulders to pound. A lone newsman boards a halfempty Air Force Two to accompany the Vice President of the United States on a twoday swing throueh New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

title: Livingston Romps . . . and So Does Nutley
description: Bob Brower reeled off touchdown runs of 3, 15 and 63 yards as Livingston coasted to a 567 victory yesterday over Boonton at Livingston. Brower rushed 21 times for 163 yards as Livingston won its second straight. Boonton is 02.

title: Louisiana Legislator Is Victor In Runoff for Rep. Herbert's Seat
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 2 (AP)State Representative Richard A. Tonry won a primary runoff election today for the Democratic nomination to the United States House of Reperesentatives.

title: State Orders Easy Access for the Handicapped
description: TRENTON UNDER new standards adopted by the state, physically handicapped persons no longer will have to undergo the indignity of being carried up the steps of public buildings, be forced to use freight elevators to get to their apartments or have to be squeezed into awkward positions to use a telephone or water fountain.

title: Harmony From the Distaff Side
description: MELVILLE ON Sundays, Sandra McCain sings soprano in her North Bellmore church choir; on Thursdays, she is suddenly transformed into a bass. That's her night to sing barbershop music, and somehow in fourpart harmony, female style at least, a soprano can become a bass or vice versa.

description: OCTOBER 3, 1976

title: Jacqueline M. Depuy Married to Richard F. Lawley in Pennsylvania
description: Jacqueline M. Depuy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warner M. Depuy of Milford, Pa., and Richard F. Lawler were married yesterday in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Milford by the Rev. Richard Russell, Catholic chaplain at Yale University.

title: TV VIEW
description: Suddenly, right there in the middle of Jimmy Carter's sentence, the sound went out and stayed out for almost a half hour. And puzzlement. momentarily covered the land, which was being forcefed the Presidential debate via live simultaneous transmission on four national hookupsthose of ABC, CBS, NBC and the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Riding Boxcars With Conrail
description: AN OLDTIMER looking at the new big board on the wall at Conrail's Newark headquarters is apt to figure that it's strictly Rube Goldberg. A newtimer might decide that it looks like the wiring diagram of a Space Age computer.

title: Miss Osman, James Fieber Plan Nuptials
description: The engagement of Deborah. Jane Osman to James Albert Fieber has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. Osman of Stamford, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman A. Fieber, also of Stamford.

title: The Guest Word
description: The People of Kau (Harper and Row, $25) is a photographic study of a primitive Nuba tribe in the African Sudan, a sequel to The Last of the Nuba, published in 1974. The author and photographer, Leni Riefenstahl, is in the words of Susan Sontag (The New York Review of Books, Feb. 6, 1975) the only major artist who was completely identified with the Nazi era and whose worknot only during the Third Reich but thirty years after its fallhas consistently illustrated some of the themes of fascist aesthetics. Riefenstahl has been a movie star, a director of fiction and nonfiction films including the two great examples of Nazi propaganda, The Triumph of the Will (1935) and Olympiad (1938), and a photographer. She is currently at work film about the Nuba.

title: A Reply to the Critics: Detroit Ain't Down Yet!
description: DETROITAmerican cities are having troublesbig troubles. But as one who is committed to the future of Detroit, I am losing patience with the selfappointed analysts who select our city to illustrate the ills of urban America and who conclude on the hopeless note that nothing can be done to prevent Detroit from sinking beneath a tidal wave of social and economic problems.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The nation, says Charlton Heston, who delivers the pious narration for the American Film Institute's anthology film, America At The Movies, endured not by its power and wealth but by its spirit. Yet when one recalls the 82 films that have supplied America At The Movies with 93 scenes designed, in the words of George Stevens, Jr., to show the American people and spirit as we've seen it on the screen, the one fairly obvious common denominator they all share is a concern for powerthe desire for, acquisition of, perversions of, corruption by, loss of. This is true whether the film is a Western like John Ford's Cheyenne Autumn, a gangster melodrama like Mervyn Le Roy's Little Caesar, a screwball comedy like Frank Capra's It Happened One Night, or a W.C. Fields short like The Pharmacist which provides America At The Movies with one of its few highlights when Fields triesunsuccessfullyto do civilized combat with his shrewish wife and a daughter somewhat large and overaged to be the brat she is.

title: PROGRESS REPORTED IN FORD AUTO TALKS
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 2For the first time since the United Automobile Workers went on strike at the Ford Motor Company 18 days ago, there appeared today to be a good prospect that the strike could be settled soonperhaps before the weekend is over.

title: The Economics Behind a Fruit and Vegetable Stand
description: STEPHENTOWN, N.Y.  The alarm clock went off at 4:10 the other morning and Cynthia Pease got up, dressed, ate breakfast and drove off before it got light to the wholesale fruit and vegetable market in Menands, just north of Albany, about 25 miles from her farm.

title: Dean C. Hanger, Alison W. Peake Marry in Capital
description: The marriage of Alison Wainwright Peake to Dean Charles Hanger took place yesterday afternoon in the Little Sanctuary at Mount St. Alban in Washington. The Rev. Thomas B. Allen, uncle of the bridegroom, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: 'Kings' Travel Long Screen Road
description: Roads have usually been thought of as destinations; they were built to go somewhere and that's what people mostly have used them for. But destinations have been in decline these last few decades, at least as a subject for the imagination. "On the Road," "Easy Rider," these were about leaving, not about arriving.In "Kings of the Road," by the West German director Wim Wenders, there is nothing but the road, or a series of roads. They run through the North German plain, overcast most of the time, with fog and rain erupting continually and with a sunlight that manages to look dark. The world, whether as a point of departure or a destination, has all but finishedthe road remains as a kind of Limbo of our time."Kings," which is being shown today and tomorrow at the New York Film Festival and will open Tuesday at the Embassy 72d Street Theater, focuses upon two citizens of the road, one permanent and one temporary.The first is Bruno, who makes his home in a moving-van and drives from town to town fixing the projectors in the local movie house. He is loose, sleepy, shrewd, good-humored and totally unattached. He longs for women, is attractive to them, but lacks the power of concentrationpermanent or temporaryto settle on any particular one.Bruno has accepted aimlessness and unattachment. He drives through the dour countryside and visits the dour towns, whose streets are virtually unpopulated and whose gas stations seem to be always closed. It's not that aimlessness doesn't hurt him: It does, but so deeply that he doesn't show it.He has, in fact, only one commitment: to the proper projection of motion pictures and the proper maintenance of the machinery. It is a solitary ideal; the projectionists he deals with are slipshod and indifferent, and more and more villages are are shutting their cinemas down.Bruno has withdrawn from the world, then, or perhaps it is the other way around. Into his solitude, propelled at full speed, comes a temporary refugee, Robert. Robert is an intellectual who engages actively with societyhe studies children's speechbut his recent encounters have been shattering. His wife has left him, for example.Two meet, comically: Robert, full of anger and distraction, drives his car into a lake by mistake and it sinks. Bruno and his van are parked nearby. They join forces.It is a long, slow, wandering they embark upon. Robert becomes Bruno's assistant. He can't face his own world, for the time being: but every time he spots a telephone he tries to call his wife, and every time he sees a newspaper on the ground he reads it.There are a series of encounters in which each, in his own way, enacts the difficulty of communication. Bruno spends a night with the cashier of a movie house. There is a lovely tenderness, but all he can do, literally, is sleep with her.Robert visits his father, editor of a small newspaper, and tries to speak of his childhood resentments. But he can't get the words out so finally, as the old man sleeps at his desk, the son goes to work on the linotype. By morning, he has printed a two-page denunciation of his father's treatment of his mother. He finishes, hands the pages to his father; they embrace delicately and part.Eventually, Robert goes back. His nature is to commit himself, even to an imperfect, half-dead world. He takes a train, that most constrained and committed form of transportation. Bruno, the idealist, wanders on in his lumpy van, whose mournful pace and elephantine presence make a lovely unifying symbol for the film.It needs one badly. "Kings" is often fascinating. It has a number of compelling and witty scenes, and its imagery is harshly apt. But it is three hours long, which is at least an hour too much; and its successes are scattered like meager raisins through a mass of gray dough.It moves like silence and sleep, and with a great parsimony of things to look at. Nothing happens but what is happening, and it happens one thing at a time, and one or two people at a time. Our peripheral vision is starved, and we are ready to take the train some time before Robert does.

title: REPORT FROM WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON The bicentennial year is running into its final quarter, to the relief of some and the remorse of others, but this city's theatrical life is not facing a postbicentennial slump. As Washingtonians have come to expect in the course of its fiveyear history, the principal theatrical pillar here will be the Kennedy Center, which in fact will move beyond its walls this season to present a new play by Tom Stoppard.

title: Backward and Upward With Michael Tilson Thomas
description: A funny thing happened on Michael Tilson Thomas's way to superstardom. He turned back. In 1971, when he was 26 and had been in the public eye for a mere two years, the question was: will this Boy Wonder fill the shoes of none other than Leonard Bernstein?a tough act to follow by anybody's reckoning. In 1976, memories being short, the question is: Whatever happened to Michael Tilson Thomas?

Kearney Inc., an international management consulting concern based in Chicago. Kearney's president, Donald E. Ramlow, is a member of the Koehring board of directors. Because of this, he was criticized by dissident Koehring stockholders, who accused him of having a conflict of interest and demanded his resignation from the board.

title: Young Sailor Has LongRange Goal
description: The exuberance of youth. The adventure of following the shadows as square riggers around Cape Horn. The discipline of circumnavigating the world alone in a 31foot sailboat. No. Bob Gainer is no Tom Sawyer. Except forthe ripples of enthusiasm breaking through a calm demeanor, he's all business Gainer, 23 years old, of Hillsdale, N.J., cast off from the South Street Seaport Museum yesterday and sailed his fiberglass sloop, Boodles Jinny, down the East River. And, if all goes according to schedule, the next steeple he will see will be at the same pier in 292 days. In between, he has to sail 25,779 nautical miles.

title: If You Go ...
description: .. . on the Hellas Express from Munich, you can make reservations at the Munich Hauptbahnhof and at travel agencies. When traveling in the opposite direction, however, don't try to get international rail tickets at the Athens Station; they're available only from agencies in central Athens. Depending on the season, book from two days to a week in advance. You can take any amount of baggage but keep items wanted during the trip in a separate bag for easier access. Wear wrinklefree synthetics for couchette travel. Toilet facilities on the train are clean and there is hot water, but bring your own drinking water. Couchette compartments can and should be kept locked from inside at night to avoid any worries about nocturnal sneakthieves.J.A.C.

title: Double Your Knit
Salmon ranches and lobster farms
description: An entrepreneur on the West Coast invested $50,000 last year to install a large fish tank in his backyard and stock it with crabs flown in from Indonesia. He believed he had the beginnings of a lucrative new business known as aquaculture or, more simply, fish farming. What he didn't know, among a lot of other things, was that his backyard herd of crabs was fiercely cannibalistic. Penned together in the tank, the crabs began to eat one another. The man wound up with a $50,000 loss and one crab.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE GOVERNMENT'S INDEX of leading economic Indicators fell 1.5 percent in August to 108.0 [1967= 100], the first drop in 18 months . . . The nation posted its third largest monthly trade deficit in August of $757.7 million. Exports totaled $9.69 billion and imports were $10.44 billion, the Commerce Department said . . . The basic money supply, M1, fell a record $2.8 billion last week, following a record increase of $4.5 billion a week earlier, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported . . . Construction contracts in August declined 13 percent to $8.5 billion from the $9.77 billion in July and dropped 19 percent from the $105 billion announced in June, F. W. Dodge said.

title: For Designers, Schools Replace Work at Trade
description: Instead of pasting up swatches for a big manufacturer or picking up pins at a Paris couture house. American fashion designers are increasingly learning their craft in the halls of academe.

title: Food
description: For years we have pondered the name of one of the most famous chicken dishes served in Europe. It is called polio pepitoria, or chicken pepitoria, and is a specialty of Le Provenal restaurant in JuanlesPins in the AlpesMaritimes, in France. Only recently did an acquaintance unravel this mystery. The name stems from pepitas, the Spanish word for pumpkin seeds, he explained. The confusion, we suppose, lay in the fact that the dish, more often than not, is made with almonds rather than pumpkin seeds. We have tried it with pumpkin seeds, which are available in health food stores, as well as with almonds, and either way it is delectable. So are the two other chicken recipes printed here, both saut dishesone made with potatoes, the other with mushrooms and rosemary.

description: It never attracted much attention in the Eastern press, but the murder trial of Dr. John Hill in Houston, 1971, was the talk of Texas. It had all the ingredients of a mystery story, plus glamorous personalities, plus big money, plus some very prominent Texans, plus a proandcon lineup of the medical profession. It ended in a mistrial. Did Dr. John Hill really kill his wife? Nobody knows. Nobody will ever know, for Dr. Hill was assassinated in 1972. But that was not the end of the case. Who was responsible for Dr. Hill's death?

title: The Color

Try to describe them adequately and you are immediately in danger of drowning in superlatives.

Eventually the price was fixed at $4 million, to be spread over 18 years after a down payment, the same total that the Islanders agreed in 1971 to pay the Rangers in the National Hockey League expansion. But at the time of the basketball merger, Roy Boe, the president of both the Nets and the Islanders, was trying to soften his cash flow. In a quiet conversation with Mike Burke, the Knicks president, Roy Boe had a startling suggestion.

It is therefore significant that it has been done without the use of force.
