title: 'Alex and Gypsy,' Sutton Film With Lemmon, Misses Mark
description: Genevieve Bujold is standing in the garden, dressed in a red nightgown. She is looking fiercely at the moon and saying:"Jowl, jowl."Why is she saying that?Because, in the new movie, "Alex and the Gypsy," which opened yesterday at the Sutton Theater, she plays a gypsy. And "jowl, jowl," we are told, is what gypsies say when they want to get pregnant.It is a small point, but it is a fair sample of the kind of ludicrousness that repeatedly overtakes "Alex," a movie that works away at being wonderful, funny and romantic. Once in a while it succeeds, but more often it is like the star English pupil in a Borneo grammar school reciting the witches' lines from "Macbeth." The sounds are there, more or less, but the emphases are wildly off."Alex" is about a bail bondsman, a man who puts up surety that people facing a trial will show up for it, and protects his risk by keeping a close watch on them. Alex, played by Jack Lemmon, is a crabby, cynical man whose pride in his peculiar work is masked by a flood of black humor.Alex's carefully controlled life was knocked askew just once. Maritza, running away from her arranged gypsy wedding, attached herself to him. Her unreserved and enthusiastic passion foundered on his cragginess, and she walked out. When the movie opens, Maritza is back, this time awaiting sentencing for stabbing her thuggish husband.She begs Alex to bail her out for the four days before sentencing; gypsies die in jail, she tells him. He hesitates, then puts up the bail. The balance of the movie is devoted to the four days they spend together. He is a watchdog gradually defanged by love: she, the defanger, turns the watchdog into something like a racing whippet.Except for an awkward use of flashbacks showing the earlier relationship of Alex and Maritza, the film is well constructed and well paced. There are some lovely details: for example, Alex's disenchanted grilling of a potential customer, a horrendous young maniac arrested for setting fire to someone who annoyed him. "Arson," Alex decides. "That's a bailable offense."The central relationship, the dismantling of a sour principle of order by black-haired, black-eyed Life Force, is hardly a novelty, but it has possibilities and sometimes it is touching.But neither of the principals brings it off. Miss Bujold is a good actress if she has a compelling energy on the screen. But she is quite wrong in the part. It's not merely her catered accent; as if "jowl, jowl" and an erractic deletion of the definite article were enough to establish the gypsy. More seriously, her tumultuousness is only flamboyance. It lacks the stolidity, the reserve that is essential to any representation of gypsy passion. She comes close to resembling the American tourist shown dancing Flamenco in sherry ads, her arms raised a fatal 3 inches too high.Jack Lemmon, scruffy, tough and vulnerable, has a role that is modeled on a Sam Spade or a Philip Marlowe. The object is to be a Noble Wreck. But Mr. Lemmon lacks the assurance, the self-denial for wrecked nobility. He keeps letting the shlemiel in, and the tension out. There is an essential difference between irony and clowning, but Mr. Lemmon doesn't manage it.

title: Television
Syrian Economy Hit Hard by Lebanon Involvement

description: The second annual installment of medieval and Renaissance music called In Praise of Early Music at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon served three ostensible functions. It called attention to an upcoming series by providing samples of the work of each of the five participating groups in the series: It suggested that the cathedral is becoming the center for early music in New York. And it provided for a sampler of French and Flemish music from the medieval and Renaissance periods.

Widnall. The record shows that once incumbents are reelected they become particularly difficult to oust. title: Police in Darien Face New Foe: Crime
Shofar Sounding a Last Time At a Brooklyn Synagogue
description: Rabbi Solomon B. Shapiro will sound the shofar for the last time at sundown tonight, marking an end to Yom Kippur and to the life of his synagogue on a tree lined street in Brooklyn's East Flatbush.

title: U.S. Fails on Copper Bid
Issue and Debate
description: Though uncertainty about the true financial condition of New York and other cities has upset the municipal securities market, investors still are not getting nearly as much detailed information about state and city fiscal affairs as they can from the smallest publicly owned corporation.

title: Congress Votes to Close A Loophole of $1 Billion In Social Security Law
description: Congress has given unanimous approval in both houses to a bill that would close a $1 billion loophole in the Social Security law by barring refunds to charitable organizations and their employees.

title: Islanders Close Exhibition Slate With a Flourish
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 3The New York Islanders, happy to finish a tough preseason grind, wrapped up their ex hibition schedule tonight with a brisk trouncing of the Atlanta Flames, 62, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: The Future of Communications
description: WASHINGTON  After five years and $100 million, Datran, one of the new competitive communications carriers, filed bankruptcy. It also filed a $285 million antitrust suit against its chief competitor, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Certainly this is an issue for the courts. But Datran's struggle to survive is part of a larger controversy that has been bubbling in the House Subcommittee on Communications. The controversy concerns the future of the communications industry: Competition or monopoly? A free marketplace or de facto nationalization?

title: In West Germany, Even the Winners Swallow Results With Signs of Irritability and Lack of Jubilation
description: BONN, Oct. 3Practically everybody claimed victory tonight after West German voters gave Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's coalition Government a sharply reduced majority.

title: President of P.B.A. Calls 24Hour Halt In Demonstrations
description: Douglas D. Weaving. preSident of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, asked New York City's 18,000 police officers to stop demonstrating for 24 hours starting at sundown yesterday in observence. of Yom Kippur, but he urged them to resume tonight their protests against deferred wages and lengthened work Schedules.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: U.S. AGENCY IS CHALLENGED ON ITS DEFINITION OF INDIAN
description: PETOSKEY, Mich., Oct. 3The power of the Bureau of Indian Affairs to restrict the definition of Indian to members of federally recognized tribes is being challenged in United States District Court in Grand Rapids, Mich.

title: Doubts About Carter Are Abundant Among Milwaukee Working Class
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 3  Doubts about Jimmy Carter abound in the solidly workingclass South Side of this city: doubts about his character, his religion and his views. But all of these seem less detrimental to his candidacy, finally, than an underlying doubt as to whether strong Presidential leadership is even possible anymore.

title: Control of Hospitals At Issue in the Bronx
description: In the last two months, the dazzling new North Central Bronx Hospital has been more of a controversy than an institution, the focus of almost daily demonstrations by people trying to get it open and the subject of a debate that could come to a head this week.

title: Thurber Cartoons on Wall Being Salvaged
description: Eight cartoons scribbled n the attic walls of a house in Newtown, Conn., by James Thurber more than 40 years ago are being shipped to Columbus, Ohio, where they will go on display as part of Ohio State University's permanent Thurber collection.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Tomorrow is the last day New Yorkers may register to vote for the Nov. 2 general election. This may be done at local polling places from 1 P.M. to 9 P.M. today and tomorrow.

title: Gottfried and Tanner Gain Coast Tennis Final
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 (AP) Brian Gottfried coasted to a 60, 63 victory over Sherwood Stewart and Roscoe Tanner, beat Dick Stockton, 63, 46, 64, today and gained the final of the $125,000 Fireman's Fund tennis tournament.

title: Sedate Wine Auction Proves a Rousing Success
description: LONDON, Oct. 3After four days of gentlemanly bidding, buyers from all over Europe, the United States and Australia went home from one of Christie's most successful wine auctions ever.

title: Around the Nation
description: DETROIT, Oct. 3 (UPI)Earlier optimism that a new contract agreement would be reached in the 19th day of the United Automobile Workers strike against the Ford Motor Company faded today as bargainers headed into a late, evening session.

title: HEAD OF I.M.F. URGES HALT TO BORROWING TO COVER DEFICITS
description: MANILA, Monday, Oct. 3The time has come for nations, both rich and poor, to stop borrowing so much to cover their balance of payments deficits and start eliminating the deficits, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund said today.

title: Administration's Stockpiling Plan Is Expected to Lift Copper Prices
description: The Government's plan to rebuild its stockpiles of 72 of the 93 raw materials it keeps for military and other emergency needs, which was announced late last Friday, is expected to reverse the downward course of copper prices.

title: ARABS AND ISRAELIS CLASH ON WEST BANK
description: HEBRON, Occupied West Bank, Oct. 3Rioting and violent clashes erupted here today between Arab youths and Israeli security forces after Moslems and Jews accused one another of desecrating Moslem and Jewish artifacts at a shrine sacred to both faiths.

title: Daughter Born to Ervings
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.,Oct. 3 (AP)Turquoise Erving, wife of Julius Erving of the New York Nets, gave birth to an 8pound 6ounce girl this morning at Long Island Jewish Hospital. The girl is the couple's third child.

title: Buffalo Orchestra Combines Ives, Dvorak in Odd Couple Program
description: In pursuit, as ever, of the program that skews away from the everyday concert experience, Michael Tilson Thomas caught up with Dvorak and Ives yesterday at Carnegie Hall. The conductor and his Buffalo Philharmonic addressed themselves to that old couple in the first of the orchestra's three Manhattan concerts this season, playing in succession the Psalm 90 of Ives and a cantata, The American Flag, of Dvorak.

title: Books of The Times
description: A celebration of the color blue: Blue pencils, blue noses, blue movies, laws, blue legs and stockings, the language of birds, bees and flowers as sung by longshoremen, the leadlike look the skin has when affected by cold, contusion, sickness, fear; the rotten rum or gin they call blue ruin and the blue devil of its delirium. . . A case against the direct depiction of sexual material in literature: I would like to suggest that at least on the face of it a stroke by stroke story of a copulation is exactly as absurd as a chew by chew account of the consumption of a chicken's wing. An investigation of the dirty words hidden in Hamlet'; the true blueness of the fiction of Samuel Beckett and Stanley Elkin; the difference between the use, mention and utterance of words; and the psychology of color perception as explained by the classical philosophers. What do these exercises have in common?

title: CRITICISM OF BUTZ CONTINUES TO GROW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Criticism of Earl L. Butz for making racist remarks continued to mount today, but neither the Secretary of Agriculture nor White House officials would say whether he would resign or be dismissed.

title: About New York
description: The two pregnant giraffes looked beautiful. Not just because they were giraffes and stood there like soaring patchwork fantasies, and were containing images of themselves. But because it was becoming night in the Bronx Zoo and all the humans had been cleared out except for a favored few who could witness the great contrived gathering of life even more clearly in the dusk and in the absence of most human babble.

title: Meyer of Penn Wins E.C.A.C. Singles Title
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Final to Miss Replogle
description: Special to The New York Times

title: MRS. SCHAFFER SUPPORTS LOWER DEFENSE BUDGET
description: Gloria Schaffer, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator from Connecticut, said yesterday that she would vote to reduce the defense budget if elected.

title: Hunt Triumphs, Lauda Is 7th In Canadian Grand Prix Race
description: MOSPORT. Ontario, Oct. 3 (AP)James Hunt, driving a McLaren, zoomed to the front on the sixth lap today, then held off a relentless challenge by Patrick Depailler and finished first in the Canadian Grand Prix.

title: Paramus Policeman Dies in Crash
description: PARAMUS, N.J., Oct. 3 (UPI) A Paramus police officer was killed today when his patrol car struck a utility pole on Route 17 while he was responding to a burglary alarm, the police reported. The victim, Michael McEllen, 27 years old, of Paramus, was declared dead at the scene.

title: Butter Jackson, 67, Dies
description: Quentin (Butter) Jackson, a trombonist who played with Cab Calloway's, Duke Ellington's and Count Basie's bands, died of a heart attack Saturday at St. Clare's Hospital. He became ill at the Broadway Theater, where he was playing in the orchestra of Guys and Dolls. He was 67 years old and lived at 780 Greenwich Street.

title: TAYLOR DANCERS SET A SEASON IN CAPITAL
description: The Paul Taylor Dance Company, which announced two weeks ago that it was disbanding indefinitely because of financial difficulties, has become the focus of an emergency fundraising effort that includes the National Endowment for the Arts, Betty Ford, Joanne Woodward, a group of business executives and a Washington impresario. A special season has been scheduled to provide work for the internationally known modern dance troupe.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will be able to park their, cars today on both sides of those streets, where alternatesideofthestreet regulations are normally in effect. The regulations have been suspnded because oa Yom Kippur. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply.

title: Young Women Obstetricians Find That They're in Demand
description: A sadeyed woman in her 50's stepped into examining booth No. 14 at Jacobi Hospital's obstetrics and gynecology clinic the other day and beamed at the sight of Teresa Suarez.

title: New $35 Million SewageTreatment Facility Opened in Parsippany
description: Special to The New York Times

title: U.S. HOUSING PAYOFFS START WIDE INQUIRY
description: United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein said yesterday that his office had started an investigation into apparently widespread kickbacks in Federal construction contracts.

title: Protesters Halt Paris Train
description: PARIS, Oct. 3 (Reuters)A group of antiSoviet demonstrators stopped the ParisCopenhagenMoscow Express by pulling the emergency cord shortly after it left here today, railway officials said. The group then distributed leaflets among passengers, calling for the release of a Norwegian and a Frenchman they said had been imprisoned in the Soviet Union for political offenses.

title: Bridge:
description: Many players of great ability confine their activities to rubber bridge because duplicate, for one reason or another, the artificiality, the conventions, or the slow pace, has no appeal to them. But some of them will occasionally emerge to take part in headtohead team matches, in which a rubberbridge style is effective. And in doing so they often upset opponents who underestimate them.

title: ThirdWorld Nations at U.N. Show Interest in Curbs on Arms Sales
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 3Long dormant interest in limiting the world's growing commercial arms traffic is cropping up in unexpected and promising new guise before the 31st General Assembly.

title: Grambling Beats Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 3 (AP)Cliff Martin of Grambling ran for three touchdowns as the Tigers overpowered the University of Hawaii, 3423, yesterday. Martin got loose on a 72yard romp for Grambling's first touchdown, and he added scoring runs of 1 yard and 15 yards.

title: Levine Conducts the Philharmonic In Mahler's Sixth at Carnegie Hall
description: James Levine's conception of Mahler's Symphony No. 6 Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, part of the New York Philharmonic's Mahler Festival, had its describable characteristics, its considerable virtues and its limitations.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
Bronx Zoo Becomes the Wood for Very Happy WinniethePooh Fans
FOUNDATIONS TO PAY FOR MAYORAL AGENCY
description: A new office is being set up under the First Deputy Mayor, John E. Zuccotti, and will be paid for by leading foundations to try to plan how best to reorganize education, health and similar social services during the New York City budget crisis.

title: COL. DAVID BRADY AT 79
description: Col. David Brady, a member of the New York law firm of Bergreene & Bergreene, died yesterday at his home, 15 West 81st Street, after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Namath Fumble Causes A 31Yard Scoring Run
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3In a negative sort of way, things are getting a little better for the New York Jets, who lost to the San Francisco 49ers, 176, at Candlestick Park today. Although this was their fourth defeat without a victory, it was their smallest losing margin of the season, and they managed to score their first touchdown in three weeks. They also succeeded in keeping the 49ers scoreless for the first 44 minutes of the 60minute game.

title: Rain Ends Yanks Regular Season, Their Most Successful in 12 Years
NATO Talk: Feier Ouen Redie Is Feuerbereitschaftsmeldung
Good Crop and Lower Costs Raise Spirits in Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Sept. 28  The news from Bangladesh is good for a changeor at least not quite so bad as usual.

title: 2 Escape Broome Jail
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 3 (UPI)The police were searching today for two prisoners who staged the first successful breakout in the 37year history of the Broome County Jail, the Broome County Sheriffs Department said. The fugitives, who apparently escaped from a work detail inside the Binghamton building yesterday, were identified as 16yearold Allan Feeney of Endicott and Roy Cope, 32, Buffalo. Mr. Feeney was serving a sentence for criminal mischief and Mr. Cope for thirddegree burglary, deputies said.

title: Patriots Rout Raiders, 4817, Scoring 3d Upset
description: Steve Grogan and the New England Patriots are for real. The Oakland Raiders learned this yesterday, when they became the Patriots third straight upset victim. Grogan passed for three touchdowns and ran for two more in a 4817 stomping of the previously undefeated Raiders at Schaefer Stadium in Foxboro, Mass.

title: U.S. and Latins: Violations of Rights vs. Aid From Congress
Pulaski Day: Rain on the Parade
A Fire Chief Benefits By Demoting Himself
description: On Saturday, Frank Carruthers was chief of operations for the Fire Department of the City of New York, the thirdhighest officer in the department.

title: Ancient Chinese Rite Honors A New Rights Commissioner
description: Gongs, drums and a Chinese trumpet heralded the start of an ancient ritual yesterday, and Richard Wong smiled. Tai hoi mun, he said. It mean, Open up the door wide. It's a welcoming song.

title: Heart Surgery for Kuenn
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 3 (AP)Harvey Kuenn, a Milwaukee Brewers coach and a former major leaguer, will undergo openheart surgery Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital in Milwaukee. He had received medical tests after reporting numbness in his face and left arm. The 45yearold Kuenn played, 15 seasons in the majors, breaking in with the Detroit Tigers in 1952.

title: Coach Hayes Defends His LatePunt Strategy
description: The buck didn't stop where one might have expected it to when Ohio State's head coach, Woody Hayes, explained the Buckeyes failure to gamble the last time they had the ball Saturday in their 1010 tie with the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: Fall, When Leaves Turn Color and Suntans Fade
description: T. S. Eliot notwithstanding, most women would vote October, rather than April, as the cruelest month. For their looks, anyway. Summer was all carefree and backtonature, now with store windows full of fall clothes, summer's face begins to look all wrong. Fading suntans and bedraggled hair are not nearly as attractive as they were when they were fresh at the beginning of July.

title: INTERNS' COMMITTEE TO STRIKE HOSPITALS
description: The Committee of Interns and Residents voted yesterday to strike nine voluntary hospitals in New York City at 7 A.M. tomorrow because, it said, the institutions had refused to bargain with them on new contracts.

title: Crime and Sense
description: President Ford made a rousing anticrime speech in his recent appearance before the International Association of Chiefs of Police in Miami Beach. While crime is a serious problem and there are serious things to be said about it, the President failed to say most of them.

title: CRITICISM OF BUTZ CONTINUES TO GROW
Las Vegas Cracking Down on Merchandising of Sex
LEO B. TRAVERS
description: Leo B, Travers, a retired partner in the former oddlot brokerage house of Carlisle & Jacquelin, died yesterday at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Spring Lake, N.J. He was 85 years old and resided in Spring Lake and at the New York Athletic Club.

title: Rams Turn Back Dolphins by 3128 On Dempsey Kick in Last 2 Minutes
RIKERS ISLAND INMATE, 19, IS FOUND DEAD IN HIS CELL
description: A 19yearold youth awaiting trial on a robbery charge committed suicide in his cell at the Adolescent Reception/ Detention Center on Rikers Island yesterday afternoon, according to the Department of Correction.

title: Dance: Utah Company Ends Visit
description: The repertory of the Repertory Dance Theater from Utah is fairly matched with works by wellknown qutside choreographers, such as Lar Lubovitch or the late Jose Limn, and works created by members of its own company. During the company's weeklong New York season at the Manhattan School of Music on Claremont Avenue, which ended this weekend, the company offered virtually two programs, but on Saturday it substituted the Donald McKayle ballet in the second program for a duet called Synapse by a company member, Karen Steele.

title: BANKERS PESSIMISTIC ON ECONOMIC UPTURN BEFORE EARLY 1977
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  American bankers assembling here for the 102d annual convention of the American Bankers Association this week, generally believe the pace of the nation's economic recovery will stay sluggish for the remainder of this year.

title: Police in Darien Face NewFoe: Crime
description: DARIEN, Conn.  When Joseph Spadaro drove down the ramp at Exit 13 of the Connecticut Turnpike here the other day, three things were immediately apparent.

title: Muzorewa, Back in Rhodesia, Says U.S. Aids Rival Nationalist, Nkomo
Rocks Show Earth Was Hotter 3 Billion Years Ago
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 3Temperatures on earth were much warmer three billion years ago, reaching perhaps 160 degrees Fahrenheit, according to an analysis of geochemical thermometers made here at the California Institute of Technology.

title: The Butz Insult
description: Now that it has been established that Agriculture Secretary Earl Butz is no poet, the questions remaining are whether he is fit to continue serving in the Cabinet and what President Ford should do about him.

title: Final Standings
description: Monday, October 4, 1976

title: Giants Beaten by Cards, 2721
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3The Giants are going home losers again, but after today's 2721 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals, they are going home proud and defiant losers.

title: Pressure Intensifies on UNESCO To Reverse Ruling Barring Israel
description: PARIS, Oct. 3Pressure on UNESCO to reverse its 1974 decision barring Israel from taking part in the work of the organization was intensified last night when an international conference here of scientists and intellectuals set up a permanent action committee to press the case.

title: EXGOV. QUINN TO FACE MATSUNAGA IN HAWAII
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 3Spark M. Matsumaga, a seventerm Democratic Representative, and William F. Quinn, a onetime Republican Governor, squared off today for a month's campaigning for one of Hawaii's United States Senate seats.

title: Article 2  No Title
SCHOOL WORKERS END WALKOUT IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK. Oct. 3Two unions of striking noninstructional school employees voted today to accept a school board contract offer and return to work.

title: $400,000 Paris Race Goes To Ivanjica, KentuckyBred
description: PARIS, Oct. 3The course was soft, and that was good for the United Statesbred filly during the race and even better for her French jockey after the race, the only moment during the day that was scary for the winning duo.

title: Mensa Meeting Provides Setting Where High I.Q.Is No Drawback
description: MAPLEWOOD, Oct. 3What is the Latin word for table that was the password at a party here last night for people who are smarter than 98 percent of their neighbors?

title: Success in Salvaging
description: There is a success story in the lowincome housing field in New York City. This is a surprising statement, given the grim facts of deteriorating neighborhoods and increasing numbers of abandoned buildings.

title: A Cool and Private Chancellor
description: BONN, Oct. 3Helmut Schmidt has always been a lonely man, driven by ambition and a cool, Protestant North German selfesteem that has often repelled the clubby politicians in his own party. In the past twoandahalf years as Chancellor, he has been driven by necessity and logic and pragmatism, not by the warm idealism of his predecessor Willy Brandtrespected but not really loved. Only Mr. Schmidt's steelgray hair betrays his age. His trim, short figure and his chiseled features make him look younger than his 57 years. He speaks flat, colloquial English so well that it is hard to believe he taught himself the language, after the British occupied his native city of Hamburg in 1945.

title: Madlock, Brett Barely Win Batting Titles
description: The game of inches became the game of decimals yesterday as the baseball season ended with two batting races going down to the last inning.

title: Ali May Have Regrets, Skips Mosque Talk
WEST GERMANS BACK SCHMIDT'S COALITION BUT HE LOSES SEATS
Film Stars Go for BeatUp RentaCars
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1The cars are battered and beaten. The fenders are crumpled, the doors smashed and the upholstery torn. The place looks like an automobile junk yard. Few people would suspect it of being the most popular carrental agency in Hollywood.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will be able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternatesideofthestreet regulations are normally in effect. The regulations have been suspnded because of Yom Kippur. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply.

title: A Landmark Project...
description: It is to be hoped that New York's notorious death wish does not extend from the local community board to the Board of Estimate in the matter of the Villard Houses and the projected Palace Hotel at Madison Avenue and 50th Street. If approval of this project meant that the city was endorsing new construction at any cost, there might be real reasons to hold up the plans for the hotel.

title: ANALYSTS EXPECTING DROP IN BOND RATES TO CONTINUE TREND
description: It has been just a year since interest rates on municipal bonds hit their highest levels on record. It is also just a year since Moody's Investors Service lowered its ratings of both New York City and New York State on news that State Comptroller Arthur Levitt would invest state pension funds in state notes.

title: Saudi Arabia to Withdraw Its Golan Heights Force
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 3Saudi Arabia has decided to withdraw from Syria the brigade of troops it has maintained on the Golan Heights facing Israel since the October 1973 Middle East war.

title: Commodities
description: Each year at this time the winners and losers among the commodity futures trading fraternity become increasingly more discernible by their trading tactics.

title: Career of Butz Is Marked by Conflicts And Abrasive Remarks on Touchy Topics
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3I don't know. why Earl makes those remarks, an associate of Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz told a reporter not long ago. It must be part of the image he wants to project out in the country for his farm constituents.

title: The List That Never Was
description: WASHINGTONThe punishment for journalists on the newest enemies list is the Carter campaign's refusal to respond to any question submitted by the listee. Perhaps more favored newsmen will press for answers to longignored questions like these:

title: Stiffer Penalties Proposed For AntitrustAct Violators
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Donald I Baker, the new head of the Justice Department's antitrust division believes that much stiffer sentences should be imposed on criminal violators of the antitrust laws.

title: . . . Small but Vital
description: Building may be at a standstill in New York, but planning is not. Although this is clearly not the time for the kind of largescale development controls that produced special district zoning and new kinds of construction in New York in the 1960'sfor some of the most progressive and visible results in the countryneither is it the time, as some critics would have it, to declare the city's planners expendable.

title: INCREASE IN BLACKS IN OFFICE IS DOUBTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The number of black men and women elected to political office, which has grown from about 400 to nearly 4,000 in 10 years, appears unlikely to change dramatically this year, according to information available here.

title: Voiding of Miranda Ruling at Issue In Case Before High Court Today
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 3Every murder is awful, but Pamela Powers's was especially terrible.

title: CATHOLICS PROMISE TO OPPOSE ABORTION
description: Hundreds of worshipers at St. Patrick's Cathedral signed pledge cards yesterday the day was called Respect Life Sundaycommitting themselves to support the bishops of the Roman Catholic Church in their fight against abortion, which is now an issue in the political campaigns.

title: State Will Institute Courier Mail System
description: TRENTON, Oct. 3 (UPI)A new courier system will go into effect later this month to carry mail between New Jersey government offices in Trenton and Newark in the first of a series of attempts to streamline the state's postal delivery system.

title: The U.N. Today
Front Page 1  No Title
Advertising
description: For companies introducing new products the New York market is a fearsome place, important because of its size, yes, but scary because it is so different from the rest of the country.

title: Without a Net
description: Two years ago, amid panic over the impact on the Western industrial countries of the quintupling of oil prices by OPEC, Secretary of State Kissinger launched a drive to create a Financial Support Fund. Nicknamed the safety net, the fund was to allow nations unable to cover the cost of needed oil imports to borrow up to $25 billion.

title: Copies of Rifles Are a Boon for Retailers
description: Copies of American rifles of the Revolutionary and Civil Wars, black powder and Ioadingfiring accessories have become big business.

title: Three Men and a Horse
description: In the past it has been Muhammad Ali's practice to retire the morning after a fight. On one occasion, in Kuala Lumpur for a caper with Joe Bugner, he announced his retirement before the fight. The fact that it took him 48 hours after his match with Ken Norton to pack it in again shows how he is slowing down. The Norton bout made it clear that the champion has next to nothing left as a fighter of the top rank, though this seemed to escape the attention of the ring officials. Whether he makes his comeback this year or next, it says here that he cannot whip Norton or George Foreman, and there may be others among the leading contenders who would be too much for him. One of this group, Duane Bobick, presented his credentials on television Saturday afternoon. He opened a few more crevices in Chuck Wepner's hemstitched visage, stopping Bayonne's oneman blood bank in the sixth round. At the same time, however, the real heavyweight champion of the worlda horse named Foregowas doing his thing on another network and this caused such a distraction it was difficult to appraise Bobick's performance accurately.

title: To East and West German Writers Freedom Is a Relative Condition
description: WEST BERLINOn Unter den Linden in East Berlin, the bookstores are promoting Flaubert's Madame Bovary, Arnold Zweig's Sergeant Grischa. most but not all of the works of Bertolt Brecht (the exception is a proAmerican memoir), and contemporary novelists lip ing in East Germany. On the Kurfurstendamm in West Berlin, the bookstores are up to Saul Bellow's latest novel, Humholdt's Gift. in English or German.

title: Palestinians Await Political Moves As War Action Slows in Lebanon
Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: EXREP. SMITH DIES AT HOME IN VIRGINIA
description: Former Representative Howard Worth Smith of Virginia, who during his 36 years in Congress rose to the position of chairman of the House Rules Committee, where he led conservative opposition to civil rights legislation, died yesterday at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 93 years old.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1976

title: Article 1  No Title
HEAD OF I.M.F. URGES HALT TO BORROWING TO COVER DEFICITS
description: MANILA, Monday, October 4  The time has come for nations, both rich and poor, to stop borrowing so much to cover their balance of payments deficits and start eliminating the deficits, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund said today.

title: Kentucky G.O.P. Chief Backs Butz's Humor
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Oct. 3 (UPI)Larry Van Hoose, executive director of the Republican Party in Kentucky, said today that what America needs is a sense of humor and that Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz should not be forced to resign.

title: BuckleyMoynihan Contest Offers A ConservativeLiberal Showdown
Haven Logan Is Married to John Cottone Jr.
description: Haven Logan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harlan Logan of Meriden, N.H., was married yesterday at the Monk's Court, a restaurant in New York, to John Cottone Jr. of Beverly Hills, Calif., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cottone of Huntington, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Laurence Hamblen, who, like the bride, is an ordained minister with the Movement of Spiritual Inner Awareness.

title: Woman Excused From Saxe Jury Is Accused of Gambling in Boston
description: BOSTON, Oct. 4 (AP)A 24yearold woman excused last week as a juror in Susan Saxe's trial on charges of murder and armed robbery was arraigned today in the same courthouse on gambling charges.

title: GUNMEN IN SPAIN KILL HIGHRANKING BASQUE
description: MADRID, Oct. 4Gunmen assassinated a member of the Council of the Realm this afternoon and killed three bodyguards and a chauffeur in the northern Basque city of San Sebastin.

title: Hempstead Town Official Is Found Guilty of Lying To Kickback Grand Jury
Priest and Rabbi Exchange Charges On AntiCatholicism Among Jews
Economist Plans American Edition
description: The Economist, the British weekly that has aggressively been seeking new subscribers in the United States is now preparing to offer them to United States advertisers.

title: Barshai,Noted Soviet Conductor, Is Asking to Emigrate to Israel
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 4Rudolf Barshai, who created and now conducts the Soviet Union's most prominent chamber orchestra, has applied for emigration to Israel, according to sources in music circles. Last night he gave what may have been his final concert in Moscow.

title: Still to be Won
description: Despite the late Jim Farley's pretelevision dictum that voters in a Presidential campaign have their minds made up by Labor Day, the strong impression left by two weeks of travel in major electoral states from coast to coast is that the 1976 election is still to be won in the month remaining.

title: Tanner Tops Gottfried in Coast Final
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4 (UPI)Roscoe Tanner ended Brian Gottfried's streak tonight with a 46, 75, 61 victory in the final of the $125,000 Fireman's Fund international tennis tournament.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: MANILA, Oct. 4Even though there are no widespread expectations of noteworthy decisions from the annual joint meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the International sank for Reconstruction and Development here this week, the conclave has, as usual, drawn a blue ribbon audience from both the public and the private sectors of the financial world.

title: In the U.N. Today
Florida Ready to Proceed
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Captain Pleads in Fishing Case
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 4 (UPI) Capt. Hristo Popov of the Bulgarian stern trawler Ofelia pleaded not guilty today to a criminal charge of fishing inside the United States 12mile limit, an offense which could send him to jail as well as result in confiscation of his vessel. United States Magistrate George Juba said he would set a nonjury trial for later this week. The 274foot Ofelia was seized Sept. 26 for allegedly fishing 11.4 miles off the Oregon coast.

title: BUTZ QUITS UNDER FIRE AMID RISING PROTESTS ABOUT RACIST REMARK
Film Fete: Memory of Justice
Candidate in Suffolk Says Pro Bumper Stickers Are Really a Con Game
description: ISLIP, L.I., Oct. 4 (UPI)The bumper stickers read For the Sake of Islip Town . . . Keep Supervisior Cohalan. Islip Town Supervisor Peter Cohalan might normally regard the stickers, despite the bad spelling, as a compliment to his administration, but he took an opposite view today since he is the RepublicanConservative candidate for Representative from Suffolk County's Second Congressional District.

title: EXTRA AID IS DENIED 70,000 AGED, DISABLED
description: Seventy thousand of 390,000 New York State aged, blind and disabled poor in the Supplemental Security Income program failed to get the costofliving increases many of them had expected last Friday, according to Federal estimates yesterday.

title: Fire Kills Mother and 4 Children
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 4 (AP)A fire, apparently started by a cigarette dropped on the sofa, swept through an apartment here yesterday, killing a 42yearold mother and her four children. Firemen said the blaze had blocked all exits on the upper floor of the fourstory brick building. Witnesses said they saw the victims at the bedroom window, screaming for help.

title: 2 Hold Up Staten Island Bank
description: Two men armed with pistols held up the Northfield Savings Bank at 1731 Victory Boulevard in the Westerleigh section of Staten Island yesterday morning, according to the police, and escaped with $2,300. The bank's manager, Elsa Nelsen, said that an accounting later had found that about $1,500 had actually been taken. A correction officer who had been in the bank at the time of the holdup pursued the thieves, who escaped.

title: Maine Municipalities in Turmoil Over Land Suit Filed by Indians
description: MILLINOCKET Me., Oct. 4 Michael T. Lachance, the Town Manager of Millinocket, expects a cash settlement of an old suit filed by Maine Indians seeking twothirds of the land in the state.

title: CARTER SCORES FORD ON ECONOMIC POLICY
Dr. Alfred E. Emerson, 79, Expert On Social Behavior of Termites
description: Dr. Alfred E. Emerson, an international authority on the classification and social behavior of termites, died Sunday of a heart attack at Glens Falls (N. Y.) Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Huletts Landing on Lake George.

title: SANYO SETS ACCORD FOR WHIRLPOOL UNIT
description: The Whirlpool Corporation of Benton Harbor. Mich.. and the Sanyo Electric Company of Osaka. Japan. said yesterday that they had entered into a definite agreement for Sanyo to acquire the controlling interest in the television business of Warwick Electronics Inc., a 57 percentowned subsidiary of Whirlpool. Under the agreement, a new Warwick subsidiary, the Sanyo Manufacturing Corporation, would acquire Warwick's TV business with the new unit's stock spun off to Warwick shareholders on a share for share basis. Whirlpool's interest in the company will he valued at $10.3 :million, or $4.16 a share, while Sanyo will also offer to purchase the stock interest of all other Warwick stockholders, except for the 25 percent held by Sears Roebuck and Company. on the basis of $4.43 a share, as previously announced.

title: Smaller Nations Find U.N. Membership Brings Benefits, Despite High Costs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4President James Mancham of the Seychelles says he is happy that his Indian Ocean republic has joined the world organization even though the costs are high for his nation of 60,000 and his delegation was bombed out of its New York hotel by explosives intended for another target.

title: In Magdalany Play,Boo Hoo, The Subject Is Friendship
AsianAmerican Voters Play Growing Role in Carter Drive
Summary of Various Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Supreme Court, opening its 197677 term, took. the following actions today:

title: G.M. Plans '77 Output for 2 Vans
description: PONTIAC. Mich., Oct. 4 (AP)The General Motors Corporation's Truck & Coach division said today that it would begin production of two General Motors van models at the G.M.C. facilities here starting next year. Robert W. Truxell, a G.M. vice president and general manager of the G.M.C. division, said about 1,800 new jobs could be added to the division's current employment of 12,600 workers in Pontiac.

title: REPORT ON 2 DEATHS CRITICIZES HOSPITAL
Warner Communications Completes Atari Takeover
description: Warner Communications Inc. reported yesterday the acquisition of all common and preferred stock of the privately owned Atari Inc., for a total of $28 million in cash and debt. Atari applies advanced semiconductor technology to consumer products and is a leading producer of coinoperated video games and consumer video games.

title: MIDWEST FARMERS REGRET BUTZ MOVE
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4Farmers in the pivotal grain and livestock states of the Midwest, who usually vote Republican, were not surprised today when the Secretary of Agriculture, Earl L. Butz resigned, and many thought President Ford had no alternative but to accept the resignation.

title: The Making of a Democratic Senate Candidate
description: After Daniel P. Moynihan announced that he would not run for United States Senator from New York, Joseph F. Crangle, the Democratic leader of Erie County, wrote him a letter. I said that if and when the Holy Spirit came and enlightened him, Mr. Crangle recalled with a smile, that I'd be most willing to help him.

title: Pretoria Denies Training Angolans
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 4 (Reuters)  Defense headquarters tonight denied claims made by the SouthWest African People's Organization that South; African forces were training guerrillas of the Westernbacked Angolan nationalist movement, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola.

title: Advertising
description: Have any of the advertisers who dropped Esquire from their schedules as a result of the last Simmons study looked at some of the direct marketing advertisers in the magazine and asked themselves, Do they know something that I don't know?

title: Ford Flies to California for Debate And to Start SixDay Campaign Trip
24 More Food Outlets Cited For Violations of Health Code
Market Place
description: While the Gray Tool Company has announced that 50 percent of its stock is in friendly hands enough to block control by Petrolane Inc.. Gray's ardent suitorGray, a Houstonbased oil service company, is nonetheless looking around for a marriage partner more to its liking.

title: A NEW DELHI NEWSPAPER PADLOCKED BY THE POLICE
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 4 (AP)Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government, locked in a battle with India's largest newspaper chain, sent armed policemen to the offices of The Indian Express today and padlocked its presses.

title: Body of Girl, 17, Who Vanished In July Is Found
description: JOHNSTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 4 (UPI)Two men were held without hail in Fulton County jail today on charges of having kidnapped a teenaged girl whose body was found during the weekend. The police said she had been murdered.

title: Review of McCarthy Petitions is Begun by New York Elections Board
18 Reporters Begin Joint Inquiry Into Arizona Crime
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 2Eighteen reporters from 15 newspapers have begun an unusual experiment in group journalism a joint investigation of crime and corruption in Arizona, the nation's fastestgrowing state.

title: Miami Editor Named
description: MIAMI, Oct. 4 (UPI)John McMullan has been named executive editor of The Miami Herald, succeeding Larry Jinks, who will become editor, of The San Jose Mercury and News, KnightRidder Newspapers Inc. announced today. Mr. McMullan, 55 years old, a KnightRidder corporate vice president for the past four years, was executive editor and vice president of The Philadelphia Inquirer from 1970 to 1972.

title: DR. GABRIEL F. CUCOLO, 58, SURGEON AND EDUCATOR
description: Dr. Gabriel F. Cucolo, director of surgery and medical education at the Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home at 110 84th Street in the Bay Ridge section. He was 58 years old.

title: Books of the Times
Harlem News Service Is Planning To Survive by Going Commercial
description: Officials of the Harlembased Community News Service vowed yesterday to revive the orgiinization with an aggressive tundraising campaign and to try to turn the nonprofit service into a commercial news agency.

title: St. Francis of Assisi Church Honors Its Patron Saint
Hospital Fiasco
description: The embittered impasse that has developed between the Health and Hospitals Corporation and the State Health Department over the opening of the new North Central Bronx Hospital reflects the chaotic condition of health services administration and financing .in this city and, for that matter, in the state and nation.

title: Yanks Pick Hunter for Opener
Schmidt Victory Widely Hailed in Europe
description: BONN, Oct. 4The reelection of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Socialistliberal coalition was welcomed throughout Europe today, East and West, because governments almost always prefer the prospect of continued dealings withteams they know to dealing with new ones. Whether the reaction stressed Mr. Schmidt's sharply reduced majority or that he would remain in charge depended on domestic politics.

title: San Francisco's Cable Cars Romantic, but Costly to Run
Annoyer of Dole Is Accused
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 4 (AP)Brian McNellis, 23 years old, of Burlington, pleaded no contest today to a charge stemming from an incident during Senator Robert J. Dole's weekend campaign stop in Vermont. He was charged with a misdemeanor for allegedly tossing a crumpled paper cup in Mr. Dole's direction. The object did not strike the Senator. He was held today for further investigation.

title: P.L.O. OPENS TALKS ON ROLE IN LEBANON
Ukrainian Museum, Devoted to Folk Art, Opens on 2d Ave.
description: The Ukrainian Museum, New York's newest showcase for folk art, opened Sunday on two floors of an imaginatively remodeled tenement at 203 Second Avenue (at 13th Street).

title: Alaska Oil Pipeline Is Expected to Open on Schedule
description: PRUDHOE BAY, AlaskaFrom the look of things, the Alaska oil pipeline appears likely to open about on schedule next summer.

title: Trenton Topics
PRICES CONTINUE UP IN CREDIT MARKETS
Article 2  No Title
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4President James Mancham of the Seychelles says he is happy that his Indian Ocean republic has joined the world organization even though the costs are high for his nation of 60,000 and his delegation was bombed out of its New York hotel by explosives intended for another target.

title: Congress Gave U.S. Authorization To Ratify New Rules for I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  Congress passed legislation in its waning hours last week that authorizes the United States to ratify new International Monetary Fund rules formally sanctioning floating exchange rates and raising this country's backing for the agency by about $2 billion.

title: Argentina Confirms Attack on President
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 4 (AP)The Argentine Army today confirmed an apparent attack over the weekend on the life of President Jorge Rafael Videla.

title: 2 Key Trgdeau Programs Opposed By Western Provinces in Canada
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 4Two of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's key programs have been jolted by opposition from the West, where suspicion of Ottawa is a political tradition.

title: Bridge:
description: Perhaps eight of every nine players are happy to play rubber bridge or fourdeal bridge in the privacy of their homes. It is, however, the conspicuous oneninth of duplicate players, the tip of the iceberg, that receive most of the attention from writers on the game. The large mass below the surface is generally neglected.

title: Carey Replaces Economic Panel, Reportedly to End Release of Proposals Before Political Effect Is Weighed
U.S. Voices Regret in Shooting
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (Reuters)The United States has expressed deep regrets to the Soviet Union over the shooting of an embassy employee here. Sergei Stepanov, 59, a building maintenance official, was shot outside a grocery store on Saturday by an unknown assailant who had attempted to rob the store. The Russian is in a hospital in serious condition.

title: We Cut, You Cut
description: WASHINGTONIn the spring of 1964, there was a tokensized United Stales troop withdrawal from Europe, a littlenoticed and seemingly isolated event.

title: Orchestras and Their Musicians Negotiate in Fights for Existence
description: The expired union contract, an irritation that periodically afflicts American cultural institutions like the boils of Job, is again causing problems for the New York City Opera and the New York Philharmonic.

title: Taxes &
Indians Sign Robinson To a Managerial Pact
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 4 (AP)Frank Robinson was rehired today as manager of the Cleveland Indians despite disappointment in this season's performance on the part of both Robinson and Phil Seghi, the Indians general manager.

title: RAYMOND H. HERING, 62, OF TRAVEL AGENTS SOCIETY
description: Raymond H. Hering, executive vice president for industry relations of the American Society of Travel Agents, an international organization with head%quarters at 711 Fifth Avenue, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Rockville Centre, L.. I. He was 62 years old.

title: GreekAmerican Journalist Gets 15 Months, in Absentia, in Athens
description: ATHENS, Oct. 4 (Reuters)A GreekAmerican journalist was sentenced to 15 months imprisonment in his absence today for asserting that an Athens Englishlanguage newspaper was on the payroll of the Soviet intelligence service, the K.G.B.

title: Pat Boone Is Surprised That Butz Had to Quit
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 4 (AP)Pat Boone, the singer, who along with John W. Dean 3d heard the remarks that led to Earl L. Butz's resignation, said today: I just can't get it into my head that a Cabinet man can tell a bad joke in private and get fired, and then John Dean can tell the same joke to millions and get paid for it.

title: DR. ROBERT STONE GRINNELL
description: Dr. Robert Stone Grinnell, a retired surgeon on the staff of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and an assistant professor of clinical surgery, died Sunday in Barnstable (Mass.) County Hospital after a brief illness. He was 84 years old and lived at 1158 Fifth Avenue in New York City.

title: Agriculture School for Vietnam
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, Oct. 4 (AP)Vietnam has abolished the schools of art, law and general science at the University of Can Tho in the Mekong Delta area south of Saigon and turned it into a university of agriculture, the Hanoi radio said today.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: 4 Hospitals Facing Intern Strike Today
description: A group of interns and residents, demanding reinstatement as bargaining agent for hospital staff physicians, pressed forward with plans for a strike against four voluntary hospitals at 7 A.M. today despite lastminute defections by the resident staffs at six other voluntary institutions.

title: Boy Scouts Doing a Good Deed for Jersey
Sensational, 101, Steals Show From Mrs. Warren in Frizette
description: Mrs. Warren's coronation as queen of thoroughbred racing's 2yearold fillies will have to await further deliberations.

title: Marshall Resumes Supreme Court Work
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall, who was hospitalized last July 4 after what doctors described as a mild heart attack, was on the bench today as the Court began its new term.

title: STEEL OUTPUT IN WEEK OFF TO 2.33 MILLION TONS
description: Domestic steel production for the week ended Oct. 2 fell 2.1 percent lower than in the preceding week, dropping total output to 2.33 million tons, its lowest level since the week ended Feb. 7 when only 2.29 million tons were poured.

title: Dole Calls Carter Frightening on Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican VicePresidential candidate, asserted today that Jimmy Carter was downright frightening in some of his pronouncements on foreign and defense policies.

title: A Helping Hand for the Uneasy Shopper
EXRACEWAY HEAD LOSES SUPREME COURT APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)  Leon Greenberg, a former president of the Monticello Raceway, (N.Y.) lost a bid, today for Supreme Court review of his conviction for conspiracy and mail fraud stemming from what the Government said was a scheme to defraud the raceway.

title: Plans for Saudi Takeover of Aramco Due
Times and News Meet With Union
NEW YORK POLICE SET NEW PROTESTS TODAY
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and New York City remained at loggerheads yesterday in their dispute over working conditions and back pay, and the head of the union said that demonstrations would resume at 11:30 A.M. today with the wives and children of police officers picketing City Hall.

title: Article 4  No Title
Mark and Swiss Franc Decline Against Dollar
description: LONDON, Oct. 4 (AP) The dollar fluctuated against European currencies today, gaining against the mark and the Swiss francthe two strongest continental currenciesand easing against others.

title: KALLINGER RECALLED AS KIND OF WEIRD
description: HACKENSACK, Oct. 4A former employer of Joseph Kallinger testified today that the Philadelphia shoe repair man was known as Crazy Joe at least a decade ago.

title: Protests Snag Transit Service
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 (UPI)Ahout 100 demonstrators, protesting cutbacks transit service, picketed two garages this morning, crippling bus and trolley service for more than 100,000 rushhour commuters and school children. Transit officials. obtained a temporary restraining order in Common Pleas Court shortly before 7 A.M., but delays in filing the order and reading it to demonstrators kept the vehicles inside for most of the rushhour period.

title: Issue and Debate
description: On Sunday, Oct. 17, the second game of the 1976 World Series will be played at night, the first time a weekend World Series game has been scheduled for what television people call prime time. Weekday World Series games have been played at night since 1971, and this year some of the league championship playoff games also will be played and televised at night.

title: After Trial and Error, These Pioneers Thrive in the West
description: COSTA MESA, Calif.When Betty Weintraub married Eric Young three years ago in Brooklyn's Chimes restaurant, she made him promise her that she was not going to live and die in Brooklyn.

title: British and U.S. Envoys Meet Rhodesia's Premier.
Squeaker in Germany
description: A conservative tide was running in West Germany but it was not powerful enough in Sunday's election to dislodge Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and his coalition of Social and Free Democrats. In his first campaign at the Federal level, Helmut Kohl, Governor of the Rhineland Palatinate, led the Christian Union opposition back to its old position as the country's leading political force but finished about two percentage points behind the Government tandem.

title: Soybean, Wheat and Corn Prices Up
Alaska Oil Pipeline Is Expected to Open on Schedule
Rangers Beat New Haven In Final Exhibition, 52
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 4 (AP)The New York Rangers, in their final tuneup before the start of the National Hockey League season, got a pair of goals from Wayne Dillon tonight as they beat their American Hockey League farm club, the New Haven Nighthawks, 52. The Rangers open their regular season Wednesday.

title: Mass Flu Inoculations Start This Month in City Area
Sudan Closes Off Area in South Reporting Unidentified Disease
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Oct. 4 (AP)Sudanese authorities have barred movement into the southern Sudan and closed off the Maridi area in western Equatoria Province because of a mysterious contagious disease in the area.

title: Soweto Traffic Men, All Black, Are Withdrawn After Threats
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 4 (Reuters)All 40 traffic policemen have been withdrawn from the Soweto black township here after repeated threats against them by black youths, a police spokesman said today.

title: Richard J. Burke, 66, an Attorney Who Was U.S. Prosecutor's Aide
description: Richard J. Burke, who in the early 1940's was chief of the criminal division of the office of United States Attorney for the Southern District in New York and later the founding partner of a Manhattan law firm, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Pelham Manor, N. Y. He was 66 years old.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1976

title: Social Security Recipients Find Checkless Society Has Problems
description: WASHINGTONIn recent weeks, nearly 1,000 letters have poured into a small House of Representatives committee office here, all concerned with an innovation that allows senior citizens to have their Social Security checks deposited directly into their bank accounts.

title: Indicted Lefkowitz Aide Is Said to Have Thrown Christmas Party With Predecessor's Leftover Bribe Money
Presbyterian Church Reducing Staff at National Headquarters Here
description: Twentyeight persons  five middleechelon executives and 23 secretarieshave been dismissed by the national headquarters here of the 2.6millionmember United Presbyterian Church.

title: U.S. Publishers Are Cool to Soviet Exhibit Bid
United Nuclear Contract
Fleeing Suspect Who Injured 2 Shot by Police
Contrasts Evident in JapaneseSoviet Movie
Chess:
description: Although the striking power of the bishop pair was recognized by the brilliant American strategist Louis Paulsen in the mid1850's, there are still games in which only one of the antagonists appreciates Paulsen's insight.

title: SIMON SAYS NATIONS CONSUMING OIL FACE $50 BILLION DEFICIT
description: MANILA, Tuesday, Oct. 5 Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon told the finance ministers of more than 100 oilimporting nations today that they faced a massive balance of payments deficit of about $50 billion next year as a counterpart of a renewed increase in the surplus of the oilproducing countries.

title: Court Rules Virginia Localities Can Sign Pacts With Employees
description: ARLINGTON, Va. Oct. 4 (AP)A Circuit Court judge struck down today Virginia's contention that its local governments cannot legally sign collective bargaining agreements with public employees.

title: West Side Woman Is Found Dead In Bed, 2 Pillows Over Her Face
description: A 40yearold woman who had gone home Saturday to her West 71st Street apartment to recover from an operation on her broken hip was found dead there last night, with two pillows pressed over her face.

title: KEITH EDWARD BULLEN
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 4Keith Edward Bullen, a prominent seismologist, has died in New Zealand at the age of 70, his family announced here today. Long a professor of applied mathematics at the University of Sydney, Dr. Bullen served in the mid1950's as president of the International Association of Seismology and Physics of the Interior of the Earth.

title: Buckley Urges Tax Relief Program
Joseph Memorial Service Slated
description: A memorial service for Richard Joseph, a travel writer, will be held at. 5:30 P.M. Thursday in the United Nations chapel, 777 United Nations Plaza. Mr. Joseph died Thursday at the age of 66.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: RADIO LIBERTY IS MERGED WITH RADIO FREE EUROPE
description: Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, two United States Government networks that broadcast to Sovietbloc countries, were formally merged last week to form a new corporation, RFE/RL Inc.

title: Schmidt Acts to Bolster Coalition
OLIVER TROSTER DIES
description: Col. Oliver J. Troster, a leader of the overthecounter securities trading business, died last Saturday at Champaign, Ill., at the age of 82. Col. Troster, who was a member of the University of Illinois Foundation, the school's fundraising body, was in Champaign for a meeting of that group.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LIKE IT IS the documentary is a film form that can be as infinitely varied and often more intriguing than the fiction film. What's Happening? is a series of new, controversial documentaries by independent film makers that, starting today, will be shown Tuesdays at the New York Public Library's Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street, and at the Museum of Modern Art, right across the street at No. 11.

title: Exit Mr. Butz
description: When New Times magazine identified Earl Butz as the source of some crude and racist remarks, a White House spokesman announced that President Ford had reprimanded his Secretary of Agriculture severely. When a storm of protest broke over Mr. Butt's head, the White House said the President was waiting for the dust to settle before taking action. When the storm grew, Mr. Ford became totally inaccessible to the press.

title: People in Sports
description: John Havlicek, star forward of the Boston Celtics and fourthhighest scorer in the history of the National Basketball Association, agreed yesterday to a oneyear contract with the club and reported to its training camp at the Massachusetts Maritime Academy. The 36yearold Havlicek, veteran of 14 seasons with Boston, had stayed away from the training camp while negotiating the contract and had reportedly wanted a twoyear agreement to succeed his $250,000ayear pact. The terms of the new contract, other than its duration, were not announced.

title: Article 1  No Title
Democratic Party's Financial Problems Arousing Anxiety and Causing Salary Cuts
Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI)The Food and Drug Administration today closed the door on the sevenyearold cyclamate controversy, ruling that the artificial sweetener is too dangerous to be allowed back on the market.

title: The Halftime Summary
description: At the halfway point in the Presidential campaign, here is the balance sheet on how the candidates stand:

title: Texts of Butz Statement and Letter and Ford's Reply
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  Following are the texts of a statement by Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, who resigned today: of a letter from Mr. Butz to President Ford, and of Mr. Ford's reply:

title: California Financial Corp. Consider Merger Proposals
description: The California Financial Corporation said yesterday that it was continuing to consider a number of proposals to acquire most of its assets, based on a price of $7 to $10 a share for its stockholders. In line with that announcement, the United Financial Corporation said that it had increased the offer of $8.50 a share that it made in January to $10, which would amount to a total of about $63.5 million.

title: Acting Secretary of Agriculture
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  After six years as a Government lawyeron Capitol Hill, with the Small Business Administration and the Department of AgricultureJohn Albert Knebel decided last year that he had had enough and he was going to return to a more lucrative life as a private lawyer in Washington. But today, his 40th birthday, Mr. Knebel received a call from the White House and he is now running the Department of Agriculture as its Acting Secretary.

title: TV: Crusty Harry S. Truman: Plain Speaking
description: The speaker is no crackpot on a street corner soapbox. He is Harry S. Truman, addressing his colleagues in the Senate in December 1937:

title: Kennecott Uncertain Over Delay in Peabody Sale
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation said that it did not know if the sudden withdrawal of Texasgulf Inc. from a group seeking to acquire the peahocly Coal Company, a Kennecott subsidiary, would cause a delay in a special hoard of directors meeting scheduled for the next several weeks to vote on the proposals.

title: Revlon Admits Big Payments Made Overseas
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Revlon Inc. has admitted making substantial amounts of questionable payments overseas, inchiding $19,000 that was distributed in an unidentified country after its Government publicly denounced such payments.

title: Article 3  No Title
Socialist Leader in India Appears In Court, Handcuffed but Defiant
Right to Die
description: California's Gov. Edmund Brown Jr. has signed into law the nation's first right to die measure. It provides that a patient who has made his desire known previously under a socalled living will may have lifesupport equipment, such as respirators, shut off if his death imminent. The new law protects doctors who act in accordance with such instructions, and it deprives insurance companies of the right to treat such a death as suicide.

title: A.&P. Net in 2d Quarter and Half Climbs Sharply as Sales Increase
A Study of Malpractice Deaths Reported Ended Without Action
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 (AP)A mortality survey committee of city doctors spent eight years reviewing hospital deaths caused by alleged malpractice but kept no records and took no disciplinary action, according to the Philadelphia medical examiner.

title: $83.6 Million Yonkers Bond Sale Ends a Year of Fiscal Uncertainty
description: YONKERS, Oct. 4Yonkers ended a year of fiscal uncertainty today with the announcement that it had sold $83.6 million in shortterm and longterm bonds.

title: STAFFORD L. LAMBERT
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 (UPI)Stafford L. Lambert. an aviation pioneer, died yesterday in a hospital in Woodruff, Wis.. after suffering a heart attack at his summer home near Minocqua, Wis.

title: ASSASSINATION PANEL NAMES TOP COUNSEL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Richard A. Sprague. who led the investigation that finally brought the arrest and murder conviction of W. A. Boyle, the deposed head of the United Mine Workers Union, has agreed to head a new Congressional examination of the assassinations of President Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Rail Rate Rise Asked For West and South
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 4 (UPI)Western and southern railroads agreed today to ask for a 4 percent acrosstheboard freight rate increase, to be effective Jan. 1.

title: Viola Carew, 85, Long Active In S.I. Community Affairs, Dies
description: Viola M. Carew, who was cochairman of Staten Island's Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in World War II, and active for many years in Staten Island's community affairs, died Sunday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N. J., at the age of 85. She lived in Rossmoor, a retirement community in Jamesburg, N. J., to which she moved in 1968 from Staten Island.

title: People and Business
description: Marshall S. Armstrong, chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board. expressed concern yesterday that the cries of alarmists will prevent others from fairly and objectively evaluating the issues Involved in the board's longawaited discussion memorandum on the objectives of financial accounting. In a speech at the Detroit Economic Club, Mr. Armstrong said the board, the private sector's top rulemaking body in accounting, intended to publish the document, a severalhundredpage tome, next month.

title: Dave Anderson
Uruguay's Military Leaders Angry Over Congressional Cutoff on Aid for Arms
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 29 Uruguay's military leaders have reacted with indignation to the recent ban by the United States Congress on further military aid to their Government, which is accused of systematic violations of human rights.

title: Lawyers for N.A.A.C.P. Request $1 Million in Fees from Memphis
RickshaWallahs in Bangladesh: Torturous Life at 5 Cents a Mile
The Making of a Democratic Senate Candidate
FORD TO OFFER PLAN ON NUCLEAR EXPORT
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 4President Ford is expected to propose within the next 10 days a plan to tighten control of the worldwide use of certain kinds of nuclear power equipment and material that can also be used to make atomic bombs.

title: Essential Oil Exports Studied in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 4Indonesia has begun an investigation to determine whether a local export company may have defrauded American and European importers of more than $1 million on sales of essential oils.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: William R. Phillips, 42 years old, of North Cape May, a master on the Cape MayLewes, Del., ferry, pleaded guilty to negligence before a Coast Guard administrative judge in Philadelphia. The charge was filed as a result of a Sept. 10 sideswiping of his ferry, the New Jersey, with the ferry Delaware. Judge Francis X. J. Coughlin withheld action on the plea pending a hearing of a similar negligence charge against James J. Gormley, 61, of Atlantic City, the master of the Delaware. According to the Coast Guard, damage in the collision, which occurred in Delaware Bay, was slight and some 265 passengers aboard the two $4 million ferries escaped injury. Mr. Phillips faces either revocation of his license or a temporary suspension, or an administrative action of negligence, which would simply be marked on his record.

title: Israeli Forces Seem Strong, and Military's Optimism Gains
Prayda Accuses Japan of Delay In Resolving the MIG25 Affair
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 4 (Reuters)Moscow today condemned Japanese delays in returning a topsecret MIG25 jet fighter that was flown to Japan a month ago by a defecting Soviet Air Force pilot.

title: U.S. AIDES SEE SHIFT IN SOVIET ATOM BID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Senior United States officials said today that they were giving serious attention to a new, unexpected Soviet proposal that could open, the way to negotiations for a total ban on underground nuclear explosions.

title: Messages for Yom Kippur Urge A Rededication to Moral Values

description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 4 (UPI)A man who ordained a black man to the Mormon priesthood in defiance of church doctrine was barred from the church's, semiannual conference yesterday under a court order.

title: Braun of Twins Signs, Leaving 28 Free Agents
description: Steve Braun withdrew from the freeagent draft and signed a 1976 contract with the Minnesota Twins Sunday night just before he would have ended his six years with the team. It reduced the draft pool to 28 players.

title: Nyerere
description: Some years hack I worked for a year in a small communal farm in the south of Tanzania. From time to time, the President of the country, Julius K. Nyerere, would come down to see the progress of the villagers, to talk to them about their work, to discuss plans to build the nation.

title: UNREST IS GROWING IN TURKEY'S UNIONS

Ford and Jimmy Carter for 27 minutes, according to Jack Kelly, CBS producer in charge of Wednesday night's debate. He said yesterday that he had no doubt that the debate at the Palace of Fine Arts Theater would come off without a technical hitch.

title: Gurney Trial Put Off Until Oct. 12
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 4 (AP)The perjury teal cf former Senator Edward Gurney has been postponed until Oct. 12 by Federal District Judge George C. Young. Mr. Gurney, 62 years old, a Republican from Winter Park, is charged with lying to a grand jury when he denied knowing until June of 1972 that a fund raiser was collecting money for him by allegedly pressuring building contractors in Florida.

title: Canto Keeps Ring Title
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 4 (AP)Miguel Canto of Mexico, World Boxing Council flyweight champion, retained his title last night on a split 15round decision over Venezuela's Betulio Gonzalez.

title: A REPORT BY TREASURY SEES GOLD PRICE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI)The price of goldstripped of inflationwill probably rise over the next decade if the Government does not increase the volume of its gold sales, according to a Treasury Department report.

title: Modest Recovery in the Economy Linked to Rise in Government Jobs
description: A labor union analysis has reported that the nation's modest economic recovery resulted primarily from massive increases in government jobs rather than from jobs in the socalled free market.

title: 350 in Queens Jail, Protesting Delays, Stay Out of Cells
description: In a nonviolent protest against court delays and bail provisions, more than 350 inmates awaiting trial at the Queens House of Detention in Kew Gardens refused to he locked in their cells last night.

title: Taxes &
description: Shareholders in companies with subsidiaries in Mexico should brace themselves for sad news on thirdquarter earnings because of the 40 percent devaluation of the peso last Aug. 31. Page 70.

title: 4 Hospitals Facing Intern Strike Today
description: A group of interns and residents, demanding reinstatement as bargaining agent for hospital staff physicians, pressed forward with plans for a strike against four voluntary hospitals at 7 A.M. today despite lastminute defections by the resident staffs at six other voluntary institutions.

title: Justices Reject Review Requests In a Number of Civil Rights Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Requests for Supreme Court reviews of a number of civil rights caseswith issues including sex discrimination, racial bias in housing and racial and religious discrimination by a private clubwere turned down by the Justices today.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Justice Department prosecutors, having established the details of illegal burglaries carried out by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the New York City area, are beginning an inquiry into an effort by officials of the bureau to withhold knowledge of those burglaries from Congress.

title: SUPREME COURT ENDS DEATH PENALTY BAN IN CASES OF MURDER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its July 2 decision upholding the death penalty for murder and lifted the stay that has been blocking the states from putting that decision into effect.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)President Ford today signed a wideranging tax revision bill that eases the tax burden for individuals and businesses.

Spokesmen for the P.B.A. complain that their men are being treated like second class citizens because the Beame Administration insists that they give up some of the lavish fringe benefits they have acquired over the past decade in return for the rehiring of 400 laidoff officers and limitedthough still quite substantialpay increases.

description: New and simplified regulations for fresh and saltwater fishing are being proposed by the. New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, a concept, if wisely carried out, that will gladden the hearts of anglers.

title: Music: KC and Sunshine Band
description: KC and the Sunshine Band are representative of two phenomena in popular music. One is the tendency of the music to selfcorrect, reverting to simple. danceable good times whenever things get too pretentious. The other is the apparently greater ease With which white practitioners of black music (or, in this case, white bandleaders in basically black bands) attain and sustain national success than black artists.

title: Syria Steps Up Campaign Of Criticism of the P.L.O., But Hints at Settlement
Notes on People
description: President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France arrived in Teheran yesterday on a combination official visit and sales trip. He flew into the Iranian capital aboard a sample of one line of French wares for which he seeks a market, a Concorde supersonic jetliner.

title: ARABS ON WEST BANK QUESTION TREATMENT
description: HOLHOUL, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, ect. 4In the wake of the latest round of clashes between Arabs and Israelis in tense West Bank towns, Arab officials are asking an old question with renewed vigor: Does the occupying Israeli Government render the same treatment to Arabs as to Jews?

title: Mass Flu Inoculations Will Begin Today in Some of State's Centers
Romano Is Lauded as Pitt's Defensive Star
description: An outstanding middle guard on defense will usually get the best of an outstanding offensive center, according to Johnny Majors, the Pittsburgh coach. That was one of many aspects of undefeated Pitt's 4431 victory over Duke last Saturday that satisfied this Tennessee country gentleman. The Panthers' middle guard, Al Romano, outmaneuvered Duke's strong center, Billy Bryan, most of the time.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 AP()The nearcollision of two large passenger planes near Spokane International Airport last April 1 was caused by inadequate local air traffic control procedures, a Federal accident investigating agency said today.

description: Profit taking depressed cocoa futures contracts on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. The December contract dropped the daily limit of 2 cents a pound to close at $1.17.

title: Randy Jones Faces Arm Operation
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct, 5 (AP)The future of Randy Jones, the National League's top winning pitcher in 1976, was a question mark today with the discovery of a detached bicep tendon in his pitching arm. The San Diego Padres star lefthander, who posted a 2214 wonlost record this season, will undergo surgery Thursday.

description: DACCA, Bangladesh  The sluggish brown waters of the Ganges, which flow from India through Bangladesh and into the Bay of Bengal, have become the focus of a bitter political dispute between the two South Asian neighbors, as they were between India and Pakistan.

title: At Least 15 Die in Thailand as Police Raid Campus in Political Dispute
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, Wednesday, Oct. 6 (AP)Thai policemen firing machine guns; grenades and antitank weapons stormed a university campus today where several thousand students were demonstrating against the presence in Thailand of the former military ruler, Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn.
