description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5President Ford and Jimmy Carter will address a number of foreign policy and defense issues in their televised debate tomorrow night. Following is a rundown of some of the issues likely to be raised and some points for viewers to look for in the discussion.

It is an embalming, though an elegant and sometimes a funny one.

description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 5 (UPI)Officials today reported 39 dead in a coalmine explosion 200 miles northwest of Calcutta. Officials said three more bodies were taken from the Sudamdih mine near Dhanhad today. First reports had said 36 miners were killed and 28 injured.

title: Advertising
description: James Whitmore, the actor, is starring in a new film that you'll never see unless you're in position to buy duplicating equipment for your corporation.

title: HOSPITALS PROJECT $75 MILLION DEFICIT
Books of the Times
description: In his introduction to American Talk: Where our Words Came from, the linguistics specialist J. L. Dillard describes his latest book as part of a continuing effort to determine the origins and influences on the language spoken in the United States of America. But to this reader of Professor Dillard's earlier books, Black English: Its History and USage in the United States (1972) and AllAmerican English: A History of the English Language in America (1974), his new book seems more a diminishing effort than continuing one. For where in his earlier books Professor Dillard developed and illustrated a thesis of major significancenamely, that American English is not the corrupted version of British English that dialectologists argue it is, but rather a language that has continued to be transformed throughout American history by contact with tongues that British English never encountered in its native milieu in American Talk, Mr. Dillard has not provided much hi the way of either illustration or thesis.

title: Immigration Agency Investigates 9 Suspected as Nazis
description: The former police commander of Naziheld Croatia, who is now living in California, and five other Eastern European immigrants here who are accused of wartime atrocities, are reported to be among nine leading suspected Nazi war criminals under investigation by United States Immigration authorities.

title: Stocks Off 11 Points On Economic Fears
Uncertainty in France
description: Inflation at home and recurrent devaluation of the franc abroad are the price France has paid since World War II for full employment and the stimulation of a high growth rate, one of the highest in West Europe.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5Earl L. Butz, who resigned yesterday as Secretary of Agriculture, will keep a still undetermined number of his campaign commitments, with his next appearance now planned for this Friday night in Mississippi.

description: TRENTON, Oct. 5Governor Byrne today signed into law a bill creating a separate Department of Corrections to run the New Jersey prison system, and said he planned to name Robert E. Mulcahy 3d to run the department.

description: COMMERCE. Tex., Oct. 5 (AP)Terry Dean Allen, a freshman basketball player at East Texas State University, died of cardiac arrest after being stricken during a practice session yesterday..

It is the first time that the team, honoring their captain from 1965 through 1974, will retire a player's number.

description: ST. CLAIR, Mich., Oct. 5 (UPI)Miss U. S., the winning hydroplane in last summer's gold cup race on the Detroit River, flipped over and disintegrated today during a high speed test run on the St. Clair river. The driver, Dave Irwin, suffered stomach and back injuries, and was reported in fairtogood condition.

title: Takeover and Merger For Chirurg &
description: An agreement has been reached for the acquisition for cash of Chirurg & Cairns's New York operation by Leber Katz Partners. At the same time another agreement has been reached for the merger of the Boston and Hartford offices of Chirurg & Cairns and Provandie, Eastwood & Lombardi of Boston to become Provandie & Chirurg.

title: About New York
Woman, 19, Abducted Last Month, Flies to the U.S. From Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 5 (AP) An American woman abducted from her home last month flew to the United States last night. The United States Embassy said Argentine authorities placed Patricia Ann Erb, 19 years old, aboard a commercial jetliner bound for Miami.

description: DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 5American men's and women's volleyball teams were soundly trounced by visiting teams from China today at the beginning of an 11day United States tour.

title: Jade Prince, 2YearOld Pacer, Betters World Mark
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 5 (AP)Jade Prince, a 2yearold son of Meadow Skipper, raced the fastest mile in a race in harnessracing history today, timed in 1:54 1/5 in the second heat of the $62,755 Fayette Pace at the RedMile. Driven by Jack Kopas of London, Ontario, Jade Prince had won the first heat in 1:55 1/5 before setting the world record. The previous mark of 1:54 3/5 was set. by Albatross as a 4yearold in 1972 at Sportsmen's Park, outside Chicago, and equaled by Tauros Bomber as a 3yearold earlier this year at Springfield, Ill.

title: Many Nations Cite Currency Problems at I.M. F. Meeting
description: MANILA, Oct. 5 While none of the industrialized countries here at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund has urged a return to the old system of fixed currency exchange rates, a number of them today and yesterday have expressed forcefully for the first time some of the serious problems posed for them by floating rates.

description: AURAL Tonight at 6 o'clock, two literary figures  Ishmael Reed the poet and novelist, and Victor Hernandez Cruz, the poetwill read from their works at the College of Staten Island in Richmond Hall at 130 Stuyvesant Place on the St. George campus. There will also be a panel discussion of contemporary American literature. Panelists are faculty members: William Demby, Bertha Harris, Herbert Leibowitz and Edward Morgolies. Quincy Troupe; also a faculty member and coeditor of Giant Talk, an anthology of third world writings, will moderate. For information, call 7203090. There is no admission charge.

Heavens, the Irish's leading rusher as a freshman a year ago with 756 yards and the leading ground gainer with 204 yards this year, had surgery yesterday to remove torn cartilage in his right knee.

description: HACKENSACK, Oct. 5Two of Joseph Kallinger's children testified at his murder trial today that their father kept a torture chamber in their basement to punish them and their brothers whenever an itch in his hand told him they had misbehaved.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Striking inmates at the Queens House of Detention continued to debate last night. whether to end their onedayold protest. Like other protests in tht city's jails in the last month, the nonviolent strike at. the Queens jail. involving a refusal to be locked in cells or appear in court, was directed mostly at the court system, not at jail conditions. Many of the inmates demandsfor example, one calling for the repeal of the state's drug lawrequire legislative action.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5, (AP)Pan American World Airways has won approval from the Civil Aeronautics Board to transport passengers between Detroit and Boston, marking its first entry into domestic service.

title: Aide Named for Ford in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 5 (UPI)Don Lenz of Farmington has been appointed .field supervisor of President Ford's Connecticut campaign, it was announced today. Mr. Lenz lost a bid this summer for the Republican nomination to the state House of Representatives. He has been a legislative assistant to the Republican leadership in the Connecticut House and serves on the Farmington Republican Town Committee.

title: South African Economy Held Unaffected by Black Rioting

Oppenheimer, head of the largest industrial empire in South Africa, said today that four months of often violent protest by blacks there had not severely affected the South African economy and business. The months of dissent, however, have changed the thinking of many business leaders, who now want changes that would lead to the elimination of apartheid, he said.

title: Israeli Court Backs Journalist
description: TEL AVIV, Oct 5 (Reuters)An Israeli judge today upheld a journalist's right to refuse to divulge his sources of information, and ruled that this was an inherent characteristic of a democratic society. The magistrate. Israel Cannel, refused to order the accused in a libel case, Yosef Yanai, a reporter for the Israeli weekly Haolam Hazeh, to divulge the sources for his article on the alleged use of drugs among pupils in a Tel Aviv school.

title: Italy's 'Illustrious Corpses,' Disappointing Film
description: More and more, Francesco Rosi, the Italian director of such politically conscious films as "Salvatore Giuliano," "Hands Upon the City" and the recent "The Mattei Affair," has come to construct his movies as if they were jig-saw puzzles from which key pieces must remain missing. This is not because he hasn't a very good idea what the missing pieces are, but because he thinks that to supply them would dampen the speculation he means to stir up.Sometimes, as in the case of "The Mattei Affair," this works. But then "The Mattei Affair" was based on the life of an Italian industrialist who died under circumstances that have never been satisfactorily explained. In the newest Rosi film, "Illustrious Corpses" ("Cadaveri Eccellenti"), the method is self-defeating. It stirs up not speculation but suspicions that the completed picture is artificially made more complex and provocative than its missing pieces would have revealed it to be.Until one realizes that one has been manipulated to rather predictable ends, "Illustrious Corpses" is a dazzling example of fashionably radical Italian film makingelegantly composed, breathlessly paced, photographed in the beautiful, drained colors of a landscape in mourning for the sun. It's all so beautiful, in fact, that when you see a long shot of a Sicilian piazza in which everything, including the sky, is the same matching beige, you wouldn't be at all surprised to see a high-fashion model, dressed to the scarlet nines, posing amid beige urchins.The setting of "Illustrious Corpses" seems to be Sicily, though it's never identified, which allows the director to create a fictitious capitalistic social-political structure that cannot be immediately criticized for not being accurately Italian. Wherever it is, corruption and conspiracies are rampant, the poor are getting poorer, the rich are getting richer and the paranoid power elite, when it isn't listening to wiretaps and watching movies made by hidden cameras, attends parties where there are women and food to enchant every tastebud.The film begins effectively enough. A prominent prosecutor is murdered. Several days later, a prominent judge is similarly assassinated. Later another judge, and another. The country is thrown into disorder. Inspector Rogas (Lino Ventura), a creased, tired policeman from a more conventional mystery melodrama, investigates and becomes convinced that a man, who was once wrongly convicted and sent to prison, is carrying out a campaign of revenge.The inspector's superiors, however, don't want to hear his evidence. More assassinations occur. The inspector then stumbles on a conspiracy that involves all of his superiors, who are apparently using one man's private vengeance to effect a plot involving the fate of the nation."Illustrious Corpses" is full of individually arresting details, such as a sequence shot in an ancient catacomb and a scene in which Max Von Sydow, as the mad chief justice, explains that when a judge "celebrates the law," he is like a priest celebrating mass and thus incapable of error. I particularly liked Alain Cuny as another rotten judge, a man completely, almost beatifically composed except for his wayward left hand. It keeps wanting to misbehave and has to be slapped in punishment.All of these arresting details and bizarre characters don't eventually add up to much more than an indictment of government that's so broad, so general, it has no particular force. The end effect is trivial. This is not to say that "Illustrious Corpses" is boring. Rather it's acutely disappointing. The art of so many people, including that of Mr. Rosi and his actors, has been lavishly spent on a knickknack."Illustrious Corpses" will be shown at the New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 9:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 6:15 P.M.

description: The New England Small College Athletic Conference has eleven member colleges, a group of apparently happy coaches, nothing but amateur players, no actual champion, and ideas about football's proper place in an academic setting. That May %seem strange to many bigtime college administrators. For instance, the coaches are forbidden to travel off campus for purposes of recruiting high school football players. Bob Odell, Williams College's head football coach, said, That's the only way to recruit. I've seen through the whole gamut. It's no fun recruiting by running all over the country. This has driven more men out of coaching than anything. Odell has coached at Wisconsin, Bucknell and Pennsylvania, where recruiting is a goandget'em, highpressure business at times.

title: BUCKLEY MOVE WINS PUBLIC TV AD TIME
description: Taking advantage of a section of the Federal Communications Act, Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, is forcing WNETTV and seven other public educational television stations in the state to run political commercials for the first time.

title: Iran's Oil Output Sets a Record
description: TEHERAN. Iran. Oct. 6 (UPI)Iran's crude oil production reached a record of 6.4 million barrels a day during September, according to official figures released today. The National Iranian Oil Company figures showed that the country's oil supplies were in heavy demand because of an expected 10 to 15 percent rise in the price cf oil by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries early next year.

title: Financier's Sister Is Killed in Maine
description: FALMOUTH. Me., Oct. 6Anne Payson Bolt, sister of Charles Shipman Payson, the financier and social leader, was shot late last night by intruders in the firstfloor bedroom of her shorefront estate at Falmouth Foreside. Mrs. Holt, who was 79 years old, died this morning at the Maine Medical Center, Portland.

title: Article 1  No Title
Nets Not Drawing Well Without Dr. J
Demo Demosthenes
description: MONTAUK, L. I., Oct. 6Listening to Jimmy Carter castigate Henry Kissinger for amorality and secrecy is, to one who mistrusts them both, a form of intolerable pleasure. I want to leap to my feet and yell, Yes, yes, you're rightbut where were you when it counted?

title: Wife of a G.O.P. Official Is Found Shot to Death In Family Home Upstate
A Brief Look at Thailand
description: POPULATIONAbout 75 percent of Thailand's population of more than 40 million is of Thai stock. Some 14 percent are overseas Chinese, an urban group important in banking, mining and commerce. Other minorities are of Malaysian, Indian, Khmer and Vietnamese descent.

title: M.A.C. CALLS ON MOODY'S TO STOP RATING ITS BONDS
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, charging that Moody's Investors Service had engaged in reckless and negligent conduct in its downgrading of M.A.C. bonds last spring, formally requested the rating service yesterday to refrain from evaluating its obligations.

title: SHAH AND GISCARD SIGN PACT ON NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 6 (Reuters)The Shah of Iran signed a nuclearcooperation agreement today with President Valry Giscard d'Estaing or France under which the French will build two nuclear reactors in this country.

title: Suckers With Red Dye Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI)The Food and Drug Administration announced today the recall of more than 80,000 orangeflavored suckers colored with Red Dye No. 2, the coloring agent banned last February because of unanswered safety questions. The agency said that the suckers were made by the Abilene Candy Company of Abilene, Tex.; and recalled by the company beginning in August. The suckers, not otherwise labeled, were distributed nationwide, the agency said.

title: A Sweet Deal for Giants: Suites in Meadowlands for Their WellHeeled Patrons
description: The Giants had no trouble finding customers for the 72 de luxe mezzanine suites that ring their new stadium in the Hackensack Meadowlands. It took less than three months last winter and spring to rent. out the 20'20 rooms that have 16 seats in two rows right outside sliding glass doors.

title: Victoria Spivey Is Dead at 68
description: Victoria Spivey, a blues singer, died Sunday at BeekmanDowntown Hospital. She was 68 years old and a resident of Brooklyn.

title: POLICE CHALLENGED ON PEDDLERS LAW
description: Despite a public commitment by the Police Department to enforce a proposed law to regulate licensed peddlers and drive unlicensed vendors from city streets, some City Councilmen expressed grave doubts yesterday that the depleted police force could do the job.

title: Soybean Futures Prices Climb
description: Soybean prices advanced yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, closing up 8 cents a bushel to $6.53 for the November delivery.

title: Hurricane Due to Hit Mexican Coast Today
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 6 (AP)A tropical storm has turned into hurricane with winds of 105 miles an hour and is expected to strige Mexico's Pacific seaboard at about noon tomorrow, the Water Resources Department reported.

title: Price of Copper Cut By 4 Cents a Pound In Sudden Actions
description: The price of copper took a sudden unexpected tumble of 4 cents a pound yesterday. The Phelps Dodge Corporation led the move with an announcement in midafternoon that it was cutting by 4 cents a pound its price for whole plate electrolytic copper cathodes. The new price will be 70 cents a pound. Later in the aftenoon, Asarco Inc. said its new price for cathodes would be the same as Phelps Dodge's and its price for wire bars would be 70.625 cents a pound.

title: NURSINGHOMES AIDE HAS BEEN DISMISSED
STOCKS DECLINE 7.07 TO A7MONTH LOW; VOLUME MOVES UP
description: Wall Street's uneasiness over the recent sluggishness in the economic recovery continued to plague the stock market yesterday as prices fell to their lowest level in more than seven months.

title: 70 Are Killed in Colombian Flood: Big Rain After Drought Ruins Dike
description: PEREIRA, Colombia, Oct. 6 (AP)Rain swollen waters broke through a dike on the outskirts of Pereira early today, killing at least 70 people and injuring 26, officials said.

title: Overruling of Damages to ChrisCraft in Piper Aircraft Fight by High Court Expected
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The Supreme Court appeared today to be headed toward a decision striking down an award of $35 million to ChrisCraft Industries, the loser of a celebrated 1969 fight with the Bangor Punta Corporation for control of the Piper Aircraft Corporation.

title: Mineola Teachers Strike When the School Board Rejects a Draft Contract
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 6Teachers in the Mineola School District went on strike today after the school board refused to accept the provisions of a new contract proposed by a conciliator from the Public Emplopyment Relations Board.

title: Anker Suspends District 2 Board For Refusal to Drop Shutdown Plan
description: The community board of District 2, the largest school district in Manhattan, was suspended indefinitely yesterday by Chancellor Irving Anker for its refusal to rescind plans to close its school this month as a nrotest against budget cuts.

title: 20 Protesting Arms Money Are Arrested in North Carolina
description: NEWBERN, N.C., Oct. 6Twenty members of a group marchin& from New Orleans to Washington to protest arms spending were arrested in Newbern yesterday when they stopped and held a rally despite being told not to.

title: New Violence in San Sebastian
description: MADRID, Oct. 6 (UPI)New violence involving Basque nationalists, rightWing extremists and police erupted tonight in San Sebastian., Spanish news agency reports said shots were fired on at least two occasions and that several persons had been injured.

title: Ousted Lottery Director Sues Daily News, Asking $7.35 Million for Libel
description: ALBANY, Oct. 6Gerald Bruno, who was dismissed last November as State Lottery Director by Governor Carey after tick duplication and other irregularities led me Governor to suspend the lottery, sued The Daily News of New York City today for libel and slander.

title: Chess:
The ThirdWorld South
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.Southerners have long marveled at how a region so rich in the basic ingredients of food, fuel and fiber could wind up on the bottom in terms of percapita income, health care, education and, perhaps most important, locallyowned assets.

title: St. Joe Minerals Reaches Accord To Acquire Coquina Oil for Stock
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation said yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Coquina Oil Corporation of Midland, Tex., through a taxfree exchange of common stock valued at about $44 million. Under termsof the agreement, St. Joe will issue 0.555 of a share of %its common stock for each %outstanding share of Coquina common. It is contemplated that St. Joe will issue a total of about 1.08 million shares for 1.94 million shares of Coquina outstanding.

title: 78 Are Believed Killed as Cuban Jetliner Crashes in Sea After Blast
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Oct. 6 (AP)Cuban passenger jet plunged into the sea near this Caribbean resort island today while the pilot was trying to return to Barbados after an explosion on board. Officials said none of the 78 people aboard survived.

title: Dog Show Judge Combines Theology With Genetics
description: Every morning for a quarter of a century, the voice of the Rev. Dr. Braxton Sawyer has been heard on the Radio Pulpit program from Fort Smith, Ark.. where it also is beamed to four neighboring states.

title: THAI MILITARY TAKES POWER AFTER POLICE BATTLE PROTESTERS
Utility Charges for Outlays Limited in Vote by F.P.C.
West Seeking to Avert Denunciation of Israel in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6Diplomatic efforts are building up, under a public cover of traditional antiIsrael speeches, to head off another inflammatory denunciation of Israel by this year's General Assembly.

title: Carter Turns A Corner
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6The most striking aspect. of the second Presidential debate was the temper of Jimmy Carter: tough, assured, confident. The confidence was especially notable, and it reflected what he has been showing on the stump this last week. He evidently felt he had turned a corner and there were reasons for that.

title: Prosecutor Named for Onondaga
description: Governor Carey announced yesterday the appointment of Edward Kearse, Corporation Counsel for the City of Syracuse, to the post of interim District Attorney of Onondaga County.

title: Zambian Site Ruled Out
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Oct. 6 (Reuters)Zambia today ruled uut its southern border town of Livingstone as a possible site for a Rhodesian conference because it was too close to the area of conflict, meaning the guerrilla war.

title: AIRLINES BALK AT FEE IMPOSED BY VIETNAM
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 6An effort by international airlines to resume flights over Indochina, suspended since the end of the war there last year has been held up by a demand by Vietnam for large fees for the rieht to enter its airsnace.

title: Egypt Parades Its Aging Weapons to Mark 73 War
description: CAIRO, Oct. 6Egypt displayed its aging Sovietmade weapons with a limited supply of Westernmade arms today in a military parade during celebrations of the third anniversary of the Egyptian and Syrian attack on Israeli forces in Sinai and on the Golan Heights.

title: ROBERT J. BELKNAP
description: Robert J. Belknap, who retired in 1968 as managing director of Esso East Africa, died yesterday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany. He was 63 years old and a resident of Hillsdale, N.Y.

title: Rangers Top North Stars, 65, As Murdoch Scores 2 Goals
People in Sports
description: Eddie Yost and Roy McMillan were released as coaches by the Mets yesterday. Rube Walker and Joe Pignatano were retained and Tom Burgess was promoted to the parent club from Tidewater, the farm team in the International League.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Oct. 6Joel R. Jacobson, the president of the Board of Public Utility Commissioners, said the commission planned to ask the Legislature to allow it to consider utility rate increases in private.

title: U.S.Soviet Arms Session Held
description: GENEVA, Oct. 6 (Reuters)United States and Soviet negotiatiors met for an hour and 40 minutes here today and agreed to hold the next session of their talks on the limitation of strategic arms next Wednesday, conference sources said. Last Friday President Ford and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, discussed arms issues.

title: L.I. Potatoes Sold Heavily To Europeans
description: ALBANY. Oct. 6A Danish ship, the Anett Bentsen, will sail tomorrow or Friday from the Port of Albany, her hold laden with Long Island potatoes destined for consumers in France.

title: Bliss Sets 7677 Fund Goal $4 Million Above Last Year's
description: The Metropolitan Opera yesterday announced that its 1976.77 fundraising goal would be $4 million above the $8.7 million raised last year. Despite a record level of giving in 197576, the company was forced to further exhaust its capital reserves by $2.1 million.

title: Social Security Taxes Will Rise for 19 Million
Clue to Mixture Of Sexual Traits Believed Found
News Summary
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1976

title: Washington &
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Somewhere in Philadelphia, there is a teenage girl whose middleincome parents were turned away this summer when they sought a bank loan to get her teeth straightened.

title: Proceedings Are Begun Against Three Yeshivas On Charges of Contempt
Hospitals and Fiscal Realities
Guard at Nassau County Jail Accused of Plot to Sell Marijuana
description: MINEOLA, L. I. Oct. 6 (UPI)A 24 yearold guard at the Nassau County Jail pleaded guilty today to a misdemeanor charge of conspiracy to sell marijuana.

title: Soviet Buys Corn and Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (Reuters)The Agriculture Department said today that the Soviet Union had bought 700,000 tons of corn and 178,000 tons of wheat in the United States.

title: Talks on Aid to Rhodesia Open
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (Reuters)The United States, Britain and South Africa opened talks at the State Department here today on proposals for a $1.5 billion fund to assist Rhodesia after transition to black majority rule. The American delegation is led by William D. Rogers, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs. Norman Aspin, Assistant Under Secretary for the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, heads the British delegation, and R. F. Botha, the South African Ambassador in Washington, is leading his country's team.

title: Minneapolis and Salt Lake City Off High Unemployment List
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)Two metropolitan areas were dropped in September from the Government's list of major labor areas with unemployment rates greater than 6 percent, the Labor Department announced today.

title: Sultan Goes Shopping With $1.5 Million List
description: ROLLING MEADOWS, Ill., Oct. 6 (AP)The shopping list read like a sultan's ransom. Fittingly, the Sultan of Oman was doing the $1.5 million in shopping and paying the $194,500 to charter a Boeing 747 cargo jet to get the goods home.

title: Barbara Nichols Dies at 47
description: HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I., Oct. 6 (AP)Barbara Nichols, a movie and television actress, died Tuesday night in Cedar Sinai Hospital in Hollywood. She was 47 years old.

title: Islanders to Open Tonight,. Stewart Is Traded
MIG25 FOUND TO LAG BEHIND U.S. AIRCRAFT
GILBERT D. BOGART JR.
description: VERONA, N.J., Oct. 6Gilbert D. Bogart Jr., president of CullenBogartParker Inc., a Clifton insurance company, died last Monday while attending a convention in White Sulphur Springs, Va. He was 48 years old.

title: Simon &
description: James H. Silberman is leaving his post as vice president and editor in chief of the adult division at Random House, to become the head of Hampshire Press, a newly founded and wholly owned subsidiary of Simon & Schuster. Although it has been financed by Simon & Schuster, the new publishing house will be distinct and independent, according to Mr. Silberman and Richard E. Snyder, Simon & Schuster's president.

title: Fighting the Boycott
description: The Export Administration Act, which declared it to be the policy of the United States to oppose restrictive trade practices and boycotts fostered or imposed by foreign countries against other countries friendly to the United States, expired with the ending of the 94th Congress. An effort to strengthen that mild legislationwhich in fact had been weakly administered by the Department of Commercewas made in the last Congressional session; but this attempt, in the form of the socalled RosenthalBingham Amendment to the Export Administration Act, also died with the 94th Congress.

title: Supermarkets GiveAway Games Spread
description: Last week, a Manhattan seamstress, Mary Bray, won $100 simply for doing what she does almost every daygoing to the supermarket. A few days earlier, Catherine Kreijanovskv also was a $100 winner in the Match & Win contest sponsored by the Grand Union supermarket at 350 East Mk Street at Second Avenue in Manhattan.

title: JAN J. MEDER
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 6 (AP)  Jan J. Meder, a regional editor for the St. Petersburg Times, died today In a Tampa hospital. He was 51 years old. Before joining The. Times in April 1968, Mr. Meder worked for the Orlando Sentinel and the Tampa Times. He is survived by his wife, Mary Lee; a son Jay and two daughters, Joy and Letia.

title: Former Aide to Hughes Fails to Answer Subpoena At a Hearing on Estate
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6John Holmes, one of the late Howard R. Hughes's longtime personal aides, failed to appear for a deposition scheduled for today in a lawyer's office here.

title: In Memoriam
description: ALPERDavid. Dearest nephew, no day more precious than the day of your birth. I miss you so.

title: New York State and City Taxes Too High, Legislators Are Told
description: Representatives of the advertising, printing and entertainment industries told a state legislative committee yesterday that, in effect, what is good for them is good for New York City and New York State.

title: France Reduces Priority of Effort To Enhance Conditions of Women
5 Women Trot Drivers From Italy Start Tour
Corporation Affairs
description: A joint mining and refining venture will be formed by Alcoa Minerals of Jamaica, a subsidiary of the Aluminum Company of America, and the Government of Jamaica, the parent company announced yesterday.

title: Misericordia Affiliation Is Urged For North Central Bronx Hospital
description: The Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that it wanted Misericordia Hospital rather than Montefiore Hospital to provide the medical staff for the new North Central Bronx Hospital and it asked the New York State Health Department to allow the opening of the new Bronx hospital under those terms.

title: Charles Roger Albright, 85, Pioneer in Visual Education
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 6 (AP) Charles Roger Albright, a pioneer in the field of visual education, died today at Burlington convalescent home after a brief illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Dividends
Albany Board Weighs Putting McCarthy on the Ballot
description: Amid reports that they were split on party lines. the members of the State Board of Elections met last night to decide whether to place Eugene J. McCarthy on the election ballot in New York as an independent Presidential candidate.

title: DR. JOSEPH GOLOMB, 81, HEADED PEDIATRICS UNIT
description: Dr. Joseph Golomb, former director of pediatrics at Fordham Hospital, died Tuesday while attending a meeting of the Jewish War Veterans in the Bronx. He was SI years old and lived at 1840 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ADD ONE Fifth Avenue, the boulevard of museumsthere's the Frick, the Met, the Guggenheim, the Jewish, the Museum of the City of New York and the Studio Museum in Harlemgets another: the CooperHewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design. The official address is 2 East 91st Street.

title: Rahway Woman Wins A Million in Lottery
description: TRENTON, Oct. 6 (UPI)Jean Pilch of Rahway won a guaranteed $1 million today in the first grand prize drawing in New Jersey's Presidential Instant Lottery.

title: Arab Mediator Warns Lebanese Peacekeeping Force Might Leave
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 6 (AP)The Arab League's mediator in the Lebanese civil war, Dr. Hassan Sabry elKholy, threatened today to withdraw the League's small peacekeeping force from its position at the crossing point between Moslem west Beirut and Christian east Beirut unless rightwing Christians stopped firing iin the area.

title: Progress in Yonkers
description: Yonkers sale of $83.6 million in bonds this week offers another hopeful sign of progress in Governor Carey's fight to restore the fiscal integrity of state government and bankruptcythreatened municipalitiesnotably Yonkers and New York Citythrough tightly enforced fiscal controls. The state, too, has recently returned to the money market with success as a result of austerities imonsed by the Governor to restore a balanced budget.

title: BUCKLEY GIVES VIEWS ON URBAN PROBLEMS
description: Senator Jamts L. Buckley declared yesterday that urban problems could not be solved through multibilliondollar Federal boondoggles, but only by dealing with each one in a way that did not mean added taxes or crippling inflation for wage earners.

title: With TV's Philemon, the Charm Wears Thin
description: This week's new Hollywood Television Theater production, being offered on Channel 13 tonight at 9:30 is Philemon, a musical by Torn Jones, lyricist, and Harvey Schmidt. composer. Produced and directed by Norman Lloyd, the play attempts to weave its curious spell through wily childlike charms. It fails.

title: Article 5  No Title
Oil Production in October to Drop
description: Oil production in the United States will drop in October to its lowest level since March, approaching a 10year output low, according to estimates released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: THAI MILITARY TAKES POWER AFTER POLICE BATTLE PROTESTERS; 30 Believed Dead and 1,700 Seized Constitution Is Suspended and Publications Banned
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Thursday, Oct. 7  Thailand's military seized power last night within hours after policemen and university students fought violent battles in which 30 persons were believed killed and hundreds wounded. More than 1,700 students were arrested.

title: Interest Rate Is Lowered to 10% On S.B.A.'s Guaranteed Loans
Card of Thanks
description: ARKOWITZMrs. Jacob. Deeply appreciates and gratefully acknowledges your kind expressions of sympathy on the loss of my dearly beloved husband Judge Jacob Markowitz.

title: Quakes Kill 7 in Ecuador
description: QUITO, Equador, Oct. 6 (AP)Small earthquakes in the Andean province of Cotopaxi, 50 miles south of Quito, have killed seven persons and caused damage to the towns of Pastocalle, Toacaso and Taniguchi.

title: College Names Division Head
description: SENECA FALLS, N.Y. (AP)Dr. Paul R. Curtis has been named director of the Eisenhower College division of science and mathematics. Dr. Curtis, who had been professor of biology, succeeds Dr. Donald S. Allen, who will retire nexa year. Dr. Curtis joined the college faculty in 1970.

title: PROGRAM BLACKLISTED IN 60 REVIVED BY WCBS; Camera Three Show on Politics Stars Howard da Silva; refused to deny membership in the Communist Party before Congressional UnAmerican Activities Committees, and even taught at the Jefferson School of Social Sciences. Communist indoc??rination school, will host an NBCTV program this coming Sundayon POLITICS. Performed for Republicans
Canadian Sights U.S. Balloonist
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 6 (Reuters) Edward Yost of Sioux Falls, S.D., who left Maine yesterday in a balloon bound for Europe, was reported today to he over the northeastern coast of New Brunswick.. The 57yearold balloonist was detectected by a lighthouse keeper at the town of Shippegan.

title: Film:
No Evidence of a Crime Is Found In Mellon Seizure of 2 Daughters
description: District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn announced yesterday that five and a half months of investigation by his staff and extensive hearings by a grand jury had produced no evidence that any crime was committed in Seward Prosser Mellon's seizure of his two daughters on a Brooklyn street last March 19.

title: Former Councilman Sentenced
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 (UPI)  A visiting Judge today sentenced former City Councilman Isadore Bellis to two years, probation and ordered him to repay $9,000 he allegedly received in re. turn for influencing a contract award at Philadelphia International Airport. Mr. Bellis, 56 years old, had been convicted last July of malfeasanse, misfeasance and nonfeasance in connection with his alleged acceptance of $9,000 from John Bolte, a Norristown architect.

title: $37 Million Waste Found in Day Care
description: New York City's muchcriticized daycare program has been wasting more than $37 million a year because centers are underused, children are too frequently absent and staffs are required to have too many employees with overly high qualifications, a state audit contended yseterday.

title: Butz Is Confident That His Policies Will Be Continued
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Former Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today that he felt he could leave Washington with confidence that the policies he had fostered during nearly five years in office would continue unchanged.

title: UNESCO Chief Proposes a Panel To Review Controversial Issues
description: PARIS, Oct. 6 (UPI)Amadou Mahtar M'Bow, general director of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, proposed a new committee today to make the agency's next general meeting less political.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Carter Said to Weigh M.A.C. Plan
description: Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential nominee, was described by a campaign aide yesterday as seriously considering endorsing a proposal by Felix G. Rohatyn to get Federal guarantees for Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds and stretch out the retirement of $10 billion in longterm city debt. Mr. Rohatyn is chairman of the corporation.

title: U.S. UNIT CRITICIZED ON FRANKLIN FAILURE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct.6 (AP) Although evidence of trouble accumulated for five years before the Franklin National Bank failed, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency did not do all it could to enforce corrections, the House Government Operations Committee said today.

title: Two Container Ports Are Bustling
Her Comeback Leaves Doubts For Mrs. King
World Tennis Starts Monday
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., Oct. 6 (AP)Evonne Goolagong plays Sue Barker and Rod Laver goes against Bjorn Borg in the opening matches of the $195,000 World Invitational Tennis Classic next Monday. Eight players are entered in the weeklong event in men's and women's singles and doubles and mixed doubles.

title: House Panel, in Last Report, Urges New Security Plan on Secret Files
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The House ethics committee, in making public its final report into its investigation of the unauthorized disclosure of the Pike intelligence committee report, urged today that Congress set up a new security and classification system for secret documents.

title: Notes on People
description: The first assault team of the American Bicentennial Everest Expedition, led by Dr. Chris Chandler of Vashon, Wash., got off to an early start yesterday, amid hopes that the peak of the world's tallest mountain may be scaled by tomorrow. With Dr. Chandler were Robert Cormack, a glider pilot from Boulder, Colo., and a Sherpa guide from Katmandu, Nepal, named Ang Phurba. At nighfall they were camped 2,828 feet from the 28,028foot peak. Communication with the base camp of the expedition was difficult, but from information available it was apparent that neither of the two women in the 12 member expedition was scheduled to make the final assault on Everest. Barbara Roach was having acclimatization problems with the thin Himalayan air, and Arlene Blum was suffering from dysentery.

title: Carter Ahead in California Poll, With Smaller Edge
U.S. Soccer Team Strikes Over Shoddy Treatment
Executives and Workmen Celebrate Topping Out Of the Citicorp Center
description: Bankers and construction workers, marketing experts and Lutheran clergymenwith emotions as varied as their occupationsmet high above Lexington Avenue yesterday in a toppingout party for the new Citicorp Center, which will be the only major office building to be completed here next year.

title: Mexico to Study Dike's Rupture
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 6 (AP)President Luis Echeverria has ordered an investigation to determine what caused a dike to burst when a hurricane struck La Paz last week, the Federal Attorney General's office reported has reported. The earthen dike was built in 1973 to prevent flood waters from entering a heavily populated dry river bed. The official death toll from the storm has reached 500,

title: New Jersey Is Planning Action Against Lobbying Ad Violations
description: TRENTON, Oct. 6 (AP)New Jersey is planning its first crackdown against violators of the 1971 Lobbying Act, which requires lobbyists to file reports on their activities every three months.

title: Rehearsal:
description: The tantalizing title of Jack Gelber's new play is Jack Gelber's New Play: Rehearsal. It is a play within a play. In it, actors are rehearsing a play about prison, in which the actor playing the author is persuaded to act as a convict, a character who is raped by a fellow inmate, and who, metaphorically, is raped by the system. To complicate the metaphor, the reallife director is Mr. Gelber himself.

title: Mondale Says the Campaign Has Turned Around
The Policy Connection:
description: Last night's debate between President Ford and Jimmy Carter was billed as a confrontation on foreign policyas the first debate was supposed to be confined to domestic policy, especially domestic economic policy. But can United States foreign policy and domestic economic policy be kept in separate compartments? The answer is certainly no. Yet there is a tendency on the part of politicians to treat the relationships between foreign and domestic econpmic policy as thoug:n they were a dirty little secret.

title: Ford Denies Moscow Dominates East Europe; Carter Rebuts Him
description: President Ford said last night in his debate with Jimmy Carter that there was no Soviet domination of Eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford Administration.

title: U. S. TO SEEK SHIFT IN I.M.F. GOLD SALES TO A WEEKLY BASIS
description: MANILA, Oct. 6The United States will formally propose shortly to the executive board of the International Monetary Fund that the fund's schedule of gold auctions be changed to an auction every week instead of every six weeks. The disclosure was made in an interview today with Edwin H. Yeo 3d, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, who is here attending the annual meeting of the I.M.F.

title: Hunter Hid A Sore Arm
South African Cleric Attacked
description: DURBAN, South Africa, Oct. 6 (Agence FrancePresse)  Three gasoline bombs were thrown last night at the home of the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Durban, Denis Hurley, one of apartheid's leading critics. Only one bomb exploded and a fire was quickly put out.

title: Butz Incident Raises PressPrivacy Issue
description: When a public official makes a remark obviously not intended for publication, is the printing of the remark an invasion of his privacy and none of the public's business? Or do news organizations have a legitimate obligation to print the comment if it reveals something about the man?

title: Allegations Heard On Bias in Rentals By Realty Brokers
description: With a Greenwich Village realestate concern and its staff as the first defendants. New York State yesterday began a series of hearings to determine whether a dozen Manhattan realty companies had practiced racial discrimination in referring people for apartment rentals.

title: FORD PACT CALLED STEP TO 4DAY WEEK
Slum Evictions in Manila Embarrass the World Bank
description: MANILA, Oct. 6 More than 400 families have been forcibly evicted and their houses have been demolished in and around the Tondo slum area of this city, one of the worst such areas in Asia and, at the same time, the scene of a major urban renewal project of the World Bank.

title: Dole Denies Charges by Mondale
AGRICULTURE RIGHTS UNIT STAVED OFF MERGER PLAN
Memorial Services
description: OSEPHRichard. Memorial services for Esquire's beloved Travel Editorwill be held on Thursday, Oct. 7, at 5:30 P.M. at the Church Center for the United Nations, 777 U.N. Plaza, New York City. The family requests that In lieu of flowers contributions be made to the J.H. Wyse Scholarship Fund, c/o Temple Israel, Emerson Ave., Dayton, Ohio.

title: Marathon Man Thriller of a Film
Grazing Halt Urged in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Oct, 6 (AP)  Radiation from the Chinese nuclear blast has led to high levels of iodine in the milk of Connecticut cattle, prompting a recommendation that farmers feed their cows silage rather than let them graze in fields, the state health commissioner said today.

title: $37 Million Waste Found in Day Care
description: New York City's muchcriticized daycare program has been wasting more than $37 million a year because centers are underused, children are too frequently absent and staffs are required to have too many employees with overly high qualifications, a state audit contended yseterday.

title: TENSION INCREASING IN HOSPITAL WALKOUT
description: The strike against three private nonprofit hospitals by doctors seeking recognition of their union went into its second day yesterday with little apparent effect on patient care, but with rising tension on both sides.

title: Bridge:
description: It is interesting to speculate what would happen if a team of modern champions, with the aid of a time machine, were able to play against the players of 40 years ago, The chances are that the moderns would gain substantially by their more sophisiticated and accurate bidding, and get very slightly the best of the play.

title: Food and Style:
Ford Denies Moscow Dominates East Europe
description: President Ford said last night in his debate with Jimmy Carter that there was no Soviet domination of Eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford Administration.

Hockey
description: PRESEASON GAMES

title: Stokely Carmichael Predicts End of the Capitalist System
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 6 (UPI)Stokely Carmichael, a United States civil rights activist of the 1960's who now lives in Africa, said today that he was working to destroy the American capitalistic system. He is on a visit here.

title: New Hampshire Nuclear Plant Gets Building Permit From U.S.
THOUSANDS OF SPANIARDS AT POLICEMEN'S FUNERAL
description: MADRID, Oct. 6Several thousand people, a large number of them believed to be policemen in civilian clothes, marched silently today in Madrid behind the coffins of two policemen killed Monday in the Basque city of San Sebastian.

title: Japan and U.S. Are Bargaining On Airline Ties
description: TOKYO, Oct. 6Japanese and American diplomats are meeting behind closed doors here in the latest in a series of hard bargaining sessions designed eventually to hammer out new civil aviation agreements between the two nations, At stake are the lucrative transPacific passenger and cargo air routes linking Asia and North America and beyond. The prize is more than $880 million in sales a year.

title: Free Democrats in Bonn Continue To Support Schmidt for Chancellor
description: BONN, Oct. 6 (UPI)The small Free Democratic Party, which holds the balance of power in Parliament, told the leader of the Christian Democratic Party, Helmut Kohl, today that it would support Helmut Schmidt as Chancellor, continuing its sevenyear coalition with the Social Democrats.

title: Westbury Track Top Earner by Far for Garden
Couple, Recently Robbed, Take Their Own Lives, Citing Fear
description: An elderly couple who were assaulted and robbed in their Bronx apartment last month hanged themselves from their bedroom doorknob after leaving a note saying that, we don't want to live in fear anymore.

title: General Aviation Billings in Month Up 39.8% to $128.2 Million High
description: Manufacturers of general aviation products had a record month in September, the General Aviation Manutacturers Association, said yesterday. During the 30day period, factory billings were up 39.8 percent to $128.2 million while new aircraft shipments rose 9.3 percent to 1,329 units from 1,216 in the yearearlier level, the Washingtonbased. association reported.

title: BOND PRICES ADVANCE IN FLURRY OF TRADING
description: Bond prices rose sharply yesterday in active trading as the conviction spread that a weakerthanexpected economy would lead the Federal Reserve to let shortterm interest rates decline. The Fed yesterday seemed in no hurry to absorbexcess bank reserves as the interest rate on loans of reserves dropped all the way to 1 percent, the central bank's lack of alacrity being interpreted as a hint of a possible policy shift. With the wholesale price index scheduled to be published today and with the Government's unemployment figures due tomorrow, it was widely believed that the Federal Reserve had enough preliminary indications of the data yesterday to begin to adjust its stance and permit interest rates to work omewhat downward.

title: DISTORTION CHARGED TO CAREY ON RELIEF
description: ALBANY, Oct. 6The Republicans in the New York State Senate charged today that Governor Carey was deliberately exaggerating the problem of increases in the welfare caseload to steer public attention away from what they said were the real reasons for overruns in the state's welfare budgetadministrative failures in welfare management both in Albany and in New York Gity.

title: Queens Prisoners End Protest Over Courts
description: Threatened with the use of force, inmates at the Queens House of Detention ended a twoday protest against court Conditions and returned to their cells last night.

title: DISSENT SURROUNDS FLU SHOT PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6From the easternmost promontory of Maine to the western tip of Guam, Americans are being urged to roll up their sleeves this month for the swine flu vaccine.

title: Expansion of a Jersey Hospital Is Upheld by Appellate Division
description: TRENTON, Oct. 6 (UPI)The Appellate Division of Superior Court yesterday upheld a decision by the state to grant Perth Amboy General Hospital permission to build a satellite facility in Madison Township.

title: Sutton and Garvey Gain Top September Awards
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct, 6 (UPI)Don Sutton has been named pitcher of the month and his Los Angeles Dodger teammate, Steve Garvey, player of the month for September, the National League announced today.

title: Story of Sin' Delights the Eye but Fails to Be Gripping
description: If sin, like truth and beauty, is in the eye of the beholder, then "Story of Sin," the Polish entry at the New York Film Festival tonight and tomorrow night, is a delight to the eye. But Walerian Borowczyk, the Polish director who previously worked in France, is enamored of a saga that is, in essence, a cross between grand and soap opera.His principals may be true to themselves. Victorian moralities and their vintage settings but, despite the dedication of the director and his cast, their "Story of Sin" evolves more as a quaint, visually engrossing album of a faded past than as a gripping motion picture.In fashioning his script from an old Polish novel, Mr. Borowczyk, and an English prologue and subtitles, make it plain that turn-of-the-century Czarist-dominated Warsaw was rough on the staunchly Catholic, disenfranchised Polish petit bourgeois. And our pure, religiously proper young heroine is no exception. She is quickly caught up in the throes of first love with a lodger in her parents' apartment who, it happens, is seeking a divorce. As might be guessed, this is the start of a convoluted, bitter romance indicating that sin isn't necessarily simple.As was the case in Mr. Borowczyk's "Immoral Tales," seen here early this year, eroticism, costuming, settings and photography are artistically detailed. Lovers engulfed in newly found ecstacy in cramped village quarters or in a baroque Riviera suite leave little to the imagination.And lust and murder are made equally specific in rich, red damask rooms filled with bibelots and the sounds of a raucous ancient gramophone.The primal drive of love and the beastliness of sinners in our heroine's life make for a complex plot with some seemingly abrupt transitions. But Mr. Borowczyk's fascination with his subject appears to have rubbed off on his willing players. If he is precise in dealing with action in the boudoir, he is just as careful in maintaining a fast narrative pace.(In a largely unbilled cast that contributes to that momentum, Grazyna Dlugolecka is outstanding as the pretty, driven outcast. She is curvaceous, but more importantly, genuinely winning and realistic, both as the virgin introduced to love and sex amid swirling white petticoats or nude or in black corsets as the seemingly callous streetwalker.If Jerzy Zelnik's portrait of her beleaguered student dover is merely a profile, others, including Olgierd Lucaszewicz, vigorously project sincere if sometimes-postured portrayals.Mr. Borowczyk and his actors colorfully evoke the people and places of a restrictive society with the dedication of historians. There inspection of the complexities of sin, however, is as obvious and colorful as a vintage snapshot."Story of Sin" is slated to start an engagement at the RKO Twin 1 Theater on East 59th Street next Thursday.

title: Militant Jews Bury Desecrated Scrolls at Hebron
description: HEBRON, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Oct., 6A funeral service for desecrated Jewish Torah scrolls and holy books was held in this tense Moslem Arab city today by about 3,000 religious Jews who interred the artifacts under the protection of hundreds of Israeli soldiers.

title: JOHN H. DUNN JR., 68, DIES
description: John H. Dunn Jr., a longtime journalist who was the editor of NBC Today Show for 13 years, until his retirement in 1973, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 68 years old and was a Manhattan resident.

title: Bomb Blast Hurts Policeman
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 6 (AP)An explosion device felled one of the policemen who responded today to a report of a bomb in the New Rochelle public library. The policeman was not severely injured, authorities said, and there was minimal damage to the library.

title: 3 Teams Refuse to Let Rival Cross Goal
description: A simple theory of football is bringing success to three teams in the metropolitan area. The theory is: If you don't give up any points, you can't lose. The teams are Dobbs Ferry in Westchester, Flushing from Oueens and DeWitt Clinton from the Bronx. None has given up points this season.

title: Heath, Ending Silence, Backs Mrs. Thatcher as Party Chief
description: LONDON, Oct. 6In an emotional atmosphere at the annual Conservative Party conference, former Prime Minister Edward Heath announced his confidence in Margaret Thatcher's leadership today the first time he had done so since she displaced him as party leader 20 months ago.

title: Series Sellout for Phillies
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 (AP)The Philadelphia Phillies announced today they were sold out of tickets for the World Series. The Phils, who open the National League playoff Saturday against Cincinnati, began accepting Series ticket orders by mail yesterday.

title: PRESIDENT IN A BID TO NONREPUBLICANS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6President Ford, contending that Democrats and independents were wary of Jimmy Carter's candidacy, created a citizens committee today to encourage voters to disregard party labels in the Nov. 2 election.

title: 2 Psychiatrists Tell Murder Jury Kallinger Is Insane
A.M.C. Prices Rise 4.8% For '77, Below Big Three
description: DETROIT, Oct. 6  The American Motors Corporation said today that it was raising prices of its 1977 models by 4.8 percent, or $167 over comparably equipped 1976 models. The increase was slightly less than those announced by the Big Three auto companies in recent weeks.

title: S.E.C. Says ExTenneco Official Received $509,000 in Kickbacks
Another Hospital Strike
description: The strike of interns and residents against a few of New York's voluntary and affiliated municipal hospitals raises disturbing questions about these young doctors sense of responsibility toward the innocent patients who inevitably will be the chief sufferers.

title: EVA M. LARRY
description: Eva M. Larry, a former principal of Junior High School 159 and of Public School 78, both in Manhattan, died Tuesday in the Bethel Nursing Home, Ossining, N.Y., after a long illness. She was 90 years old.

title: Marx Given Bit Part By Carter in Debate
description: Even Karl Marx crept into last night's debate between President Ford and Jimmy Carter.

title: KISSINGER DENOUNCES REPORT ON MAYAGUEZ
description: Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger rejected yesterday a Congressional report criticizing the Ford Administration's handling of the Mayaguez incident, in which 41 American servicemen died, saying it was based on misleading information and 'a misunderstanding of government, United Press International reported.

title: SUSAN SAXE RESTS CASE WITHOUT ANY WITNESS
description: BOSTON, Oct. 6 (AP)The defense in the murder and bank robbery trial of Susan E. Saxe rested its case today without calling a single witness.

title: August's Consumer Credit Growth Of $1.4 Billion Largest Since May
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)Auto buyers borrowed at a record pace in August to push total consumer installment borrowing up by the largest amount in three months, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

description: The State Lottery Director, John Quinn, reported yesterday that 14,500 tickets had been stolen from vendors, but that the thieves would not get rich from them.

description: It is ironic that the United States Supreme Court decision in July upholding the death penalty for murderthe Court on Monday refused to reconsider that decisionshould have come on the eve of the 200th anniversary of the nation's birth.

title: Old Liberty Ships Now Aid Sea Denizens
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 6They once served as America's lifeline across the North Atlantic, dodging German submarines to carry vital war supplies to the Allies in Europe. Now, the last of the nation's World War II Liberty Ships are quietly being buried at sea.

title: Soviet Communist, Disillusioned at 84, Resigns From Party
RHODESIA QUESTIONS PACT NEGOTIABILITY
Jumblat Visits Algeria
description: ALGIERS, Oct. 6 (UPI)The Lebanese leftist leader, Kamal Jumblat, conferred today with President Houari Boumediene and Foreign Minister Abdelaziz Bouteflika on ways to reach a peaceful solution to the Lebanese civil war.

title: DR. MANASSEH J. KAMEN
description: Dr. Manasseh J. Kamen, a retired general practitioner, died in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Monday while on vacation. He was 71 years old and lived at 1722 Avenue N in Brooklyn. A 1929 graduate of the Long Island College of Medicine and Hospital, he retired from practice last year. He had been on the staff of the Kings Highway Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: INDEPENDENT GOVERNOR DECLINES TO BACK FORD
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 6 (AP)Gov. James B. Longley said today that President Ford had asked him to endorse his candidacy. But Mr. Longley told a news conference that he was not yet prepared to back the Republican candidate.

title: CurtissWright Sells Airport
description: WOODRIDGE, N.J., Oct. 6 (UPI)CurtissWright, an early leader in the aircraft industry, completed its withdrawal from the business by selling its 278acre airport at Caldwell, N.J., to Essex County for $8 million, Essex County already is operating the airport as a general aviation facility. CurtisWright still makes aerospace components, but has not made either commercial or military planes or big aircraft engines in some years,

title: HUMPHREYS FOUND TO PAY 48% OF INCOME IN TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)Senator and Mrs. Hubert H. Humphrey have a net worth of $636,584 and paid more than 48 percent of their income in taxes over the last five years.

description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 6Chile dropped out of the Andean Pact today with the consent of the other five members, who will continue working toward a common market.

title: BRITISH POUND FALLS IN A JITTERY SESSION

title: James T. Farrell's New Book Is His 50th, a Milestone Novel
description: James T. Farrell's newest work is a novel called The Dunne Family. It is his 50th hook, but it is something more. It is a milestone in a literary career that includes novels, short stories, personal reflections and commentary on literature and politics. Nevertheless, there is a kind of esthetic justice in the fact tha the new look is a novel. For it was Mr. Farrell's first novels, the Studs Lonigan trilogy, that established his reputation and in a sense, have sustained it ever since.

description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 6 (AP)The Englishlanguage Indian Express, one of India's last independent newspapers, won a court order today freeing its presses from a Governmentordered padlocking.

description: BERN  In Western Europe, where some countries are pulling in one direction and some in another, Switzerland and the Netherlands are frequently mentioned by politicians as models of the opposite extremes.

description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 7How is the Billie Jean King comeback going?Carelessly, casually and awful, said Mrs. King today, slumping into a chair after having eked out an 80minute windblown victory over Kris Shaw, 63, 76, in the 870,000 Talley women's tournament.

Moynihan, disagreed fundamentally yesterday on various domestic issues, but displayed wide agreement on foreign affairs, particularly the continuing threat of the Soviet Union.
