description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 6Hun dreds of cars in bright shades of blue, green and yellow were rolling off the assembly line yesterday in the big General Motors plant here on the banks of the Hudson.

title: Syrian Troop Movement Is Reported in Lebanon; Guerrillas Fear Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 7 (Reuters)Large movements of Syrian troops were reported today in mountain areas southeast of here. Palestinian guerrilla spokesmen said it appeared that an attack against the port city of Saida was being prepared.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: There's a big new show of rarely seen pottery that has just opened at Asia House Gallery, 112 East 64th Street (PL 14210). Southeast Asian Ceramics displays 109 pieces made between the 9th and 17th centuries in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia. What with all the attention paid to ceramics from Japan and China, Southeast Asian pottery has often been overlooked. The items on display come from leading kilns and centers. There are unusual examples made by the Khmer. You will see celadons from the Sawankhalok kilns in Thailandyou'll have to go to see what that's all about, because there's no room to go into it. here. The gallery is on the second floor of the handsome, narrow building that houses the Asia Society. Admission is free. You can rent a taped tour for $1 with one earpiece, $1.50 for two earpieces. Open Mondays to Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 5; until 8:30 P.M. on Thursdays.

title: Screen: Minnellis, Pereet Fille
description: IF you can imagine a feature-film equivalent to a Radio City Music Hall stage show, it might look very much like Vincente Minnelli's "A Matter of Time," which opened yesterdayappropriatelyat Radio City Music Hall, where Mr. Minnelli began his career years ago as a designer and producer. It is full of glittery costumes and spectacular props. It is performed by talented, sophisticated people who adopt the faux-naif gestures of an earlier show-biz tradition, and though it is expensive, it sounds peculiarly tacky."A Matter of Time" might better have retained the title of the Maurice Druon novel from which John Gay adapted his screenplay"Film of Memory." "A Matter of Time" is a jumbosize pousse-caf of memories in the form of a fairy tale about a little girl from the Italian provinces who comes to Rome and becomes a big, glamorous movie queen.Its principal star is none other than Liza Minnelli, Mr. Minnelli's daughter by Judy Garland and a screen personality whose appearance recalls her father and whose voice and mannerisms recall her mother. She has talent of her own, but it comes to us through the remembered presence of others."A Matter of Time" is not only composed of memories, it is about memory as a mysteriously enriching human capacity, though it never realizes the poetic potential of its subject. Playing opposite Miss Minnelli is Ingrid Bergman as a dotty old contessa, once the toast of Europe and now reduced to living in poverty in the rundown, hotel where Liza takes a job as a chamber-maid.As the contessa spins tales about her turn-of-the-century conquests, little Liza, whose eyes seem to have been widened surgically to play this part, relives the memories on screen, providing Mr. Minnelli with an opportunity for some fancy, romantic fooling of the sort that distinguished the regression sequences in "On a Clear Day You Can See Forever."Only one sequence, however, comes off with the anticipated lan: Liza, as the contessa, is the hostess at one of those gala, pre-World War I Venice masquerades. She bids good night on the Grand Canal to the Kaiser ("Please call me Wilhelm"), walks back into her palazzo, knee-deep in confetti, discarding her costume as she goes. By the time she reaches the far end of the ballroom, she has returned to mid-20th, century. There, backed by five black musicians who had been packing to leave, she drifts into a sort of elegiacal rendition of the great Gershwin number, "Do It Again."No other moment in the film comes anywhere near to capturing this sort of ghostly, romantic elegance. In addition to "Do It Again," Miss Minnelli sings two new Fred Ebb-John Kander songs, yet the film has the air of an operetta from which the music has been removed. It's even acted that way.When Miss Minnelli's chambermaid enters a room, it's the way chambermaids enter rooms in operettas. She opens the door breezily, twirls around to close the door with her back to the audience, thus making it possible for her to be struck with dumb surprise or shock when she turns again to see what's going on. It's all a teeny, tiny bit arch.So is the casting of Charles Boyer in the small role of the contessa's long-lost husband, recalling the teaming or Miss Bergman and Mr. Boyer in "Gaslight." Mr. Boyer has such weight that, after he has been on the screen, the film seems even flimsier than it need be when he disappears.A further family note: Isabella Rossellini, Miss Bergman's daughter by Roberto Rossellini, shows up at the end of the film as a nun, looking meltingly beautiful, much the way her mother did when she first came to Hollywood.The English dialogue of the European actors has apparently been post-synchronized, which contributes to the effect of overall hollowness of the movie. Because "A Matter of Time" has moments of real visual beauty, and because what the characters say to each other is mostly dumb, it may be a film to attend while wearing your earplugs."A Matter of Time" has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") for reasons that may have to do with the merest soupon of discreet nudity, but I'm not sure. It seems totally harmless to me.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (millions of dollars)

title: The Pop Life
description: IT OFTEN SEEMS THESE DAYS as if everybody wants to do something other than what he or she is already doing. Athletes and singers act. Actors become politicians. Politicians become television newscasters. And models, athletes and actors sing.

title: Broadway
description: SO QUIETLY you can hear a cashier cough, ticket prices are rising, slowly, unevenly, but inexorably. A Chorus Line, which still is the hottest ticket in town, has gone to a top price of $16.50, while next month The Wiz will go from $15 to $16 for seats in the orchestra on Friday and Saturday nights. Regrettable, Ken Harper, the producer, said, but the rise is simply due to increased operating costs. Meanwhile, My Fair Lady has been getting $17.50 on Saturday nights for the last month or so, while Chicago has been getting $17.50 for even longer than that.

title: HENRY X. GLASER
description: Henry X. Glaser, who retired from The New York Journal American in 1959 after working there 59 years as a writer and editor in the sports department, died Wednesday in Red Bank, N.J., after a long illness. He was 92 years old.

title: Ecumenical Service for Letelier, Slain Chilean, is Set for Sunday
description: An ecumenical memorial service for Orlando Letelier, who was foreign minister in the Chilean government of Salvador Allende Gossens, will be held at 7:30 P.M. Sunday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, 415 West 59th Street.

title: Antiques
description: T HROUGHOUT history the greatest jewelers have prided themselves on designs that incorporated precious gems sparely or merely to add sparkle. And Louis Cartier, that master of the Art Deco style who dominated the Parisbased jewelry concern from 1902 to 1942, was no exception.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Connecticut's blue laws are still on the books, but the state's Chief Attorney's office has advised prosecutors to stop enforcing them. The advisory was issued after a Court of Common Pleas judge in New Britain called the laws unconstitutional in dismissing charges of illegal Sunday sales against the manager of a Two Guys department store in Newington.

title: U.S. Soccer Team Returns To Practice as Strike Ends
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Oct. 7 (AP)The United States national soccer team returned to the practice field today after a shortlived strike that ended in acceptance of a compromise salary offer from the United States Soccer Federation.

title: Bomb Hoax at New Delhi Airport
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 7 (Reuters)A warning that there was a bomb aboard forced an AirIndia jetliner to return here shortly after takeoff for Kuwait today but no bomb was found.

title: News Summary
description: Corporations that have joined the Arab boycott of Israel will not be named by the Commerce Department. Apparently retreating from a pledge he made during the debate, President Ford directed the department to make public all future reports on boycott matters. A Commerce Department spokesman stressed the confidentiality of previous information filed. [Page A1, Cols. 45.]

title: Giants and Jets, 08, Likely to Be 010 on Sunday
description: As the Giants and Jets prepare to open their home seasons on Sunday, one mast appreciate that they have made history. Never before have New York's pro teams had a collective 08 wonlost record in the first month of the season. The Giants last About lost their first four games in 1932 and the Jets in 1965. Pro The Jets opener against Football Buffalo did not sell out 72 hours in advance, as required, but the Giants game against Dallas in the new stadium has sold out, so it will be televised locally by Channel 2, starting at 1 P.M. Channel 4 will show Miami at Baltimore, starting at P.M. Previews of all games follow with the teams wonlosttied records in parentheses.

title: News From The Lehigh Valley
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 7The important question about these Presidential debates is not what the reporters or the foreign policy experts think about them but what the voters think, and on this decisive election point, they are a real puzzle.

title: Reviewing the Mayaguez
description: When Cambodian troops seized the Mayagilez, an American merchant vessel, 60 miles off the Cambodian coast on May 12, 1975, it was clearly the United States Government's duty to take whatever steps seemed necessary to free the ship and its crew. Another Pueblo could not be tolerated by the American peoplenor would it have been. The action ordered by President Ford accomplished its purpose, although unfortunately only after 41 American lives had been lost.

title: Basic Money Supply Is Down $1.2 Billion
Mississippi Blacks to Picket Butz When He Appears at G.O.P. Event
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 7 (UPI)Charles Evers, the civil rights leader and Mayor of Fayette, Miss., said today that former Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz is not welcome in Mississippi and blacks will picket his scheduled appearance in the state tomorrow afternoon.

title: Article 3  No Title
Resch, Islanders Thwart Flyers, 30
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7A virtually flawless performance in the Spectrum tonight gave the Islanders a 30 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers, the first seasonopening triumph in New York's fiveyear history.

title: Neighborhoods: Greeks in Bay Ridge
description: The quiet streets and comfortable homes of Bay Ridge that in past decades attracted Scandinavians, Irish and Italians are now luring increasing numbers of Greeks to that tranquil corner of Brooklyn.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Your child has just been caught cheating. it comes as a real shock. It's so unlike him, you saywhen, mani???. it was exactly like him.

title: DoleMondale Debate Set For Houston Next Friday; A New Format is Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7David Owen, campaign director for Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican VicePresidential candidate, said last night that an agreement had finally been reached on details for the debate between Mr. Dole and Senator Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic nominee.

title: Jappe Recalls Days of 1925 As Original Football Giant
description: I didn't see as good a future playing football with the Giants as selling Easy Wash washing machines, Jappe (pronounced JAPee) explains.

title: Chains Report Gain In September Sales; Clothing Still Lags
description: The nation's largest general merchandise retailers yesterday reported moderate to sizable sales gains in September over a year ago, but there was continuing evidence of reluctance by American consumers to buy apparel and other soft linws.

title: CBS Says 83 Million Watched 2d Debate
description: Based on ratings figures for New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, the audience for the second Presidential debate Wednesday night was slightly smaller than for the first one.

title: Market Place
description: The biggest news concerning the nation's leading chemical companies has been negative in recent months.

title: Under the Gun
description: An angry Mayor Beame spoke for every New Yorker early yesterday when in the wake of another riotous demonstration by offduty policemen he declared: I won't stand for it and the people of the city won't stand for it.

title: Article 4  No Title
Some Abroad See a Grave Error In Ford Comment on East Europe
description: A major gaffe and a grave faux pas were how some foreign newspapers, commentators and diplomats yesterday described President Ford's statement that Eastern Europe is not dominated by the Soviet Union.

title: Audit by Control Board Finds City U. is Meeting Its Fiscal 1977 Target
description: The City University of New York was reported on target yesterday in meeting its fiscal 1977 financial plan.

title: Notes on People
description: New York University's Gallatin Medal was presented last night to Alice Tully, a musician, philanthropist, and patron of the arts perhaps best known to New Yorkers for the concert hall in ???ncoln Center bearing her name. Miss Tully's gift made possible the construction of Allice Tully Hall, which opened in 1969.

title: Life Terms Asked in Stuttgart For 3 Guerrilla Group Leaders
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Oct. 7 (Reuters)Lice imprisonment for three accused leaders of the BaaderMeinhof urban guerrilla group was demanded today by the prosecution.

title: Third Ave. Fair Sunday and Monday
description: Third Avenue between 14th and 30th Streets will be dotted with street musicians, dance troupes and international food stands Sunday and Monday for the Third Avenue Merchants Association county fair.

title: Public Library is Down but Not Out
description: Imagine someone with hundreds of millions of dollars, who lives in a mansion so magnificent that it is a national landmark, panhandling for survival.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on student loans in The Times Wednesday stated incorrectly that a bill awaiting President Ford's signature would retain a maximum loan limit of $15,000 for graduate education. The present limit is $10,000; the pending bill would increase it to $15,000.

title: Don't Think Ill of Me
description: My lovely RYou are my queen. You fulfill me. Each day, when we are apart, a thousand thoughts of you spark me and warm me. You are the woman I've waited my lifetime for, another could never take your place. But now, with great difficulty, I must confess my infidelity.

title: Tessie O'Shea Belts it Out
description: Tessie O'Shea, late of the musical Something's Afoot, is now filling the Grand Finale, 210 West 70th Street, with lively echoes of the British music halls and American vaudeville. Miss O'Shea, a large woman draped in a loosely fitting electric blue gown, bubbles with enthusiasm and unflagging energy as she sings, prances, chatters glibly and even bangs away on a banjo, sustaining a momentum that is in high gear from the moment she enters, belting out I Got Rhythm.

title: They Even Do the Hat Dance
description: The Ballet Folklorico of Mexico has been offering a movable fiesta to New Yorkers since its dazzling debut here in 1962. This weekend will mark the troupe's first appearance at the Felt Forum, with performances tonight at 8 P.M. and tomorrow at 2:30 and P.M.

title: Polls Show More Viewers Rate Carter as Winner of 2d Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7While both sides were claiming victory, two national surveys indicated today that more people thought Jimmy Carter had won last night's television debate than felt President Ford had won.

title: 2 Killed, Many Wounded As First Major Race Riot Breaks Out in Portugal
description: LISBON, Oct. 7Two men from Portugal's former colony of the Cape Verde Islands were killed and a score of Cape Verdeans and Portuguese were wounded last night in this country's first major race riot.

title: Teacher Will Appeal Ouster Over Nudity
description: POMONA, N.J., Oct. 7 (UPI) A former professor at Stockton State College who has been discharged for inviting students to his Tome for classes in the nude said he had not given up efforts to get his job back.

title: Tenor Has a Change of Voice
description: LUCIANO FAVAROTTI, the heroically large tenor of the Metropolitan Opera, is goodhumored about his bulk, but not really forthcoming. if you ask how much he weighs, now that he has lost 25 Pounds on a diet, he replies, Less than before. And how much did he weigh before? More than now. He proudly displays his diet chart, which lists only these items for the evening meal: 100 grams tuna fish, 150 grams tomato, 50 grams bread, 1 peach. Looking more like Falstaff or Nero than T. S. Eliot's Prufrock (Do I dare to eat a peach?), the tenor sits imperiously in a togalike bathrobe in his hotel suite on Central Park South and nurses the last few ounces of red wine in a small cruet, his allotment for the day.

title: He is to Be Arraigned Today in $45,000 Theft by 3 Armed Men From Branch of Citibank
description: A 39yearold New York City police detective was arrested yesterday on bank robbery charge.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 (UPI)An agreement that will split $9 million among shareholders of the Ampex Corporation has been approved by a Federal District Court judge, Spencer Wilhams, in a settlement of a fiveyearold suit against the company.

title: Some Major Differences
description: The lively and often bitter debate between. President Ford and Jimmy Carter underscored more clearly than before that they differ significantly on a number of important international issues, even while agreeing at least in principle on some others. The debate Wednesday night also revealed the candidates contrasting approaches to America's role in the worldMr. Ford more cautious, Mr. Carter more farranging on specific questions, they differed on how to deal with the Middle East, particularly the Arab nations; the problem of arms sales abroad, especially to Iran; the Panama Canal negotiations, and relations with the Soviet Union. They seemed to agree more than disagree on the need for large expenditures for defense, continued backing for Taiwan and major support for Israel.

title: About Real Estate
description: CHENANGO BRIDGE N.Y.In this suburban town in the hills and farms north of Binghamton, in southcentral New York State, home building knows no peaks and valleys, says Edward W. McGowan. We just kind of plod along.

title: Policemen March on Times Square as Talks Begin
description: Offduty policemen marched through midtown Manhattan shouting slogans and blowing service whistles last night in the second straight night of boisterous demonstrations.

title: Books of The Times
description: A great deal goes on in the eighth, last, longest and presumably climactic chapter of Lovers and Tyrants, a first novel by the journalist and social critic Francine du Plessix Cray (Divine Disobedience and Hawaii: The SugarCoated Fortress). There is abundant activity: Stephanie, the story's protagonist and firstperson narrator, has left her ideal little nuclear family and its bowwow quackquack miaowmiaow dollhouse happiness, gone to Tucson, Ariz., to report on a weeklong meditation symposium for The New York Times and taken up with a homosexual named Elijah Stewart some 20 years younger than she.

title: U.S. is Reducing Its Requirements On Reporting of Foreign Currency
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (Reuters)The Treasury Department said today that it was cutting foreigncurrency reporting requirements for nonbank concerns, which will reduce the number of such companies reporting by about 120.

title: COLOMBIA AGAIN IMPOSES NATIONWIDE STATE OF SIEGE
description: One reason government sources cited for the emergency was the need for security for King Juan Carlos of Spain during his fiveday visit here next week.

title: Memorial Services
description: HILLW. Martin. Service at the Church Center for the United Nations, 777 U.N. Plaza at 12 noon, Oct. 13, 1976.

title: Reliever Has Knee Surgery
description: CLEVELAND. Oct. 7 (UPI)Stan Thomas, righthanded relief pitcher for the Cleveland Indians, underwent surgery today to repair a deteriorated cartilage in his right knee. Last winter Thomas's left knee was operated on. Thomas, 44 last season with a 2.30 earnedrun average, is expected to be hospitalized about a week.

title: People and Business
description: If there is another oil embargo, the International Energy Agency will decide who gets how much and the companies will have nothing to do with that, the agency's deputy executive director, Wallace Hopkins, asserted yesterday in Washington.

title: Pepsico Earnings Climb 25% to Record Level As Sales Advance 14%
description: Pepsico Inc., second largest producer of soft drinks after the CocaCola Company, reported yesterday a 25 percent. increase in thirdquarter earnings to record on a sales gain of 14 percent.

title: Local Delegates of U.A.W. Vote To Accept Agreement With Ford
description: DETROIT, Oct. 7  Delegates from union locals around the country overwhelmingly approved a new contract agreement between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers today. Union officials predicted that rankandfile members would approve the contract by next Tuesday.

title: Curb on Land Sales Awaits Ford Move
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)A bill awaiting consideration by President Ford would allow Congress to veto proposed large sales of Federal land to private interests.

title: People in Sports
description: Four days after ending his 23year playing career with a runproducing single, Henry Aaron yesterday embarked on a new sort of baseball career. He was signed by the Atlanta Braves as a vice president in charge of player development and as a supervisor of the Braves farm system.

title: Client Drops Andersen On Disclosure Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7In what may be the first case of its kind, the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company has lost a client because of the rigorous view it took toward the disclosure of questionable commission and billing practices, according to report made available today at the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: N.F.L. is Appealing On Antitrust Setback
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)The National Football League has given notice it will appeal a Federal court ruling that the annual college draft violated antitrust laws, an attorney in the case said today.

title: Shipping /Mails
Byrne to Sign Bill For Death Penalty If Legislature Acts
description: TRENTON, Oct. 7Governor Byrne told a joint session of the State Legislature today that he would sign a bill restoring the death penalty although he believed capital punishment was more an emotional response to deep fears of violence than a practical cure for crime.

title: 35 Years Levied for $6 Robbery
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 (AP)A $6 robbery has led to a 35year prison term for the robber who shot the victim. The sentence was imposed yesterday on Bruce Morton, 21 years old, of Philadelphia by United States Judge Joseph Lord. Last week, Judge Lord meted out a 25year sentence to another Philadelphian, Kevin Williams, 19, for the same crime. They pleaded guilty to shooting Marine Cpl. Guy Douglas Browning, 19, of Detroit during the May 14 robbery.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: WALT WHITMAN was enthusiastic about Brooklyn Heights. As a boy he had lived for a time on Cranberry Street (the house is no longer standing), across from what is now Plymouth Church's backyard in 1861, he was pointing out to readers of The Brooklyn Standard that, from the earliest days of the white settlers, Manhattan (bleak, sterile and rough) was considered inferior for residential purposes to the western end of Long Island across the East River (a beautifully rich country, sufficiently diversified with slopes and hills  a superb paradise of a country).

title: News Summary
description: Corporations that have joined the Arab boycott of Israel will not be named by the Commerce Department. Apparently retreating from a pledge he made during the debate, President Ford directed the department to make public all future reports on boycott matters. A Commerce Department spokesman stressed the confidentiality of previous information filed. [Page A1, Cols. 45.]

title: Elderly South Bronx Couple Disregarded Advice to Move
description: News of the elderly couple in the South Bronx who had decided that dying together was preferable to continuing life as victims of crime blared yesterday from a radio the police had turned on in their apartment to scare away thieves.

title: Graduate Students At City University Decrease by 25%
description: The number of graduate students at the City University of New York has dropped by 25 percent this yeara figure Imore than nine times as much as officials had projected as part of the university's planned retrenchment.

title: Needlepoint From Pucci
description: Remember those madly patterned Pucci dresses everyone was slinking around in a while back? Now, any Pucci aficionados who are reasonably handy with a needle, yarn and canvas can perk up their home decor with similar designs.

title: Buckley Drops Request to Buy Time On W NET and Accepts Free Offer
description: The campaign committee of Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, yesterday withdrew its request for a series of fiveminute paid political commercials on Channel 13 and accepted instead a free 15minute program on the publictelevision station one night next week.

title: Schmalz is Man on the Spot for Jets
description: Greg Schmalz picked up a few million more fans yesterday, but few know who he is, what he does, or how he does it.

title: Hunting the Elusive Bottle Of Fine Italian Wine
description: Italy is the premier wine producing nation in the world. Italians are the biggest wine drinkers in the world. it follows that Italy should produce some extraordinary wines. it does. But you'd never know it here in New York.

title: Stage: Martial Arts of Kabuki
description: KABUKI drama from Japan is not new to this country. But it is doubtful that any presentation of Kabuki here has zoomed in on one specific convention of this highly stylized theater as did Martial Arts of Kabuki, the fascinating program, given at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night.

title: In Memoriam
description: LAGINESTRATheresa. Happy Birthday, Terri, our beloved late Advisory Board. Member from the staff and Advisory Board of the Mental Retardation Institute of New York Medical College. We continue to miss our bright and beautiful friend, the beloved and creative source of enthusiasm, Inspiration and encouragement in our struggite to care for the thousands of handicapped children who look to us for help. Your everpresent Influence guides us and warms our hearts. Accept our love.

title: TAXABATEMENT PLAN VOTED FOR PROJECTS
description: After a stormy afternoon session, the Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to approve Mayor Beame's proposal to restore or continue tax abatements worth $7.1 million to 60 MitchellLama housing projects throughout the city.

title: Medicaid Mismanagement Blamed by a House Panel For Crippling of Children
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 7 (UPI)Mismanagement in the Medicaid program allows the crippling, retardation and death of thousands of poor children who are entitled to help, a House subcommittee reported today.

title: Vietnam Describes Ford as Hostile
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 7 (Reuters)Vietnam's observer mission at the United Nations said today that the only obstacle to a solution of the question of United States servicemen missing in action was the Ford Administration's hostile policy toward Vietnam.

title: ExBrooklynite Seized in Buffalo In a New York Motel Murder
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 7 (UPI)  A former Brooklyn man was arrested here yesterday in the slaying of a Buffalo man in New York City on Sept. 22.

title: Dance: Erica Meyers and Trio Perform at Water St. Fountain
description: Erica Meyers and her trio (the other two members are Beth Davis and Deb Riley, created stylish squiggles of movements and repose Wednesday noon at the fountain at 55 Water Street. The two dances occupied the nautically appointed plaza with a mixture of casualness and concern.

title: In South Lebanon, an Odd War: Arab Soldiers With Israeli Arms
description: RUMAYSH, Lebanon, Oct. 7Lebanese soldiers in this region close to the Israeli border carry hand grenades, assault rifles and other weapons with Hebrew markings. Their uniforms and other equipment, down to canteens, are the standard issue of the Israeli armed forces.

title: At the Movies
description: WHERE were you the day James Dean died? For those in a mood for morbid reminiscence, the opportunity to relive that historic moment will be offered in 9/30/55, a new film directed by James Bridges and starring Richard Thomas as a worshiper of the sullen, charismatic actor who sped to his death a car crash two decades ago, but survives to this day as a vivid symbol of youthful rebellion.

title: Peru's Military Government Reports it Has Quelled a Communist Group Supporting Itself by Crime
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 7Peru's military Government said today that it had broken up a revolutionary group of Communists who were supported financially by bank robberies and smuggling of cocaine.

title: Manila Talks Rekindle SimonMcNamara Feud
description: MANILA, Oct. 7One of the most remarkable aspects of the 31st annual meeting of the world's two major financial institutions this week has been the absence of any significant, ooen controversy on the surface. It appears that all is sweetness and honey. However, there are some potentially divisive questions to be decided how to conduct an effective surveillance of individual countries currency operations, what action to take on the pending application for a big $3.9 billion I.M.F. drawing by Britain and how to accomplish an expansion of the capital resources of the World Bank and its affiliates.

title: Serail Fails To Be Haunting
description: There are a number of good names involved in Serail but the movie doesn't so much use them as drop them.

title: Retail Sales Rise is Cited Volume Declines
description: The stock market broke its recent losing streak yesterday on the strength of a Commerce Department report that retail sales rose markedly last week.

title: Charges Are Dismissed Against Mother of Infant Who Was Killed by a Dog
description: Upon the recommendation of the Manhattan District Attorney's office, a State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed homicide charges against Joanne Bashold, whose infant daughter was killed by her dog.

title: HERMAN GEIGERTOREL, 69, HEAD OF CANADIAN OPERA
description: TORONTO, Oct. 7 (Reuters)Herman GeigerTorel, general director emeritus of the Canadian Opera Company, died last night of a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: With baseball's Series looming on the NBCTV schedule, this weekend's sports focus is on the playoff games in the American League, the New York Yankees will play the Royals in Kansas City Saturday at 12:30 P.M. and Sunday at 9 P.M. Both games will be carried on Channel 7 and 11. For the National League, the Cincinnati Reds will play the Phillies in Philadelphia Saturday night at 8 and Sunday at 3:30 P.M., only on Channel 7.

title: Federal Agents Arrest Over 250 in Raids to Bar Flow of Mexican Heroin
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)  Federal narcotics agents today arrested more than 250 alleged dealers in Mexican heroin and said that the action bad struck a major blow at heroin smuggling operations in the country.

title: Moody's to Rate M.A.C. Bonds Despite Cancellation of Contract
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it would continue to evaluate Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds, despite an announcement by the corporation that it was canceling the contract under which the rating agency had issued its ratings in the past.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The spectacular public hanging of Palestinian terrorists in Damascus emphasizes an aspect of the reality of the Middle East which is crucial for the solution of the Palestine problem.

title: New Thai Junta Solidifies Rule; Curfew Lifted
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 7Thailand's new military rulers today began the complex task of consolidating the power they seized yesterday.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN CLARIFIES SPORTS INTEGRATION VIEW
description: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Oct. 7 (AP)A Government official declared today that South Africa's new sports policy, which Government supporters call a breakthrough in ending racial discrimination in sport, did not allow racial integration of teams without special approval in each case.

title: Pressure Grows for U.S. to Raise Exports of Huge Food Surpluses
description: Pressure is mounting on the Department of Agriculture to increase exports of the nation's growing food surpluses as bumper crops of grains and soybeans sharply reduce farm income just weeks before the Presidential election.

title: AUTO OUTPUT UP 11% IN WEEK DESPITE STRIKE
description: DETROIT. Oct. 7 American auto production increased 11 percent this week from last despite the strike by the United Automobile Workers Union against the Ford Motor Company, according to Automotive News.

title: Plane Sales to Congo Described
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)The C.I.A. declined comment on General Aircraft's charges.

title: Stage: Gelber's Rehearsal, A Play Within a Play
description: What is a play? How does it happen? What makes it work? These were the basic issues behind Jack Gelber's new play, which is called, beguilingly enough, Jack Gelber's New Play: Rehearsal. it is directed by the author. And it is not a rehearsal. But it tries to be the substance of a rehearsalwhich might be something less or might be something more. it opened last night at the American Place Theater.

title: Article 6  No Title
KALLINGER PULLS OUT JAGGED LENS AT TRIAL
description: HACKENSACK, Oct. 7With the jury in his murder trial watching, Joseph Kallinger was subdued today by sheriff's officers after he pulled a jagged piece of glass from his pocket.

title: New Thai Junta Solidifies Rule; Curfew Lifted
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 7Thailand's new military rulers today began the complex task of consolidating the power they seized yesterday.

title: Japan Demands Soviet Free Boat
description: TOKYO, Oct. 7 (Reuters)Japan today demanded the return of a fishing boat and its sevenmember crew seized by a Soviet patrol boat off Siberia last month, the Foreign Ministry reported, Earlier last month, a Soviet pilot defected to Japan in a topsecret MIG25 jet interceptor, which has been taken apart and examined by Japanese and Americans.

title: Investors Insurance Files A Suit to Block an Offer By Superior for Williams
description: The Investors Insurance Company of America of Teaneck, N.J., said yesterday that it had filed suit in United States Distrcit Court in Pittsburgh to halt the tender offer of the Superior Tube Company to purchase all the common shares.

title: Maddox Ruled Late in Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 7 (AP)Former Gov. Lester G. Maddox of Georgia waited too long to try to get on the Texas general election ballot as a candidate for President Federal District Judge Tom Gee ruled today. Judge Gee said it was impossible to place Mr. Maddox's name on the absentee ballot and there was a substantial chance that it could not be placed on the general election ballot in some counties.

title: White House Confirms I.R.S. Audit of Ford's Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  The White House confirmed today major elements of a newspaper account of an Internal Revenue Service audit of President Ford's income taxes. But, in a statement, the White House sought to rebut any suggestion of impropriety in Mr. Ford's tax history.

title: F.D.A. Moves to Curb Danger From Mercury Vapor Lamps
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration moved today to protect consumers from damaged mercury vapor lamps, which have been responsible for at least 100 iniuries.

title: Article 5  No Title
Buckley and Moynihan Debate Role of Government
description: In a literate, lively and often witty debate, Senator James L. Buckley and his Democratic opponent, Daniel P. Moynihan, disagreed fundamentally yesterday on various domestic issues, but displayed wide agreement on foreign affairs, particularly the continuing threat of the Soviet Union.

title: 2 Affluent Communities Enriched by U.S. Aid
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y. After creating twin municipal governments to help themselves win jurisdictional disputes, two welltodo Westchester County communities have suddenly found that the arrangements are bringing them 30 to 50 percent more money in state and Federal revenuesharing money.

title: ETHNIC GROUPS SCORE FORD ON EUROPE VIEW
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 7Eastern European ethnic groups reacted with astonishment and derision today to President Ford's twicestated assertion last night that the Soviet Union did not hold dominance over the nations of Eastern Europe.

title: Allon, at U.N., Avoids Attack That Would Give P.L.O. Chance to Speak
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 7Israel argued its case before the General Assembly today, carefully avoiding a direct attack on the Palestine Liberation Organization that could have given that nonmember organization a chance to take the rostrum.

title: Nigerian Assails Kissinger Secrecy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 7Nigeria's Commissioner for External Affairs today attacked the secrecy surrounding Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's negotiations on southern Africa and complained that he might have impaired efforts to secure early independence for Namibia, as SouthWest Africa is known here.

title: Rhodesia Says Rebels Bomb Bridge, Sending Train Crashing Into River
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 7 (UPI)Rhodesian security forces said today that black nationalist guerrillas blew up a concreteandsteel railroad bridge yesterday as an ore train was crossing the Matetsi River.

title: Stars and Stripes Chief in Europe Quits After Dispute Over Articles
description: BONN, Oct. 7The editor in chief of the United States armed forcessponsored newspaper. The Stars and Stripes, left his job a week early today after his superiors complained that they bad not been warned about publication of a series of articles on the black market for Army goods in Europe.

title: Sports Today
description: Julio (Diablo) Valdez vs. Felix Figueroa, junior lightweights, 10 rounds, at Sunnyside Garden, Queens Boulevard and 45th Street, Sunnyside, Queens. First preliminary, 8:30 P.M.

title: ETHNIC GROUPS SCORE FORD ON EUROPE VIEW
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 7Eastern European ethnic groups reacted with astonishment and derision today to President Ford's twicestated assertion last night that the Soviet Union did not hold dominance over the nations of Eastern Europe.

title: Knicks Beat Nets With Speed, 112107
description: Are the Knicks abandoning their pattern offense for more of a running game? Will Spencer Haywood be the starting center?

title: Britain Sees Gains in North Sea Oil
description: LONDON, Oct 7 (Reuters)By the end of the decade Britain's offshore oil, by official forecasts, could he earning each year more than double the $3,9 billion the Government is now trying to borrow from the International Monetary Fund and ending the dependence on foreign oil that is now contributing heavily to Britain's economic difficulties.

title: HARRY STEELE
description: Harry Steele, president of H. Steele & Co. of Mexico City, the largest distributor of timepieces in Mexico, died in New York City Tuesday while on a business trip. He was 86 years old.

title: Soybean Prices Up for 4th Day; Corn Also Gains
description: Soybean prices rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade for the fourth day in a row. The November contract closed at 56.56, up 7 cents, after being as high as $6.62

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on student loans in The Times Wednesday stated incorrectly that a bill awaiting President Ford's signature would retain a maximum loan limit of $15,000 for graduate education. The present limit is $10,000; the pending bill would increase it'to $15,000.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for 10776.

title: Restaurants
description: S O MUCH FOR the glitter and the glamour. If there is one fact firmly established about the newly refurbished Tavern on the Green in Central Park, it is that it is a gorgeous and glorious wonderland of sparkling crystal chandeliers and frosted mirrors with garlands of blossoms, handsome wood carvings and glittering brass.

title: Women to Be Taught Men's Work
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 7That Westchester County Parkway policeman pulling you over for speeding on the Taconic State Parkway may be a Westchester County Parkway policewoman in the near future. Similarly, a woman may be restoring service atop a telephone pole in front of your house or delivering milk around the back at dawn.

title: Montefiore Hospital Averts Strike; Walkouts Continue at 3 Institutions
description: Officials of Montefiore Hospital reached agreement yesterday with interns and resident physicians to recognize their union, averting a threatened strike there, while a strike by such physicians at three other private nonprofit hospitals continued into its third day.

title: Mississippi Paper Supports Ford
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 7 (UPI)The Jackson Daily News endorsed President Ford yesterday, saying it had suffered a period of disenchantment concerning the gentleman from Georgia, Jimmy Carter.

title: A Run for the Finish
description: I came away from the first CarterFord debate without any strong convictions about it, but feeling rather vaguely that President Ford had performed somewhat more strongly, while Jimmy Carter had not suffered much damage and might have been picking up speed just before the sound went off.

title: Tragedy and Comedy Open In New Haven
description: TRADITIONALLY, New Haven was the tryout town. Musicals, comedies and even dramas would test their strengthsand presumably discover their weaknessesin New Haven before coming to Broadway. After opening night at the Shubert Theater, the author, director and friends from New York would gather in the Taft Hotel to wait for reviews. Depending on the verdict, frantic rewrites might start immediately.

title: For Children
Montefiore Selected to Provide Medical Staff for Bronx Hospital
description: The board of directors of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation decided yesterday to allow Montefiore Hospital, rather than Misericordia Hospital, to provide the medical staff for the new North Central Bronx Hospital, overruling Wednesday's decision by the corporation's president.

title: Ruling Against Model HighRise Disputes Federal Housing Ideas
description: MINNEAPOLISThe tall towers of Cedar Riverside stand out boldly against the small houses surrounding them, their sharply detailed concrete forms intended to herald a new age for urban housing.

title: Art: An Expatriate On Native Grounds
description: N OT ALL OF THE BEST painting by American artists is being produced in New York these days, or even in the United States. The great age of expatriate artists communities may belong to a distant past, but there are still individual painters and sculptors who find it agreeable to live and work abroad. Whatever the lurethe museums, the exchange rate, the art market, the climate or the vagaries of personal tasteEurope still beckons certain talents, and offers them a kind of comfort, solace and inspiration they do not find on home ground.

title: Action on Move, for First Time, is in Concert
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange announced in separate but simultaneous statements yesterday the formation of committees to study the possibility of merging.

title: Art People
description: T HERE WAS A PERIOD when who the hell ever listened to jazz, recalls the painter Norman Lewis. I danced to Duke Ellington! As the remark indicates, Mr. Lewis goes back a way. As a young Harlemite in the 1930's, he quit playing pool to take up painting and has never stopped since, progressing from outandout political art, which depicted the plight of the poor, to the lyrical abstract work that today reflects purely esthetic concerns. Now, at 67. Mr. Lewis is having his first retrospective show, opening Tuesday in the pedestrian mall of the City University Graduate Center at 33 West 42d Street.

title: U.S. AND PANAMA SET NEW TALKS ON CANAL
description: The United States and Panama agreed yesterday to resume negotiations in the next two weeks on a new Panama Canal treaty.

title: A Date That Lives in Infamy
description: For the first time, the New York Yankees are halfchampions of the American Leagu'e. After standing around all week with their mouths full of teeth, they will set out tomorrow in quest of the half they still must win to represent their tong in the World Series. While they dawdled, waiting for their electronic masters to focus the weekend television cameras, an anniversary passed. Chances are Oct 5, 1941, exactly 35 years ago last Tuesday, had no special meaning to any Yankee of today, though it may have been noted by Phil Rizzuto, the broadcaster, who played shortstop that day. it is a date that lives in infamy in Brooklyn, for that was the day Hugh Casey threw a third strike past Tommy Henrich to complete a 43 victory for the Dodgers and square the World Series with the Yankees at two games each. But Casey also threw it past his catcher, Mickey. Owen.

title: Aircraft Company Says C.I.A. U Used Its Name as Cover
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7A Massachussetts aircraft corporation is claiming $25 million damages from the Central Intelligence Agency for the alleged wrongful use of its name for cover operations during the 1960's, its lawyers here said today.

title: Open Interest
description: (in ????) Wed.

title: CARTER SEEN ENDING EROSION OF HIS LEAD BY TAKING OFFENSIVE
description: The precipitous slide in Jimmy Carter's fortunes, which cost him most of a lead that seemed insurmountable in July, appears to have stopped.

title: New Leader in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 7Several months ago, a crew from Bangkok's Metropolitan Electricity Authority found it would have to turn off the voltage in a group of select houses along a small lane on the outskirts of the city. They approached one of the houses with trepidation. it was occupied by a senior Thai military official and such officials are not used to being told that they will have to do without something, particularly by a governmental organization. But when the problem was explained, the official, a chunky man with closecropped hair and a broad face, smiled, observed that it was all for the public good, the electricity went off and the work was quickly completed.

title: HUMPHREY'S BLADDER REMOVED IN SURGERY
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey underwent radical surgery here yesterday to remove his bladder for the treatment of cancer.

title: The Foreign Policy Debate
description: The televised debate in San Francisco Wednesday night between the two major Presidential candidates was far more illuminating to the American electorate and gave a far clearer presentation of the views of Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carterthan the first in this series of joint appearances two weeks ago in Philadelphia.

title: A Celebration of Femaleness In Dr. DensenGerber's Book
description: Dr. Judianne DensenGerber confides in her new book Walk in My Shoes that her brand of feminism includes fantasies that range from being an amoeba to being an elephant. The amoeba impresses her with its immortalitythroughendlessreproduction. Elephants, pregnant for 22 months, make her jealous of their long specialness and fill her with admiration for their need for auntie elephants to help with delivery and child care: Females aiding females. That is the message of sisterhood, and the elephants have done it already.

title: Graham Shrugs Off Carter Son's Remark
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 7 (AP)The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham, the evangelist, said today that he held no ill feeling toward Jimmy Carter's son over a remark questioning his doctor of divinity degree.

title: Britain Takes Harsh Steps to Aid Pound
description: LONDON, Oct. 7The British Government imposed harsh and unprecedented restraints on its ailing economy today. It was the boldest effort yet to protect the pound and to salvage an economic policy that has suddenly shown signs of coming undone.

title: Jack Rosenthal Gets New Job on The Times
description: Jack Rosenthal, associate editor of The New York Times and editor of The Times Magazine, will become assistant editor of the editorial page effective early next year.

title: French Sign Iran ADeal, Assail U.S.
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 7 (Reuters)President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France said today that he had signed deals with the Shah of Iran worth $8 billion, including the construction of eight nuclear power plants.

title: Rhodesia, Two Weeks Later: Dismay for Some, Hope for Others and Bewilderment for Nearly All
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 7The backtracking and backbiting in the two weeks that have passed since Prime Minister Ian D. Smith stunned Rhodesians with his announcement of majority rule within two years have dispelled the euphoria of those who greeted it as the way outeven if not the one many whites had hoped forof an impasse of international ostracism and rising guerrilla warfare.

title: U.S. Women Lead by 7
description: VILAMOURA. Portugal, Oct. 7 (AP)Nancy Lopez shot a twooverpar 75 today and led the American team to a sevenstroke lead over France after two rounds of the women's world amateur team golf championship.

title: Irwin and Floyd Gain Golf Semifinals
description: VIRGINIA WATERS, England, Oct. 7 (UPI)Hale Irwin and Ray Floyd scored narrow victories today and reached the semi finals of the $127,500 Piccadilly world matchplay golf tournament.

title: Economic Catalyst
description: The appointment of Osborn Elliott, mactazine editor and chairman of the voluntary Citizens Committee for New York City, to the newly created post of Deputy Mayor for Economic Development signals the beginning of a longawaited fresh approach to the crucial task reviving this city's flagging economy.

title: Article 1  No Title
New York State Official Calls the City Permissive On WelfareCheck Fraud
description: The State Welfare Inspector General, Richard V. Horan, charged yesterdaythat New York City had been wantonly permissive in dealing with welfarecheck frauds and assailed what he called maladministration and lackadaisical pursuit of offenders.

title: Government Tells Italians Sacrifices Will Be Needed
description: ROME, Oct. 7The Italian Government, faced with a new drop in the lira, is moving once again to try to bolster confidence and persuade Italians that they may have to accept some austerity.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Oct. 7Policemen and firemen demonstrated outside the state capitol today for a bill that would allow them to retire on half pay after 20 years.

title: U.S. Study Projects a Worsening Of Deficit in Industrialized Lands
description: MANILA, Oct. 7A new United States analysis, not yet fully supported by the International Monetary Fund, projects significant improvement next year in the balanceofpayments situation of the less developed countries that do not produce oil and an equally important worsening of the collective payments deficit of the industrialized countries.

title: In South Lebanon, an Odd War: Arab Soldiers With Israeli Arms
description: RUMAYSH, Lebanon, Oct. 7Lebanese soldiers in this region close to the Israeli border carry hand grenades, assault rifles and other weapons with Hebrew markings. Their uniforms and other equipment, down to canteens, are the standard issue of the Israeli armed forces.

title: Today's Slipcovers Glamorize Even Furniture That's New
description: If the word slipcovers brings to mind an artless disguise for a tattered sofa, you're behind the times. Of course, grandmother always had a set that was removed dutifully around this time of year and put into mothballs. They looked baggy, the seams puckered and they never seemed to stay put on the sofa.

title: Shorter Workweek: Breakthrough by Labor
description: A shorter workweek has been a ritualistic part of the collective bargaining program of every major union since the birth of the modern labor movement nearly a century ago. Yet no general breakthrough toward reducing worktime has been made since the passage in 1938 of the Fair Labor Standards Act estatblishing a fiveday, 40hour basic schedule throughout interstate industry.

title: Steve Lobell is Seeking A Triple Crown Today
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 7 (UPI)Eight challengers, including trotting's fastest filly, are scheduled to start tomorrow in the. $100,000 Kentucky Futurity in an effort to stop Steve Lobell's bid for trotting's triple crown.

title: A Surprising Dartmouth In Key Ivy Test With Yale
description: An observer at Princeton last week noted, It looks as though everybody underestimated Dartmouth. The remark followed the news of Dartmouth's rout of Holy Cross, keeping the Big Green's record unsullied in three games. Tomorrow Dartmouth faces Yale in New Haven, a key test for both teams in the Ivy League race to unseat Harvard, the defending champion. The Crimson plays host to Cornell; undefeated Brown faces victoryless Penn and Columbia and Princeton tangle at Baker Field.

title: Screen: A 'Shadow of the Hawk'
description: A threshold of fright so minimal that it is bestirred by a jack-in-the-box or a Halloween mask seems to be the pre-requisite for enjoyment of "Shadow of the Hawk," now playing at an assortment of local theaters.To make a long and rather tedious story short, this seems to be the Indian version of "The Exorcist," with chief Dan George as the old medicine man who journeys to the big city to bring back his grandson, played by Jan-Michael Vincent, to apply the strength of youth against a wily evil sorceress named Dsonoqua.At no time is there any question about the outcome of this 200-year-old family feud. But as grandfather and grandson proceed, accompanied by a freelance woman journalist, masks come out of the woods and mist, snakes and bears attack, Indians with white-painted faces appear and disappear, humans take on animal form and cars do strange things. There are incantations and machinations with tiny dolls.The director, George McCowan, tends to be better at conveying eeriness with cinematic devices, such as a car that appears and disappears and finally crashes into an invisible wall, than he is at conjuring up terror with the myriad Indian props at his disposal. Dsonaqua is too ill-defined to be taken seriously as a match for the old medicine man and the new. "Shadow of the Hawk" settles for minor intermittent surprises instead of cumulative horror. The PG rating may be attributable to the general intent of the film, rather than to any particular excesses of language, violence or sexual activity.

title: Publishing: Joan Didion Doesn't Waste Words
description: THAT largish extract from a new novel in the current Harper's by Joan Didion (Play It as it Lays, Slouching Towards Bethlehem) is not from a work in progress. it is from the finished work and Simon & Schuster will be bringing the book out in March as A Book of Common Prayer.

title: LEONARD LYONS DIES; COLUMNIST 40 YEARS
description: Leonard Lyons, whose Broadway column The Lyons Den appeared in The New York Post and scores of other new spapers for 40 years, died yesterday at his home on Central Park West after a long illness, He was 70 years old.

title: McRae of Royals is a Good Hitter on Basepaths, Too
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 7When George Brett and Hal McRae, the American League's top two hitters this year face the Yankees in the playoffs starting Saturday, the way the batting championship was decided between them won't hold any significance. Great significance, however, could lie in the possible reason behind the way the title was decidedMcRae's aggressive style of play.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.Listed to speak: Chad, Burma, Panama, Uganda, Mali, Byelorussia, Bhutan, GuineaBissau, Honduras.

title: PRICES AT WHOLESALE UP 0.9% LAST MONTH, MOST SINCE FALL 75
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  Wholesale prices increased in September by ninetenths of 1 percent, their largest rise in nearly a year, the Labor Department reported today.

title: JACOB BERGER
description: Jacob Berger, a retired partner in the Rex Stroll Chair Manufacturing Company in New York City, died yesterday in Columbia Presbyterian Hospital after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 600 West 246th Street, Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Cards Pick Rapp, Giants Altobelli As 77 Managers
description: Choosing not to follow the popular practice of choosing a manager from among name players or recently discarded bench bosses, the St. Louis Cardinals and the San Francisco Giants yesterday turned to the minor leagues to fill vacancies.

title: Le Baseball is Not Yet Big, but it is Catching on as a Pastime in France
description: PARIS. Oct. 5 Jacques Martineau is jumping up and down near the equivalent of the dugout, flailing with his fists in the air and yelling: Cours, Pascal! Ne t'arretes jamais! (Run, Pascal. Don't ever stop.)

title: U.S. Mediation in Africa Denounced by Brezhnev As Fictitions Liberation
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party leader, today assailed United States mediation efforts in southern Africa as an attempt to substitute a fictitious liberation that would actually perpetuate white supremacy there.

title: Advertising
description: Bernard Goldberg believes in advertising but doesn't think it can insure a product's success. He commissions consumer research, but doesn't feel hound by the results. And he trusts his own intuition over test marketing and has a string of successful product introductions behind him.

title: Both Made Factual Mistakes And Misleading Statements
description: At one point in their foreign policy debate Wednesday night, Jimmy Carter said that Mr. Ford, unfortunately, just made a statement that's not true. President Ford's statement was incorrect, in fact, but both candidates produced inaccurate and misleading figures and statements throughout their exchanges.

title: A Stage Set For Dining
description: Less has never been more to Warner LeRoy, whose creation of Maxwell's Plum a decade ago gave New York its first respectably silly dining room. Before Maxwell's, the characteristic New York restaurants were either serious places designed by architects, like the Four Seasons; posh essays in the red banquette school of interior design, like La Cote Basque, or ethnic holes in the wall like everyone's little place in Chinatown with no tablecloths.

title: Nuclear War is Inescapable, Swedish Group Asserts
description: STOCKHOLM, Friday, Oct. 8 (Reuters) About 35 countries will be able to make atomic weapons within nine years and nuclear war will become inevitable, the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute forecast today.

title: Card of Thanks
description: MARKOWITZMrs. Jacob, Deeply appreciates and gratefully acknowledeges your kind expressions of sympathy on the loss of her dearly beloved husband Judge Jacob Markowitz.

title: State Seeks an Overhaul of Auto Insurance Ratings
description: TRENTON, Oct. 7New Jersey's Commissioner of Insurance called today for major revisions in the classification and territory system used by insurance companies in determining the cost of automobile coverage.

title: KALLINGER PULLS OUT JAGGED LENS AT TRIAL
description: HACKENSACK N.J., Oct. 7With the jury in his murder trial watching, Joseph Kallinger was subdued today by sheritf's officers after he pulled a jagged piece of glass from his Docket.

title: Excerpts From Debate by Buckley and Moynihan on Issues in Campaign for Senate
description: BUCKLEY: You speak about the right to organize. And I respect the right to organize, and I believe it was a constructive development in the 1930's. But I also believe that we should respect certain rights inherent in our Federal system. Specifically, would you advocate, would you vote for pending legislation that would extend the right to organize and strike to municipal and state employees?

title: Ford,Trying to Bind Up Wound, Backs Freedom for East Europe
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7President Ford made an effort today to bind up a political wound suffered in the second Presidential debate by expressing firm support for Eastern European aspirations for freedom from domination by the Soviet Union.

title: A Sanctuary For Sport Or Solitude
description: Some people come just for the solitude, Anthony J. (Buzz) Buzzanco insisted recently over the din at the Westmoreland Sanctuary near Mount Kisco, N.Y. The directornaturalist was referring to the seven miles of paths in the midWestchester reserve, not the commotion outside his office.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Newark City Councilman Jess L. Allen, 45 years old, was charged in an Essex County grand jury indictment yesterday with carrying a loaded .38caliber pistol without a permit. Mr. Allen was arrested by policemen who questioned him about a bulge under his jacket when he approached them as they were ticketing his car for a parking violation on July 18.

title: M'CARTHY, AS CANDIDATE, GETTING U.S. PROTECTION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)Eugene J. McCarthy will get Secret Service protection, but another independent Presidential candidate, Lester G. Maddox, will not the Treasury Department said today.

title: An ExJersey DeathRow Inmate Charged in California Stabbing
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 7 (UPI)Edgar Smith, who went free in 1971 after 14 years on New Jersey's death row, was charged today with abducting and stabbing a Woman.

title: Salutes to New Museum
description: Following is a list of some museums and cultural institutions that will hold satellite exhibitions to mark the opening of the CooperHewitt Museum:

title: Ford Seems to Retreat on Pledge Of Disclosures in Arabs Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Despite an apparent pledge by President Ford during last night's debate, the Commerce Department said today that it would not disclose the names of United States companies that have participated in the Arab boycott of Israel.

title: Court Finds StaviskyGoodman Law Never in Effect
description: The Appellate Division in Manhattan unanimously ruled yesterday that the StaviskyGoodman Law, which had already been declared invalid by a lowercourt judge, never took effect because Governor Carey's veto of the bill last spring was never legally overridden.

title: Commodity Price Index Declines 1.7 From the WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstaffs and industrial materials fell to 198.1 from 199.8 last week.

title: Enforcing ChildSupport
description: For two decades, administrations and Congressional committees have produced specious solutions to the socalled welfare problem. The welfare nostrum of the last decade was work incentives. Recipients would be able to keep a portion of earnings, so they would themselves feel impelled to work. Between 1967 and 1974, the Government paid out $5.3 billion for the incentive arrangement without notable effect on caseloads. Apparently, gimmicks will not keep people off welfare while we run a 7 or 8 percent unemployment rate.

title: 6 Ways to Enjoy Autumn's Wonders
description: Tour I: A short tour through the Westchester County, a comfortable afternoon's drive.

title: MAN HELD IN ROBBERIES AT 35 MIDTOWN OFFICES
description: A 22yearold nnn suspected of holding up more than 35 midtown New York offices over the last three months was arrested yesterday, minutes after he had allegedly held up two offices in a Fifth Avenue building.

title: On the Fall Foliage Trail
description: As the days grow shorter and the nights colder, the annual colorful spectacle of autumn foliage is beginning to unfold in upstate New York, with a tide of crimson, gold, scarlet and yellow sweeping south to the metropolitan area.

title: Scorers Named for Playoffs
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 7 (UPI)Phil Pepe of The New York Daily News and Sid Bordman of the Kansas City Star were named official scorers today for the American League playoffs.

title: The Economic Scene
description: A notable aspect of the meeting in Manila of th World Bank and the International Monetary Fund has been the absenceon the surface, at least of opens controversy. Page D4.

title: BOARD IS UNDECIDED ON M'CARTHY PETITION
description: After meeting for 12 hours, the New York State Board of Elections left unsettied yesterday the question of whether Eugene J. McCarthy, the former Senator, would appear on the Nov. 2 election ballot in the state as an independent candidate for President.

title: Cook Gets Pirates Post
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 7 (UP)The Pittsburgh Pirates named Murray Cook today as director of minor league clubs, succeeding Harding Peterson, who has been named vice president in charge of player personnel. Cook had been assistant director of minor league clubs since 1969.

title: Nigeria Drafts Democratic Charter Keyed to Restoring of Civilian Rule
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 7The military Government released today the draft of a new constitution, a voluminous and painstakingly prepared document that would turn Nigeria into Africa's foremost multiparty democracy.

title: Bridge:
description: The country that takes bridge more seriously than any other is Sweden. The Swedish team is always one of the best in Europe, largely because every encouragement is given to young players.

title: Trevino is Sharp
description: INZAI, Japan, Oct. 7 (AP)Lee Trevino used a hot putter to run off five birdies over the last nine holes and move into a share of the lead with Allen Miller after the first round of the $300,000 Pacific Masters golf tournament today.

title: Dodgers Hire Gomez
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 (AP)The Los Angeles Dodgers said today that Preston Gomez, a former coach, had rejoined the staff. Gomez, who served as a Dodger coach under Walter Alston from 1965 through 1966 will join Red Adams, Monty Basgall and Jim Gilliam on Manager Tommy Lasorda's staff.

title: The Composer Turns SoHo Cabaret Performer In Broadway at the Ballroom Series
description: In the 12 years since Fiddler on the Roof opened in 1964, tens of thousands of people have seen the musical unaware that they were missing a song to Tevye's horse that was cut out before the show even went into rehearsal.

title: BOND MARKET GAINS, BUOYED BY M1 DROP
description: Buoyed by the continued decline in the nation's money supply and scarcely disturbed by the steep rise in the wholesale price index, the bond market continued its strong advance yesterday. An issue of Aarated electric utility bonds was offered to investors at a yield of S.33 percentthe lowest for such an investment in two and a half years and it was threequarters sold by late afternoon. And municipal bond interest rates declined to their lowest levels since early 1975.

title: HumanRights and Morality Issue Runs Through FordCarter Debate
description: The theme of human rights and morality in foreign policy ran throughout the debate between President Ford and Jimmy Carter, as it has throughout the election year. Their two approaches embodied profoundly different philosophies of foreign policy and conflicting tendencies in American history.

title: LAWYER IS INDICTED ON PAYOFF CHARGE
description: A prominent lawyer in the nursinghome industry was indicted yesterday on charges stemming from a $5,000 payoff allegedly made to an unnamed public official to gain approval of a Bronx nursing home.

title: Ruling Against Model HighRise Disputes Federal Housing Ideas
description: MINNEAPOLISThe tall towers of Cedar Riverside stand out boldly against the small houses surrounding them, their sharply detailed concrete forms intended to herald a new age for urban housing.

title: 2 Viking Sites on Mars Alike in Iron Content
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 7 (AP)An Xray instrument on the Viking 2 lander told scientists yesterday that the ironrich topsoil at the Utopia landing site strikingly resembles that found around the Viking 1 site, 4,600 miles away.

title: Weekend Gardening
description: This weekend I'm stripping my flower beds for the winter. Last year I skipped that step, and it made a difference; this summer the weeds were more persistent, and spider mites and phlox mildew made their appearance for the first time in years. So it's out with the clippers and shovel and manure tomorrow.

title: Rail Freight Traffic is Off 0.8%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.6 billion tonmiles, off 0.8 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 488,614 cars, 3.5 percent below last year, The American Trucking Association inc., reported that. intercity truck tonnage was 5.5 percent above last year.

title: CARTER ASSAILS FORD ON SERIOUS BLUNDER
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 7Jimmy Carter, eagerly seizing the campaign initiative, accused President Ford today of insensitivity to human aspirations and political oppression.

title: Management
description: A knotty problem for many managers is the disgruntled employee who leaves the company and takes his knowledge or some customerswith him. One method of limiting such risks has been to make the employee sign at contract limiting his right to compete and to solicit customers when he leaves.

title: Brazilian Police Seize an Issue Of Weekly on Censorship Grounds
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 7 (AP)The federal police confiscated 40,000 copies of Opiniao, a political weekly, today on the ground that it violated censorship rules.

title: Events and Openings
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, Carnegie Hall, 8:38.

title: CARTER SEEN ENDING EROSION OF HIS LEAD BY TAKING OFFENSIVE
description: The precipitous slide in Jimmy Carter's fortunes, which cost him most of a lead that seemed insurmountable in July, appears to have stopped.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)The National Education Association said today that it had contributed $50,000 to help the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People appeal a court judgment in Mississippi.

title: Art: Beyond Good And Bad Taste
description: FRANK STELLA'S NEW WORK at Knoedler's, 19 East 70th Street, brings back to the uptown art scene a quality that seemed to have left it forever provocation.

title: Rep. Meyner is Given Good Chance of Keeping Seat Despite Strong Challenge by Her G.O.P. Opponent
description: LAMBERTVILLE, Oct. 7The 13th Congressional District was carved out by Republican majorities in the State Legislature especially for Joseph J. Maraziti. But when Representative Maraziti was found to have a woman friend on his payroll in a noshow job, it helped tip the 1974 election to Helen Stevenson Meyner, a Democrat, who won by more than 20,000 votes in the postWatergate climate.

title: Officers Changed Sides at Precinct Protest as Shift Ended
description: The noisy demonstration by angry offduty police officers outside the 17th Precinct station on East 51st Street fell strangely silent early yesterday morning as the Police Department changed work shifts and the antagonists changed sides.

title: Car Trials Are Postponed
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 7 (AP)Rain today washed out the second day of time trials for Sunday's National 500 Grand National stock car race and the run for the pole position in Saturday's $125,000 World Service Life 300 Sportsman race. Qualifying for positions 2140 for the 500mile race and for positions 110 for the 300miler were rescheduled for tomorrow morning.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The North Jersey Federation of Senior Citizens is planning a tax convention in December aimed at supplanting the recently passed state income tax with legislation acceptable to all elements of the society.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (APP)  Money rates for Oct. 8, 1976.

title: Bruins Suing to Obtain Compensation for Orr
description: BOSTON, Oct. 8 (AP)The Boston Bruins filed suit in United States District Court today, seeking to bar Bobby Orr from playing with the Chicago Black Hawks until the Boston club is compeesated for the star defenseman in accordance with National Hockey League rules.

title: Swedish Premier Names Cabinet, Outlines Policy
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 8 (Reuters)Sweden's new Prime Minister, Thorbjorn Falldin, presented to Parliament today a 20member Cabinet including five women and delivered a policy speech that abandoned his electioncampaign insistence on halting the spread of nuclear power plants.

title: ...But This Writer Asks, What Radicals?
description: MEDFORD, Mass.I am known for tolerance and geniality, but I confess one recent refrain has infuriated me. After witnessing the Democrats in convention born again, many commentators were troubled. Their somber query: Where have all the radicals gone?

title: 200 Guards From Rikers I. End Revolt at Bronx Jail
description: More than 200 guards from Rikers Island forced rebellious inmates at the Bronx House of Detention back into their cells yesterday following weeks of intermittent protests over allegedly high bails and long trial delays in the court system and visiting rights at the jails.

title: Small Midwest Breweries Are Fighting for Survival
description: MONROE, Wis.Hattie's Bar and Grill, on busy State Route 69 in this small town near the Illinois line, has its name on a sign that advertises Old Style beer.

title: Today's College Football Games at a Glance
description: COMMENT

title: Closed End Funds
description: Week ended Oct. 8, 1976

title: Banks Report on Their Earnings and Revenues
description: For periods ended Sept. 30

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1976

title: State Police Report Road Deaths In 1975 Lowest in Over Ten Years
description: TRENTON. Oct. 8The New Jersey state police reported today that last year the state had the lowest number of motorvehicle fatalities in more than a decade. They attributed the decrease to the public's observance of the national 55mileanhour speed limit, increased police enforcement of the speed limits, improved highways and better emergency medical care.

title: It's Pop Art Porcelain And Paper Plate Chic
description: No hostess worth her salt would dream of setting a table with milk cartons and the disposable containers used for takeout orders of cole slaw and french fries. And as for paper plates, perish the thought! They're not to be countenanced except for picnics and cookouts.

title: Detroit Mayor's Bid for Reelection Linked to Controversy Over Police
description: DETROIT, Oct. 9Recent developments surrounding this city's police department have suddenly raised questions about the political future of Coleman A. Young, Detroit's first black Mayor. With the start of his reelection campaign already in sight, what happens in the next few weeks could have a decisive effect on his chances in the election next year.

title: Philadelphians Rally to Ailing Hotel
description: PHILADELPHIA., Oct. 8  Nearly 1,000 prominent Philadelphians went to a getwell party last night, a gala staged by the city's society, business and labor establishments to help the ailing Bellevue Stratford Hotel.

title: F.D.I.C. Set to Advance Funds In Hamilton Bank Takeover
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it would advance about $22.4 million to facilitate the takeover of the failed Hamilton Bank and Trust Company of Atlanta by the National Bank of Georgia.

title: Arab Boycott Demands in U.S. Are Ordered Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Commerce Department, responding to a directive by President Ford, issued rules today that require that all demands for participation in the Arab boycott received by American companies on or after Oct. 7 be made available for public scrutiny.

title: Grain, Soybean Markets Lose Strength in Chicago; Crop Report Due Monday
description: After four days of strength in the grain and soybean markets, prices moved down yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade under the impact of profit taking. Before a weekend speculators like to even up and be out of the market.

title: A Crystal Tomb for Mao's Body
description: PEKING, Oct. 8China announced tonight that the body of Mao Tsetung would be placed in a crystal sarcophagus and displayed in a mausoleum to be constructed in Peking.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT DENVER

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1976

title: Polarization in Spain
description: The 5,000 rightists who in a Madrid manifestation this week demanded the ouster of the Government and military rule in Spain have dramatized the intractable political problem confronting King Juan Carlos and Prime Minister Adolfo Surez Gonzlez.

title: Old Steamer Will Cruise Up the Hudson
description: Steamboat Bills and Belles are gathering today for a blasta rare Hudson River fall foliage cruise all the way to Albany with a return trip tomorrow.

title: Wabash to Buy Assets Of Avnet Division

title: Miss Fromholz Tops Mrs. King
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 8Billie Jean King was beaten today, just two matches after making her comeback to bigtime tournament singles. It was more a massacre inthis S75,000 Talley tournament than a match as Dianne Fromholz, the redhaired Australian who turned 20 in August, won, 63, 62, in 40 minutes. Afterward, the victor. declared, I thought I would win, but I expected it to go three sets with a lot of tough games. Maybe something was wrong with her leg.

description: Sunday store openings, begun by major retailers Aug. 29 and joined by additional retailers since, have helped sales in New York City and the metropolitan area.
