title: 2d Debate Showed a Change of Character
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8If the cycle of Presidential debates can be viewed for argument's sake as a television serial, then the second episode Wednesday night can be said to have turned on the development it showed in the character of the challenger, Jimmy Carter.

title: State Changing Idea on Staffing Bronx Hospital
description: In a further reversal, the New York State Health Department told the Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday it wanted Misericordia Hospital, and not Montefiore, to provide professional staff for the yetunopened North Central Bronx Hospital.

title: About New York
description: Bob Greenman, a teacher at James Madison High School in Brooklyn, hitched a ride to work down Bedford Avenue the other morningfrom the same house he lived in 20 years ago when he attended the same schooland never once did he think of the city fiscal crisis and such melodramatic questions as Will New York survive?

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Paterson man was held for possible grand jury action yesterday on charges of kidnapping and murdering an 11yearold girl and her brother in March 1975. William Cruz Pantoja, 29 years old, was placed in the Hudson County Jail following arraignment before Judge Rudolph Naddeo of Hoboken Municipal Court and Judge Robert Simeone of Union City Municipal Court. The Hudson County Prosecutor, James O'Halloran said that Mr. Cruz did not file an application for bail.

title: RELAXATION IS URGED IN WORLDBANK RATES
description: MANILA, Oct. 8Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, told the finance ministers of the less developed countries today that the bank could relax the recent hardening of its lending terms once the United States and a few other industrial countries agreed upon an increase in the bank's capital.

title: Grace Bumbry Receives Ovation In Debut in Bolshoi's Don Carlos
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8Grace Bumbry, the American soprano, made her debut tonight with the Bolshoi Opera Company in the role of Princess Eboli in Verdi's Don Carlo.

title: Study Suggests Ways to Slash Con Ed's Costs
description: The final phase of a management study of the Consolidated Edison Company has concluded that the utility could reduce costs or improve revenues by at least $27.6 million a year.

title: PROTESTERS GREET BUTZ IN MISSISSIPPI
description: GREENVILLE, Miss., Oct. 8Earl L. Butz, in his first public appearance since resigning as Secretary of Agriculture, slipped past demonstrators today to reach a news conference here but then met a barrage of tough questions, many of them from the same protesters, about the racial slur that led to his downfall.

description: Questions are based on news reported in The Times during the last week.

description: Filling one of New York's cultural vacuumsentertainment for children between the ages of 10 and whenever they are deemed old enough to venture out at night on their ownis the goal of an afternoon concert series that starts at Town Hall at 2 P.M. today.

description: New York City reached agreement yesterday with the state and Federal governments on a $1.2 billion financing plan to complete three major sewagetreatment projects.

description: GENEVA, Oct. 8  The International Labor Organization says that the merchant fleets of the Soviet bloc countries may capture a substantially larger share of world cargoes in the years immediately ahead.

description: In his book, Blind Ambition: The White House Years, John W. Dean 3d, President Nixon's counsel and a key figure in the Watergate affair and trials, continues to implicate Mr. Nixon as the central personality in the breakin and the coverup.

title: Mrs. Carter Narrates The Lincoln Portrait
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Led by the first Southerner to run for President in modern times, the Democrats are ratsing money by invoking the name of the Northern Republican President who freed the slaves, Abraham Lincoln.

title: Small but Select Field for Ruffian Headed by Proud Delta, Revidere
description: Rain or no rain, Proud Delta probably will go to the post at Belmont Park today in the first running of the $132,375 Ruffian Stakes. According to Peter Howe, her trainer, the 4yearold filly just doesn't like mud. On that kind of track, Proud Delta feels insecure. But Mrs. Marion du Pont Scott, in whose Montpelier colors the filly races, apparently has decided the illfated Ruffian deserves the best memorial salute possible.

title: Baseball Playoffs
Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: The Cost of Polluting
description: Federal District Judge Robert R. Mehrige Jr. in Richmond laid it on the line for all polluters by levying a $13,375,000 fine on the Allied Chemical Company for knowingly dumping Keponeladen water and other chemicals into the James River. In explaining his reasons for imposing such a sentence, Judge Mehrige pointed out: The environment belongs to every citizen from the highest to the lowest. He made clear the effect he wanted his sentence to have: I hope, after this sentence, that every corporate employee who has any reason to believe that pollution is going on will say to himself, I'd better do something about this if I want to keep my company, if I want to keep my job. That, in our book, is a pretty fair way of making sure that the law is effective and that the environment is indeed saved for everyone, both high and low.

title: Around the Nation
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. S (AP)A Federal District judge asked the Justice Department today to investigate to determine whether Spiro T. Agnew had violated the probation imposed when he was convicted of income tax evasion in 1973.

title: FootInMouth Diseases

title: PENNSY SEEKS PERMISSION TO SELL YALE CLUB BUILDING
description: The bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company sought permission yesterday from a Philadelphia Federal court, overseeing the company's reorganization, to sell the building and the land housing the midManhattan Yale Club.

title: Science Writers for The Times And Washington Post Honored
description: Walter Sullivan of The New York Times and Stuart Auerbach of The Washington Post have been selected as winners of the fourth annual ScienceinJournalism Competition sponsored by the National Association of Science Writers.

title: Dave Anderson
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 8Two of baseball's most enchanting elements, hostility and history, dominate the plot for tomorrow's opener of the American League championship series. Hell hath no fury like a pitcher scorned, and Larry Gura, the softspoken 28yearold lefthander who will start for the Kansas City Royals, was scorned by Billy Martin, the New York Yankees outspoken manager. Scorned twice actuallyonce in 1974 when Billy Martin was managing the Texas Rangers and again early this season when the Yankeel traded him to the Royals for Fran Healy, a bullpen catcher. I got rid of him in Texas, says Billy Martin, because he didn't get the ball over, and I got rid of him this year because he wasn't as good as any of my four starters. And if I had him now, I'd get rid of him again. But if Larry Gura wins tomorrow, Billy Martin will have contracted a classic case of hoofinmouth disease and Whitey Herzog, the Royals manager, will have created a mod remake of the Howard Ehmke legend.

title: Announcement Welcomed by Smith
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 8 (UPI)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's Government and black nationalist groups welcomed Britain's announcement today of a Geneva conference in two weeks to set up an interim, multiracial government for Rhodesia.

title: VORSTER REJECTS DEMAND BY BLACKS
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 8The first direct negotiations between Prime Minister John Vorster and the black leaders of South Africa since the recent black upheaval began today with Mr. Vorster rejecting a demand for a multiracial convention to discuss the country's racial problems, saying he saw no merit in the idea at all.

title: U.S. Offers Talks; Moscow Is Silent
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 8The United States has decided to end its refusal of months to take part in Cabinetlevel SovietAmerican commissions and has proposed to Moscow that a Joint Commerce Commission convene in Washington in two weeks.

title: Hall of Fame Exhibition: Fashion in a Cozy Setting
description: The small fashion exhibitions in the Shirley Goodman Resource Center, part of the Fashion Institute of Technology, are fast rivaling the moreelaborate productions uptown at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The school is at 27th Street and Seventh Avenue, a few blocks south of the heart of the sarment district.

title: Book's of the Times
description: I am Margaret Mitchell of Atlanta, author of Gone With the Wind. So the unknown writer of what would become history's bestselling novel (20 million copies up to now) leads off an early letter in this collection, written to thank, at considerable length, one of her many laudatory reviewers. Those words could stand as a onesentence summary of Margaret Mitchell's life.

title: Bridge:
description: Exaggerated importance is given by some players to the following question: If the opener has two fourcard majors, which suit should he bid after a Staymen response to his one notrump?

title: Federation of Musicians Urges Strike of Philharmonic on Oct. 19
description: Max Arons, president of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, announced yesterday that the union was recommending that the members of the New York Philharmonic vote to go on strike on Oct. 19, the day scheduled for the reopening of Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Buckley Alone in PublicTV Ad Bid
description: Although Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, succeeded in placing the equivalent of a fiveminute commercial on several public television stations, no other candidates in the state or in the country have attempted to follow his example, officials of the Public Broadcasting Service said yesterday

title: Notes on People
description: After 33 years in which he was unable to marry his francs e and companion, Prince Bertil of Sweden, the bachelor uncle of King Carl XVI Gustaf, will now be able to take as his bride Lillian Craig, an Englishwoman, in December, the royal court in Stockholm announced yesterday.

title: Film: Good Guys vs. Bad Guys:'Fighting Mad' Is Showing at Neighborhood Theaters
description: Given a determined effort at self-delusion, it is possible to believe that "Fighting Mad," which opened Friday at neighborhood theaters, is just another good guys versus bad guys movie. The bad guys in this case are a strip miner-land developer, his henchmen, corrupt politicians and inertia-ridden policemen, and the good guys are the sort of farm folk that we know are determined to cleave to their land because they have the sort of faces that made nimble the brush hands of Grant Wood and Norman Rockwell.The truth is that "Fighting Mad," starring Peter Fonda, is a little less than just another good guys versus bad guys movie. The holes in its story line occasionally yawn wide enough to admit six abreast the bulldozers that evil, murderous Crabtree is using in the strip-mining and land-development schemes that are consuming and menacing the farmers' land.One of the landowners is the father of Tom Hunter, played by Fonda. He has come home to the family horse ranch from the city with his little boy after the breakup of his marriage only to find the clean rustic life he seeks imperilled by men who will stop at nothing to impose their vision of progress on the farmers. So he takes up the cudgels or whatever else is handy.The result is a film so determined to stir the viscera that it overlooks the nourishment of the brain. The real lesson of this sort of movie doesn't seem to be that right wins out in the end. Not so bad comes through. Villains and peripheral characters suffer and die when injured and shot. The protagonist's gunshot wounds don't hurt too much and heal fast. And the law doesn't seem to mind vigilantes.Well, it isn't life. And, heaven knows, it isn't art.

title: Vietnam Accuses U.S. Of Role in Thailand
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 8 (Reuters)Vietnam charged the United States today with responsibility for Wednesday's military coup in Thailand. A commentary carried by the Vietnam press agency said leaders of the coup all were proU.S. militarists.

title: Chairman of Rhodesia Parley
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 8The puffs of smoke mounting from his thick pipe are a measure of the intensity of Ivor Richard's concentration. The harder he is thinking, the faster they come.

title: Ford Makes 2 Attempts to Clarify Statement
description: LAWTON, Okla., Oct. 8President Ford apologized today to the leader of a major PolishAmerican organization for having said that Eastern Europe was not dominated by the Soviet Union.

title: The Incredible Cockpit of Lebanon
description: Still another try to bring peace to Lebanon is scheduled to be made today at a conference in the resort town of Chtaura, where President Elias Sarkis was inaugurated more than two weeks ago.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OCTOBER ART The Washington Square art show in which paintings and often poetry were draped on Greenwich Village fences, began in 1931. That show's success over the years led to the creation of several other neighborhood outdoor art exhibitions. And now, some of the recreations believe that they have eclipsed the Washington Square show in the quality of presentations.

title: Scottsboro Defendant Applies for a Pardon
description: I was tired of being a fugitive, Clarence (Willie) Norris said the other day. I want to clear the record. I don't want my family bothered or worried. I want to be able to take them any place in this country.

title: Irwin and Graham Piccadilly Finalists
description: VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. 8 (AP)Hale Irwin and David Graham won golf matches today to reach the final of the $127,500 Piccadilly World Match Play tournament. They will compete tomorrow for first prize of $42,500.

title: Radicals, It Is Argued, Are Alive and Well...
description: When my colleague Tom Hayden ran for the Democratic nomination for Senate in California this year, his official campaign biography stated: Tom Hayden has accomplished more out of office than most elected officials have after a lifetime in office.

title: Treasury Bill Yields In 3 and 6 Months Fall
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Yields declines on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Autograph Recital at Korvettes Given by Horowitz, the Recluse
description: At 4:07 yesterday afternoon Vladimir Horowitz walked onto the fourth floor of the Korvettes store at Fifth Avenue and 47th Street, where thousands of his fans were waiting, and began signing autographs.

title: Deaths
description: ABBOTTRev. Frederic Everett. 72. died October 6, in Charlottesville,. Va. Rev. Abbott was in the publishing business in New York belore entering the ministry. Funeral service will be held at 2 P.M. Saturday, October 9, In Bedford Village, N.Y.

title: THOMAS A. CURRY, WRITER OF WESTERN NOVELS, DIES
description: NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 8Thomas A. Curry, who wrote more than 120 western and adventure stories, died last night at his home here. He was 75 years old.

title: Patents: Way to Speed Delivery Of Packages by Post Is Invented
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8A packagelabeling apparatus that was patented this week is intended to speed mail delivery. It is now being tested in the research and development department of the United States Postal Service at Rockville, Md. Patent 3,984,279, which is assigned to the RCA Corporation, was granted to Bohdan W. Siryj, an engineer in the company's advanced technology laboratories at Camden, N.J. The work was done under a contract with the Postal Service.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Quick Pay Ends Steve Lobell's Triple Crown Bid
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 8  Quick Pay, who had spent most of this season losing close finishes, won a pair of tight ones today and captured the $100,000 Kentucky Futurity. His victory ruined his stablemate Steve Lobell's bid for trotting's triple crown.

title: Nashville Banner Endorses Ford
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 6 (UPI)President Ford today received the endorsement of The Nashville Banner, which said: An overwhelming majority of the American public has reached the point where it wants less Federal Government, less intrusion into their lives and liberties, less tax burden and fewer grandiose programs which cost billions of tax dollars.

title: 1,200 Iraqis Reach Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Oct. 8 (AP)Leftist sources here said 1,200 Iraqi soldiers with tanks and rocket launchers arrived in two ships this week to reinforce Palestinian guerrillas and leftist militia units.

title: Hope for SouthWest Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Oct. 8 (AP)Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that a conference on SouthWest Africa, also known as Namibia, can be assembled in the near future and a firm date for Namibian independence be established. Mr. Kissinger, in his recent visit to Africa, negotiated for independence of Namibia from South Africa, which controls the territory 10 years after the United Nations General Assembly demanded its withdrawal.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE EASES A BIT TO 7.8%; NO BASIC SHIFT SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The national unemployment rate eased a trifle in September, but there was no fundamental change in the employmentunemployment picture, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Erie County, Facing a Possible Note Default, to Be Audited by State
description: Governor Carey announced late yesterday that a team of auditors working under State Comptroller Arthur Levitt would immediately begin an emergency audit of the financial records of Erie County, which is faced with a possible default on Nov. 1 of $31 million in shortterm notes.

title: RUMANIAN PRELATE DENOUNCED BY JEWS
description: Thirty members of Concerned Jewish Youth disrupted a meeting of the policymaking governing board of the National Council of Churches for two hours yesterday with shouted demands for the ouster as a board member of the Rumanian Orthodox Bishop of America, Valerian D. Trifa.

title: Wilkins Wants Blacks Named As Political Debate Questioners
description: Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, complained yesterday over the failure to include any blacks among the questioners in the two Presidential debates held so far, United Press International reported.

title: Peter Allen Sings at Bottom Line
description: On records, Peter Allen seems the most convincing of the latterday cabaret songsmiths. His songs have an unforced sophistication that sets them apart, and his singing, piano playing and instrumental at companiment are all both classy and vital.

title: EUNICE GOODALE, LEADER IN CHILDHOOD EDUCATION
description: BOSTON, Oct. 8Eunice C. Campbell Goodale, an authority on early childhood education and widow of Robert L. Goodale, a Boston insurance executive, died here today at Deaconess Hospital of cancer. She was 68 years old and was a resident of this city.

title: NursingHome Flu Shots Canceled
description: New York City's Department of Health has canceled a plan to distribute swine flu vaccine to the public through 90 privately owned nursing homes, and the association representing the homes angrily charged yesterday that the cancellation had been motivated by adverse publicity rather than questions of competence.

title: New York's P.B.A. vs. the People
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association during the past two weeks has subjected New York to the most serious challenge to the city's survival that municipal officials have faced since the fiscal crisis began two years ago. The danger is twofold.

title: Italian Austerity Package Raises Price of Gasoline by 25 Percent
description: ROME, Oct. 8 (Reuters)  The Italian Government decided on an economic austerity package today that included a 25 percent rise in the price of gasoline to the equivalent of $2.16 a gallon, officials said. It also decided to lower the price for diesel oil by 16.7 percent.

title: Carter Demands That Ford Tell the Truth
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 8Jimmy Carter demanded here today that President Ford tell the truth about Administration policies and his own personal finances.

title: Congoleum Offers $153 Million for Universal Leaf
description: The Congoleum Corporation of Milwaukee, which is in the process of divesting itself of its carpet, furniture and home furnishings divisions, said yesterday that it had made an offer to the directors of the Universal Leaf Tobacco Company or Richmond to merge Universal Leaf into Congoleum in a cash transaction valued at $153 million. Universal Leaf promptly expressed its opposition to the offer.

title: Ford Claim of a U.S. Role In Blocking Lisbon Reds Stirs Portuguese Anger
description: LISBON, Oct. 8  President Ford's statement that democracy in Portugal was a foreignpolicy success for the United States stirred general resentment among the Portuguese today.

Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Oct. 8In his address to a joint session of the Legislature yesterday, Governor Byrne embraced for the first time the new state income tax.

title: Bonn Is Under Attack by I.M.F. To Speed Up Economic Recovery
description: BONN, Oct. 8West Germany is coming under pressure from its neighbors and the International Monetary Fund to change its economic course. Some want it to promote recovery more aggressively, while others are demanding a revalution of the mark.

title: Yankees and Royals Meet Today in Start Of American League's NewLook Playoff
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 8The Yankees, the glamour team of the American League past, and the Kansas City Royals, the most successful of the American League's expansion clubs, concluded preparations today for tomorrow's start of the league's newlook playoff.

title: Tories End Parley, Hoping for Early Return to Power
description: BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 8  As charged up as these genteel sons and daughters of the middle class can ever be, Britain's Conservatives ended their annual conference here today hoping for an early return to power and confident that they could actually govern the country if only the country would ask them.

title: LISBON SETS SURCHARGE TO CUT FOREIGN DEFICIT
description: LISBON, Oct. 8Portugal announced today a 60 percent surcharge tax on luxury and superfluous goods in a move to reduce consumption and restrict imports. This was part of a series of austerity measures taken to try to reduce the country's balance of payments deficit. The country is spending abroad more than what we earn; this situation cannot continue, Antonio Sousa Gomes, Minister of Planning and Economic Coordination, said today at a news conference.

title: Carter's Goal: A Mandate

He wants a mandate, an aide to the Democratic nominee said today. He will settle for winning, of course, but he's going to be shooting for a mandate from now on out.

It was written, directed and produced by Hikmet Avedis, which if it's a pseudonym, is the only indication of good sense connected with the movie. It opened around town yesterday at a number of theaers, including the Cinerama, where they sometimes forget to lower the lights when the movie starts.

title: New York Boys' Club, at 100, Is Still a Place to Go Besides Home

title: EXCONVICT WRITER SOUGHT IN STABBING
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 8Edgar J. Smith, who was convicted of the 1957 killing of a Hackensack, N.J., high school girl and whose prison writings in 14 years on death row attracted wide sympathy and helped him win his freedom in 1971, was sought here today on charges of kidnapping and attempted murder.

McCarthy actually contain the 20,000 valid signatures required to place his name on New York's Presidential ballot in November. The McCarthy petitions were challenged by the local Democratic organization in a desperate effort to ferret out signatures which might be invalid.

description: PHILADELPHIA., Oct. 8  Nearly 1,000 prominent Philadelphians went to a getwell party last night, a gala staged by the city's society, business and labor establishments to help the ailing Bellevue Stratford Hotel.

Janet Soares, originator of the series and still its director, has been midwife to more than 120 new works since then and calmly, so it appears, looks forward to the next hundred or so. Thursday evening's concert took place as usual at Barnard College, but in the college's gymnasium.

title: Dead. Needlessly.
description: PAWLING, N.Y.I killed your cat early this morning. You know, the small blackandwhite one, sleekfurred and friendlyabout three months old, I'd say. I laid it down on the front section of yesterday's newspaper and folded a part of the paper over its headthe white side upand then I took an old walking stick and I bashed the paper over the head as hard as I could. Four times, just to make sure. It broke the old walking stick.

title: 'Strongman Ferdinand,' at Film Festival, Is Original Satire of West German Society
description: The morning is sour and dark. Ferdinand Rieche, a security policeman demoted for overzealousness, is having breakfast. With a mournful countenance, a prominent nose and a face that resembles both mousetrap and mouse, he devours raisin cake. The radio announces a tropical storm approaching Wiesbaden.Ferdinand grabs his atlas, locates Wiesbaden, assesses its distance from the East German frontier, road routes, rivers. He chews and ponders: who can be behind this storm?This is part of the prologue of Alexander Kluge's "Strongman Ferdinand," a satire on West German society that is being shown in the New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall today and tomorrow. It is obsessively narrow in its focus and drawn out too far, but in its better momentsand there are a lot of themit is original, apt and very, very funny.Nothing is so troublesome to a society as a man who follows its principles literally. To Kluge, West Germany is a society that maintains a fat complacency by making an idol of order and resistance to change.Rieche is the dangerous total believer. He pursues order to the point where it becomes outlawry, mad yet oddly logical. Security is his profession and his obsession. When a superior at the factory where he has become chief of securityafter leaving the police forcequestions the usefulness of his elaborate measures, he retorts:"With security, it's not a question of usefulness." It is a question of the whole purpose of life."Strongman Ferdinand" is the tragicomic story of what happens when Rieche50, in poor health, his career broken by his tendency to harangue his police superiors on the need to arrest people before they break the lawgets a last chance.The factory security post becomes vacant. The previous chief was discharged for placing snipers to shoot workers who break plant discipline. The press had got on to the story, and so the bossesbland, hypocritical men  hire Rieche. They order him to do "enough, but not too much" but they have hired a one-man disaster.Within 48 hours, Rieche has knocked down his office walls with a sledgehammer to make it bigger, turned it into an advanced communications post, begun drilling the middle-aged factory guards as an lite commando force, and put in so many locks that the washroom attendant is locked in.Obstacles are put in the way of this small figure with the enormous head who storms around in a green trenchcoat, upsetting everything. He has to take a medical exam: his solution is to force a young woman employee caught pilfering to give him her urine sample. "Very young urine," the doctor congratulates him. "In fact, if you were a woman, I'd say you were three months pregnant."More seriously, the factory bosses keep cracking down on him for excess; as when he and his guards raid another factory for a training exercise, or when he insists on body-searching a group of visiting American industrialists. It become a mounting war between Rieche and management and eventually, as the battles become more and more comically outrageous, between Rieche and a society that can't understand his efforts to defend it.The movie is done in short, clipped sequences  there are too many of them, though  each like a brief stanza in the ballad of Rieche. The dry, deadpan style of this social fantasy is counter-pointed beautifully by a camera that becomes lyrical: focusing on a full moon wrinkled by chimney smoke, or showing the security guards drilling on the beach at dawn and lit up in profile like a line of long-legged wading-birds.The harshness is redeemed even more by the character of Ferdinand himself, memorably played by Heinz Schubert. He is a small man who sometimes totters under the weight of his big mission. He is fond of cake and his blonde taxi-driving girlfriend, Gertie. They celebrate birthdays at midnight feast in cheap restaurants, and go on a winter trailer trip to practice for Christmas."Christmas needs training or it won't work," Rieche says. He is something like Chaplin; something like Hitler played by Chaplin. The combination is unforgettable.

title: TEAMSTER AIDE QUITS DICE PRESIDENT POST
description: William Presser, the teamsters' union official who has been convicted three times for offenses growing out of union business, resigned late Thursday night as a vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: In Memoriam
description: LAGINESTRATheresa. Happy Birthday, Terri, our beloved late Advisory Board Member from the staff and Advisory Board of the Mental Retardation Institute of New York Medical College. We continue to miss our bright and beautiful friend, the beloved and creative source of enthusiasm, inspiration and encouragement in our struggle to care for the thousands of handicapped children who look to us for help. Your everpresent influence guides us and warms our hearts. Accept our love.

title: Madrid Official Boldly Forging A New Alliance
description: MADRID, Oct. 9On the lefthand side of Spain's splintered political spectrum, he is sometimes called a dangerous man, an instinctive authoritarian. Toward the center the judgments become more generous: He is considered a dynamic, highly intelligent figure from the past who is moving reassuringly toward the future.

title: Jews Open Observance Of Festival of Succoth
description: The weeklong Jewish Festival of Succoth, or Feast of the Tabernacles, began at sundown on Friday with synagogue services, as religious leaders emphasized Succoth's meaning of religious and political freedom.

title: 'Touch of Zen,' a Fascinating Mix From Taiwan, Is at Film Festival
description: Bruce Lee, as his saddened fans know, is gone. But the frenzied, largely incredible kung fu action fare he popularized is still being churned out in familiar style by the Orient's busy moviemakers. However, "Touch of Zen," the Taiwanese feature on view this afternoon and tomorrow night at the New York Film Festival, is proof that familiarity can also breed a touch of annoyance with a standard approach to the genre.Its unfamiliar writer-director, King Hu, has not ignored traditional mayhem here, but he has demonstrated that pictorial artistry, Zen mysticism and the stylized martial arts, can make a fascinating mix.There is more than a touch of Zen and mystery in this period piece, despite its English subtitles. Program notes are necessary in fixing the time and locale as 14th-century China. But it is slowly made evident that a murderous warlord is out to eliminate a fugitive young lady loyal to the Ming Emperor, whose father he has aready dispatched; her two trusted aides and her country-bumpkin lover.Our renegade brunette beauty, it should be stressed, is no demure flower arranger. She is, it turns out, a prize pupil and acolyte of Zen Buddhist monks, who are as adept at weaponless, defensive kung fu as they are devoted to pacifism. As befits a grand myth, she and her equally expert cohort eventually eliminate those blood-thirsty pursuers in a succession of clanging swordplays and hand-to-hand clashes.As a Renaissance man also credited with the film's art direction and costumes, King Hu, who reportedly spent several years on this king-sized (three-hour) project, is obviously as dedicated to visual beauty and meditative Zen concepts as he is to action. And his views of gloomy bamboo forests, sun-dappled, green or rocky mountain crevasses and rushing rivers and waterfalls make truly spectacular backgrounds to both the peaceful and warring moods of the monks and the combatants.The confrontations between our heroine and her monks and the glaring villains are, of course, ludicrous and impossible. But King Hu and his cinematographer, Hua Hui-Ying, have staged all the prodigious leaps, the sparring and sword swinging with eye-catching, balletic effect.Aside from the almost mandatory posturing called for in these bouts, the performances are naturalistic, if flamboyant on occasion. As the saffron-robed monk-abbot, Roy Chiao Hung is a monolithic figure who not only is impressive as an imperturbable, unbeatable karate-chopper but also is fairly convincing as a contemplative type. Hsu Feng is animated and appealing as the harried lady sword swinger who sadly forsakes her lover and baby and chooses peace and sanctuary in his monastery. Shih Chun is properly trusting and helpful as her lover and Tien Peng makes a handsome, if menacing, secret-police official.In adapting his material from a collection of classical Chinese short stories, King Hu and his cooperative crew have given us a mite too much of a good thing. But they have added a touch of class to this "Touch of Zen."

title: Jean L. Koven Married To Paul Miller, Lawyer
description: Jean L. Koven of Brooklyn was married yesterday to Paul Vincent Miller of Bethlehem, Pa., a lawyer with the Bethlehem Steel Company. The Rev. Carl Nelson performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. He was assisted by the Rev. James G. Miller of Kingman, Ariz., also a Presbyterian minister and brother of the bridegroom.

title: BRIDGE
description: Defensive signals can be divided, like Gaul, into three parts. In different circumstances the play of a high spot card can mean a desire for the suit played, an even number of cards in the suit played, or a desire for a highranking side suit. But there are some important situations in which none of these signals fit the bill.

title: A Controversial Discipline
description: Psychohistory makes the American Psychiatric Association nervous. This relatively new and increasingly popular discipline combines the insights of psychology (mainly psychoanalysis) with the data of history.

title: My Side
description: If New York's commercial theater is really dying (which I doubt), it will have received some lovely tributes on its deathbed. To the recent spate of books about the great days of Broadway two more are now addedboth by eminent actresses: Ruth Gordon and Cornelia Otis Skinner.

title: Man Held in Death Threats
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 9 (UPI)William M. Griffith, who says he  a member of the Charles Manson group, has been arrested on charges of sending threatening letters to President Ford and Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday. An F.B.I. spokesman said letters received by Mr. Ford, Mr. Brown and members of the San Diego Women's Parole Board threatened them with death if three Manson followers, Lynette Fromme, Sandra Good and Susan Murphy, were not released from prison.

title: Progress on the Environment
description: A modest antidote for the gloom that so often attends discussions of the environment is the seventh annual report of the Council on Environmental Quality. The study not only raises the hope that the nation will one day have tolerably clean air and water, but disposes of several myths about the impact of cleanup programs on the growth and economy of the country.

title: Yanks Win Playoff Opener, 41; Reds 63 Victors Over Phillies
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9The Cincinnati Reds opened their bid for their fourth pennant in seven years tonight in their best mean manner: eight extrabase hits, four stolen bases in four attempts and a 63 muscling of the Philadelphia Phillies in the first game of the National League playoff.

title: CLARENCE L. JOHNSON, DESIGNER OF OUTBOARD
description: LAKE PARK, Fla., Oct. 9 (UPI)Clarence L. Johnson, an aviation pioneer and designer of one of the first outboard motors for boats, died Thursday at his home here. He was one of four brothers who pioneered as plane builders and barnstormers and founded the Johnson Outboard Motor Corporation, later merged into Outboard Marine Corporation.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: MANILAThere is a temptation to conclude that nothing of great moment occurred at this week's joint annual session of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Any such assessment, however, would be grossly misleading.

title: A critics' critic criticized and other entertainments
description: Convinced that many play reviewers are selfindulgent, irresponsible and heedless of the popular will, Lehman Engel assesses the New York playreviewing tribe member by member in The Critics and glances at a few outoftown and retired writers as well. His method is that of quotation followed by comment, with extended comparisons of critical performances on litmus paper items like Peter Shaffer's Equus. And his judgments flow, by his claim, from personal standards of clarity, accuracy, and objectivity.

title: A Troubled Dictator
description: MEXICO CITYConservative opposition in the United States to a new Panama Canal treaty has been visibly strengthened by the Presidential campaign, but internal unrest in Panama has also added obstacles to rapid conclusion of the negotiations.

title: Rutgers Trounces UConn, 380
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.. Oct. 9The rain stopped just in time for Rutgers to rout Connecticut, 380, today and extend college football's longest winning, streak to 12 games.

title: NEW YORK CITY FINDS ABUSES OF MEDICAID IN PSYCHIATRIC CARE
description: The New York City Department of Health, concerned over alleged Medicaid abuses in psychiatry and psychiatric clinics in the publichealth field, has started an investigation into fraudulent practices such as billings for fictitious or questionable psychiatric services.

title: An Eagleton Eye View
description: NOT many people in New Jersey would recognize their names, but a number of men and women serving in the Legislature are regarded highly by constituents in their own districts. Senators Beadleston, Bateman. Dodd and Musto and Assemblymen Ewing, Foran, Kean and LeFante are among them. Together, they have won more than 50 elections to the Legislature.

title: Harassment in India
description: Whenever the Government of India relaxes censorship or releases a few political prisoners, there is a tendency among all who wish that country well to believe the worst is overthat Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is at last beginning to make good her promise to end oppression and restore freedom. Such hopes are invariably dashed in short order by harsh Government acts or proposals further to dismantle India's democratic structures.

title: MAYAGUEZ REPORT PUTS FOCUS ON G.A.O.
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 9Officials of the General Accounting Office acknowledge that their agency is not exactly a household word.

title: Towns Bar Tax Cut As Bait for Industry
description: Suburban towns and cities have a lovehate relationship with business and industry: they love the taxes and they hate the traffic, appearance, sound and smell, if any.

title: 5,000 Hit Trail But Few Taste Joy in Mudville
description: The nation's largest scholastic crosscountry meet became the wettest one at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday, and there were 5,000 runners coated with mud to prove it. One was John Gregorek of St. Anthony's of Smithtown, L.I., who avoided most of the splatter by running in front of his varsity field and staying there until the finish for his fourth victory of the season.

title: Letters
description: Bruce Porter's article (I'll do things my way, Sept. 19) about Utica's political aberration[Mayor] Ed Hannacontains one omission and two cheap shots which call for a response. I was Mr. Hanna's legislative assistant during his pathetic oneyear term as State Assemblyman, and have followed his career with considerable interest since.

title: Barbara Buketoff Is Married
description: Barbara Buketoff, administrative assistant of the Friends of City Center, was married last evening to Richard Reynolds Mouk, manager of consolidated reports and financial policy for Gulf arid Western Industries.

title: Stengel, the Certified Genius
description: Well, when Harvey A. Dorfman, the English teacher who tried to debunk the legend of Casey Stengel (Views of Sport, Sept. 26), was in high school in the Bronx, I was covering Casey and the Yankees for a local newspaper. I saw Stengel daily, from the first day of spring training until the last day of the World Series, maybe 280 days a year for six years. I won't go into how often we talked in saloons.

title: Will Ford Really Do?
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9You have to wonder, at this halfway house in the Presidential campaign, whether the brutal test is not beyond the limits of physical endurance and human intelligence. It is a marathon run at the pace of a 100yard dash, and inevitably the runners falter, stagger, and blunder.

title: New ReactorCooling Developed
description: BUFFALO (AP)Nuclear engineers at the State University at Buffalo say they have developed an advanced emergency cooling system for nuclear reactors.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: In recent months the nation's press (including the numismatic hobby press) has devoted considerable space to reports (actually rumors) that our coinage was about to undergo vast changes. The dollar coin would be made smaller, or thinner, or would be octagonal instead of round; the half dollar would be discontinued altogether, the copper cent would be replaced by a twocent piece, and so on. These rumors were effectively put down by the Treasury Department's announcement that the special Bicentennial designs on the reverse of the quarter, half dollar and dollar would be replaced next year by the old (1974) eagle designs . . . in other words, those three coins will be minted, as before, in 1977.

title: The Diva As TV Interviewer?
description: Several years ago, I suddenly realized I was the Beatles of the opera, says Beverly Sills, one of the most highly paid opera singers in the world today, munching a donut in the deserted NBC commissary at 7 P.M., while her black coffee grows tepid paper cup. Now, on the heels of Barbara Walters's defection to ABC, NBC executives have drafted Miss Sills, a distinguished soprano who capped her career with a debut at the Met 1975, for the unexpected role as an interviewer on television.

title: Private and Public Weather
description: WASHINGTONNearly a quartercentury ago, I met Vera Micheles Dean, then nearing the end of her distinguished career as a writer and lecturer on foreign affairs. During the course of lunch, she lamented the change in the tone of public life that had occurred in the several years since the death of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: Yesterday's Results in Scholastic Sports
description: Football

title: Laurie Noel Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Friel of Boston have announced the engagement of Mrs. Friel's sister, Laurie Ann Nol, to Lawrence B. Van Ingen 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Ingen of Glen Head, L. A January wedding is planned.

title: STAMPS
description: This year has been dominated philatelically by the celebration of centuryold anniversaries, and now it is Great Britain with an unusual and handsome issue of four commemoratives marking the 500th anniversary of the introduction of printing in England by William Caxton.

title: A Symphonic Baedeker
description: Even back in the days of 78rpm records, selecting the best version of a standard symphonic work presented a problem. In 1948 a prospective purchaser of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony was faced with 11 possible choices, including performances by such formidable conductors as Toscanini, Furtwingler, Mengelberg, Weingartner, Strauss and Stokowskieach different and each offering a valid perspective on a masterpiece.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: IT was too big a document, I guess, and too widely disseminated. I guess to keep quiet, said Otis G. Pike. The Democratic Representative from Riverhead was sitting in the lobby off the House floor, reading newspapers and chaffing. Now that it was all over, he said, he could talk about it. There was no bitterness or angerjust intense disappointment.

title: Woman in Italy, First in Cabinet, Wins Applause
description: ROME, Oct. 9As the first woman in the cabinet in the 30 years of the Italian Republic, Tina Anselmi has already managed to help keep the planes in the air.

title: HOME CLINICS
description: EXPERTS agree that the most important part of any outside paint job, regardless of whether one is painting only part of the trim or the entire house, is the preparatory work that is done even before a brush is dipped into the can.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALL paint experts agree that whether you are painting only part of the trim or the entire house, the most important part of any outside paint job is the preparatory work. Selecting a good quality paint that is formulated for the type of surface being painted is, of course, essential, but the money spent will be wasted if you don't clean, scrape, patch, and otherwise prepare the old surface before any paint is applied.

title: Barbara Bradford Is Bride
description: The marriage of Barbara Reed Bradford to Warren Neil Davis took place yesterday evening in the Plymouth Church (Congregational) in Shaker Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. David Rees performed the ceremony. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. William Cochran Bradford of Cleveland. Mr. Davis is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Davis of Denver. The couple are lawyers in Washington. Formerly with the New York law firm of Breed, Abbott and Morgan, Mrs. Davis will be an associate with Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson and Alexander beginning Nov. 1. Mr. Davis is with Sutherland, Asbill & Brennan.

title: Imperil the 3 R's?

title: The Fishing Clinic
description: That time of year is fast approaching when yellow leaves, or few, or none will hang on bare, black boughs and when valuable fishing equipment is often stuffed into a closet or flung into a corner of the cellar. Such treatment is not. good, of course, particularly when salt water gear is involved.

title: Policeman Hurt in Soccer Riot
description: LONDON, Oct. 9 (UPI)A policeman suffered a fractured skull today when Glasgow Rangers' fans rioted during a soccer game against Aston Villa at Birmingham, forcing the match to be stopped after 51 minutes.

title: Courts And Rule By Law
description: PROUD of its centuriesold traditions of equal justice under law, America sees itself as a government of laws and not of men. And yet, when it imposes criminal penalties, society delegates that awesome power to a single individual who often has few precise standards to guide his crucial deliberations and virtually no accountability to that very same public which demands protection. The system needs revision.

title: Pamela A. Geitgey Bride Of Peter Uihlein, Brewer
description: Pamela Ann Geitgey, daughter of Mrs. Standen Easton of Rocky River, Ohio, was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Trace Uihlein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Alfred Uihlein Jr. of Milwaukee.

title: Food
description: If chocolate truffles are as we have been told of Italian origin then the desserts on this page are indeed international in scope Besides the truffles there are Swiss walnut fingers (the recipe for which came to us through the predominately Mexican kitchen of Dana Kennedy who is English), pears a In vigneronne the name of which smacks of the vineyards of France; and finally an outrageously rich pecan pie, the origin of which is the Mississippi Delta One warning about the chocolate truffles (known in Italy as tartufi): They are like freshroasted peanuts, insidiously good and therefore irresistible.

title: Penn State Trounces Army, 3816, After 3 Losses; Princeton Grinds Out 93 Triumph Over Columbia
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Oct. 9Joe Paterno, Penn State's football coach, decided it was time for a change. Making the most extensive inseason realignment of players in his 11 years at the helm, Paterno came up with a young and enthusiastic combination that trounced Army, 3816, today and ended the Nittany Lions' threegame losing streak.

title: Peter Frampton, Easily Fusing Rock and Pop, Conquers Garden

title: Belgians Isolate Virus

Indeed, this country's big four domestic carriers, United, American, Eastern and Delta, have made about 48 million flights in the last 25 years and only 35 of those have ended in a crash. Of the 1.1 billion passengers who went along, only 1,390about one tenthousandth of one percentwere killed.

title: Under the poison cloud
description: Every evening, Giovanni and Domenica Foti leave the Milan hotel where they are reluctant guests, get in their car and drive along a highway that runs from the outskirts of Milan north through the rolling green region of Lower Brianza, heading for the town of Seveso, 12 miles away. They talk matteroffactly during the first part of the trip, but fall silent as they approach road signs that read Polluted area. Keep all windows closed.

title: What's Doing in BOMBAY
description: THE CITYThis is India's great metropolis. New Delhi may have its monuments and Madras its fine beaches, but Bombay has an abundance of both plus a ceaseless dynamism. It is a lively, spirited city that never seems to sleep. Two hundred years ago Bombay. known then as Mumbai, after Mumba Devi, a local goddesswas converted by the British from a string of seven small islands into a huge commercial port. Much of modern Bombay stands on reclaimed land, and there is an annual ceremony in which candies and flowers are offered to Mumba Devi so she will continue propping up the city. The old British influence is everywhere, despite a rash of modern steelandglass skyscrapers. There are scores of remarkably wellpreserved buildings with neoGothic turrets and arcades. There are also buildings in the Islamic style with large domes and minarets.

title: The Awful New York Kitchen
description: The New York City kitchen is a turkey.

title: Dean Witter Wall Street East and West
description: SAN FRANCISCOWhen outsiders call Dean Witter & Company here and ask to speak to William M. Witter, the chairman of the board, the next voice they hear may be that of Mr, Witter himself. He often answers his own telephone.

title: Massachusetts College Gets Head

The appointment was announced Thursday by Charles Hamilton, chairman of the Board of Regional Community Colleges. Mr. Donato, dean of Howard Community College in Columbia, Md., will replace the acting president of Quinsigamond, Richard Offenberg. He will he paid $37,128 a year.

title: A place in Paris between James Thurber and Elliot Paul
description: Here in 20th Century Journey are the first 26 years of William L. Shirer, that historian of our times, and here is the public world that surrounded him. In the summer of 1925 he might have served as an exemplar of the young Americans who stormed into Montparnasse like a herd of stampeding Herefords, as Ford Madox Ford said of them with tolerant wonder. Perhaps Bill Shirer was even more innocent than the others. He was 21 and had just been graduated from Coe College, in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, where he had edited the college weekly. Having borrowed $200, which he hoped would last him for two months on the Left Bank, he said goodbye to his girl and worked his way to Europe on a cattle boat

title: Running in place
description: It is a chill, rainy Monday afternoon in Binghamton, N. Y., and Fritz Mondale must do his interviews with the local press before he delivers his speech at the university and then gives his pep talk at the reception the Democrats have scheduled. It has been arranged as painlessly as possible. Three reporters from different television stations will interview him at the studios of WBNG, four questions each, seriatim. The host station goes first in Studio B, and then Mondale is led into Studio A where a brightly lighted platform has been equipped with two chairs, one of which contains young reporter ready to ask his questions. Mondale answers them, then waits as a young woman from another station takes the young man's place, replaces his microphone with her own and his camera with hers..in the studio, just outside the circle of light, the national reporters who travel with Mondale sit and wait, too, their notebooks in their laps though they don't expect to use them. Fritz Mondale is, after all, a professional, and he not going to say anything in some television interview in Binghamton, N. Y., for heaven's sake.

title: The .680 Hitter
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 9  As a hitter, George Brett is more documented than a bank statement. He is the American League batting champion with a .333 average and with 215 hits, he led the league in that category for the second consecutive season. But the 23yearold third baseman of the Kansas City Royals also does things that baffle baseball's auditors. He once had at least three hits in six consecutive games. That's probably a major league record but nobody knows for sure. He also is believed to hold a record with 13 consecutive hits off the same pitcher, Ed Figueroa, the New York Yankees' starter tomorrow night in the second game of the American League championship series.

Education of Handicapped Is Hurt by New York City Budget Cuts

That is how 15yearold Bonnie Ziet started her letter in a recent language exercise at Intermediate School 237 in Flushing, Queens. Also expressing concern, about the loss of the specially trained physicaleducation teacher was her classmate, Phyllis Green, who wrote, I like to tell you that you bumped the wrong person for gym.

title: Sunshine Law Beams At Most Meetings

The object of the statute is to force governmental bodies at every level to open their meetings and their decisionmaking to the public: commonly referred to as the Sunshine Law, the act is designed to prevent public officials from carrying out public policy in secret.

title: For young readers
description: Long ago, we are told in Ashley Bryan's fascinating recounting of an African tale, Cat and Dog lived among people as brothers. It is a long, involved magic tale that has echoes of Aladdin's lamp and Jack and the Beanstalk to mention, just two familiar stories with similar motifs. There is the stupid  but  good  hearted son, the longsuffering mother, the unfair trade, a transformed king, a magical ring that grants wishes, the traditional African trickster Ananse and, most important, the noble cat and the base dog.

title: Book Ends
description: Quotesmanship . Being a wellknown author (The American Way of Death) Jessica Mitford receives a lot of requests from publishers for a quote they can use in advertising a book (assuming it's a favorable quote, of course). Generally she turns them down, she wrote us, but recently, to help out a young woman writer whose book she found a jolly good effort, Miss Milford sent a quote indicating she thought the book totally absorbing. She was crestfallen when the embarrassed author wrote back: It seems that the publisher's experience with the words totally absorbing has been that they are not as effective as certain other descriptive words, Better Miss Mitford should say something along the lines of tremendously exciting and important or highly significant and compelling drama. Miss Mitford brooded a while and then came up with a modest proposal: How about asking the publishers to furnish a checklist . . . of desirable phrases for use on book jackets? The checklist could be graduated, starting with such triedandtrue encomia as blockbuster and ending with my poor old ineffective totally absorbing. I believe this would save everybody a lot of time, particularly if the list were coded; one would merely have to notify the publisher of the code number (e.g., 1 for blockbuster, 18 for totally absorbing). Publishers may submit their lists of preferred words to this column, where they will be tabulated and ranked by popularity. We'll start the ball rolling with riveting, hypnotic, pageturner, a good read and a gorgeous book.

title: Detroit's Trend Is Thinking Smaller

October 1977 brings the beginning of the end of the iron monster, at least in its grossest toms: the long, low, wide, bulgesided roadship; the zoomy, rubberpeeling, powerpacked, 450 to 500cubicinch V8, 4,500poundplus gasoline waster.

title: In 10 Years, I'll Be The Greatest Playwright
description: It is hardly any trouble to get to Willow Terrace in Hoboken, which is ten minutes and 35 years away from Manhattan. (There is no willow and no terrace on Willow Terrace; it is only called that.) Hoboken is Irish and Italian, and here and there it is Puerto Rican. These are the names of the people who live in the row houses on Willow Terrace, just across from a body and fender shop and an Italian social club: Keegan, Gill, Cannon, McMaster, Garvey, Calabrese, DeMarco, Morano and La Russo. La Russo is a bard; he writes plays.

title: U.S. Cup Soccer Team Needs Help
description: The president and secretary of the United States Soccer Federation were in Europe last week. Their mission was to persuade the Belgian Soccer Federation to allow Julie Veee, an American citizen who plays in the First Division there, to compete for the United States in its qualifying match Friday in Puebla, Mexico, against the Mexicans. After a scoreless tie last Sunday between the United States and Mexico in Los Angeles during the first qualifying game, Walt Chyzowych, the United States coach, said: We are one player away from winning. America has that player in Julie Veee and we will try to get him for the next two games.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Syrians Are Served News In Confusing Portions, Well Spiced by Rumors
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 7The Government does not hurry to give the news of war and politics in neighboring Lebanon. In Al Kordaha, the village that is the birthplace of President Hafez alAssad, as in the capital, people often get at least an approximation of what is happening in a classically Levantine wayby assembling facts obscured in layers of rumor, much as the national dish consists of a bit of chopped mutton hidden in thick crust.

title: Jazz in New York's Lofts New Music in a New Setting
description: Artists' studios, remodeled warehouses and converted basements of downtown Manhattan living spaces popularly if somewhat loosely referred to as loftshave been the site of an unprecedented amount of jazz activity in recent months, and the activity is increasing. In the lofts, unlike the clubs, oblivious conversationalists and ringing cash registers never intrude on the creative flow of improvisation, and musicians can play whatever they want for as long as they wish.

It is also his boast that he has never taken a human life, nor does he ever intend to.

title: Students Protest in Colombia
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 8 (AP)Leftist students rioted here today to protest renewed martial law proclaimed this week by President Alfonso Lpez Michelson. The police said that students at the National University had taken four vehicles to the campus and set them on fire before policemen surrounded the area and dispersed them with tear gas.

title: DONALD B. PERCY
description: Donald B. Percy, a Westchester County real estate executive for many years, died Friday at his home. He was 79 years old and lived on Cross River State Road in Katonah, N. Y.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: Article 5  No Title
Smile! It's Profitable for Club Med
description: It has, at least, for the Club Mediterrane, whose revenues have doubled every three years since 1968. Last year, consolidated revenue approached the equivalent of $200 millionup 33.5 percent from 1974and net income was almost $9 million. The club, in fact, is probably the world's biggest, and fastest growing, tourism company.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1976

title: Amelia Le Clair Is Married To Garrow Throop, Designer
description: Amelia Le Clair, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold J. Le Clair of Peterborough, N.H., was married yesterday morning to Garrow Throop, son of Mr. and Mrs. Enos Throop of Lawrence, L.I. The Rev. John Kilbjorsen, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony in the Cathedral of the Pines, Rindge, N.H.

title: Where the Big Races Are: Should All of Them Be in New York?
description: Of all the major sports in this country, only thoroughbred racing has been accustomed to limiting its championship events to a small geographical area within 30 miles of Manhattan Island. Except for the Kentucky Derby and, to a lesser extent, the Preakness, the horse elections have been won in New York in the fall. It may be more than a coincidence that the managers of thoroughbred racing are the first to complain about a lack of national interest in their sport.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Last Week's Bond Sale Went Surprisingly Well, but Difficulties Are Not Over
description: After a year of onagain, offagain fiscal crisis, Yonkers, the fourth largest city in New York State, last week arranged the sale of $83.6 million in bonds, and was finally relieved of the threat of bankruptcy. That threat had caused Yonkers to drop 400 teaching positions, cut the number of fire fighters and policemen on duty, cancel park and recreation improvements, trim support for public libraries, curtail other departments and services, halt all capital improvements, and even shut the city jail. Had the bond offering not attracted buyers, Yonkers would have been insolvent.

title: MYSTERIOUS DISEASE TAKING AFRICAN TOLL
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 9Four weeks ago a villager who had walked from the southern Sudanese hamlet of Nzara to the regional center of Maridi was gripped by a sudden high fever. Taken to the local 30bed hospital, he developed a rash and died within two days.

title: Michigan Romps Over Mich. State
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 9 (AP)Harlan Huckleby scored three touchdowns today and Rob Lytle rushed for 180 yards as Michigan crushed Michigan State, 4210, in a Big Ten football game.

title: Deborah Foss Wed at Chapel To Ronald J. Benza, Ad Man
description: Abbey Memorial Chapel of Mount Holyoke College was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Deborah Foss to Ronald J. Benza. Dean Deane William Ferm of the chapel, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Headliners
description: Mr. Heath, Mrs. Thatcher Make Up

title: SEXIST LANGUAGE CHANGED BY AMERICAN LUTHERANS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP)Delegates to an American Lutheran Church convention have agreed to delete most references to gender in official church documents or to change those references to language not considered sexist.

title: HEBRON CLASH STIRS WIDE ISRAELI IMPACT
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 9The acts of religious vandalism committed at a shrine in Hebron sacred to both Moslems and Jews are having a political impact in Israel, including indications of a worsening of relations between Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and Defense Minister Shimon Peres.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Having no political insights into the FordCarter affair worth publishing. I wrote to Tombstone John Flanigan asking if I could borrow some of his. Tombstone John is one of the nation's most sagacious political authorities, having spent 48 years voting tombstones for Mayors of Chicago. He now lives in retirement in Pittsburgh. He wrote the following:

title: Dancing in Graham's Footsteps
description: AMODERNDANCE program with a difference has just opened in Great Neck, and in the process the village has become, in a way, a sister city to Paris.

title: For young readers
description: Peter Mayle is well known as the author of two successful booksWhere Did I Come From? and What's Happening to Me? He now moves to explore the reputed life beyond death, and with mixed results. He begins well enough, with a sensible chapter on why people die. Next he discusses various concepts of the afterlifereincarnation, the Happy Hunting Grounds, the Valhalla of the Viking warriors. Abruptly the focus shifts to Hell, and unfortunately this is by far the most memorable section of the book. The drawings of devils, pitchforks and darting flames are ghastly enough to keep any small child awake. One shows a tormented soul, sweating profusely, pursued by Old Nick; the other depicts the traditional Devil himself gazing gleefully at a thermometer marked WarmHotVery HotBoilingOuch!

title: Ray Seeks Review of Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)James Earl Ray asked the Supreme Court today to review his conviction for the assassination of the Rev. Dr, Martin Luther King in 1968. In his petition for review, Mr. Ray argued that he had been denied an effective defense at his trial because of a conflict of interest among his attorneys; that his guilty plea was coerced and not made voluntarily; and that he was denied the right to call key witnesses.

description: 1PETER HUJAR

title: Freeport's Painful Fight Over a Hostel
description: FROM the outside the house at Cedar Street boasts little to distinguish it from most of the other wellkept, middleclass homes on the block. It is unoccupied and stands at a corner, but there the differences seem to end.

title: University Hospital Will End Program  For Drug Addicts
description: MANHASSET, L. 1., Oct. 9The North Shore University Hospital, which has one of the largest drugabuse treatment centers in the state, will phase out the program because of a 25 percent cut in financing.

title: Head of Social Services Cites Data That Support Carey in Relief Dispute
description: The State Commissioner of Social Services insisted yesterday that the projected overrun in the state's welfare budget was as serious as Governor Carey announced it was last month and said Republicans in the State Senate, and not the Governor, had been playing games with the welfare numbers.

title: Stephen Grotsky Fiance Of Vicki E. Zimmerman
description: Judge Donald Zimmerman of the State Court of Claims and Mrs. Zimmerman of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Vicki Ellen Zimmerman, to Stephen Richard Grotsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Grotsky of the Bronx.

title: Texas Tech Turns Back The Aggies
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 9 (AP)  Rodney Allison won a duel of sub quarterbacks from David Walker today as Texas Tech defeated Texas A.&M., 2716, in a Southwest Conference game before the third largest crowd in Texas A.&M. history.

title: PARCEL STRIKE TAXES POSTAL FACILITIES
description: Working overtime with extra help and added facilities, the United States Postal Service is laboring to move mountains of parcels dumped on it since a strike paralyzed United Parcel Service along the Eastern Seaboard three weeks ago.

Faith Ritchie Bride Of Richard Menaker
description: In St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University yesterday, Faith Ann Ritchie and Richard G. Menaker were married by the Rev. Paul Dinter, Roman Catholic chaplain.

title: Match Golf Is Captured By Graham
description: VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. 9 (AP)David Graham of Australia sank a 12foot birdie putt on the second hole of sudden death play to beat the defending champion, Hale Irwin, for the title in the $127,500 Piccadilly World Match Play golf championship today.

title: Solomon, Lutz Win Semifinals
description: KAANAPALI, Hawaii, Oct. 9Stan Smith's long road back from adversity and pain hit another detour today.

title: College Football Results
Buckley, Behind In Polls, Ahead In Appearances
description: Although he is the incumbent, Senator James L. Buckley is campaigning much more intensively than his Democratic challenger, Daniel P. Moynihan. In the eight days ended Friday, for example, the Senator made 43 scheduled public appearances compared with Mr. Moynihan's 17. Mr. Moynihan is Political losing two days a week Notes alone because has returned to teaching at Harvard University. The considerably different paces are undoubtedly significant. One theory is that Mr. Moynihan believes he is well ahead and does not need to show up at every beer bash. That theory is supported by a Newsday/ Gannett poll and the candidate's own poll, which shows him with at least a 10point lead. Conversely, Mr. Buckley needs to pump every hand in sight.

title: Carter Offers Maritime Plan To Sea Union
description: Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential candidate, told the National Maritime Union last week that the demands of national defense and economic security required a clearly defined and effectively implemented national maritime policy.

title: FISHING
description: FOR stripedbass fishermen, the season is now. Bass were reported pouring around Montauk and through Plum Gut last week, with gill netters taking bass off Jones Beach and initial flurries being trolled off Long Beach.

description: Captain Cross speaking. We'll be taking off in approximately one minute's time.

description: British Football

title: FISHING
description: FOR stripedbass fishermen, the season is now. The long stretch of northeasterly winds and heavy weather has prompted large schools of bass off Rhode Island and Massachusetts to begin their southward migration in earnest.

title: Patti Obrow Is Engaged To Geoffrey Ross White
description: The engagement of Patti Ellen Obrow to Geoffrey Ross White has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. D. Irving Obrow of Rumson, N. J., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard B. White of Locust, N. J. A spring wedding is planned.

title: ART
description: HEMPSTEAD MEG PERLMAN, who has recently been named director of the Emily Lowe Gallery at Hofstra University, envisions the campus gallery as an artistic showcase for active student, faculty and community involvement. The shows we will hold will have relevance to the university experience, she said in an interview. This is a university gallery and should play an integral part of university life.

title: RedsPhillies Scoring
Carla Randazzo Married
description: Carla Jeanne Randazzo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Randazzo of Garden City, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to George Wanzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Edgar Wanzer of West Hempstead, L. I. Judge Donald Clavin of the Nassau County Second District Court performed the ceremony at the Randazzo residence.

title: The Technology Crisis
description: ALL Americans suffer a lovehate relationship with technology. We snap up its offerings airconditioning, dishvrashers, flights to faroff nationsand sneer at materialism

title: Diane Colony Fiero Wed To Richard Alan Brown
description: Diane Colony Fiero, an administrative secretary with the Sperry Univac Corporation in Washington, was married yesterday to Richard Alan Brown of Alexandria, Va., a Government linguist in Russian.

title: Chris Evert Gains Final; Miss Fromholtz Is Victor
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 9It had to be a surprise when secondseeded Billie Jean King was beaten on her comeback attempt by Dianne Fromholtz yesterday. Today the little Australian redhead took her second big scalp, fighting back to defeat thirdseeded Martina Navratilova, 16, 63, 75, in a furious struggle over 90 minutes.

title: Endpaper
description: Not long ago, the campaign of Jimmy Carter would have summoned no more national response than the perennial candidacy of Olla Ray Boyd, the fabulous swine breeder from Pinetown, N.C. Even there they snickered, beloved though he was of the bucolics in his little corner of this earth. But now, Southerners know the Carter candidacy is the natural culmination of a phenomenon known as The Pork Chop Conspiracy. Scarcely more than a century after the bloody failure of The Late Great War, Southerners have managed to broadcast, to infect this whole land with their attitudes, prejudices, customs, pseudofolkways, language, music and God knows what else.

title: Paperbacks
description: CURIOUS GEORGE GOES TO THE HOSPITAL, by Margaret and H. A. Rey. (Houghton/Sandpiper, $1.95.) George, a monkey, swallows a piece from a jigsaw puzzle and gets the full hospital treatment excellent medicine when a young child has to go the hospital.

title: W.H.O. Studying Specimens
description: GENEVA, Oct. 9The first specimens of the lethal virus from the Southern Sudan are being examined in a highsecurity laboratory, the World Health Organization said yesterday.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A: GRACKLE NUISANCE (Sept. 12) D.F.C., Mamaroneck, N. Y., asked if anyone had solved the problem of nuisance grackles which scare away the more desirable birds. We checked with Peter Roberts, personality on WOR radio, who is a grackle enthusiast. He had this to say, In the first place, grackles have been mistakenly called a nuisance. Farmers will attest to their sterling qualities in keeping valuable plants insect free. The grackle should not be confused with the starling. But a good supply of moth bails sprinkled under a hedge or groundcover will usually discourage starlings and grackles. After all is done and sird, The grackle is a noble bird.

title: Thailand's Military Coup
description: Three brief years of freely elected government in Thailand, brought about by a student revolt against military rule, have now come to a sad end. The return of former strongman Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn, followed by a bloody crackdown on student protests, provided the pretext the military sought, evidently since January, to terminate Thailand's first wobbly experiment in democracy. Southeast Asia and the world are poorer for it.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in the Arts and Leisure section:

title: The Weak Get Weaker
description: WASHINGTONWhatever its blessings, the abandonment of fixed exchange rates has not done much to restore tranquility to the international monetary scene. Under the current system of floating rates, in which the ebb and flow of market forces determine each currency's value, world money markets are in disarray again.

title: Who Should
description: ALL of us have had our consciousness raised in the last three years as one inslitution after another has been found to be human; frail and capable of making mistakes. Political upheavals in Washington, Albany and Nassau and Suffolk Counties have been dramatic at times, but more often subtle. Changes both in community attitude and structure have come to government and politics that a decade ago would have been unthinkable.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayNimrod Farm, Weston Road, Weston, Conn; Amateurowner and junior working hunters, ponies, equitation. 8 A.M.

title: Ted Shawn
description: When the United States was preparing to make the world safe for democracy, Ted Shawn set out to make the United States safe for male dancing. This was Shawn's most publicized crusade, and there is no more startling account of the life of Papa Shawn and Ruth St. Denis, the socalled parents of modern dance, than this book.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The last Sunday of this month will see the start of the eighth season of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center (hereafter referred to as CMSLC), and it is no secret that the 14 pairs of concerts in this series make up one of the most treasured of New York musical institutions. When the New Friends of Music went out of business many years ago it left a gap in this city's musical life that never really was filled. Not that the city lacked chamber music. The Lexington Avenue Y.M.Y.W.H.A. kept on presenting the Budapest Quartet in its annual Beethoven series, and Hunter College had plenty cf chamber music, and visiting ensembles did visit the bigger halls. But there was a difference.

title: Pregnant Mare Killed At Famed Team Farm
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 (AP)  Vandals armed with a highpowered rifle shot and killed a pregnant Clydesdale mare yesterday. The mare had produced several colts for the AnheuserBusch Inc. brewery's famed eighthorse hitch teams.

title: MULTIPLE CANCERS TERMED ON INCREASE
description: Increasing numbers of rancor patients are living to develop second and sometimes third primary cancers, medical researchers reported here last week.

title: STORM CUTS POWER FOR 150,000 HOMES
description: Blackouts struck more than 150,000 homes across the metropolitan area yesterday as a storm with battering winds and driving rains felled power lines and trees, disrupted traffic and cast a shroud of midday darkness over the city and suburbs.

title: FAMILY COURT IS CITED AS VASTLY IMPROVED
description: Under new leadership, widely criticized New York City Family Court has experienced a turnaround marked by a 60 percent decrease in the case backlog during a 15month period ending last April, according to a study made public yesterday.

title: Baseball Playoffs
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE YANKEES VS. ROYALS

title: At the Same Time, They're a Family And Writers' Colony
description: NORTH BROOKLIN, Me.  Helen Bassine Yglesias was 17, the tail end of a family of six children of immigrant parents in New York City, when she first turned her hand to an autobiographical novel. She showed it to a domineering older brother who so traumatized her about her aspirations to write that her hook was never finished. She was 54 years old before she started on a book a rain.

title: Dollhouse Kits Appeal to Adults
description: BERKELEY HEIGHTS THE burgeoning mania for miniatures, from tiny tiered wedding cakes to Lilliputian furniture, has provided a new direction for an established New Jersey concern, the only one in the state that manufactures dollhouse furniture kits.

title: ART
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE two exhibitions now on view at the Rutgers University Art Gallery are an apt demonstration of the commitment of this institution to contemporary art. The gallery never has concentrated on showing only the most acceptable forms of modern esthetic expression; it also has ventured into its lessestablished forms. These two exhibitions contain some of both.

title: Journal of a Peruvian Package: Dreams and Nightmares
description: My doctor says I'm getting better and should be able to leave soon. I don't know that I want to, though; it's so quiet here at the Rest Home. At our afternoon, group therapy session, they started in on me again: Everyone told you you were crazy to go to the Amazon. Why did you ignore them? They told you of the piranhas and the alligators, the boas, the anaconda. Why did you insist on going to Africa? The Amazon is not in Africa, I screamed. It's in South America. Oh, yes, South America, RITA BLOCKER HALLEY describes herself as a writer of fiction specialising in funding proposals and quarterly reports.

title: Clean Cars of 1985: Will Anybody Buy?
