description: EVEREST BASE CAMP, Nepal, Oct. 9 (AP)Two members of the AmericanBicentennial Everest Expedition have scaled the world's highest mountain, but strong winds have put in doubt a summit attempt by additional climbers.

title: Steinbeck's Arthur
description: Some people there are who, being grown, forget the horrible task of learning to read. It is perhaps the greatest single effort that the human undertakes, and he must do it as a child. An adult is rarely successful in the undertakingthe reduction of experience to a set of symbols. For a thousand thousand years these humans have existed and they have only learned this trickthis magicin the final ten thousand of the thousand thousand.

title: New Theater Group to Bow in Bergen
description: WHEN word got around about Bergenstage Inc., a new and adventurous littletheater company in Teaneck and Bergen County's fist professional residenttheater group, frierrds approached Bing Bills, a member of Bergenstage's board of directors.

title: Nancy Gerstein Plans to Marry John Novogrod
description: Mr. and Mrs. Max Gerstein of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ellen Gerstein, to John Campner Novogrod, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Novogrod of Scarsdale, N.Y. The marriage is planned for Nov. 7.

title: There Are 600,000 Who Have Been Out of Work a Year or More
description: Behind the official report that national unemployment stood still last month at a level close to 7.5 million are some grim statistical indicators of the toll being inflicted on the jobless and their families by the sluggishness of economic recovery. The report shows that nearly 600,000 workers have been jobless for more than a year without being able to find work. The figure is twice that for people out of work more than six months.

title: Ford's New Engine
description: The engineers call it the dual displacement engine. In plainer terms, it is an engine that can be operated with some of its cylinders shut down. The obvious advantage is a significant savings in fuel. While the idea dates back more than 50 years, it may just be that, after all the tinkering, its time has finally come.

title: Human Suffering And the Bureaucracy
description: AS a result of an insensitive system that selfserving Long Island healthplanning agencies have helped to perpetuate, the lives of thousands of our fellow citizens have been destroyed and millions of taxpayer dollars wasted in the last 10 years.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Oct. 13Westchester Sports Car Club meeting at Sir Loins, Greenburgh Shopping Center, Route 100A, Hartsdale, N. Y. 8:30 P.M., Interested persons welcome. Information: Mary Minkon, phone (914)7699314.

title: Environmentalists Criticize Carey
description: The Environmental Planning Lobby has released a study that indicates New York's legislators are continuing to support environmental issues, but that warns of disturbing signs of erosion on such issues by Governor Carey.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: REPORT FROM ROME
description: ROME October is normally one of the more pleasant months in Italy. The sun leaves the illusion of unending summer, tourists begin to fade away, restaurants keep their tables outside and Italian women begin the fall fashion show around the Piazza del Popolo and the Corso. And, despite recurring troubles indeed, almost in defiance of themthe nation's cultural life begins to stir.

title: Deborah Wolf Married
description: Deborah Wolf, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Wolf of Jericho, Vt., was married there yesterday morning to Stephen Smith Page, son of Dr. Russell Page of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Lorraine Page. Justice of the Peace Willadin0 O. Cochran of Jericho performed the ceremony at the Wolf home.

title: HALT IN SAFETY PLAN IS LAID TO MEDDLING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9A House subcommittee charged today that a Federal program that could prevent an estimated 11,000 deaths each year had been stopped dead in its tracks because of political interference by the White House, Congress and industry.

title: 3 French Resorts to Bid For 1984 Winter Games
description: CHAMBERY, France, Oct. 9 (UPI)The neighboring winter sports resorts of Courchevel, Meribel and Vallee de Belleville made it official today that they are jointly applying to host the 1984 winter Olympics.

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: Dtente Starts Moving With Ammonia
description: VENTSPILS, U.S.S.R.Let there always be sunshine, announces the slogan lettered in Russian on a new American storage tank rising 150 feet above the finegrained Latvian seashore.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: A Montclair Resident Warns on Late Strolls

title: Mississippi Wins From Georgia
description: OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 9 (UPI)Tim Ellis, a quarterback, ran five yards for one touchdown and passed 36 yards for another today in sparking Mississippi to a 2117 upset victory over Georgia.

title: Vision of Pro Yachting Becomes Fact
description: The sea beckoned and Eric Eastman answered. The vision of a professional yacht racing circuit, conceived five months ago by the 31yearold Montauk resident, had reached fruition. Eastman never envisioned it quite this way. Men with cameras wrapped in plastic bags were pacing the docks, talking into walkietalkies with cameramen aboard committee boats with the control center of the Montauk Yacht Club and Inn. They were recording the excitement. And with 15 mileperhour northeasterly winds gusting to 52 m.p.h., there was excitement  sometimes chaos.

title: Fires, sex and freaks
description: SAN FRANCISCO. George McManus, a genial 35yearold reporter for radio station KCBS, was standing with other news people on a San Francisco street a year ago, waiting for President Ford. Seeing the normal bustle that precedes a President, McManus spoke over his portable transmitter to the 32ndfloor studio in a nearby skyscraper.

title: NEW RESIGNATIONS HIT LUTHERAN CHURCH
description: A majority of the officials and administrators of the Atlantic District of the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod have announced their resignations, the latest results of the schism that is attecting the 2.8 millionmember church body, the second largest and most conservative of the nation's three major Lutheran synods.

title: Leaves Get a New Lease On Life Preserved in Plastic
description: How fleeting is the autumn season's foliage spectacular. The hillsides, streets, valleys and parks are splashed with reds, scarlets, mauves, yellows and goldbrilliant leaf colors that fade to the ground too soon.

title: POLITICS
description: IT HAS become a tradition in New Jersey in election years for the pollsters at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers to ask prospective voters to identify the candidates running for the United States Senate and the House of Representatives. The results this year indicate that, although everyone knows there is a Presidential election, a large number of voters are not sure anythine else is at stake.

title: Advertising
description: A new advertising spectacular is coming to the Great White Way, inspired, believe it or not, by similar installations in Moscow, Kuwait and Tijuana, Mexico. Talk about carrying coals to Newcastle.

title: Mondale Marches in Two Parades,Sharing Spotlight With Republicans
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 10Senator Walter F. Mondale, who will march in tomorrow's Columbus Day parade in New York City, of into training today by marching in two ethnic paradesin Buffalo and in Newarkin which he had to share the spotlight with Republicans.

title: Humphrey Doing Very, Very Well
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey was described as doing very, very well yesterday. Dr. Willet F. Whitmore, who operated on the Minnesota Democrat for removal of a cancerous bladder Thursday, told The Associated Press: He's a model patient. He's calm, relaxed, friendly and cooperative. His vital signs are stable, his temperature's normal, his biochemical tests are normal and his recovery is right ??n schedule. He read the Sunday papers and has been listening to music.

title: FORD DUE TO APPROVE NEW COPYRIGHTS LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10After 15 years of debate and discussion and a lobbying effort that was the bread and butter of hundreds of lawyers, Congress has finally reviewed the nation's copyright law for the first time since 1909.

title: Cowboys Top Giants BY 2414
Banks Closed Today
description: Banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed today in observance of Columbus Day. The cocoa and the coffee and sugar exchanges in New York will also be closed, but other commodities exchanges and securities exchanges throughout the nation will remain open.

title: Kenyans Told Not to Press Changes
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 10The Attorney General of Kenya has warned politicians here who have called for constitutional revisions dealing with presidential succession that it is a criminal offense punishable by death for anyone to imagine, devise or intend the death or deposition of the president.

title: Concert: HighVoltage Mahler
description: The Philharmonic's ongoing Mahler Festival reached a climax of sorts Saturday night in Carnegie Hall with a performance of the composer's Eighth Symphony conducted by James Levine. Although four concerts still remain in the series, there was an unmistakable aura of festive culmination surrounding the event.

title: Once There Was a Wishbone That Sang Boheme
description: In Ellen Silvers's studio apartment, the cupboards and whatnot cases, the closets and table tops, and quite a bit of the floor are swarming with little Madame Butterflys, Carmens, Escamillos, Don Joss, Lohengrins, Elsas, Siegfrieds, Mimis, Rudolfos and many other operatic characters.

title: OnceCelebrated Moon Rocks Are Now Passe
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 8They were rock celebrities five years ago. People traveled hundreds of miles to see them. Politicans cozied up to be photographed beside them. Volumes were written about them. They were studied, oohed, analyzed and aahed.

title: Black Rhodesian Leader Softens Demands on Talks
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Oct. 10 (Reuters)A Rhodesian black nationalist leader said today that only some of the demands voiced by nationalists yesterday were conditions for attending the Britishsponsored Geneva conference on Rhodesia's future.

title: Article 3  No Title
Donnie Allison Captures 500Mile Stock Car Race
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 10 (AP)Donnie Allison, taking the lead for good with 40 miles to go, won the 17th annual National 500 today for his first Grand National stock car victory in five years.

title: A Nuclear Glossary
description: ReactorA device for initiating and maintaining a controlled nuclear chain reaction in a fissionable fuelthat is, splitting, or, in effect, burning uranium atomsfor the purpose of creating heat to drive a steam turbine to generate electricity or of producing additional fissionable material.

title: U.S. Dilemma: World Energy Need Encourages Spread of Atomic Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The construction of nuclear reactors around the world for the production of electricity and the resulting spread of material that could be used for making atomic weapons are placing increasing pressure on the United States to devise new policies on nuclear energy and international control.

title: New, RockFree Jonathan Richman
description: Hearing the records doesn't begin to prepare you for Jonathan Richman and the Modern Lovers in live performance. The reclusive cult hero has been known for six years as about the oddest thing in rockandroll. This year, suddenly, two disks of his music finally appeareda collection of older material and a bunch of new songs with a new hand. Saturday night's concert at Town Hall marked the first time he has appeared here since the release of the records, and the place was packed with the tastemakers, the curious and the connoisseurs of the exotic.

title: Roderick HaigBrown, 68; Canadian Author Wrote With Love of the Outdoors
description: CAMPBELL RIVER, Canada, Oct. 10 (AP)Roderick HaigBrown, environmentalist, author and former chancellor of the University of Victoria, is dead at the age of 68.

title: Rise in Dropouts In New York City Shocks Regents
description: Although there is a dispute over just who is a dropout, the number of students who are leaving New York City high schools without earning a diploma is steadily rising, adding another worry to a school system that is already stumbling from the impact of repeated financial blows.

title: Unbeaten Pitt Wins 5th Game, Loses 2d Quarterback
description: Pittsburgh's excellent football team is undefeated untied and unlucky.

title: Notables of Many Fields Hail Columbus in Newark
description: NEWARK, Oct. 10Bob Hope wore sweat socks. The Republican VicePresidential candidate, Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, got more boos than applause, but shook hundreds of hands.

title: City Opera May Cancel Its Season
description: The New York City Opera expects to cancel the remainder of its fall season if the strike by its musicians that began Sept. 28 is not settled by Thursday night.

title: Scrantons Stage Coup With Country Elegance
description: DALTON, Pa., Oct. 9Secretary General Kurt Waldheim and the President of the Security Council, Iqbal Akhund of Pakistan, had a long serious chat on the couch as the other guests swirled around just out of hearing. Peter Florin of East Germany listened to the strolling musicians. Pearl Bailey, a regular adjunct to the United States mission to the United Nations, played with the children.

title: Anger Mixed With Faint Smiles In Westchester Storm Aftermath
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 10That's some toothpick there, said John Brady, a repairman from the Con Edison service center in Eastview, as he arrived at one Scarsdale home this afternoon to see a 70foot tree trunk balanced precariously on the roof.

title: Pate Triumphs In Pacific Golf By 2 Strokes
description: INZAO, Japan, Oct. 10 (AP)Jerry Pate, a firstyear pro from Pensacola, Fla., shot a par 71 today for a fourround total of 279 and won the $300,000 Pacific Masters golf tournament.

title: Abolition of F.C.C. Is Promised
description: STERLING, Colo., Oct. 10 (AP)Roger MacBride, Presidential candidate of the Libertarian Party, said today that he would eliminate the Federal Communications Commission if he got into the White House. He said he was concerned that the agency's power to grant or withhold licenses gave it virtual censorship control over the nation's electronic news media.

title: Donor's Anger at N.Y.U.'s Handling of Her Literary Collection Leads to Switch of Letters to Public Library
description: Furious at what she considered the failure of New York University to honor its commitments, Frances Steloff of the Gotham Book Mart has withdrawn her great literary collection from the university and donated it to the Berg Collection of the New York Public Library.

title: The SovietChinese Relationship
description: Any analyst attempting to compare the latest statements on SinoSoviet relations by the two sides gets the impression that he is in a universe created by Franz Kafka where nothing is what it appears to be.

title: About New York
description: The Times Square businessman certainly seemed outraged. These loiterers and winos are ruining this area and hurting my business, he said. Look, I pay taxes, and he waved a $2,600 check made out to the Government in behalf of the Crossroads bookstore.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide et Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook lime. For high tide at Atlantic City (Steel Pier), deduct 26 min. from Sandy Hook lime. For high tide de at Jones Inlet (Pt. Lookout), deduct 19 min. from Sandy Hook lime.

title: Mondale Marches in Two Parades, Sharing Spotlight With Republicans
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 10Senator Walter F. Mondale, who will march in tomorrow's Columbus Day parade in New York City, of into training today by marching in two ethnic paradesin Buffalo and in Newarkin which he had to share the spotlight with Republicans.

title: DR. LAWRENCE A. SCHIFF, WESTBORO HOSPITAL HEAD
description: Dr. Lawrence F. Schiff, superintendent of Westboro State Hospital, Westboro, Mass., since 1972, died Thursday of cancer at the Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 39 years old and lived at 175 Mt. Vernon Street, West Newton, Mass.

title: Attica Amnesty
description: It was a noteworthy achievement last summer that violence was averted at Attica, despite high tension and a prisoners' strike. This achievement was significant partially because the memory of Attica was still very much alive at the fifth anniversary of that bloody revolt. It was that fact more than any other that made so remarkable the feat of the state Department of Correctional Services in negotiating the difficulties.

title: American Symphony and Synthetic Sounds
description: It is more than 20 years since Varse broke the ground with his Dserts, but the potential that seemed to lie in his juxtaposition of live musicians and taped sound has not been realized.Most essays in this hybrid form strike this listener as parts of one long, continuous piece that has been snipped up and sent around to the world's composers for their use.

title: DOCTORS AT LINCOLN URGE WIDE CHANGES
description: Doctors at Lincoln Hospital, some of whom said they had warned the administration of impending disaster a month before two stabbing victims died there allegedly because of a shortage of personnel, called yesterday for major administrative and budgetary changes in the new South Bronx institution.

title: Wrote Expertly on Fishing
description: Roderick Langmere HaigBrown was a prolific author who loved the outdoors without being sentimental about it. In his lifetime, he was a logger, guide, trapper, fisherman, farmer, sportsman, conservationist, magistrate and, above all, a gifted writer with a remarkable feeling for the rustic life.

title: Kansas City Wins, 73 Playoff Is Tied
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 10The Yankees have introduced walkietalkie warfare into playoff baseball, but their novel tactics didn't help tonight as the slumbering Kansas City Royals finally awoke and whipped the Yankees, 73, in the second game of the American League pennant playoff.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: BEAME IS PREPARING DRASTIC CUTBACKS IN CITY'S SPENDING
description: Amid fears that its worst budget crises are yet to come, the Beame administration is refining a harsh new program of drastic cuts and other steps to produce nearly $500 million in savingsbeyond those achieved alreadyfor the year beginning next July 1.

title: Jugular Jimmy
description: WASHINGTONThe joke is told of a longhidden Adolf Hitler, asked to lead a neoNazi putsch to take over the world, reluctantly responding: Okay, but this timeno more Mr. Nice Guy.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Oct. 10National politiclans seem to have discovered New Jersey anew in the last few days.

title: Turks on Russian Frontier Lose Their Fear But Not Their Distrust
description: KARS, TurkeyEveryone in Kars has two television antennas, one tuned to the Turkish station, the other to the Russian. Since Turkish television plays here only about 15 hours a week, the Russian station is widely watched, particularly for sports and cultural events.

title: Pitt Remains Unbeaten, but Loses 2d Quarterback
description: Pittsburgh's excellent football team is undefeated, untied and unlucky.

title: ATHENAISE THIELE
description: Athenaise Thiele, sister of Frederick Irving Lundy, owner of Lundy's, a prominent seafood restaurant in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, died Saturday at New York Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: VILLAGE STROLL A short, selfdesigned walking tour may be organized for today or almost any weekday along Bleecker Street between Eighth Avenue and Seventh Avenue South, where more than two dozen shops deal in antiques and decorative accessories. The store owners contend that they have, collectively, the largest selection of Country French furnishings outside of France. There are also shops dealing in American, African and South American primitives; one store has thousands of miniature objects; Middle Eastern rugs are available, as are fabrics. Furniture and accessories from the Orient, Europe and Britain and art galleries and boutiques complete the scene.

title: Nancy Benson Is Bride Of Martin Rothenberg
description: Nancy Ellen Benson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lee Benson of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Martin Louis Rothenberg, son of Mrs. Mike Miller of New York and Howard R. Rothenberg of St. Petersburg, Fla. The Rev. Gary P. Brown, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony with Rabbi David Greenberg at the Benson home.

title: Economic Fears Heightened by New Statistics
description: For the last six months, an unusually vigorous debate has raged over the strength of the economic recovery  some economists say a pause is underway, others say that the recovery is alive and well, a small group fears a second recession threatens.

title: The FourDay Week
description: The modest opening toward a fourday workweek made by the Ford Motor Company strikers ushers in what could be a creative quartercentury in American labormanagement relations. New leaders are in process of taking charge in almost all of the country's principal industrial unions. Even George Meany, the 82yearold patriarch of the A.F.L.C.I.O., talks at times of retiring.

title: Rise in Dropouts In New York City Shocks Regents
description: Although there is a dispute over just who is a dropout, the number of students who are leaving New York City high schools without earning a diploma is steadily rising, adding another worry to a school system that is already stumbling from the impact of repeated financial blows.

title: U.S. Dilemma: World Energy Need Encourages Spread of Atomic Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The construction of nuclear reactors around the world for the production of electricity and the resulting spread of material that could be used for making atomic weapons are placing increasing pressure on the United States to devise new policies on nuclear energy and international control.

title: Airedale Named Best in Show Of 1,182 Dogs at Mahwah Fixture
description: MAHWAH, N.J., Oct. 10The Airedale is the biggest of all the terrier breeds. Today, one of the descendents of the dogs said to have originated in Britain's Aire Valley scored one of the biggest victories of his career when he was named best in a field of 1,182 in the Ramapo Kennel Club show on the grounds of Ramapo College of New Jersey.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follow:

title: Road to Zimbabwe
description: After two weeks of confusion, conflict and strenuous diplomacy on many fronts, the BritishAmerican plan for the peaceful transition of Rhodesia to African majority rule seems back on the track. Britain, still the legal authority on the country whose white rulers announced independence eleven years ago, has scheduled a conference on Rhodesia in Geneva later this month.

title: $68 MILLION STADIUM FOR FOOTBALL GIANTS IS OPENED IN JERSEY
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 10  The opening of the $68 million Giants Stadium went more smoothly for the 76,042 spectators today than it did for their frustrated pro football team.

title: Margaret E. Strauss Bride of Bruce Black
description: Margaret Ellin Strauss, daughter of Mrs. John S. Forbes of White Plains and the late L. Z. Morris Strauss Jr., was married yesterday to Bruce William Black, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Wallace Black of South Hadley, Mass. Rabbi Julius Rosenthal performed the ceremony in the Woman's Club of White Plains.

title: Portisch Plays Tal to Draw
description: VARESE, Italy, Oct. 10 (UPI)Lajos Portisch, the Hungarian grandmaster, fought Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union to a draw today in the second round of a chess elimination tournament to determine a challenger to the world champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union. Portsch and Tal drew after 34 moves in 4 hours 45 minutes. In the first round yesterday, Tal and Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union played to a draw after 18 moves in 2 hours 45 minutes.

title: Dole Visits Jersey And Illinois in Quest For Ethnic Votes
description: CICERO, Ill., Oct. 10With the possibility of the Republicans capturing any substantial support from the nation's East Europeanethnic communities apparently slipping away. Senator Robert J. Dole campaigned heartily today at a Columbus Day parade in Newark and at a Bohemian mushroom festival here.

title: Market Place
description: Last Friday's bid by the Congoleum Corporation Inc. to purchase the Universal Leaf Tobacco Company for $32.50 a share was greeted by investors as an exciting development in an otherwise dismal stock market.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York Telephone Company has agreed not to enter unoccupied apartments to reclaim telephone equipment from customers whose service is terminated for nonpayment, according to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz. Mr. Lefkowitz said his office began an investigation of the company practice when a woman in the Greenwich Village section of New York complained that a telephone company employee removed her telephone without her knowledge or permission while she was at work. The employee gained entry to the apartment by getting a key from the building superintendent, the woman said, although the key was to be used only in emergencies. A ruling in civil court found the company guilty of trespassing.

title: Hiring Faculty Women
description: Should universities be compelled to remedy sex discrimination by setting numerical hiring goals for women faculty members? Opponents of these goals, required by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, insist on tagging them as quotas. Why?

title: GEN. TROY H. MIDDLETON, LED TROOPS AT THE BULGE
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 10 (UPI)Lieut. Gen. Troy H. Middleton, a hero of the Battle of the Bulge who later served as president of Louisiana State University, died yesterday. He was 86 years old.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: APPOINTMENT OF HUA STILL UNCONFIRMED
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 10Prime Minister Hua Kuofeng appears to have been chosen chairman of the Chinese Communist Party to succeed Mao Tseturng, but there were signs of confusion and possible conflict in Peking today over his appointment and there was still no official announcement confirming it.

title: Giants Bow to Cowboys, 2414, and Hear Many Boos
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 10In a setting worthy of the Dallas Cowboys, the Giants played at their stately new home for the first time today. The Cowboys won 2414

title: Local Vote Buoys Belgian Coalition
description: BRUSSELS, Monday, Oct. 11 (Reuters) The governing centerright coalition of Prime Minister Leo Tindemans weathered a midterm test in municipal elections yesterday in Belgium.

title: Columbus Day
description: Today is Columbus Day, the 484th anniversary of the discovery of the New World. Schools, colleges, banks, post offices, courts and other New York City, state and Federal offices will be closed. There will be no regular sanitation pickups.

title: The boss says, Do it. You do it. Trouble.
description: WASHINGTONIf your boss tells you to do something illegal and you do what he says, you could wind up in jail.

title: Universities Are Warned of Federal Intervention Unless They Correct Abuses in Educational Marketplace
description: DENVER, Oct. 9There is a college in upper New England that has included in its promotional material an enticing photograph of a student couple relaxing at the shore of a lake.

title: Dance: A Gleeful Senta Driver
description: Seven month ago, a concert by Senta Driver's dance company, Harry, at the American Theater Laboratory, led to the conclusion that Miss Driver's work was original, intellectual and manic in its gleeful humor. Following Harry's concert Saturday night at the same location, there is no reason to change that opinion. Miss Driver is all that she ever was, only more so. She is one of the freshest dance voices around.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Carter Turns to Biting Language In Effort to Capitalize on Debate
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 10Pressing for maximum gain from his apparent victory in the second Presidential campaign debate, Jimmy Carter has criticized President Ford so harshly that some of the Democratic nominee's associates have privately encouraged him to tone down his language.

title: Where Every Prospect Pleases, Etc.
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Oct. 10The oldest established, permanent floating franchise in the National Football League came to rest yesterday on a reclaimed garbage dump in a Jersey swamp. Until they hit the road three years ago, the Jersey Giants were a New York team that played in Yankee Stadium, sometimes referred to as the Home of Champions. They are now established permanently, not to say interred, in the newest and perhaps most admirably functional playground in creation, to be known henceforth as the Home of Losers. Wan a crowd of 76,042 booing a welcome, they staged a housewarming highlighted by a 2414 loss to the Dallas Cowboys, their fifth defeat in five games this fall. It was a momentous occasion which changed nothing but the losers address. The Cowboys came north as leaders the National Conference's Eastern Division with the only perfect record in the league. They are still on top, with five victories for five starts. The Giants held their ground in last place. Not since 1947 when they tied one and lost seven of their first eight games have they opened a season so ingloriously.

title: News Summary
description: Faced with the worldwide spread of nuclear reactors for the production of electricity, the United States is confronting major decisions regarding new policies to forestall an accompanying spread of material that could be used to produce nuclear weapons. According to specialists, two fundamental questions are whether to foster reactors that use plutonium despite the fact the material could be used for weapons, or to use its leverage to create tougher international controls over the spread of material that could be used for weapons. [Page 1, Columns 23.]

title: Books of The Times
description: It wasn't simply sex, Kate Alexander says to her current lover: I was just being free. This is only one of a long list of objections that I have to Gael Greene's novel, Blue Skies, No Candy. After thousands of years of political and social evolution, this is what freedom has come to mean, not only to Kate, but to a growing number of other women as well. To sleep with any man who excites her curiosity is represented as the ultimate expression of personal choice.

title: Rockland U.F.O. Invasion Starts Round of Explanations
description: SUFFERN, N.Y.  Shaped like two enormous upsidedown soup bowls, the objects hovered in the sky just over a dip in the Ramapo mountain range.

title: Interest by Blacks in Genealogy Is Gaining
description: WASHINGTON  Estelle Meeks of Springfield, Ill., who is 93 years old and the daughter of a slave, was able to determine through pension records at the National Archives and the Hall of Records in Annapolis, Md., that her father had served in the Civil War and had been the former slave of John Carroll, a signer of the Declaration of Independence.

title: South Africans Concerned About the Flight of Capital
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 8 When a Johannesburg property magnate fled the country recently just before his empire collapsed, officials moved immediately to have his sea shipment returned from Amsterdam. After checking bank statements, they suspected that the fugitive millionaire might have a fortune in cash hidden inside his antiques.

title: Sergeants Balking At City Police Pact
description: Delegates of the Sergeants Benevolent Association, apparently uncertain about a proposed new work chart under which New York City would require police sergeants to work an additional 10 days a year, refused yesterday to ratify a tentative settlement that their leaders had reached with the Beame administration last Friday.

title: Backers of Amendments for Equal Rights in Massachusetts and Colorado Constitutions Appear to Be Ahead
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Advocates of amendments to state constitutions guaranteeing equal legal rights, regardless of sex, are believed to be winning in the only two states where the issue is on the ballot this yearMassachusetts and Colorado.

title: Saturday's College Football
description: Yesterday's Football School

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1976

title: Auto Workers the Next Elite?; New Contract at Ford Regarded by Some as Sign Of New Aristocracy in Era of Smaller Labor Force
description: DETROIT, Oct. 10For most of this century, men and women in poor straits have fled the crossroads and countryside by the millions and headed for Detroit, Cleveland and other automobile manufacturing cities. There they have joined the unskilled from the city streets in pursuit of the economic security conferred by jobs in the car factories. It has been one of America's sagas. Are those days over? The question arises in connection with the tentative new labor contract agreed to last week by the United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company.

title: Cliff Burwell, Arranger for Vallee Was Composer of Sweet Lorraine
description: Cliff Burwell, a composer who was arranger for the Rudy Vallee orchestra and wrote the hit song Sweet Lorraine, died yesterday at his home in West Haven. Conn. He was 78 years old.

title: Chris Evert Wins Final By 61, 75
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 10It took all of Chris Evert's coolness in the clutch to come from 03 in the second set and defeat an inspired Dianne Fromholtz. 61, 75, in the final of the $75,000 Talley tennis tournament today.

description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: $68 MILLION STADIUM FOR FOOTBALL GIANTS IS OPENED IN JERSEY
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 10  The opening of the $68 million Giants Stadium went more smoothly for the 76,042 spectators today than it did for their frustrated pro football team.
