title: Decoding the Genes
description: Modem biology can be said to have begun in 1900 with the rediscovery of Gregor Mendel's longforgotten writings on the basic laws of heredity. A half century later an AngloAmerican pair of biologists at Cambridge University in England, Francis Crick and James Watson, worked out the basic mechanism of heredity in all known organisms, the chemical machinery explaining the beautiful, stark simplicity of Mendel's laws. That discoverythe role of the doublestranded DNA molecule as the primary bearer of hereditary traits from generatiOn to generationopened the possibility that man might some day assume godlike powers by intervening directly to alter inheritable characteristics specifically and purposefully.

title: The Inheritor Of Mao's Title

No, the guide replied, shaking his head, and neither did any of his friends. Mr. Hua's name was not exactly a household word in China.

title: Film: Jacques Rivette's 'Duelle':Rivalry of Gorgons Remains Obscure to the Audience
description: The valve of myths is resonance; to make a perspective for some contemporary problem or at least some contemporary sensibility. We don't follow these demigods or gorgons for their own sakes but because they give us a far view of a near condition.The mortal defect of Jacques Rivette's "Duelle" is not its slow pace or mannered style or even its obscurities. It is its failuredeliberate, apparentlyto cross over to its audience at any point or to inveigle its audience across to it."Duelle," which is showing today and tomorrow at the New York Film Festival in Alice Tully Hall, is about the struggle between a Sun spirit and a Moon spirit, in the course of which several ordinary people are badly chewed up. It is simply about itself, despite its contemporary references and setting. It spills over into nothing of ours but dcor, and even the dcor is an airless, garish, 1930's affair.The whole thing is filmed inside a Tiffany lamp. As the characters stand at the far end of significant perspectives, they resemble nothing so much as show-window mannequins draped portentiously in the foreground of some nonexistent intriguesheikhs seducers or beached Rolls-Royces in the background.Bulle Ogier and Juliet Berto are, respectively, the Sun and Moon spirits. They duel for possession of a large diamond that will permit the victor to remain on earth for more than the allotted 40 days annual terrestrial leave. Both are fine actresses and it is interesting to see what different effects their inchoate roles have upon them.Miss Berto has mobile features and the wooliness of her part results in our not being quite sure, for a long way into the film, whether she is one or several characters. Miss Ogier, an actress of very pronounced character, is always Bulle Ogier; sometimes dressed up in a Sun-spirit wig.Their rivalry has them interfering in the lives of several people  Lucie, a hotel night clerk; Elsa, a tax dancer, and Pierrot, a man of no defined profession who variously possess or know the whereabouts of the talisman. The rival spirits maneuver these humans back and forth. All three end up damager, two of them mortally.The episodes, and some of the speeches, drift off at times into substantial obscurity; although their general meaning is not hard to grasp. Rivette and his screenwriter, Eduardo de Gregorio, have set out the two spirits with a deliberate, prosaic harshness. There is nothing suggestive or allusive about them.Their virtue, at most and only rarely, is to be funny. There is an amusing scene where they gossip through pastry and champagne in what looks like a corner of the Hotel Ritz, before taking up their duel.There are one or two places where Rivette takes the momentum of the duel's climax and makes something visually affecting out of it: a confrontation, for instance, on a Metro platform between the Moon spirit and Pierrot. But these moments come far too late in a long, elaborate and profoundly unnecessary movie.

There he was whisked from the airport to a meeting with highlevel Italian scientists plus a few foreigners who, like him, had been recruited by the Italian Government to help determine the extent of the tragedy at Seveso, near Milan, where a cloud of poisonous dioxin gas had escaped from a Swissowned chemical plant.

title: Ford and Carter Appear to Cling To Coattails of Lesser Candidates
description: CHICAGOWhen a politician talks ahow coattails, it is the candidate at the top of the ticket who is presumed to he wearing the coat, and the lesser candidates who are presumed to hang on for the ride to victory.

title: About Real Estate
description: The variety of practices in home sales across New York State hardly simplifies regulation, but the recently appointed Secretary of State, Mario Cuomo, has set out to issue uniform rules to correct alleged abuses.

title: Good News About Sugar
description: The sweet word from Consumer Affairs Commissioner Elinor Guggenheimer yesterday was that sugar prices last week were at their lowest level in almost two years.

title: Net Opens 92d Season as Gavazzeni, In. Debut, Leads Exciting Trovatore
description: It's still one of the glamorous musical events, especially when things went as well as they did Monday night. The Metropolitan Opera opened its season with its handsome production of Verdi's nerennial favorite. Il Trovatore.

title: Jersey Senate President Indicted With 2 Others in Liquor Bribery
description: NEWARK, Oct. 12Matthew Feldman of Teaneck, N.J., the 57yearold president of the New Jersey Senate, and his son were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of bribing a restaurant chain representative to obtain $240,000 in business for Mr. Feldman's liquor distribution company.

title: SWINE FLU PROGRAM IS HALTED IN 9 STATES AS 3 DIE AFTER SHOTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Swine flu vaccination programs in nine states and in Pittsburgh and its suburbs were suspended today, two weeks after they began nationally, after the deaths of three elderly persons who received the vaccine yesterday at a clinic in Pittsburgh.

title: Advertising
description: Robert Coen. McCann  Erickson's prized forecaster, who has already said that there will be a greater percentage increase in advertising expenditures this year than in any other year since World War II. yesterday revised his figuresupward.

title: Meadowlands
New Zealanders Cancel Trip
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Oct. 12 (Reuters)A tour of South Africa by a blind New Zealand lawn bowling team has been canceled because it was feared that it might be interpreted as supporting the South African policy of apartheid. The fivemember team was invited to take part in a world tournament for the blind in Durban early next year, but the Royal New Zealand Foundation for the Blind has withdrawn its support for the trip on the ground that it might be viewed as showing sympathy for the South African Government policy.

title: 259% RATE INCREASE SOUGHT BY BLUE CROSS
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York is seeking to raise hospitalization premiums by an average of 25.9 percent for four million of its policyholders in New York City, on Long Island and in 10 other downstate counties.

title: COLUMBIA HALTS ACTIVITIES OF GROUP TIED TO REV. MOON
description: A student group associated with the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's controversial Unification Church has been suspended for the next two years from organizing activities at Columbia University.

title: Baseball Playoffs
Meadowlands Results
Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Muttontown Wins in Polo
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 12Mot tontown defeated Huntington, S3, and Fairfield whipped Meadowbrook, 93 today in the opening round of the Wanamaker 10goal polo tournament at Hickox Field. Peter Rizzo and Paul Rizzo scored three goals each for Muttontown. Adi von Gontard paced Fairfield with four goals.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)Declaring that the highway does not have to be a place of sudden death, Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman Jr. unveiled today two experimental automobiles he said could become the safe, cloan cars of the future.

title: BUTZ FINDS HIS ROLE IN CAMPAIGN ENDING
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12I feel like the fellow who saw his picture on the post office wall, Earl L. Butz said as he wound up a series of addresses in Mississippi and California. It's nice to be wanted.

title: Ford Gives Suburbanites Pledge of Horne Tax Relief
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 13President Ford came to the suburbs today to tell suburbanites what they wanted to hear: that he stood for financial assistance to local communities, tax relief for homeowners and a continued fight against inflation.

title: Spending Shortfall :A Slowdown Reason?
description: The effort to solve the mystery of the current economic slowdown and decline in the stock market has certain resemblance to the plot of Agatha Christie's Murder on the Orient Express, in which virtually every one on the train had a hand in the murder.

title: Turin Has a General Strike
description: TURIN, Italy, Oct. 13 (AP)A fourhour general strike idled most industrial and commercial activities m this Italian automobile capital today in the first major organized protest against austerity measures introduced by the Government last week. Workers at Fiat and Lancia struck four hours each shift.

title: Phantom Flu
description: The national swine flu vaccination program is only few days old; but already the nation's press is full headlines about elderly people dying shortly after being vaccinated.

title: U.S. Files to Deport 3 Accused of Nazi War Crimes
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday accused a former Latvian Nazi policeman and two other longtime resident aliens of war crimes and opened proceedings to deport them.

title: CITIES AND U.S. CLASH ON FOOD STAMP THEFT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Thousands of cards authorizing citizens to buy Federal food stamps are being diverted from the mails into an illicit market, and local officials around the country are refusing to help the Postal Service do anything about it, according to the chief postal inspector.

title: CBS Ousts Taylor as Its President; Paley to Yield Chief Executive Post
description: In an action that took Wall Street by surprise and stunned highranking executives within the company, CBS Inc. yesterday dismissed Arthur R. Taylor as president and appointed John D. Backe, 44yearold head of the CBS publishing division, to succeed him.

title: Miami News Endorses Carter
description: MIAMI, Oct. 13 (UPI)The Miami News calls Jimmy Carter clearly the better choice to be President of the United States. The newspaper endorsed the Democratic candidate yesterday. The News editorial said, Jimmy Carter has demonstrated a capacity for national leadership. He has shown a keen perception of the nation's problems and expressed a firm resolve in handling them through employment of America's internal and external strengths.

title: Army's Tipton Big Success As150Pound Football Coach
description: Army took a 250 lead over Navy Saturday, held on through a comeback by the Middies and intercepted a pass on the Cadet 5yard line in the last few seconds to preserve a 2521 victory at Annapolis. Md. It was the Cadets

title: Associated Press
description: URBAN WILDLIFE: The Seattle skyline forms a backdrop for a flock of Canada geese that have taken up residence on Lake Union in the Washington city

title: The New York Times/Chester Higgins Jr. Avery Fisher Hall in its last stages of reconstruction. Dr. Cyril Harris, the acoustics consultant, said. I have been too busy to be nervous.
description: There still are workmen all over the place, and there will continue to be virtually up to the opening New York Philharmonic Pension Fund concert next Tuesday. But the new Avery Fisher Hall is substantially completed, and concertgoers in this city will have what in effect is a brandnew vision to admire or to argue about, as the case may be.

title: Republicans
description: DALLASRay Hutchinson, the genial chairman of the Texas Republican Party, leaned back in his swivel chair and surveyed his officethe office of a man accustomed to wheeling and dealing, with a constantly ringing telephone, a desk littered with pink message slips, a bookcase holding an autographed Dallas Cowboys football.

title: Market Place
description: The management of the Tandy Corporation is so sure that the company's shares are undervalued that it is going into debt to buy them upagain.

title: School Official in Boston Asks For More Protection by Police
description: BOSTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)The headmaster of Hyde Park High School asked for more police protection today after pushing and shoving incidents in the school corridors involving whites and blacks.

title: Rikers I. Prisoner Is Suicide in Cell; 10th in City System
description: A 25yearold convict hanged himself in his cell on Rikers Island yesterday afternoon, less than a day after he had reportedly complained that people were out to get him and he had been transferred for his own protection to a special section of the Rikers Island Correctional Institution for Men.

title: PUERTO RICAN PLIGHT IN U.S. IS DEPLORED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct.13After 30 years of significant migration, the poor socioeconomic position of the 1.7 million Puerto Ricans on the United States mainland remains largely unchanged and in some respects is even worsening, and the prospects for future improvement are uncertain, according to the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: FORD CAN OUTSPEND CARTER THIS MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct.13Jimmy Carter has spent more than three times as much noncy rs President Ford so f^r in the national campaign, and has only about half as much left for the closing four weeks under the legal ceiling.

title: REV. MAURICE A. FEENEY
description: The Rev. Maurice A. Feeney, a former Maryknoll missionary who spent more than 40 years in the Far East, died Sunday at St. Teresa's Residence in Maryknoll. N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: SPECIAL TASK FORCE WILL PRESS CHARGES IN CORPORATE BRIBES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The Justice Department has formed a special task force to press criminal charges in corporate bribery cases, a senior official of the department disclosed today.

title: DUKE POWER BONDS OFFITED AT 8.42%
description: Analysts Expectations Exceeded by Strong Showing of Issue in a Desultory Market

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Medicaid Law Loopholes Allow $ 1 .5 Million Nursing Home Deal
description: TRENTON, Oct. 12An East Orange nursing home operator testified today at a state inquiry that a loophole in Federal and state Medicaid laws had allowed him to pledge a $1.5 million profit to be paid by taxpayers to a foreign creditor in return for a $75.000 loan.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The battle over whether New York City's deficitridden Government has enough money to run its new North Central Bronx Hospital has raised a much larger question of whether municipalities should be in the hospital business at all

title: ASTRONAUTS MAY RENEW USABILITY OF SPACE LAB
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)The Federal space agency is considering sending astronauts in 1980 up to the abandoned Skylab space station in earth orbit. Their mission would be to rocket it into a higher orbit, for possible later use.

title: Albany Studies Evidence Tied To Inquiry on Lefkowitz's Aides
description: The Albany County District Attorney's office has begun an investigation of the evidence referred to it by the Manhattan District Attorney's ofice after the indictments of thre aides to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and one former aide.

title: THEODORE W. ALLIS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Theodore W. Allis, chief counsel for the United States Customs Service, died today at the Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md., after a long illness. He was 51 years old.

title: Prospects Brighten for Westway
description: President Ford's endorsement of the controversial Westway sixlane Interstate System highway projectthe plan to replace the dilapidated, elevated West Side Highwayis expected to lead to a formal Federal decision before year's end.

title: Farm Commodity Futures Climb Limits on Estimate of Reduced Crops
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) The Agriculture Department lowered its 1976 corn and soybean production estimates by small amount and farm commodity futures on the Chicago Board of Trade advanced allowable limits today.

title: Washington &
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The deaths of two elderly women and one man in Pittsburgh early this week put an exclamation mark on a business problem that has afflicted the national swineflu immunization program since its beginning.

title: An ExAssociate of Rubin Carter Charges Pressure
description: JERSEY CITY. Oct. 13A former close associate of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter said today that the Passaic County Prosecutor's office had tried to pressure her to testify falsely against Mr. Carter at his current trial for murder.

title: Harris of Rams Injured, To Be Out Two Weeks
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 (UFO)James Harris, their starting quarterback, suffered a badly bruised right shoulder in the Los Angeles Rams 160 loss to the San Francisco 49ers Monday night and will be out of action for the next two games, the Rams disclosed today. Harris was sacked 10 times during the game but he played the full four periods.

title: Mark Climbs to a I5Month High Against the Dollar
description: LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP)The West German mark rose to a 15month high against the dollar today as the French franc declined to a 32month low.

title: PastDue Loans of Banks Decline To Lowest Level in 18 Months
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 13 (UPI)The number of pastdue loans held by the nation's 4,700 banks has dropped to the lowest level in a year and a half, the acting Comptroller of the Currency said today.

title: Article 4  No Title

title: Belmont Racing
YourFault
description: When national health insurance was introduced in Europe a century ago, most serious medical problems resulted from infectious diseases. In 1900, the three diseases killing the most people were influenza, tuberculosis and gastroenteritis. Little was known about their cause, prevention or treatment, and they occurred in innocent and unsuspecting victims.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Coroner Testifies in Trial of Doctor in Murder Case
description: MINEOLA, LI., Oct. 13A Pennsylvania Coroner testified today that Sophie Friedgood died within four to six hours after she had eaten and could not have been alive the next morning, as her husband, Dr. Charles E. Friedgood, had asserted.

title: New LowFare Airline Service Proposed for the Chicago Area
description: The Civil Aeuronautics Board was asked yesterday to approve a new lowfare airline service that would connect Chicago's largely abandoned Midway Airport and major cities within a radius of 500 miles.

title: Laver Top W.T.T. Rookie
description: World Team Tennis named 37yearold Rod Laver of the San Diego Friars as male rookie of the year and Sandy Mayer of the New York Sets the most valuable men's player.

title: Tarantula Meal Is an Attraction Of Insect Zoo At Smithsonian
description: WASHINGTONAt last the earth's most abundant, and some say most successful, form of animal life has a zoo of its own. Its called the Insect Zoo, and it is housed at no less prestigious a place than the Smithsonian Institution here.

description: ENTRIES

title: Arafat Appeals for Help
description: BEIRUT, Oct. 13 (AP)A guerrilla spokesman said today that Yasir Arafat, chief of the Palestine Liberation Organization, had phoned Arabs and asked them to put pressure on the Syrians to stop their attack.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
Study of 3 Deaths in Pittsburgh Indicates Vaccine Was Not Cause
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13Preliminary results of a medical investigation into the deaths of three elderly Pittsburgh residents who died Monday shortly after receiving influenza shots at the same health clinic here have shown no evidence that the vaccine was responsible, the director of the Allegheny County Health Department said in an interview here today.

title: News People Named For Friday's Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)Jim Hoge, editor of The Chicago SunTimes, will be moderator for Friday's VicePresidential debate between Senators Walter F. Mondale and Robert J. Dole, the sponsoring League of Women Voters Education Fund announced today.

title: Flyers, Kings Are Fined $9.750 for N.H.L. Brawl
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 13 (UPI)Clarence Campbell, the National Hockey League president, announced fines today totaling 59,750 against the Philadelphia Flyers and Los Angeles Kings for two benchclearing incidents in a game last Sunday.

title: Deaths
The New York Times/Chester Higgins Jr.
description: Avery Fisher Hall in its last stages of reconstruction. Dr. Cyril Harris, the acoustics consultant, said, I have been too busy to be nervous.

title: Latvian Tells of Life in U.S.
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 13Mr. Detlays, a bulky, baldish, whitehaired man with a heavy accent, described himself as a forester in prewar Latvia. After coming to the United States from Germany as a displaced person in 1946, he worked for 26 years at a Baltimore insulation plant of the General Electric Company. He retired in 1973 when he lost his left leg because of cancer, and wears a prosthesis.

title: Arnsparger Benches Morton for Snead
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y.. Oct. 13After three years of rebuilding, the Giants returned to Norm Snead today.

title: Doctor Charged in Actress's Death
description: TORRANCE, Calif., Oct. 13 (UPI)A. physician linked to the drug overdose death of a young television actress, Mary Anissa Jones, hss been charged with 11 felony counts of illegally prescribing powerful drugs. Dr. Don Carlos Moshos, 65 years old, was ordered to appear at preliminary hearing on Nov. 3. He was freed on $5,000 bail. Miss Jones, 19, died on Aug. 28. She portrayed Buffy in the TV series Family Affair.

title: NATIONAL BANK URGED FOR URBAN REVIVAL
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 13More than 2,000 housing and community development officials from cities and towns around the country are urging the establishment of a national development bank that would raise money for state or local governments to use in rebuilding declining urban neighborhoods and communities.

title: Trucker Indicted in Sex Slaying
description: FREEHOLD, N.J. Oct. 13 (UPI) A trucker who was jailed last month in the t ex slaying of a Kean College student has been indicted by a Monmouth County grand jury. The accused, William H. Mat thews, 35 years old, of Farmingdale, was indicted yesterday on charges of murder, rape, sodomy and possession of a knife in the stabbing of Virginia Duerkes, 20, in her Howell Township home on Sept. 2.

title: Rhodesian Warns Black Leaders on Geneva Talks
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 13Prime Minister Ian D. Smith today warned the black nationalist leaders invited to the coming Geneva conference that many moderate Africans were ready to cooperate in forming an interim government if the nationalist leaders did not come to terms under the provisions of the agreement he negotiated last month with Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: SYRIAN ARMY OPENS A 2D LEBANON DRIVE AGAINST GUERRILLAS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 13The Syrian Army, having struck at Palestinian guerrillas south pf here yesterday, opened new drive today against Palestinian units 12 miles east of Beirut.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LANDMARK CONCERT The fourstory house at 28 East 20th Street is a landmark. Its architecture is mid19th century Gothic Revival and Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th President, was born there Oct. 27, 1858. The house is open for visitors daily between 9 A.M. and 4:30 P.M. And currently, on Thursday evenings, there is a series of concerts of the American Landmark Festivals, featuring professional artists.

title: Restrictions Proposed On Killing of Dolphins
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)The National Marine Fisheries Service proposed today regulations that would make it illegal for tuna fishermen to kill certain types of dolphins, either accidentally or intentionally.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Swede Is for South Africa Sanctions
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13Sweden accused South Africa today of brutal oppression of its black populaion and proposed a ban on future investments in South Africa and SouthWest Africa, called Namibia by liberation forces, which it controls despite United Nations resolutions.

title: Dow Rises 15.95 to 948.30 As Trading Pace Quickens
description: The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 15.95 points yesterday to 948.30, in a rally analysts termed a technical reaction to the stock market's recent slump.

title: Two Policewomen Charge Bias
description: Last June, male members of the Nassau County. Police Department filed a class. action suit in United States District Court in Brooklyn charging that the promotion of 13 women officers to the rank of detective was discriminatory. The suit was subsequently dropped. Now, two policewomen have filed a class action suit charging they were discriminated against on the basis of sex because they were denied promotion to the rank of detective until last May 28 although both had joined the department in 1968.

title: The Urban Awakening
description: The longneglected urban issue in this Presidential campaign finally began to receive some serious attention this week as President Ford came to New York woo the critical urban vote.

title: Kodak's Earnings Off 7% in Quarter
description: The Eastern Kodak Company, the world's largest producer of photographic products reported yesterday a 7 percent decline in net income for the 12 weeks ended Sept. 5.

title: Music: Liszt
description: If Liszt's music has been receiving special attention in recent years his Annees de Pelerinage (Years of Pilgrimage) have for the most part been unaccountably neglected. These hooks of piano pieces that recall scenes visited during travels or reflect on artistic works are among the composer's more original and thoughtful creations.

title: Gullett Will Pitch for Reds; Bailey and Driessen to Bat
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 13People were still picking up the pieces from the annual pennantclinching uproar here today as the Cincinnati Reds confirmed their next battle plan: they will open the World Series on Saturday with Don Gullett pitching and either Dan Driessen or Bob Bailey as the designated hitter under the patchwork rules of baseball.

title: Dictaphone Buys 89.4% of Stock Of Data Documents at $45 Share
description: The Dictaphone Corporation said yesterday that a total of 419,814 shares, or 89.4 percent of the stock of Data Documents Inc.. had been tendered as a result of its offer of Oct. 1 to buy the shares at $45 a share.

title: Subway Trains Kill Two Men, Both Apparent Suicide Victims
description: Two men were killed by subway trains apparent suicidesin Queens and Manhattan yesterday. Neither victim was identified.

title: U.S. Flag Back on Top in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 13Gov. George C. Wallace has quietly made symbolic gesture to end a lingering 15year battle over the Civil War in Alabama, but his compromise has left Confederate sympathizers stridently angry.

title: PRICESUPPORT LOANS FOR FARMERS LIFTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  President Ford, reversing recent Agriculture Department pronouncements, decided today to increase pricesupport loans for farmers who grow wheat, corn and other livestockfeed grains.

title: our State Votes on Nonreturnable Beverage Containers Called Test of the Strength of Environmentalists
description: A significant test of the impetus of the environmental movement will come on Nov. 2 when citizens in Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan and Colorado vote on initiative measures to ban nonreturnable beverage containers.

title: RUFF IS URGED TO CHECK FORD ROLE IN WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 13 (AP)Charles F. Ruff, the Watergate special prosecutor, reportedly will decide this week whether to look into allegations that President Ford discussed blocking an early Watergate investigation with officials of the Nixon White House.

title: AMERICAN PARTY LISTED ON BALLOT IN 18 STATES
description: PIGEON FORGE, Tenn., Oct. 13 (UPI)The American Party Presidential, candidate Tom Anderson, is on the ballot in 18 states, and supporters are in court trying to get him listed in seven others, his campaign manager said today.

title: Islanders Turn Back Sabres, 43
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 13A banner in the balcony posed a tasteless riddle: Name two chickens and a turkey. Although the chickens were not identified, the turkey was, and it turned out to be Garry Howatt.

title: CONNECTICUT PANEL ASKS WIDE CHANGES
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 13A committee appointed by Gov. Ella T. Grasso to make proposals for restructuring the Connecticut government recommended today that the existing 256 agencies, boards and commissions reporting directly to the Governor be reduced to 14 for easier and moreefficient provision of government services.

title: Neighborhoods: Sugar Hill in Harlem, Once a Model of Sweet Life, Has Soured
description: The faded awning that stretches from the doorway of 409 Edgecombe Avenue and the massive redbrick building's commanding view of the Harlem Valley and the Bronx are about all that is left of the trappings of the good life and the elegance that once gave the area the name Sugar Hill.

title: Report at U.N. Says RichPoor Gap Can Be Narrowed by the Year 2000
description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., Oct. 13The oncefashionable doomsday economics, which warned that the planet could not sustain advancing economic growth, was questioned again today with publication of a detailed blueprint to help world governments narrow the gap between rich and poor nations by the year 2000.

title: Billy's Big Wish That Got Away
description: Dave Anderson

title: Mistrial Is Ruled for Susan Saxe As MurderTrial Jury Deadlocks
description: BOSTON. Oct. 13A mistrial was declared today in the bank robberymurder case of Susan Saxe as the jury found itself hopelessly deadlocked.

title: Justice Department Appoints New Chief of Its Crime Section
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)Assistant Attorney General Richard L, Thornburgh said today that he was shifting William S. Lynch, head of the Justice Department's organized crime section, to a new job as chief of the narcotics and dangerous chugs section.

title: Carter and Kennedy
description: Parallels are often drawn between Jimmy Carter and John F. Kennedy: the fresh personality in politics, the outsider winning over the established forces in the Democratic Party, the candidate's religion as an issue. But there is another Kennedy echo, one not so reassuring, that I think helps to explain the continuing doubts felt about Carter by some people naturally inclined to vote Democratic.

title: CIVILIAN LOSES POWER TO SETTLE NAVY DISPUTE
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Oct. 13 (AP)The Navy has stripped Gordon W. Rule, its top civilian contracting officer, of his power to settle a dispute with Newport News Shipbuilding & Dry Dock Company. The action came one day after the settlement was signed by Mr. Rule.

title: Average Church Donation: $137; Above 74, but Not Up to Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)The National Council of Churches said today that the average church member gave $137.09 in 1975, a slight increase over 1974 but not large enough to keep pace with inflation.

title: Joan Mondale on the Trail: A Chance to Speak Out
description: Joan Mondale wouldn't dream of speaking out on private matters as other political wives have done in recent years.

title: Disunity in Canada
description: Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau shocked Canadians recently with his pessimistic view of the country's future. In a speech in Toronto, he said in effect that time was running out for solving some of the nation's major problems. He particularly stressed the bitter divisions between the Federal and provincial governments on economic development policies and between English and Frenchspeaking Canadians on the issues of bilingualism and biculturalism.

title: Jets Appreciate Extra Day of Rest
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., Oct. 13Thanks to the National Football League's schedulemaker, who had put them down for next Monday night's televised game against New England at Foxboro, Mass., the New York Jets got their second straight day off today. The doctor couldn't have prescribed anything better.

title: Court Says State Must Allow Bronx Hospital to Open
description: A Supreme Court justice in Manhattan ordered the New York State Health Department yesterday to permit the opening of North Central Bronx Hospital, taking the first judicial step in a two  month controversy that has virtually paralyzed the municipal institution.

title: I. B, M. NET UP 18,5% FOR THIRD QUARTER; HONEYWELL UP 20.1%
description: The International Business Machines Corporation reported an 18.5 percent rise in thirdquarter earnings yesterday on a 9.9 percent sales rise.

title: Vikings Fined by N.F.L. For Showing Up Late
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 13 (AP) The Minnesota Vikings acknowledged today they had been fined and reprimanded by the National Football League for arriving late for their game against Detroit on Sept. 26.

title: TEACHER UNION LOSES DUESCHECKOFF RIGHT AS A STRIKE PENALTY
description: The state stripped the United Federation of Teachers yesterday of its right to automatic dues checkoff as punishment for the fiveday strike by New York City teachers last fall.

title: Opera: A Steady Meistersinger
description: The first Meistersinger of the season, last night at the Metropolitan Opera, saw a cast liberally sprinkled with debuts in addition to the presence of two singers heard in their roles for the first time. This cast suggested a Metropolitan miniraid on German opera houses. Gerd Brenneis, the Walther; Peter Meven, the Pogner: and Dieter Weller, the Beckmasser, all are Germanborn and active in German houses. Each was making his debut.

title: Radio
Haig Reports Readiness Deficiencies and a Garrison Mentality
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., Supreme Allied Cornii ander in Europe, said today there were ierious readiness deficiences within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, including what he described as a garrison mentality among the troops.

title: Arts Studio Keeps Trucking
description: KEYPORT, Oct. 11A mobile Hispanic arts studio, operating from a truck, opened here this week to provide free instruction in drawing, painting, printmaking, sculpture, video arts, photography and film making.

title: Suffolk's 2d District Voters Face Choice of WellLiked Candidates
description: ISLIP, L.I., OCT. 13The voters of the Second Congressional District, id southwestern Suffolk County, like to think they are faced with the choice between the better of two good men.

title: Meadowlands Is Proving A Hit With Trotting Fans
description: After only six weeks of existence, the Meadowlands harnesshorse track seems a sure thing to become America's leader or nearleader in attracting racing patrons. Already, its attendance figures compare favorably even with the nation's top thorougnbred layouts, Last week, for example, the New Jersey onemile oval, about

title: Australian Sailor Is Acquitted Of Rape in Unusual CourtMartial
description: WASHINGTON, Oct.13 (AP)An Australian sailor was found not guilty today of a charge of rape in an unusual courtmartial conducted in the Washington Navy Yard by the sailor's Australian Deers.

title: New York Likely to Regain Control Over Lake George
description: ALBANY, Oct. 13New York State is on the way to regaining its sovereignty over Lake George and the vessels that ply its waters.

title: Obraztsova Is Great in Aida
description: Should opera be about great drama or about great singing? Both, of course, when possible, and the Metropolitan Opera debut of the Soviet mezzosoprano Elena Obraztsova on Tuesday night made that everpresent possibility a reality. Miss Obraztsova, who first appeared in New York last season during the Bolshoi Opera's visit, sent the Met audience into a happy state of pandemonium with her fullthroated, grippingly acted Amneris in the season's first Aida. She is the finest Amnerls this reviewer has heard since the prime of Giulietta Simionato, and that is nearly 20 years ago.

title: British Unveil Reuter Monument
description: LONDON, Oct. 13 (Reuters)A monument to Baron Paul Julius deReuter, founder of the news organization that bears his name, was unveiled today. The monument, erected to mark the 125th anni,.crsary of the founding of Reuters ,n 1 ondon, consists of a monolith, a bust of Baron Reuter and a pavement with Eel:S in the court of the Royal Exchange Build. tug. Baron Reuter, born in Kassel, Gonnany, in 1816, founded his office in the building in 1851.

title: Ford Signs Medical Training Bill To Send Doctors to Areas of Need
description: WASHINGON, Oct. 13President Ford signed into law today a compromise $2.1 billion health manpower bill that for the first time ties Federal support to medical schools to the redistribution of doctors by location and choice of practice.

title: Chess:
description: In Days of Old, the Knights Were Boldbut Nowadays?

title: $1 MILLION IS GIVEN TO MODERN MUSEUM
description: A $1 million gift to the Museum of Modern Art, expressly for the renovation of its 37yearold auditorium and for its endowment, has been given by Roy V. Titus, son of the late Helena Rubinstein and retired chairman of the cosmetics company she founded.

title: 5th Small Church FireBombed In Mainly Black Area in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Oct. 13 (AP)Another small church was firebombed early today in a predominantly black area of Las Vegas. It was the fifth such blaze in the last three weeks.

title: Motor Homes Are Handy on Show Circuit

We make the house calls. We are the initial responder and we orovide the initial care.

description: Roy Boe, president of the Nets, gave the Los Angeles Lakers, Milwaukee Bucks and Philadelphia 76ers permission yesterday to negotiate with Julius Erving. The Knicks had also expressed interest in the Nets star, but were not given the same permission.

title: Brown U. Employees Approve Pact
description: PROVIDENCE, RI, Oct. 13 (AP)A twoyear contract has been ratified by striking service employees at Brown University, ending a 104day walkout at the school by about 330 food services, housing and maintenance workers. About 200 union members voted to approve the contract last night. There were 32 dissenting votes. The university said that the contract calls for an increase of no less than 25 cents an hour and no more than 30 cents an hour.

title: Amicable
description: Officials of the Patrolman's Benevolent Association and the city are scheduled to meet again today for the eighth straight day of informal talks aimed at finding a way around an impasse over working schedules and a deferred increase in wages.

title: THAI CALLS ELECTION AT LEAST 4 YEARS OFF
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 13The Prime Ministerdesignate said tonight that it would be at least four years before democratic elections were held in Thailand and as much as a decade before full democratic rule might be restored.

title: Williams Is Retained as Counsel For T.W.A. Hijacking Defendant
description: Edward Bennett Williams was retained yesterday to defend Zvonko Busic, the alleged leader of last month's hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet after thou.; sands of Croatian sympathizers raised $75,000 as a retainer.

description: The passage of the Civil Rights Attorneys Fees Award Act after a sharp struggle in the Senate was a major advance for the publicinterest law movement. It also provided insights into both the importance and the vulnerability of that movement.

title: Shipping/Mails
Ford Move on New Arms to Israel Is Termed Political
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  President Ford's decision to lift the ban on some advanced military equipment for Israel apparently caught middlelevel State Department and Defense Department experts by surprise. This reinforced the view in both agencies that the decision had been timed primarily for political purposes.

title: Priest Abducted in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 13 (AP)An Irish Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Patrick Rice of County Cork, was abducted by armed men today while conducting a prayer meeting in a Buenos Aires slum area, the Irish Embassy said. The abduction was expected to cause new friction between Argentina's military regime and the church.

title: The U.N. Today
Israel Reports 5 Who Landed In Speedboat Were Guerrillas
description: TEL AVIV, Oct.13Five Palestinians who landed a speedboat on a beach here in daylight on Sept. 25 were officially identified today as terrorists and members of Al Fatah guerrilla organization. The speedboat in which they approached the beach was said by military sources to have been launched from a Turkish freighter that was sailing from Lebanon to Egypt.

title: Bruins Down Rangers; Sheppard Gets 3 Goals
description: The revamped New York Rangers failed last night in their first big test against a club with an established reputaton losing by 51 to the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden.

title: HERBERT J. STONE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Herbert J. Stone, senior producer in the Voice of America's Far East Division, died Sunday in Roosevelt Hospital in New York after undergoing surgery for cancer, the United States Information Agency announced here today. Mr. Stone, who was 68 years old, lived in Arlington, Va.

title: Calder's Universe
description: Calder's Universe at the Whitney Museum of Art starts with a great advantage: Most people can never see enough of Alexander Calder and his work. No living American artist is more loved than he.

title: Citibank Heads Group In South Africa Loan
description: An agreement to grant a Eurodollar loan of about $300 million to the South African Government is expected to be signed in the next eight days by Citibank and other leading banks, industry sources said yesterday.

title: APPEAL TO SCIENTISTS CALLS FOR ACTIVISM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13An international panel of scientists has challenged their colleagues around the world to come out of hiding and help guide the world away from a variety of potential disasters.

title: Democrat Jailed as War Resister Giving McCloskey Fight on Coast
description: PALO ALTO. Calf.. Oct. 13When the Vietnam war was a burning issue in this area a few years ago, David Harris went to jail rather than serve in the army and Paul N. McCloskey Jr. was a Republican Representative challenging his incumbent President, Richard Nixon.

title: Oct. 110 Auto Sales Up by 7.2%; Ford's Off 8.2% Because of Strike
description: DETROIT, Oct. 13The American auto industry reported today that total sales from Oct. 1. to 10 rose by 7.2 percent from last year although the Ford Motor Company said its sales declined by 8.2 percent because of the strike by the United Automobile Workers union.

He was charged with kidnapping and attempted murder.

title: More Deaths Reported Alter Shots But No Link to Flu Vaccine Is Found

But the center said there was no evidence than any of the deaths had been caused by the vaccine.

title: Notes on People

title: Drama: Touch of British Humor

The British playwright Michael Freya started life, or at least started his career, as a columnist who could be directly compared with our own Russell Baker. He was always funny, but always pertinent, and he wore his political heart on his sleeve as if the sleeve in question were wearing a broken wrist. Or worse.

In New Jersey, the Senate President becomes Acting Governor whenever the Governor leaves the state.

title: A Trustee of Grant Charges 27 Banks Acted to Aid Selves

Grant Company of having dominated and controlled Grant's directors and management. Such actions, the complaint said, enabled the banks to serve their own interests to the detriment of the company its creditors and shareholders.

title: Liberals
description: Mayor Beanie, who was the first major New York politician to endorse Jimmy Carter for President, will not be on the dais when Mr. Carter speaks at the Liberal Party dinner tonight.

title: Film: A Sequel:'Sounder Part 2' Is Gloomy and Full of Sentimentality
description: Every dog has his day, and apparently the hound-type dog that gave his name to the movie "Sounder" five years ago had had his.In "Part 2 Sounder" the dog is hardly to be seen: He's just part of the barnyard background. It's like making something called "King Kong 2" with only a view or two of an ape in long shot.The original "Sounder" was a sentimental, immensely popular film about the maturing of a small black farm boy under various types of adversity. The sequel has more maturing, more adversity and enough unleavened sentimentality to give a rhinoceros heart-burn."Part 2 Sounder" is about the same Louisiana farm family as the original. David, the boy, sets his heart on getting a school for the neighborhood. His father, Nathan, takes up the cause, enlists his neighbors, and works day and night to get a schoolhouse built so that the local teacherwho planned to go Northwill stay.It is a depressed kind of film, with a lot of gloominess and teeth-gritting. It is unrelievedly didacticabout the need of working hard and persevering and believingand lets in as little life or liveliness as a McGuffey's Reader. As the mother, dubious about the school-building effort. Ebony Wright gives a performance that is strong and modulated and above its material. As the father, Harold Sylvester does an obvious rendition of gloom and resolution. The children, particularly Darryl Young as David, are allowed to overact painfully."Part 2 Sounder," which opened yesterday at showcase theaters, has Robert B. Radnitz as executive producer and Lonne Elder 3d as screenplay-writer. They were the authors of the original "Sounder"; on the other hand, Mr. Radnitz has chosen a new director, William Graham, to replace Martin Ritt, as well as a new cast. The changes doesn't seem to be an improvement.

title: Hunt Withdraws From Race
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 13 (UPI)James Hunt, the British racecar driver who is suffering from a left arm injury aggravated by two recent crashes, withdrew today from the International Race of Champions Series set for this weekend at Riverside Raceway. Hunt will not be replaced in the lineup, which will now feature 11 drivers in the allstar series.

description: Jean Renoir's preeminence as a film artist is again being acknowledged this year by the New York Film Festival with a retrospective showing of one of his great early works, Nana, produced in 192526 and never before (as far as I can learn) seen here in as complete a version as the one that the festival is presenting. The film, being projected from a fine new 35 mm print with piano accompaniment by Arthur Kleiner, will be presented at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 9:15 and Saturday at 2:30 P.M.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Declines 2.1%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The Association of American Railroads reported todaythat freight traffic on United States:: railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.2 billion tonmiles, 2:1 percent below the yearearlier level. Car loadings in the same period totaled 475,OM cars, down 4.6 percent from last year. The American Trucking AssociaI dons Inc., reported that intercity truck, tonnage was 6 percent above last year.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14Two more large companies have admitted making questionable foreign payments, and a third company has found an account that may have been used to make small political contributions in this country, according to Securities and Exchange Commission filings made public today.

title: Art: de Kooning's New Frontiers
description: SOME OF THE MOST memorable marks ever made with paint on canvas have been made at one time or another by Willem de Kooning. Those marks of his have a life of their own: wayward, fullfleshed, temerarious. Sometimes they connect with pictorial ambitions of a kind once nurtured by Rubens, Rembrandt, Jordaens. Sometimes they seem to be there just for the hell of it. Either way, they suggest that Mr. de Kooning is still probing the frontiers of possibility in painting and that one day one of them will give way again.

title: Market Place

title: Gov. Grasso to Address Dinner

title: Trade Centers Proliferating Both in the U.S. and Abroad
description: Whether goldsmiths or garment makers, people in the same business have always preferred to be together in their own districts to share news, services and markets. And now something of the same flocking instinct is resulting in a growing number of world trade centers, appropriately on a worldwide scale.

title: You Can Say It. The Kids Are 21.
description: POTSDA.M, N. Y.  Watching the news while we did the dishes, my 15yearold son and I speculated over the forbidden words that Earl Butz had spoken at the wrong moment in the presence of the wrong person. The careful circumlocutions in the evening newspaper, the awesome retribution of resignation from high office, the sanctimonious evasions by commentators  all glistened and whirled around another word, decent. Former Secretary Butz called President Ford decent. Mr. Ford spoke of Mr. Butz as decent. Only the words, apparently, were indecent, and therefore indiscreet.

title: Viking 2 Misses a Report
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 14 (UPI)An unknown problem cut the main communications link between the Viking 2 on Mars and its controllers on Earth, scientists at the Jet Propulsion laboratory said today. A radio data transmission scheduled to arrive last night was not received, a spokesman said. Scientists switched successfully to a backup system.

title: 3d Satellite Launched In Marisat System
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 14 (AP)Marisat 3, the final link in $100million satellite network for ships and submarines, was launched into space at 6:44 P.M. today atop a Delta rocket.

title: Records: Remember The Swingle Singers?
description: A dozen years ago, the two hottest groups in pop music were the Beatles and the Swingle Singers. The Beatles need no introduction. But the Swingle Singers? They were seven French singers and Ward Swingle, an American, who used such vocalized sounds as dabbaclabbadab, dododo and bumpahdah to create swinging versions of Bach (their Bach's Greatest Hits was on the topselling charts for more than a year), Vivaldi, Mozart and Chopin. It was a novelty that had great momentary appeal, but the appeal wore off as suddenly as it arrived.

title: Emily Burke Is Married To John K. Herrmann
description: Mrs. Emily Schweizer Burke and John K. Herrmann, both of Madison, Conn., were married there yesterday in the chapel of the First Congregational Church. The Rev. Franklin A. Bower performed the ceremony. Mr. Herrmann's brotherinlaw and sister, Mr. and Mrs. William E. Hill of New York and Old Black Point, Conn., attended the couple.

title: Antiques
description: AT THE TURN of the century, the arts and crafts movement filled the offices and dens of America with robust furniture some of it was called mission styleas well as stainedglass lamps and weighty art pottery. Now it is back and booming. This week the revival of the style seemed headed for success with the opening in SoHo of the Jordan Volpe Gallery. 457 West Broadway.

title: Stagehands Reach Accord With Theaters
description: A tentative agreement has been reached by the League of New York Theaters and Producers and Theatrical Protective Union, Local 1, representing stagehands, on a new threeyear contract. Bernard Jacobs, chief negotiator for the theater owners and producers, said the dispute had been resolved with the assistance of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees union. Terms and conditions were not announced, pending ratification by league members and the stagehands membership.

title: Vladimir Visson, at 71; Director of Exhibitions For Wildenstein Galleries
description: Vladimir Visson, who for 32 years was director of exhibitions for the Wildenstein Galleries in New York, died at his home, 315 East 68 Street, on Wednesday. He was 71 years old, and had been in poor health for several years.

title: The Economic Scene
description: The American business presence looms very large in Hong Kong, especially in banking, but also in the securities business, petroleum, electronics and other industries. Page D3.

title: William Cahn Dies at 64, A Newsman Who Turned To Writing About Unions
description: William Cahn, a newspaperman who turned to writing profiles of corporations and labor unions, died Wednesday at the Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: About Real Estate
description: The inbaskets at the Federal Housing Administration's regional offices here are filling up these days with builders applications for mortgage insurance on multifamily housing. A Federal mortgageinsurance commitment is a sure ticket to mortgage money the scarcity of which in the city has inexorably ground down the production of privately financed apartments.

title: Management: Executive Job Gain Is Called Good Sign for Economy
description: The executive job market, after contracting somewhat last month, seems to be looking up in a trend that could spell continued good news for the economy as a whole.

title: Dennis Says He Knows Way to Beat Foreman in Bout Tonight
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Oct. 14His mom and dad run five times a week, and three of his friends hitchhiked here from Attleboro, Mass., to show their loyalty.

title: ... Prickly Laureate
description: On receiving the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics yesterday, Prof. Milton Friedman of the University of Chicago displayed his characteristic gall by expressing disdain for the very jury of the Swedish Royal Academy of Science that had awarded him the honor. It was not that, like Groucho Marx, Friedman would refuse to join any club that would have him, but rather that he would not accept the particular seven people who make these awards as the jury to which I would want to submit my scientific work.

title: Kennecott Will Sell Peabody Coal for $102 Billion T o Holding Company Headed by N ewmont Mining
description: Kennecott has been under a 1971 order by the Federal Trade Commission to divest itself of Peabody. Besides Newmont, he other concerns involved in the purchase are the Williams Companies, the Bechtel Corporation, the Fluor Corporation and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

title: Shell Expects Gain
description: John S. Bookout, president of the Shell Oil Company, told security analysts in San Francisco that he expected thirdquarter earnings to exceed last year $2.36 a share and that 1976 full year's net would top the record $9.21 a share earned in 1974.

title: State Aides Warn at Present Rate There Will Be a 229 Million Budget Deficit by End of Fiscal Year
description: state budget officials warned yesterday that at current rates of spending and tax collections, the state's precariously balanced budget faced a deficit of $229 million by the time the fiscal year ends six months from now.

title: Jews Occupy Building and Urge Ouster of Prelate
description: Twentyfive members of Concerned Jowish Youth took over the headquarters of the National Council of Churches yesterday in a nonviolent protest against the refusal of the council's governing board to oust one of its members who has been accused of World War II crimes.

title: Jazz: David Murray on Saxophone
description: David Murray, a young tenorsaxophonist who has emerged as one of the more fluent and promising players on this instrument since he arrived in New York more than a year ago, went long way toward fulfilling his promise Wednesday at New York University's Eisner and Lubin Auditorium.

title: Jazz Echoes In NoHo Art Gallery
description: Musical evenings are becoming standard fare in the art galleries of downtown Manhattan, but the evenings the Center for International Arts has planned for the next month are hardly the ordinary bill of fare. Where else can one hear a soloist who plays preColumbian Mayan, Aztec and Toltec instruments, an IndianAfricanjazz fusion group, traditional music from the Andes, and some of the most progressive young musicians from Brazil, in addition to contemporary chamber music and jazz?

title: Bridge:
description: Witdtther or not the number of bridge players in the country is increasing hard to assess, but there are some indications.

title: Calvin Tomkins Travels Through Art Landscapes
description: It is the artist who decides what is art, the Metropolitan Museum curator Henry Geldzahler once announced to panel discussion convened to dispose of a thennew phenomenon, Pop Art. After reading Calvin Tomkins's travel journals through the art world of the 1960's and 70's, describing some prominent landmarks, the armchair tourist feels he knows enough to say that the definition of art is considerably more complicated than it used to be, even in today's permissive climate, where artists make up the rulesor rather, insist upon the lack of them. Since Mr. Tomkins is a better tour guide than cartographer, the reader is advised to sit back and enjoy the Sceneiy of a lively, ifit's1962this  mustbe Pop Art whirl through a special world that breeds new esthetic movements faster than new nations pop up at the United Nations.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Public Service Electric & Gas Company received a $136.5 million rate increase raising an average customer's electric bill by about $2.50 a month. The Board of Public Utility Commissioners approved the increase, but ordered a revision of the company's residential electric rate structure so that lowusage customers receive a smaller increase than highusage customers.

title: By Boat: Postcard View of New York
description: In the absence of mangobearing maidens with hibiscus blossoms in their hair, in the absence of loinclothwearing fishermen, cooking freshcaught sea bass over driftwood fires, it is sometimes difficult to remember that we are all island dwellers on this place known as Manhattan. Some of us are natives and some are explorers who came looking for a 20thcentury version of the Indian spice route. Some of us are castawayscontentedly shipwrecked or miserably marooned. None of us, at any rate, can De too mucn farther than a dozen miles from the ocean, though months may go by without our laying eyes on so much as dinghy.

title: Music : Mozart at the Y
description: The New York Chamber Soloists inaugurated what promises to be a most worthy series called The Intimate Mozart Wednesday night at the 92nd Street Y. But before one gets to the music, a gripe: It seems perverse, in a series devoted to Mozart's less frequently heard chamber master works, in the words of the program, that there weren't any notes on the music. A whole page of artist biographies and another whole page of credits, plus a largely blank front page.

title: Art People
description: MARCIA TUCKER, curator of contemporary art at the Whitney Museum for the last eight years, has, been dismissed by Tom Armstrong, the Whitney's director. Mr. Armstrong would not comment on the dismissal yesterday, but issued an epic statement: Any changes in the staff of the museum are judgments by the director toward the attainment of objectives based upon priorities established at a particular time in the history of the museum. tionship with the Whitney, I was professionally supported and nurtured by this institution, and I'm deeply, deeply sorry to leave it. What will she do after her departure, as of Jan. 1? Observing that one by one, museums are cutting down on activity in contemporary art, she says that she would like to create again the kind of situation now missing in New Yorkan institute of contemporary art that would nurture living artists.

title: Film Festival: 'Harlan County'
description: COAL MINERS are a permanent underground in more than the literal sense. They trouble any society they support: like feet, the more they are weighed down by their owners the more pain they give.In East Germany and Poland the authorities treat them with a special deference. Even in its harsher times the Franco regime was never able to stop them from striking. Laws against assembly were useless. A hammer would stop a mile below ground; the man in the next chamber would go to see what the matter was; the silence would spread and a line of stubborn, blackened men came to the surface and stayed until the Government could figure out some way of getting them back down.Miners' strength, their assertiveness and solidarity are based largely on their economic power; and where coal-mining becomes marginal to the economy of a region, they lose much of their ability to fight. There is another factor, though. Miners in their tunnels, vulnerable to explosions, cave-ins and destroyed lungs, weigh on a society's conscience as well as its economy. Their grievances command an instinctive respect.One of the reasons for the defeat of Prime Minister Edward Heath in Britain two years ago was a widespread feeling that in choosing the miners as the target for his austerity fight he had picked just the wrong target."Harlan County, U.S.A.," to be shown tonight and tomorrow at the New York Film Festival in Alice Tully Hall, is a full-length documentary of the year-long strike carried on by the miners at the Brookside works in eastern Kentucky. It has flaws, some of them considerable, but it is a fascinating and moving work. Its strength lies chiefly in its ability to illuminate the peculiar frightfulness and valor of coal-mining, and made it clear just why coal-miners can never be rightly treated as a less than a very special case.Barbara Kopple and her photographers have got right inside the life of the miners and their families in their long struggle against the operators of the Brookside mine and its parent company, the Duke Power Company. It is a brilliantly detailed report from one side of a battle that caused one death, several shootings and a flood of violent bitterness; and that brought back to Harlan County memories of the much-bloodier coal strikes of the early 1930's.The strike began after the miners voted to join the United Mine Workers of Americawhich had lost its hold in eastern Kentuckyand the owners refused to sign a standard U.M.W. contract. It was not until more than a yaer laterafter the violence had claimed the life of one striker  that Duke Power, under strong pressure from Federal mediators, agreed to sign.The film shows the picketing, the use of state troopers to keep the road open for nonstrikers, the confrontations, a shooting, the efforts of the strikers and their families to remain organized and united through the long year. It intercuts old footage from the 1931 strike, where five miners were killed. It also details the successful battle of reformers to oust the old national leadership of the U.M.W.; and the support given to the Harlen County strike by the new leadership under Arnold R. Miller.Some of the thematic interweaving is awkward, but this is more than made up for by the extraordinary intimacy Miss Kopple has achieved with the strikers and with the bitter life of the strike. There is an old miner, lungs torn by coal dust, who makes our chests hurt as he talks. There are frightening scenes of tight-lipped strike-breakers, guns openly displayed rushing through the pickets. There is a terrifying night scene where shots are fired and we see the leader of the strike-breakers brandishing a pistol in the cab of his pick-up truck. There is a heartbreaking scene where the mother of the slain miner collapses at his wake. There is much more, equally good.The film is entirely partisan. Considering that the company's refusal to sign a contract was condemned by the National Labor Relations Board as a pretext not to recognize the union and considering that the film itself is forthrightly an effort to see the struggle through the miners' own eyes, this is no real drawback. Perhaps there is some skimping: it is something of a cinematic trick to film the President of Duke Power in such tight closeup that his face completely fills the screen.More serious are the sometimes questionable ways in which the film advances its message: that the Harlan strike is only part of a struggle, and that the miners must go on struggling and striking. The instance I am thinking of comes in its suggestion that the reformist leadership of the U.M.W. may ave sold out in 1974after the Harlan County strike was overby recommending acceptance of a national mine contract that curtails local strikes.The film does not call this a sell-outit uses no narration at all and conveys its message by its editingbut all reactions of individual miners that it shows before the vote are negative. Yet the membership ratified the contract by 44,000 to 34,000. The film states this, to be sure; yet somehow all the faces we have learned to admire during the long Harlan County struggle seem to push us to feel toward Mr. Miller the same way we felt toward the recalcitrant mine owners.

title: The Screen: Fassbinder's 'Fear of Fear'
description: THE most terrifying fear is the fear that has no discernable cause. It simply exists. Like an air plant, it requires no soil to flourish and grow, only a host.Margot (Margit Carstensen), the heroine in Rainer Werner Fassbinder's spare, spooky, always sunlit new film, "Fear of Fear" (Angstvor der Angst), knows that the anxieties she began to feel in the last months of her pregnancy, and that have become more and more frequent since the birth of her child, have no particular source.Margot is beautiful, with the perfect features of a department-store mannequin. She has a husband and two small children she loves. They have a car, a comfortable apartment, an idealized middle-class existence. Her mother-in-law and sister-in-law are continually prying into Margot's life and disapproving, but they can be dealt with. Yet something is decidedly wrong.There are times Margot feels as if she were existing under water. Communication is dulled. Movements are slow. To hear music she must turn up the stereo so high it shakes her brain cells. When she looks at that perfect face in the mirror she isn't sure she knows whose it is though she realizes that's crazy. Crazy? She takes a couple of Valiums or a swig of brandy and she calms down. For a little while, anyway."Fear of Fear," which Mr. Fassbinder made last year for West German television, is about the autumn of materialism in the form of an intensely personal case history of a schizophrenic. As in the world where she lives, everything is perfect for Margot, yet nothing works. Something important is missing. Just what is never stated. The direction of the film is straightforward, blunt, but its meanings and associations are manifest obliquely.Mr. Fassbinder ("The Bitter Tears of Petra Von Kant," "The Merchant of Four Seasons," "AliFear Eats the Soul" and "Fox") continues to beat the age of 31the most fascinating, talented, prolific, original young film maker in West Germany and, for that matter, one of the most exciting in Western Europe today.Compared to a full-scale portraitist like Bernardo Bertolucci, he is a sketch artist, but the sketches are singular, and in their abundance they reveal a film maker of broad and original visions. His work is so rich that I'm sure not even he is always aware of the interpretations that can be read into them, nor that he much cares. He's already moved on to a new project."Fear of Fear" is a small film, as perfectly sculpted as Miss Carstensen's features, which, in turn, were as much a part of the decor as the settings and costumes of "Petra Von Kant." The film looks realistic, but these looks are deceiving. Like all Fassbinder films, "Fear of Fear" presents us with a distillation of realitya dream in which everything countsrather than photographed reportage on the way things are. Mr. Fassbinder is a major artist and one of the principal discoveries of the 14-year-old New York Film Festival."Fear of Fear" will be shown today at the festival at Alice Tully Hall at 6:15 P.M. and tomorrow at 9 P.M.

title: At a Tycoon's 80th Birthday, Guess Who Pops Out of the Cake
description: If you can believe a 1,000pound cake, 6 feet in diameter and 12 feet high, fitted inside with a little airvented room, furnished with an easy chair and two lights, then you can believe Bob Hope popping out of it. Which is exactly what happened last night in the middle of the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Ports Reopened to Foreign Beef After National Quotas Were Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI)A United States Customs official said yesterday that all ports of entry Were temporarily closed Wednesday night to shipments of foreign beef, but that they had been reonened.

Dr. Clark does not take issue with Mr. Moynihan's studies of black families.

title: The Tragedyof Joanne: From a Small Ohio Town To Despair in New York
description: By all accounts, it was the happiest day in the largely unhappy life of Joanne Bashold; not in all her 24 years had her family ever heard her so exuberant.

title: Advertising
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo.,Oct. 14 The head of a company that places more than $200 million worth of advertising a year in the media soundly criticized print and broadcast journalism's coverage of business before an audience of other major national advertisers here today.

title: Notes on People
description: Four silenced men, dissidents under prison sentence in their own countries, were designated by Robert L. Bernstein, head of Random House, to share the $1,000 from his 1976 Florina Lasker Civil Liberties Award for 1976. The publishing executive was honored at a Pierre Hotel dinner Wednesday by the New York Civil Liberties Union, which cited his personal and professional decidation to the rights of men and women everywhere to speak and publish freely.

title: Good Weather for Series
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 1 (AP)  Comd weather is forecast for the Iveekend World Series games in Cincinnati, according to the National Weather Service. Saturday is expected to be partly cloudy with high temperatures in the lowtomid 60's. The forecast for Sunday is fair.

title: ExPremier of Rhodesia Joins a Black Delegation To Geneva Conference
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 14 (UPI)Former Prime Minister R. S. Garfield Todd, a sharp critic of the white minority Government, who was under house arrest at his ranch until four months ago, was joined a black nationalist delegation to the Rhodesia conference in Geneva.

title: Stages of Childhood Now Playing a Busy Fall Schedule
description: The scene is as magical a garden as any child (or adult, for that matter) could want: trees, a pool, a stone bridge and glass towers rising beyond the wall. On every side are marvelous figures of metal and stone, such as a king might command for his backyard, the works of masters like Rodin, Henry Moore, Maillol and Giacometti. This is, of course, the Museum of Modern Art's Sculpture Garden, which will be presenting Alice Through the Looking Glass, its first fulllength outdoor play for children, this Sunday.

title: Spanish Publisher Is in Hot Water For Linking 11 to Lockheed Affair
description: MADRID, Oct. 14Spain's Lockheed nonscandal has landed Eugenio Stirez, the nation's bestknown muckraker, in hot water.

First it sent the Opera de Paris to appear at the Metropolitan Opera House and at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, and now it is the turn of the Orchestre de Paris, which is making an American tour.

title: Nobel Research . .
description: Since the days of President Lyndon B. Johnson, rising impatience with basic medical research has been evident among those in both executive and legislative branches of Government who control the distribution of research funds in Washington. In effect, the demand has been that scientists work directly on such great tasks as, say, curing cancer and not waste time on peripheral matters whose practical importance is not apparent.

title: Security, Not Silence
description: MYSTIC, Conn.National silence is not the same as national security. Unfortunately, that was not the message from the House of Representatives when it suppressed the House Intelligence Committee's final report and then investigated those who had uncovered the United States misdeeds.

title: NORTHEAST IS FOUND FAR BEHIND ON JOBS
description: Employment in the Northeast has grown very little since the economic recovery began last year, though it has risen significantly in other regions of the country, a Bureau of Labor Statistics official reported yesterday.

title: Despite Rhodesian Acrimony, U. S. Officials Expect Accord by YearEnd
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14Administration officials said today they expected agreement by year's end on an interim Rhodesian government to replace the regime of Ian D. Smith despite the sharp public differences between black and white Rhodesian leaders.

title: Allied Chemical's Net Down 55.8% in Quarter Pollution Fine Is Cited
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation's thirdquarter earnings were dealt a severe blow by a Federal District Court's fine of $13.38 million for polluting the James River in Virginia with the insecticide Kepone. The company said yesterday that earnines for the quarter fell 55.8 percent.

description: Wendy Sears of Camaiore, Italy, daughter of Mrs. Samuel P. Sears of Dennis, Mass., and the late Mr. Sears, was married in Massa, Italy, yesterday to Andrea Grassi of Massa, a sculptor. The civil ceremony was performed by the local Mayor in his city hall office.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14Charles F. Ruff, the Watergate special prosecutor, said today that he had found no evidence to support an allegation that President Ford had misused political contributions from maritime unions or a reason to believe that any other violations of law had occurred.

description: What is the influence of parents on the development of homosexuality in their children?

title: Publishing: Chagall Biographer
description: SIDNEY ALEXANDER, novelist essayist and translator, was saying the other day: I came up too fast from the 16th century to the 20th. There was a block for a while, but the dam finally broke, and now the book is virtually done. He was talking about his new biography of Marc Chagall, one of the bestknown painters of the school of Paris, which G. P. Putnam's Sons will be publishing at a date not yet announced.

title: A Grass Court Roman a Clef
description: Why should professional tennis, with all its attendant glamour and pecuniary rewards, be exploited only by the lithe panthers of the courts? Or only by the makers of racquets and the manufacturers of apparel? Why not novelists? After all, what we have here is a world of international travel, of adulation by multilingual crowds, of televised excitementall the ingredients for racy, titillating fiction. And so here comes Ralph M. Demers, an Englishman, with The Circuit. Like the Las Vegas challenge matches with purses of $250,000 to the winner, this novel simply had to happen. Tennis is that kind of game.

title: Peking Warns Against Conspiring And Tampering With Mao's Words
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 14China's information media have begun issuing strongly worded warnings against conspiracies and anyone who tampers with the words of Chairman Mao Tsetung, as Chinese officials continued their silence today on reports that at least four senior leftist leaders had been arrested.

title: Martha Graham Hailed by Nation; Given Freedom Medal by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  Martha Graham, whose 50year pioneering career as a dancer and choreographer has made her the foremost figure in American modern dance, received the nation's highest civilian award from President Ford tonight.

title: Broadway
description: 'HERZL, by Dore Schary and Amos Elon, will go into rehearsal Oct. 25, start previews Nov. 19, and then open at the Palace on Nov. 30. Raising the money was rough, Mr. Schary, who is also the producer of Herzl said, a long, long battle, but now we have it. So naturally, I'm excited. Mr. Schary said that Paul Hecht would play Herzl, while Judith Light would play his wife, and that the production would be directed by J. Fanelli. (Mr. Ranelli disdains not ony a first name; he disdains a period, too.)

title: Sentence for Kallinger Means Confinement for Life
description: HACKENSACK, Oct. 14Judge Thomas F. Dalton of Superior Court sentenced Joseph Kallinger today to life in prison for murdering Maria Fasching in Leonia last year, and ordered that the term be consecutive with a previous sentence, rather than concurrent, to insure that Mr. Kallinger will not be back on the streets in any short period of time.

title: Memorial Seruices

Saturday, October 16th, Contributions to the Janet Vail Memorial Center wilt be welcomed be Juanita Vail Kusner, R.D. 5. Boo 293, East Stroudsburg, Pa. 18301.

Or the Depression and the proletariat, which brings us to W.P.A., a recently opened restaurant on Spring Street in SoHo, and in spite of the campy grimness of its theme, an original and amusing newcomer,
