title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON. Oct. 14Matthew Feldma, who was indicted earlier this week by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy and commercial hrlery, said today he had no intention of :stepping down as Senate President. He said he would serve as Acting Goyernor next Tuesday when Governor Byrne left the state on a weeklong visit to 5anan.

title: Ad Aides See Presidential Candidates as the Issues
description: In the makingor the remakingof the President this year, issues are not the issue, John Deardourff, President Ford's advertising consultant, said yesterday. The issue he added, is the candidate's character, his experience, his intellect and his decisiveness.

title: People and Business
description: Jack Grey, president of Standard Oil of California, and J. U. Langston, vice president for exploration of the Exxon Corporation, were among those issued legislative subpoenas in California yesterday seeking to compel them to testify about their natural gas reserves.

title: Where to Dance
description: The following is a list of some of the more popular discotheques in the city. Admission charges include the price of one or two druths, and all of the places remain open until 4 A.M. on busy nights.

title: Books of The Times
description: The space you are working in is 42 inches high. The 12 inches at the bottom is icy water, but after swinging a pick or shovel in a half crouch for a couple of hours, you finally have to kneel down in the wet, which further stiffens your already stiff joints. Sometimes the water has sulphur in it, Much, when it inevitably gets inside your boots, burns the outer layer of skin off your feet. After a backbreaking eight hours work, you may have choice of crawling on your hands and knees through a halfmile of low tunnel or risking a ride on the conveyor belt. Sometimes the belt is moving fast, too fast for you to jump off if there's an obstruction ahead; sometimes it does not stop when you pull on the automatic break.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE SOPHOMORE JINX is a phenomenon not limited to athletes. In popular music, it supposedly manifests itself in the second albums of performers who have attracted a lot of attention with their first albums. There are exceptions to the rule, of courseso many that there may be no rule at all. Still, the notion makes sense that a pop star might have beginner's luck with his or her debut album, pouring youthful, unselfconscious inspiration into it, and then stumble trying to imitate it the second time around.

title: How to Play Politics
description: Jimmy Carter asked for it the other day, and Gerald Ford promptly let him have it. On Tuesday, Mr. Carter called for an increase in pricesupport loans to grain farmers, saying such an increase was long overdue. On Wednesday, President Ford directed the Agriculture Department to announce such an increase50 percent for wheat, 20 percent for corn, and proportional increases for the other principal feed grains.

description: TOP WEEKEND FILMS

title: Weekend Gardening: Desert Flowers
description: The indoor drought of winter will soon be upon us. And for all the warm comfort central heating offers, it reduces the relative humidity in the average home to slightly less than that of the Sahara. This can spell problems for house plants, unless one is growing succulents such as cactus.

title: World Series Schedule
British Trade Deficit Rises $118 Million; Pound Off to $1.64
description: LONDON, Oct. 14The British Government reported today a $118 million rise in its monthly trade deficit. To compound the nation's problems, the powerful miners threatened to strike and the pound dropped to $1.64, just a fraction of a cent above its record low.

title: Decline Attributed to Currency Changes
description: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the third quarter fell 5.5 percent but gained slightly for the first nine months of the year.

description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1976

title: Forsythe and Rival Debate on Jobs
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Oct. 14The two major candidates for the Sixth Congressional District seat both have lowkey campaign styles. They also agree that unemployment is a paramount problem in the area, where it exceeds 11 percent. There the similarity between them ends.

title: Pact Reached in City Opera Strike
description: The New York City Opera and the musicians union reached tentative agreement early this morning on a new threeyear contract, ending a 17day strike.

title: Opera: Met Is Steady in Season's First Meistersinger
description: THE first Meistersinger of the season, Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera, saw a cast liberally sprinkled with debuts in addition to the presence of two singers heard in their roles for the first time. This cast suggested a Metropolitan miniraid on German opera houses. Gerd Brenneis, the Walther; Peter Meven, the Pogner, and Dieter Weller, the Beckmasser, all are Germanborn and active in German houses. Each was making his debut.

title: A Handout Is No Policy
description: In choosing Yonkers as the site for the signing of the law to extend Federal revenuesharing, President Ford has unwittingly turned a political  campaign gesture into a public reminder of a flawed Federal program. While posing as a Chief Executive rushing to an embattled city's rescue, Mr. Ford merely underscored the inadequacy of his Administration's approach to urban problemsin Yonkers and elsewhere.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Since tonight's more unusual featureshoxing on CBS at 7:30 and Vice Presidential debating on ABC, CBS, NBC and PBS at 9:30are live and outside the clutches of prereviewing, this is an opportunity to mention TV's older brother. Contrary to casual impressions, radio is very much alive and doing rather well with, among others, young people on the street carrying portables, shutins who detest TV, and automobile commuters. This writer is an earlymorning addict of radio and, on Sunday afternoons from I to 6, prefers to listen to Latin salsa music on WRVRFM, where it is knowledgeably presented by Roger Dawson, nonLatin conga drummer from California.

title: Joffrey Ballet Takes an AllAmerican Leap
description: JUST when we were all about to put the Bicentennial year to rest, the Joffrey Ballet has come up with an allAmerican season at the City Center  30 ballets by American choreographers.

description: TRENTON, Oct. 14Two real estate experts from Fort Lee testified today at an inquiry on Medicaid nursinghome costs that entrepreneurs in New Jersey were being paid grossly excessive rents from the State Medicaid program in some instances.

title: Friedman Consumption View Held Free of Political Bias
description: Why was Milton Friedman awarded the 1976 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science? Certainly not for his rightwing political viewsthese probably kept him waiting in line for a few extra yearsbut for scientific contributionss whose validity is generally deemed to be independent of his political biases or aims. Dr. Friedman's contributions in economics to be singled out by Sweden's Royal Academy of Science was his work on consumption analysis. This is an area that he himself considers a contribution in pure or positive economics, devoid of specific political content.

title: France's Nuclear Turn
description: International measures to discourage the spread of atomic weapons and, especially, of the civilian nuclear technology and equipment contributing to proliferation are apparently arousing new and belated interest on the part of the French Government, a principal footdragger on nuclear controls. The first policy statement of President Giscard d'Estaing's new cabinetlevel committee on nuclear export policy raises some hope of progress in this direction.

title: DartmouthHarvard Contest A MustWin Game for Each

title: Pauline Koner In Nondancing Role
description: I've got so many clothes from the 30's, I could open a boutique, now that they're so fashionable, Pauline Koner said. Artistically, too, I think that's what's happening to me. I've lasted long enough for the fashion to get back to my kind of dancing.

title: Carter, Focusing on Ford Record, Gains Among Independents in Poll
description: Jimmy Carter has succeeded in making President Ford's record, rather than his own personality, the main focus of the most recent phase of the Presidential contest, and as a result the Georgian has regained the strong position he held at the beginning of the general election campaign.

title: Stage: A Fiorello With Bounce
description: There is an appropriateness to the Equity Theater Library's revival of Fiorello! that only history could devise. What with Watergate, the nursing home ripoffs and other plots against the citizenry, the Jerry BockSheldon Harnick chronicle of a man of true blue integrity chasing the scoundrels out of New York City politics has the freshness and attractiveness of a newly cut bowl of flowers. The career of Fiorello La Guardia had builtin drama, and Jerome Weidman and George Abbott, who devised the book, had the mother wit to see it.

title: Moynihan Urges Voters to Spurn Buckley's Radicalism of the Right
description: Daniel P. Moynihan, the DemocraticLiberal candidate for the United States Senate, yesterday exhorted all people of both major parties who stand in the vital center of the political spectrum to reject his otmonent's radicalism of the right.

description: The Federal Government won a major round yesterday in its efforts to permit oil companies to begin drilling in the Atlantic Ocean for offshore oil with a potential value of billions of dollars.

description: Edward S. Mills, former president of Longmans, Green & Company, New York book publishers, died Sunday in his home on Quinby Lane in Bridgehampton, L. I. He was 93 years old.

description: HOUSTON, Oct. 14After spending most of this week in Washington in preparation, Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican VicePresidential candidate, flew here today for a debate he has made few bones about wishing were not scheduled.

title: A Woman Film Maker In the Coal Fields
description: In the 1930's the coal mines of Kentucky's Harlan County were the scene of some of the bloodiest battles in the history of American trade unionism. Forty years later, as history threatened to repeat itself, a softspoken young film maker named Barbara Kopple was there to record it, in the faces and words of officials of the Duke Power Company and the United Mine Workers, of armed strikebreakers and rankandfile organizers and, most of all, of the miners, their wives and the children of Harlan County.

title: The Best And the Worst
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14In his latest televised press conference, President Ford dramatized the best and the worst of his Administration. He described in his opening statement what the ideal of the Presidential campaign really should be, and in the rest of the conference, what it really was.

description: The city's fiscal monitors yesterday projected a series of revenue shortfalls and cost overruns that might increase its deficit this yearbut not enough to warrant any new immediate spending cuts.

description: BUFFALO, Oct. 14United States Senator James L. Buckley nearly crossed paths with the Democratic Presidential candidate, Jimmy Carter, in Rochester this morning as he began a tour that included Buffalo today and will include Syracuse and Albany tomorrow.

Gilbert Kalish's second record, however, seems to he heading us in the right direction. Mr. Kalish is not only

title: FORD SCORES CARTER ON ECONOMIC POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  President Ford used a nationally televised news conference tonight to attack his campaign opponent. Jimmy Carter, and to stress what he called distinct differences between himself and the Democratic candidate on government spending and tax policy.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14Charles F. Ruff, the Watergate special prosecutor, said today that he had found no evidence to support an allegation that President Ford had misused political contributions from maritime unions or a 'reason to believe that any other violations of law had occurred.

description: CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP)Farm commodity futures fell heavily on the Chicago Board of Trade today, led by soybean futures, which fell the limit of 20 cents a bushel. Soybeans had advanced the limit of 20 cents a bushel in the previous session.

title: U.N. Unit Says Chile Abuses Widen
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14A United Nations panel of inquiry has charged that Chile's ruling military junta is systematically extending its suppression of human rights to additional sectors of the population, including the church, trade unions, academics and professional groups.

description: The Joffrey Ballet opened a fourweek season at the City Center Wednesay night with a few curtain speeches marking the company's 20th anniversary and tenth year of its residency in the house.

title: Retail Store Sales Increase 8%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The Department of Commerce reported today that retail store sales last week were an estimated $12.53 billion, up about 8 percent from last year's $11.59 billion. Department store sales weer about $1.29 billion, up about 12 perecent from the yearearlier level of $1.5 billion.

In the opener, the Philadelphia 76ers, the favorite so far for National Basketball Association honors, overwhelmed the Boston Celtics 14199. The crowd was 10.079.

description: MADRID, Oct. 11 (AP)?? Vitas of Argentina. the tooseeded player, withdrew from the 575,000 Madrid tennis tournament today after suffering, a hand injury during practice. Vilas's forfeit advanced Balazs Toreczy of Hungary into the quartercinals of the Grand Prix event.

description: ?? ADELPHIA. Oct. 14 (UPI)?? and Bob Gainey scored v.) op.Is each tonight in leading the ?? Canadiens to a 71 victory ?? Philadelphia Flyers.

title: 4 Banks in N.Y. Raise Earnings For 3d Quarter
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, reported yesterday an earnings increase of 37.6 percent in thirdquarter operating earnings. Three other New York commercial banking organizations reported moderately improved thirdquarter earnings.

title: City Starts Filling In a Big HoleAll That's Left of a Grand Plan
description: The mud holes filled with greenish brown water and the rats that cover good part of the vacant lot at 101st Street and Shore Road in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn are not what the builders who purchased the lot a few years back had in mind when they talked about putting in a swimming pool.

title: SYRIANS PENETRATE PALESTINIAN LINES, IMPERIL WEST BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 14Syrian tanks and infantry supported by heavy artillery fire broke through Palestinian positions today both east and south of here, virtually cutting off the predominantly Moslem western part of Beirut from the rest of the country.

title: PRISON AGENCY HEAD DISMISSES TOP AIDE
description: Step by New York State Correction Commissioner Adds to Dispute on Inmate Rights Policy

title: PITTSBURGH REVIVES FLU SHOTS PROGRAM
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14 Health officials announced today that flu shots for senior citizens and those with chronic illnesses will be resumed here next Monday under a new set of guidelines that could affect the way that such shots are given elsewhere in the country.

title: Enough Is Enough
description: More than four decades ago, the Scottsboro case came to stand as the basic metaphor for the injustices inflicted on black citizens by the American judicial system. It was classic. In the spring of 1931, nine young black men were accused of raping two white women on a freight train in the South. Though one of the women later recanted and became an active participant in the defense of the Scottsboro Boys, the nine defendants were, nevertheless, pursued remorselessly by the processes of Alabama justice.

title: STOCKS DROP 1238, RESUMING DECLINE AFTER 1DAY RALLY
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.38 points yesterday to close at 935.92, resuming its lengthy decline and nearly erasing Wednesday's singleday rally of 15.95 points.

title: Auto Output to Rise 2.3% This Week
description: DETROIT, Oct. 14Newcar production is expected to be up 2.3 percent this week from last as a result of the reopening of some Ford Motor Company plants closed by the United Automobile Workers strike, according to industry analysts.

title: At the Movies
description: By now, moviegoers know who the Marathon Man is. He's Dustin Hoffman, a panicked graduate student who is pursued through the streets of New York by secret agents, double agents and Nazi ogres. But who is the Marathon woman, the harried hero's enigmatic classmate whose extracurricular activities include spying, skullduggery and sexual deceit?

title: Broadway Enjoying Black Talent Boom
description: As weekend playgoers are discovering, Broadway is burgeoning with black theater. There is so much black talent working thereactors singers, writers, directorsand such a lively black audience that the theater district could almost be retagged the Great Black Way. At the same time, white audiences are discovering black theater. This is not an insular variety of entertainment, but very much part of the mainstream.

title: Where One Man Hopes The Jazz Will Be Heavenly
description: Heavenly jazz, according to a man who has formed an organization called Heavenly Jazz Inc., is jazz that can be heard without the babble of people who aren't listening to the music.

title: Hospital Agency Is Planning Major Cuts and Layoffs.
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that would meet a $34.3million budget deficit by speeding up its bill collections now and by unspecified layoffs and reductions in medical care in the city's municipal hospitals beginning Jan. 1.

title: Nazi War Crimes Suspect Asserts C.I.A. Used Him as AntiSoviet Spy
description: A Californian who has been under investigation by Federal immigration officials for alleged Nazi war crimes said yesterday that he had been recruited by the Central Intelligence Agency for antiSoviet spy work and that the agency had discussed his case with the authorities of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: St. Louis Paper Endorses Ford
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14 (AP)The Republican Presidential ticket of Gerald R. Ford and Senator Robert J. Dole was endorsed today by The GlobeDemocrat. The newspaper terms itself an independent. It backed Richard M. Nixon in the 1968 and 1972 Presidential elections.

title: Met Opens Egyptian Galleries
description: THE good news from the Metropolitan Museum of Art is that the new Egyptian galleriesor, to be precise, what is called Phase I in the reinstallation of the museum's permanent collection of Egyptian art and artifactsare a great success. Though this phase of the installation is limited, for the moment, to the earliest and latest material in the collectionwith the art of the middle periods scheduled to go on view at a later time, not yet specifiedone feels no hesitation in saying that Egyptian galleries are a triumph of museological intelligence. They open to the public tomorrow, and remain on permanent view.

title: CocaCola in Accord For Taylor Wine Co.
description: The CocaCola Company announced in Atlanta yesterday that it had entered into a preliminary agreement with the Taylor Wine Company of Hammo???? port, N. Y., for merging Taylor inte CocaCola for CocaCala stock wortp 393.6 million. An announcement on the merger talks had been made last month

title: Presence of U.S. Business Looms Large in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 14  Early retirement in Florida began to pale several months ago for Stanley Young, a veteran Asian hand. He missed the attractions of this part of the world after a fouryear absence, and so he decided to accept an invitation to

title: Marijuana Charge's Against King Dismissed
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 14 (UPI)Charges of marijuana possession were dismissed today against Tennessee's basketball star, Bernard King, who is one of the top scorers in the country.

title: Hartford's Elderly Take Their Flu Shots in Stride
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 14 Jimmy Williams downed his way up the line to get his swine flu shot at the Parkville Senior Center today, making such faces and going through such mock angaish that he scarcely noticed the sho in the arm when he got it.

title: The New York Times/D. Gorton Jimmy Carter waves to wellwishers at Americana Hotel where he joined more than 2,000 others in tribute to Liberal Party. Joining in welcome to the Democratic Presidential candidate are Donald Harrington, left, a party leader, and Goevrnor Carey. Story on page B5.
Miss Lee a Hit At the Waldorf
description: Peggy Lee's annual appearances in the Empire Room of the Waldorf Astoria Hotel are always somewhat of an adventure. There have been times when her performances there have been brilliant and others, such as the last two years, when, because of material, orchestrations or battles with the sound system, she has been surprisingly ineffective.

title: MORRIS ZELDIN, 86, DIES; AN EARLY ZIONIST LEADER
description: Morris A. Zeldin, a pioneer in the Zionist movement here 60 years ago and one of the organizers ofthe United Jewish Appeal of New York 37 years ago, died Thursday in Long Beach (L.I.) Memorial Hospital after a brief illness. He was 86 years old and lived at 3885 Darby Lane, Seaford, L.I.

title: White House Orders F.B.I. Head To Shelve an Attack on the Press
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The White House today ordered Clarence M. Kelley the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investiga t ion, to abandon a proposed speech that was sharply critical of recent news coveraee of his aeencv.

title: Comsat Reports a Decrease of 35.6 Percent in Income for the 3d Quarter
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation, which derives most of its revenues from leasing channels on a worldwide communications satellite system, yesterday reported declines of 35.6 percent in third quarter income and 18.5 percent for the first nine months.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Oct. 15. 1976

title: World Series Schedule
description: Yankees vs. Cincinnati

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Universal Leaf Files Complaint on Congoleura
description: The Universal Leaf Tobacco Company said it had filed a complaint in the United States Federal District Court in Richmond seeking an injunction against the Congoleum Corporation's acquiting any Universal shares or attempting to acquire control of Universal.

title: ECONOMY IS STRESSED BY DOLE AND MONDALE DURING SHARP DEBATE
description: Senators Walter F. Mondale and Robert J. Dole met last night in a sporadically acrimonious debate, the first ever between VicePresidential nominees, and argued whether Republican fiscal prudence or Democratic social programs would best serve the nation's economy.

title: THIRD PARTY IS NAMED IN THE POLICE DISPUTE
description: The City of New York and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday called in Michael I, Sovern, dean of the Columbia University Law School and veteran labor mediator, to help resolve a contract dispute that has resulted in several weeks of street demonstrations by offduty policemen.

title: Navy Reports Promising Contact.. With F14 That Fell Off Carrier
description: LONDON, Oct. 15 (AP)A promising contact has been made with an F'14 Tomcat fighter that rolled off the deck of the carrier John F. Kennedy a month ago and sank in 1,890 feet of water off the north coast of Scotland, the United States Navy announced today.

title: 2 Black Actors to Be Tried for Transkei Remarks
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 15John Kani and Winston Ntshona, two black actors who won Tony awards on Broadway last year, will be brought to trial in connection with their performances last week in the prizewinning play, Sizwe Banzi is Dead, Kaiser Matanzima, chief minister of the Transkei. said tonight.

title: Buckley, in a Shift to the Offensive, Quickens the Pace of His Campaign
description: ALBANY, Oct. 15With Election Day little more than two weeks away, Senator James L. Buckley is cramming as many appearances as time will allow from dawn to midnight, upstate and downstate, into a hard campaign for reelection.

title: Wall Posters in China Charge Four Leftists With Plotting Against Party
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 15Wall posters appeared in Shanghai and other cities today accusing four senior leftists, including Chairman Mao Tsetung's widow, Chiang Ching, of having plotted against the Communist Party. There were unconfirmed rumors that the four had tried to assassinate Hua Kuofeng, the new party chairman.

title: THAI MILITARY JUNTA ROUNDS UP LEFTISTS UNDER NEW DIRECTIVE
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Saturday, Oct. 16 Thailand's military junta has begun nationwide roundup of leftist writers, professors and intellectuals under a new directive allowing detention of suspected Communists for up to 30 days with no bail and no charges.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15A preliminary report by the General Tire and Rubber Company's special review committee indicates it has found many of the same questionable and illegal practices with which the Securities and Exchange Commission charged it last spring.

title: EXCLUSION OF BLACKS ON JURIES CRITICIZED
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 15A United States District Court judge declared today that Federal prosecutors in Connecticut had been using their right to peremptory jury challenges too frequently on blacks, keeping them from serving on criminal juries, and he moved to halt the practice.

title: Cincinnati AllRound Club
description: ? Uct. 15Out here in Middle America along the banks of the Ohio River, the uncertainties of life and even of Presidential politics were yielding today to some sure things: Johnny Bench's throwing arm, Joe Morgan's ability to steal bases, George Foster's booming bat and the widespread notion that the Cincinnati Reds will train all these weapons on the New York Yankees in the World Series, which opens here tomorrow at Riverfront Stadium.

title: Musicians Vote To Accept Pact With City Opera
description: Members of the musicians union, who have been on strike against the New York City Opera, ratified a new agreement yesterday, opening the way for a resumption of performances Tuesday night.

title: EARNINGS DOWN BY 42.3% FOR FIRST PENNSYLVANIA
description: The First Pennsylvania Corporation, the nation's 19th largest banking organization, reported yesterday that thirdquarter operating earnings declined 42.3 percent to $4.8 million, or 36 cents a share, from $9.3 million, or 71 cents a share, in the 1975 quarter.

title: ERA. URGES A CURB ON FLUOROCARBONS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The Food and Drug Administration proposed today to phase out all nonessential uses of fluorocarbon propellants in spray cans because of the danger they pose to the Earth's protective ozone layer.

title: A Battle of Undefeated, Untied Today: C.W. Post Eleven Plays Kings Point
description: Two of the undefeated and untied football teams that are ranked among the top five in the nation meet today. This is not a match between Michigan and Maryland, which were No. 1 and No. 5, respectively, in this week's Associated Press majorcollege poll of sportswriters. The Wolverines and the Terrapins are not scheduled to meet this season or any other season in the near future.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: LION MAULS NEWSMAN: Del Donahoo, Cleveland newscaster, sitting on lion Tuesday in Elyria, Ohio, during filming of a TV special. Suddenly,
description: animal turned on the newsman and bit him on the face and neck. At righ Dave Chivonic, a trainer, trying to stop attack. Donahoo was injured slightly

title: Agency Issues Strongest Assertion of Vaccine Safety
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Americans have received more than two and a half million doses of flu vaccine in the last two weeks, a Federal agency reported today, and there has been no evidence whatever that the vaccinations are causing deaths.

title: ECONOMY IS STRESSED BY DOLE AND MONDALE DURING SHARP DEBATE
description: Senators Walter F. Mondale and Robert J. Dole met last night in a sporadically acrimonious debate, the first ever between VicePresidential nominees, and argued whether Republican fiscal prudence or Democratic social programs would best serve the nation's economy.

title: Probable Lineups For Series Opener
RUFF REJECTS INQUIRY ON FORD'S ROLE IN 72
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Charles F. Ruff, the Watergate special prosecutor, has declined to begin an inquiry into whether President Ford, as a Congressman in 1972, sought to block an investigation of Watergate by a committee of the House of Representatives at the behest of the Nixon White House.

title: Fed OutputIndex Failed to Go Up For September
description: For the first time in a year and a half, the Federal Reserve Board's index of industrial production failed to rise last month.

title: North Korea Accuses U.S.
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 15 (Reuters)North Korea today accused the United States of having conducted reconnaisance flights over its territory. The official North Korean press agency said that an SR71 highaltitude reconnaissance plane flew over North Korea last Thursday and Friday.

title: Patents: Portable Heart Device Diagnoses Disorders by Sound
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The vice president in charge of real estate for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has made an invention for the company in a distinctly different field. Samuel H. Hellenbrand was granted a patent this week for what is called a heart detective.

title: SAUL KAPLAN
description: Saul Kaplan, an attorney and former chief counsel to the New York State Democratic Party and the legislative leadership died Thursday at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Miami, Fla. He was 66 years old and lived in Bay Harbor Island, Fla. since his retirement in 1965.

title: Honey, Drive On. Nothing Here.
description: WAUBUN, Minn.While living in Minnesota's White Earth State Forest, I have gradually come to suspect our contemporary notions of wilderness. I live in a cabin surrounded by lakes and forests, and I have traveled and hiked thousands of miles to visit such famed wilderness areas as Washington's North Cascades National Park. I've stood above Mount Rainier's timberline on a cloudless, January day, and I have also dreamed of crossing Lake Superior in a canoe. In short, have become a man in love with wilderness, and in search of wilderness. It is with special sorrow, then, that contemplate the dying wilderness.

title: Napoli, Leader of Gambling Ring, Is Sentenced to Five Years in Jail
description: James V. Napoli Sr., who headed the largest gambling operation in the country, with 2,000 employees in the metropolitan area and an operation estimated at $120 million to $150 million a year, was sentenced yesterday to five years in jail and a $20,000 fine. It was the maximum penalty under the law.

title: Carter Says Rohatyn Plan Deserves Consideration
description: Jimmy Carter said yesterday that Felix Q.. Rohatyn's plan to stretch out the longterm debt of New York City merits serious consideration, and he criticized President Ford for what he described as Mr. Ford's cavalier rejection of the refinancing proposal.

title: Care Is Urged to Ease Fears of Elderly on Flu Shots
description: TRENTON, Oct. 15Two New Jersey health officials said today that a general lack of consideration might have contributed to the deaths of a number of elderly persons in recent days at swineflu clinics.

title: THAI MILITARY JUNTA ROUNDS UP LEFTISTS UNDER NEW DIRECTIVE
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Saturday, Oct. 16 Thailand's military junta has begun a nationwide roundup of leftist writers, professors and intellectuals under a new directive allowing detention of suspected Communists for up to 30 days with no bail and no charges.

title: Mexico Blanks U.S. In Soccer Qualifying
description: PUEBLA, Mexico, Oct. 15 (AP)The United States soccer team had a day today it would like to forget. The Americans lost to Mexico, 30, in a World Cup qualifying game, and when they returned to their dressing room they found their clothes and personal belongings had been stolen.

title: IRA S. STEVENS
description: Ira S. Stevens, an executive in the motion picture industry, died Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 54 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: SELFPROPELLED Orchestra conducting as a distinct procedure began to get under way in the 17th century. Until then, in the Baroque period (roughly, 16001700), for example, music was scored for small groups. Orchestration was simple, the pulse of the music coincided with the melodic line and conducting chores were handled by the first violinist, the organist or the harpsichordist. Beethoven, in effect, created the modern orchestra and his music's drastic tempo changes, pauses and his personal interpretation demanded orchestral leadership.

title: Testimony Is Ended in Perez's Lawsuit Against Ali
description: Testimony ended yesterday in the fourday, multimilliondoilar court battle between Muhammad Ali, the heavyweight champion, and a fight referee, Anthony Perez. The trial in United States District Court is expected to go to the jury of four women and two men on Monday after each side makes a summation and the judge issues instructions on the law to the jurors. Perez, a referee for eight years, claims that All made false and defamatory statements that he was a dirty referee . . paid by gangsters after the AliChuck Wepner fight in March 1975.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Once Again the Powder Keg
description: ATHENS The Balkan peninsula used to be regarded by statesmen as the world's powder keg, the area most likely to explode into armed conflict, and it is noteworthy that this century's three most dangerous international military confrontations prior to World War II began in that general area.

title: ALIEN AGENCY QUERIED ON C.I.A., EXNAZI LINK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI)Two members of Congress asked the commissioner of the In and Naturalization Service today to confirm or deny that the Central Intelligence Agency had intervened in behalf of alleged Nazi war criminals discovered in this country.

title: Saban, Bills
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 15 (UP1)Lou Saban resigned today as head coach of the National Football League Buffalo Bills and Jim Ringo, an assistant whom Saban hired in 1972, was named to replace him.

title: About the World Series
description: RULESFirst team to win four games wins Series. TEAMS  New York Yankees (American League) vs. Cincinnati Reds (National League).

title: Ragtime Revival for Those GoldenOak Oldies
description: HIGH POINT, N. C., Oct 15Gay 90's nostalgia has swept through furniture collections introduced this week at the Southern Furniture Market here. And some of the thousands of manufacturers and store buyers gathered for the semiannual showings view the weighty resultsthe roam desks and moustache shavings stands, the brass beds, fainting couches and player pianos as the biggst furniture fad to hit since Mediterranean flooded the market in the late 1960's.

title: Around the Nation
description: The surgeon who removed SenatOr Hubert H. Humphrey's cancerous bladder last week said yesterday that pathological tests showed that, cancer had penetrated the bladder wall and involved some of the regional lymph nodes.

title: Japan Chooses F15, But Cost Is a Problem
description: TOKYO, Oct. 15Japan has selected the McDonnellDouglas F15 as its next mainstay fighter for its SelfDefense Forces.

title: Reynolds Packard Dies
description: Reynolds Packard, a flamboyant foreign correspondent who retired in 1972 after covering wars and revolutions in South America, Africa, Europe and Asia for more than three decades, died in a Rome hospital last Friday. He was 72 years old and had been ill for some time, according to friends in Rome, where he had lived for many years.

title: The Night Those Yankees Copped The Pennant
description: A joyous epilogue to the dramatic lastinning Yankee pennant victory over Kansas City erupted Thursday night outside Yankee Stadium and went on until after 1 A.M. yesterday, with strangers embracing, pounding one another on the back and shoulders, offering one another drinks out of bottles.

title: Transcript of Debate Between the VicePresidential Candidates
description: Following is the transcript of the debate between Senator Robert J. Dole and Senator Walter F. Mondale last night at the Alley Theater in Houston, as recorded by The New yore Times through the facilities of ABC News. The moderator was James Hoge of The Chicago SunTimes. The questioners were Marilyn Berger of NBC News, Walter Mears of The Associated Press and Hal Bruno of Newsweek.

title: New Yankee Magic
description: Chris Chambliss supplied the lightning on the first pitch in the last of the ninth in the final game of the American League championship series. The Yankees won the game and their first American League pennant in 12 years. So the stadium exploded and a warm feeling of pride spread through the night to the rest of the city.

title: Companies Report on Sales and Earnings Results
Cincinnati AllRound Club
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 15Out here in Middle America along the banks of the Ohio River, the uncertainties of life and even of Presidential politics were yielding today to some sure things: Johnny Bench's throwing arm, Joe Morgan's ability to steal bases, George Foster's booming hat and the widespread notion that the Cincinnati Reds will train all these weapons on the New York Yankees in the World Series. which opens here tomorrow at Riverfront Stadium.

title: Some in Pittsburgh Now Unsure About Getting Swine Flu Shots
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct 14When this city resumes its flu immunization program Monday, Mrs. James Carlson might not be in the line for her shot.

title: U.S. Weighing Beef Import Quotas
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (Reuters)The United States Government is proposing beef import quotas that would allow Australia, New Zealand and other exporters to ship beef to the United States this year in the same quantities previously set under voluntary restraint agreements, informed diplomatic sources said today.

title: Belgian Concern Makes Food Town Stores Offer
description: Food Town Stores of Salisbury, N. C., operators of a chain of 42 supermarkets in North Carolina, said that Etablissements Delhaize Freres et Cia of Brussels had made a tender offer to buy 391,000 shares of Food Town common stock at $25 a share for a total of about $9.8 million.

title: Mobile Home Industry Is Trimming Sales Estimates as Economy Lags
description: LOS ANGELES. OCT. 15A cooler economy has taken some of the steam out of what a few months ago had promised to be a blistering recovery for the nation's mobile home industry.

title: Westinghouse Sues Uranium Suppliers In a Counter Action
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation filed an antitrust suit yesterday against 29 uranium producers, charging price fixing and curtailment of supply.

title: West Bank Town Remains Uneasy After 11 Days Under lsraeli Curfew
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 15A curfew imposed on the West Bank town of Hebron by Israeli military forces entered its 12th day today as top Government officials sought to dampen the religious passions aroused among Moslems and Jews by acts of desecration committed at a Hebron shrine revered by both faiths.

title: Dow Is Up 1.08 to 937 as Forecast On Economy Spurs Some Buying
description: The stock market closed slightly high er yesterday in slower trading.

title: RETIRED TEAMSTERS SUE OVER PENSIONS
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP)A lawyer for 10 present and retired members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters says he has filed a classaction suit accusing three teamsters union pension funds of cheating their members out of pensions.

title: NEW LOITERING LAW IS DECLARED INVALID
description: The state's new antiloitering law, which was designed to combat street prostitution, was declared unconstitutionally vague yesterday by a Manhattan Criminal Court judge.

title: Bridge:
description: Those who brood on their disasters at the bridge table long after the event sometimes make an embarrassing and irritating discovery: That the winning contract had eluded them in the bidding, and also in the immediate postmortem.

title: Hometown Acting to Shape Virile Defense of Valentino
description: CASTELLANETA, Italy, Oct. 14Rudolph Valentino, dressed as a gaucho, cuts in on a couple on the dance floor, knocks the man to the ground and sweeps the girl into his arms for a slow tango, followed by a kiss. Later, as a sheik, he

title: Soybean and Grain Futures Decline
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP)Soybean futures prices fell heavily on the Chicago Board of Trade today and strongly influenced lower prices in nearly all other commodities on the floor.

title: Holy Cross Ends 9Game Losing Streak
description: BOSTON, Oct.15 (AP)Bob Morton, a junior quarterback, scored touchdowns on runs of 3 and 52 yards and Holy Cross snapped a ninegame losing streak tonight with a 3111 victory over Boston University, The Crusaders were ignited by a 50yard return of the opening kickoff by Larry Ewald, a freshman. They needed just four plays to go 48 yards, Morton picking out a hole to score standing up with the game just 55 seconds old.

title: Gullett and Alexander Open World Series Today
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 15In a matchup that will mark the World Series debut of the designated hitter and the return of the New York Yankees, the Cincinnati Reds will open the defense of their baseball championship tomorrow with Don Gullett pitching against Doyle Alexander.

title: No 1976 Nobel Peace Prize Award
description: OSLO, Oct. 15The Nobel Committee of the Norwegian Parliament decided today not to award a Nobel Peace Prize

title: W.Van Alan Clark Sr.Dies In Falmouth, Mass., at 88; Former Chairman of Avon
description: W. Van Alan Clark Sr., former board chairman of Avon Inc. and a philanthropist, died Thursday at Falmouth Hospital, Falmouth, Mass. He was 88 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: Youth Is Slain in Chinatown; Police Fear New Gang Violence
description: A 16yearold youth was shot and failed in Chinatown last night by three people who the police believe are members of the White Eagles youth gang. The victim, shot once in the chest at 90 Elizabeth Street with what police believed was a small pistol, was removed to St. Vincent's Hospital. He died on the operating table. The police were seeking his identification. A witness was being questioned by detectives.

title: Visitors Bureau Reports Boom in Tourism
description: New York City's tourist industry is enjoying a boomlet this year, with rises in the number of vacation and convention visitors pushing hotel occupancy well above 1975 levels.

title: About the World Series
description: RULESFirst team to win four games wins Series. TEAMSNew York Yankees (American League) vs. Cincinnati Reds (National League).

title: About New York
description: Proud and calculating, the owners and breeders of thoroughbred competitors convened Thursday night at the Lithuanian hall in Maspeth, Queens, for the great futurity race todayexactly 308.483 miles from Charlottesville, Va., to Joe LaRocca's loft, as the pigeon flies.

title: Seales Stops Italian Boxer
description: MILAN, Italy, Oct. 15 (AP)Sugar Ray Seales of the United States stopped Gianni Mingardi of Italy tonight in the sixth round of their scheduled eightround middleweight fight. Seales, 24 years old, scored his 32d victory as a professional against the 33yearold Italian. Seales won the gold medal in the welterweight division at the Munich Olympics in 1972.

title: U.S. Deplores Action
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The State Department issued a statement today deploring Prime Minister Castro's unilateral and unwarranted action in announcing that he would cancel the antihijacking agreement.

title: CORRECTION
description: An incorrect data for a United Nations Day concert at the General Assembly, with Marian Anderson as narrator, was given in The Times last Saturday. The correct date is Oct. 24.

title: Control Board Spurns Proposals For Hospital and Transit Budgets
description: Expressing irritation and impatience, the Emergency Financial Control Board told Mayor Beame yesterday that it could not accept any budget submissions from the New York City hospital system without a restructuring of management at the Health and Hospitals Corporationincluding the possible replacement of Dr. L. S. Holloman, the corporation president.

title: Changing the Look Without Changing the Furniture
description: WHITE PLAINSEllen Altman was afraid to sit on a chair. So she perched on the living room steps of her splitlevel house in White Plains.

title: Bronfman Judge Warns Lawyers Not to Talk Outside of Courtroom
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 15The judge in the Bronfman kidnapping trial, disturbed by the contents of a television newscast yesterday, today directed defense and prosecution attorneys not to discuss the case with reporters until the jury reached a verdict.

title: State Ordered to Open Bronx Hospital at Once
description: State Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Greenfield ordered the New York State Health Department yesterday to issue forthwith an operating certificate for the new North Central Bronx Hospital, but the state agency filed an appeal in the Appellate Division, thus delaying further the hospital's opening.

description: Questions on Page 24

title: RUFF REJECTS INQUIRY ON FORD'S ROLE IN '72
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 15Charles F. Ruff, the Watergate special prosecutor, has declined to begin an inquiry into whether President Ford, as a Congressman in 1972, sought to block an investigation of Watergate by a committee of the House of Representatives at the behest of the Nixon White House.

title: Atomic Fallout in Milk Declines
description: HARRISBURG. Pa., Oct. 15 (AP)The level of nuclear material in milk has dropped steadily through the week, spokesman for the State Department of Environmental Resources said today. Radioactive iodine 131 was first found in milk samples early last week, the result of fallout from a Sept. 26 nuclear bomb test in China. The radiation never approached the intensity that scientists considered dangerous but state laboratories here have kept careful watch on milk.

title: Syrians Pressing Lebanese Town;
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 15Syrian tanks and infantry increased their pressure today on the Palestinian stronghold of Aleih, east of here, but though the fighting was fierce, they gained little ground.

title: Progress in City Hall ...
description: New York is not yet out of the red by a long shot. Tough times and painful new belttightening still lie ahead. Bankruptcy remains an ominous possibility.

title: Pound Moves Ahead As Loan Rates Rise; Dollar Also Gains
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 15 (UPI)The pound closed substantially higher on European money markets today, after the Bank of England raised borrowing rates for currency speculators. The dollar also closed on a higher trend.

title: FRANK MENDELL LEWIS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 15 (A15)Frank Mendell Lewis, an authority on problems of vibrations in ships arid marine power plants who had been a professor at Massachusetts Institute. of Technology, is dead at the age of 81.

description: Meadowlands Drivers

title: Notes on People
description: The only woman in the West German Cabinet, Health Minister Katharina Focke, announced her resignation yesterday after four years. She had served earlier in the government of Willy Brandt and will retain her seat in Parliament. Mrs. Focke, who left Germany with her antiNazi family in World War II, studied in 195152 at the University of Oklahoma and has a Ph.D. in philology.

description: Music

description: Friday, October 15, 1976

description: Horses listed In order of Post Positions

title: Ford Appears to Modify Position On Policy for Mideast Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 15  President Ford has apparently modified the Administration's policy on Middle East negotiations and brought it closer to that favored by Israel.

title: Economic Gains Expected To Continue in 77 and 78

Instead, they forecast that steady economic growth would resume toward the end of the year andcontinue throughout 1977 and into 1978

description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 15  Warner Bros., which was chosen by the Israeli Government from more than a dozen applicants for official cooperation in producing feature film on the rescue of airline hostages from Uganda, will not go ahead with the film, it was announced in Jerusalem today.

title: Lebanon Climax Near?
description: A climax may finally be approaching in the long civil war that has devastated Lebanon for so many months at a cruel cost in human lives. Hopes for peace have so often been disappointed in the past that skepticism concerning the latest promise of an end to the fighting is understandable. Yet, some new elements in the picture suggest that the stage may be set for at least a temporary settlement in the near future.

title: Mammoth Wyeth Exhibition at Met
description: About the art of Andrew Wyeth, everyone seems to have made up his mindoften, it seems, quite independently of any firsthand experience of the artist's work or any serious reflection upon itso perhaps all that a critic need do is announce to the world that a nnanunoth exhibition of Mr. Wyeth's paintings and drawings opens today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and let it go at that.

title: Penalty, Not Revenge
description: In temporarily depriving the United Federation of Teachers of its automatic dues checkoff privilege, the Public Employment Relations Board has merely imposed the penalty mandated by law. It is unquestionably the most effective response to illegal strikes. It is not, as union president Albert Shanker charges, a vengeful act nor an attempt, as he suggests, to make of the teachers the scapegoat for other municipal workers.

The molten metal is later, returned to the blast furnace for recycling.

title: Article 7  No Title
'Car Wash' Froths on Screen With Pop Life
description: It is early morning in the Los Angeles civilization of thruways, service stations, used-car lots, quick-lunch spots and portable swimming pools sold at discount. The start of another day much like any other, the dawn coming up with the voice of a manic disk jockey whose spiel is so fast that the last syllable of one word becomes the first syllable of the next. The sentences are nonstop and, like the records the disk jockey plays, they don't have endings. No record is ever allowed to finish. It is dismissed. The volume is lowered until it is overwhelmed by the record following. It's a glorious, unending river of sound, a Far Western metaphor for life measured in decibels.Thus begins "Car Wash," a cheerful, somewhat vulgar, very cleverly executed comedy about what goes on in a single 10-hour period in a Los Angeles car wash. Written by Joel Schumacher, who wrote "Sparkle," and directed by Michael Schultz, who was responsible for "Cooley High," "Car Wash" dips into and out of the lives of more than two dozen characters. It demobilizes the old service comedy and returns it to civilian life in blithely free form.Lonnie (Ivan Dixon), the ex-con; Duane (Bill Duke), the black activist; Lindy, (Antonio Fargas), the homosexual whose wrist is limp and whose mouth is loud, and all the other workers at the car wash are updated G.I.'s out of uniform. Mr. B., (Sully Boyar), the harried owner of the car wash, would once have been the C.O. and his nitwit son, played by Richard Brestoff, who carries Mao's little red book around, wears a Mao T-shirt and wants to liberate the workers, is the commandant's overeducated offspring who is, of course, no match for the enlisted men.But "Car Wash," which opened at four theaters in New York yesterday, is more than an old comedy genre recycled. It's a terrifically shrewd piece of movie-making.Mr. Schumacher, Mr. Schultz and the members of the large, mostly black cast have created a cohesive comedy out of dozens of tiny pieces of narratives and one outstanding "cameo." This is the appearance of Richard Pryor as "Daddy" Rich, the founder-head of the Church of Divine Economic Spirituality, a fellow who drives a gold limousine with a license plate that spells T-I-T-H-E.Some of the others who turn up in the course of the day are Lauren Jones as a down-on-her-luck hooker with a sullen disposition and a different wig for every occasion, and Melanie Mayron, who plays the car-wash secretary, a moony young woman who spends more time on her nail polish than on the accounts and who at one pointthough how I don't remembermanages to drop one contact lens into a jar of cold cream.There are also a mad bomber, played by Prof. Irwin Corey, as well as a ratty little boy who terrorizes the neighborhood by being so good on a skate board, a woman who's fearful that her son's having been sick on her car door will ruin its finish, a would-be holdup man and on and on.Nothing terribly dramatic happens, and some of the comedy gets a bit forced, but the wonder of the film is how it manages to succeed so much of the time. "Car Wash" has the rhythm, beat and drive of the rock songs that are playing throughout the film, virtually nonstop, all reflecting a certain mindless contemporary mood without saying anything whatsoever about it. If "Car Wash" makes no comment on our pop culture, it's because it's a piece of it.The film, which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some mildly obscene words and rude gestures.

title: Books of The Times
description: There's so much talk about broken traditions and shattered styles up there in the cultural stratosphere, that it's fun to tumble off Parnassus, slide across the donkey's bridge and wallow about in entertainment. Like westerns and gangster films, today's spy novels and thrillers about international terrorism make breezy hack work of political reality. Such entertainments bog down only when they aspire to Art or grapple with Significance and beg for comparisons to Graham Greene or John le Carre.

title: Screen: 'Deadly Hero,' a Manhattan Melodrama
description: "These are troubled times." Don Murray, the troubled, titular cop of "Deadly Hero," intones while rehearsing a speech to be made before a right-wing group. It's an augury of the rough out simplistic things to come in this fairly derivative Manhattan melodrama that crashed into local theaters yesterday.As a youthful 18-year veteran with bravery commendations, our hero has been demoted from detective to patrol cars as a dangerously quick-on-the-trigger, law-and-order type. So it's not surprising that, seething with anger and four-letter epithets??? he'll shoot a black mugger-shakedown artist who's been terrorizing a young woman at knifepoint in her West Side apartment.Hero? Not quite. On second, sober thought, the lady, a schoolteacher and conductor of an avant-garde musical, changes her testimony to implicate our tough cop as a cold-blooded killer. And, of course, threats, tragedy and terror follow in his frenzied steps to extricate himself from the mess.Mr. Murray's characterization of a blatant bigot forced into bloody desperation to save himself and his career may be workmanlike, but it is mostly superficial talk and action. Diahn Williams is attractive, but not especially forceful as the constantly threatened woman. And several topflight performers, including Lilia Skala, as her solicitous neighbor; James Earl Jones, as the malicious mugger, and George S. Irving, as an oily mayoral candidate, seem wasted in brief, broad portrayals.Graffiti-besmirched streets, a schoolroom, a rehearsal hall and a precinct station house bear the lively, moodfilled authenticity of a color film shot in New York. But the script and unimaginative direction by Ivan Nagy, a comparative newcomer to the movies, do little to enhance this thin, commonplace "Deadly Hero."

Sencer, the head of the Federal Government's Center for Disease Control in Atlanta, normally contends with problems that originate far from his officean outbreak of cholera in Texas, contaminated drugs in the Middle West, a rash of mysterious deaths in Pennsylvania, a measles epidemic here, a flareup of equine encephalitis there. title: Notes: The Fall Season Yields A Couple of Surprises
description: The new television season has produced two big surprises. One is that CBS is running third in the ratings race and has failed to dominate a single evening for the first three weeks of the competition, something that has never happened before. The other is that ABC's Charlie's Angels, a sleeper to be sure, has burst forth into what people within the business call the runaway hitthe program that garners a tremendous rating the first week and doesn't lose it in subsequent weeks.

title: The Frustrations of Being Independent
description: Martha Coolidge has won an award for every movie she has made since film school. Yet her name is unknown to the general public. Why? Because, like the 10,000 other independent filmniakers across the country, she has encountered enormous obstacles in getting her work distributed. Therefore, her serious, highly personal films such as the recent Not a Pretty Picture, an autobiographical account a teenage rapeare seen almost exclusively by a handful of adventurous visitors to film societies, to the Whitney Museum's series devoted to independent American films, or to an occasional festival, such as the recent women's film festival in New York.

title: Judgments and the material for judgments; Kissinger; The European Mind in American Policy. By Bruce Mazlish.; 330 pp. New York: Basic Books. $10.95.; Henry Kissingei; The Anguish of Power. By John G. Stoessinger.; 234 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $8.95.; The Arabs, Israelis,; And Kissinger; A Secret History of American Diplomacy in the Middle East. By Edward R. F. Sheehan.; 288 pp. New York: Reader's Digest Press. Distributed by Thomas Y. Crowell Co. $8.95.; The Kissinger Study; Of Southern Africa; National Security Study Memorandum 39. (SECRET).; Edited and Introduced by Mohamed A. EIKhawas and Bany Cohen. 189 pp. Westport, Conn.: Lawrence Hill & Co. $6.95.
description: These four books are raw material for a contemporary evaluation of the most intriguing Americah statesman to appear since Franklin Roosevelt. Two of them, Kissinger. The European Mind in American Policy and Henry Kissinger. The Anguish of Power, both by professors, quite consciously set out to grade Kissinger's performance in office. The remaining two, one a brilliant piece of reportage on Kissinger's diplomacy in the Middle East, and the other a perceptively annotated publication of the previously leaked, but still classified, Kissinger study of Southern Africa are less speculative and more helpful in understanding Kissinger's world view and his diplomacy.

title: Mystery Cloaks the Trident
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif. The brightest star in the Lockheed corporate constellation during the last few years of crisis has been its Missiles and Space Company here.

title: SHOP TALK
description: VALLEY STREAM

title: Maryland Captures Sixth in Row
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 16 (AP)A 27yard field goal by Mike Sochko with 2 minutes 56 seconds remaining to play today, following a blocked punt by Ken Roy, provided the winning points for unbeaten Maryland in a hardearned 1715 football victory over Wake Forest.

title: Stacy Noble Wardrop Wed to Ralph Roe 2d
description: Stacy Noble Wardrop, a cartographer for the Southwestern Regional Planning Agency in Rowayton, Conn., and Ralph Coats Roe 2d, an architect, were married yesterday in Sewickley, Pa. The Rev. John Guest performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wardrop 2d.

description: Fiction and Poetry

description: In Summary

title: Soviet Tests Building on Springs
description: MOSCOW, Oct. IS (Reuters)Highrise buildings mounted on springs may become a common sight in areas troubled by violent earthquakes, the Soviet press agency TIM reported. The agency said that buildings with steel springs between the foundation and the main structure are being successfully tested in Turkmania in Central Ask.

title: Britain Postpones Conference Over Rhodesia at Request of Blacks
description: LONDON, Oct. 16The British Government agreed today to postpone the formal opening of the forthcoming Geneva conference on Rhodesia, whose purpose is to form an interim biracial Rhodesian government that will lead to rule by the black majority in the southern African country.

title: Tennis
description: AT MADRID Quarterfinal Round

title: Levitt Says S.L.A. Is Lax in Monitoring Prices Charged by Wholesalers
description: The New York State Comptroller, Arthur Levitt, last week uncorked an attack on the State Liquor Authority.

title: Voltaire And the Century Of Light
description: Reading these two latest contributions to the pile of publications on the Enlightenment, was irresistibly reminded of Voltaire's gloomy response to the books that were inundating his desk. The writer who seeks originality, he thought, was compelled to he eccentric; the writer who wishes to avoid eccentricity is bound to be unoriginal. While both J. H. Huizinga's new biography of Rousseau and A. Owen Aldridge's new biography of Voltaire have their intellectually redeeming qualities, they amply demonstrate that the situation that tf, troubled Voltaire two centuries ago has lost none of its threatening actuality.

title: Neither Snow, Nor Rain...
description: THE New Yorkers mailed me an application blank for World Series tickets in an envelope postmarked in the Bronx on Sept. 21, 1976.

title: Diary of a Visit To a Haunted Hotel
description: I am not a fan of mystery tales. As a child, shunned Nancy Drew just as I have, as an adult, avoided Agatha Christie. Still, I am not immune to curiosity. So, when I was assigned to visit the site linked to one of this country's most chilling medical mysteriesPhiladelphia's Bellevue Stratford Hoteldespite a certain apprehension, went.

title: Henry Wallace, Harry Truman, And the Cold War
description: Two definitions of tragedy are pertinent to the beginnings of the cold war, according to Arthur Schlesinger Jr. in an essay published in 1967; the Greek 'tragedy of necessity'where the feeling aroused in the spectator is What a pity it had to be this way, and the Christian 'tragedy of possibility, where the feeling aroused is What a pity it was this way when it might have been otherwise. The consensus of historical opinion in recent years, including Schlesinger's, has tended to interpret the origins of the hostility between the United States and the Soviet Union that has dominated international politics for three decades as a Greek tragedy; a series of misunderstandings between two nations with vastly different histories, domestic political systems and visions of international order, that turned an uneasy wartime partnership into rivalry that took every possible form except outright war.

title: The Dog Days Of Arthur Cane
description: If you, as I, have ever believed you were an animal trapped in a human body (a transspecieal), lacking only a tail, the ability to remain on all fours for extended periods of time, and a distinctive voice, e.g. growl or bark, to be the real you, then I recommend The Dog Days of Arthur Cane. It is invaluable for those who want to know what it' s really like to change, before taking the big step themselves.

title: The Exhilarating Freshness of Stevie Wonder
description: Stevle Wonder's new album, Songs in the Key of Life, has been the most eagerly awaited piece of pop music this year. Already it has been greeted with fulsome effusivenessThere is not one flaw in this double album, gushed one television critic. In fact, the album ,seems full of things one could carp about But that doesn't invalidate the scope, depth and delight in Mr. Wonder's achievement; this is an album that is both worthy of the most serious consideration and exhilarating to listen to, and as such it lays claim to our attention in the way that the greatest pop records of the 1960's used to do.

title: Surprising Nudes And Still Lifes
description: GENE THORNTON

title: Some Caveats on a Sure Thing
description: ISAT on my personal Olympus during the summer (usually a perch three feet above the Great South Bay's mean high water) and pondered the problem. Having returned from the Democratic National Convention and being an observer at forums for a pride of Senatorial hopefuls, I had heard the enthusiasm and applause as candidates called for a system of national health insurance.

title: Linda Tuttle Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Seymour Tuttle Jr. of Middlebury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Dinsmore Tuttle, to Richard Allen Stevens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Ives Stevens of Middlebury and Fort Lauderdale. Fla.

title: When Cassius Steals the Show
description: NEM HAVEN j41ulius Caesar can be considered as a play about the death of Caesar or the conspiracy of Brutus. It can be viewed as a play about Marc Antony; because of Marlon Brando, the Joseph Mankiewicz movie version shifted the play somewhat in that direction. The Yale Repertory Theater version, directed by Alvin Epstein, may be the first time that it has become a play about Cassius.

title: A few years ago, underdogs found it their best friend.Nowadays they have good reason to appeal every way but to the top.
description: Picture the classic scene. The publicized trial or hearing is over, and the press crowds around the courthouse steps to hear what the defeated side intends to do now. The losera defendant convicted of a crime or an individual who has unsuccessfully tried to fight city hall for some equally impersonal government agency) on a question of individual liberty emerges from the building accompanied by his lawyer. Together they announce to the world that they are going to appeal the decision all the way to the Supreme Court.

title: AROUND THE Garen
description: This Week:

title: Choate and Echarte Stand Out On Offense and Defense
description: A strong defense and a speedy halfback from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., who plays both offense and defense gave Choate a 190 victory yesterday over Taft at Wallingford, Conn. The young star, Guillermo Echarte, took a 29yard adoring pass. from Mike Ewanowski in the first period for the first touchdown and then recovered a Taft fumble in the end zone in the third period to put the game out of reach and seal Choate's third victory in four outings. Taft's record is now 22.

title: Elaine Greenfield's Debut On Piano Is Admirable
description: It's refreshing to hear a young pianist present a debut recital of the sort given by Elaine Greenfield last Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. Not only was the choice of music wellbalanced and unhackneyed, but each piece was admirably tailored to the pianist's capabilities and temperament.

title: CUTBACKS BY BRITAIN DISTURB NATO AWES
description: LONDONA projected additional cut in British defense expenditures has prompted some senior officials of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to question whether Britain would be able to fulfill its basic military commitments in a conflict with the Soviet Union.
