description: The master plan for Central Park, with which varying Parks Administrations in the past five years have played lost and found, if not fast and loose, has disappeared completely with the city's fiscal crisis. Its primary purpose was rehabilitation; and some of its key projects surface occasionally as the present administration seeks state and Federal funds for urgent spot repairs.

title: MILTON SHEEN
description: Milton Sheen, legal counsel for several liquor dealers and restaurant associations and a former owner of Luna Park on Coney Island and Oetjens Restaurant in. Brooklyn, died yesterday of a heart attack following surgery at Maimonides Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 165 Argyle Road, Brooklyn.

title: Music: Cello Sonatas by Starker
description: If the audience for Janos Starker's Metropolitan Museum recital Saturday night seemed slightly sparser than is usually the case when this cellist presents a concert, it was undoubtedly because of the program: the first in a series of three recitals surveying 20thcentury cello sonatas. Concertgoers are evidently still scared off by the prospect of so much new music, and Mr. Starker even felt it necessary to say a few words in defense of the program before he began to play.

title: Robust and Uninhibited
description: BOSTON, Oct. 17In our time the Supreme Court has reshaped fundamentals in American life: race relations, the makeup of legislatures, freedom of the press, the workings od criminal justice. That extraordinary record is familiar history to most of us, but few appreciate how large part has been played in it by one man.

title: Carey Staff, With First Breather, Searches for an Enduring Image
description: ALBANYPeter C. Goldmark Jr. has started going out for lunch.

title: Old Campaign Buttons Bringing Top Prices
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 17 (UPI)In 1900, supporter sof William Jennings Bryan for President gave away buttons with his picture on them. Today. Bryan button could cost as much as $125.

title: Hunter Says Pitch to Perez Was in Wrong Place
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 17  Unlike the first game, the Yankees waged their walkietalkie warfare tonight, but they were foiled nevertheless. That's because they used the wrong weapon. Instead of employing walkietalkies to position the outfielders, they should have used a remote control laser beam to direct the baseball into their fielders gloves.

title: Rinaldo Confident, but Taking Nothing for Granted
description: UNION, Oct. 17Though registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by more than 20 percent in the 12th Congressional District, which encompasses 18 communities in Union County, the voters have repeatedly sent Republicans to the House of Representatives. Representative Matthew .1. Rinaldo, the incumbent, is confident that it will remain that way, but he is taking nothing for granted.

title: Fire Destroys A.F.P. Office in Lima
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 17 (Agence FrancePresse  Fire gutted the Agence FrancePresse offices on the 11th Floor of a building in the center of the Peruvian capital today. The caretaker escaped unhurt after failing to put out the flames with extinguishers. All installations and records were destroyed.

title: Dr. Thomas Rigney Weds Marian Picard Thompson
description: Marian Picard Thompson of Montrose, N.Y., and Peru, Vt., widow of Kenneth R. Thompson, an admiralty lawyer, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Thomas Gerald Rigney of Beacon, N.Y., and Albany. He is director of regional health services for the state Department of Correctional Services.

title: Schlesinger on China
description: The debate in the United States about how best advance the normalization of relations with China has been stilled momentarily by the dramatic political events and uncertainties over the succession to Chairman Mao. But the debate undoubtedly will revive. When it does, significant weight will have to be given to the testimony of former Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger on his recent visit to China and talks with its present leaders.

title: Doubts About French Forces Cause NATO Anxiety
description: Uncertainty about the quality of the French armed forces and their equipment, their strategic deployment and the country's longterm armsprocurement policy is a serious but unpublicized problem in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: The Ninth Is Conducted With Care and Accuracy
description: It might seem perverse to describe Pierre Boulez's Mahler in terms of what it is not, but it is not a lot of things. Mr. Boulez doesn't offer the heartfelt sentimentality of Bruno Walter, nor the theatricalized passion of Leonard Bernstein, nor the silken smoothness of Herbert von Karajan, nor the hearty directness of Sir Georg Solti, nor the brash energy of James Levine. He doesn't even offer the cultivated exactitude of Pierre Boulez in French and modern repertory.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Study for H.E.W. Bolsters Full Federal Health Plan Backed by Labor
description: WASEINGTON, Oct. I7An actuarial study of health insurance reform, prepared for the Federal Government, says that the cradletograve plan for national health insurance that is backed by organized labor and is most like the plan outlined by Jimmy Carter ;nay not be the most expensive of the reform plans proposed, as it had been labeled.

title: WEST GERMAN MARK IS REVALUED 2%6% AGAINST 6 CURRENCIES
description: BONN, Monday, Oct. 18The West German mark was revalued upward against six other Western Europeancurrencies at a surprise meeting of finance ministers and central bankers in Frankfurt yesterday, according to a West German spokesman.

title: Ship and 37 Vanish In Bermuda Triangle On Voyage to U.S.
description: A 590foot cargo ship with a crew of 37 has been missing since early Friday and is feared sunk in the area known as the Bermuda Triangle, the Coast Guard reported yesterday.

title: SunPowered Boiler Is Given Test By U.S. Engineers in the Pyrenees
description: ODEILLO, FranceAt a French solar installation here in the Pyrenees, two American engineers have successfully tested a special onemegawatt powerplant steam boiler designed to run on sunlight. The boiler worked successfully in a recent demonstration, said Charles Blake of the Denverbased Martin Marietta Corporation, one of the concerns involved in the testing.

title: Radio
Soyuz Lands on a Lake at Night; Splashdown Is the First for Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 17The two Soviet astronauts who aborted their mission and made an emergency return to earth yesterday came down through a heavy nighttime snow and ended up in a lake in Soviet Asia. Whether intentional or not, it was the first splashdown in the 15 years of the Soviet space program, which in the past has parachuted manned capsules down to the hard ground.

title: Numbers Show the Yankees Are Down by 20, but Not Out
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 17How much does winning the first game of the World Series mean?

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: The New York Times/Paul Hosefros

title: WEST GERMAN MARK IS REVALUED 2%6% AGAINST 6 CURRENCIES
description: BONN, Monday, Oct. 18The West German mark was revalued upward against six other Western European currencies at a surprise meeting of finance ministers and central bankers in Frankfurt yesterday, according to a West German spokesman.

title: Dividend Meetings
Seahawks Beat Bucs; Penalties Near Record
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 17The Expansion Bowl, between the Seattle Seahawks and the Tampa Bay.Buccaneers, was everything it was supposed to be today.

title: Verdi Park Is the Site of Concert Designed to Help Improve Image
description: The only panic in Needle Park yesterday camebrieflywhen rain threatened to stop the music and dampen the community spirit.

title: JOBS HELD TOP PRIORITY BY COUNCIL OF CHURCHES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI)Full employment should be the nation's first priority, the National Council of Churches told President Ford and Jimmy Carter in an open letter today.

title: Buckley Urges at Ukrainian Rally That U.S. Foreign Policy Stress Freedom for All Captive Nations
description: Ukrainian banners, sky blue and wheat yellow, tossed in a chill wind behind him as Senator James L. Buckley told a rally in Bryant Park yesterday that a keystone of American foreign policy should be freedom for all captive nations.

title: New Ads for Ford Show Man in Street Expressing Doubt About Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17The latest television commercials for President Ford make heavy use of maninthestreet interviewsin the streets of Atlanta, especiallyin order to underscore the doubts that voters most often voice about Jimmy Carter.

title: Marcona: A Takeover Without Retaliation
description: LIMA, PeruThe compensation settlement reached by Peru with the Marcona Mining Company, an American multinational concern shows how a nationalistic country can expropriate a foreign enterprise without triggering economic retaliation.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Some Suspected of Nazi War Crimes Are Known as Model Citizens
description: On national holidays they are often the first in their neighborhoods to hang out the American Flag. They go to church, work hard, and tend their flower gardens. They are called model neighbors friendly. kind and unobtrusive.

title: East Germans Vote Overwhelmingly For CommunistApproved Slate
description: EAST BERLIN, Oct. 17 (Reuters)East Germans turned out in force at polling places today and voted by 99.86 percent the kind of overwhelming ballot expectedfor the official Communistapproved candidates for a new Parliament and East Berlin City Council.

title: Labor: MassProduction Unions Facing Schism in Their Ranks
description: The nearveto by skilled tradesmen of the strike settlement at the Ford Motor Company focuses attention on an upper middleclass revolt that has been seething inside most of the nation's mass production unions since the pod of World War II.

title: Ship and 37 Vanish In Bermuda Triangle On Voyage to U.S.
description: A 590foot cargo ship with a crew of 37 has been missing since early Friday and is feared sunk in the area known as the Bermuda Triangle, the Coast Guard reported yesterday.

title: 51 From World War II Underground Group in France Visit Some in U.S. Whom They Helped Save
description: Fiftyone members of an underground organization that spirited Allied airmen and soldiers out of Nazioccupied France are winding up a visit to the United States where they met again some of the men they rescued.

title: FREDERICK C. TANNER
description: PROVIDENCE, Oct, 17 (AP)Frederick C. Tanner, a business and civic leader, died Friday at the age of 72.

title: Around the Nation
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 (AP)A moderate earthquake jolted a wide area north of Los Angeles last night. There were no immediate reports of damage, but public agencies received many calls.

title: Jose Lago, Guitarist, Outstanding In Classical and Flamenco Styles
description: Most guitarists concentrate on either the flamenco or classical style, but Jose Fernandez Lago seemed very much at home in both at his concert Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. In fact, Mr. Lago, who is from Valencia, Spain, and has been playing the instrument for 21 of his 24 years, performs with such ease that the guitar seems like anatural extension of himself.

title: World News Briefs
description: A 17thCentury Scot Canonized by Pope

title: OilExporting Lands Raising Investments In the United States
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17Governments of oilexporting countries are investing an increasing proportion of their surplus money in the United States and showing an increasing willingness to hold securities other than shortterm Treasury debt, according to a new Treasury analysis.

title: Going out Guider
description: THE SCULPTURE Jacques Lipchitz, the sculptor who helped revolutionize modern sculpture through his involvement in Cubism and his creation of new sculptural language, lived and worked in HastingsonHudson, N.Y., for nearly 20 years, starting about 1953. His studio, which is still there, fronted on the Croton Aqueduct, and he would snack in the tom diner when he took a respite from work.

title: Television
description: (7)Happy Days (R) (11)700 Club

title: Commodities : PriceSupport Rise May Help WheatCorn Spreaders
description: When President Ford ordered a rise in grain pricesupport levels last Wednesday, he may have inadvrtantly helped future traders who play the most popular commodities spreadthe buying of wheat and simultaneous selling of corn for delivery in the same month, normally December.

title: Ford's Campaign Group Provides Little Insight Into His Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17Congressional requirements that political candidates make public the financial details of their campaigns have provided very little insight into the way President Ford has thus far spent part of his $20 million general election subsidy in an effort to retain control of the White House.

title: PROGRESS IS HINTED AT ARAB CONFERENCE
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 17 (Reuters)Crown Prince Fand of Saudi Arabia indicated today that progress had been made at the first formal session of a sixparty Arab conference trying to find ways to end the Lebanese civil war.

title: Books of The Times
description: What one naturally keeps looking for in Saul Bellow's To Jerusalem and Back: A Personal Account is a unifying vision, a final irony, the last analysis, IT you willat least one telling epipbtny to illuminate the collision between this urban intellectual from Chicago and the globe's most precarious frontier. For Mr. Bellow is, above all,

title: Will Benefits Tolson's Brother
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI)Clyde Tolson's only brother, excluded from the will of the late associate director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, reached an outofcourt agreement Friday to receive $100,000 from the estate. A Superior Court judge approved the settlement with 78yearold Hillory Tolson. The late F.B.I. director, J. Edgar Hoover left Mr. Tolson more than $500,000 when he died in 1972. Mr. Tolson died last year at age 75.

title: Flu Shots Resuming for Pittsburgh HighRisk Group Under New Rules
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17As preparations were made to resume the influenza immunization program for highrisk patients tomorrow, the Allegheny County health director expressed hope that the campaign would succeed without further incident under new guidelines.

title: Stevenson Papers in Princeton Library
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 17After losing the 1952 Presidential election, Adlai E. Stevenson said he felt like a little boy who had stubbed his toe in the dark . . . too old to cry but it hurts too much to laugh.

title: PETER TOSH PERFORMS WITH NEW REGGAE BAND
description: Peter Tosh, an original member of the reggae supergroup the Wailers, created an impression of abundant if somewhat unfocused talent with his recent solo album of Columbia records. When the album was good, it was so good that it surpassed the recent efforts of Bob Marley, who now leads the Wailers and has been almost singlehandedly responsible for making reggae a force in American pop music.

title: Eastchester High Reunion: From Arthritis and When You're Smiling
description: In a row of wooden folding chairs set up along the 20yard line of the Jarvis Bowl in Eastchester, N.Y., group of graduates from the class of 1918 talked about arthritis Saturday while, a short way off, graduates from another generation passed around marijuana joint. On the handstand in front of them, Eastchester alumni from the 30's  one or two in bifocals checked the lyrics to When You're Smiling as a thickwaisted team of former football stars and motherly looking cheerleaders acted out a skirmish on the field.

title: JuryPicking in Reporter's Slaying Begun Under Security in Phoenix
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 18 Jury selection for the trial of the accused slayer of Don Bolles, an investigative reporter for The Arizona Republic, began today behind closed doors and under tight security in a Phoenix courtroom.

title: Jamaican Arena Stampede Kills 5
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 18 (Reuters) Five children were killed and at least 100 persons injured in Kingston's national sports stadium today when a tropical downpour sent a 30,000 crowd stampeding for the exits. The downpour burst on the stadium minutes before a festival involving 5,000 performers was due to begin to mark Jamaica's National Heroes Day.

title: Candidate for First Lady Tours New York
description: The women who greeted the actor George Peppard at a Queens Democratic luncheon yesterday could not have welcomed him more warmly if he had been their candidate for President.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, Oct. 18, 1976

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (UPI)  The San Francisco Zephyr, an Amtrak passenger train. 117 passengers aboard, derailed today on Chicago's Southwest Side. The authorities said 40 persons had been taken to hospitals but none appeared critically injured.

title: Carter's Forces, in Effort to Recoup In New York, Stress City's Problems
description: Obviously concerned over Jimmy Carter's slippage in New York State, campaign aides have begun linking the Democratic Presidential candidate to the fate of New York City and to the coattails of local Democratic candidates.

title: Aid Backed for the Wife of Man Who Died While Chasing Mugger
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin and the New York City Corporation Counsel have approved a Good Samaritan Award of $8,582.43 a year for Anna Maresca of Brooklyn in memory of her husband, Andrew, who died of a heart attack while chasing a mugger last December.

title: N.AA.C.P. Presses Drive in Alabama for Pardon of Scottsboro Defendant From a 1946 Parole Violation
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has begun a drive in Alabama to get the last known surviving Scottsboro boy pardoned from a 1946 parole violation.

title: Moynihan TV Ads About to Start, With U.N. Angle
description: The first of four MoynihanforSenator television commercialsthe vanguard at a truncated schedule that the campaign team hopes will reach $200,000 in TV time by election daywill make its debut tomorrow.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney discusses how three prominent American stock market officials viewed the annual meeting of the International Federation of Stock Exchanges in Tokyo. Page 57

title: Echeverria Indicates Readiness To Take Waldheirn's Post at U.N
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 President Luis Echeverria Alvarez of !Mexico injected unexpected competition into the election of the next Secretary General today by declaring his readiness Ito run against the incumbent, Kurt Waldheim of Austria.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 When allegations of wrongdoing are made against an incumbent President, who should investigate? Should it be the Attorney General, who has been appointed by the President? or should it be an independent prosecutor such as those named in the Watergate affair?

title: BRITAIN ASKING 4TH BLACK TO RHODESIA CONFERENCE
description: LONDON, Oct. 18 (Reuter) Britain is inviting a fourth black nationalist leader, the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole, to attend the conference on Rhodesia's future that is scheduled to begin in Geneva on Oct. 28. the Foreign Office said today.

title: Companies Approached on Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI)Following is the Commerce Department's list of corporations that it said have participated in the Arab boycott of Israel since Oct. 7, and the country that made the request.

title: 500 Protest Proposal For New OTB Sites
description: Nine busloads of middleclass residents from Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx went to City Hall yesterday to protest before the Site Selection Board against the opening of Offtrack Betting Corpora tion parlors in their respective neighborhoods.

title: S.E.C. Will Test Easing of Its Rules On Small Companies New Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The Securities and Exchange Commission intends to make it significantly easier for small companies to raise capital by increasing to perhaps $2 million the size of securities offerings that can he made with a minimum of red tape and expense Roderick M. I tills, the agency's chairman disclosed at a news conferene today.

title: Winter Ball
description: Considering the current plight of our local champions, it may seem churlish to grumble about the conditions under which the second game of the World Series was played Sunday night, but appearances ought not to be allowed to preclude a modest comment about NBC's arctic night baseball. The game at Cincinnati's Riverfront Stadium set a precedent as the first Sunday night World Series game in history. it may have set a record for greed and insensitivity as well.

title: STAFF OF P.S.C. URGES BIG CUT IN RATE RISE PROPOSED BY CON ED
description: Staff members of the New York State Public Service Commission, in an unusually critical review of a rate increase sought by Consolidated Edison, recommended yesterday that all but $11.4 million of the $249.8 million annual increase sought by the utility be denied.

title: Javamine Leads Sweep By Miller Belmont Entry
description: A display of togetherness was evidenced in two instances of the $55,450 Long Island Handicap, held over Belmont Park's 1 1/16mile turf course before 13,592 chilled fans yesterday.

title: Group is Formed to Help Clean Up New York
description: With Mayor Beanie conceding that budget cuts have made our sanitationmen somewhat less than omnipresent, a new coalition led by top business executives and the head of the sanitation union yesterday announced a permanent new educational effort"I Love a Clean NOW York Inc.

title: Shaw's Philanderer Offers Insight Into Philosophy of His Later Plays
description: There are two sneaky, subliminal, and even inadvertent jokes in Bernard Shaw's The Philanderer, the secondbest of which is displayed all over the place at the opening of Act Two. Act Two, as it is being engagingly performed at the Roundabout Theater through Sunday, takes place in the Library of an Ibsen Club, circa 1893, and displayed all over the placemost notably on the sedate bookshelves are signs requesting, if not demanding, Silence. Fat chance. In a play by Bernard Shaw? The act runs for 40 minutes and the signs keep glaring at us the whole time that Shaw's characters Shaw, Shaw, Shaw and Shaw) rattle on without a moment's interruption. I kert, wondering whether the signs were Shaw's own thumbtonose inspiration, or whether the Roundabout's property man was simply being waggish.

title: HAROLD TEITELBAUM
description: Harold Teitelbaum, a certified public accountant, collapsed and died Sunday while playing tennis. He was 48 years old and a resident of Teaneck, N.J.

title: William Moran of Steel Union; Candidate for National Office
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 (AP) William Moran, a United Steelworkers of America official who was a candidate for international secretary on the Official Family slate of Lloyd McBride, died of an apparent heart attack yesterday while at Philadelphia International Airport. He was 62 years old.

title: Chess:
description: Why is it that a sacritice, even a perfectly innocuous one, so often succeeds dramatically?

title: Yoshimura Trial Opened in Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 18 Wendy Yoshimura, underground traveling companion of Patricia Hearst, went on trial here today on charges of illegal possession of a machine gun, destructive devices and explosives.

title: Some Ghosts of World Series Past
description: The World Series, which used to be a standard feature of autumn in New York, returns to the Bronx tonight after 12 years that changed almost everything but the name of the game. The Yankees, now two games down to the Cincinnati Reds and that's halfway to extinction, are playing for the North American baseball championship for the 30th time, though not remarkably well. When they last represented the American League there were nine men on a team, 10 teams in a league and seven afternoon games in the tournament and when they lost to the St. Louis Cardinals each Yankee received $5,309.29. Now 10man teams from 12team leagues compete at night, with the winners getting approximately $25,000 a man. Since 1964 the Yankees have changed owners, managers and playing personnel, and New York's, taxpayers have spent $100 million converting old Yankee Stadium into a new park.

title: People and Business: ExChief Of Currency Agency Joins Bank
description: James E. Smith, who resigned in June after a sometimes stormy tour as Comptroller of the Currency, has taken a senior position in the banking industry he formerly regulated. First Chicago Corporation, parent of the First National Bank of Chicago, yesterday announced that effective Nov. 1 Mr. Smith, 46 years old, will be Joining the bank holding company as executive vice president.

title: Snow in Upstate New York
description: JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 18 (UPI) Authorities in Chautauqua County reported today that two to four inches of snow had fallen in the county overnight. A sheriff's department spokesman in Mayville, said that most of the snow bad melted by midmorning but that about an inch remained on the ground and roads were slippery. No accidents were reported.

title: 6 ARAB LEADERS SIGN PACT TO STRENGTHEN LEBANON PEACE FORCE
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 18 Six Arab leaders signed a peace plan for Lebanon today calling for a ceasefire this week and creation of a 30,000man Arab force to supervise the withdrawal of the warring factions.

title: Cardinals Lose Linebacker
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18 (AP)Ray White, the St. Louis Cardinals middle linebacker will miss the rest of the National Football League season because of a knee jury suffered yesterday in a game against Dallas. White had been replacing Greg Hartle, who also will be out the scazon with an injury.

title: Flu Shots and Administration
description: PITTSBURGH, C 18A Federal medical investigation has given the swine flu vaccine a clean bill of health and the program here resumed today with a prescription designed to correct what are widely regarded as administrative ills in the national campaign.

title: Coach Quits at Weber State
description: OGDEN, Utah, Oct. 18 (AP)Dick Gwinn, who has not had a winning football season since becoming head coach at Weber State College here in 1973, resigned today, effective Jan. 31, wnen his contract expires.

title: Cuban Exile Admits Bombing an Airliner Killing 73 Aboard
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 A Cuban exile under arrest in Trinidad has admitted planting a bomb that caused a Cuban airliner to crash off Barbados on Oct. 6, killing 73 persons, according to reports reaching Government officials here today.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Off in Both Maturities
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Moynihan Warns on Effect of Arab Ideology Drive
description: Daniel Patrick Moynihan warned last night that Israel was threatened more by ideas than by guns because of an Arab ideological campaign that also threatened the United States and the entire democratic world.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The first week in November could be eventful for the State of Georgia. On Nov. 3, they might celebrate the election of a Georgian as U.S. President. And three days later, to the State of Georgia could go the honor of becoming the first state to kill a human being following the 1976 Supreme Court decision that capital revenge (I cannot call it punishment) is permissible. A Georgia judge has ordered Nov. 6 as the date for exterminating Wilburn Wiley Dobbs, 27, who killed a grocer in 1973.

title: It's a Magazine That Tries to Be a Knowledgeable Friend
description: Pari passu is a Latin phrase that means with equal pace, speed or progress, side by side.

title: F. KEITH BROWN DIES AT 63; LEGAL ADVISER TO LLOYD'S
description: F. Keith Brown, a partner in the law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leigy & MacRae, 140 Broadway, died in Doctors Hospital Saturday after a short illness. His age 63.

title: Frozen Foods: Two Successes, Some Disasters
description: When Marya Mannes dubbed ours the age of wasted miracles, she was referring to television, but the same observation could as easily be applied to frozen foods.

title: News Summary
description: A peace plan for Lebanon was signed by six Arab leaders in Saudi Arabia, calling for a ceasefire to take effect Thursday and a 30,000man Arab force to supervise the withdrawal of the warring Lebanese factions. The agreement requires the opponents in the civil war to pull back to the positions they held in April 1975, but it leaves unclear whether Syrian forces in Lebanon will be withdrawn or become part of the peacekeeping force. [Page I, Column 6.]

title: Samuel Chao Chung Ting
description: His day begins with breakfast at the cafeteria of the European Nuclear Research Center, known as CERN, in Geneva, Switzerland. it ends when he leaves his laboratory to sleep in his apartment, a tenminute drive from the center. This is also his routine on one weekend out of two on alternate weekends he takes off to see his wife and two young daughters in Lexington, Mass. By Monday he is back at CERN.

title: Ballet: Joffrey's Time Goes By
description: The Joffrey Ballet seems to be enjoying great success with its current red while and blue engagement devoted to American choreographers on Sunday night at the 55th Street City Center, it brought a largely new cast into the season's first performance of As Time Goes By, which Twyla Tharp created for the company in 1973.

title: 3M Company Reports 3dQuarter Profit Up 3.1%
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, known as the 3M Company, reported yesterday that its net income for the third quarter gained 3.1 percent from a year ago despite substantial adverse currency changes. Sales, however, were a record for any quarter in its history, the St. Paulbased diversified producer said.

title: Philharmonic Will Open Tonight Pending Approval of a New Pact
description: The New York Philharmonic will open its 135th subscription season tonight at the reconstructed Avery Fisher Hall, pending final approval this morning by orchestra players of a new contract.

title: Grogan's Runs, Passes Help Patriots Rout Jets
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Oct, 18Wlith the Jets behind, 347, midway through the third quarter here tonight, Joe Namath was retired for the evening and Richard Todd succeeded him at quarterback for the Jets. But it was too late for Todd, the rookie from Alabama who is going to have to lead the Jets out of the wilderness in the next decade. The opposition, the New England Patriots, was playing such superb football that Todd's presence made no difference to the outcome as the Pats won, 417.

title: Auto Union and General Motors Resume Talks on New Contract
description: DETROIT, Oct, 18 (UPI)The United Automobile Workers resumed contract talks today with the General Motors Corporation while the Ford Motor Company, the auto industry patternsetter, struggled to bring its production back to prestrike levels.

title: Hughes Tool Near Merger
description: Hughes Tool announced in Houston yesterday that its board had approved a letter of intent for the merger of Hughes and Reagan Offshore International Inc. whose board also approved the merger. Under the terms of the merger, shareholders of Reagan would receive a minimum of 475,000 Hughes.

title: Notes on People
description: Edward Aguirre, an Arizonaborn former teacher of industrial arts, was installed by President Ford yesterday as Commissioner of Education in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. Dr. Aguirre, age 46, has been in San Francisco as H.E.W.'s regional commissioner of education since 1973. He also served four years in Washington and California with the Labor Department's manpower agency.

title: Dh, Still 4Letter Word to Anderson, Seen as the NotSoGreat Equalizer
description: Sparky Anderson, who has managed 1,264 Cincinnati Reds games under ordinary baseball rules, has now managed two using the designated hitter and his opinion about that rule has firmed up. Before trying it, he considered it terrible after the first game of the World Series, he upgraded that to it stinks now he considers moronic.

title: Soviet Schedules Missile Teats
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 18 (AP)The Soviet Union will be conducting rocket teas in the Barents Sea from Oct. 22 to Nov. 5, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today. The target area is a radius of 40 nautical miles, with the center at 73 degrees north latitude and 35 deuegt east longitude.

title: High Winds Sweep Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 18 (UPI) Winds with gusts of hurricane strength swept across northern and eastern Yugoslavia over the weekend, damaging houses and cars in small towns and destroying crops. No deaths or injuries were reported.

title: In Memoriam
description: BARTLETTElla Herbert. The dead are like the stars by day, withdrawn from mortal eyes, but not extinct, they hold their way in glory through the sky. Cherished memories.

title: Health Care Crisis
description: The demand of the Emergency Financial Control Board for a restructuring of the deficitridden Health and Hospitals Corporations touches only one aspect a broader health care crisis which threatens to overwhelm New York City's already overburdened budget.

title: World News Briefs
description: OSLO, Oct. 18 (Reuters)  Norway today told the entire staff of the North Korean Embassy here to leave the country within six days, accusing them of having smuggled liquor and cigarettes.

title: National Medal of Science is Awarded by Ford to
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) President Ford today awarded the National Medal of Science, the nation's highest award for distinguished scientific achievement, to 15 scientists, one of them now dead.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: Carryovers on capital gains and losses are among factors to be considered in yearend tax strategies. Page 59.

title: Orion Capital Begins OverCounter Trade
description: The common stock of the Orion Capital Corporation, formerly the Equity Funding Corporation, began trading yesterday in the overthecounter market.

title: Beame Reported To Seek Removal Of Dr. Holloman
description: The Beanie administration is actively seeking a replacement for Dr. John L. S. Holloman, the beleaguered president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, but it has been turned down by three of the persons approached, officials said yesterday.

title: Buckley Says Brown Should Quit; Others Join in Attack on General
description: Senator James L. Buckley of New York called yesterday for the resignation of Gen. George S. Brown, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who had been quoted in an interview as suggesting that Israel was a military burden for the United States.

title: Carter Will Campaign To Overcome Apathy
description: TAMPA, Fla, Oct. 18 (AP) Declaring the election up for grabs, Jimmy Carter flew to Florida today where he embarked on what aides said would be a concentrated effort to overcome voter apathy in the remaining days of the campaign.

title: INDEPENDENT TEAMS DISCOVERED PARTICLE
description: On Oct. 22, 1974, Dr. Samuel C. C. Ting went into the data analysis room of his experimental team at Brookhaven National Laboratory, near Upton, L.I., and posted a note on the bulletin board: I owe M. Schwartz $10.

title: Lebanese Christians Capture a Key Guerrilla Post
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 18 Lebanese rightwing Christian forces equipped with Israeli weapons stormed into a Moslemheld military barracks in southern Lebanon today on the second day of an offensive in the area.

title: A Judge Rules person is Non Grata
description: Ellen Donna Cooperman went to court the other day in an effort to change her name to Cooperperson. She lost.

title: Chinese Paper Alludes to a Coup Bid
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 19 (AP)  The principal Chinese newspaper, Jenmin Jih Pao, said today that a firm campaign must he waged to thoroughly expose and criticize those who attempted to snatch power from the party.

title: Business Records
Dow Climbs 9.56 to 946.56 In Broad Market Advance
BANKAMERICA RAISES EARNINGS BY 12,6%
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's largest banking organization, reported yesterday a 12.6 percent increase in thirdquarter operating earnings.

title: Expert on Aging Calls on Medicine To Plan for Bigger Problems Ahead
description: By the time today's young people reach retirement age it is likely that one out of every five Americans will be over 65 years old, double the proportion of today.

title: BUCKLEY RIDICULES MOYNIHAN CAMPAIGN
description: Senator James L. Buckley last night dubbed his opponent. Daniel P. Moynihan, a hired gun in the liberal cause who was not fighting for principles but hoping for a job.

title: Revaluatin of the Mark is Seen As Buying Time for Currency Float
description: PARIS, Oct. 18The upwara revaluation of the robust West German mark was seen today by many bankers in Europe as inadequate to relieve more than a little of he strain on the Contient's weaker currencies.

title: The Nightmare of Jo Anne! Is Staged Humanly and Fairly
description: The story of Joan Little, the young black prisoner in North Carolina who was accused and acquitted of murdering her white jailer last year, is a potentially treacherous subject for dramatization on stage it could easily be turned into a political diatribe, a platform for special pleading, or a courtroom melodrama.

title: Dole, Stumping Through the Midwest, is Defending President's Farm Record and Sharply Attacking Carter
description: CAPE GIRARDEAU. Mo., Oct. 18 Senator Robert J. Dote, the Republican VicePresidential candidate, has spent the last three days stumping through his native Midwest in an attempt to repair sagging Republican fences.

title: Cardinal Lercaro, Reformed Mass And a Foe of Leftists and Fascists
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Oct. 18 (AP)  Giacomo Cardinal Lercaro, a driving force behind the Vatican's liturgical reforms and for 16 years Archbishop of this Communistadministered city, died today. He was 84 years old.

title: Poster Says Wife Tried to Kill Mao
description: PEKING, Oct. 18A wall poster in Peking has accused Mao Tsetung's widow, Chiang Ching, of trying to murder her husband.

title: Leader of Italian Communists Warns Dissenters Party Must Help to Keep the Christian Democrats in Power
description: ROME, Oct. 18 Enrico Berlinguer, the Communist Party leader, who is faced with increased dissent among his rank and file, said tonight that the party must help keep the Christian Democrats in power at present to avoid the economic and financial collapse of Italy.

title: Sunday Is a business day.
description: Sunday, January 30, that is, when executives engaged in international affairs assemble over the pages of The New York Times 1977 International Economic Survey.

title: CAREY NAMES 3 JUSTICES TO APPELLATE DIVISION
description: Governor Carey yesterday elevated three Justices of the State Supreme Court Frank D. O'Conor, Milton Molten, and Joseph A. Suozzito the court's Appellate Division, Second Department.

title: Watergate, Vietnam and Howe Make Moss Bid in Utah a Tossup
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 18 Although campaigning for his fourth term as United States Senator, Frank B. Moss is rated the underdog. It's a position he seems to be in every six years, but this year, the 65yearold Utahan does not seem to relish it.

title: TV: Our Wintery Fall Classic
description: Except for the last few innings of the second game, baseball's World Series between the New York Yankees and the Cincinnati Reds has beeii a surprisingly dull television affair so far. Perhaps it is merely the cold weather. There is something ludicrous about watching baseball players massaging a hot water bottle to warm their hands. Or perhaps the good citizens of Cincinnati are a touch too polite, too serenely confident, to generate more than acceotable excitement.

title: WEICKER ACCUSED OF EVADING DEBATE
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 18Gloria Schaffer, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate from Connecticut, accused her Republican opponent today of backing out of a series of scheduled debates now that this campaign has become a horse race.

title: Shanghai Drive is Widened By FOX BUTTERFIELD
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 18 The effort to undercut China's leftists continued to spread today with reports of wall posters attacking lesser officials in Shanghai for their ties to Chiang Ching, Mao Tsetung's widow, and three other senior leaders reportedly arrested 10 days ago.

title: Ship Missing in Bermuda Triangle Now Presumed to Be Lost at Sea
description: The United States Coast Guard said yesterday that the 590foot cargo ship missing since Friday with 37 crew members in the area known as The Bermuda Triangle was now presumed to have been lost at sea in heavy winds and high seas.

title: Kate Isn't in P.S. 87. Here's Why:
description: One sunny day in October 1975, my daughter Kate became thoughtful on the way to school. If the money strike is over, she asked earnestly as she walked up the stairs to her kindergarten class at P.S. 87 in Manhattan, can I stay in this school all the way to fifth grade? I really love it here.

title: Advertising
description: Most rough executions of television commercials are practically as effective for copy testing as finished spots, a business school professor told a large assembly of advertising researchers yesterday.

title: Ali Scores Over Referee As Libel Suit is Defeated
description: Muhammad All won a big decision in a court fight yesterday when a Manhattan jury rejected a boxing referee's $20 million libel suit against the world heavyweight champion.

title: Arnsparger Continues Toiling for the Future
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 18Maybe Bill Arnsparger, coach of a football team with an 06 wonlost record and about to play the Pittsburgh Stealers, should be worrying about next Sunday. He does, after all, like his job.

title: OIL ANALYSTS SEE 10% OPEC PRICE RISE AT DECEMBER TALKS
description: BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 18A minimum price increase of 10 percent can be expected when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meets in Qatar in December according several oil analysts and economists gathered today at the University of Colorado for the third annual international conference on energy and development.

title: Carter Campaign is Stressing New York City's Plight
description: Obviously concerned over Jimmy Carter's slippage in New York State, campaign aides have begun linking the Democratic Presidential candidate to the fate of New York City and to the coattails of local Democratic candidates.

title: STATE ACTION URGED TO CUT CANCER RISK
description: EDISON, Oct. 18Federal and state officials concerned with the high incidence of cancer in New Jersey said today that while there were still many unknown factors, the state should take steps to reduce the exposure of individuals to possible cancercausing agents.

title: Article 4  No Title
The Environmental Issues
description: The protection of the environment is a major concern for many citizens and for the nation's future. Despite its importance, neither Presidential candidate has devoted much attention to the issue.

title: Kissinger Tells China U.S. Remains Steadfast Against Any Soviet Threat
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has publicly reassured the new Chinese leadership that the United States would regard a Russian threat against China as a graye matter.

title: 80 More Tons of Marijuana Found on Panama Ship
description: MIAMI, Oct. 18 (AP) The United States Coastt Guard said today that80more tons of marijuana had been found aboard a seized Panamanian freighter, bringing the total to 160 tons, which apparently the largest seizure of marijuana on record.

title: Yankee Mixup Holds That Tiger for Series Game And Has Marching Band at Princeton Roaring
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 18The Princeton University marching band, which prides itself on humorous halftime shows during the school's football games, was not in a funny frame of mind today.

title: Cocoa Futures Jump to Record, Then Ease a Bit
description: Cocoa futures prices set a record high yesterday, when the December contract jumped the daily limit of 4 cents a pound to reach $1.23 90/100 on the New York Cocoa Exchange.

title: Helmets Blamed for More Injuries
description: Dr. Donald Cooper has nothing but bad things to say about the hard shell football helmets that have been in use for years. The team physician for Oklahoma State University was particularly adamant on the subject yesterday after hardshellhelmet injuries last Saturday sidelined a few of the outstanding players in the Big Eight Conference for the remainder of the season. They were Nolan Cromwell, the Kansas quarterback, Robert Turner, the Oklahoma State fullback, and Jerry Anderson, Oklahoma's right cornerback. Speaking by phone from his office in Stillwater, Dr. Cooper said of these helmets, They're the damnedest, meanest tool on the face of the earth. If kids aren't seriously hurt in a game Saturday then on Sunday and Monday they have so many bruises that they look like they have been tattooed by a ballpeen hammer.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The RCA Corporation said yesterday that it was continuing its internal investigation into the circumstances surrounding the resignation on Sept. IS of Anthony L. Conrad as chairman.

title: Campaign Down Upside
description: The election campaign now being held in China is quite different from ours. For one thing, the campaign has nothing to do with the election.

title: THE WILSON QUARTERLY, REVIEW OF IDEAS, ISSUED
description: The first issue of The Wilson Quarterly, which calls itself a national review of ideas and information, was published yesterday in Washington.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Englewood Hospital administrators and 400 striking nurses reached a tentative contract agreement last night. James Buffington, executive vice president of the hospital, said both sides reached agreement following an eighthour negotiating session. The nurses have been on strike since last Tuesday over the issues of staffing, rotating shifts, nurses training and nonnursing duties. Details of the tentative contract agreement were immediately made public.

title: Her Styles in His Shops: A Quiet Revolution
description: After a decade of shaking the pillars of American society, the feminist revolution is transforming the showcases of some of New York's most steadfastly masculine stores.

title: M.T.A. Chief Warns Of Increase in Fare
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that his agency would consider shortly raising the 50cent fare by 10 or 15 cents necause of a loss of revenues that had been expected.

title: McCarthy Says He Could Win If Allowed to Debate His Rivals
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18 (UPI) Eugene McCarthy, an independent candidate for the Presidency, said today that he would have a good chance to be elected if he were allowed to take part in the final debate Friday night.

title: U.S.British Air Talks Begin
description: WASINGTON, Oct. 18 (Reuters) Britain and the United States today resumed negotations on an agreement to share air traffic between the two countries. Britain has complain that American airlines received more than their fair share of crossAtlantic traffic.

title: For Mexico's President, the U.N. Is Only One of Several Objectives
description: MEXICO CITY. Oct. 18 For four years, President Luis Echeverria Alvarez, has campaigned tirelessly for a new world economic order, hoping to win either the Nobel Peace Prize or the Secretary Generalship of the United Nations before his Presidential term ends Dec. 1.

title: JetsPatriots Scoring
Vorster Rules Out Blacks Role In Political Life of South Africa
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 18 Prime Minister John Vorster made it clear today that his Government would continue to exclude blacks from participation in the mainstream of South Africa's political life, but he pledged that discriminatory measures that did not serve to limit racial friction would be scrapped.

title: Some Ghosts of World Series Past
description: The World Series, which used to be a standard feature of autumn in New York, returns to the Bronx tonight after 12 years that changed almost everything but the name the game. The Yankees, now two games down to the Cincinnati Reds and that's halfway to extinction, are playing for the North American baseball championship for the 30th time, though not remarkably well. When they last represented the American League there were nine men on a team, 10 teams in a league and seven afternoon games in the tournament, and when they lost to the St. Louis Cardinals each Yankee received $5,309.29. Now 10man teams from 12team leagues compete at night, with the winners getting approximately $25,000 a man. Since 1964 the Yankees have changed owners, managers and playing personnel, and New York's taxpayers have spent $100 million converting old Yankee Stadium into a new park.

title: Bahamas to Execute an American Today for Murder of 3 Tourists
description: NASSAU. Bahamas, Oct. 18 (APA Milwaukee handyman is to be hanged for murder at Fox Hill Prison shortly after sunrise tomorrowthe first American executed in the Bahamas in 15 years.

title: Excerpts From an Interview With Vorster in Pretoria
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 18Following are excerpts from an interview with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa.

title: Bridge:
description: If there was an award for the most prolific writer of bridge books and another for the most entertaining writer, both awards might well go to Victor Mollo of England.

title: MARK'S REVALUATION RELIEVES PRESSURES IN CURRENCY TRADING
description: BONN, Oct. 18 Pressures eased in many European currency markets today following West Germany's surprise upward revaluation of the mark against six other European currencies last night. However, the move did little to relieve the stress upon the currencies of Germany's most important European trading partnersthe British pound, the French franc and the Italian lira.

title: An Israeli Bank Chief is Arrested
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. l8 Ashar Yadlin, Governordesignate of the Bank of Israel, was detained by police today after an intensive investigation into allegations that he made illicit profits in kickbacks through a series of real estate transactions by the Labor Federation's disability fund, which he headed.

title: Market Place
description: Merrill Lynch is bullish on America but it appears that a relatively limited number of Merrill Lynch customers arc bullish on Japan  at least at the firm's offices at 345 Park Avenue.

title: Maddox Expects to Get Another Knee Operation
description: Elliott Maddox the Yankee outfielder who missed most of this season following knee surgery, said yesterday he needs another operation on the knee.

title: Du Pont Net Rose 17% in 3d Quarter; Sales Up by 9.6%
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday a gain of 17.5 percent in thirdquarter earnings as sales rose by 9.6 percent.

title: Talk of the Series
description: And so the World Series finally returns to Yankee Stadium, the house that Ruth built and Beanie rebuilt, the shrine where generations of small boys looked for spiritual strength and homerun powerincluding Pat Zachry of Waco, Tex., who will pitch tonight for the Cincinnati Reds; Johnny Bench of Oklahoma City, his catcher; Sparky Anderson of Bridgewater, S.D., their manager, and Billy Martin of Berkeley, Calif., who will try to get something going for the Yankees.

title: 2 NOBEL PRIZES WON BY 3 U. S. SCIENTISTS
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 18  Three more Americans were awarded Nobel Prizes here todayProf. William N. Lipscomb of Harvard University for chemistry and Prof. Burton Richter of Stanford University and Prof. Samuel C. C. Ting of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for physics.

title: NursingHome Rent Jersey Pays Ts Scored as Grossly Excessive
description: TRENTON, Oct. 18The State Commission of Investigation said today it was urgent to change New Jersey's Medicaid regulations to lower the grossly excessive rent payments to some nursinghome owners, many of whom live in New York. The commission said that a year of investigation had shown that a large percentage of the $22 million a year paid by the slate as rent to owners of nursing homes for Medicaid patients was unIn addition, the S.C.I.an independent commission that checks on the operation of state programs at the direction of the Governorsaid that New Jersey's program of auditing nursing homes was inadequate.

title: Stage: Kander and Ebb Spiral On
description: There is a new kind of musical emerging in the world. it is something like cabaret, it is something like a retrospective, it is something like an anthology. Oddly enough, I think the format really started in London with Cowardy Custard, a delicious and far from Wane melange of the music and lyrics of Noel Coward. London repeated this success with a similar, pious yet exultant tribute to Cole Porter. So far the movement has not caught on in New York. Last night might have changed that.

title: Minister Loses Bombing Plea
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 18 (UPI)A Federal judge today rejected a request for probation for a lay minister, Marvin Horan, and upheld his threeyear sentence for bombing conspiracy in the 1974 Kanawha County textbook dispute. The verdict was justified, District Court Judge K. K. Hall told Mr. Horan, leader of the 1974 drive against antiGod and antiAmerican textbooks. In my Opin, ion, Mr. Horan was more guilty than them all.

title: Survey Shows Carter. Holds Lead Because He is Seen as Moderate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 A major reason that Jimmy Carter holds a lead over President Ford in the race for the Presidency is that he has succeeded in painting a solidly moderate image of himself among the voters.

title: Byrne Tells Congressional Panel That Overhaul of Welfare is Needed
description: Governor Byrne told a Congressional delegation considering the economic problems of the Northeast and Middle West yesterday that reforming the welfare system to provide minimum benefits financed by the Federal Government for recipients countrywide was the first priority facing legislators.

title: News Summary
description: A peace plan for Lebanon was signed by six Arab leaders in Saudi Arabia, calling for a ceasefire to take effect Thursday and a 30,000man Arab force to supervise the withdrawal of the warring Lebanese factions. The agreement requires the opponents in the civil war to pull back to the positions they held in April 1975, but it leaves unclear whether Syrian forces in Lebanon will be withdrawn or become part of the peacekeeping force. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Rozelle Rule Again is Held To Be Invalid
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18Professional football's Rozelle Rule violates Federal antitrust laws by unduly restricting the rights of players to change teams, a Federal appeals court here ruled today.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Oct. 18As clinics dispensing swine flu vaccine to the public prepared to open Wednesday in the four northwest counties, the State Health Department sought to find enough doctors to supervise some of the clinics.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. ISSUES REPORTS ABOUT ARAB BOYCOTT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The Commerce Department made public today 59 reports from companies that said they had been asked to comply with the Arab states boycott of Israel. None of the companies said it would refuse to comply.

title: World Series Schedule
description: Yankees vs. Cinchmati

title: SOUTH AFRICA ARMS BAN PROPOSED IN U.N. COUNCIL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 Thirdworld countries proposed in the Security Council today that an arms embargo be imposed on South Africa to compel it to give up SouthWest Africa and accede to free elections there under United Nations auspices.

title: WEBER ACCUSED OF EVADING DEBATE
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 18Gloria Schaffer, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate from Connecticut, accused her Republican opponent today of backing out of a series of scheduled debates now that this campaign has become a horse race.

title: Slight Tremors Strike Cuba
description: HAVANA, Oct. 18 (Reuters) Three earthquakes of little intensity shook Santiago de Cuba yesterday without causing any casualties or damage, it was reported today.

title: The Band is Planning Final Farewell Concert For Thanksgiving Day
description: The Band, perhaps North America's most respected rock group, will give a farewell concert in San Francisco on Thanksgiving Day, according to spokesmen close to the band and to the many guest artists who are planning to participate.

title: West Beirut Residents Beset by Shelling and Looting
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 18 Shells crashed into a fruit stand in west Beirut today, critically wounding the owner and killing his 12yearold son.

title: Events Today
description: BEST FRIEND, a play by Michael Sawyer. Directed by Marty Jacobs. Starring Barbara Baxley. At the Lyceum Theater, 149 Mast 45th Street at 7.

title: Is Poverty Abolished?
description: Has the United States abolished, or almost abolished, poverty and just failed to realize that fact?

title: NassauSuffolk Race for Congress Pits G.O.P. Against A.F.L.C.I.O.
description: ??? L.I.. Oct. 18  The Republian National Committee and the are fighting a kind of proxy war over the state's Third Congressional District that straddles the NassauSuffolk line, where two widely dissimilar candidates are in one of the closest Congressional races on Long Island.

title: STAFF OF P.S.C. URGES BIG CUT IN RATE RISE PROPOSED BY CON ED
description: Staff members of the New York State Public Service Commission, in an unusually critical review of a rate increase sought by Consolidated Edison, recommended yesterday that all but $11.4 million of the $249.8 million annual increase sought by the utility be denied.

title: Reds Favored in Third Game
description: RENO. Oct. 18 (UPI)Harrah's Sports and Race Book today quoted the Cincinnati Reds as 1310 favorites to beat the New York Yankees in the third game of the World Series tomorrow night.

title: SPLASHDOWN OF SOYUZ 23 IN LAKE IS LAID TO CHANCE
description: MOSCOW, Oct 18 (Reuters) The hazardous splashdown by two Soviet astronauts into a blizzardswept lake was the result of chance rather than mission planning, Izvestia, the Government newspaper, indicated tonight.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: KUNGSHOLM (Flagship). Lett Bermuda Oct. 18; due 9 A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: Hungarian President in Cuba
description: MIAMI, Oct. 18 (AP) President Pal Lasonczi of Hungary has arrived in Havana at the head of a delegation visiting Peru, Panama and Cuba, the Havana radio said today.

title: Setting is Mideast, but Life In Kibbutz Echoes the Midwest
description: KIBBUTZ AFIKIM, IsraelA searing October afternoon in the Jordan Valley. The sun scorches the bald pates of the bleached hills in the distance, siphons precious moisture from the irrigated acres of baking crops and stuns a stroller into nearsomnambulism.

title: U.S. ISSUES REPORTS ABOUT ARAB BOYCOTT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The Commerce Department made public today 59 reports from companies that said they had been asked to comply with the Arab states boycott of Israel. None of the companies said it would refuse to comply.

title: TAPES ARE ENTERED IN BRONFMAN TRIAL
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 18 Two unreteased tape recordings that have been the focus of considerable interest on the part of defense lawyers for one of the two men accused of having abducted Samuel Bronfman 2d were entered today in the Bronfman kidnapping trial here.

title: 2 NOBEL PRIZES WON BY 3 U. S, SCIENTISTS
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 18  Three more Americans were awarded Nobel Prizes here todayProf. William N. Lipscomb of Harvard University for chemistry and Prof. Burton Richter of Stanford University and Prof. Samuel C. C, Ting of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for physics.

title: Nation of Islam Changes Name To Fight Black Separatist Image
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) The Nation of Islam is changing its name, in part to fight its image as a black separatist group. The chief minister, Wallace D. Muhammad, proposed last week that the group's name be changed to the World Community of Islam in the West. The change is already in effect, a spokesman said today.

title: Georgia Governor Urged to Bar First U.S. Execution in a Decade
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 18 (UPI) Civil rights activists and prominent politicians pressed Gov. George Busbee today to suspend death sentences indefinitely in Georgia, which could become the first state to execute prisoners in almost a decade.

title: Massachusetts to Vote on Gun Curb
description: BOSTON, Oct. 17 Massachusetts will become the first state in the nation to ban private ownership of handguns if the voters approve a referendum on the ballot Nov.2.

title: Ford Plans 10Day Campaign Blitz in About 13 States After the Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  President Ford's political strategists said today that he planned to spend the last 10 days of the election campaign away from Washington on an intensive blitz designed to help defeat Jimmy Carter, his Democratic opponent.

title: Article 6  No Title
Proving Professor Wrong Led To Nobel Prize for Lipscomb
description: When William N. Lipscomb Jr. was a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, he heard a professor propose a theory of chemical bonding in certain boron compounds. Something about the theory did not seem right, and he set out to prove his professor wrong. In so doing, he won the 1976 Nobel Prize in chemistry.

title: Crack in Nuclear Door
description: Soviet Foreign Minister Gromyko's new offer to discuss onsite inspection adds some credibility to Moscow's old proposal to ban all underground nuclear weapons tests. But major obstacles still hinder a comprehensive test ban. Russia's insistence that all five nuclear weapons states must agree is a deadend street; France and China have refused even to join in the SovietAmericanBritish ban on atmospheric tests, which China continues to set off.

title: 3 MONTH BILL RATES LOWEST SINCE APRIL
description: The credit markets seemed to have second thoughts about the nearterm outlook for interest rates yesterday and the case for a continued decline in rates became less convincing in the money market, the funds rate traded mostly at 5 percent and rose to 5 1/16 percent before the Federal Reserve pumped some temporary reserves into the banking system. That lessened the conviction that the central ban now was aiming to push this key rate to 4 percent Nevertheless, threemonth Treasury bills were sold yesterday at an average discount rate of 4.80 percent, the lowest rate in a weekly bill auction since midApril.

title: The High Cost of Loving
description: PRESERVATION HALL. By Scott Spencer. 273 pages. Knopf. $8.95.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  money rates for Monday.

title: Blacks Turn Violent After Soweto Burial
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct 18 (Reuters)Nearly 700 blacks in the township of Soweto marched last night on a municipal depot, forced their way past its guards and commandeered a dozen trucks and a water tanker and drove the vehicles through fences and into walls, according to police.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 3 P.M: on SouthWest Africa.

title: Wood, Field &Stream: Semantics and the Hunter
description: Some time ago in this column I deplored the use of harvest to describe the killing of game by hunters.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A oneyear contract covering 1976 that does not provide for a salary increase for the 12,500 members of the Nassau County Civil Service Employees Association was mandated by the Board of Supervisors. Irving, Flaumenbaum president of the union, said it would challenge the hoard's action in State Supreme Court. Meanwhile, county and union officials agreed to meet Thursday to start negotiations for a 1977 contract.

title: Anaconda Company Unit Joins In Reduction of Copper Prices
description: Following the recent action of other major producers, the Anaconda Sales Company, a unit of the Anaconda Company, announced yesterday a reduction of 4 cents a pound in its copper prices.

title: WESLEY L. WHEELER, 77; DESIGNED AND BUILT SHIPS
description: Wesley Lunn Wheeler, who designed and built thousand of ships, died last Wednesday in Rye, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: Old Fans Cheer Tagliavini in Carnegie Hall Recital
description: Ferruccio Tagliavini's return to New York on Sunday night was one of those sentimental occasions that give opera followers the opportunity to cheer an old favorite. Mr. Tagliavini is not really old except as tenors go He is only 63 years old. A leading Italian tenor during and shortly after World War it he sang lyris roles at the Melropolitan from 1947 through 1951. How many singers from that period still dare to appear in public?

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Months since reports of illness. Also in reception party are Nikolai V. Podgorny, third from left, Soviet President; Leonid I. Brezhnev, center, Communist Party Secretary, and Andrei A. Gromyko, Foreign Minister.

title: Summary of the Various Actions Taken Yesterday By the United States Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The Supreme Court took the following actions today.

title: Setting is Mideast, but Life In Kibbutz Echoes the Midwest
description: KIBBUTZ AFIKIM, IsraelA searing October afternoon in the Jordan Valley. The sun scorches the bald pates of the bleached hills in the distance, siphons precious moisture from the irrigated acres of baking crops and stuns a stroller into nearsomnambulism.

title: Taxes & Accounting: EndofYear Capital Gain and Loss Strategies
description: Given the precipitous drop in stock prices recently, more investors than usual will be weighing tax loss carryover factors in their trading decisions between now and the end of the Year.

title: M.T.A. Chief Warns Of Increase in Fare
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that his agency would consider shortly raising the 50cent fare by 10 or 15 cents because of a loss of revenues that had been expected.

title: Trail Blazers Trade Malone to Braves
description: Moses Malone, trying to survive in the world of professional basketball ever since he bypassed college in 1974 to sign with the Utah Stars of the American Basketball Association, was traded yesterday by the Portland Trail Blazers to the Buffalo Braves.

title: I.R.S. Reported Investigating ExNew York Realty Commissioner
description: The Internal Revenue Service is investigating the financial affairs of Ira Duchan, who retired suddenly on Saturday from his post as New York City Real Estate Commissioner, persons close to Mr. Duchan said yesterday.

title: Supreme Court Agrees to Review Cunningham's Bid to Keep Post Despite Refusal to Testify in Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The Supreme Court set the stage today for a major ruling on the Fifth Amendment privilege against selfincrimination, in a case involving Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic Bronx County chairman.

title: The Most Pervasive Corruption
description: Two stories appearing on facing pages of The New York Times for Sunday, Oct. 17, suggest a solid reason for the apparently widespread disaffection, apathy, cynicism and despair of the American people in their Bicentennial year. The reason is corruption not necessarily outright bribery and graft, but the pervasive corruption of advantage, deception, greed and disregard of the public interest.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WOMEN & MONEY The First Women's Bank is one year and four days old. Deposits are up to $13 million, there are 5,000 accounts for people from Maine to California and more than 90 percent of the bank's borrowers are women.

title: Article 3  No Title
Thomas E. Mullaney
description: TOKYONot expecting any notable achievements, three prominent stock market officials from the United States arrived here a week ago to join some 75 of their counterparts from other countries for the annual meeting of the International Federation of Stock Exchanges. When they left last Saturday for some sightseeing and a tour of business and industry in other Japanese cities, they were surprised and pleased over what had been accomplished here to facilitate the international movement of capital.

title: Court to Decide if Separate School May Be Established for Each Sex
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a city's public school system may have one college preparatory school solely for boys and one solely for girls.

title: Former Gov. Noe Of Louisiana Dies; A Huey Long Ally
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) Former Gov. James A. Noe of Louisiana, a Depressionera ally of Huey P. Long and a pioneer in the Louisiana oil industry, died today in a hospital where he had been under treatment for a heart ailment. He was 82 years old and lived in Monroe, La.

title: NASSAU STRIKE BEGUN BY SPECIAL TEACHERS
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 18 Teachers employed by the Nassau County Board of Cooperative Educational Services went on strike today, affecting classes for 8,500 pupils in occupational and special educational programs.

title: Three Governors Ask for a Return Of Economic Aid to the Northeast
description: The governors of the three largest Northeastern States, Carey of New York, Byrne of New Jersey and Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania, told a Congressional committee yesterday that the Northeast region had long helped other parts of the country to grow economically ani that was now its turn to get some help.

title: Argentine Executive Reported Slain
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 18 (UPI)Terrorists firing from an automobile assassinated an executive of the Argentine subsidiary of the Borgward car firm of West Gennany today, police sources said. He was identified as Enrique Arrosagaray.

title: THREE PIANISTS DELIVER SOME HEAVENLY JAZZ
description: Roland Hanna, Dave McKenna and Jimmy Rowles, three accomplished jazz pianists, and George Mraz, who assisted on bass, performed in the first of a series of Heavenly Jazz concerts Sunday at flue Church of Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue an 90th Street. The results were somewhat less than celestial and the church itself was the principal culprit.

title: Sketches of Physics and Chemistry Laureates
description: I knew I had written a lot of nice papers about boranes, but I never actually knew that anyone read them. In science, when you're working on highly original research, the only thing you worry about is not falling flat on your face in your next publication. The tall, thin, 56yearold chemist stood beaming the in his book lined thirdfloor office on the Harvard He had just been notified that he had won the. Nobel Prize in Chemistry, and his students and fellow professors had broken out some champagne for the occasion. Dr. Lipscomb said that he was astounded to win the price after 27 years of research in one of the most esoteric areas of inorganic chemistry.

title: Tins Cows Producing More
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. (UPI) Dairy production in Texas has increased about 25 percent since 1961. Dr. Michael Tomaszewski of the Texas Agricultural Extension Service said annual milk production for each daily cow in Texas in 1961 was 9,256 pounds a year. 1975,1 the average had reached 12,905 pounds a year for each cow, he said.

title: JAMES OSBORN, 70, A LITERARY SCHOLAR
description: James M. Osborn, a Yale University English scholar and literary detective, died Sunday at YaleNew Haven Hospital. He was 70 years old and a resident of New Haven.

title: European Steelmakers Brace for Another Slump
description: PARTS, Oct. 18The expected autumn pickup in Western European demand for steel has failed to materialize, and steelmakers are bracing for another slump.

title: Music: A Juilliard Anniversary
description: The Juilliard String Quartet is 30 years old this month, but it is a young 30. of the four musicians who currently perform under that proud banner, only one, Robert Mann, was a member of the original group. Mr. Mann, the first violinist, led an anniversary performance at the Juilliard Theater on Sunday that brought into focus several characteristics long associated with the Juilliard, as well as others that set the 1976 edition of the quartet apart from its predecessors.

title: Beame Reported To Seek Removal Of Dr. Holloman
description: The Beanie administration is actively seeking a replacement for Dr. John L. S. Holloman, the beleaguered president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, but it has been turned down by three of the persons approached, officials said yesterday.

title: Residents of Harlem Area Battle An Increasingly Shifty Foe: Crime
description: I was talking to my neighbor about a baby's funeralthe one that fell out the window, recalled Theresa Skinner, When all of a sudden I felt something hit my foot. I don't know who did it or where it came from, but I had been shot.

title: Ford and Rumsfeld Endorse Brown to Continue as Head of Joint Chiefs of Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 Gen. George S. Brown appeared at a Pentagon news conference today to clarify his comments on Israel, Britain and Iran and received the endorsement of President Ford and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld to continue as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: Article 2  No Title
$20 Million Provided to Improve BostonWashington Rail Corridor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) The Federal Railroad Administration announced today that it was making available $20 million to be used for the first purchase of materials for upgrading the Northeast Corridor railroad line between Boston and Washington.

title: Gambino Funeral Subdued, With Few Crime Figures
description: Carlo Gambino was interred in a family crypt in Queens yesterday after a funeral service at Our Lady of Grace Church in Brooklyn that would have been more appropriate for a prosperous grandfather than for the godfather of the underworld.

title: FORD SIGNS LEGISLATION ON MIDDECADE CENSUS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI)President Ford today signed into law a bill providing for middecade censuses of the populationthe first to be in 1985 with subsequent ones to be every 10 years.

title: 4 Years Later, Carter's Reorganization of Georgia Government is Controversial
description: ATLANTAFour and a half years after it went into effect, Jimmy Carter's ambitious reorganization of the government of Georgia is still so controversial that there is hardly anyone in the state government who does not harbor strong feelings about it.

title: Can Yanks, 02, Bounce Back? Ellis Hurls at Stadium Tonight
description: Still seeking their 100th World Series victory after a lapse of 12 years plus two games, the Yankees will resume their uphill battle with the Cincinnati Reds for baseball's championship tonight before 57,000 fans shivering in their polar seats at Yankee Stadium and millions more lounging in the warmth of their living rooms.

title: Burton Richter
description: Professor Richter called his discovery the psi particle. Another physicist 3,000 miles away called his discovery the J particle. But both atomic particies turned out to be the same and each man discovered that his discovery was identical with that of the other man's. And so, for their joint discovery, achieved independently two years ago, the two were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics yesterday. Dr. Richter, at the Stanford Nuclear Accelerator in California, along with Dr. Samuel Ting at the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, had discovered a new subatomic particle with unique qualities, a feat discribed by one Nobel judge as the greatest discovery ever in the field of elementary particles.

title: Memorial Services
description: VAILJanet Bentz Droving. Friends are cordially Invited to attend a memorial service of music at the Princeton University Chanel 10 A.M., Saturday, October 21. Contributions to the Janet Vail Memorlal Center wilt be welcomed by Juanita Vail Kusner RD 5, box 298, East Stroudsburg, Pa. 18301.

title: 20 Reported Dead in South Africa In Clash Between Black Tribesmen
description: PIETERMARITZBURG, South Africa, Oct. 18 (Reuters) Twenty tribesmen died when rival factions of the Bomvu tribe fought with guns and spears near here during the weekend, the police said today.

title: 30 Hurt in Madrid Subway Crash
description: MADRID, Oct. 18 (UPI) Two Crowdext subway trains collided today during the morning rush hour, injuring about 30 passengers, none of them seriously, subway officials said.

title: Telephone Company Is Giving Scores
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide inningbyinning scores of the World Series games to fans calling 9991313. The scores will be updated after each half inning, and final scores will be carried for several hours after the end of each game.

title: Foreign Exchange
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Monday's foreign exchange in dollars and decimals of a

title: Pedro Sanjuan, 90, Who Founded The Havana Philharmonic, is Dead
description: Pedro Sanjudn, Spanish composer and conductor who founded the Havana Philharmonic, died yesterday in Washington. He would have been 90 years old on Nov. 15.

title: CHAMBER SERIES OPENED BY SIYO MUSIC SOCIETY
description: The SiYo Music Society's sixth annual chamber music series got under way Sunday afternoon at Pace University's Schimmel Center for the Arts. Although the four musicians participating in the concert do not constitute a regularly performing quartet, their readings left little to be desired in terms of ensemble rapport and perceptive insights on the music at hand.

title: ,Debate Over Computers to China
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI)The State Department is pressing for the sale of American computer equipment to China despite strong protests from the Energy Research and Development Administration and reservations by the Pentagon, the magazine Aviation Week and Space Technology reported today. The weekly said that the potential sales involves two Cyber 172 computers, which the State Department says would be used by Peking too monitor seismic events. The energy agency and the Defense Department maintain that the computers could also be used, as was done by the United States several years ago.

title: NEW YORK CITY REJECTS HOUSE STUDY OF PENSIONS
description: New York City's Deputy Mayor for finance, John C. Burton, took strong exception yesterday to a publicized, but unreleased, draft report of the Pension Task Force of the House subcommittee on labor standards that was highly critical of the investment practices of New York pension systems.

title: Reg Murphy, Critic of Carter, Given Credentials for Campaign
