description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 20Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, met today with President Hafez alAssad in Damascus.

title: John Graham Dead; ExTreasury Official A Member of A.E.C
description: John Stephens Graham, former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury and a former member of the Atomic Energy Commission, died yesterday in George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 71 years old and lived in the capital.

title: Dismissal of One of 3 Indictments Indicated
description: Justice Leonard H. Sandler of State Supreme Court indicated yesterday that he would dismiss one indictment against Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx County Democratic chairman, and added that he had found the evidence to be extremely sparse in two other indictments against him.

title: Japan Plans NonU.S. Planes
description: TOKYO, Oct. 20 (Reuters)Japan will give more consideration in the future to buying aircraft from nonUnited States manufacturers, following the impact of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporodon's payments scandal, a senior official of the Ministry International Trade and Industry said. At a briefing for foreign newsmen, Japan's international trade; policy directorgeneral, Toshihiko Yano, acknowledged United States manufacturers had so far dominated aircrafts supply to Japan.

title: U. S. BASES IN GREECE STIR ATHENS DISPUTE
description: ATHENS. Oct. 20The continuing presence of American military bases here has become an emotional and political Issue that reflects deep disagreements over the future course of Greek foreign policy.

title: Scandinavians Press Investigation Of Reported Korean Smuggling
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 20Police authorities in four northern European countries pressed forward today with investigations into what some officials now believe was a wellorchestrated smuggling operation organized by North Korean diplomats and directed at most of Scandinavia.

title: IRAN TO PAY KRUPP OVER $200 MILLION FOR ITS 25.01% SHARE
description: PARIS, Oct. 20Iran is paying, according to unofficial estimates, more than $200 million for a 25.01 percent share in the Krupp industrial complex, and will pump some $70 million of capital into the former West German arms builder under terms of a dramatic purchase agreement announced yesterday in Teheran.

title: Atomic Agency Completes Report Amid Charges it Stilled Criticism
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, apparently concerned by mounting criticism that safety questions raised by its technical experts are being stifled by top staff members, has completed a 300page study of the question.

title: News Summary
description: President Ford would not tolerate another Arab oil embargo, he told White House news conference, adding that his Administration's Middle East policies made the chances for another embargo virtually nil. He said American diplomacy had won the confidence of both Israel and Arab countries, making the chances of their fighting less than in 1973. The assessment reflected the view of the intelligence community concerning the effect of splits in the Arab world, the fighting in Lebanon, Israeli armed power and American influence. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Democratic Leaders in Jersey Report They Are Uneasy About Carter's Presidential Campaign in the State
description: Nekv Jersey's state Democratic chairman. James P. Dugan, says that he is uneasy about Jimmy Carter's Presidential campaign in the state and that the candidate's campaign staff has exhibited a cavalier attitude about getting him in here.

title: Religious Leaders Score Group's Reported Effort To Elect Only Christians
description: Four religious leaders yesterday condemned what they termed the efforts of a group of conservative evangelical organizations of persuade Christians to vote only for Christian candidates for Congress.

title: The Housing Issue
description: The interplay of recession and inflation has had some of Its most severe, distorting effects in the housing industry. The nation has lived for so long with the sad reality of big city slums and of tarpaper shacks and tumbledown houses in halfhidden rural villages that housing crisis has come to be regarded as a permanent feature of the social landscape.

title: 8RONFMAN JUDGE MAKES SUGGESTION TO LAWYERS
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 20  The judge in the Bronfman kidnapping trial, who last week directed defense and prosecution attorneys not to discuss the case with reporters, today suggested that attorneys, for the Bronfman family not Take any further statements about the case.

title: Ford Expected to Sign Alaskan Gas Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20President Ford Is expected to sign this week a bill that purports to provide for choosing a naturalgas delivery route from Alaska, but which is more likely to set the stage for a bruising threeway lobbying battle in Congress in 1977.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS U.S. WOULD NOT TOLERATE NEW ARAB OIL CUTOFF
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  President Ford said today that he would not tolerate another Arab oil embargo, but added that because of his Administration's Middle East policies, the chances for another embargo are virtually nil.

title: 5 NATIONS DISCUSS PLACE FOR CUBAN EXILES TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Legal representatives of five Caribbean governments met in Port of Spain, Trinidad, today to determine where a group of Cuban exiles accused of causing a plane crash fatal to 73 persons should be tried.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The 18 elementary schools in the Township of Cherry Hill will be open for classes today despite a threat to plant a second bomb at one of the schools, should classes he scheduled.

title: Georgia Governor Grants Delay In Execution Set for Next Week
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 20 (UPI)Gov. George Busbee said today that he would grant 90day stay of execution for a convicted doublemurderer scheduled to become the first person to be executed in the United States since 1967.

title: 24 DEAD, 50 MISSING AS TANKER CAPSIZES MISSISSIPPI FERRY
description: LULING, La., Oct. 20 At least 24 persons died and as many as 50 others were believed drowned when a tanker and ferry collided on the Mississippi River here today.

title: Screen: Song 'Remains the Same':Zeppelin's Rock Pulverizes Eardrums at Cinema I
description: "The Song Remains the Same" is a movie to listen to Led Zeppelin by. If you want to listen to Led Zeppelin. If you don't, there's no point going.If you do, it's still a dubious proposition. Certainly the sound system at the Cinema I Theater, where it opened yesterday, does full justice to the decibels. Even using the squashed-up balls of paper napkin recommended by a knowledgeable member of this newspaper's music staff, it was loud. Powered ear-drum floated about.Presumably, though, putting this British rock group in a movie was intended to be the equivalent not of listening to their records but of attending one of their concerts. This is very hard to do on film: We miss the immediacy, the sense of physical presence and even, to an extent, physical peril. The power of a mass audience to communicate excitement is absent.To make up for this, the film intercuts a variety of scenes while each of the 13 numbers is being performed. A few are more or less realistic  a sequence outside Madison Square Garden, an argument between the group's manager and a Garden official  and others are fantasy. Members of the group put on cloaks, ride around on horses, stand in the moonlight.They are pseudodreams, like the unconvinced artwork on rock record jackets. The scenes showing the group performing are more informative though not much more powerful.They are dominated by the singer, Robert Plant. A great mass of yellow curls tumbling around his shoulders, Mr. Plant sashays around the stage, posturing, pouting and conducting a meaningful relationship with the microphone. It looks like a sheep trying to seduce a telephone pole.Possibly this is what led to a PG (Parental Guidance Suggested) rating. For the first two-thirds  which was all this reviewer stayedthere seemed to be no other particular threat to the future adults in a stone-deaf civilization.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The controversy swirling around the Mayaguez affair misses the most important point. That point is not that additional diplomatic initiatives might have been undertaken or that the assault on Koh Tang island seems not to have influenced the release of the crew. President Ford's complaint about second guessing seems fair (if not entirely on the merits) in meeting these charges. Rather, the point is that despite a successful crisis management of an illegal seizure of American shipping the Ford Administration lacks a principled vision for the protection of United States oceans interests and for the future reduction of such incidents.

title: Compass and the Second City Improvise Reunion in Chicago
description: CHICAGOAt class reunions old graduates often idealize the past, ??? the present and take the measure of one another's success and failure in contrast, when the praduates of the Compass and the Second City gathered last weekend at the University of Chicago (where the improvisational movement began 21 years ago), the reunion was primarily a celebration and a recreation.

title: 4 Children Die in Fire and Blast
description: LEICESTER, Mass., Oct. 20 (AP)Four young children were killed this morning when they were trapped in an upstairs bedroom after an explosion and fire ripped through their home, destroying it. Six of the 11 other children of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Sawicki escaped from the house, and Mrs. Sawicki was rescued. Mr. Sawicki and one son were not at home.

title: Ladies Home Journal Sets New Campaign
description: On Monday The Ladies Home Journal will be breaking a big new advertising campaign aimed at raising both advertising revenues and circulation. The first ad will also introduce The Number One Woman, who will be seen throughout the campaign.

title: PuddleWonderful
description: When I was 15, I appeared early one day at Joseph Kling's bookshop on Eighth Street, having saved up $7.50 to purchase an outofprint edition had seen there of E. E. Cummings's Tulips and Chimneys. An aweinspiring figure in his eyeshade and thick glasses, the generally surly Mr. Kling seemed surprisingly touched by my eagerness to have that volume and, without any suggestion from me, spontaneously reduced the price to $6.50. All the world loves a lover.

title: Nursing Homes Gifts to Charities Under Study by Special Prosecutor
description: The state's special nursinghome prosecutor is investigating whether Medicaid funds were Improperly used to make thousands of dollars of contributions to charitable organizations, particularly the United Jewish Appeal, according to people familiar with the inquiry.

title: Hare Krishna and Parents of 2 Members Rebut Brainwashing Charges
description: Officials of the Hare Krishna movement offered testimony by the parents of two of its members and that of a clinical psychologist, a theologian and others yesterday to rebut charges by the Queens District Attorney that the sect uses mindcontrol techniques to manipulate its members.

title: Advertising
description: The American consumer, who went from a mood of pessimism in the last half of 1975 to one of optimism in the first half of this year, now has retreated to a middle position of cautious optimism, Philip Levine, senior vice president and executive research director of Ogilvy & Mather, told a group of marketing people yesterday.

title: New York Cries Foul On Series Ball Sales
description: Consumer Affairs Commissioner Elinor Guggenheimer has ruled out as a foul ball an effort by a mailorder merchant.

title: Bridge:
description: Few postmortems last more than a minute or two, although tenacious analysts have been known to brood on a hand for a day or two after the event. But the process may take much longer when the object of the exercise is a world championship deal.

title: Dr. Sanford C. Abelow Dies at 53; A New York City Agency Attorney
description: Dr. Sanford C. Abelow, an administrative attorney and chief of the legal unit of the New York City Department of Personnel, died of a heart attack Tuesday in BeekmanDowntown Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: Baseball and Debate Present TV Problem
description: The television debate tomorrow night between President Ford and his Democratic opponent, Jimmy Carter, may force a change in the starting time of the fifth game of the World Seriesif a fifth game is required.

title: Linda Stargatt Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce M. Stargatt of Wilmington, Del., have announced, the engagement of their daughter, Linda Susan Stargatt, to Lawrence Paul Mann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Mann of Freeport, L.I. A wedding in the spring is planned. Miss Stargatt is a senior at American University in Washington, from which her fiance graduated. He is a student at the Catholic University's Columbus School of Law.

title: Poor Murderer Plays on the Mind
description: What is illusion and what reality? What is playacting and what is life? The questions are very partinently put by the Czech playwright Pavel Kohout in his play Poor Murderer, which opened last night at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

title: MUNICH TALK ON FARE ASSAILED BY BERGER
description: Stephen Berger, executive director of the Emergency Financial Control Board, charged yesterday that David L. Yunich was floating trial balloons filled with transcontinental hot air aboutthe probability of a 10 or 15cent increase in the New York City transit fare.

title: Benevolent Sergeants
description: The kind of courageous, enlightened leadership essential to New York's future was demonstrated when delegates of the Sergeants Benevolent Association overwhelmingly approved a new contract that offer significant savings to the city with no gains for the union.

title: Moynihan Uses Rainout in Series To Score Points in Queens Stops
description: Armed with an important upstate newspaper endorsement  and a new campaign slogan  Daniel P. Moynihan, the DemocraticLiberal Party candidate for the United States Senate, brought his campaign to Queens last night, making unscheduled stops at candidates nights in Wocdhaven and Forest Hills and Democratic Club in Richmond Hill.

title: Israelis Doubt That Arab Proposals Will Bring an End to Lebanese War
description: JERUSALEM, Oct, 20  Israeli Foreign Ministry officials said today they doubted that a peace plan signed by six Arab leaders in Saudi Arabia on. Monday would result in an end to the Lebanese civil war.

title: News Summary
description: President Ford would not tolerate another Arab oil embargo, he told White House news conference, adding that his Administration's Middle East policies made the chances for another embargo virtually nil. He said American diplomacy had won the confidence of both Israel and Arab countries, making the chances of their fighting less than in 1973. The assessment reflected the view of the intelligence community concerning the effect of splits in the Arab world, the fighting in Lebanon, Israeli armed power and American influence. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: F.T.C. SAYS 200,000 GOT REFUNDS BY STORE CHAINS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI)Nearly 200,000 people across the country have received more than $3.5 million in refunds from several departmentstore chains that did not tell them they overpaid their bills, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Morality In Foreign Policy
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20In dealing with the world, Henry Kissinger said the other day, we must distinguish morality from moralizing. Even those who do not regard the Secretary of Mate as a preeminent moral philosopher will accept the importance of the distinction.

title: Market Place
description: The General American Oil Company, which has been wooed by many wouldbe marriage partners in the past, may be getting the rush againor so the Wall Street rumor mill would have investors think.

title: OIL DISTILLATE STOCKS ROSE FOR LATEST WEEK
description: Oil distillate stocks, used chiefly for homeheating oil, continued to rise in the week ended Oct. 15 as the nation's refiners adjusted to cold weather, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A quotation attributed to Senator George McGovern that appeared in a news analysis in The Times yesterday originated with John Chancellor of NBC News, whose remarks at a meeting in New York were cited by Senator McGovern in a later speech. The reference was to emptiness and pettiness in the 1976 political campaign.

title: CARTER BACKS GOVERNORS ON REGIONAL ENERGY PLAN
description: The creation of a regional energy devel opment corporation, has been proposed by a coalition of Democratic Governors from seven Northeast states, was endorsed yesterday by Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential nominee.

title: Haverford Go Coed? Bryn Mawr Bristles
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Oct. 20Resembling a family fight that the neighbors can hear, the Quakers at Haverford College are almost at the point of having a crockerythrowing setto with the Quakers down the road at Bryn Mawr College over a proposal by Haverford to go coeducational.

title: JEWS ARE PROMISED HIGH SOVIET PARLEY
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 20A group of Jewish dissulenrs who reported having been beaten by plainclothesmen ended a sitin at the Supreme Soviet today after ben promised a meeting with the Minister Internal Affairs to discuss emigration policy.

title: Blanchard K. Parsons Dead at 55; Official of U.S.I.S. in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 20 (UPI) Blanchard K. Parsons, 55 years old, an American diplomatic officer, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home in Pusan, about 205 miles south of Seoul, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

title: Betty Stove Gets Through Tennis Ordeal
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 20It has taken Betty Stove four matches over four days to qualify for the $200,000 Colgate Inaugural women's tennis tournament. Why the Dutchwoman had to submit to such indignity baffles her in any of the six languages she speaks.

title: Board Votes Shared Affiliation for Lincoln Hospital
description: Faced with a bitter dispute over whether a Jewish or a Roman Catholic institution would provide doctors and other health professionals to a major new municipal hospitalLincoln in the Bronxthe board of directors of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation voted yesterday to let them share the multimilliondollar contract.

title: Poll in West Europe Finds U.S. Prestige Lowest in 22 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 A preliminary analysis of an Administrationsponsored survey of West European attitudes toward the United States last summer concludes that while there is still a large reservoir of good will toward the United States in West Europe, it is currently at its lowest level in the 22year history of U.S.I.A. surveys.

title: ITALIAN RED LEADERS IN AN ANGRY DEBATE
description: ROME, Oct. 20The simmering dispute in Italy's Communist Party over strategy has broken out in the open, in the form of a rare display of public disunity during a meeting of its Central Committee.

title: Stocks Rise 4.90 As Housing Gain Remains a Spur
description: Stock prices advanced slightly yesterday in what Wall Street analysts termed a continued reaction to a Government announcement Tuesday that housing starts in September rose to their highest rate in two and a half years.

title: Who's Erwin Rabhan?
description: PORTLAND, Ore.Nobody ever made a report of contributors, said the candidate who would never lie to US about his 1970 campaign fatcat list, and we didn't maintain those records.

title: Excerpts From. President Ford's News Conference
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Following are excerpts from President Ford's news conference today.

title: 22 Queens Garden Wildfowl Shot
description: Seven geese and 15 ducks, all prize stock kept for the delight of both young and old at the Queens Botanical Garden in Flushing, were shot and killed by vandals late Monday or early Tuesday morning.

title: Boren is Ridden To Hunter Title
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 20Going into the stake, the final class, Caryl Tate,'s Boren was trailing Hunterdon's Dillon by I point tonight in the race for th. ????year green working hunter championship at the Pennsylvania N:It'onal liorsc Show.

title: CITY HALL PREPARING LIST OF PUBLIC WORKS
description: With more than 2,500 construction jobs in New York City at stake, Beanie administration officials sought yesterday to formulate a final list of publicworks projects to qualify for nearly $100 million in new Federal financing.

title: The Secular Slowdown Thesis
description: The current recovery from the 197375 recessionthe worst of the postwar periodis feebler than most economists had expected. Most disturbingly, capital spending by business has been slow to ignite. The accompanying chart, constructed by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, shows how capital spending has lagged far behind the rate of recovery in the preceding four businesscycle upswings.

title: Calder is Honored by Artists at Whitney Dinner
description: Alexander Calder, the sculptor, was honored last night at a dinner at the Whitney Museum of American Art that was attended by some of the leading lights of the cultural world.

title: Dollar Falls Mostly on the European Markets
description: LONDON, Oct. 20 (AP)The dollar fell on major European currency markets today, but edged ahead against the British pound. Gold prices retreated slightly on the main bullion markets in London and Zurich.

title: Bulova Watch Company is Moving Its Headquarters to Flushing
description: The Bulova Watch Company, one of the country's largest watch makers, is moving its executive headquarters, sales and advertising departments from Rockefeller Center to its Bulova Park facility in Flushing, Queens.

title: Escaped Rikers Island Inmate Seized by Police in South Bronx
description: David Wanton, one of seven convicts who escaped from the House of Detention for Men on Rikers Island three weeks ago, was seized last night in the South Bronx.

title: In Memorium
description: BARTLETTElla Herbert. The dead are like the stars by day withdrawn from mortal eyes, but not extinct, they hold their way in glory through the sky: Cherished memories.

title: LOUISE M. MILLS, LEADER IN GIRL SCOUTS, 74, DIES
description: Louise M, Mills of Locust Valley, L.I., the wife of Dudley H: Mills, a financier, died suddenly Tuesday while visiting a daughter, Mrs. John R. Petty, in Washington. She was 74 years old.

title: Poll in West Europe Finds U.S. Prestige Lowest in 22 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20A preliminary analysis of an Administrationsponsored survey of West European attitudes toward the United States last summer concludes that while there is still a large reservoir of good will toward the United States in West Europe, it is currently at its lowest level in the 22year history of U.S.I.A. surveys.

title: Jersey Slayer Held in Kidnapping
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 20 (UPI)Edgar Smith Jr., 42 years old, the New Jersey death row author charged with kidnapping and attempted murder here, is being held on bail of $250,000. He charged with the Oct. 1 kidnapping of Mrs. Lefteriva Ozbun, 33, of Chula Vista, Calif., from a parking lot and stabbing her in the abdomen as they struggled in his car on a freeway. He was arrested Oct. 7 in Las Vegas in his 14 years on New Jersey's death row for the bludgeon murder of a Mahwah, N.J., high school cheerleader, he wrote Brief Against Death. He was paroled in 1971.

title: Student Equestrians Moving Forward in Leaps and Bounds Toward National Horse Show
description: PITTSTOWN, N. J.George Morris, a slim, sternfaced man swathed in riding clothes from hat boot, stood with West Point erectness in a pasture here the other day and watched six young equestrians lump their horses over fences.

title: General Brown And Burdens
description: The United States command's increasing concern over an imbalance between this countly's strategic global commitments and its resources is cited by many top officers in the services and in the Defense Department as the basis for Gen. George S. Brown's comment that Israel represents a burden to America. These sources point out that the question in an interview that provoked General. Brown's answer included the words America's ?Joint strategic interest. When all the elements of that interest are considered, they say, then the possibility of going to Israel's aid or of diverting weapons and logistical support to Israel becomes, if not a burden, a distraction. The sources were speaking only in military, and not political, terms.

title: F.P.C. Cuts Gas Price Rise 25%; Admits an Error in July Estimates
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20In an action that is expected to save consumers $500 million a year, the Federal Power Commission today reduced the size of an increase in natural gas prices by 25 percent.

title: John Petty Named By Marine Midland
description: After a long search, the troubled Marine Midland Banking Group announced yesterday that it had named a new president and chief operating officer. He is John R. Petty, 46 years old, a partner and board member with Lehman Brothers Inc. and before that an Assistant Treasury Secretary for International Affairs under Presidents Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard M. Nixon.

title: Bridge:
description: Few postmortems last more than minute or two, although tenacious analysts have been known to brood on a hand for a day or two after the event. But the process may take much longer when the object of the exercise is a world championship deal.

title: Article 1  No Title
THE HARTFORD TIMES CEASES PUBLICATION
description: The Hartford Times ceased publication yesterday after 159 years.

title: The Program
description: BOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA, Seill Crzavra, conturtor. Galina Vishoevkaya, soprano Clatianal; Pamela Gore, mezzosoorano (Madame Larina); Joy Davidson, contralto (Olga); Lili Chookasian, mezzosoprano (Filipievna); Benjamin Ltrxon, baritone f Eugen Untold); NiCalai Ceoda, tenor (Lenski); Paul Plishka, bass (Prince Gremin); Gregory Reinhart, bassbaritone (Captain); David Arnold, bass (Zaretski); Jean Duocauy, tenor (Monsieur Triquct); Tanglewood Festival Chorus, John Oliver, director. At Carreoin Hall.

title: Collins Signs With Flyers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (UPI) The Philadelphia Flyers today signed Billy Collins, a 10year National Hockey League veteran. The 6foot, 178pound Collins was signed as a free agent after working out with the club for two days. The 33yearold forward was dropped by the New York Rangers this season.

title: Hill's Streak is Threatened as JetsWeigh Lineup shifts
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 20In the confusion of a rookie season, Coach Lou Holtz today added to the uncertainty by indicating that Winston Hill, his most experienced player, may have lost his job.

title: Notes on People
description: In a public avowal of innocence, Kakuei Tanaka, the former Japanese Prime Minister, has denied involvement in the Lockheed payoff scandal and indicated he will run for reelection to the Parliament.

title: Reports on Insider Operations Issued by Big Board and Amex
description: The latest reports of changes in stock ownership by officers, directors and large stockholders in listed companies were issued yesterday by the New York and American Stock Exchanges. The lists include the following.

title: Brakeman Killed in Jersey
description: ROXBURY, N.J., Oct. 20 (UPI)Robert Thomas, 56 years old of Scranton, Pa., a conrail brakeman, was crushed to death Tuesday between an engine and a freight car at the Port Morris rail yard. The police said the engine apparently had backed into the freight car accidentally. The State Board on Public Utility Commissioners and Conrail opened an investigation into the death.

title: White Sox Told to Pay Part of Tanner's Salary
description: Lee MacPhail, the American League president, ruled yesterday that the Chicago White Sox must pay part of Chuck Tanner'zs salary for the past season but are free of any obligations to Tanner thereafter.

title: Watson of Harvard to Retire
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 20 (AP)Robert B. Watson announced today that he would step down in July after six years as director of athletics at Harvard.

title: A New Look at Oceanic Dumping
description: FORKED RIVER, Oct. 20 The black tide, or algae blanket, that has been contaminating the Eastern shore waters since midsummer, has led to a new look at oceandumping procedures, Federal environmental officials said today.

title: 2 Flyers to Stand Trial on Charges of Assault
description: TORONTO, Oct. 20, (AP)  Mel Bridgman, a center, and Bob Kelly, a wing, of the Philadelphia Flyers will stand trial Nov. 8 on charges of assault pausing bodily harm.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ALL ABOUT ANNE The empty rooms are rather surprisingly large, as tourists learn when visiting the most famous attic in Amsterdam, where small group of Dutch Jews, including the family of Otto Frank, hid from the Nazis for more than two years. The walls hold the only surviving, personal touches. One is a tiny map, with thumb tacks used by Mr. Frank to mark the advance of the Allied forces. Nearby are two small pictures of Deanna Durbin and Norma Shearer, placed beside her bed by his young daughter, Anne.

title: Article 4  No Title
Dr. Samuel Rosof Dies at 70; Of Wyckoff Heights Hospital Staff
description: Dr. Samuel Rosof, a general praeticioner, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 70 years old and resident of Flushing, Queens.

title: Barbara Ward is Given an Award For Work in Natural Resources
description: Barbara Ward, the British author and economist, was honored by the Natural Resources Defense Council last night for her careerlong efforts in focusing attention on the limited supply of natural resources and her work against nuclear, proliferation.

title: Issue and Debate
description: One of the most important issues now confronting Governor Carey's blueribbon commission on the future of higher education in New York State is the question of merging the City University and the. State University.

title: Husband Held in Wife's Death
description: SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 20 (AP) David DuBeck, 35 years old, who has be charged with the strangulation of his estranged wife, Carol, 35, whose body was discovered here last week was arraigned yesterday in New Bruswick before Judge John E. Bachman of Superior Court who set bail at $100,000.

title: Article 2  No Title
Caster Returns to Tight End
description: Richard Caster will go back to being the best tight end, according to Holtz. Caster has been tried at wide receiver in an attempt to get more speed among the catching brigade.  Steve Davis will be out at least two weeks, the same amount of time that will keep Ed Marinaro on the sidelines.  The starting running backs against the Colts will be Bob Gresham and Clark Gaines. The New Yorkers boast an injury list of 17 names.

title: Urban League Critical of a Ford Ad
description: Vernon Jordan, the executive director of the National Urban League, urged President Ford yesterday to discontinue the unauthorized use in black newspaper advertisements of a twoyearold photograph of the President and three black leaders that implies my endorsement of your candidacy.

title: Common Cause Says U.S. Agencies Are Hurt by Conflicts of Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The integrity and objectivity of decisions made by 15 Federal agencies have been seriously undermined by actual or potential conflicts of interests of hundreds of officials and consultants working for these agencies, according to a study by Common Cause.

title: Chess:
description: The fourth annual world open tournament held at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York was won by Anatoy Lein, a former Russian grandmaster who has emigrated to the United States, and Bernard Zuckerman of New York, an international master.

title: Life on a Treadmill: Financing College for Several Children
description: A New Orleans rabbi pondered the bill for college tuition on his desk and said, My life savings are being tragically depleted and there's no relief in sight. I've had to draw on savings that I thought I'd be able to use for my retirement. I'm feeling pulverized, and each year it gets rougher.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Bond in Boycott Case Is Cut to $110,000 to Allow Appeal
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People won an important legal victory yesterday when Federal judge in Mississippi granted the organization a preliminary injunction against enforcement of an $1.25 million award against it and others for an alleged illegal boycott of white merchants in Port Gibson, Miss., in the late 1960's.

title: U.S. MILITARY STILL USING THAI BASE FOR REFUELING
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 20The United States military continues to use a former American military base in Thailand as a refueling stop for its reconnaissance planes, American officials said today.

title: In Secret, in Public
description: Following are excerpts from the forthcoming book Familiar Faces, Hidden Lives, by Dr. Howard J. Brown, Health: Services Administrator during Mayor John V. Lindsay's administration, who died at the age of 50 in 1975. He was a founder of the National Gay Task Force.

title: 4,000 THAIS ARRESTED SINCE MILITARY COUP
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 20 Thailand's military rulers disclosed today that more than 4,000 people had been arrested since the coup of Oct. 6 on suspicion of being Communist subversives. Nearly twothirds of them are still in custody, a spokesman for the junta said.

title: Three Are Suspected in Slayings of Five in Teaneck
description: TEANECK, Oct. 20 The New York City Police Department says it has three definite suspects in the slayings last December of the wife and four children of Wesley Diggs in this Bergen County community, but local investigators are less convinced.

title: Rangers Beaten by Kings, 42
description: Under the National Hockey League's rules, a fiveminute penalty to Greg Polls, who fought with Dave Schultz, led to the critical goal for Los Angeles as the Kings beat the New York Rangers, 42, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Defender of Health Care for Poor
description: In the darkpaneled office at 125 Worth Street that is his as president of the New iork City Health and Hospitals Corporation, Dr. John Lawrence Sullivan Holloman Jr. has put up on the walls quotations from John F. Kennedv and the Rev. Dr. Merin Luther King Jr. But the saying that is most prominent in Dr. Holloman's office is on his desk, embossed on the back uesk, embossed on the back of his nameplate. it says: Health Care Is Right.

title: Music: Boston Symphony Takes on Onegin
description: Giving concert versions of operas has been the in thing for visiting symphony orchestras ever since the famous Rheingold of Sir Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony some years back. it is the Boston Symphony's turn this season. Seiji Ozawa, last night in Carnegie Hall, took on no less than Tchaikovsky's Eugen Onegin in its entirety, sung in Russian, with a cast headed by Galina Vishnevskaya who, at least linguistically, should be the ideal Tatiana.

title: Rochester Papers Back Ford
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 20 (UPI)Calling it a difficult choice, the Gannett Rochester TimesUnion and The Democrat & Chronicle endorsed President Ford today over Jimmy Carter. The morning Democrat & Chronicle also endorsed Daniel P. Moynihan over James L. Buckley in the New York Senate race. The endorsements were determined by an editorial board serving both newspapers.

title: Goodyear and Goodrich Report Losses After Rubber Workers Strike
description: The fourmonth rubber workers strike that began April 21 against most domestic tire plants of the big four rubber producers reduced sales and wiped out profits.

title: Meadowlands
description: Meadowlands

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, Oct. 20, 1976

title: Barrier to Growing Old Gracefully: Crime
description: The old people, crowded into the bright yellow and white dining room of the oldage center on the Lower East Side yesterday, seemed not to notice its cheeriness nor the homey smell of roasting chicken being prepared for lunch.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on question of Comorian island of Mayotte.

title: Aid for 18 Pennsylvania Areas
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) Eighteen counties in Pennsylvania were declared eligible for Federal disaster funds today as a result of storms and flooding in the state on Oct. S. The counties are Adams. Bradford, Columbia, Cumberland, Dauphin, Franklin, Lackawanna, Lancaster, Lebanon Luzerne, Mifflin, Perry, Schuylkill, Snyder, Susquehanna, Wayne, Wyoming and York. A spokesman for the Federal Disaster Assistance Administration said disaster assistance centers would, be set up in the affect arras.

title: Chinese Campaign Against 4 Reaches Streets of Capital
description: PEKING, Thursday, Oct. 21 (Reuters)Tic campaign against Mao Tsetung's widow, Chiang Ching, spilled onto the streets of Peking today with thousands of demonstrators demanding her downfall.

title: 2 Killed in Chemical Tank
description: CARTERET, N.J., Oct. 20 (UPI)Two men found dead at the bottom of a chemical tank apparently asphyxiated accidentally, authorities said today. James Winesky, 24 years old and Steven Farrell, 19, both of Carteret, were found inside the 10,000gallon tank Tuesday by a foreman making a routine check at the Amsco Division of the Union Oil Company. The police said the tank contained residue of tolvene, a glue additive that creates euphoric feeling when inhaled. The police theorized the men might have climbed into the tank to inhale the fumes.

title: A Sparse Case On Cunningham Found by Judge
description: Justice Leonard H. Sandler of State Supreme Court indicated yesterday that he would dismiss one indictment against Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx County Democratic chairman, and added that he had found the evidence to be extremely sparse in two other indictments against him.

title: Article 5  No Title
2 Accused of Adirondack Arson
description: RAY BROOK, N.Y., Oct 20 (AP)The state police have charged two Franklin County men with breaking into the Adirondack Park Agency headquarters here and attempting to set it afire. The breakin was interrupted by an agency employee. A spokesman said gasoline had been spilled all over the place. Charged with attempted arson and assault were Brian Gale, 25 years old, of Tupper Lake, and Jonathan F. Barnes, 19, of Tupper Lake and New York City.

title: Surgery Study Aims Criticism At Nonsurgeons
description: A Harvard University report on surgical practices in four parts of the country contends that far too many doctors who are not surgical specialists are performing operations while the nation's most qualified surgeons are not busy enough.

title: New York State Insurers Reluctant To Write New Automobile Policies
description: Some of the largest auto insurers have stopped writing policies in New York State, and others are now accepting only a small fraction of applicants despite higher rates that state officials approved to encourage the companies to take on new business.

title: Career of Beagle Fancier A Success Since Age of 7
description: At the age of 7, a little girl with a nearSheltie made her debut at show in St. Petersburg, Fla. She swept the boards, taking three first placeshest trick dog, best groomed and the most wellinformed owner. That was my start, said Michelle Leathers Billings, and it's pretty hard to top it. I guess dogs always have played a part in my life. My father had Eng(kit springers, foxhounds and beagles. When I started seriously, it was with German shepherds in the early 1950's and I finished two or three.

title: Chess:
description: The fourth annual world open tournament held at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York was won by Anatoy Lein, a former Russian grandmaster who has emigrated to the United States, and Bernard Zuckerman of New York, an international master.

title: People and Business
description: Dr. Armand Hammer, the 78yearold chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, was received in Moscow by Party Leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported yesterday.

title: Celanese Unit Lifts Yarn Prices; Magma Cuts Levels on Cathodes
description: The price of all arnel triacetate filament yarns has been raised 5 cents a pound, effective Nov. 1, by the Celanese Fibers Marketing Company, a unit of the Celanese Corporation. The yarns are used primarily in tricot knit velours, suedes and print base fabrications as well as in woven fabrics such as pongees and crepes.

title: TAXEXEMPT BATES HOLDING SHARP GAIN
description: Interest rates on taxexempt bonds continued this week's sharp upward move yesterday, reflecting the large volume of new issues for sale to investors, the credit market's revised view of the Federal Reserve's aim for the reduction of shortterm interest rates and news that the housing industry showed some pickup last month. By yesterday afternoon, interest rates on state and city bonds were as much as 15 basis points higher than they were at the end of last week.

title: President and Carter Grow More Alike as Nov. 2 Nears
description: MIAMI, Fla, Oct. 19  A few days ago as President Ford's whistle stop campaign train pulled out of a station in southern Illinois, the disembodied voice of the President came through loudspeakers in the passenger cars as Mr. Ford spoke and waved to bystanders from his open observation platform.

title: 83 Policemen Slain in 9 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today that 83 state and local law enforcement officers were killed by criminal action in the first nine months of this year, as against 95 deaths in the same period in 1975. There were seven deaths last month, and 10 for the same month last year, the bureau said.

title: E.P.A. Study Warns Of Kepone in Seafood
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)  Seafood contaminated by an accumulation of the pesticide Kepone could, if eaten, pose a threat to human health, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: Chile Acts to Reject U.S. Assistance
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Chile, angered over limits on its aid imposed by Congress, formally notified Washington today that it did not want to receive any economic assistance from the United States.

title: Washington & Business: Redlining Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20When the Home Loan Mortgage Disclosure Act of 1975 was signed last year, Gale Cincotta let out a resounding whoop.

title: Article 7  No Title
Nation's First AllBlack City Facing a Fiscal Collapse
description: EATONVILLE, Fla.Fleeing postCivil War oppression and searching for jobs, a number of black families settled in this area and, in 1887, founded this municipality as the nation's first allblack incorporated city.

title: U.S., in Shift, Gives Agency Permit To Go Ahead With a School Census
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Ford Administration changed course today and decided to allow the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to go ahead with a survey of school systems to determine the composition of schools by race, sex and other factors.

title: Big Flood of Mail Registrations Is Swamping Board of Elections
description: Because of heavy mail registration, the city's Board of Elections is under the most severe pressure in its history to get its records in order for the Nov. 2 election.

title: Six Student Equestrians Avance in Leaps and Bounds Toward the National Horse Show
description: PITTSTOWN, N. J.George Morris, a slim, sternfaced man swathed in riding clothes from hat to boot, stood with West Point erectness in a pasture here the other day and watched six young equestrians jump their horses over fences.

title: F.P.C. Cuts Gas Price Rise 25%; Admits an Error in July Estimates
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 In an action that is expected to save consumers $500 m;Ilion a year, the Federal Power Commission today reduced the size of an increase in natural gas prices by 25 percent.

title: Osborn Elliott, Sworn in as the Deputy Mayor for Economic Affairs, Pledges a Crusade for,Jobs
description: New York still is a helluva town, said Osborn Elliott as he was sworn in yesterday as the city's first Deputy Mayor for Economic Development and pledged a crusade for jobs.

title: Erving's Sale to 76ers is Likely; Celtics Trade Silas, Get Rowe
description: The status of Julius Erving appeared to be resolved yesterday. His sale to the Philadelphia 76ers needed only the signature of Roy Boe, the president of the New York Nets, and Bob Carlson, the team's lawyer, both of whom met into the early hours this morning with 7Ger lawyers in an effort to complete the deal. At the same time, Erving met with another group of lawyers to sign a sixyear contract worth $3.5 million.

title: U.S. Farm Exports Set Record
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI)Agricuitural exports by the United States reached a record $22.1 billion during the fiscal year, including a sharp increase to the Soviet Union, the Agriculture Department reported today. The ment said shipments to the Soviet Union reached a record $1.9 billionfour times the fiscal 1975 levelmaking the Soviet Union the second largest purchaser or American agricultural products. Japan was first.

title: Prices of Cocoa Futures Rise Again to New Highs; Sugar Off to Contract Low
description: Cocoa futures climbed to a record price yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, topping the previous high set on Tuesday.

title: Sports Today
description: World Series, fourth game, Yankees vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8:30 P.M. (TelevisionChannels 4 and 11, 8:15 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, WCBSA.M., 8:15 P.M.)

title: Article 6  No Title
description: A GOOD DAY FOR UMBRELLA VENDORS, as this activity on the corner of 86th Street and Broadway yesterday attests, was an idle day for the Reds and Yanks.

title: New York City Criticized For Awarding Contracts Without State's Approval
description: The chief state auditor of New York City's financial affairs asserted yesterday that the city had been violating the intent of New York State laws forbidding the city from awarding contracts without prior approval from the Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: Meteorites Found on Antarctic Ice Offer Science New Clues to Study
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 20Within a radius of a few miles in Antarctica, Japanese scientists have found, spread across the ice, more than 1,000 meteorites of diverse types, The discovery is believed to be without precedent and the Japanese say no ready explanation is known.

title: Chemical Companies Lift Profit For Quarter, but Dow Shows Dip
description: Major chemical companies yesterday reported increases in thirdquarter earnings. But the Dow Chemical Company ran against the trend and posted a decline of 22.4 percent in the third quarter.

title: Ballet: Splendid Calder Tribute
description: Times change in 1935 and 1936, when Martha Graham invited Alexander Calder to collaborate with her on two dance pieces, the strange hanging deices that the sculptor created and oiled mobiles were so unfamiliar and puzzling that they were deemed a distraction from the dancing.

title: Staid Law Journal Unbends a Bit
description: NEWARK, Oct. 20 Does the legal profession have a sense of humor? There are mixed opinions on that following solicitation for advertising sent out by the staid New Jersey Law Journal, now in its 98th year.

title: Thrown Stones Kill Truck Driver
description: WOODSTOCK, III., Oct. 20 (UPI)Heavy stones thrown from a speeding car smashed through the windshields of truck and two autos last night and early today, killing a truck driver and injuring two other drivers. The police mounted search for the rock throwers in this area 50 miles northwest of Chicago and appealed for information. The dead truck driver was identified as David Klawes, 26 years old, of Lawrence, Ill.

title: Richardson Says the White House Twice Overruled Him on Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  Secretary of Commerce Elliot L. Richardson said today that he had sought unsuccessfully on at least two occasions this year to get White House authorization for disclosing the names of American companies that reported they had been approached to participate in the Arab boycott against Israel.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Smyth Van Line Inc., one of the nation's largest moving companies, yesterday announced one of the first doortodoor containerized moving services.

title: Riting Inglish Real Good
description: AMBLER, Pa.  I see the hand writing on the wall. it reads, In are times the responsible writer must read the hand writing on the wall so he can asses the human conditions. It reads, The modern day literature has it's good merit's as well as it's had one's but I don't think so. it reads, Joyce was liveing symotanious to Kafka all though the did not aide each other in utilizing the same standart of excellent like stream of conscience.

title: Article 3  No Title
F.B.I,'S BREAK1N BAN REPORTED VIOLATED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Despite a written order from J. Edgar Hoover to halt illegal burglaries by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, agents of the bureau repeatedly broke into a Greenwich Village apartment in the last six months of the life of the agency's Director, according to authoritative sources familiar with those burglaries.

title: FORD AND CARTER VIE TONIGHT IN NEW YORK
description: When President Ford and his Democratic opponent, Jimmy Carter, speak at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Dinner tonight, their forum will be a sociological relic of a New York that no longer exists, but is still a political testing ground of some significance.

title: Title Fight in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (AP)Alfredo Escalera of Puerto Rico will defend his World Boxing Council junior lightweight championship in a 15round bout here Nov. 30 against unbeaten Tyrone Everett of Philadelphia.

title: Kwalik Undergoes Surgery
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 20 (AP)Ted Kwalik, who joined the Oakland Raiders as a free agent last year, will be out of action indefinitely after an emergency apendectomy on Monday. Kwalik a tight end, played six years with the San Francisco 49ers before jumping to the World Football League to begin the 1975 season.

title: Sheets  a Refreshing Change From Geometrics
description: Barbara D'Arcy, who with her flair for drama and innovation put Bloomingdale's model rooms on the map, has now turned her hand to designing bed linens.

title: Ford Vetoes 64th Bill but Signs Copyright and Railroad. Measures
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)President Ford today vetoed legislation for the 64th time, rejecting a measure under which the Government would have appraised the nation's land and water rerources and developed a plan for their use.

title: FORD SCORES CARTER OVER BOYCOTT STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  President Ford accused Jimmy Carter today of having impugned the records of four former Presidents, described the Democratic nominee as naive about diplomacy and chastised him for having consented to be interviewed by Playboy magazine.

title: Mondale Speaks in Muted Tones As Campaign Approaches an End
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20Senator Walter F. Mondale is offering audiences a bland diet of speeches in the closing weeks of the VicePresidential campaign. His adopted style has mostly muffled the voice of innovation in such areas as child care, school integration and tax reform with which he established himself in national politics.

title: Drilling Yield Oil Instead of Gas
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 20 (AP)The Southern Connecticut Gas Company, in its first attempt at drilling for natural gas, has struck oil, a company spokesman said today. A division of the company formed to explore for gas. Resource Production Inc., has brought in its first well on a tract in Ohio, but that well iv producing oil, not natural gas. The well will be productive enough to pay for it self, the company spokesman said. The oil will be sold, he added, and the money will be used for further leases and exploration for gas.

title: Forego Out for Season With Ailment in Ankle
description: Forego, who is the top candidate to become Horse of the Year for the third straight time, was sidelined for the season yesterday. A tenderness in the 6yearold gelding's right front ankle caused his owner, Martha L. Gerry, to make the decision. Trainer Frank Whiteley and I were bitterly disappointed, said Mrs. Gerry. But rather than risk further injury to Forego, we decided to retire him for the year and take comfort in reflecting upon his marvelous performances this season.

title: Composite Box of 3 Series Games
Shared Affiliation Contract Voted For Lincoln by Hospitals Board
description: Faced with a bitter dispute over whether a Jewish or a Roman Catholic institution would provide doctors and other health professioals to a major new municipal hospitalLincoln in the Bronxthe board of directors of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation voted yesterday to let both share the multimilliondollar contract.

title: 12 Undergo Appendicitis Operation For Ailment Calling for Antibiotics
description: HOLLAND PATENT, N.Y., Oct. 20 (AP) A dozen youngsters here who have had emergency appendectomies in the last three weeks did not have appendicitis at all, but a rare intestinal disease with the same symptoms, physicians reported today.

title: Morton Gets Job Back for Steeler Game
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 20 Coach Bill Arnsparger said today Craig Morton would start again at quarterback for the Giants against the Pittsburgh Steelers Sunday in the second same at their new home in New Jersey.

title: U.S. AND ISRAEL DISCUSS JOINT OUTPUT OF F16 JET
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 20Deputy Secretary of Defense William P. Clements Jr. said today that the United States and Israql were discussing a coproduction arrangement for F16 jet fighters but that the talks had not entered the stage of detailed negotiations.

title: 4th Series Game Set for Tonight; Yanks Face Same Uphill 03 Task
description: Heavy rains forced postponement of the fourth game of the World Series last night and perhaps postponed the inevitable as wellthe demise of the. Yankees in the face of the Cincinnati Reds seemingly unstoppable onslaught.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
U. of Cincinnati Undefeated And Untied,With One Loss
description: The mighty asterisk may prove to be more powerful than a good defense or a good offense in football. All team has to do is put * next to its wonlost column, and an L is converted into a W. At least that's the waythe University of Cincinnati hopes the, magical asterisk works. it is a fact that eight majorcollege fokball teams are undefeated and untied so far this season. It is known that seven of them are Rutgers, East Carolina, Maryland, Pittsburgh; Michigan, Colgate and Texas Tech. Cincinnati and Southwestern Louisiana each claim to be the eighth undefeated and untied team. But both can't get away with this claim, because they have played each other. That's where the trouble lies.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A quotation attributed to Senator. George McGovern that appeared in news analysis in The Times yesterday originated with John Chancellor of NBC News, whose remarks at a meeting in New York were cited by Senator McGovern in.a later speech. The reference was to emptiness and pettiness in the 1976 political campaign.

title: EGYPT IN NEW CHARGES AGAINST ISRAEL IN U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20Egypt requested a Security Council meeting today and accused Israel of carrying out repressive measures on the West Bank and in Gaza, including arrests and beatings of Palestinians.

title: Israeli Food Deal Dropped
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (Reuters)The, United States has backed out of a fiveyear grain deal promised to Israel by former Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz, which would have guaranteed Israel up to 300,000 tons of food grains over the next five years, United States officials said today. But State Department spokesman Frederick Z. Brown said the United States remained willing to meet Israel's food needs on an annual basis.

title: TV Covers Ford's News Session Only by Excerpts
description: President Ford's news conference yesterday afternoon was covered by television in the way the periodic news briefings of his Democratic opponent, Jimmy Carter, have been covered in excerpt form for brief summaries in evening and morning newscasts.

title: To Boost the Ratings, CBS is Reshuffling Programs
description: In a move to better its standing in the television ratings, in which it has been running third since the beginning of the season, except for the week ending Oct. 17 when it was second, CBSTV has announced a reshuffling of its Saturday and Wednesday evening programs.

title: Study Finds Independent Voter Usually Stays With One Party
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 20 (AP)Many voters who describe themselves as independent vote for the same party year after year, just as Republicans and Democrats do, a research group reported today.

title: Giants Get Crawford in a Trade With Cardinals
description: The St. Louis Cardinals traded an outfielder, Willie Crawford, to the San Francisco Giants yesterday in a sixplayer deal, the first trade since the close of the regular season.

title: Britain Renews Sanctions
description: LONDON, Oct. 20The House of Commons today renewed its annual order for economic sanctions against Rhodesia, in case next week's negotiations for majority rule fail.

title: To Safeguard the Land
description: Few Americans are aware that the Federal Government acting through the Bureau of Land Management, an agency of the Interior Department, is landlord for tens of millions of acres of public land. Although agencies such as the National Park Service and the Forest Service are much better known, the B.L.M. actually manages more sizable domain.

title: Patten's Drive to Keep House Seat Modeled After His Previous Ones
description: PERTH AMBOY, Oct. 20 One of Representative Edward J. Patten's first concerns when he returned from Washington this month to campaign for reelection in the 15th Congressional District was what he should buy for the championship Little League team that bears his name.

title: Springfield Union Endorses Ford
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 20 (AP)Saying that President Ford has served commendably in the White House, The Springfield Union endorsed him today for election to a full term.

title: Business Records
description: SHERYL RESTAURANT CORP., trading as THE BEEF BARN. Rt. 6 and 17 M., Middletown, N.Y.Liabilif es, 5510.003; assets, 5350,000. Sesretamltreaseter is Lisa Brauel.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A retired New York City narcotics detective who owns a yacht, a Florida condominium and a waterfront home in Atlantic Beach, Queens, pleaded guilty to evading more than $67,000 in Federal income taxes on unreported income of nearly $155,000 between 1972 and 1975. The defendant, Vincent W. Albano, retired from the police force in 1970 at the age of 38 with a disability pension of $8,400 a year shortly after he was the victim of a mysterious shooting outside Chez Joey, a Bronx restaurant.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 20 (UPI)The deposed King of Sikkim, unconscious for more than a day due to an apparent overdose of sleeping pills, was reported responding to treatment tonight at a nursing home in Calcutta.

title: 24 DEAD, 50 MISSING AS TANKER CAPSIZES MISSISSIPPI FERRY
description: LULING, La., Oct. 20At least 24 persons died and as many as 50 others were believed drowned when a tanker and ferry collided on the Mississippi River here today.

title: American, Braniff And T. W. A. Show Major Gains in Net
description: Three major airlinesAmerican. Braniff, and Trans Worldreported strong improvements yesterday in earnings for the third quarter, compared with figures for a year ago.

title: Stage: The Innocents Stars Claire Bloom
description: How time jets. It is now a quarter of a century since the Englishspeaking stage first saw William Archibald's play The Innocents, based, somewhat clumsily, upon Henry James's short novel The Turn of the Screw. In New York the leading role of the governess was played by Beatrice Straight, and I saw Flora Robson play it in London. A subsequent film version had Deborah Kerr.in this pivotal role of a woman who discovers two children who are possessed.

title: Police Mediator Is Asked for a Solution During a Break in Negotiations
description: After reportedly making some progress in their dispute over work schedules and deferred wages, representatives of New York City and the police officers union broke off their latest round of talks at 2:30 A.M. yesterday. They asked the mediator who has been listening to them for several days to recommend a solution.

title: The Voice of Bellow: An Excerpt
description: Charlw Citrine, sounding suspiciously like the real Saul Bellow, discusses his friend Von Humboldt Fleisher in Mr. Bellow's last novel, Humboldt's Gift:

title: The General Clarifies
description: It is deplorable that the personal services of Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld were required to police a news conference at which Gen. George S. Brown, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, clarified the illconsidered swings he had taken at a number of this country's allies and the wisdom of American military policies.

title: New Bronx Hospital To Open by Monday
description: After months of infighting over fiscal and medical questions, the State Health Department said yesterday that it would issue an operating certificate for North Central Bronx Hospital today.

title: Candidate Plunges to Death From West Side Apartment
description: Bernard Ploscowe, a Republican candidate for Congress in the 20th Congressional District, plunged to his death from a window of his eighthfloor West Side apartment yesterday afternoon. The police called the death an apparent suicide.

title: News Summary
description: A revolt by Chinese leftists was shattered by the Central Committee of the Communist Party under the leadership of Hua Kuofeng, the Chinese press agency announced. The announcement also confirmed that Mr. Hua had succeeded Mao Tsetung as chairman of the party. The report said that Mao's widow was among the leaders of the revolt. [Page A1, Column, 6.]

title: EARNINGS OF BANKS EXPECTED TO STAY AT 75 LEVEL IN 76
description: The American banking industry is recovering slowly from the economic recession, and among those who follow its fortunes the belief is now widespread that the worst is overat least for the moment.

title: Jews in Moscow Resume Visa SitIn
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 21A group of Jewish dissidents resumed their sitin at the Supreme Soviet reception office today after their leaders had what they called an unsuccessful meeting with the Minister of Internal Affairs, Gen. Nikolai A. Shchelokov. At the end of the day, they were once again.driven in buses to the outskirts of Moscow, where they were released.

title: Networks to Carry The Debate Tonight
description: Tonight's Presidential debate between President Ford and Jimmy Carter will be telecast live from Williamsburg Va., on the three networks and on the Public Broadcasting Service from 9:30. to 11, with coverage locally on Channels 2, 4, 7 and 13.

title: Lice Cause School Closing
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 21, (AP)Lice invaded the hair of so many pupils and teachers at an elementary school here that officials closed it until Monday to give it a thorough scrubbing. Half the 600 pupils enrolled at Oyler Elementary School were absent when it was closed yesterday amid demands by parents and teachers for action against the infestation.

title: About Real Estate
description: A dozen years ago Stephen Rosenberg wanted to be a theatrical director. That was before he and a few friends invested in a handful of Lower East Side tenement buildings. Ultimately he had to take over the management himself because the bills weren't getting paid.

title: Church Council Group Will Consider Charges Against Archbishop Trifa
description: A special meeting of the 49member executive committee of the policy making governing board of the National Council of Churches will be held in about 10 days to consider charges that the board harbors an alleged Nazi war criminal.

title: Advertising
description: Pickpockets aren't the only kind of people who love crowds. Marketers certainly do also. They just can't look at a crowd scene without thinking up some way to commercialize on it.

title: Amen Corner Is Victor At Penn Horse Show
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 21Amen Corner could do no better than, a secondplace finish in the stake tonight, but won the firstyear green working hunter championship by a narrow margin at the Pennsylvania National horse show.

title: Dance: Feld's First Solo Leans to the Experimental
description: THERE is an impression that the Eliot Feld Ballet, which opened Wednesday night at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Newman Theater, is run by a director who is not keen on guest artists.

title: ROBERTSON C. DAMRELL
description: Robertson C. Damrell of Plymouth Mass., a senior partner for 25 years with Hodgdon & Company, Boston investment. brokers, died Wednesday in Jordan Hospital in Plymouth. He was 69 years old.

title: Weekend Gardening: Chestnut Trees
description: The Chinese chestnut tree, Castanea mollissima, is a close relative of the American chestnut, that former monarch of the eastern forests whose spreading boughs no longer grace the landscape except in rare skeletal silhouette. The Chinese chestnut is not the majestic tree the American chestnut was before blight wasted it away nor is it suitable timber for wideboard floors. But the nut itself is by all accounts superior, being far larger and often sweeter in taste.

title: Knicks Down Lakers, 10297 In Opener
CBS SHUNS A REQUEST TO DELAY BOMB SHOW
description: CBSTV proceeded last night with a scheduled episode of Hawaii FiveO about a band of criminals who attempt to build nuclear bombs for terrorists, rejecting an appeal from the Atomic Industrial Forum to postpone the program until after the Nov. 2 elections.

title: Bridge:
description: After years of practice, even the more absentminded tournament players can generally find their way to the right table. Those who plant themselves at the right table number, but the wrong section, run the risk of being described, in a bellow from a microphone, as sectional deviates.

title: United FruitC.I.A. Link Charged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21A former executive of the United Brands Company says he was told that the organization previously known as the United Fruit Company, lent two of its freighters to the Central Intelligence Agency for use during the agency's unsuccessful attempt to invade Cuba in 1961.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An account of executive changes at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company that appeared in late editions of the Times on Wednesday was garbled. A corrected version appears on Page D12.

title: Productivity, T.A. Style
description: In the flap over transit budget shortages and a threatened fare rise, which appeared to recede yesterday, a hidden problem at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has been overlookeda deceptive misinterpretation of productivity that could further penalize the public.

title: Tennis
description: Chris Evert defeated Rosie C,asals, 61, 60; Dianne Fromholtz, Australia, defeated Billie Jean King, 62, 64; Francoise Durr, France defeated Julie Anthony, 63, 63; Virginia Wade, Britain, defeated Mona Guerrant, 76 62; Betty Stove, the Netherlands, defeated Mima Jausovec, Yugoslavia, 6.2, 62; Martina Navrafflova defeated Sue Barker, Britain, 63, 12.

title: Rap Brown, Black Power Advocate Is Paroled From a New York Prison
description: H. Rap Brown, an ardent advocate of black power during the late 1960's and for a time one of the F.B.I.'s most hunted fugitives, was paroled from an upstate New York prison yesterday, where he was serving a 5to15year sentence for robbery and assault.

title: Rohmer's MarquiseIs Talk in Action
description: Eric Rohmer's universe is curved. His theater is in toward the middle of things. The passions in his films set off outward bound at a gallop. They approach an extreme, bounce, and soon they are back, trotting the other way. The tragedy turns funny, the comedy serious. The erotic is tangled in constraintthe hand that never gets above Claire's knee, the long night of weighing possibilities at Maude's. The escapes become returns.

title: Rhodesians Report Death of 7 In Struggle Against Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 12 (UPI)The security forces headquarters said today that seven persons were killed in the last few days in the anti guerrilla conflict. A Rhodesian Air Force officer was killed during a training flight. The security headquarters said three black constables had died in action, two guerrillas had been killed by troops and a black youth had been slain by terrorist crossfire during a skirmish.

title: Restaurants
description: ONE OF THE most promising new restaurants to come to town in a long time is Le Coup de Fusil. It is a lushly romantic, pocketsize setting, with walls paneled in wood or covered with rose matelass6, floraletched glass panels mirrors reflecting frosty Laliquelike flower wall sconces and a pressedtin, Art Deco ceiling left unfinished to retain a satiny pewter glow.

title: Carter Maintains His Lead Of 6 Points in Gallup Poll With 47% to Ford's 41 %
description: A Gallup poll of 1,032 registered voters conducted last weekend found Jimmy Carter leading President Ford, 47 percent to 41 percent, the Gallup Organization reported yesterday.

title: Music: Fisher Hall Even Better on 2d Hearing
description: THE first sultcription concert of the New York Philharmonic's 1976.77 season, in the brandnew Avery Fisher Hall, took place last night and was devoted to one workthe Third Symphony by Gustav Mahler. Not even the glamour of the new auditorium was enough to overcome the handicap of a relatively unfamiliar and exceedingly long work and there were many unoccupied seats.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ROTTERDAM (Hell. Amer.). Nassau 0:t. 25; sirs 4:3)1 P.M. from W. 55th St.

title: 1633 BROADWAY BUILDING SOLD TO PRIVATE GROUP
description: The Irving Trust Company, managing partner for the four banks that foreclosed on the building at 1633 Broadway in May 1974, reported yesterday the sale of the 48story building to a group of private investors.

title: Pop Music Gerstein Sings
description: Richard Cerstein, who is performing through Sunday, at Tramp's, 125 Fast 15th Street, was born in New York City, grew up in the Caribbean, and gained some of his early experience as a professional musician in the South. His music, some of it original and some rearranged from other sources partakes of all these geographical influences and the result is a dizzyingly eclectic brew.

title: Novelist Deals With Jews in America
description: If Saul Bellow didn't exist, someone exactly like him would have had to have been invented, just after the Second World War, by New York intellectuals, in a backroom at Partisan Review. Everybody wrote esAn says and book reviews, but a novelist was needed Appraisal very special sort of novelist, a highbrow with muscles, to tell the story of the Jewish romance with America. Nathanael West was dead, Henry Roth was silent, Daniel Fuchs did screenplays, Irwin Shaw and Herman Wouk were middlebrows short stories by Delmore Schwartz and Isaac Rosenfeld were not enough, and Norman Mailer was clearly not to be trusted.

title: Connors Takes Hickok Honor
description: Jimmy Connors, the United States Open tennis champion, yesterday was named the September winner in the Hickok professional athlete of the year award competition. Connors received 33 firstplace votes and 167 points in balloting by sports writers and broadcasters. Steve Grogan, quarterback of the New England Patriots, was second and Ken Norton, beaten on a unanimous but controversial derision by heavyweight champion Muhammad Ali was third. Ali finished 10th.

title: Jazz: What's in a Label?
description: The ECM Festival of Music Wednesday night in Avery Fisher Hall should have served two functions: the showcasing of talent on the ECM avantgarde jazz label, and a further demonstration of the new Fisher Hall's attributes. For this was the first nonclassical concert in the reconstructed facility, and indeed the first concert of any kind open to the general public.

title: Strauss Predicts Vicious Attack on Carter by G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic national chairman, predicted today that the Republicans were about to begin the most vicious attack ever made at the highest level of political activity against Jimmy Carter in an attempt to destroy his character and his credibility.

title: McCullough Vies With HardDriving Florio for House Seat
description: CAMDEN, Oct. 21By knocking on 30,000 doors since April and wearing out seven pairs of shoes, Mayor Joseph I. McCullough Jr. of Haddon Heights has succeeded in making his name known throughout the First Congressional District.

title: Federal Law on Boycotts Urged
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (AP)The American Association of Port Authorities today adopted a resolution that it favored a new Federal law establishing a single uniform national policy dealing with restrictive trade practices or boycotts fostered or imposed by foreign countries.

title: SOUTHERN PACIFIC'S NET FOR QUARTER OFF 12.41%
description: The Southern Pacific Company, which operates the nation's second largest railroad after Union Pacific, reported yesterday that its earnings for the third quarter declined 12.4 percent.

title: ROBERT H.LOUGHBOROUGH
description: Robert H. Loughborough, former vice president of Johnson & Higgins, an insurance company in New York City, died Monday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 81 years old.

title: The Pennsylvania Ballet Blossoms in Brooklyn
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet, which is small as major ballet companies goit numbers only 27 dancershas nevertheless earned a widespread reputation for versatility. This weekend it hopes to prove that reputation with two programs at the Brooklyn Academy of Music where it is in its third year as resident ballet company.

title: Korvette, Citing Losses, Will Halt Its Sales of Carpets and Furniture
description: After more than 20 years, the Korvette stores, one of New York's largest retail chains, will discontinue its furniture and carpet operations as a result of deficits of more than $4 million annually for several years in those departments.

title: DICK ROMAN
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 21 (AP)Dick Roman, 38 years old, an entertainer here was found dead yesterday of an apparent heart attack. A fellow singer, Jerry Vale said he discovered the body in Mr. Roman's apartment yesterday afternoon. He said Mr. Roman was seated in front of a television set that was still on.

title: Ford Announces Layoffs of 40,000
description: DETROIT, Oct. 21The Ford Motor Company announced today the layoff of 40,000 workers at eight car plants and several manufacturing plants because of parts shortages caused by a continued strike at its Cleveland stamping plant.

title: Article 2  No Title
The Shah on Israel,Corruption Torture and.
description: Following are excerpts of a Mike Wallace interview with the Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevl, that will be seen on 60 Minutes Sunday at 7 P.M. The full transcript was made available by CBS.

title: Dole Focusing On Key Areas As Vote Nears
description: LAFAYETTE, La., Oct. 21Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican VicePresidential candidate, clambered up on the body of a flatbed truck in the chill morning air on the outskirts of Jackson, Miss. today and waited expectantly for his introduction as a shivering country band flailed at the last notes of Dixie.

title: The Most Intellectual of the Best Sellers
description: When Saul Bellow won a Pulitzer pnze this May for Humboldt's Gift, be said he was pleased, tickled amused, but he said nothing atm; being surprised. It is likely that the N4_thel Prize did not surprise him either. for Mr. Bellow is an author whose work has received careful and serious consideration from the beginning of his career. Whether the critics have liked his work or notand there have been dissentersit has been given the kind of close reading, the kind of analysis often reserved for the work of the safely great and the safely dead.

title: At the Movies
description: As DIRECTOR, I'm 41; as an actress I'm 35, said Joan Darling, an attractive, lamentably unemployed actress who is making her debut as a movie director with First Love, a romantic comedydrama about a fervent college student whose vulnerable heart is set on having an oldfashioned love affair, replete with ringing bells, moonlit embraces and vows of eternal fidelity.. The film, written by Jane Stanton Hitchcock and David Freeman, is scheduled for Paramount production this January by Lawrence Turman and David Foster.

title: Notes on People
description: Borls Onishchenko, the 38yearold viet fencer caught cheating at the Montreal Olympics last summer, has been reduced to a job as an assistant direcior of one of Kiev's municipal swimming pools. Mr. Onishchenko had used a foil rigged with a device to register a hit when none had occurred.

title: Herold C. Hunt Dies at 74; Was Harvard Professor And an ExAdministrator
description: Herold C. Hunt, a retired professor at Hardvard University and a former Under Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, died Sunday in Lexington, Mass. He was 74 years old.

title: People and Business
description: Anthony L. Conrad, who was dismissed as chairman and chief executive qfficer of the RCA Corporation on Sept. 16 after disclosing that he had failed to file personal income tax returns for five years through 1975, has resigned as director of the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company.

title: In Memoriam
description: FINESINGERSol B. Prof. Nov. 17 1900. On Friday morning, 6:30 AM September 17, 1976. Of New York City. We kept each other alive. You were so brave and so courageous after all the years of suffering. Sol you had such a peaceful, sweet smile on your dear face. I shall always pray that you are at peace at last. I am so alone I shall always miss you. You tell me to go to Heaven, you have taken me with you. Your widow Jean Finesinger.

title: FourthGame Box Score
description: ErrorsMorgan, Concepcion. Double playsYankees 1. Left on baseCincinnati 4. Yankees 9. Two base hitsRose, Chambliss, Geronimo, Concepcion. Home runsBench 2 (3) Stolen basesGeronimo, Morgan, Rivers.

title: LISBON GENERAL WARNS OF A THREAT FROM RIGHT
description: LISBON, Oct. 21The Governor of Lisbon's military region warned today that rightwing political forces were trying to destabilize Pornmal's armed forces.

title: Publishing Caldwell in MidAmerica
