(516) 6691800, CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Nets, on Coast, Sing Blues Over Sale of Erving and Their Fate in N.B.A.
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 21On the ??? from the airport last night, when ??? of Julius Erving's sale circulated among the New York Nets, Rich Jones ??? out the window and sang a little ??? of his own:

title: Music: The Fauvel Legend A Medieval Beast Allegory
description: IT might easily have been mistaken for a political satire written for the electon year iof 1976. The protagonist is an ass, a donkey whose stupidity is matched by his avarice and ambition. His progress from lowly beast of the stable to crowned king could be the evergreen legend American politics: the yokel who rises to rule the nation.

title: Transkei Approaches Nationhood Helped, and Burdened, by Its Ties to South Africa
description: UMTATA, South Africa, Oct. 19A group of black men, none of whom played a musical instrument until a few months ago, sit in the center of a rugby field working their way laboriously through John Philip Sousa's Manhattan Beach. In front of them, offering gentle exhortations, stands a South African Army bandmaster.

title: Troubled Youngsters Early Help
description: The baby doesn't smile or snuggle; the toddler withdraws within himself for long periods of time; the preschool child doesn't talk, or have the conceptual ability to use a swing or slide.

title: Day Tripping With Art Lovers
description: The bus raced along through a golden late afternoon on its way back to New York. Inside, the talk among the passengers was of Matisse, Cezanne, Soutine and Modigliani. Bunny Mautner walked up and down the narrow aisle serving cream sherry in little paper cups. Bunny's first class all the way, someone said.

title: The Dance: A Tribute to Eakins
description: Philadelphia nourished a select group of painters at the end of Lhe last century, of whom Thomas Eakins was undoubtedly the most outstanding. Ridiculed a good part of his life, he was, of course, celebrated after his death. Belatedly, but fittingly, in this selfcongratulatory year, Rodney Griffin Philadelphiahorn choreographer, created a beautiful tribute to the artist Eakins View, which has been handsomely mounted by the Pennsylvania Ballet. It was presented Thursday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An account of executive changes at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company that appeared in late editions of the Times on Wednesday was garbled. A corrected version appears on Page D12.

title: Products Are Ageless At Procter & Gamble
description: Some marketing people believe that products have life cycles. That, however, is not a popular theory at Procter & Gamble, masters of the marketing art.

title: Art People
description: THE WINDOWS at Bonwit Teller's will look a little different next week. The glamorous fantasies selling cashmere and tweed will be replaced by earthier tableaux: In one window a group of mannequins act out a tabloid crime of passion, in several others, a woman's aging process is laid bare, and still another recreates a room in disarray at the Chelsea Hotel, with a pair of televisionwatching mannequins lying in bed. There'll even be live action One window will house members of the Committee for the Future, who'll answer questions on the future for passersby; from another, a mannequin programmed to talk with people will make daily street appearances around.

title: Ford Tells of Pride In American Sweep
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP)President Ford, likening the Nobel Prize to a world Olympics in the arts and sciences, said today that Americans have swept the field in a way no other country has ever done before.

title: Art: The Fascination of Portraits
description: MODERN PORTRAITS The Self & Others is the title of a splendid unexpected exhibition that has just opened at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East 64th Street, as a benefit for the Graduate Research Fund of Columbia University's Department of Art History and Archeology which was responsible for its organization and conception.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor On Sept. 26, The Times ran an article by Robert Reinhold indicating that scarcely half of the American voters are expected to go to the polls on Nov. 2. As Mr. Reinhold indicated one of the explanations now in vogue for this low turnout is that after Vietnam, Watergate and other political rot, the American voter is disenchanted, alienated and uncertain that voting makes a difference. I think that this explanation needs elaboration.

title: Dollar Eases Against the Pound
description: LONDON, Oct. 21 (AP)The dollar had a mixed day on European exchange markets today, easing against the troubled British pound and Italian lira. The price of gold rose on main bullion markets.

title: Antiques
description: AMERICAN COLLECTORS of musical instruments have complained for years that to buy or sell at auction the fine period strings, winds, keyboards or brasses they covet, they must do at or through London galleries. Now the practice is changingdramatically.

title: Lynch Is Identified as Owner of Car Where Bronfman Ransom Was Put
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 21Mel Patrick Lynch, one of the two defendants in the Bronfman kidnapping frial here, was identified by the prosecution today as the owner of the car in which a $2.3 million ransom had been placed after the alleged abduction last year of Samuel Bronfman 2d, the 21yearold heir to the Seagram liquor fortune.

title: Car Cannibals of Queens: A Continuing Drama
description: On a quiet street in Corona. Queens, the removal of a parked automobile yesterday brought to an end another vignette in a continuing street drama.

title: Two Purchase Students Are Raped
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 21Two State University students were raped this week in a wave of sexual assaults in Westchester County that also included attacks ona 10yearold girl and a Tarrytown housewife.

title: Promoters Plan Flying Nightclub With Dancing, Maybe Gambling
description: Gambling on an apparent legal vacuum in the skies, two New York travel promoters have announced plans for a flying nightclubperhaps with card games and rouletteaboard a chartered plane circling over the Atlantic off Kennedy International Airport.

title: Shah Assails Palestinian Terrorism
description: Shan Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran has rebuked our good Palestinian friends for trying to bully the world by ??rrorism and blackmail.

title: YankeesReds Scoring
description: FIRST INNING

title: Deaths
description: ABELESMinerva L. Widow of Judge Peter Abeles. Dear mother of Audrey Gerstenhaher, Lowell Abeles, Rodman Abeles and Arynne Simon and the late Sheldon. Darling grandmother and greatgrandmother. Services Sunday, 12 noon. The Riverside 76 St. Amsterdam Ave.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Acne is a malevolent disease that scarboth physically and emotionallythe waning years of childhood. Yet it is often trivialized. Adults manage to screen off the pain of their own teenage years, so that the selfdisdain that was rampant then emerges now only as a certain repugnance associated with the word, acne, and occasional scornful references to pimplefaced kids. But to be of any assistance to children with acne a parent has to be both understanding of how disturbing the disease can be and it's also helpful to be aware of new thinking that debunks a lot of the old myths about such things as diet and facewashing.

title: Hunt Continues for Dead in Mississippi Ferry Crash
description: DESTREHAN, La., Oct. 21It had the look of some bizarre water show, two big workboats with derricks and cables moving slowly up and down, up and down. But the spectators on the banks watched with a grim interest that had nothing to do with entertainment.

title: Meadowlands Results
Poll of Students at 5 Universities Finds Carter Ahead, 54% to 36%
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 21 (AP)A poll by campus newspapers at Yale, Harvard Princeton, the University of Pennsylvania and Rutgers shows Jimmy Carter leading President Ford among those students surveyed.

title: Padres Proceed With Increase
description: SAN DIEGO. Oct. 21 (AP)  In September the San Diego Padres threatened to raise ticket prices unless the baseball club was allowed to stretch out the repayment of a $2 million loan by the city. The Council refused and so today the Padres announced a 25cent raise in prices.

title: PENTAGON EXPLAINS BAN ON PROISRAELI ARTICLE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Defense Department said today that it had blocked publication of an article stressing a strong strategic relationship between the United States and Israel because was feared it might be construed as representing United States Government policy.

title: Roosevelt
description: RESULTS

title: ROYAL INDUSTRIES TARGET OF OFFER
description: Monogram Industries said yesterday that it intended to make a $35.2 million tender offer for 3.2 million shares of Royal Industries common stock at $11 a share.

title: Horse Shows
description: THE CHIEF AWARDS AmateurOwner Working Hunters, Morning ClassAnne Devereux's Menotti. Regular Working HuntersMr. and Mrs. Robert E. Brunder's Circuit Breaker. First Year Green Working Hunter StakeKim Hells's in the Black.

title: Benjamin Gross Is Dead; Engineer and Inventor, 83 Headed Capehart Concern
description: Benjamin Gross, an erectrical engineer and inventor, died at his Manhattan home yesterday. He was 83 years old and lived at 50 East 77th Street.

title: Meadowlands
Department Store Sales Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.33 billion, up 16 percent from the yearearlier $1.141 billion. Total retail store sales were about $12.55 billion, up 9 percent from last year's $11.5 billion.

title: The City Opera Comes Back Singing
description: Somewhat bloodied but still full of vitality, the New York City Opera will resume its full schedule this weekend at the New York State Theater with two new productions.

title: Erving Trade Is Official; Nets Fans Complaining
description: After 19 hours of continuous negot ??? tions that ended at 3 P.M. yesterday the trade of Julius Erving by the New York Nets to the Philadelphia 76ers became official. The immediate ??? ??? berations were:

title: Students Boycotting Canarsie High
description: About half the 3,300student population at Canarsie High School in Brooklyn boycotted classes yesterday to emphasize demands for more effective security and safety measures.

title: Consumer Price Index Rose 0.6% in September In New York City Area
description: Higher prices for clothing and auto liability insurance pushed the Consumer Price Index for the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey region up sixtenths of 1 percent in September.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: The last Presidential debate starts Friday night at 9:30 on ABC, CBS, NBC and PBS. Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter will face the press, if not each other, at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va. The moderator will be Barbara Walters of ABC News. The questioners will be Jack Nelson of The Los Angeles Times, Robert C. Maynard of The Washington Post and Joseph Kraft, a syndicated columnist.

title: EARNINGS FOR ALCOA CLIMBED IN QUARTER
description: The Aluminum Company of America reported yesterday a sharp gain in thirdquarter earnings, reflecting the turnaround from last year's recession.

title: More Moderate Policies Indicated for China in the Wake of Antileftist Campaign
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 21With the emergence of Hua Kuofeng as China's new leader and the downfall of the socalled leftists, China has undergone its most important political changes since the Cultural Revolution of the 1960's. Ultimately the events of the last six weeks, since Mao Tsetung died on Sept. 9, may prove to be the most significant since the Cornmunists came to power in 1949.

title: Ad Showing Ford With Three Blacks To Be Withdrawn
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  President Ford's campaign organization agreed today to discontinue using in newspapers with largely black readership, advertisements showing a twoyearold photograph of the President with Vernon Jordan, the executive director of the National Urban League, and other black leaders.

title: Candidates for Senate Reported to Have Spent $23.4 Million, a Record
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP)Candidates running for the United States Senate have already spent a record $23.4 million in their campaigns, a study released today by Common Cause disclosed.

title: How to Get There
description: To reach the PAF Playhouse, take the Long Island Expressway to Route 110 (Exit 49), north to Second Street in Huntington Station and turn right. The playhouse is at the end of the street, just before the railroad underpass, at No. 185.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP; REAL WAGES DECLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The rise in consumer prices slowed slightly in September but the typical worker continued to lose real purchasing power, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Colbert Shoots 67 and Leads Southern Open by a Stroke
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Oct. 21 (AP)Jim Colbert struggled through swirling winds and biting cold to a threeunderpar 67 and a onestroke lead today in the first round of the $125,000 Southern open.

title: F. T. C. Tells Sears To Change Practice In Appliance Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Federal Trade Commission today ordered Sears Roebuck & Company, the world's largest retailer, to stop using bait and switch tactics in selling its millions of major home appliances each year.

title: CHINA REPORTS PLOT BY 4 TO SEIZE POWER SHATTERED BY HUA
description: HONG KONG, Friday, Oct. 22China announced today that the Central Committee under the leadership of Hua Kuofeng had shattered an attempt by four senior leftists, including Mao Tsetung's widow, Chiang Ching, to usurp party and state power.

title: SHARP DROP SHOWN BY GLAMOUR STOCKS; DOW OFF 9.97 POINTS
description: Glamour stocks fell sharply yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged nearly 10 points after registering small advances in the four previous sessions.

title: Mr. McCarthy defeated Robert F.
description: PORTLAND. Ore., Oct.. 21 (UPI)??? through the state that gave him a primacy triumph in his unsuccessful 1968 bid for the White House, Eugene J. McCarthy yesterday compared himself to another political maverick the late Wayne Morse.

title: Market Place
description: The Class B voting shares of Resorts International, have almost doubled in the last week or so, and Wall Street is baffled.

title: Swedes Convinced North Korea Directed Smuggling
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 21A smuggling operation organized by North Korean diplomats in Scandinavia was directed from the North Korean capital of Pyongyang informed Swedish sources believe.

title: CHINA REPORTS PLOT BY 4 TO SEIZE POWER SHATTERED BY HUA
description: HONG KONG, Friday, Oct. 22China announced today that the Central Committee under the leadership of HuaKuofeng had shattered an attempt by four senior leftists, including Mao Tsetung's widow, Chiang Ching, to usurp party and state Power.

title: Broadway
description: ANEW COMEDY by Ira I ewis called The Sponsor, which will be directed and produced by Jack Garfein, is supposed to come to Broadway early next year after trying out in California. More and more plays are trying out there, and now Westwood, Calif., will do for The Sponsors what New Haven might have done for it in the past. The Sponsors will run six weeks at the Westwood Playhouse, starting Nov. 24, and star Joseph Wiseman and Michael Strong. Mr. Wiseman was on Broadway last season in Elie Wiesel's Zalman, or the Madness of God, while Mr. Strong was most recently out touring with Arthur Miller's The Price. Mr. Garfein has been for years in Hollywood, but when he was here he directed End as a Man, and then the Broadway production of Sean O'Ca.sey's Shadow of a Gunman.

title: Sports Complex Gives Its Neighbors Free Tickets to the Rutgers Game
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, Oct. 21The mauimai arrived at each home here the other day with a surprise from the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authoritytwo free tickets to the ColumbiaRutgers football game Saturday at Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands.

title: Upsets Mark Tennis Play On Coast
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 22Chris Evert reached the semifinal round of the $200,000 Colgate Inaugural last night, but in a series of cataclysmic upsets Martina Navratilova was drubbed by Francoise Our; Dianne Fromholtz was wiped out by Terry Holladay and it took Virginia Wade 2 hours 20 minutes to survive against Betty Stove in a threeset thriller that kept the crowd until long after midnight.

title: FORD AND CARTER, IN LAST DEBATE, PROMISE TO PUT STRESS ON ISSUES
description: President Ford and Jimmy carter concluded their historic series of nationally televised debates last night by promising to stress issues rather than personalities in the final days of the campaign in the hope of awakening widespread interest among disillusioned voters.

title: White Plains Battles Over Which House Was Washington's Headquarters
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 22The second Battle of White Plains, a contemporary engagement over the identity of Washington's headquarters during the original battle two hundred years ago, appeared to have been won today by the Town of North Castle and the Daughters of the American Revolution.

title: U.S, TAX REVISION HURTING AMERICANS EMPLOYED ABROAD
description: PARIS, Oct.22The taxrevision bill of 1976, which President Ford signed Oct. 4, is squeezing 100,000 Americans who work abroad by putting a bigger bite on, their income, and most don't like it very much.

title: About New York
description: Norman Kramer Ffires in live television without a hotcomb.

title: Alternatives to Abortion
description: SAN MARINO, Calif.The abortion issue has reached ridiculous prominence in this Presidential campaign. It is a natural human characteristic of Americans, and other nationalities and religions, to abhor abortion as inhumane, but concern over a constitutional amendment skirts three far more serious national and world problems. America's rise in teenage pregnancy, its lack of teenage education and access to contraceptives, and the most serious problem of all, world population growth that exacerbates every other national and world concern now and for many years to come.

title: Darling Directs City Opera's Dutchman
NEW ORDERS SHOW DIP FOR 3D MONTH IN DURABLE GOODS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP)  New orders received by manufacturers of durable goods, a key indicator of consumer and business spending, declined for the third consecutive month during September, the Government renorted today.

title: U.S. Soccer Team Defeated, 20
description: Huracan of Argentina defeated the United States National Team, 20, in a soccer match last night at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island. The Americans had qualified for World Cup play by defeaing Canada, 20, this week in Seattle.

title: Nancy List is Married To Richard H. Block
description: Nancy List, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin List, was married here yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents to Richard Harris Block, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Lester Block of Princeton and Loveladies, N.J. Rabbi Avraham Soltes, Jewish chaplain at the United States Military Academy performed the ceremony.

title: Yanks Are Haunted By a Big Red Sweep
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 22 (AP)The scene was the same as last year's. The crowd was about the same size and they were cheering for the same heroes.

title: OPEN MARKET UNIT SEEKS A RATE ON FUNDS AT 5%
description: The 12man Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve System decided at its Sept. 21 meeting that it should continue to aim for an average weekly Federal funds rate of 5 percent until its Oct. 19 meeting, the minutes of an earlier gathering disclosed yesterday.

title: New Freedom for the Spaniards: Surreal Politics and Anxieties
description: Madrid, Oct. 21Spaniards sometimes talk about their country as if it were some great, newly unchained and unpredictable beast, capable of terrible things in the cafes and political salons of this charming, smokey, congested city, there is a considerable amount of intellectual agonizing over of the chances of the two Madrid Spains  one privileged, one poor, both given to violencegoing at it again as the restraining fetters of the Franco state wither away.

title: Alejandro Rodriguez de Valcarcel Dies at 59
description: MADRID, Oct. 22 (Reuters)Alejandro Rodriguez de Valcrcel, who swore in King Juan Carlos after heading the threeman Regency Council that took power after Generalissimo Francisco Franco's death last November, died here today. He was 59.

title: Windhoek Panel Agrees on Charter
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Oct. 22 (Reuters)Black and white delegates agreed here today to draw up a draft constitution for an interim government in SouthWest Africa within the next few months.

title: MICHIGAN CAMPAIGN BECOMING VOLATILE
description: DETROIT, Oct. 22Sex and alleged dirty tricks have become the foremost issues in a bareknuckled campaign for a United States Senate seat in Michigana state long known for its relatively civilized, seriousminded politics.

title: NEW YORK'S SCHOOLS FOND IN CONTEMPT
description: The Board of Education and the School Chancellor of New York City were ruled in contempt of court yesterday for having failed steadily and repeatedly to exercise their power to expedite a bilingual education program for Spanishspeaking Students.

title: Spurs Beat Philadelphia In Opener, 121118
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29Let it be everywhere recorded that the time was 8:04 tonight when the Spectrum went dark in anticipation of the dawn of a new era in Philadelphia basketball. The only lights were on the overhead message board, and they spelled: Is There a Doctor in the House?

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Ranchers Exploration and Development Corporation announced yesterday it would seek to recover soluble uranium remaining in residue from previous uranium milling operations in Colorado.

title: IRISH LEADER QUITS OVER I.R.A.
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 22  The President of Ireland resigned today, four days after the Defense Minister called him a thundering disgrace for questioning the constitutionality of emergency legislation designed to stop the activities of Irish Republican Army guerrillas.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR, on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station.

title: But is it Really Yogurt?
description: Is frozen yogurt really just yogurt that has been frozen? a friend who is a devotee of that latest food craze asked recently.

title: Buckley, in Albany and New York, Asks 4 Ethnic Groups to Back Him
description: Senator James L. Buckley wooed blacks and voters of Chinese, Italian and Polish descent yesterday, appealing to each ethnic group's sense of pride in its heritage and attacking the biggovernment programs supported by his opponent.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne said in Tokyo that he had invited Japan's two top automobile manufacturers to open assembly plants in New Jersey. The Governor, who went to Japan with Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said he had outlined advantages of opening plants in New Jersey to the Toyota and Nissan motor companies. He spid he would make informal offers to other Japanese car manufacturers, including Honda Motor Company. Mr. Byrne said the locations offered the Japanese companies were in the port district in the vicinity of Elizabeth, Newark and Jersey City all 25 miles from the Statue of Liberty.

title: Congress: The Region
description: Continuing its comment on Congressional elections, The Times limits itself today, apart from the two Senatorial races to those House contests in New Jersey and Connecticut that fall within the metropolitan regionthat is, the northern half of New Jersey and Fairfield County in Connecticut.

title: Europe's Currency Move
description: The upward revaluation of the West German mark reflects an effort to keep a dream alive, the dream of a United States of Europe.

title: Crowds of Antileftists in Peking Hail the ownfall of Mao's Widow
description: HONG KONG. Oct. 22Hundreds of thousands of Chinese paraded througt Peking for a second day today to denounce the antiparty clique of four senior leftists, following the announcement in the official press this morning that the group had been shattered.

title: TROY BEGINS SERVING 60DAY PRISON TERM
description: A somber Matthew J. Troy Jr. walked into the Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn yesterday to start serving a 60day jail term for a tax violation.

title: ItalianAmerican Disenchantment With Candidates Bodes Ill for Carter and Democrats in Connecticut
description: WATERBURY, Conn, Oct. 21If anybody should be voting Democratic this year, it's Amato Mange NuzzoSteve to friends.

title: Nirvana Wins Jump Title At Pennsylvania Show
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 22Mrs. Sieta Platten's Nirvana, one of the mainstays of the division all season, came on with a rush in the last class and captured the amateurowner jumper championship tonight at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

title: Personal Finance: Banks, Gifts and Interest
description: When the Dime savings Bank of New York and the Brooklyn Savings Bank opened new branch offices last weekthe one at 56th Street and Madison Avenue, the other at 2030 Northern Boulevard in Manhasset, L.I.there was the usual promotional hoopla.

title: Priest Slain in Louisiana
description: HOMER, La., Oct. 22 (UPI)A Roman Catholic priest who expressed fear of serious violence at his vandalismplagued North Louisiana church was shot fatally at the rectory door, the authorities said today. The Rev. Theodore Lelieveld, 50 years old, was shot twice at about 10 A.M. yesterday, Claibotne Parish authorities said. He died on the way to a Shreveport hospital.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TODAY, OCT, 23

title: Pullman Payouts Abroad Widened
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22The accounting firm of Arthur Young & Company transmitted money to a foreign tax official on behalf of Pullman Inc., one of its clients, according to a Pullman filing made available today at the Securities and Exchange Commission. This is believed to be the first instance to come to light in which an accountant aided a company making questionable foreign Payments.

title: Michael Barkway is Dead at 65; Leading Canadian Financial Editor
description: TORONTO, Oct. 22 (AP)  Michael Barkway, former editor and publisher of The Financial Times of Canada, died of a heart attack today. He was 65 years old.

title: After the Riyadh Talks, Foes and Friends Exchange Roles
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 22  Lebanon and the Middle East scene this week were like a kaleidoscope that had been given a sudden jolt. Abruptly, all the shapes and colors have changed. it would be wrong to say that there has been reversal of alliances. But clearly the Riyadh conference of Arab leaders has brought a new alignment of forces in the area. Syria and Egypt, which had been at odds since the second Sinai agreement 14 months ago, are moving toward an accommodation. The Syrians and the Palestinians, whose regular armed forces fought a pitched battle a few days ago, are trying to rekindle their natural alliance.

title: I.R.S. Must Tell Taxpayer It Wants Bank Records
description: Though the new amendments to the income tax law make it harder to use some traditional tax shelters, they also make it harder for the Internal Revenue Service to get access to a taxpayer's hank records. According to a study of the new law by the American. Civil Liberties Union, the I.R.S. must now notify a taxpayer that it wants a look at his hank records and must give him 14 days to challenge the request in court.

title: Psychiatric Clinic on Upper West Side Stirs a Furor
description: The small, smokefilled lobby of the Stevens Psychiatric Clinic at 520 Amsterdam Avenue is almost always packed with patients.

title: Around the Nation
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 22 (AP)Edward Gullion, one of two men sought in connection with a series of terrorist bombings, was arrested here today less than one day after the apprehension of his partner on'the F.B.I.'s 10 most wanted list.

title: Employees at Key Ford Plant Give Approval to New Contract
description: DETROIT, Oct. 22 (UPI)The 3,700 Ford Motor Company workers at the ratified a new local contract today, ending the threat that the automaker would have to halt assembly line operations because of parts shortages.

title: Aid for Divorced Catholics Urged
description: DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 22Delegates to a historic Call to Action of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States today urged the hierarchy to promote greater support and spiritual service to Catholics who are separated, divorced and remarried.

title: King of Thailand Gives Approval To New RightistMilitary Regime
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 22King Phumiphol Aduldet approved today a 17member civilian Government dominated by the rightwing and military and a new Constitution with no specific guarantees of civil or human rights.

title: Books of the Times
description: In the last couple of years the American women's movement has shifted its attention from liberation to workingclass women out of a realization, no doubt, that the earlier feminism was bounded by the professional and middleclass concerns out of which it was born. These concerns not only produced the powerful The Feminine Mystique, but they also led women to ponder their special historical experience.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SIP TRIP A program featuring Johann Sebastian Bach's Coffee Cantata aptly opens the second season of Lincoln Center's informal Coffee Concert Series this afternoon at 4 o'clock, as Richard Capp conducts the Philharmonia Virtuosi of New York and soloists in an hourlong session without intermission. Then the musicians will mingle with the audience over coffee and doughnuts, a popular innovation last year at Mice Tully Hall covered by the $4 admission. Tickets are available at the hall's box office.

title: LILIAN MURTAGH, 69, DEAD; AIDED CONCERT ORGANISTS
description: Lilian Murtagh, a manager of American and European concert organists for many years, died yesterday at her home in Canaan, Conn. She was 69 years old.

title: MilitaryIndustrial Complexes
description: PARISMuch as in the United States although on a smaller scale, France's militaryindustrial complex has simultaneously become a political football and deeply involved in a scandal that could produce a kind of French variety of the Watergate and Lockheed affairs.

title: Kunstler Decries Vote For a Frown or Clown
description: NEW BRUNSWICK N.J. (UPI)William M. Kunstler told 750 students at Rutgers University last night that voting in the Presidential eelction this year would be like voting for a frown or a clown.

title: Diebold Venture Chairman Quits Before Special Meeting Convenes
description: The Diebold Venture Capital Corporation, a closedend investment corporation, announced yesterday just before a special meeting of stockholders was convened that John Diebold, the computer consultant and venture capitalist who founded the company in 1968, had resigned as chairman.

title: Feld Troupe Dances At Midnight
description: Eliot Feld had a promising career with American Ballet Theater some years ago until he decided to have a mere promising one by creating h's own company. The urge has subsequently become something of a habit with young dancers from that company. His company still has an artistic relationship to Ballet Theater; it also has a couple of its former dancers and two of the ballets that Mr. Feld created there. He presented the second of these, the haunting At Midnight. Thursday evening at the Newman Theater.

title: TV Cameras Don't Capture Scene Around the Debaters
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 22There was more to the television debate here tonight than met the camera's eye.

title: News Summary
description: In their third and final debate, President Ford and Jimmy Carter both indicated they would stress issues rather than personalities during the final days of the campaign. The tone of the meeting was subdued and almost conciliatory as both men appeared relaxed during the 90minute debate on the campus of the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va. The two traded barbed comments toward the end of their nationally televised meeting but the exchange was brief. Page 1, Columns 36.1

title: Ford Predicts Surprise Victory As He Starts Final Campaigning
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va. Oct. 22President Ford predicted today that he would achieve the political surprise of the century by overtaking Jimmy Carter in the closing days of the contest for the White House.

title: Mendenhall Hurt, Adding To Giants Woe
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 22Thought it couldn't get worse, Giants fans?

title: RHODESIA  BLACKS DEFIANT IN BUILDING SHANTYTOWN
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct 22 (Reuters) The police erected roadblocks today to try to stop more blacks joining some 18,000 squatters in a new black shantytown that has sprung up near Salisbury in defiance of the law.

title: Rep. Tonry is Ruled Nominee Of the Democrats in Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 22 (UPI)The Lobisiana Supreme Court today declared Representative Richard Tonry, Democrat Of Chalmette, the Democratic Congressional nominee in the First District. The court reversed an appeals court decision and ruled against a suit by City Councilman James Moreau, who contended that forgeries and fraudulent votes had made Mr. Tonry the winner in the Democratic gurioff.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: THE PRESS IS CURBED IN RUBIN CARTER CASE
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 22News reporters and the public were barred today from observing the jury selection in the retrial of the murder case against Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis.

title: Commodity Market Index Drops 2.2 From WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 195.7 from 197.9 last week.

title: U.S. Bars State Housing Agencies From Getting RentSubsidy Funds
description: TRENTON, Oct. 22Federal housing officials have prohibited state housing finance agencies from receiving rentsubsidy money from 1977 appropriations for low and moderateincome housing, and have, in effect, killed plans for construction of 1,100 units for the elderly in New Jersey, Commissioner Patricia Q. Sheehan of the Department of Community Affairs charged today.

title: JEROME D. GRANT
description: Jerome D. Grant, a Westport, Conn., lawyer, died of cancer yesterday at Stamford Hospital. He was 38 years old and a resident of Westport.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Now that the Cincinnati Reds have won the World Series again, they want to be the first National League team to win it three consecutive years. But first, they must win the National League West next season and that's where Tom Lasorda might create a challenge, with his spirit as well as with his team. Tom Lasorda is the new manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, succeeding Walter Alston, and Tom Lasorda is as combative as Walter Alston was calm.

title: Notes on People
description: More than 60 of Jacques Barzun's friends and former students from the literary and intellectual world met at a University Club dinner last night for the cultural historian and Columbia University scholar. They presented him with a festschrifta celebratory collection of 31 new writings inspired by his career. it includes an unfinished essay that Lionel Trilling, Dr. Barzun's close friend and colleague, was working on at his death last November.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES RISE ON COMMERCIAL BUYING
description: Soybeans rose sharply in price yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, with the November contract closing at $6.50 a bushel, up from $6.26 Thursday.

title: Wings Deal Islanders First Loss
description: DETROIT, Oct. 21After flying high above the 17 other clubs of the National Hockey League by going six games without suffering a loss, the Islanders fell back into reality tonight by losing, 50, to the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Erie Democrats Puzzled by Polls Indicating a Drift Toward G.O.P.
Court Bars Delaware Executions
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 22 (AP) 1 The Delaware Supreme Court ruled today that the state's mandatory capital punishment law was unconstitutional on the ground laid down by the United States Supreme Court. The decision directly affected 13 inmates who had been awaiting

title: Crowds of Antileftists in Peking Hail the Downfall of Mao's Widow
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 22Hundreds of thousands of Chinese paraded through Peking for a second day today to denounce the antiparty clique of four senior leftists, following the announcement in the official press this morning that the group had been shattered.

title: Nation's Guidance Counselors: Many Things to Many People
description: Last month the boy wanted to be an accountant, but later on he decided he wanted to be an airplane mechanic. Not only that, he shuffled his feet and indicated he did not want to waste much time talking to Joan Kazin, his guidance counselor at Manhasset High School in Long Island.

title: Democrats Hold Moynihan Rally And Carey Warns of a Close Race
description: Regular Democratic leaders rallied around Daniel P. Moynihan yesterday, calling on each other and all Democratic officeholders to drum up support for Mr. Moynihan's campaign for the United States Senate from New York.

title: Dixie, Off Times Sq., Now the Carter Hotel
description: Workmen clambered about the marquee of the Dixie Hotel, a half block west of Times Square, as they began yesterday to change its name to the Carter Hotel. The new name has been taken from the company that operates the hotel and four others in Buffalo and Boston.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: U.S. 7th Army in Germany Regains Combat Spirit After a Low in 1970
description: HLIDELBERG, West Germany  The United States Seventh Army, in 1970 illarmed, unmotivated and drained by the Vietnam War of its best soldiers, has been turned into an aggressively efficient force by rigorous training, new weapons and the transition to a force of professionals. Its great combat power and improved capability to conduct sustained operations have been stressed by its commander, Gen. George S. Blanchard, as significant for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Coping With the Pain of Liberation
description: On the plus side, says Dr. Martin Symonds, a psychiatrist, the liberation movement is breeding some wonderfully independent and resourceful career women. But not so happily, he adds, it is also breeding women who are developing an impatience and intolerance of dependence of any sort.

title: 241 Fire Control Victor Over Hurdles at Belmont
description: It took more than five minutes for Fire Control to get home first at $50.60 for $2 in the Temple Gwathmey Handicap yesterday, which gives you an idea of what kind of day it was at Belmont Park in case anyone hadn't heard, it was National Steeplechase Day. And the 2 5/8mile Temple Gwathmey, once the nation's richest steeplechase event, was being staged here for the first time since 1971.

title: Lefkowitz Heeds Irate Net Fans
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowiz of New York State said yesterday he was conducting an inquiry into the rights of season ticketholders seeking refunds from the Nets because of the sale of Julius Erving to the Philadelphia 76ers. The Attorney General's office said it had received numerous complaints from irate ticketholders asking about refunds.

title: Kennecott Copper Achieves a Profit After Loss in 1975
description: Iry Kennecott Copper Corporation reported yesterday a turnaround in thirdquarter net income as sales rose 32.3 percent over the 1975 period. The report put net income at $4.8 million, or 15 cents a share, on sales and other income amounting to $254.7 million. This contrasted with a loss of $20.5 million for the three months ended Sept. 30, 1975 when sales and other income totaled $192.5 million.

title: On Boston Waterfront, Instant Neighborhood Glitters
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20A halfdozen years ago, Boston's waterfront was a dilapidated collection of tincovered fish shacks, banana warehouses and rotting wharves.

title: Finding of Bronfman is Described
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 22James E. Schry, a New York City detective testified at the Bronfman kidnapping trial today that Samuel Bronfman 2d, the alleged victim, was dazed and filthy when he was found by law enforcement authorities in the Brooklyn apartment of Mel Patrick Lynch one of the defendants.

title: Sports Today
description: National 500 stock car race, at Charlotte, N.C. (TelevisionChannel 7, 2 P.M., tape) Du Quoin (Ill.) dirt track championships. The world lightweight karate championship bout will be seen as a segment of this show.(TelevisionChannel 2, 4:30 P.M.)

title: Missing Daughter Cables Parents
description: A cable arrived yesterday at the suburban Detroit home of Kenneth and Elizabeth Anderson, the couple who have been searching all over New York City for their 19yearold daughter, Leigh, who failed to return to school in Ann Arbor on Sunday after a brief visit to Manhattan.

title: Pippin Celebrates Fourth Anniversary
description: Pippin, the musical by Roger O. Hirson and Stephen Schwartz, will celebrate its fourth year on Broadway today at the Imperial Theater. Produced by Stuart Ostrow, the show has grossed $21,346,742, earning net profits of $3.280.000.

title: Dollar is Mixed Abroad With Slight Differences; Price of Gold is Lower
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 22 (UPI)The dollar closed mixed on European money markets today but differences in the closing rates remained small.

title: Transcript of the Final Debate Between 2 Presidential Candidates
description: Following is a transcript of last nigel's debate between President Ford and Jimmy Carter at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News. The moderator was Barbara Walters of ABC News. The questioners were Joseph Kraft, syndicated columnist; Robert C. Maynard of The Washington Post, and Jack Nelson of The Los Angeles Times.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Transit, Agency Asked For Help on Pupil Fares

title: Saul Bellow, Laureate
description: In giving its reasons for awarding the Nobel Prize for Literature to Saul Bellow the Swedish Academy offered a remarkably perceptive critique of the Chicagobased but internationally respected novelist.

title: News Summary
description: In their third and final debate, President Ford and Jimmy Carter both indicated they would stress issues rather than personalities during the final days of the campaign. The tone of the meeting was subdued and almost conciliatory as both men appeared relaxed during the 90minute debate on the campus of the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg. Va. The two traded barbed comments toward the end of their nationally televised meeting but the exchange was brief. I Page 1, Columns 36. 1

title: Barnes Reports for Physical
description: DETROIT, Oct. 22 (UPI)Marvin Barnes, who has been suspended by the Detroit Pistons for missing practice, reported about three hours late for a team physical exam today. A team spokesman said it was possible that Barnes could play tomorrow night if the confusion is cleared up.

title: M'CARTHY RULED OFF BALLOT IN  NEW YORK
description: ALBANY, Oct. 22In the first phase of a legal battle that may not be permanently decided until just before the Presidential election, a State Supreme Court justice today struck down the independent Presidential candidacy in New York State of former United States Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota.

title: Patents: Gravity Unit Transports Blood
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22Blood and other specimens from the body are susceptible to damage if transported at the speed they encounter in the customary hospital pneumatic tubes. At the New York University Medical Center a gravity system has been installed that carries specimens at one or two miles an hour in contrast to the usual velocity of 15 to 30 miles hour.

title: World News Briefs
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 22More than half of an expected total of 4,000 United Jewish Appeal fundraisers and community leaders arrived in Israel today from the United States for a nineday demonstration of the unwavering support of American Jewry for Israel, an official of the appeal said.

title: Hoey, Special Prosecutor In Suffolk for 13 Months, Quits to Resume Practice
description: HAUPPAGUE, Li., Oct. 22Joseph P. Hoey, the Suffolk County special prosecutor, resigned today from his 13month investigation into the personal and political feud between the county's Police Commissioner and its District Attorney, citing the completion of most of his work on the project and a desire to return to private law practice.

title: G.O.P. NAMES CANDIDATE TO REPLACE PLOSCOWE
description: The Republican organization in Manhattan named Denise T. Wiseman yesterday as the replacement on the Nov. ballot for Bernard L. Ploscowe, the Republican nominee in the 20th Congressional District, who jumped to his death from the window of his eighthfloor Central Park West apartment on Thursday.

title: Jones of Colts Appears In Top Form for Jets
description: The last time the Jets beat the Baltimore Colts a 23yearold quarterback named Bert Jones completed 36 of 53 passes, including a National Football League mark of 17 in a row.

title: IRISH LEADER QUITS OVER I.R.A MASURES
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 22  The President of Ireland resigned today, four days after the Defense Minister called him a thundering disgrace for questioning the constitutionality of emergency legislation designed to stop the activities of Irish Republican Army guerrillas.

title: Ervin Feels 73 Talk With Nixon Was Used in Plan to Dismiss Cox
description: Former Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. of North Carolina who was chairman of the Senate Watergate committee; says he strongly suspects that a meeting he had three years ago with President Nixon to work out a deal for release of transcripts of the White House tapes was used by Mr. Nixon as part of a cover plan to dismiss Archibald Cox, the Watergate special prosecutor.

title: Court Lifts Tuna Fishing Ban
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 22 (UPI)Saying the economic consequences would be enormous, a Federal judge has ordered the National Fisheries Service and Coast Guard not to enforce a tuna fishing ban scheduled to go into effect today and meant to save porpoises from death in fishermen's nets. The 10day restraining order was issued yesterday in response to pleas from fishermen that it would wreck their industry. The Government said that the tuna fisheries could afford to suspend fishing for the rest of the Year and that Congress meant to take such steps to protect porpoises and other marine mammals.

title: Views Differ Sharply on the Loss By Moynihan of the Liberal Line
description: Democratic, Republican, Liberal and Conservative politicians differed widely yesterday on the potential effect of State Supreme Court justice's decision removing Daniel P. Moynihan from the Liberal Party line in the Nov. 2 election.

title: NBC Abandons Its Plan to Increase Newscasts in Evening to One Hour
description: In a statement issued yesterday that dismayed the rival networks and left their news chiefs dejected, NBC announced That it had ceased considering the possibility of expanding the early evening newscast from 30 minutes to an hour on weeknights.

title: McDonnell Douglas Sues Times Over a Review of Two Books
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 22 (AP)  The McDonnell Douglas Corporation filed a $25 million libel suit against The New York Times Company today in United States District Court here.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Oct. 22So many unemployed people in New Jersey have exhausted their eligibility under Federal and state unemployment benefit programs that the state is now once again able to pay its own way.

title: NEW HOSPITAL'S STAFF ELATED OVER OPENING
description: The executive director of the North Central Bronx Hospital said yesterday that his staff was elated over winning a sixweek battle with the State Health Department, which finally granted the new facility an operating certificate.

title: Lebanese Continue Battle in South
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 22Military action continued in southern Lebanon today near the Israeli border while the ceasefire that was proclaimed yesterday morning appeared to be effective for the most part in Beirut and the rest of the country.

title: 76 PAY RISES FOUND BELOW LAST YEAR'S
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22The Labor Department reported today that wage increases negotiated in major collective bargaining agreements in the first nine months of 1976 were smaller than in 1975

title: Tradition a Big Barrier in Kenya's MarriageReform Drive
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 22Few political issues since Kenya's independence have stirred the popular and academic debate that now surrounds a pending marriage bill, which among other things, would give wives a veto over a husband's polygamous plans, permit wives to share control of family property and send adulterers to fail for six months.

title: Protest in Rome Halts Trains
description: ROME, Oct. 22 (Reuters)About 1,000 civil servants blocked lines at Rome's central station today to protest plans to abolish their rights to cheap fares on Laly's stateowned railway system. Rail officials said no trains were able to leave or enter the station.

title: Dow Off 6.15; Fall in Orders Is Depressant
description: Stocks closed lower yesterday after prices weakened in the afternoon following a report from the Commerce Department that new orders for durable goods showed a sharp 3.1 percent drop September, the third monthly decline a row.

title: Wallace Sues a Sex Magazine For Unauthorized Use of Photo
description: Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama filed a $5 million libel suit yesterday against Screw magazine, a sexual tabloid that printed a photograph of him on its back cover earlier this year. The Governor also asked a New York state judge to enjoin the magazine from using his photograph for advertising, the news agency Reuters reported.

title: Settlement Reached In Job Bias Lawsuit
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 22 (UPI) Parties to a classaction suit charging employment discrimination at Braniff Airways Inc. have agreed to a $1.1 million outofcourt settlement, an attorney for black and Hispanic employees said today.

title: Ford Completes Action On All Bills Before Him; Spurs Alaskan Gas Flow
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP)President Ford cleared up the last of the bills awaiting his action today. Among those signed was a bill to speed up the flow of natural as from Alaska reserves.

title: Couple Indicted in Death of Girl
description: CLEVELAND. Tenn., Oct. 22 (UPI)A Cleveland couple was indicted today on first degree murder charges for the torture death of a 4yearold girl. No trial date was immediately set for Ronald and Wanda Maddox, accused in the aid and Wanda Maddux, accused in the dux's daughter. Melisha Morganna Gibson.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions on Page 27

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: U.S. Court Overturns Curb on Medicaid Abortions
description: A Federal District judge held yesterday that a Federal curb..on Medicaid reimbursement for most abortions was unconstitutional, thus barring its implementation in all 50 states.

title: Scientists Employing U2 Find Space Dust in the Stratosphere
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 21After two and a half years of sampling with a U2 plane flying at high altitude, scientists from three American laboratories have found that more than half the larger, naturally occurring dust grains in the stratosphere have come from space.

title: Spirit of Dashing Founder Guides Commune
description: WAILIJA, Hawaii  Ninety people drawn from the confused remnants of the social upheavals of the 1960's are living quietly and in apparent happiness in a religious commune set up by an unusual middleaged adventurer.

title: Despite Problems, Hughes is Called Leader in House Race With Hurley
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 22Representative William 1. 1highes is confident that he will become the first Democrat since the Roosevelt era to win two consecutive terms in the conservative Second Congressional District.

title: NEW YORK AND POLICE IN TENTATIVE ACCORD OVER PAY AND HOURS
description: New York City and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association tentatively accepted a compromise solution yesterday to their long labor dispute, giving the police $1,045 in back pay and what their leaders regard as an improved work schedule.

title: A Shop in the Suburbs Lures Lovers of DowntoEarth Crafts
description: Crafts hunting is getting better all the time in the suburbs, as good shops keep opening, or established ones expand and show better wares.

title: SHORT INTEREST UP, BIG BOARD REPORTS
description: The New York Stock Exchange reporied Wednesday that the short interest in the month ended Oct. 15, 1976, increased by 520,159 to 23,191,653 shares. This was the highest total since July 15, 1976, when the short interest was 24,225,595 shares.

title: Lois Bewley Presents Dance Premiere Tonight
description: This evening, Lois Bewley, formerly a member of American Ballet Theater and the New York City Ballet as well as a principal guest artist at the Spoleto Festival, will present the world premiere of her onewoman dance concert, The Return of Lois Bewley.

title: Marilyn Fee is Married to Paul J. White 3d
description: Marilyn Patricia Fee and Paul Joseph White 3d were married yesterday afternoon in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Cathedral in Rock ville Centre, II. Msgr. Edward Melton performed the ceremony.

title: McCarthy Loses Bid For a Role in Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP)Eugene J. McCarthy failed today in move to block tonight's Presidential campaign debate from proceeding without him.

title: 9 Bonwit Stores Set Sunday Yule Sales
description: Bonwit Teller, the Fifth Avenuebased specialty store chain, will open for business on Sundays during the Christmas shoppine season beginning Nov. 28.

title: 2 Tied in Italy Golf
description: IS MULAS, Italy, Oct. 22 (Reuters) Sam Torrance of England and Baldovino Dassu of Italy shared the halfway lead in the $60,000 Italian open golf championship today with 36hole totals of 142, two under par. They were two strokes ahead of Carl Mason of. England, the first round leader.

title: Israelis Charge 74 in the West Bank
description: CHERRON, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Oct. 22An Israeli military spokesman for the ?? territories of the West Bank of the Jordan said today that 74 Arab youths had been charged with desecrating Jewish religious artifacts during a conflict at a shrine here that is sacred to both Moslems and Jews.

title: Guards Prepared to Shoot to Kill Are Increased at 14 Nuclear Sites
description: Armored personnel carriers and guards equipped with the Army's latest rapidfire rifles are being added to the serurity forces at 14 Federal nuclear sites.

title: Baltimore Subway Delayed
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 22 (AP)Approval of the first major construction contract for the Baltimore subway system was delayed today because of concern over whether Maryland minority businesses would get a fair share of the work.

title: William Parker, Baritone, Sings In a Style to Live Up to Rumors
description: There had been some promising advance word about William Parker, a baritone who made his New York recital debut in Alice Tully Hall Thursday night. He had won many prizes; he had been singled out in public by Pierre Bernac, one of his many teachers, as an extraordinary talent his recital here was an award from the special Joy in Singing course presided over by Winifred Cecil.

title: Open Interest
description: (In bushels, 000 omitted) Thur.

title: JOHN KING BENZIGER
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 22John King Benziger, an investment banker associated with Shields and Company and Reynolds and Company of New York City, lied Wednesday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at Will Merry Lane in Greenwich.

title: COMBUSTION SEEKS GRAY TOOL STOCK
description: Combustion Engineering said in Stamford, Conn., yesterday that it was offering to purchase any and all common shares of the Gray Tool Company of Houston at $38 a share.

title: Unions and Doctors Are Ahead In Group Campaign Donations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI)Organized labor contributed nearly half the specialinterest money that went to Presidential and Congressional candidates this year, Federal Election Commission records showed today.

title: Transparent Evasion
description: If the FordCarter debates did not violate the law, they certainly made a farce of it. The cream of the jest is that very few people, despite the resurgent reverence for law supposedly born of the Watergate affair, seemed to care. Both candidates, running as models of uplift, collaborated readily with the League of Women Voters, the television networks, the two dominant parties and an indifferent public to create a legal fiction for getting around the law they didn't like this year.

title: Minnesota U. Seeks Halt Of Indefinite Probation
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct, 22 (AP)The University of Minnesota said today would go into Federal Court in an attempt to block an indefinite probation period for all men's sports imposed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The N.C.A.A. action was a result of infractions in the basketball program under former Coach Bill Musselman. The charges were filed in July 1975.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reported in The Times during the last week.

title: On Boston Waterfront, Instant Neighborhood Glitters
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20A halfdozen years ago, Boston's waterfront was a dilapidated collection of tincovered fish shacks, banana warehouses and rotting wharves.

title: LINNE JOHNSON
description: Linne Johnson, a retired sales executive and husband of Helene Mullins who wrote a number of books on poetry under that name, died Wednesday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: St. Thomas Golf Victor
description: SHREVEPORT, La., Oct. 22 (AP)Doug Dixon and Donnie Hill helped the University of St. Thomas of Houston stretch a twostroke firstround lead into a 14stroke victory in the Centenary golf tournament today. St. Thomas had a 588 team total for two rounds of play over the par72 7,341yard Huntington Park course. Houston Baptist University was second with 602, followed by the University of New Orleans with 605.

title: Green Cards 68 For 136 and Lead In Southern Golf.
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Oct. 22 (AP)Hubert Green chipped in twice for birdies on his way to a 68 that enabled him to establish a onestroke lead today after the second round of the $125,000 Southern open golf tournament.

title: BLACK SOWETO STUDENTS REPORTED TO RAID BARS
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct 22 (Reuters)Black students in Soweto today attacked liquor stores and illicit drinking dens, or dering patrons out and smashing bottles, according to unofficial reports here tonight.

title: CANTER RULES OUT WAR OVER YUGOSLAVS
description: Jimmy Carter said last night that he did not believe a Soviet invasion of Yugoslavia would threaten American national security and therefore would not warrant the introduction of United States troops on Yugoslavia's behalf.

title: Family of Dead Fireman Sues
description: The family of a New York City fireman who was killed in a Queens factory fire in August has filed a $13 million negligence suit. The suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Queens, names the City of New York and two concerns that occupied the factory building. The fireman was Lieut. Joseph Sparacino of Wantagh, L.I.

title: Joseph W. Lippincott Dead at 89; Author Headed Publishing House
description: Joseph Wharton Lippincott, an author and the third member of his family to head the publishing house of J. B. Lippincott Company, died yesterday in a hospital in Huntington Valley, Pa., where he had a summer home. His age was 89.

title: Navy Admits Missile is Unfound
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (Reuters)The United States Navy has begun a search for a secret Phoenix missile that separated from a F14 Tomcat fighter now on the flor of the North Sea off Scotland, Government sources said today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: THE PRESS IS CURBED IN RUBIN CARTER CASE
description: Judge Leopizzi has imposed a gag ers and the public were barred today from observing the jury selection in the retrial of the murder case against Rubb (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis.

title: 2 Flu Shots 4 Weeks Apart Found Safe for Those 3 to 18 Years Old
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22Data from a national study made public today indicate that persons between the ages of 3 and 18 can be immunized safely and effectively against swine flu by giving them two doses of vaccine spaced four weeks apart.

title: U.N. APPROVES EXTENSION OF A SINAI PEACE FORCE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 22The Security Council today approved a oneyear extension of the United Nations peacekeeping force separating Egyptian and Israeli troops in the Sinai Peninsula.

title: A Fair Proposal
description: The long and embittered dispute over the police contract may be nearing a settlement through what appears to be a reasonable compromise. Mediator Michael I. Sovern, dean of the Columbia University Law School, and police union and municipal negotiators are to be commended for arriving at a formula that strives to accommodate rankandfile objections to the original contract offer without violating the nocost mandate that has been imposed on the city by state and Federal overseers.

title: Marketing is Widening Vodka Sales
description: When people talk about an egghead today, chances are they may not be referring to a Harvard intellectual. Instead, they may just be speaking about a frothy drink made with orange juice, vodka and egg that at the moment is being energetically promoted by Heublein.

title: An Implacable Irishman
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 22  Cearbhall Dalaigh, a small sprightly goodhumored mut with twinkling eyes and a restless, inquiring manner, had been President of Ireland for 23 months before he resigned today. Before that he had been one of the country's most eminent lawyers, a journalist and a failed politician. Unlike most of his predecessors, he was riot an elected President. He was the agreed nominee of the major political parties to take over when Erskine Childers died suddenly in November 1974. Mr. O Dalaigh was hastily summoned from the European Court in Luxembourg, the judicial institution of the European Community on which he had served for two years.

title: Julie L. Nussenbaum, Artist, Is Bride of James M. Fesler
description: Julie Lynn Nussenbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Nussenbaum of Old Bridge. N.J., was married in New York ye Friday afternoon to James Martin Fester, son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Fesler of New Haven.

title: A Glance at the Leading College Football Games on Schedule for Today
description: LOCAL

title: 'Orpheus Times Light, Piece By Arpino, at Joffrey Ballet
description: The wonderful aspect of the legend of Orpheus is that even after the hero ins been torn apart and his heed is floating in the river, he still goes down singing.

title: M'CARTHY RULED OFF BALLOT IN NEV, YORK
description: ALBANY, Oct. 22In the first phase of a legal battle that may not be permanently decided until just before the Presidential election, a State Supreme Court justice today struck down the independent Presidential candidacy in New York State of former United States Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota.

title: 4 PROTESTING SOVIET JEWS ARE REPORTEDLY ARRESTED
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 22 (AP)Four Jews have been arrested after taking part in a series of sitins this week at the Soviet Parliament's reception room, Jewish sources said today.

title: Nets Final Basket Beats Warriors in Debut
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 22With their former star 3,000 miles away, playing in Philadelphia, the New York Nets opened their first National Basketball Association season tonight against the Golden State Warriors.

title: Housing Dream is Fading at $50,000
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22The American dreamhouse has passed 50$50,000.

title: Rutgers Making Meadowlands Debut
description: Many residents of East Rutherford, N.J., have a couple of free tickets for the first college football game to be played at Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands. But those who live elsewhere will have to pay from $3 to $6 for the right to sit in on the RutgersColumbia game there today.

title: U.S. Court Overturns Curb on Medicaid Abortions
description: A Federal District judge held yesterday that a Federal curb on Medicaid reimbursement for most abortions was unconstitutional, thus barring its implementation in all 50 states.

title: Lawsuit Says Iowa Town Shuns Poor on U.S. Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 22Lawyers for a group opposed to discrimination in housing today asked a Federal court in Iowa to cut off community development funds to the city of Davenport, charging that the city had ignored the needs of poor people in spending the money.

title: Texas Trilogy Will End Oct. 31; Runner Stumbles Closes Oct. 30
description: Preston Jones's A Texas Trilogy, representing an investment of $350,000, will end its Broadway run at the Broadhurst Theater on Oct, 31 after a total of 63 performances.

title: TROY BEGINS SERVING 60DAY PRISON TERM
description: A somber Matthew J. Troy Jr. walked into the Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn yesterday to start serving a 60day jail term for a tax violation.

title: Budapest, 20 Years Ago
description: A certain Mr. Balogh is very anxious to talk to you, said my adjutant.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Up in 3 and 6 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180maturities.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: How to Prevent Municipal Bankruptcy

title: 300 on Big Board Offer Dividend Reinvestment
description: The number of New York Stock Exchange listed companies offering stockholders dividend reinvestment plans recently passed the 300 mark, according to a Big Board survey.

title: Times Mirror Offers $292 Million For Stock of Booth Newspapers
description: The Times Mirror Company, owner of The Los Angeles Times and three other daily newspapers, announced yesterday that it had offered to buy for $292 million in cash the outstanding stock of Booth Newspapers Inc., publisher of a chain of eight newspapers in Michigan.

title: NEW YORK AND POLICE IN TENTATIVE ACCORD ON WAGES AND HOURS
description: New York City and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association tentatively accepted a compromise solution yesterday to their long labor dispute, giving the police $1,045 in back pay and what their leaders regard as an improved work schedule.

title: Brick Wall in Buffalo Runs Head on Into a Protest
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 22A sixfoot brick wall being erected around the square in front of the City Hall here in a $575,000 publicworks beautification project is to be torn down next week because the public has found it ugly.

title: Informal Talks About Rhodesia Are Started in Geneva
description: GENEVA, Oct 22Informal aimed at reaching an accord that would establish a biracial transitional government in Rhodesia began here today with a 90minute meeting between Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia and Ivor Richard, Britain's chief representative at the United Nations, who will preside at a conference on the subject that opens here Thursday.

title: Beckett OneActers Due Dec. 3 in Capital
description: Two oneact plays by Samuel Beckett that have never been performed in this countryFootfalls and That Time will form part of a triple bill to be presented to the Arena Stage's kreeger Theater in Washington from Dec. 3 throufth Dec: 19.

title: Bridge.
description: At its annual meeting last night at the New York Hilton Hotel, the Greater New York Bridge Association reelected Paul Kern as president for a second oneyear term. He is the third man to be so hormied in the long history of the Association.

title: A Job Aide is Indicted On Urging Prostitution
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 22 (UPI) An employee of a governmentfinanced jobtraining agency in Dover, N.J., has been indicted on charges of trying to convince job applicants to become prostitutes.

title: Music in Review
description: Over the years, the list of winners of the National Federation of Music Clubs competitions has accumulated some impressive namesJohn Browning, Rosalyn Tureck, Donald Gramm and Shirley Verrett, to name some. Last year's winner in the violin division was David Ehrlich, who was presented in a New York debut recital Wednesday night at Paul Hall in the Juilliard School.

title: Witness Suggests Mandel, in Move to Benefit Friends, Sought to Upset Own Veto of Race Track
description: BALTIMORE, OCT. 23A Maryland State Senator has testified at Governor Ilarvin Mandel's corruption trial that the Governor's closest ally in the Senate told in in 1972 that the Governor wanted he Senate to override his own veto of a bill benefiting Marlboro Race Track.

title: A Room To Love
description: MONTGOMERY TOWNSHIP IT was, Town Superintendent Abraham V. A. Skillman wrote, a commodious schoolhouse conveniently arranged, neatly finished upon the latest improved plan, and very pleasantly located.

title: CHESS
description: For complex tactical play in a queenside opening, there is nothing quite like the Benoni Defense, but the most sensible plan would be to preserve it for use against positional opponents who could easily be upset by it. The tharacteristic exchange, 4 PxP; 5 PxP, unbalances the pawn formation, giving Black a queenside majority to be set in motion eventually by PQN4 and giving White a kingside majority to be activated by breaking with an eventual PK5.

title: Difficult as the Job of U.N. Secretary General May Be, Mr. Waldheim Has Challengers
description: You are merely the lens in the beam. You wut nnow life and be acknowledged by it according to your own degree of transparency. your capacity, that is, to vanish as an end, and remain purely as a means.

title: The Pleasures of Jazz
description: Now that classic jazz is a waning ghost most frequently seen on the boards of the festival circuit, and heard occasionally in its original innocence at the odd night club, a great rush of writing about the indigenous art confirms its contract with history. Where jazz is going none of these books tells us. Two furnish fresh insights into the past and give us some indication of its present state of health.

title: Nini Brooke Bride of Writer Patricia Myerson Bride of James Huntington
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Lenox, Mass., yesterday afternoon, Cornelia Ewing Brooke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. B. Brooke of Lenox, was married to George Franklin Gilder, a writer. He is the son of Mrs. Gilder Palmer of Tyringham, Mass., and the late Richard Watson Gilder, an Army Air Forces lieutenant killed during World War II.

title: Lyle Hedman, Consultant, Marries Anne Green Keating
description: Anne Green Keating, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Keating of Suffern, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lyle Donnell Hedman, son of Mrs. Edwin Anderson Melts Jr. of Wilmington, N.C., and the late Dr. Lyle Clayton Hedman.

title: McLendon Takes Lead By Shot in Georgia Golf
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Oct. 23 (AP)Mac McLendon swept past his close friend, Hubert Green, with a oneunderpar 69 today and took a onestroke lead in the third round of the $215,000 Southern open golf tournament.

title: Abbatiello Wins 3,000th
description: EST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 23Carmine Abbatiello tonight became the ninth driver in harness racing history to win 3,000 races when he steered Lucky Dapple $6.60. to a neck victory in the second race at the Meadowlands He was presented a sterling silver. plaque.

title: PEOPLE
description: The most notable law reformer in the Mate's history, as well as one of the foremost contributors to American jurisprudence, was Arthur T. Vanderbilt, who, as Chief Justice of New Jersey from 1946 to 1957, helped to mold the Mate courts into what is regarded as one of the first modern judicial systems in the United States. Now the Rutgers ?? Press is coming out with Changing Law, a biography of the late jurist and dean of NPW York University Law Scrim; fittingly, its author is Arthur T. Vthiderbilt 2d, the judge's 21 ??old grandson. who lives in Summit. The younger Mr. Vanderbilt's book had its genesis in a University Virginia Law School term paper, and he later took to Wesleyan University, where he was studying, 117 cartons Justice Vanderbilt's papers for his research. The biography's youthful author has served as clerk to State Supreme Court Justice Herman Michaels, and he is now a deputy attorney general.

title: A.J. Stein, S.B. Freiman, Physicians, Have Bridal
description: Dr. Sarise B. Freiman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Freiman of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married last night to Dr. Alan J. Stein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Solomon Stein of Ardslev. N.Y.

title: A poet's life and work
description: In the 1890's the Greek poet Constantine Cavafy wrote a note in English about the greatness of St. Simeon Stylites. Considering the fifthcentury saint as a subject for poetry, he recorded his disapproval of Tennyson's dramatic monologue Stylites and affirmed that the poet who could write worthily of such a subject would have to be some mighty king of art. In 1917, six years after the most significant turning point in his creative life, Cavafy composed his own Simeon, in which a pagan sophist explains to an associate that he is too upset to discuss seriously the sensational new poems of one Lamon because, the day before, he accidentally found himself among the Christians praying at the foot of Simeon's pillar.

title: New Yorkers to Seek Added Ingredients
description: When the Yankee triumvirate of George Steinbrenner, Gabe Paul and Billy Martin was finished shuffling and dealing their players like a deck of cards earlier this season, they were convinced the team would win the Yankees first pennant in 12 years. They were right.

title: Brooklyn Trip By Ford Has Bad Aftertaste
description: George L. Clark Jr., the Brooklyn Republican leader, went fishing the day Presidenty Ford campaigned in Brooklyn because, he said, he rid been frozen out of the planning for the trip by Richard M. Rosenbaum, the Republican state leader and Ford campaign chairman here. Mr. Clark was an early Ronald Reagan supporter, but is backing the President now. Now it develops that Vice President Rockefeller, Mr. Rosenbaum's political sponsor, was fishing that day tooin spirit if not in bodyand like, Mr. Clark, was also unhappy.

title: 1,755 Interviewed in Times Survey
description: The New York Times survey is based on interviews with 1,755 adult men and women across New York State, including 1,335 registered voters.

title: PUBLIC DEFENDERS TO AID CHILDREN IN CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 20 (AP)For the first time in the 34year history of the state's Juvenile Court, fulltime public defenders are being hired to represent indigent children; officials said this week.

description: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n

title: News Summary
description: Chinese television broadcast scenes of demonstrations by Chinese in Peking celebrating the downfall of the leftists. The broadcast, which was sent around the world, described the mood of the crowds as jubilant and told of similar demonstrations in other cities involving millions of Chinese. The demonstrations are expected to end with rally today in Peking that may be addressed by Hua Kuofeng, the new chairman. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Refugees From Timor Are Facing a Bleak Winter in Portugal and Look to Australia for a Better Future
description: VALE DO JAMOR, PortugalSharp rains and wind sweep across this valley, just northwest of Lisbon, and beat at the drab rows of mudbound army tents.

title: Some Have Reversed the Disastrous Trend
description: Attention paid to the continuing financial difficulties of New York City and Yonkers tended to obscure the varied and sometimes heroic efforts of many the region's other cities to avoid default or state takeover in the past year. We decided to move heaven and earth to avoid a state takeover when New York and Yonkers lost control over their financial affairs, says Buffalo's Commissioner of Administration and Finance, James W. Burns, and, playing device by device, I think we've done it.

title: Atomic Agency Says it is Bypassed
description: VIENNA, Oct. 23Officials of the United Nations agency that deals with atomic energy complain that their organization is being bypassed and apparently ignored by a secretive group of industrial nations that export nuclear technology.

title: Billy Martin's Burden for the 1977 Season
description: More than anyone else, Billy Martin knows that his true test as the New York Yankees manager will develop next season. Billy Martin knows that many baseball people consider him a oneyear manager. He knows that many baseball people were not shocked when the Yankees won the American League pennant this year. Billy Martin had turned around the Minnesota Twins, the Detroit Tigers and the Texas Rangers in other years, winning two division titles and threatening to win another, only to be discharged later with his team in turmoil. Billy Martin knows that many baseball people will be surprised if turmoil does not develop on the Yankees next season. Even with a new threeyear contract, that is Billy Martin's burden nowto prove that he's more than a oneyear manager, that he can sustain command.

title: Chou Enlai is Honored
description: PEKING. Oct. 23 (Agence FrancePresse)Chou Enlai was publicly associated with Rua Kuofeng when portraits of Chou were carried alongside those of the new party chairman in today's antileftist demonstration here.

description: JetsColts Statistics
