description: METUCHEN IF SOMEONE should happen to tell you that Jean Lochet of 4 Kelly Street is housing 6,000 foreign troops in his basement, don't call the Central Intelligence Agency to report an invasion. Believe him.

title: Some New Games in Town
description: PICTURE a large athletic field on a slightly overcast, chilly day on one playing field a soccer game is going on, with the usual two teams and a sprinkling of loyal, if slightly frozen, spectators.

title: The DebatesZooming In on the Visceral
description: The complaint that the televised debates between the candidates are boring is itself boring. One tires of people who sit around twirling their knobs, fiddling with themselves as though they were stereo consoles, mood synthesizers: I'm turned off. Who says that politics or politicians are supposed to turn you on? in a Presidential election year, you ought at the very least to be at a low hum without any outside help at all it is the normal respiration of intelligence.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: This time it's not a cosmetic job; it's radical surgery. After 14 years of desperate tinkering with Avery Fisher (nee Philharmonic) Hall, a whole new hall has been built in the old shell. The auditorium has been literally ripped out and replaced in a process almost as interesting as the result.

title: Diocletian's Palace Lives
description: Driving into Split, Yugoslavia, on a winter day I began to feel faintly depressed and wondered why.

title: High School Band is a Series Loser, Too
description: BAINBRIDGE, N.Y., Oct. 23The score may have been 72, but for the high school band from this small upstate community, the fourth game of the 1976 World Series amounted to a shutout.

description: Marjorie Ann Berg, a nurse on the staff of Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center in New Hyde Park, was married yesterday evening to Leonard Joseph Pugatch, who is with the law firm of Roy S. Dragotta in Port Jefferson, L. I.

description: HE hasn't found a newspaper yet with an account of the last and illfated voyage of the sloop Dream, which was lost in 1843 en route from Galveston, Tex., to New Orleans, but Richard Spellman says he'll keep rummaging through his storage garage in North Bergen because maybe I'll find it one clay.

Directed to corporation executives, the ad boasts that Honeywell has the equipment and knowledge to help other companies cut energy costs.

title: DOROTHY COLT, OPERATOR OF A THEATER SCHOOL, 87
description: Dorothy Coit, who for 37 years operated the KingCoit School of theater and design in New York City with the late Edith King, died Wednesday in a convalescent home in Southbury, Conn, Miss Coit, whose home was in Southbury, was 87 years old.

description: While stock prices drop and tax shelters spring leaks, a growing army of ?? has been snapping up one of ?? Street's prize packaged products  the unit investment trust.

title: Uniondale Deals Loss To Calhoun
description: Uniondale squeezed by Calhoun yesterday, 60, to hang on to its undefeated season and first place in Nassau Conference II.

title: The essential King Arthur, according to John Steinbeck
description: When John Steinbeck was at work on his The Acts of King Arthur and His Noble Knights in the middle and late 1950's, he hoped it would be the best work of my life and the most satisfying. Even in Its original form, the project was enormoustranslation of the complete Morte d'Arthur of Sir Thomas Malory; and the project soon bcame still more difficult, not translation but a complete retellingrethinkingof the myth. Steinbeck finished only some 293 uncorrected, unedited pages, perhaps onetenth of the original. Even so, the book Steinbeck's friend and editor Chase Horton has put together is large and important. it is in fact two books, Steinbeck's mythic fiction on King Arthur's court, and a fat, rich collection of letters exchanged between Steinbeck, Horton and Elizabeth Otis, Steinbeck's agent. The first is an incomplete but impressive work of art; the second, the complete story of a literary tragedy how Steinbeck found his way, step by step, from the idea of doing a translation for boys to the idea of writing fabulist fiction, in the mid1950's, when realism was still king.

description: RESULTS

title: A Living Monument To Eugene O'Neill
description: Earlier this month the Federal Government declared Eugene O'Neill's Tao House, in California, a National Historic Site. It's something of a breakthrough for the arts in America.

title: In Memoriam
description: FINESINGERSol B. Prof. Nov. 17, 1900. on Friday morning, 5:30 AM, September 17, 1976. of New York City. We kept each other alive. You were so brave and so courageous after ?? the years of suffering. Sol you had such a peaceful, sweet smile on your dear face. I shall always pray that you are at peace at last. I ant so alone I shall always miss you. You left me to no to Heaven, you have taken me with You. Your widow, Jean Finesinger.

title: Banks Urged to Invest Locally
description: CALDWELL A CAMPAIGN to induce banks and lending institutions in six North Jersey counties to finance more local mortgages has been started by the New Jersey Citizens Action Alliance, a new public advocac; group.

title: Are the Debates Worth It?
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.  From the vantage point of 1976, it has been easy to look back at the television debates between John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon and conclude that they in no way illuminated the submerged and painful issues with which American society was forced to grapple in the decade that followed. If there is anything that can be safely claimed for the second television tournament for the Presidency, it's that this time it won't be necessary to wait 16 years to arrive at the same conclusion.

description: THE EASTER PARADE, by Richard Yates. (Delacorte/Seymour Lawrence. $7.95.) A spare and unsparing tale of two sisters who choose different roads to futility.

title: ART
description: THE exhibition of contemporary quilts at the Newark Museum flies persuasively in the face of a prevalent notion that craftsmanship in America is dead or at least moribund in this show are a total of 11 quilts that were conceived, designed and stitched by community groups throuqhout New Jersey, and they were all made with love, imagination and patience and with an eye toward quaiity craft.

description: At Upsala College, David Stringham played reeds and Suzy Williams of Stormin Norman and Suzy mixed with the students between numbers during the concert.

title: Discovery of Soviet Crater Called a Sign That Earth Was Heavily Bombarded Even After Planet's Infancy
description: The discovery of what appears to have been an ancient impact crater six miles deep and more than 400 miles wide has been cited as evidence that bombardment of the earth by very large objects did not end in the planet's infancy.

title: Design
description: Connoisseurs of city planning have reason to be grateful to the Brooklyn Academy of Music. So have connoisseurs of drama, dance, song, chamber music, movies, children's theater and almost any other category of the performing arts that one may wish to name. For the Academy, familiarly known as BAM, is a veritable Vesuvius of incessant cultural activity, lighting up the sky over Flathush Avenue in a fashion readily visible even from myopic Manhattan. Daily and nightly throughout most of the yearthe volcano is permitted to slumber for a few weeks each summersomething exceptionally lively is sure to be going on in one or another of the several theater spaces that flourish in ingeniously isolated and soundproofed propinquity within the stout walls of the Academy.

title: POLICEMEN ANGERED Al TENTATIVE ACCORD
description: The tentative pact reached Friday by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and the Beame administration was vigorously condemned yesterday by the officers of the Midtown North Precinct.

title: U.S.C. Routs Oregon State; Reserve Stars
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (AP)Charles White, a freshman tailback, led a parade of Southern California runners through a porous Oregon State defense today, rushing for 107 yards and three touchdowns as the seventhranked Trojans swamped the Beavers 500.

title: Ramapo Beaten, 100, By Clarkstown North
description: Tradis Burkett gained more than 100 yards rushing and scored in the final 2 minutes yesterday to help Clarkstown North send Ramapo to its first setback, 100. Matt Luba ?? for North's other points ?? ?? goal.

description: ALEGISLATIVE proposal, Asembly Bill 2021, would authorize the substitution of generic drugs for the brandname drugs prescribed by a doctor. Its sponsor, Assemblyman Martin A. Herman, Democrat of Woodbury, and his supporters have claimed that there are countless dollars to be saved by prescribing generically, and so New Jersey is now seriously considering costly legislation that has proved of literally no value to other states or to our neighbor, Canada.

description: Katherine Marie Walte, of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen ?? Waite of Rye, N.Y., was rnarried yesterday to Donald Gilson white Ytterberz.

title: Bernard King Arrested
description: ALCOA, Tenn.. Oct. 23 (AP)University of Tennessee basketball star. Bernard King, was arrested early today and charged with driving while intoxicated, reckless driving and violating the state's automobile registration law, the police said. Later, Coach Ray Mears said King, who is from Brooklyn, New York, would be suspended from the team for the rest of the fall quarter.

title: College Hockey Preview: Minnesota and Brown Powerful Squads
description: Wideopen, highscoring, tensionfilled overtime conteststhey're the hockey fan's dream. Arid last weekend, there Were two of them, identical 76 scores. But they didn't take place in the National Hockey League or World Hockey Association. Instead, Wisconsin and Michigan, two of college hockey's best squads, traded victories and one of the national Collegiate Athletic Association's fastestgrowing sports began its earliest season ever.

title: Eagleton Polls Scan the State
description: NEW BRUNSWICK FROM a sprawling white mansion here, a small group of people are professional watchers of the battles that turn men into political kings. Hughes against Hurley. Siciliano against Howard. Sheehan agaiiist Maguire. Williams against Norcross. Ford against Carter. Although the elections are only a few days away, it almost business as usual at the Eagletnn Institute of Politics, a division of Rutgers University that concerns itself with evaluating, teaching, investigating and improving the functioning of government.

title: Books: Freedom or Free Enterprise?
description: Although the words ethics and freedom crop up frequently in this book, it scarcely lives up to its imposing title. Indeed, the book reflects the difficulty of dealing with ethical issues without some common point of view en consistent set of assumptions about how such values as survival, jusface, economy, and selffulfillment are to be defined and made explicit in the teal world.

title: The Region as Reliquary
description: The great prehistoric beast lumbered down a woodland path that someday would be called Broadway. it was a 10,000pound mastodon, standing nine feet high and 15 feet long, crunching its way along. Now and then it snaked an elephantlike trunk into the trees to rip off a branch of spruce needles and stuff them into its mouth.

description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 23Can Little Joe fend off Spaceman Jack?

title: Harry Trumanrevived and revised
description: Sketching out Harry Truman's strategy for the 1998 campaign, one his aides pointed to Truman's greatest political weakness. The President, said, did not exactly hold first place in the ranks of American heroes. That was an understatement. Even his upset victory over Tom Dewey brought improvement. The national joke remained, To err is Truman, and, by 1952, his popularity had reached an alltime low of 26 nercent.

title: Loopholes in RealEstate Rules
description: RULE changes for the realestate industry were recently outlined by Secretary of State Mario Cuomo in a misguided effort to aid consumers, he stands to bring chaos and disorder to one of the basic Long Island industries. Not only will he not help consumers, he may, indeed, make consumers more vulnerable to abuse.

title: The Big Effort in The Big States
description: WASHINGTONJames A. Farley, the strategic genius of the Roosevelt era, used to say that voters didn't change their minds after Labor Day. In the fifties, it was said, Mr. Farley to the contrary notwithstanding, that the voters didn't really concentrate on the campaign until after the World Series.

title: Indian Hill Stallion Triumphs
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 23Rymarkyrat, a 7yearold brown stallion owned by the Indian Hill Farms of Strafford, N. H., won the first Arabian Western pleasurehorse class tonight as the Washington International show got under way at the Capitol Centre.

title: Black Rhodesian Leaders On Way to Geneva Talks, Rivalries Still Unsettled
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Oct. 23 (Reuters)Three of the four black nationalist leaders invited to the Britishconvened conference on Rhodesia arrived in Dar es Salaam tonight en route to Geneva.

title: Battle in The Arctic Seas
description: If youlike Ensign Howard Carraway, though unlike the 35 cargo ships of Convoy PQ 17were young and seaworthy in June 1992 and crossing from Iceland to Archangel with war materiel for Russia, the chances were not very good that you would grow much older. Your ship's 30caliber machine guns (two fore, two aft) are no match for German submarines, the Luftwaffe and the battleship Tirpitz of course you have an escort, of sorts. And up ahead somewhere is a squadron of cruisers, an old battleship and an aircraft carrier. But they are going to be of little help ifas happened on the 4th of Julya message from the Admiralty orders the cruisers to withdraw and the convoy to scatter. Scatter is a terrifying word. it means you're on your own  no escort, no protection.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The first notes heard in the new Avery Fisher Hall before a full audience were the three the descending triad of The Star Spangled Banner. The concert was given last Monday for the construction workers who had labored in the hall since May, and some listeners with even more special interests than those of the construction workers were in the audience. There was the acoustician, Dr. Cyril Harris. There was Avery Fisher, whose money made it all possible. There was virtually the entire Philharmonic management. There were critics from all over the country. This concert was not to be written about; it was a preview of the official Tuesday opening. There even were a few Philharmonic musicians whose services were not needed for this concert. They too had plenty on their mind.

title: LEBANESE FIGHTING JEOPARDIZES MCE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 23Fighting today near the Israeli border in southern Lebanon posed a threat to the twodayold ceasefire in the civil war and created a new challenge to Arab heads of state who are to convene in Cairo on Monday to complete arrangements for a settlement of the crisis.

title: Paperbacks
description: BEYOND THE BEDROOM WALL, by Larry Woiwode. (Avon, $1.95.) The Neumillers traced through several generations in North Dakota and Illinois an uncommonly fine family novel.

description: WARSAW, Oct 23 (AP)American amateur boxers scored four victories and lost three bouts in the semifinals of an international tournament tonight.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE CONSUMER PRICE INDEX IN SEPTEMBER ROSE 0.4 PERCENT to 172.6 percent of the 1967 average. Food rose only 0.2 percent while services increased by 0.5 percent, the Labor Department reported  The growth rate of gross national product slowed to 4 percent in the third quarter according to the Department of Commerce in 1972 dollars, the rise was to $1,270 billion, from $1,260 billion in the second quarter in current dollars G. N. P. rose 8.5 Percent to $1,710 billion.

title: BOTH PARTIES PRESS CONNECTICUT DRIVES
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 21In the Connecticut campaign headquarters for Jimmy Carter on Asylum Avenue, map overlays are being drawn up to show the ethnic character of neighborhoods in the cities. When ceinvassers find that the residents are seripusly disaffected by or even suspicious of the oandidate, the neighborhood will be bypassed in the usual massive Democratic effort to get the city voters out on Election Day.

title: Rock, Roll & Remember
description: I played records, the kids danced, and America watched. Dick Clark's assessment of his success seems coolly evasive if not the least bit lofty in its simplicity. Yet, for nearly a decade from 1955 until late 1964he captivated the teenager's afternoon as announcer of a twoandonehalfhour collage of bobbysoxers feet and dangling ponytails moving in questionable rhythm to an even more questionable music. Today, one wonders how anything that rudimentary  including Clark's varnished wholesomenesscould exist. In fact, one network executive in the late 1950's said that if anyone would have come to him with the idea [for Band stand'], he'd have fired the man for being an idiot.

title: State Colleges and Leadership
description: THE president of a New Jersey state college must grapple with some rather special and local problems, as well as hear the burdens that all college and university presidents encounter these clays. Everywhere, presidential salaries and perquisites are good, but the hours are lane and the security distinctly lacking.

title: Robert Haines, Miss Bakewell Are Married

title: Robert Pyne Fiance Of Lisa A. Emmons

title: Battle Intensified Over Plan to Allow Casinos in Jersey
description: Amid increasingly bitter charges and countercharges, rosy promises and dire warnings, bewildering statistics and conflicting conclusions, New Jersey voters will decide Nov. 2 whether they want gambling casinos in Atlantic City.

title: Patrick Scatuorchio And Jean N. Gallatin To Marry in January
description: Jean Nissen Gallatin, whose ancestor Albert Gallatin was Secretary of the Treasury under President Thomas Jefferson, plans to be married in January to Patrick Scatuorchio.

title: Maine Indian Suit for Land Halts Bond Sales and Endangers Titles
description: CALAIS, Me., Oct. 23The Indians may legally own twothirds of Maine.

title: Chemist Finds Cooking Greatly Raises Toxicity of Carcinogenic Fungicide Used on Fruit and Vegetables
description: A widely used fruit and vegetable fungicide that collects in relatively harmless amounts on raw food crops can break down during the cooking proc ess and turn into a chemical that causes cancer and fetus deformities in animals, a Canadian chemist has found.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Ira Henry Freeman, whose articles have appeared in many magazines, was a reporter for The Times until his retirement in 1961.

title: Anthony Nears $100,000 For Second Year in Row
description: AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 23 (AP)The leading money winner on the Professional Bowlers Association tour, Earl Anthony, is headed for a second straight $100,000 year. The Tacoma, Wash. howler already has earned $91,158. Last week he won $1,250 for finishing in 13th place in a tournament in Minot, N. D.

title: Abbatiello Wins 3,000th
description: EST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 23Carmine Abbatiello tonight became the ninth driver in harness racing history to win 3,000 races when he steered Lucky Dapple $6.60. to a neck victory in the second race at the Meadowlands He was presented a sterling silver. plaque.

title: World News Briefs
description: LISBON, Oct. 23One of Portugal's revolutionary heroes, Maj. otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, was arrested today and ordered to serve 20 days in prison. An army spokesman said the radical leftist major had been arrested for expressing political views at a public meeting.

title: New jersey/This Week
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, South Munn and Central Avenues, East OrangeOthello. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Nov. 13). 53.5054.90; students and the elderly, 52.5053.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: If You Go
description: to Split and the Dalmatian coast during the fall or winter months, you will probably find the climate mild and sunny and hotels and other accommodations uncrowded. There are airports at Split and Dubrovnik, 140 miles to the south, with regular connections to most European cities. Steamers and car ferries connect the coast with Venice, Ancona, Pescara and Bari in Italy, across the Adriatic. Buses link Split with other towns along the coast.

title: Test Tube Babies
description: Dr. Douglas Bevis, professor of obstetrics and gynecology at Leeds University in England, created a sensation in July 1974, by telling members of the British Medical Association at a meeting that three babies born in Europe in the previous 18 months had been conceived in the laboratory. The ova, he indicated, were removed from the wouldbe mothers, were fertilized with sperm and the resulting embryos then placed in the women's wombs.

title: The essential Henry Miller, according to Norman Mailer
description: In The Colossus of Maroussi, that cranky and beautiful book about Greece, there are a number of passages which describe Henry Miller's encounters with Katsimbalis, a man once real and now imaginary, who is remade by Miller's inflationary prose into one of the more robust, unmannerly Greek gods. Katsimbalis is a monologist of genius very much like Miller himself, and the style of his talk matches our author's speech stream perfectly. Indeed, why shouldn't it, since the objects of Miller's incessant sentences are sounding boards which echo their origin by responding always Henree  Henreee to every shout.

title: MUSIC & DANCE
description: BAYSIDE  The Danscompany, with new works choreographed by Joyce Trisler; Saturday 8:15 P.M.; Queensborough Community College Theater. Tickets $3.50, $4 and $5. (212) 6316491.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your interesting economic review dispatch (Oct. 17) by Paul Lewis ties the lag in U.S. economy to world trends. it fails to note the obvious fact that these world trends are not an accidental mishap, Inflicted by some mysterious fate to punish mankind. They are the direct result of the victory of monetarismwhich wishes to fight inflation through general restrictive monetary policiesdue to the renewed dominance of the Central Bankers of the world exercised mainly through the International Monetary Fund over our economic destinies.

title: W.R. Reinus to Wed Elizabeth Forrestal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Forrestal Jr. of St. Louis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Katherine Forrestal, to William Ralph Reinus, son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis Z. Reinus of New York. The couple plan to he married in June in St. Louis.

title: A Few Have Had C.I.A. Training
description: WASHINGTONMost of the 600.000 Cubans who came to the United States after Fidel Castro seized power Havana have settled into normal lives. but perhaps 3,000 of them remain active antiCastro militants. And of that 3,000, a few hundred, and perhaps even fewer, according Washington sources, are still17 years laterstill carrying on terrorist activities against the Castro regime and anyone suspected of sympathizing with it.

title: New Move Started to Form Union
description: Almost all professional soccer players in this country will receive a note in the mail soon asking them for remarks, suggestions, points or recommendations about the formation of a players association. This will not be new. The same thing was done two years ago, but only two or three players responded.

title: Passes Griffin as Pitt Rolls by 450
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 23  Tony Dorsett became the leading ground gainer in majorcollege football history today when he carried for 180 yards against Navy and set a varsity career rushing record of 5,206 yards over four seasons at Pittsburgh.

title: Great men, great mission
description: The reputations of both Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill since their deaths, as in their lifetimes, have had their ups and downs, and in the last few years, especially in the case of Churchill, passed through something of a slump. Roosevelt has been variously criticized for contradictory reasons he deceived the Americans so as to lead them into World War II; he was dilatory in leading them into World War II; he was soft with Stalin; he and his Administration were responsible for starting the Cold War  and so on. Churchill has been presented by his critics, and even by some of his selfstyled friends, as man responsible for major strategic blunders, inconsiderate and tyrannical to his subordinates, petulant and childish, who betrayed the Poles and was unfair to General de Gaulle, a reactionary rhetorician inebriated, as Disraeli once said of Gladstone, with the exuberance of his own verbosity. Yet both men are great enough to survive the denigration which always follows the death of the famous; and, in an era in which the leading statesmen in Britain and America have been Sir Harold Wilson and Mr. Nixon, we can be forgiven a certain nostalgia for the grandeur of scale and epic qualities of Churchill Roosevelt.

title: 2 Chicago Newspaper Polls Show FordCarter Race Close in Illinois
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (UPI)The Chicago SunTimes Straw Poll, at the end of the first round of canvassing, showed today that President Ford had pulled to within 3.6 percentage points of Jimmy Carter in Illinois.

title: Transkei Bridles at Diplomatic Isolation
description: UMTATA, South Africa, Oct. 20The Transkei, independent next Tuesday, will not be the first underdeveloped state to come to nationhood with several of its major opposition figures in jail, its leaders publicly accused of corruption, and its treasury dependent on huge subsidies from the colonial power.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor In his review of Arthur Koestler's The Thirteenth Tribe (Aug. 29) Fitzroy Maclean credits Koestler with a new, tenable and highly intriguing theory  that racially the great majority of Eastern European Jews were not Jews at all, but TurkoKhazars, and second that, as most Western Jews came from Eastern Europe, most of them are not Jews either, that in fact there are few truly Semitic Jews anywhere. The theory that Maclean attributes to Koestler is hardly new (Koestler himself mentions earlier sources) and by no means accepted among scholars. Also, as Maclean and Koestler fail to mention, it has appeared in lunatic fringe antiSemitic propaganda for decades. Writing in the North American Review in March 1926, for example, Hiram Wesley Evans, imperial wizard of the then substantial Ku Klux Klan denigrated the Eastern Jews of recent immigration, the Jews known as the Askenasim [sic]. it is interesting to note that anthropologists now tell us that these are not true Jews, but only Judaized MongolsChazars. These, unlike the true Hebrew, show a divergence from the American type so great that there seems little hope of their assimilation.

title: POLITICS
description: RALPH G. CASO, the Nassau County Executive, sounded as if he was warming up for next year's. reelection campaign. I am fighting for the people, he said recently as he served up a batch of statistics on the salaries of policemen to support his opposition to a 1975 police raise that the Republican official has been resisting for nearly two years.

title: Briton Adjusts To a New Life With Few Frills
description: LONDON, Oct. 22Ted Brandon is not a bitter man. He is merely puzzled, in a detached sort of way. to discover that at the age of 57 he is further away from enjoying the good things in life than he was 10 years ago.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor This letter refers to the article encl. tied The Shah in New York (Sept 26) and the corrections thereof that appeared in the same section (Oct. 3) We believe that fairness requires further clarification.

title: Youth 4Length Victor In Canadian Turf Race
description: TORONTO, Oct. 23 (AP)Youth, the 3yearold French turf champion owned by Nelson Bunker Hunt, scored an easy fourlength victory today over Improviser in the $191,000 Canadian International Championship Stakes.

title: Endpaper
description: This page is an exercise in origami, the art that began in Japan more than a thousand years ago and, since then, has delighted the likes of Shelley, Lewis Carroll and Miguel De Unamuno. Although paper folding is in itself a satisfying activity, this model may be particularly appropriate to the current election campaign, when more than a few voters might appreciate the wherewithal to do some talking back.

title: Small Jersey Crowd Gives Carter a Chilly Welcome
description: NORTH BERGEN, N. J., Oct. 23Jimmy Carter received a chilly and undersized welcome in New Jersey today when he appeared at a get out the vote rally at Scheutzen Park.

title: Eurocommunism
description: The Italian and French Communist parties are now the leading examples of what has come to be called Eurocommunism. This rightist deviation, as Moscow calls it, claims indendence from the Soviet Union, asserts patriotic loyalty, and generally strives for an image of responsibility, autonomy and devotion to democracy.

title: Debate, Rated as Even, is Viewed As Having Little Effect on Race
description: The third and final debate between President Ford and Jimmy Carter, which had been viewed as a potentially conclusive confrontation in their race for the Presidency, was being seen yesterday as unlikely to have much effect on the course of the campaign in its nine remaining days.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market wound up last week with a small gain in slower trading. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced in the first three trading days, then declined in the remaining two. The average closed on Friday at 938.75, up 1.75 points for the week. Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange, fell to 83.62 million shares from 89.34 million shares the week before.

title: I,R,A. YOUTHS TAUNT BELFAST MARCHERS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 23About 12,000 supporters of the women's peace movement, singing We Shall Overcome amid volleys of mud, stones and taunts by I.R.A. youths, marched through Belfast. yesterday to urge an end to sectarian violence.

title: The Family Leader Used an Effective Collegial Approach
description: On May 10, 1963, Accursio Marinelli and Michael Scandifia, both members of the Carlo Gambino crime family, went to see another member, Peter Ferrara, at his Brooklyn office, which, unknown to any them. was bunged by the police.

title: THE MARQUISE OF O
description: People who go to movies very seldom, if ever, are the first ones to swoop down, pigeonlike, when you're in an exposed social situation to tell you how awful movies are these days and how  we  just  never  go  anymore  because  there's  nothing  to  see  is  there? At least that's what happens to me, and if it's been a long day I find the best way to avoid being mousetrapped is to say yes. It's not a foolproof defense against boredom, though. Such people feel very strongly about their ignorance and they will defend to the death their right to agree with you at endless length. Sometimes the only way out is to announce an acute case of stomach cramps, but that means you have to leave the party.

title: The Man Who Lost China
description: Chiang Kaishek dominated the Chinese Nationalist regime, with few and minor interruptions, from its formal consolidation in power in 1928 until his death in 1975. From the beginning, he confronted enemies in the domestic arena other military men and revolutionaries in 1931, Japanese imperialism began its advance onto the Asian mainland, and then, in 1937, the SinoJapanese conflict became a war. The attack at Pearl Harbor in 1941 hurled the United States into warfare with Japan and made it, all involuntarily, an ally of Chiang's autocratic regime in due course, controversy developed between Generalissimo Chiang and the American side in respect to the conduct of their common war, with one issue being whether sonic American arms should be supplied to the Chinese Communist faction, who were also fighting the Japanese.

title: A.A.U. Sets 1977 Sites For Wrestling and Luge
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 23 (AP)Sites for the 1977 wrestling and luge championships have been announced by the National Amateur Athletic Association.

title: Barbara Cuiffo is Married
description: Barbara Susan Cuiffo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Cuiffo of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Mark David McCarthy, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. McCarthy of Yonkers. The Rev. William J. Boldt performed the mass in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. The bride is a salespromotion coordinator for Americana Hotels. Her husband is a computer analyst with the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 23President Ford appealed today for a mandate from the South, but his strategists pinned his election hopes on a $4 million television and radio blitz keyed to the major industrial states.

title: Howard Hughes's MultimillionDollar Borrowings Reported to Have Been Part of Plan to Cut Income Taxes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23The unexplained large borrowings that Howard R. Hughes made at Houston banks about three months before he died were part of a plan the billionaire industrialist followed to cut his personal income taxes, according to sources familiar with his affairs.

title: Alain Tanner: Art is to Break With the Past
description: The Swiss film industry came to town for a visit the other day. His name is Alain Tanner, he is 46 years old, earns $15,000 a year (About what your Hollywood electricians make, he said wryly), and is the director of Jonah Who Will Be 25 in the Year 2000, which was one of the most warmly received films at. the recent New York Film Festival and is now playing at the Fine Arts Theater.

title: Taking License With Plates
description: THE closet egotist, aching to proclaim his name, utter small message, offer a comment or even release a sigh, has a friend at the New Jersey Division of Motor Vehicles.

title: For Students, Main Difference Was in Candidates and Images
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 23  It was past 1 o'clock in the morning in a dormitory at the College of William and Mary, where a group of students had been carefully and astutely analyzing their own responses to President Ford and Jimmy Carter as television personalities for more than two hours.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP).T. Edgar Hoover's supporters are raising a halfmillion dollars for a monument and scholarship fund honoring the man who was the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Director for 48 years.

title: NEW VIETNAM POLICY SEEN TO BE EVOLVING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The newly unified Government of Vietnam, after summer of conciliatory moves toward its Southeast Asian neighbors, appears to have returned to a tough posture to exert influence there.

description: One of the most glamourous items in Uncle Sam's catalog of surplus goods suprirtr United Statesis going on the auction block again next month. The 52.072 gross ton liner, the world's fastct passenger ship. has been in mothballs since No vember 1969, when she was withdrawn from trans. Atlantic service by her owners, United States Lines, for lack of business.

description: FOR a growing number of young craftsman and entrepreneurs, downtown Newark, with its low rents and abundance of space, has become a popular place to open stores. The result is a delightful assortment of flourishing boutiques offering oneofakind items that often sell for much less than one would expect to nay in a more chic location.

description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 23 (UPI)South African riot squads opened fire today on black mourners who police say had turned a schoolgirl's funeral in the black ghetto of Soweto into a demonstration, killing one mourner and wounding another.

description: FREEPORT, L.I., Oct. 23The Freeport School District, which adopted an austerity program after three budget defeats, has challenged the constitutionality of a state law that declares that districts on austerity may not provide school supplies for pup?? and nust bill the parents for the supplies.

title: Study is Sought on the Practice and Safety of DrugInduced Births
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 20The director of New York City's maternity and familyplanning services called today for a citywide study on electively induced laborthe practice of giving drugs to women to allow them to have babies at times convenient to doctor and mother.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONIn any year the preparation of the Federal budget by the White House is an act of creative imagination that, at best, gives rough shape to the getting and spending pattern that emerges later from Congress. When, as now, the President and Congress represent different parties, the Presidential budget can be as much a wish list as an economic documentparticularly since the introduction of the new Congressional budget control process.

title: Joanne Kelly Adds TV to Dancing
description: If memory serves, tiny television monitors began to make a timid appearance in dances during the early 60's, as an adjunct to movement activity. They were nothing fancy, merely showing black and white pictures on tiny 12 inch Screens.

title: If You Can Be a Superstar?
description: It may seem a modest proposal in view of the seriousness of the problem but perhaps a law should be passed prohibiting extremely gifted young musicians from taking up conducting. It could be at best only a first step; next the legislatures of the world would have to crack down on youthful offenders in pianism and other branches of musical performance. For, as this frustrated listener has come to believe, the presentday emphasis on Nirtuosic performance has resulted in a skimmingoff of the cream of musical talent, leaving the most important activity, composing, to be practiced by more modestly gifted people.

title: Portuguese Air Force Dismisses 15 Workers For Internal Agitation
description: LISBON, Oct. 23The Portuguese Air Force announced today that it had dismissed 15 workers from its general maintenance shop for internal agitation and excessive absenteeism and will take lesser sanctions against other workers.

description: SHORTLY before the Democratic Presidential campaign began in earnest across the country, the Democratic National Committee in Washington established new voterregistration goals for states like New Jersey. description: With toe election nine days away, two Democrats, Jimmy Carter and Daniel P. Moynihan, are running ahead of President Ford and Senator James L. Buckley in New York, according to a New York Times survey.

description: WASHINGTONWith considerable fanfare, Jimmy Carter sent President Ford a telegram last weekend accusing the President of making misleading and erroneous statements about the Carter taxation and spending proposals.

title: Awards Are Presented At Unusual Convocation Of the City University
description: A medal for Ira Gershwin, the lyricist; honorary doctorates for three other New Yorkers for achievements in journalism, science and education, and 235 other degrees were presented by the City University's Graduate Center on Friday in an unusual fall academic convocation.

description: Seaford continued to eliminate its opposition in Nassau Conference V. The latest victim was Glen Cove, which dropped a 4120 decision yesterday after Seaford rolled to a 346 lead at the half.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Speed up on bulb planting and evergreen transplanting. Store patio containers in a dry frostfree place, especially ceramic and clay pots. Put away lawn furniture and vegetable stakes. Clean up perennial borders and finish dividing.

description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's fascinating Lepercq Space, a big barnlike, brickwalled area that, with the judicious addition of tiered movable seating and batteries of lights, has been made into a handsome hall for performances of various kinds, was filled with the music of Handel on Friday night as the Tarack Chamber Ensemble began a series of four concerts there.

title: ART
description: PORT WASHINGTON THE exhibition of Charlotte Brown's art at the Central Hall Gallery substantively rebuts the misguided notion that New York City is the country's only center for esthetic experimentation. Some of the art world's elitists assert that artists in the hinterlands merely wait for artistic conceits to be established in New York before trying them on their own.

title: CARTER IS SUED BY CRITIC OF CAMPAIGN FUNDS LAW
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 23 (AP)A selfstyled tax protester filed an $88 million damage suit against the Democratic Presidential nominee, Jimmy Carter, yesterday, challenging the Federal campaign financing law under which he said Mr. Carter had received $24 million.

title: Hankyu Wins Series Opener

title: MOVIE MAILBAG
description: To the Editor In Francois TruffautA Man for All Festivals (Sept. 26), some rather unkind remarks about producer Julia Phillips were attributed to Mr. Truffaut. Knowing him as I do, it is hard for me to believe that he said these things.

title: Newspapers Honor Rep. Pike
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 22 (AP)Representative Otis G. Pike, Democrat of Riverhead, L.I., has been named recipient of the New York State Thomas Jefferson Award for his efforts to promote press freedom and curb government secrecy. The award was announced today by the New York State Publishers Association, a statewide organization of daily newspapers, and the New York Press Association, the state organization of weekly newspapers.

title: Putting Style Into the Book Business

The high rises are packed with the highest concentration of high income, highly educated people in the world. Half the people in the publishing industry in the country live within walking distance.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Bad Scene at Yankee Stadium
description: To the Sports Editor Your Yankee baseball team was spectacular in its playoff series performance. The Yankees are a very exciting, wellorganized and welldisciplined team. Too had you don't have fans to match. Their behavior was embarrassinga total disgrace to any American. Their display of atrocious manners was almost sacrilegious in the most hallowed of baseball grounds, and it absolutely ruined an otherwise thrilling series.

title: Duke Routed By Maryland, 303. in A.C.C.
description: DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 23 (AP)Mark Manges threw two touchdown passes to Bob Raba and scored once himself in leading Maryland to a 303 victory over Duke in an Atlantic Coast Conference game today.

title: Schools: When More is Less
description: WE can no longer afford our public schools, at least not as the system is presently structured. Since the end of World War II, the increases in costs for education have been phenomenal, and the expenditures continue to mount relentlessly. Every year, as school budgets are prepared, the cry from teachers, school administrators, boards of education and parentteacher organizations is for more. Then, soon after each school year begins, teachers, principals and other members of the education Establishment decry the inadequacy of books, supplies and equipment on hand. They declare the insurmountability of their tasks without additional personnel and new materials. The parentteacher organization, already compromised by its teacher membership in terms of independent thinking and discussion with regard to school needs, is further lobbied by the school administrators so that parents, too, pick up the hue and cry that the schools cannot operate without more.

title: A Legacy far SmallTown America
description: THE constitutional legacy of our forefathers is alive and well in smalltown America, visavis freedom of the press. Tragically, this reaffirmation of civic commitment is oc??sionally necessary because one often looks around himself and asks, 'Does anyone really care where our country, state or community is going? The answerin our few acres of Americawould seem to be yes.

description: Tim Wilson soored the winning touchdown on a sneak from the 1 with 3 seconds to play yesterday to keep Long Branch among the unbeaten with a 26.22 victory over Ocean Township in Ocean.
