title: Dartmouth Strikes Early,Trounces Cornell
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 23An imaginative Dartmouth eleven, seeking to keep its chances alive for at least a part of the Ivy League crown, swept over Cornell today with an easy 350 victory before about 11,000 spectators at chilly Schoelkoof Field.

title: Everybody a writer
description: Lore Segal has written her way out of a long silence between adult fictions. The quite splendid Other People's Houses was published in 1964. Since then there have been two children's books (Tell Me a Mitzi, All the Way Home), translations (of Christian Morgenstern and the Brothers Grimm), occasional essays and book reviews. And now, at last, Lucinellaa funny, nervous, affecting novel about a poet trying and failing to bring some order to her life and craft.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: You drive for show and putt for dough  the scoring zone is the last 50 yards to the hole. it's a game of finesse, not a masculinity contest. Having said and accepted all that, the supreme kick in golf is still pounding the ball past your playing partners off the tee.

title: Albany to Lower Medicaid Rates; Reimbursement Off by $2 Million
description: The State Department of Health yesterday issued medical reimbursement rates for 539 nursing homes and 224 healthrelated facilities, calling for 1976 outlays totaling $995 million, or about $2 million less than in 1975.

description: IN NASSAU.

title: Criminals At Large
description: A good espionage novel in the Eric Ambler style is TO DIE ELSEWHERE by Theodore Wilden (Harcourt Brace, Jovanovich, 57.95). This is the American debut of a Greekborn writer currently resident in London. The hero is a spy who works for a rather mysterious private intelligence agency. He is a very modern kind of agent, complete with Weltschmerz, cynicism and vast experience.

title: STAMPS
description: A stamp for the pretzel industry with a beerflavored gummed side, a stamp for the hamburger and the pickle, a stamp for Lassie, a stamp for the first chimpanzee in outer spacethese are just some of the ideas for new commemoratives that pour in by the hundreds to the United States Postal Service.

title: JOBLESS YUGOSLAVS MOVING TO SLOVENIA
description: LJUBLJANA, YugoslaviaWith the problem of unemployment in Yugoslavia growing, pressure is intensifying on prosperous Slovenia to provide jobs for the whole Communist nation.

title: Richard Morse's Mime Theater Has Poetry of the Commonplace
description: The Richard Morse Mime Theater is an excellent mime group that was reportedly formed five years ago by Mr. Morse but has never had a major showing in New York on Friday night, the sevenmember ensemble put its goods on display at Town Hall and carried its youthful audience along on a crest of hilarity.

title: Georgian Mutes Attack on Ford in Virginia and Jersey Rallies
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 23Jimmy Carter renewed his pleas today for apathetic or uncertain voters to cast their ballots on Nov. 2.

title: Shopping at a Fairfor a College
description: UNIONDALE TEENAGERS and their parents crammed into the Nassau Coliseum one night last week, picked up plastic carrying bags and snaked their way through 410 booths. They carefully auestioned the people. behind the tables while selecting literature and placing it in their bags. One dominant thought that was on everyone's mind througherit the night was How much does it cost?

title: N.Y.M.A. Downs Riverdale On Crunching Attack, 2612
description: New York Military Academy, using its two most effective weapons, the hurtling bodies of Emmett Richardson and Carlos Cabrera, defeated Rrverclale, 2612, yesterday at home. Richardson scored twice on the ground, from 80 and 21 yards out, and passed 18 yards to Hugo Anosike for another touchdown in N.Y.M.A.'s fifth victory in six tries. Cabrera added 136 yards and a touchdown to run his totals for the year to 759 yards and 11 scores. Riverdale has four victories and two losses.

title: Hardcover Report
description: The bookseller is the living link between the author and the reader. He is also the agent of the publisher who consigns him hardcover hooks at a discount that usually runs around 40 percent, with the understanding that the bookseller can return unsold books. Returns currently average about 17 percent.

title: Battered Jets Are Faced With Opportunistic Colts
description: If it weren't for the Colts passing game, running attack and defense, the Jets wouldn't have a thing to worry about today.

title: An Invasion Of Open Plazas That Aren't
description: On the southeast corner of 54th Street and First Avenue there is a luxury highrise tower called The Revere. Going into the plaza, which has a sign warning ballplayers and dogwalkers to stay out, one has to walk past the main entrance to the building. When I did, a doorman came rushing out and informed me that only tenants were allowed in the plaza. I responded that he was wrong, that the plaza is open to the public and that I was within my rights to enter it. He said that I better get a lawyer first and then went into the building, presumably to get someone else to persuade me to leave.

title: Ways to Improve Job Conditions Outlined by Corporate Psychologist
description: A vast majority of working people, not only those on production lines but in management as well, feel underutilized, leading to job frustration and limited motivation, according to Dr. William A. Snow, a psychologist and corporate official.

description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 20People expect a lot from a Presidential race. Robert Handy remarked the other day as he prepared to climb aboard the stationary bicycle he keeps in his office at Democratic headquarters here to work off the tensions of the campaign.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The police throughout New Jersey are planning to increase patrols to discourage vandalism and excessive mischiefs on Halloween night next Sunday. It's a time most cops dread, a police officer in Old Bridge said. The Nutley Police Chief, Francis T. Buel, said, We want everyone to know that there is no such thing as mischief night in Nutley. We will double the number of people on the streets and vandals will be arrested.

title: New York City Upheld on Right to Require Window Guards to Protect Small Children
description: A State Supreme Court justice last week gave approval to the New York City Board of Health to enforce a regulation, that requires the installation of window guards in virtually all apartments in the city where there are children under 10 years of age.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A firebomb was hurled at the Tunisian mission to the United Nations early yesterday morning, causing little damage and no injuries. A militant Jewish organization later asserted that it was responsible for the act, saying: Tunisia, like all Arab countries, supports the Nazistyle extermination of three million Israeli Jews. A statement from the group, Save Our Israel, also condemned the Conference of Presidents of American Jewish Organizations for their cowardly silence as the United States withholds arms promised to Israel. The police said the bomb went off at about 3:30 A.M. at the mission, at 40 East 71st Street, scorching the exterior of the building but causing no damage inside.

title: Staubach Hurtas Cowooys Sink Bears, 3121
description: DALLAS, Oct. 24The Dallas Cowboys, winning their sixth game in seven tries, tucked the Chicago Bears away today, 3121, and then began to wait. They were waiting for tomorrow night's game in Washington, where the Redskins will take on the St. Louis Cardinals, and also on Roger Staubach, their star quarterback, who has fractured bone in his passing hand.

title: Old English jumping Victor
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 26 Old English, owned by Mr and Mrs. Patrick Butler of St. Paul, turned back 30 rivals and won the first openinternational jumping class tonight at the Washington International horse show at the Capital Centre. Old English, ridden by Conrad Homfeld, was timed in 45.8 seconds with a clean round. Do Right, handled by Dennis Murphy of the United States Equestrian Team, was secmid, also clean, in 47.2.

title: First Check of Bronx Club Shows No City Building or Fire Violation
description: A first check of available data indicated yesterday that the twostory Bronx building where 25 persons died in an earlymorning fire yesterday had neither New York City Buildings Department nor Fire Department violations pending.

description: Collectors of free political buttons are finding poor pickings this year. Restrictions on campaign spending have resulted in smaller orders for buttons, but that is not the only reason for the scarcity, according to Al Cohen, who has been producing political campaign buttons since 1938.

The life of the famed aviator is traced, sometimes in plodding detail, from childhood in Kansas City to her disappearance over the Pacific in 1937 on a roundtheworld flight.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Federal Bureau of Investigation has asserted that more than ??? ??? ??? informers, concerned that their identities may become public through various inquiries into the bureau's activities, have broken off contact with the bureau over the last three months.

description: We discuss below a few Congressional contests throughout the nation that give every indication of being close and that we believe to be of particular significance. We omit reference to contests in the metropolitan area, which have previously been discussed on this page.

title: CORNELL NAMES A WOMAN TO NEW LANDGRANT POST
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 24Cornell University has named Constance E. Cook, a former Assemblywoman here, as its first vice president for landgrant affairs.

J., Oct. 24There were 6,657 noshows today for the Giants second game in their new stadiumand that's not counting the Giants offense, which failed to show anything in a 270 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers, the team's seventh straight without a victory this National Football League season.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 23One of the great taboos for American women is to think or talk about money, according to Elizabeth Forsling Harris, cofounder of Ms magazine.

description: LANSING, Mich., Oct. 23To hear the voice of June Prince, a secretary in one of the newest and busiest state offices here, is to learn that Michigan history is repeating itself in a big way.

description: On the eve of preliminary talks at the Geneva conference on Rhodesia, the danger of an early impasse increased. Speaking with reporters, spokesmen for the white minority Government and the black nationalists took deeply conflicting positions on transitional arrangements for eventual black majority rule. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: All Things to All Men
description: RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 24The most telling charge made against Jimmy Carter has been that he tries to be all things to all men. In a nice twist of irony, when Mr. Ford makes the charge, he cautiously tips his hat to the feminists and changes the accusation to all things to all people.

title: Miss Penn, Concert Aide, Bride of Michael Posnick
description: Eileen Penn, assistvnt to the president of Kazuko Hillyer International, concert managers was married yesterday to Michael Posnick, a drama instructor with the National Theater Institute in Waterford, Conn. Rabbi Richard Davis performed the ceremony with Cantors Herman Abramson and Kalman Kalich at the home of Mr and Mrs. Ascher Penn of New York, parents of the bride.

title: Man Sailing the World is Missing
description: Robert Gainer, who left New York Oct 2 seeking to become the first American to circle the world nonstop in a sailboat, may have disappeared in the Bermuda Triangle, the Coast Guard reported yesterday. A spokesman said it was very likely the sloop might have sunk in the triangle, an area off Bermuda where several ships have mysteriously disappeared.

title: Beame, at Breakfast Of a Police Group, Is Target of Boos
description: Mayor Beame, Police Commissioner Michael T. Codd and the heads of the Patrolmen's and Sergeants Benevolent Associations were booed yesterday when they were introduced at a midmorning police breakfast at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Voters in New York Face 60 Races In State Senate and 150 in Assembly
description: When the New York State Legislature adjourned in July and the campaign for control of the 1977 Legislature began, the Democrats hoped that a landslide by Jimmy Carter might give them the five additional seats they need to win control of the State Senate the same way Lyndon B. Johnson's 2.5 millionvote margin in the state gave them control of the Senate in 1964.

title: FORD'S FINAL DRIVE REFLECTS OPTIMISM
description: FOUNTAIN VALLEY, Calif., Oct. 24President Ford invited more than 25,000 Californians here today to attend the inaugural ceremonies in Washington next Jan. 20. The invitation echoed one he issued yesterday, telling audiences in three Southern states, Y'all come.

title: Lynyrd Skynyrd With 3 Guytarysts, Rocks at Palladium
description: Originality is at a premium in contemporary rock. One can use only so many melodies and chord combinations without crossing the borderline to jazz, and the polyrhythmic elaborations of the big beat one finds in New Orleans rhythmandblues or reggae seem to be too difficult for most rock rhythm sections to play, or for most rock fans to respond to. The number of guitarists who can deliver authoritatively the riffs Keith Richard learned from Chuck Berry is reaching massive proportions.

title: 'Seven-Per-Cent Solution' Movie An Exhilarating Collector's Item
description: After two months in virtual seclusion. Sherlock Holmes summons his old friend and biographer, Dr. Watson, to his rooms in Baker Street. Dr. Watson, settled family man that he has become, is shocked by both the manner and the appearance of Holmes. He has always been thin but he is now rail-like. Worse, though, is Holmes's behavior. Either he has become a lunatic or he has stumbled onto the grandest criminal conspiracy of his career.His door bolted against the evil lurking outside. Holmes strides about his untidy, gas-lit study talking in disjointed fashion about a certain Professor Moriarty, a genius, a philosopher, an 'abstract thinker, a fiend of fiends whose existence Holmes has been in the process of deducing for the last two months. The name of Moriarty means nothing to Watson."There's the genius and the wonder of the thing," exclaims Holmes, his eyes lighting up like the windows in an empty house one suddenly discovers to be haunted. "The man pervades London, the Western world, even," he says, "and no one has ever heard of him!" At which point Watson notices the empty syringe on Holmes's desk. His friend has passed into the uncharted outer reaches of cocaine madness. Watson must act at once.The adventure is called "The Seven-Per-Cent Solution," which, as adapted by Nicholas Meyer from his best-selling novel and directed and produced by Herbert Ross, is nothing less than the most exhilarating entertainment of the film year to date. Mr. Meyer and Mr. Ross have taken a few small liberties with the book (which are all to the good) but the essential conceit remains.That is that Watson, in a desperate effort to save Holmes's life, must somehow get Holmes to Vienna for treatment by a new young doctor named Sigmund Freud, and that Holmes and Freud, two of the greatest minds of their time, join forces to solve a diabolical plot involving a beautiful, red-haired musical comedy star, an arrogant, dishonorable German baron, an amorous Turkish pasha and a great train chase through Austria to the very borders of the Ottoman Empire.The film, which opened yesterday at the Plaza Theater, is popular movie-making at its most stylish. It's simultaneously contemporary in its sensibility and faithful to the courtly mood and decent spirit of the Sir Arthur Conan Doyle originals. It's also one of the most handsome evocations of a vanished period (circa 1890) since "Murder on the Orient Express," and a collector's item in terms of performances.Nicol Williamson creates an entirely new Sherlock Holmes within our memories of all the old ones a man of incomparable mental brilliance who walks the world pursued by the hallucinations of his addiction. Alan Arkin is the good Dr. Freud at the beginning of his career, somewhat shy of manner immensely kind, and a little self-conscious about discussing the latest theories that have been getting him into hot water all over Vienna.Laurence Olivier is marvelous as Professor Moriarty, an extremely tentative, timid old fellow to be such a tycoon of crime, and Vanessa Redgrave is the unfortunate lady whose beauty drives mad those men who are rich and powerful.The particular revelation of "The Seven-Per-Cent Solution" is Robert Duvall, one of America's best actors, who plays the English Dr. Watson with such wit and control that it's difficult to believe he's ever played an American with equal conviction. It's a very funny performance, and very important to the overall shape and cohesion of the film.Not since John Huston's "The Man Who Would Be King" and Sidney Lumet's "Murder on the Orient Express" has there been a new film that manages so successfully to recall the innocent qualities one associates with pre-World War II movies without being simple-minded or instant camp. The initial credit must go to Mr. Meyer, whose novel is a fine piece of literary fooling, but Mr. Ross has been equally clever and disciplined in ealizing its screen potential. It's by far the best work he's done to date."The Seven-Per-Cent Solution" has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), which is a way of alerting parents of small children to a fuzzily photographed primal-scene conclusion, some slightly nightmarish scenes involving Holmes's cocaine cure, and a sequence in a Viennese bordello that, when I was 5 years old. I would have instantly recognized as a lively, eccentric hotel.

By the time next Sunday arrives, composers from 28 countries will have been heard.

The figures showed that the growth rate for the first nine months of 1976 was 4.8 percent, compared with 5 percent for the first six months of the year.

Observers called it a market feeding upon itself, with speculators only willing to sell to take profits and later to buy in again. The record price, reached Thursday was $1.273,1 a pound, and on Friday prices soared to $1282/10.

My little girl was a saint to me. Don't tell me that you have taken her away. I don't want to hear it! No, I don't want to hear it!

She pulls right up to the curb every time. Well, I never. She's s little. I never rode with a woman driver before. That little girl working with all those men. Well, I never thought I'd live to see the day.

description: In what she described as an unusual move on her part, Svetlana Alliluyeva Peters, the only daughter of Stalin, has written the Shah of Iran asking him not to allow a defecting Soviet pilot to be returned to the Soviet Union.

description: RIOHACHA, Colombia, Oct. 20Vast drug smuggling has turned the Atlantic coast of Colombia into a terrorized region of criminal organizations, violent Indians and corrupt officials. The law is weak, and life is cheap.

description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 24 (AP) Dr. Benjamin M. Spock, the pediatrician whose books on baby care have earned him international fame, was married today to Mary Morgan Councille of Little Rock.

title: Twenty Years After
description: Wide attention is properly being paid these days to the anniversary of the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. That may seem strange to many, as the revolution itself lasted less than two weeks from the first street demonstration to the Soviet invasion that restored Moscow's control. The man installed in power in Budapest by Soviet tanks, Janos Kadar, is still there. Hungary is so completely a Soviet satellite that Hungarian troops were required to participate in the invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968. Skeptics may well ask why the anniversary of a short, abortive uprising should be honored in the democratic world.

title: Steepest Drop Since May Leaves Bond Outlook Hazy
description: The bond market last week suffered its biggest setback since May as interest rates rose sharply for the first time since Memorial Day.

title: 7 Shipwreck Victims Found
description: HALIFAX Nova Scotia, Oct 24 (Reuters)A raft with the bodies of six men and a woman who abandoned the Dutch freighter Gabriella during a storm last Tuesday washed up near St. Shott's, Newfoundland, today. All 15 people aboard the vessel when she was abandoned about 60 miles southwest of Cape Race, Newfoundland, are now accounted for. Only two crew members survived.

description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Oct. 24 (AP) Wreckage of a Cuban jetliner that crashed early this month, killing all 73 persons aboard, was located today by a British Navy frigate using sonar equipment, a government official said.

These were thoughtful essays, couched in luminous prose and written for the most part, by authors in the press box who could only imagine the creature comforts they described. Well, yesterday was raw and rainy and New York's pro football teams are not altogether irresistible magnets. It seemed a good day to rediscover what a 19inch game looked like, measured diagonally.

title: Quality of Justice
description: Justice is dispensed in a society in many different ways. Sometimes it is the policeman on the beat or in the stationhouse who decides for an accused individual whether the society is just or not. Sometimes it is a district attorney and at other times it is a state judge or a group of judges in a district who set the legal atmosphere. But no matter how large a role a single official or set of institutions may play in any given area, in the broad sweep of American society it is the Supreme Court that determines how rich or how thin the atmosphere of justice is to be. The Board of Governors of the Society of American Law Teachers asserted recently that the current Court is diluting the atmosphere for justice in this country by cutting back on the ability of a wide variety of claimants to be heard in the Federal courts.

title: New Books Suggest That Animals May Be SelfAware

title: Ford Committee is Said to Have Considered Giving Money to McCarthy After His AntiCarter Remarks
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 24James A. Baker 3d, President Ford's campaign manager, made no effort to deny that, when Republican headquarters heard what Eugene J. McCarthy was saying about Jimmy Carter, the President Ford Committee gave serious thought to putting some money into Mr. McCarthy's Povertystricken independent candidacy. It would have been perfectly legal, Mr. Baker told reporters when the subject came up the other day. And, in fact, it might never have become public if Ford finance people had simply and quietly urged wellwishers to direct their checks to the McCarthy campaign.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: This year few political observers and columnists have failed to cite voter apathy over the contest between President Ford and Governor Carter. To be sure, the low interest is a real and severe problem, but the causes seem to be misunderstood. It has become commonplace to conclude that the apathy is a direct result of the lackluster and uninspiring discussion of the real issues facing us. The candidates are portrayed as having made the strategic decision to avoid any meaningful discussion of the issues. But the facts seem otherwise.

title: Hand of the Police Seen in Yugoslav Political Trials
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 24Our case seemed so solid, I thought maybe just once there would be a fair trial, a young woman choked through tears as policemen led her father away to begin a long prison term. I guess I should have known better.

title: Arab League Ministers in Cairo Agree on Lebanon Peace Force;
description: CAIRO, Monday, Oct. 25The Foreign Ministers of most of the major Arab countries today approved the creation of a multinational Arab peacekeeping force lof 30.000 troops to be sent to Lebanon.

title: New Book Says Lenin Spared Czar's Wife and Daughters

Were Czar Nicholas II, his son, his wife and four daughters massacred by the Bolsheviks in a cellar at Ekaterinburg in the Urals? Or did some members of the family disappear and live for months, perhaps years, after their capture?

I have been following the Presidential campaigns, and I think I have been deprived of my right to a decent election. The American people will elect a Presidenta Commander in Chief; a political leader; a spiritual leader. And what will be on the minds of the voters?

The sighting was made in the remote wash flats of the Assateague Island wildlife refuge by Dr. F. Prescott Ward, an ornithologist, and was verified by Claudia Wilds.

description: NEW HAVEN  With the plays of Sam Shepard it is the withheld information and the ellipsis as much as the revealed truths and the rambunctious humor that hold us. In Suicide in B Flat. which recently joined the fall repertory at the Yale Repertory Theater  it is one of four new Shepard plays scheduled for production at various theaters this season  the author is even more mysterious than usual. This is Mr. Shepard at his most tantalizing.

description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 24 (Reuters)Three blacks were killed and dozens injured when police officers fired submachine guns and shotguns into a crowd at a funeral in the black township of Soweto today, a police spokesman Said. Reporters at the scene said there were six dead.

title: Pauline V. Hoving, Wife Of the Tiffany Executive, Dies After a Long Illness
description: Pauline Vandervoort Hoving, wife of Walter Having, chairman of the board of Tiffany & Company, died Saturday after a long illness at Klingenstein Pavilion of Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: Television
Canucks Pin A 54 Loss On Rangers
description: The Vancouver Canucks took their 54 victory over the Rangers last night at Madison Square Garden as a sign of recovery, but the future bodes ill for the New Yorkers, who again suffered from a lack of defensive strength and strategy.

title: WEAL THY FRENCIIMEN NOW IN PUBLIC EYE
description: PARIS, Oct. 22The French, whose, country is the world's fourth richest, are abandoning their traditional, if suspicious, respect for secret wealth and demanding to be told, publicly, who owns France.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The New York Times/John Leone

title: OLIVE COLE HOPKINS
description: Olive Cole Hopkins, a public healt& nurse in Carmel, N.Y., since 1927 who founded the Putnam County, District Nursing Association, died Saturday iii Northern Westchester Hospital Center: She was 76 years old, the widow of Azoit Hopkins, who was in the maintenance business, and lived at 2 Seminary Hill Road in Carmel.

title: Scoring and Statistics of N.F.L. Games
Wholesale Flower Area Imperiled By Crime and Traffic Congestion
description: The wholesale flower districta blaze of color and a bustle of business on an otherwise dreary stretch of the Avenue of the Americasis threatened by traffic congestion, crime and a shortage of parking places for customers, and it may have to transplant itself and some 1,000 jobs to New Jersey unless it can find a new site in the city.

title: Rona Rosen is the Bride Of L. R. Birkner, Engineer
description: Rona Rosen, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Benjamin Rosen of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Miami Beach, was married yesterday afternoon to Lawrence Russell Birkner, son of Dr and Mrs. Frederick E. Birkner, also of Riverdale. Rabbi Melvin Spinner performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: The Real Mr. Ford
description: How can a nice guy be so insensitive, politically, to human concerns? How can he so consistently have identified himself, over a long career in politics, with narrow and illiberal causes? How can such a person be President of the United States?

title: Miss Bronson, Arts Aide, Wed to Jonathan Altman
description: Cynthia M. Bronson and Jonathan P. Altman were married yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr and Mrs. James G. Bronson of Tarrytown and Ripton, Vt., by Justice Morrie Slifkin of the State Supreme Court.

title: Kissinger Scores Carter's Stand Of Nonintervention in Yugoslavia
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger made his most political appearance in the Presidential campaign today, specifically attacking Jimmy Carter's statement that he would not use American troops to defend Yugoslayia and generally suggesting that the Democratic candidate did not yet understand the art of foreign policy.

title: Mayor Swaps Jests With Rivals
description: Standing before a model of a big apple in the ballroom of the New York Hilton, guests at the Byline Ball of the New York Press Club poked jokes at the Mayor, and, when he got his turn, he poked back even better.

title: Shipwreck Survivor Found on Raft
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 (AP)One of three people missing at sea for nearly a month was found alive today, drifting alone on a raft in the Pacific.

title: SAMUEL D. BERNS
description: Samuel D. Berns, a film packager, died Friday in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 177 East 77th Street.

title: A.M.A. Data Indicate Malpractice Rates Raised Fee 96 Cents for Visit to Doctor
description: The American Medical Association released over the weekend, figures indicating that the average fee for an office visit to a doctor in 1975 was 96 cents higher than it would have been had malpractice insurance premiums remained at the lower 1973 rates.

title: U.S. Observes Veterans Day
description: The Federal Government observes Veterans Day today, and all Federal offices and post offices will be closed. City and state offices will operate as usual because New York State continues to observe Veterans Day on Nov. 11.

title: Cornell Women Protest Beauty Pageant as Sexist
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 24About 150 mostly male Cornell University students braved sleet and snow Friday night and matched wits with about an equal number of mostly female demonstrators who tried to block entry to the school's first Miss University beauty pageant.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Ted Cowell Jimmy Crespo comforting his wife, Marilyn, in her bed at Lincoln Hospital. Both jumped from the second floor.

title: Petty Take's First Place In 500Mile Auto Race
description: ROCKINGHAM, N.C., Oct. 24 (AP)Richard Petty, who made three lengthy, costly pit stops under the green flag, battled back each time, and won the American 500 Grand National stock car race today. He used the few yellow caution laps to his maximum advantage and gained only his third victory of the year.

title: A Hospital Divided
description: Faced with an unseemly contestwhich has been tainted by religious, ethnic and political overtonesfor a lucrative affiliation contract with the new Lincoln Hospital, the board of the Health and Hospitals Corporation has taken the easiest way out and divided the contract between a Roman Catholic hospital and a Jewish medical center.

title: Mexico Anxious for Spanish Ties, But Madrid is Reported Balking
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct, 24The Mexican Government, which gave asylum to thousands of refugees from the Spanish Civil War and refused to recognize the victorious Franco regime during 36 years, now anxious to establish diplomatic ties with the Government of King Juan Carlos.

title: Storm Builds to Hurricane Level And Moves Toward Bermuda
description: MIAMI, Oct. 2,1 (UPI)A strong tropical depression that had been slowly gaining strength in the Atlantic became Hurricane Holly this afternoon, with further strengthening expected tomorrow.

title: Advertising
description: Experts in the six major advertising media gathered on Friday at the Biltmore Hotel to forecast the future, at least as far as 1980. As you might expect, rising costs, especially in TV, were high on the agenda.

title: Prayers in Spanish Are Recited As Families Identify Their Dead
description: Ay, Dios mio! Ay, Dios mio! The pregnant woman kept repeating her wail in Spanish. Oh, my God! Then a prayer and words directed at anyone who would listen: God, she was a saint. My little girl was a saint to me. Don't tell me that you have taken her away. I don't want to hear it! No, I don't want to hear it!

title: A Positive Turn Expected Soon In Stock Market
description: The stock market's headlong plunge of the last five weeks has distressed investors and surprised many security analysts, but a new consensus is taking, shape on Wall Street that positive forces will begin to make themselves felt in the market no matter who wins the Presidential election on Nov. 2.

title: New York's First Citywide Marathon Draws Some of World's Top Runners
description: Choir boys cheered outside a church in Brooklyn, just before the 11 A.M. mass. A woman passed out complimentary oranges on East 59th Street. Motorists and taxis gave ground without a grudge.

title: King Pellinore Scores In Oak Tree on Coast
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP)Bill Shoemaker guided King Pellinore, onethird of the favored Charlie Whittinghamtrained entry, to a 1length victory over Royal Derby II, another third of the entry, in the $100,000 Oak Tree Invitational race at Santa Anita Park today. L'Heureux finished third in the 1mile event on turf. The other Whittingham  trained entry, Dahlia, came in fourth.

title: Around the Nation
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 24 (AP)The Pallottine Fathers, a Roman Catholic missionary order, spent 95 percent of the $56 million they received in charity contributions between 1970 and mid1975 for fundraising, real estate ventures and loans to businessmen, according to The Baltimore Sun.

title: About New York
description: The truth should be told about that rather pleasant little gesture of Bobby Berlin in gently pressing her ear lobe as she chatted or gazed thoughtfully at times last spring. She had two tiny, onesixteenthinch needles in her ear and she was self administering acupuncture to cut off her hunger panes.

title: Tragedy of Fire Is Nothing New For Morrisania
description: The Morrisania section of the Bronx had one more burnedout building yesterday, something that it did not need, even had the fire that swept through the Puerto Rican Social Club not left such a path of death and injuries.

title: HENRY R. BOWLER
description: Henry R. Bowler, former denominational secretary for the American Baptist Convention, with headquarters in Valley Forge, Pa., died Saturday at the nursing unit of Navesink House in Red Bank, N.J.

title: Drip Irrigation Cutting Costs in California Agribusiness
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24Some farmers call it drip. Others call it trickle. Others, well, they just call it spit irrigation.

title: INQUIRIES MAY FORCE KOREANS TO QUIT U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  Informea Government sources said today that a Federal investigation into the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency's operations in America has progressed to a point at which South Korean diplomats are in danger of being asked to leave the United States and nonofficial South Koreans face possible indictment for bribery of American officials and other violations of American law.

title: Nets Box Score
description: NETS (93)

title: Cowboys Await Status On Injured Staubach
description: DALLAS, Oct. 25 (UPI)Roger Staubach, who suffered a broken bone in he little finger of his throwing hand yesterday, missed today's workout with the Dallas Cowboys, and Coach Tom Landry said it would be near the end of the week before he knew if the National Football League's leading passer could start the next game against Washington.

title: BUCKLEY RAISES ISSUE OF MOYNIHAN'S POST
description: Senator James L. Buckley yesterday sought to raise the issue of whether it was improper or even illegal for his Democratic opponent, Daniel P. Moynihan, to campaign for the Senate while on the fulltime payroll of Harvard University.

title: The Economic Issue
description: Jimmy Carter says the latest Commerce Department figures on gross national product show a lackluster recovery that could come to a halt while inflation and unemployment remained unacceptably high. Spokesmen for President Ford, conceding that the thirdquarter growth rate of 3.95 percent is disappointing, are pleased with the reduced rate of inflation (to 4.4 percent) and the 17.6 percent increase in housing starts.

title: CARINSURANCE RATES DR2 FIRE IN ALBANY
description: New York State's Superintendent of Insurance, Thomas A. Harnett, said yesterday that he would require insurance companies to commit themselves to opening their books for new business before he would grant autoinsurance rate increases. However, the Superintendent, who testified at an Assembly Insurance Committee hearing, conceded afterward that he could require only a moral commitment from the companies, rather than one that would be legally binding.

title: British Navy to Aid Egypt
description: LONDON, Oct. 25 (Reuters)The British Navy is sending a team of divers to Egypt to help recover a thirdcentury monument, the Gate of Diocletian, submerged by the waters of the Aswan Dam since 1970, the Defense Ministry here said today. The eightman team will tly to Egypt on Thursday to work on the sixMonth project with the Egyptian Navy.

title: 12 Food Establishments Listed By Health Agency as Violators
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday listed 12 food establishments cited as having violated the city's health code, and nine others that had their final inspections. The list follows.

title: Russians Are Planning Olympic Warmup Meet
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25 (AP)The organizing committee for the 1980 Olympics in Moscow outlined plans today for handling foreign visitors. It also planned an Olympicstyle warmup competition to be held here in 1979.

title: Around the Nation
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 25 (UPI)A controversial plan backed by the Federal Government could make Berkeley the first city in the nation to charge motorists a daily fee for the use of its streets.

title: Thai Army Leader Denies Junta Is Vining Political Witch Hunt
description: PANCEOK, Thailand. Oct. 25A Thai ??? leader today denied that the new junta is conducting a witch hunt against all dissidents.

title: FORD IS CRITICIZED BY GOVERNOR BROWN
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I., Oct. 25Gov. Edmund Brown Jr of California addressed a campaign rally this afternoon at the State University Agricultural and Technical College here, and though the appearance was on behalf of the Democratic Presidential candidate. Jimmy Carter, the speech was described by some as pure Brown.

title: The Plea Bargain
description: Coldblooded murders of policemen, plea bargaining and the death penalty are three subjects that tend to drive reason out of discussions of criminal justice. When all three issues combine in one case, as they did in the sentencing of Luis S. Velezthe admitted slayer Sgt. Frederick Reddy and Officer Andrew Gloverhigh passion is bound to compete fiercely with calm judgment. It is not surprising, therefore, that New York County District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau has come under heavy fire for his decision to permit Mr. Velez to plead guilty to two counts of seconddegree murder.

title: RICHARDSON K. WOOD, 72, EXFORTUNE EDITOR, DIES
description: Richardson King Wood, managing ediIor of Fortune magazine from 1940 to 1941, died Sunday night in Manatee Hospital, Bradenton, Fla., after a short illness. He was 72 years old.

title: For Early Christmas Shoppers With a Taste for the Uncommon
description: Put together several hundred hardworking volunteers, four major charities and a location in the heart of a prestigious shopping area, and the result is the 17th annual Les Boutiques de Noel, which today opens its doors to the public.

title: International Chess Olympiad Gets Under Way in Haifa, Israel
description: HAIFA, Israel, Oct. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel, and Max Euwe president of the International Chess Federation, officially opened the 22d men's and seventh women's chess olympiads here yesterday.

title: 2 Americans Relive Years At Kwai Camp
description: KANACHANBURI, Thailand, Oct. 25 Dennis Aloysius Roland was reliving his past.

title: Television
BERGSTROM WINS IN FIGHT FOR CONTROL OF DIEBOLD
description: Erik E. Bergstrom, a private California investor, and his slate of directors have won a proxy fight for control of the Diebold Venture Capital Corporation, a closedend investment corporation.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney reports that one of the most sensitive economic issues in Japan is the effort abroad to stem the tide of Japanese products into certain foreign markets. Page 53.

title: SENATORS ARE EVALUATED ON CONSERVATION VOTES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI)The League of Conservation Voters rated the Senate only soso today in its survey of voting records on conservation issues. The league is a campaign group raising money for candidates it considers outstanding environmentalists.

title: A Tough African Nationalist
description: UMTATA, Transkei, Tuesday, Oct. 26 However disputed may be the independence of Transkei from South Africa, it marks the consecration of the political life of its Prime Minister, Chief Kaiser Daliwonga Matanzima.

title: Backlog for New Machine Tools Up $35 Million in Month to 1.29 Billion
description: The backlog for new machine tools rose by $35 million in the month ended Sept. 30 to $1.29 billion, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday. The trade association noted that total new orders in September reached $228.3 million, a gain of 13 percent over the August level and 105.1 percent higher than a year earlier. New orders for the first nine months totaled $1.52 billion, up 78.7 percent over the yearearlier level.

title: LIBERTARIAN LEADING 3D PARTY CANDIDATES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  Robert H. Meier was not exultant, but he was very pleased. It's been a quiet victory, he said, but we've moved to the front of the thirdparty pack.

title: Carter Rests at His Home Before Final Week's Swing Across Country in Crucial, Closely Contested States
description: PLAINS, Ga., Oct. 25Jimmy Carter got his last leisure time here today before a final, frenetic week of campaigning that will take him coast to coast into the crucial, closely contested states where his political fate may hang in the balance.

title: Lights Are Dimmed in Spain
description: MADRID, Oct. 25 (AP)Spain began a nationwide program of minimum lighting today and cut back on oil imports. Officials said they expect electricity comsumption to be halved under the program, which will be for an idefinite period.

title: A Grandmother's 3 Daughters Dead in Fire
description: Until Sunday morning Ramona Ballester, who is 51 years old, was happy grandmother. Three daughters had given her 10 lovely grandchildren, who often stayed at her home at 430 East 162d Street in the Bronx. Her daughter Iris, who lived in Puerto Rico and whose picture hangs on the wall of her apartment, only recently had given birth to her fifth child. And Iris had come to New York on a visit with her baby, Denise Joanna.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
NewCar Sales Off 5.4% in 10 Days As Impact of Ford Strike Lingers
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25American new car sales declined 5.4 percent in the Oct. 1120 period because of the lingering impact of the strike against the Ford Motor Company and a general shortage of big cars.

title: Rhodesian Leader Says Kissinger May Be Needed at Geneva Talks
description: GENEVA, Oct. 25Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that it might be necessary to ask Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to come to Geneva to avert the threatened impasse at the conference designed to arrange a transition to black majority rule in Rhodesia.

title: 2 Kenyans Killed in Crash
description: EL PASO, Tex., Oct. 25 (AP)  Two Kenyans, members of the University of Texas at El Paso track team, were killed in a car collision yesterday north of here in New Mexico. They were Joseph Gichongery, 23 years old, and Festus Muriithi, 22.

title: Meadowlands
A Sensitive Issue for Japan: Stemming Flood of Exports
description: TOKYOOne of the most sensitive economic issues widely discussed here these days is the effort abroad to stern the tide of some major Japanese products into certain foreign markets. This nation's electronics industry has been particularly stung by the criticism  and the charge of dumpinglodged against it in the United States over its record shipments of colored television sets and tubes to the American market this year.

title: Martin Wins in Australia
description: PERTH, Australia, Oct. 25 (AP)Billy Martin of Palos Verdes, Calif., beat Sashi Menon of India, 64, 63 and won $40,000 Hitachi tennis tournament tonight. The 19yearold Martin displayed superb allround strength and consistency, particularly with his twohanded backhand. He continually forced Menon into errors.

title: Want to Run Marathon? Take it Easy, Doctor Warns Hopeful Novices
description: So you watched some of the New York City Marathon Sunday and now vim think running 26 miles isn't really all that ridiculous, and you're going to drag out your sneakers and sweatsuit and train for next year.

title: New North Central Bronx Hospital Finally Gets to Admit First Patient
description: The North Central Bronx Hospital, a 5100million structure whose existence as a municipal institution was threatened in the debate over whether New York City had enough money to run it, finally admitted its first patient at 10:05 A.M. yesterday.

title: David D. Jones Dies at 58; Aide at Syracuse U. Also Had New York City Posts
description: David D. Jones, special assistant to the Chancellor of Syracuse University and former deputy commssioner of corrections in New York City, died Sunday at tm Veterans Administration Hospital in Syracuse. He was 58 years old and a resident of Syracuse.

title: Radio
Copper, Silver and Cocoa Prices Fall
description: Copper, silver and cocoa futures prices dropped yesterday despite the fact that all three ordinarily rise when the British pound declines sharply.

title: Theater: Oh! Calcutta! Returns
description: What do you do when you see a show for the second time that you did not much care for the first time? That is if you are a critic. And that was my problem with the erotic, or at least pseudoerotic, or at least eroticallypseudo revue, Oh! Calcutta! which has now turned up like a golden penny once more on Broadway at the Edison Teacher.

title: Drinan in Massachusetts Fight to Keep House Seat
description: BOSTON, Oct 25 (UPI)The Rev. Robert F. Drinan's first campaign for Congress was based on opposition to the Vietnam War. His fourth has become a sometimes bitter contest, and both ethnic politics and Richard M. Nixon play a central part.

title: Canadiens Trounce Islanders
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 25 Jim Roberts underestimated the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

title: Redskins Top Cards by 2010 In a Downpour
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25Mark the Washington Redskins down as superior mudders, superior opportunists, superior optimists. On a drowning football field, one soaked by an early and lasting downpour, the Redskins tonight came from behind in the final quarter, scoring two touchdowns to upset the St. Louis Cardinals, 2010.

title: NARCOTICS DEALER SEIZED IN BRONX ON GUN CHARGE
description: Leroy (Kicky) Barnes, listed by the police as one of the nation's largest narcotics dealers, was arrested in the Bronx last night and charged with illegal possession of weanons.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Police and firemen who staged a series of sickouts in Gloucester last week have won a new contract with a 15 percent raise. The city and the police and firemen reached agreement on a twoyear pact containing increases of 7.5 percent for each year. The police and firemen had staged a series of sickcall protests from last Wednesday to last Friday, with one shift each day remaining off the job to call attention to the contract dispute. Earlier shifts remained on duty to provide protection for the community of 15,000 people.

title: Other Sales and Earnings Issued

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The Soviet Union has quietly made formal application to join key ratesetting conferences in the shipping industry, a move that may prevent chaos on world trade routes and a direct RussianAmerican economic confrontation.

title: Last of Scottsboro 9 Is Pardoned; He Draws a Lesson for Everybody
description: Clarence Norris, the sole surviving Scottsboro Roy, was pardoned yesterday by Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama and asserted happily in New York City that a man should never give up hope.

title: Search is Widened For Bronx Arsonist
description: A widespread search was under way yesterday for the arsonist who caused a fire killing 25 persons in a Bronx social club early Sunday, but investigators said the case had become wide open.

title: Legislature in Suffolk Facing a Decision Today On Civil Service Raises
description: The Suffolk County Legislature will be asked today to vote on a proposal that would grant Civil Service employees stepbystep salary increases and thus end the 14month impasse between the county and its 6,500 employees.

title: Plates That Encourage Overeating
description: Sitting inconspicuously on a display counter on the china floor at Tiffany's is something that will probably cause a few puzzled frowns.

title: In Paris, It's the 1960's All Over Again
description: PARIS, Oct. 25Guess, what's tootling back to fashion? The mini, that's what.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures

description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 25 (Reuters)Militant black South Africans in Soweto township have bombed a police station and railroad line and are calling for a boycott of whiteowned shops and bars and Christmas festivities.

description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, announced today that the grain harvest could reach or'even exceed the record crop of 222.5 million tons gathered three years ago.

description: Governor Carey has come through a year of fiscal turmoil in New York City and state with a positive image among New York State residents, a survey of voters indicates, while his fellow Democrat, Mayor Beame, is rated unfavorably by a majority of New York City residents.

description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25Julio Scherer Garcia, who was ousted in July from the editorship of the Mexican daily newspaper Excelsior, accused the Government today of trying to block publication of a new independent political weekly with its investigation of charges that he embezzled $650,000 from the daily.

description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

description: Earnings of most leading publicly owned brokerage firms rebounded strongly in the third quarter of 1976 following a generally lackluster performance in the second quarter.

description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 25In a move designed to shake up players who have lost seven straight games, the Giants dismissed Bill Arnsparger as head coach today and replaced him with one of his assistants, John McVay.

title: Exxon Profit Off 3.8% in Quarter; 4 Other Oil Producers Show Gains
description: Four major oil companies yesterday reported substantially higher thirdquarter earnings, although the Exxon Corporation, the nation's largest industrial company, reported a decline of 3.8 percent.

description: L. William Seidman, the White House economic adviser, said yesterday that he believed the Government's index of leading economic indicators for September, scheduled for release late this week, will be level or off a little bit from the August results.

description: Deaths

title: Sadat and Assad Take a Firm Stand on Lebanon Pact, Telling Arab League There is No Room for Dissent
description: CAIRO, Oct. 25President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and President Hafez elAssad of Syria told the conference of Arab heads of state and government that opened here today that there was no room for dissent from or disagreement with the plan for ending the war in Lebanon adopted last week in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

title: Morton Salt Raises Its Prices
description: The Morton Salt Company, a division of MortonNorwich Products Inc., announced a price increase of from 8 percent to 12 percent on rock and evaporated salt products, effective Dec. 10. Price increases will range from $1.50 to $4 a ton on rock salt and from $3.50 to about $8 a ton on evaporated salt. The evaporated salt includes table salt.

title: Tighter Port Authority Bids Urged
description: Procurement practices of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey should be tightened, the State Comptroller's office said yesterday.

title: Stock Average Dips by 0.75 Point; Session is One of Year's Slowest
description: Stock prices fell slightly yesterday in one of the slowest trading sessions of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average finished down 035 point to 938, with declines on the New York Stock Exchange barely outnumbering advances.

title: Labor's Drive for Carter is Biggest It Has Made in a Presidential Race
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 In the drab, dusty basement of Sidney Hillman Halt a continuous murmur of overlapping female voices is punctuated by the squeak of telephone pushbuttons and the scratch of pencils on green and white computer printouts.

title: CONCERTO BAROCCO GETS ASTYLISH PERFORMANCE
description: George Balanchine has been intimately connected with the growth and development of the Pennsylvania Ballet from its modest onset 14 years ago. Its founder, the director Barbara Weissberger, was a student of his and he has supported the company with several of his choicest ballets, one of which is Concerto Barocco. Sunday evening at the Brookyn Academy of Music, it was given a stylishly restrained performance with Martine van Hamel, the company's guest artist, as the lead ballerina.

title: Coaching Natural for McVay
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 25John Edward McVay didn't really think of becoming a football coach until he was a sophomore in college.

description: LONDON, Oct. 25You get a tipoff, said Malcolm Crawford, a Canadian who for nine years has been the economics editor of London's prestigious Sunday Times. Then you talk to people who are in the best position to know, and then you go through official channels.

title: Function of New Medical Center Stirs Controversy in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 25  Just four months before its opening, a new Westchester medical center has confronted county taxpayers with estimates of a massive firstyear deficit, stirred county legislators to near revolt, disrupted the area's medical community and presented County Executive Alfred B. DelBello with the largest political problem of his relatively stable three years in office.

title: Hollow Independence
description: With many of the trappings that usually accompany this kind of event, the Transkei today celebrates the achievement of independence from South Africathe first of nine tribal homelands to take the step. But the celebration in Umtata will be a hollow one; for the Government of Chief Kaiser Matanzima faces an almost total diplomatic boycott. Not even neighboring Lesotho, smaller in population and area and no less dependent economically on South Africa, will grant recognition to the Transkei.

description: OTTAWA, Oct. 25Deepseated animosities between Frenchspeaking and Englishspeaking Canadians have plunged their country into a political crisis that, in the view of Prime Minister Pierre Elliot Trudeau and others, threatens to destroy the confederation that has held it together since its founding in 1867.

title: Court Will Hear Plea by Minnesota to Halt Indefinite Suspension Today
description: The University of Minnesota will go to court this morning in an attempt to prevent the National Collegiate Athletic Association from imposing an indefinite probation on the Gophers entire intercollegiate athletic program. The N.C.A.A. placed Minnesota's 11 varsity sports on an openended probation two weeks ago for alleged violalions of its rules. Minnenta's basketball team was put on a twoyear probation last winter for recruiting violations and some other rules infractions. The Big Ten university accepts that penalty, admitting to the wrong doing in the basketball bilsiness.
