title: Black Rhodesian Students Flee And Are Believed to Join Rebels
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 25Rhodesian officials believe that more than half of the 700 black students who have disappeared from their schools in the last five months have joined black nationalist guerrillas in neighboring Mozambique.

title: Men and Women Pros in $200,000 Golf
description: The idea of a golf tournament involving male and female professionals died a quiet death in 1966, unnoticed and unmourned.

title: 3,000 American Jews Gathering In Israel for a U.J.A. Conference
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 25 (Reuters)More than 3,000 American Jews gathered at a sports palace here today to open the national conference of the United Jewish Appeal, a fundraising organization.

title: Louisiana Governor Says His Wife Was Given $10,000 by South Korean
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 25 (AP)Gov. Edwin Edwards of Louisiana acknowledged today that his wife, Elaine, was given $10,000 in 1971 by Park Tong Sun, known in the United States as Tongsun Park, a South Korean businessman who has been identified by Korean and American intelligence sources as a member of the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency.

title: U.S. Presses African Presidents T o Help Geneva Meeting Succeed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 25The United States has urged key black African presidents to use their influence to prevent black Rhodesian nationalists from making such extreme demands that the Geneva conference collapses and the BritishAmerican plan for a Rhodesian solution is scuttled.

title: Ford Rejects Appeal by Cadets To Reinstate Them to Academy
description: The White House has rejected an appeal by cadets implicated for cheating at West Point for President Ford to dismiss charges against them and to reinstate them to the United States Military Academy.

title: CORRECTION
description: Third quarter earnings of the Continental Illinois Corporation were incorrectly reported in last Friday's editions of The Times. The correct earnings were $29.13 million, an increase of 11.5 percent over the third quarter of 1975.

title: New York State Education Agency Called Lax on Private Trade Schools
description: The New York State Consumer Protection Board accused the State Education Department yesterday of failing to deter or punish abuses by private vocational schools, and of showing a shocking bias in favor of the schools and against the students.

title: Budd and U.A.W. Will Open Talks
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25 (AP)The United Automobile Workers and the Budd Company will open negotiations Wednesday on a new contract covering about 12,000 workers in Michigan, Philadelphia and Gary, Ind. The union's contract with Budd expires next Jan. 15. Budd has its headquarters in Troy, Mich., and is a major manufacturer of automotive parts.

title: Irish Rider Wins 19Mount Jumpoff
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 25Eddie Macken of the Irish Equestrian Team piloted Boomerang to victory in the internationalopen jumper class after a jumpoff involving 19 mounts tonight at the Washington International Horse Show.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Company said yesterday that it planned to lay off several hundred workers, but added that it hoped to minimize the furloughs by placing employes in other divisions of the parent concern, the United Technologies Corporation. Pratt & Whitney, based in East Hartford, Conn., employs 30,000 persons.

title: Opposition Stays Away as the Indian Parliament Convenes a Conference on Constitutional Amendmenfs
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 25With most of its opposition members staving away in protest, the Indian Parliament convened today to consider a farreaching set of constitutional amendments that would significantly alter the balances of government.

title: 7 on Boat Missing Off Cape Cod
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (AP)The body of a fishing boat skipper was recovered but as many as seven crewmen were missing today after the disappearance of their 65foot boat in stormy weather off Cape Cod, the Coast Guard said. The body of William W. King, 45 years old, of Providencetown, was recovered near debris from the Patricia Marie about three miles off Nauset Beach, the Coast Guard said.

title: I.M.F. FACES PROBLEM OF MONEY FOR LOANS AS FUNDS RUN SHORT
description: The International Monetary Fund is running low on money, and if the world economic slowdown goes on longer than expected it could have trouble meeting demand for its loans next year.

title: Dr. Ray and G.O.P. Rival Held Even In Washington Governor's Contest
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 25To say that the race for governor of Washington is tight would be an understatement.

title: Member of Parliament in Athens Urges U.S. Greeks to Back Carter
description: ATHENS, Oct. 25 (AP)A conservative member of the Greek Parliament has called on GreekAmericans to vote for Jimmy Carter, Democratic Presidential candidate, to get Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger out of office.

title: Mondale, Campaigning in Jersey, Scores Joblessness and Inflation
description: PARAMUS, N.J., Oct. 25After campaign stops in Ohio yesterday and Pennsylvania early today, Senator Walter F, Mondale, the Democratic VicePresidential candidate, made a daylong tour through four New Jersey counties, meeting enthusiastic crowds and identifying the Democratic Presidential campaign more closely with New Jersey Senate and Congressional races.

title: People and Business
description: King Juan Carlos of Spain was on hand yesterday when Henry Ford 2d, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, formally opened his company's new $500 million factory near Valencia.

title: Transkei, a South African Black Area, Is Independent
description: UMTATA. Transkei, Tuesday. Oct. 26The Republic of Transkei was proclaimed at one minute past midnight the first of South Africa's black homelands to attain independence.

title: Dole, Blaming Democrats for 4 Wars in This Century, Says He Had Doubts About U.S. Role in World War
description: UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 25Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican VicePresidential candidate, used Veterans Day as an occasion today to renew his suggestions that the Democrats were responsible for four wars in this century, while at the same time saying at a news conference that he had had some reservations about American involvement in World War II.

title: Football Ratings
description: The top 20 teams with first place Votes in Parentheses, season records and total points. Points scored on 20151614 1210987654321 basis.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: Problems of small, closely held businesses are discussed at a conference for accountants. Page 55.

title: East Europe is Made an Issue in Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  President Ford, by missteps and misstatements, has opened the door for Eastern Europe to become an issue in a Presidential campaign for the first time since 1952.

title: Despite Hectic Week, Sills and Caldwell Forge Calm Barber
description: Beverly Silk Was standing in a utilitarianlooking corridor in the New York State Theater at 7:20 Sunday night, just before her entrance as Rosina in the new Sarah Caldwell production of The Barber of Seville for the New York City Opera.

title: Taxes & Accounting: The Small Concerns
description: If small companies feel overwhelmed by governmentand these days a great many say they doit is by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr will be serving his 60day jail sentence in the Manhattan Correctional Center off Foley Square, according to authorities. Plans to have 47yearold Queens Democrat transferred to the Federal prison at Allenwood, Pa., were dropped because of the inconvenience of processing a shortterm prisoner. The modern Manhattan facility, often used for shortterm prisoners and defendants awaiting trial, is situated behind the United States Court House a few blocks from City Hall.

title: Records of College Football Teams and the Schedules of Their Remaining Games
Candidates Meeting the Workers In Unions Bid to Help Democrats
description: ROCHESTER, Pa.  The 6,500 building trades craftsmen who work at the Shippingport, Pa., electricpower complex were visited on the job the other day by Gene Atkinson, the Democratic candidate for the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania's 25th District.

title: Chrysler Earnings 3dQuarter Record
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25The Chrysler Corporation reported today record earnings of $76.2 million, or $1.26 a share, in the third quarter. With that performance, Chrysler has netted more money during the first nine months of 1976 than in any previous whole year.

title: Rockets Are Next Stop for Malone
description: Moses Malone, once college basketball's recruiting prize, has become pro basketball's trading pawn. The 6foot11inch Malone was sold yesterday for the second time in a week. The Buffalo Braves sent hint to the Houston Rockets, the third National Basketball Association team for Malone since he began the season in the Portland Trail Blazers training camp. It will be his fifth pro team since he was graduated from Petersburg (Va.) High School and signed for the 197475 season with the Utah Stars of the nowdefunct American Basketball Association. When the Stars folded last December, Malone joined the Spirits of St. Louis. He carried a $350,000 price tag into the dispersal draft of A.B.A. players, where he was selected by the Trail Blazers.

title: BRITAIN'S POUND HIT BY RECORD SETBACK, CLOSING AT $1,595
description: LONDON, Oct. 25The British pound endured its worst attack in history today, suffering a record oneday fall of more than five cents to close at $1.595.

title: ExPrisoners and Captors Join in a Walk Over Kwai Bridge
description: KANCHANABURI, Thailand, Oct. 25This time the Japanese wore dark business smts black ties and mourning bands around their arms. Their wives wore black kimons and some of them wept. The Australians wore shirts and knee socks and an American carried two American flags.

title: Contract, a Rhapsody in Blue Ink, Is Signed for Purchase of George Gershwin's Birthplace in Brooklyn
description: Jens Nygaard, musical man of all trades, yesterday rescued George Gershwin's house in the East New York section of Brooklyn from possible demolition.

title: Meditation Clubs Flourish From Capitol to Pentagon For Dissolving Tension
description: WASHINGTONTranscendental meditation clubs have sprung up from the Capitol to the Pentagon and White House.

title: VICTOR L. JOHNSON
description: Victor L. Johnson, senior vice president since 1971 of the Amstar Corporation, died Thursday in Newton (N.J.) Memorial Hospital following a heart attack. He was 62 years old and lived at 87 Lafayette Road in Sparta, N.J.

title: THEATER IN CAPITAL SET FOR MUSICAL THEATER LAB
description: The threeyearold Musical Theater Lab, designed to develop musical theater in the United States, will be housed in a new 100seat theater to be constructed within its existing space by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington at a cost of $50,000.

title: Moynihan Seeks to Raise Funds for a LastMinute Advertising Campaign
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 25Daniel P. Moynihan, buoyed by recent polls, but troubled by a dwindling campaign chest, began the last week of campaigning with trips upstate and began an effort to raise $100.000 for additional advertising.

title: CARTER IS ENDORSED BY THE NEW YORK POST
description: The San Fruncisco Chronicle endorsed President Ford yesterday, saying that he had returned honesty and decency to the White House, while The New York Post came out for Jimmy Carter and said that New York's battle for life hinges on the outcome, United Press international reported.

title: New York City's Budget Problem Is Adding to Heat Felt by Firemen
description: It's not the ghetto fires. It's those sixstory apartment buildings that get you. By the time you stretch that hose up the stairs, you're exhausted. You're gulping that smoke and wondering if you're going to get throueh this one.

title: Raymond Queneau, French Novelist And Literary Figure, Is Dead at 73
description: PARIS, Oct. 25Raymond Queneau, one of France's most influential literary figures who acquired international fame with his novel Zazie dans le Metro, died here today in a hospital at the age of 73.

title: $200,000 in Jewelry and Money Stolen in Cartier Boutique Holdup
description: Two holdup men handcuffed two employees at a boutique of Cartier, a franchise of Cartier Inc., the jewelry concern, in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday and fled with an estimated $150,000 in jewels and $50,000 in cash.

title: A Small Practitioner Expresses Worries
description: Small wonder that some accounting firms have little trouble comprehending the big pressures on small business. They are under the same pressures themselves.

title: APPEALS COURT CANCELS SPECIAL QUEENS ELECTION
description: A special election that had been scheduled for today in the 34th Assembly District in Queens has been canceled as the result of an appellate court ruling that the State Supreme Court had no right to order the election.

title: Chess
description: Knowing when to attack is as important as knowing how to attack. There are players who attack without any provocation (they lose too many games for whatever brilliancies they may achieve) and there are players who cannot be provoked to attack (they make too many draws).

title: Medical License Seized From an Abortion Doctor Charged With Ineptitude
description: The medical license of Dr. Eliezer Shkolnik, an abortion specialist, was confiscated yesterday by New York State at the doctor's office at York Medical Associates, also known as the Central Women's Center at 331 East 29th Street.

title: Reagan to Campaign for Ford
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 (UPI)Ronald Reagan will start a campaign tour in support of President Ford at Las Vegas on Tuesday that will include at least seven stops in Western states. The former California Governor's office reported today that he sent a telegram to Mr. Ford yesterday in which he said the campaign swing is part of my determination to persuade every American I can reach to join me in voting for you on Nov. 2d,

title: Director in the Shadow of Trees
description: At the Circle in the Square, tangling with a play I knew to be ambiguous from the outset and found increasingly inconclusive as it bitterly fought its way to some kind of fadeout, I began to realize that I was attending to something other than the play itself. That, in fact, the intensity with which I was listening had relatively little to do with what the playwright Marguerite Duras had written or with what three able performersMildred Dunnock, Joseph Maher, the new and attractive Suzanne Ledererwere doing on their own to make a mystery yield its secrets. I was, I finally figured out, listening to the director.

title: TV: CBS Shows Holiday on Ice
description: We have a wonderful show for you this evening, the attractive star promises, something for everyone. This spectator would add one proviso: everyone, that is, under 10. Beyond that age, the charm of an ice show tends to melt rather quickly. Tonight's specimen, on CBS at 8, is officially called Peggy Fleming With Holiday on Ida at Madison Square Garden.

title: PRIVATE SECTOR IS URGED TO OFFER JOBS TO BLACKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The problem of high rates of joblessness among blacks can be solved only by significant expansion of jobs in the private sector of the economy, according to Andrew F. Brimmer, a former member of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Judge Finds Mrs. Peron Guilty And Orders Her Imprisonment
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 25 (Reuters)A federal judge found former President Isabel Martinez de Peron guilty of embezzlement today and ordered her to be held in preventive detention, court sources said.

title: Corporate Planes' Safety Record Is Broken by Two Recent Crashes
description: Corporate aviation, a world of privately owned executive planes that are generally conditioned like thoroughbreds and operated with consummate conservatism, has built a safety record rivaling the low accident rate for this country's airlines.

title: Transkei at a Glance
description: GEOGRAPHYThe Transkei covers 14,300 square miles carved out of South Africa's Cape Province. Nearly as large as Denmark, it has a 155mile coastline on the Indian Ocean and is bordered, to the north, by Lesotho, an independent African state hitherto surrounded entirely by South Africa. In terrain, the Transkei is as fertile and beautiful as any reeion of Africa.

title: Books of the Times
description: Consider how absurdly we clothe ourselves. See how on a springlike day in March or April people still bundle up as if it were the dead of winter.Think what we have worn in the past the crinoline and stay, the wig and pantaloon, the bustle and mailed gauntlet. Recall how changeable Western tastes have been over the past several centuries, especially in contrast to such cultures as Japan, prerevolutionary China, PreColumbian civilization and indeed all preliterate societies. Why do we do it? Because we are slaves to fashion, of course. But why particularly we in the West since about the time of Charlemagne? And why women more so than men?

title: Indictment Rises as Key Issue in Helstoski's Campaign
description: RUTHERFORD, Oct. 25The race in the Ninth Congressional District has all the usual partisan divisions over the economy, but only one real question will the indictment of the sixterm Democratic incumbent, Representatiove Henry Helstoski, on Federal extortion charges cost him his seat?

title: The U.N. Today
New Harvard Swim Coach
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Oct. 25 (AP)John Walker was named today as acting head coach of the Harvard varsity swimming team. He replaced Ray Essick who resigned to join the Amateur Athletic Union.

title: Trabert Has High Hopes In Davis Cup
description: The United States begins its quest for the 1977 Davis Cup next month with a match against Venezuela at Caracas.

title: Oh Homers as Giants Lose
description: TOKYO, Oct. 25 (AP)The Hankyu Braves defeated the Yomiuri Giants, 54, today and took a 20 edge in the fourofseven Japanese world series. The Giants Saduharo Oh got his second homer of the series.

title: Variety of Companies Report Their Sales and Earnings Figures
description: The New York Times/Oct. 26, 1976

title: INDIAN EDITOR DETAINED; WROTE FOR A U.S. PAPER
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 25An assistant editor of The Times of India has been arrested, authoritative sources here said today, because of writing he did for The Christian Science Monitor.

title: G.O.P. Senate Chiefs Rate Ads To Get Industry for N.Y.as N.G.
description: ALBANY, Oct. 25 (AP)In a report sharply critical of the State Commerce Department, the Senate's Republican majority says New York State needs a slicker advertising approach to attract business to the state.

title: Indians Continuing Occupation, Of Juvenile Center in Tacoma
description: TACOMA, Wash., Oct. 25 (AP) Puyallup Indians continued occupying a state juvenile detention center today, but Indians and state officials said good progress had been made in negotiations to end the takeover.

title: CLAIRE RUIN, WIDOW OF BASEBALL GREAT
description: Mrs. Claire Ruth, the widow of baseball's Babe Ruth, died of cancer yesterday at her memorabiliafilled apartment at 110 Riverside Drive. She was 76 years old.

title: To Bribe or Bribe Not
description: Despite all the headlines in the last two years over corporate bribery of foreign government officials, little has been done to deal with the problem. This, in itself, may be regarded as further evidence of corruption, but it is chiefly a result of the complexity of the problem of how to prevent, or punish, corrupt relationships between business and government that lie beyond the reach of national sovereignty.

title: The TwoParty Freeze
description: The difficulties Eugene McCarthy has experienced in trying to wage an independent campaign for the Presidency have made clear the extent to which the two major parties have been built into the political system, while everyone else is rather effectively shut out.

title: NATIONAL STEEL PROFIT CLIMBED IN 3D QUARTER,
description: The National Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest domestic steelmaker, reported yesterday a sharp increase in earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 30, reflecting the recovery in steel demand from consumerrelated auto and container markets. The company said both primary steel production and shipments were also up sharply from last year.

title: EDWARD MEIZELS
description: Edward Meizels, an account executive on the New York staff of the CBS Television Network sales department since 1969, died suddenly Sunday in his cottage in East Hampton, L.I. He was 47.

title: Degrading Atlantic City
description: Atlantic City's economic problems are real, and they are of concern to the whole metropolitan area. A worldfamous resort fallen on bad times and grown seedy can only detract from the wellbeing of the entire region. But if the voters of New Jersey endorse the constitutional amendment on next Tuesday's ballot to allow casino gambling in Atlantic City, they will invite a cure worse than the disease. They will be playing directly into the hands of crooks, gamblers and speculators.

title: Republicans Fear Large Turnout, Democratic Voter Study Asserts
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 25 (AP)Republicans fear a large voter turnout for the Presidential election and have waged a campaign to encourage voter apathy the chairman of a Democratic voter committee said today.

title: Holtz Apparently is Safe Despite 16 Mark of Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., Oct 25No, the New York Jets aren't dismissing their coach.

title: 30 JEWS IN MOSCOW SEIZED IN PROTESTS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25About 30 Jewish activists were arrested today as the Soviet authorities moved to cut off further demonstrations by wouldbe emigrants According to reports pieced together from friends and relatives, some of the Jews were taken from their homes, some were seized as they left their apartments and others were intercepted as they approached the reception office of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet. The office is used as a court of last resort by some citizens with grievances.

title: Rare Feat by Koroll
description: On the first penalty shot of his career, 30yearold Cliff Koroll of the Chicago Black Hawks was the victor Sunday as he slid the puck past Ed Johnston, the St. Louis Blues goalie. The Black Hawks won the game in Chicago Stadium, 72.

title: Palmer, Jones Top Pitchers
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 25 (AP)  Jim Palmer of the Baltimore Orioles and Randy Jones of San Diego were named the pitchers of the year today by Sporting News. Each won 22 games.

title: Bond Prices Continue Steep Drop; Yield on New Treasury Notes 6.11%
description: The bond market, which last week went through its steepest decline in four and a half months, continued its slump yesterday. Bond prices fell sharply and interest rates climbed, lifting the yield on the Treasury's new twoyear notes marketed only last Thursday to 6.11 percent from 5.96 percent. In the corporate bond market, the $150 million issue of the New York Telephone Company tripleA debentures that were offered originally last Tuesday at a yield of 8.25 percent dropped 1 points to raise their yield to 8.36 percent.

title: News Summary
description: A bumper Soviet grain harvest was announced by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist Party leader. He told the Central Committee that the harvest could reach or exceed the record crop of 222.5million tons reaped in 1973. The big crop, which contrasted markedly with a disastrous harvest last year, was attributed by specialists to good weather, including timely rains, [Page 1, Column 4.]

title: King Suspended by Vols
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 25 (AP)Bernard King, the Tennessee basketball ???ar from Brooklyn, has been suspended from the team for the fall quarter by Coach Ray Mears following King's arrest last Saturday in a nearby town for drunken driving, reckless driving and improper registration of his car. This was the fourth time King, a junior, had been booked on traffic charges. Terry Crosby, a sophomore from Toledo, Ohio, will replace King as a starter.

title: Carter's Mother Warns Her Son Not to Forget Pledges to Aged
description: Lillian Carter, the outspoken, 78yearold mother of the Democratic Presidential nominee, told a group of elderly citizens in Brooklyn yesterday that her son, Jimmy, would honor his promises to improve conditions for the aged.

title: Concert: Choral Masterpieces
description: Richard Westenburg's Musica Sacra of New York is a most worthy choral ??? but there were problems about its program Sunday night at ??? Tully Hall.

title: Suspect in Vandalism Seized
description: HOMER, La., Oct. 25 (AP)The authorities say they have arrested a 26yearold man in connection with antiCatholic vandalism in an area where Roman Catholic priest was shot to death last week. John B. Abercrombie, 26 years old was arrested last night at his home in Athens, a small town south of Homer in this heavily Protestant area of north Louisiana, deputies said. He was booked on charges of criminal damage to property in the vandalism of two Catholic churches in Claiborne Parish.

title: Jamaica Handicap
description: Jamaica Handicap

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Oct.25The first month's payroll deductions from the state's income tax are still dribbling in, and state officials say it will he some time before an estimate can be made on how much the levy will eventually provide.

title: JUDGE CLEARS GURNEY ON ONE OF TWO COUNTS
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 25 (UPI)A Federal judge dismissed today one of two charges that former Senator Edward J. Gurney lied to a grand jury, but ordered that the trial continue on the second portion of the indictment.

title: Environmental Chief Cites a Need For More WaterPollution Money
description: TRENTON, Oct. 25The Commissioner of Environmental Protection, David J. Bardin, said today that the state had virtually used up its allocation of $1.3 billion in Federal funds for waterpollution control and that unless additional money was forthcoming plans for construction of additional sewage treatment plants would end.

title: FORDTRAVELSNATION CITING THE POSITIVE
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 25President Ford swooped across Puget Sound today aboard a hydrofoil boat, establishing a first in Presidential campaign travel. He also promoted airplane noise control at the home of the Boeing Company and celebrated Veterans Day by helping to plant a fir tree at a hospital here.

title: Rev. Robert V. Moss Jr., 54, Dies; United Church of Christ President
description: The Rev. Robert V. Moss Jr., president of the United Church of Christ and a noted ecumenist, died of cancer yesterday at Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N.J. He was 54 years old and a resident of Upper Montclair.

title: DRUGGISTS CUT OFF MEDICAID PATIENTS
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 25Pharmacists on Long Island, in Westchester County and in about 20 other counties throughout the state refused today to fill prescriptions for Medicaid patients because they said they were losing money under new Federal and state reimbursement guidelines.

title: Concept of a General Education Is Revived on College Campuses
description: The concept of general education, which holds that a student should be exposed to courses in each of the major branches of knowledge, is making a comeback on American college campuses.

title: Radicals in Portugal Stage Wide Protest Over Leftist's Arrest
description: LISBON, Oct. 25  Radical leftists launched a campaign today with rallies, posters, murals and telegrams to protest the arrest of the revolutionary hero Maj. Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho.

title: The Lout's Progress
description: In Massachusetts not long ago two men cruising in their cars got into an argument on their citizen's band radios. After an exchange of insults, one man challenged the other to come over here and say that. The other man drove to his challenger's location, produced a gun and shot the challencer's radio.

title: Notes on People
description: Truly hilarious was Shah Riza Pahlevi's description yesterday of Gen. George S. Brown's comment last week that judging from Iran's military buildup, you wonder whether he doesn't some day have visions of reviving the Persian Empire. Are we out of our minds to go after such nonsense? said the Shah in an interview published in Teheran yesterday. Don't we have enough problems and difficulties?

title: Eastern Plane Hits a Mudbank
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) An Eastern Airlines 727 jetliner with 92 persons aboard skidded off a rain slick runway today while landing at Washington National Airport. No one was hurt. An Eastern spokesman said that the plane was en route from Newark to Orlando, Fla., when it attempted to land for a stopover about 9 A.M. The plane got stuck in a mudbank near the Potomac River, the spokesman said.

title: British Soccer Standing
description: By The Associated Press

title: CORRECTION
description: Third quarter earnings of the Continental Illinois Corporation were incorrectly reported in last Friday's editions of The Times. The correct earnings were $29.13 million, an increase of 11.5 percent over the third quarter of 1975.

title: Dance Spell Scores as Aqueduct eopens
description: New York's nonstop flatracing season switched from scenic Belmont Park to winterized Aqueduct yesterday, but the name of the game remained unchanged.

title: N.F.L. Standings
In Memoriam
description: COOPERClara 0. Inlovina memory LARRY

title: School Results
description: GIRLS FIELD HOCKEY

title: 22 Whites Held In School Clash In South Boston
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (AP)Bands of angry whites, most of them students, had brushes with the police on the streets of South Boston today in a oneday school boycott that started with two attempts at bombing integrated schools. The police reported 22 arrests, most for disorderly conduct.

title: Bridge:
description: David Berkowitz, a young New York accountant, scored a triple triumph at the Metropolitan tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association, which took place last weekend at the StatlerHilton Hotel. He won the open pairs (with John Solodar of New York), led his team to victory in the Swiss teams, and was elected to his first term on the association's board of directors at the annual meeting.

title: Indians Ask Canada for a Province
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 25Leaders of the 7,000 Indians of the Northwest Territories filed a formal demand with the Government today for ownership rights and separate political jurisdiction over 450,000 square miles of the federally administered area.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: RESULTS

title: DORA LIEBERMAN SALTZMAN
description: Dora Lieberman Saltzman, a trustee of Maimonides Hospital, died there yesterday. She was 82 years old and the widow of Irving Saltzman, who headed Premier Industries, manufacturers of women's sweaters.

title: AllStar Baseball
description: By United Press International

title: Roosevelt
description: RESULTS

title: Circus Elephant Recaptured
description: PERRYVILLE, Ark., Oct. 25 (AP)Barbara, the fiveton circus elephant that led circus officials and police around ??? circles for nearly a week, was recaptured today. Officers said that Carson & Barnes circus workers captured Barbara beside the road not far from where she escaped last Wednesday while helping right an overturned truck. Barbara was frightened by another truck and bolted into the woods.

title: Why I'm Voting for McCarthy
description: If one trusts the wisdom of political journalists, Eugene J. McCarthy is campaigning for the Presidency this year on a single, not very significant issue. Out of a desperate need to relive his glory days of 1968, he has seized on some technicalities of the new election law as the vehicle for a hopeless, perhaps vindictive quest. His campaign is an ego trip.

title: Search is Widened For Bronx Arsonist
description: A widespread search was under way yesterday for the arsonist who caused a fire killing 25 persons in a Bronx social club early Sunday, but investigators said the case had become wide open.

title: Confusing Peking Picture
description: HONG KONG., Oct. 25Despite the huge rally in Peking yesterday to celebrate the appointment of Hua Kuofeng as the new chairman of the Chinese Communist Party and the downfall of China's four senior leftists, there are still several key questions that the country's new authorities have not yet answered. Foremost among these are:

title: CHINA, DESPITE DEATH OF MAO, OPENS PLANTS BUILT BY U.S. ON TIME
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 25Displaying evidence of economic normalcy following the death of Chairman Mao Tsetung, officials in Peking and Houston announced tonight the startup on schedule of three agriculture chemical complexes that are part of the largest contract ever awarded by China to a United States company.

title: 2 MORE OF THE AGED KILLED IN THE BRONX
description: Judith Campbell kept getting a busy signal when she telephoned her 74yearold mother, so yesterday morning she went over and knocked on the door of her mother's apartment in the University Heights section of the Bronx.

title: Knicks Lineup
Dividends
Ford Tactic: TV Documentary Plus Chat With Sports Announcer
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 25The Ford high command thinks that it has found the big megaphone that just might produce a victory in the final days of the campaign.

title: Peking Declares it Will Go Ahead With Chou's Modernization Plan
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 25China's new authorities said in a major editorial today that they would carry out the ambitious program of economic development originally put forward in early 1975 by the late Prime Minister, Chou Enlai, but criticized this year in the anti rightist campaign.

title: Tennis
Why the Giants Changed Coaches
description: After the Giants had lost three games this season, Bill Arnsparger called a secret meeting of his players.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The New York Times/Frank C. Dougherty

title: Opening Day in Emergency Room: Pains, High Fever and a Seizure
description: A 27yearold man entered the North Central Bronx Hospital emergency room yesterday complaining of chest pains. A 62yearold woman arrived, saying she felt dizzy. A 13yearold girl with a 104degree temperature was brought by a medical paraprofessional from her high school. And an 8yearold boy, so severely retarded he could not sit up or speak was brought by his mother, who said the child had just suffered a seizure?

title: Mrs. Ruth is Dead
description: Mrs. Claire Ruth, widow of the homerun slugger, died of cancer here yesterday at the age of 76. An obituary appears on Page 42.

title: TOP ENTERTAINERS PROMOTING CASINOS
description: NEWARK, Oct. 25I believe in gambling, Henny Youngman said today.Everybody wants to have a little fun. My mother liked to gamble. She went to Las Vegas and played the stamp machine. She won about half the time.

title: Venezuela Depicts Intrigue Among Exiles in Crash of Cuban Plane
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 23Shortly before a bomb exploded aboard a Cuban airliner on Oct. 6, forcing it to crash off Barbados with the loss of all 73 aboard, the telephone rang here in the office of a private investigating company.

title: 2 Women Drivers Seek To Qualify for Car Race
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 (AP)Two women drivers, Janet Guthrie and Arlene Hiss, have entered the Times 500 NASCAR race Nov. 21, a spokesman for the sponsor said today. They still must qualify for the race.

title: Advertising
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Oct. 25With happiness in their hearts and money in their pockets the members of the 57yearold Magazine Publishers Association began their annual meeting here today, their bright hopes for the future only slightly dimmed by the omnipresent specter of television.

title: Transkei, a South African Black Area, Is Independent
description: UMTATA, Transkei, Tuesday, Oct. 26The Republic of Transkei was proclaimed at one minute past midnight, the first of South Africa's black homelands to attain independence.

title: CAREY TOPS BEANIE IN POLL ON FINANCES
description: Governor Carey has come through a year of fiscal turmoil in New York City and state with a positive image among New York State residents, a survey of voters indicates, while his fellow Democrat, Mayor Beanie, is rated unfavorably by a majority of New York City residents.

title: Indifference is Reaction to vote Drive in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.
description: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Oct. 25There are no political billboards on the roads of this picturesque village nestled now in the pastel colors of fall. No political posters adorn the shop windows on Main Street, where the onestory and twostory buildings have a commanding view of the Hudson River.

title: Market Place
description: The Franklin Mint, a company whose directmail sales of commemorative coins and metals, leatherbound books, china and crystal have been growing sharply, stumbled in the third quarter, and its shares took a dive.

title: Bergen Sheriff's Officers Press For Same Raises as County Police
description: HACKENSACK, Oct. 25The Bergen County Board of Freeholders and the county's 260 sheriff's officers are embroiled in a salary dispute set off by the board's decision to break a longstanding policy of maintaining pay parity between the sheriff's men and the county's police officers.

title: Champion and Hoerner Resume Talks on Merger
description: Merger negotiations between the Champion International Corporation and the Hoerner Waldorf Corporation, which were terminated in July of 1975, have been resumed, it was announced jointly by the two companies yesterday. Under terms of the agreement calling for exchange of stock valued at $317.5 million, Champion International would exchange 0.95 share of Champion International for each share of Hoerner Waldorf.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: LERMONIOV (March). Left Le Havre Oct. 18; due A.M. at W 55 in St.

title: ExPrisoners and Captors Join in a Walk Over Kwai Bridge
description: KANCHANABLIRI, Thailand, Oct. 25This time the Japanese wore dark business suits, black ties and mourning bands around their arms. Their wives wore black kimonos and some of them wept. The Australians wore shirts and knee socks and an American carried two American flags.

title: Children, New Gurney Play, Begins Brightly, Then Falters
description: A young wife turns to her husband and says, Here I am in your mother's outfit, you're in your father's bathrobe, and we're living in your family's house. In A. R. Gurney Jr.'s new play, Children, which opened Sunday at the Manhattan Theater Club, the familyrich, rulebound and very Waspishis a sustaining but also a stunting force.

title: Eda Lord, a U.S. Raised Writer Living in London, Is Dead at 69
description: Eda Lord, who was raised in the United States but lived in Europe, died Saturday in London where she lived. She was 69 years old.

title: News Summary
description: A bumper Soviet grain harvest was announced by Leonid I, Brezhnev, the Communist Party leader. He told the Central Committee that the harvest Could reach or exceed the record crop of 222.5million tons reaped in 1973. The big crop, which contrasted markedly with a disastrous harvest last year, was attributed by specialists to good weather, including timely rains. [Page 1, Column 4.]

title: U.S. and Hanoi Aides to Meet Soon
description: May be willing to clear up the missinginaction now because President Ford has threatened a United States veto of Vietnam's application to the United Nations unless that issue is resolved. That threat, last month, led the French to put off a Security Council vote until after November to provide time for a diplomattic resolutiral of the matter.

title: British Open Raises Purse
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Oct. 26 (AP)Prize money for next year's British Open golf championship has been raised to $160,000, an increase of onethird over 1976. The Royal and Ancient Club, annoucing prize money for the 1977 Open at Turnberry, Scotland, said the winner would get $16,000. That is $4,000 more than Johnny AliFier collected for winning the title at Birkdale this year.

title: Ann Buckley Forsakes Privacy to Campaign for Husband and His Philosophy
description: ??? Buckley is a very private person who has gone public.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Favors Moynihan; Key Black Group is Still Reticent
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm endorsed the Senate candidacy of Daniel P. Moynihan yesterday, thus becoming the most prominent black elected official to announce support of him.

title: Goldstein Says ProCasino Forces Distort Possible Benefit to State
description: NEWARK, Oct. 26United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein accused backers of legalized casinos in Atlantic City today of exaggerating the possible economic benefits of gambling revenues to the state.

title: Simpson Rides Texas to Title In Puissance
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 26Texas, a mount owned by the Canadian Equestrian Team, cleared a 6foot4inch fence tonight to win the puissance (high jump) at the Washington International horse show.

title: Elizabeth Moynihan Leaves the Sidelines for an Active Role in Senate Race
description: Elizabeth Brennan Moynihan, who by her own admission has been making mischief in her husband's senatorial campaign, was sitting on a beige sofa in their East Side sublet the other day when somebody mentioned doubledomed intellectuals.

title: Einstein on the Beach, by Wilson And Glass, Coming to Met Nov. 21
description: The Metropolitan Opera has confirmed that the American premiere of Einstein on the Beach an avantgarde theater piece by Robert Wilson with a score by Philip Glass, will be given on Nov. 21. The performance will be a copresentation of the Met and the Byrd Hoffman Foundation, Mr. Wilson's organization. Pair. Wilson's previous works seen in New York include The Life and Times of Josef Stalin and A Letter to Queen Victoria.

title: Wallace Leads Qualifiers Of NorthSouth Seniors
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 26 (AP)Bob Wallace of Pensacola, Fla., carded a oneoverpar 73 today to take twostroke lead after the first round of qualifying for the North and South seniors golf championship at the Pinehurst Country Club.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
Fisher Measures Up to Carnegie
description: Amateur acousticians and possibly a few of the protessionals as well have been busy drawing comparisons between the rebuilt Avery Fisher Hall and its elder sister, Carnegie. And in these opening days of the New York Philharmonics season, an extraordinary conflation of circumstances gave any interested listener the opportunity to hear the same work in both halls, with the same orchestra and the same conductor.

title: Catholic Call to Action
description: Near the end of the national Roman Catholic Call to Action conference last week in Detroit, Archbishop Peter L. Gerety of the Archdiocese of Newark clasped Msgr. John Egan of the University of Notre Dame in a bear hug and exclaimed, Jack, this is one of the greatest days in the church. The next day three delegates from New York expressed similar enthusiasm in a report before the Archdiocesan pastoral council.

title: Secret Service Irksome to Officials and Newsmen
description: When Jimmy Carter arrives at Seventh Avenue and 36th Street for the traditional Democratic garmentcenter rally at 12:30 this afternoon, he will be surrounded by a squadron of nervous, waryeyed young men in raincoats.

title: He Warns I.M.F. Against Forcing Policies on Britain Harmful to the Economy
description: LONDON, Oct. 25Despite criticism from its political opponents, the Labor Government showed no signs today of backing down from its belief that Britain, in order to save the pound, might prefer to reduce its overseas commitments before cutting social prograss at home.

title: Ford Accused by 10 Nobel Winners Of Inaccurate Claims on Science Aid
description: Ten American winners of the Nobel Prize charged yesterday that President Ford was using the nation's Nobel sweep this year to make inaccurate claims about Government accomplishments in the support of science.

title: Redskins Set for Cowboys After Turning Back Cards
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Diron Talbert, Washington's ferocious defensive tackle, said today that he didn't care it Tom Landry himself played quarterback for the Dallas Cowboys here on Sunday, the Redskins would be ready to conquer again. Talbert About was swaggering a little in the wake of Washington's Pro remarkable 2010 victory Football over the St. Louis Cardinals last night in the rain and mud of R.F.K. Stadium.

description: There are two times in the year when one can scarcely stay indoors. in the spring, when the buds are about to burst, and now, soon after the first hard frost.

description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Oct. 26Magazines, once the only national advertising medium, are now looked upon only as carriers of special promotions or sendoff coupons by many of the major advertisers.

CAIRO MEETING ENDS WITH NO FINAL PACT ON A LEBANON FORCE
description: CAIRO, Oct. 26Arab leaders ended a twoday conference here without final agreement on arrangements for an expanded Arab peacekeeping force for Lebn anon. But their closing statements appeared to imply that Syrian troops already in Lebanon would dominate it.

title: Airline Strike Continues
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (AP)A strike by pilots against Continental Air Lines continued today and a company spokesman said that no new talks had been scheduled. The spokesman, Bruce Plowman, said that all. 383 daily flights had been canceled through Thursday and ticketholders had been shifted to other airlines.

title: Books of The Times
description: There was a time when, travel being difficult, kings sent painters abroad to execute and bring back portraits of eligible wives. Now we have novelists who go abroad to bring back portraits of ineligible peoples, those so different from us that a marriage of minds or cultures seems improbable. These writers, or portraitists, are not commissioned by kings, or even publishers. but by their own curiosity or conscience.

title: Article 6  No Title
Detroit Begins Taxes and Jobs Drive
description: DETROIT. Oct. 26  Faced with fiscal and jobs crises that in many respects resemble those of New York City, Mayor Coleman A. Young officially formed today an Economic Growth Council charged to review the city government's operations and tax structure and develop programs to reverse the diminishing jobs trend here, all within the next 12 months.

title: Brownstones Sprucer Now In'the Valley in Harlem
description: A major preoccupation of homeowners who live between the crowded avenues above 110th Street in Harlem is with overcoming the stigma of living in the Valley.

description: The unions are pushing for a fourday week but we retailers in New York State now have to work seven days a week, declared Arnold Lerner, the owner of a furniture store in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn.

title: Dividends

description: Crocheting today is far from being all afghans and baby booties. in the last decade a small number of craftsmen have chosen this technique as medium of esthetic expression.

description: Black politicians and social activists in Harlem began a citywide campaign yesterday to get out the largest black vote possible in November.

title: Proposal for FlatRate Electricity Billing is Assailed
description: BOSTON, Oct. 26  Utter chaos would follow if Massachusetts voters approved a referendum next Tuesday calling for socalled flatrate electricity billing, the president of one of the state's leading industrial employers said today.

title: which lever?
description: To the best of our knowledge the League of Women Voters is the only nonpartisan organization whose object is to getpeople to vote and to vote intelligently. We are told it neither supports nor opposes any party or any particular candidate.

title: SOUTH KOREA DENIES LINKS TO LOBBYIST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The South Korean Embassy denied today that there was any connection between the Seoul Government and Park Tong Sun, a wealthy Korean businessman, who is under Federal investigation, accused of seeking to influence members of Congress.

title: A Tax Break for Cities
description: In the pastiche of tax reform provisions just signed into law, there is one real reform that will have a substantial effect on cities. it has been Federal tax policy until now never to give a landmark an even break. The law has rewarded landmark demolition by making it tax deductible and added insult to injury by providing for accelerated depreciation on the replacement.

description: The Knicks are beginning to convert the nonbelievers.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 26Five women who were adopted as children pleaded today in Superior Court that adopted children, when they grow up, have the right of access to their birth certificates so they can search for their natural parents.

title: People in Sports
description: Whitey Herzog, who managed the Kanas City Royals to their first Western Division title in the club's eightyear history, was named yesterday American League manager of the year by United Press International.

title: PAPER ASSERTS WIFE REWORDED MAO DATA
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 26Shortly after Mao Tsetung died last month, his widow, Chiang Ching, took out several of Mao's documents from the Communist Party's special archives and reworded them, a Hong Kong newspaper said today.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: Aqueduct Racing

title: President, Deviating From Pledge, Attacks Carter on Foreign Policy
description: CHICAGO. Oct. 26President Ford, deviating from his pledge not to attack his rival, declared today that the election of Jimmy Carter as President would threaten world stability, weaken American security and alter the foundations of the foreign policy pursued by the United States for three decades.

title: Virginian, 67, Gets Life
description: FREDERICK, Md., Oct. 26 (AP)A 67yearold Virginia man was sentenced today to life in prison by Circuit Judge Robert E. Clapp Jr. for the murder of two women here last Jan. 8. The judge sentenced Robert L. Turner of Woodstock, Va., after turning down a request by the prosecutor for consecutive life terms. Such a sentence would have made parole more difficult.

title: 2 in Congress Doubt Ford's View on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The chairmen of the Congressional committees that recommended Gerald R. Ford's confirmation as Vice President in 1973 raised questions today about the President's contention that their committees had cleared him of allegations that he helped to block a 1972 House investigation of the Watergate breakin.

title: The New York Times/Gary Settle
description: MOLINE. III., Oct. 26Jimmy Carter set out today on his final week of campaigning, which will take him to six major battleground states where the 1976 Presidential election will probably he decided. He exhorted the uncertain and the apathetic to cast their ballots, promising to replace stagnation in government with aggressive but prudent action.

title: Music: AvantGardists Tax Limits
description: BOSTON, Oct. 26Since Sunday, the World Music Days of the International Society for Contemporary Music has been holding strenuously forth at Jordan Hall of the New England Conservatory of Music. Strenuous is the correct word. The sessions call for two concerts a day, each some two hours long, filled with complex avantgarde music that taxes the minds of the listeners as strenuously as it taxes the capabilities of the performers.

title: West Point Lawyer Who Challenged Academy in HonorCode Scandal Resigning After Losing Promotion
description: WEST POINT, Oct. 26Capt. Arthur Lincoln, the military lawyer who successfully challenged the United States Military Academy's handling of what became its biggest cheating scandal, is leaving West Point and the Army under pressure.

title: News Summary
description: The Cairo meeting of Arab leaders produced no accord on the makeup of an expanded peacekeeping force for Lebanon, but their closing statements seemed to imply that Syria would dominate it. This was in spite of objections by Iraq, Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization to Syria's role with 23,000 of its soldiers in the country. [Page 1, Column 6.1

title: Some Young Voters in Fort Worth Seem to Be Leaning Toward Ford
description: FORT WORTH, Oct. 25  Othar McCurry is worried. A strong supporter of Jimmy Carter who says he has not found out anything Ford's done as President, Mr. McCurry has an uneasy feeling that the election is slipping away from the Democratic nominee.

title: New Shops, Uptown and Downtown, Cater to Those Who Like to Eat Well
description: To lovers of good food, the arrival on the local scene of even one shop offering original and delectable specialties would be considered welcome news. But to have two such newcomers in town is cause for a fullscale celebration, a time to eat and rejoice.

title: The Television Blitz
description: A great change has come over the candidates in the last week of the campaign. The magical theatrical arts of Times Square and the cunning techniques of Madison Avenue, with just the right camera angles, voice levels and patriotic crowd shots, have suddenly transformed Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter into flawless statesmen.

title: Rockefeller's West Virginia Funds Near $3 Million in Governor Race
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 26It now seems likely that John D. Rockefeller 4th will spend something near $3 million here, most of it from his sham of the family fortune, to correct the mistake he made in 1972losing the West Virginia governorship and clouding a national political future.

title: U.S. is Set to Help Rebuild Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26State Department officials said today that a worldwide effort costing as much as $300 million to $500 million might be needed to help Lebanon in postwar reconstruction if the present ceasefire proved effective.

title: Candace Mossier Garrison Dies; Was Tried in Murder of Husband
description: MIAMI BEACH. Oct. 26 (UPI)Candace Mossier Garrison, acquitted in the 1964 death of her millionaire husband in one of the most sensational murder trials of the 1960's, died in her sleep today.

title: Bankers on Continent Distressed by Remarks
description: PARIS, Oct. 26Disquiet is growing on the Continent over Britain's third monetary crisis this year and its implications for world economic and financial stability.

title: For Doctors Wives, Clouds But No Silver Linings
description: LOS ANGELESTo many women, marrying a physician means financial security and social prestige. To others, however, it means a short, unhappy marriage that ends in divorce.

title: Inmates, for $30, Received Whisky In Cans of Juice
description: STORMVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 26 (AP)Some inmates at the Green Haven State Correctional Facility have been receiving whisky mailed into the maximumsecurity facility. in fruit juice cans, the state police said today.

title: McVay Takes Giants' Helm Quietly
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 26The Giants still have an 07 wonlost record.

description: 4 very thin slices white bread

title: The Contest Is Nostalgic, Skillful Play
description: Shirley Mezvinsky Lauro's first play, The Contest, an oldfashioned, naturalistic sliceoflife that takes place in a small town in the Middle West in 1943, rises far above its genre. Mrs. Lauro, a novelist, has a natural talent for the theater, and the production, as directed by Paul Austin at the Ensemble Studio Theater, is impeccable.

title: Illness Halts Shapp's Speeches
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 26 (AP)Gov. Milton J. Shapp ruptured a blood vessel in his throat during a speech in New York City over the weekend and will be unable to make any more speeches for Democratic candidates, an aide said today. It's apparently not serious, said Mike McLaughlin, the Governor's press secretary.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Oct. 26The growing power struggle between New Jersey's 600 school boards and 100,000 teachers and school administrators is expected to intensify during the next two weeks.

title: Norman Lear and Mobil Oil Take 2 Approaches to Syndicate Serials
description: Norman Lear and Herbert Schmertz are determined to beat the system.

title: CARTER AND FORD AIM AT L.I. TO WIN STATE
description: With President Ford, Vice President Rockefeller and Jimmy Carter campaigning on Long Island during the final week of the Presidential contest, the suburbs there have become a crucial battleground in the fight for New York State's 41 electoral votes.

title: Suit on Sludge Sought in Jersey
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., Oct. 26 (AP)State Senator John Russo, Democrat of Ocean County, said he would ask the State Public Advocate's office to sue New York and New Jersey communities that dump sludge off the New Jersey coast. Mr. Russo said yesterday that he and Robert A. Gasser, a County Freeholder, would meet with Stanley Van Ness, the Public Advocate, here tomorrow to discuss a course of action. Mr. Russo said that there was a growing concern that sludge dumping was one of the major contributory factors in the algae growth, which caused several fishkills along Ocean County beaches this summer.

title: Grandmother is Raped and Robbed By a Burglar in Her Bronx Home
description: A 69yearold grandmother was raped and robbed in her bedroom yesterday after she interrupted a burglar as he prowled through her house on a quiet residential street in the Bronx.

title: Charges of Wrongdoing Being Ignored in Congress Races
description: GRIFFIN, Ga., Oct. 26Charges of political corruption or personal scandal appear to be making little impression on American voters in a number of Congressional races around the country.

title: L.I. Plane Flights Set To Bridgeport JaiAlai
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 26Sound Air Aviation, in cooperation with the operators of the JaiAlai Fronton, will begin eightpassenger flights from MacArthurIslip Airport to the Bridgeport Airport, starling tomorrow evening.

title: issue: The Human Condition
description: On Aug. 12, 1974, three days after he took the oath of office, President Ford told a joint session of Congress: As Vice President, I studied various proposals for better health care financing. I saw them coming closer together, and urged my friends in the Congress and in the Administration to sit down and sweat out a sound compromise. Why don't we write and I ask this with the greatest spirit of cooperations good health bill on the statute books before this Congress adjourns?

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Beame administration announced a plan to save $1 million by limiting the checkcashing privileges of 225,000 city employees. Up to now, according to Ivan E. Irizarry, the city Finance Administrator, municipal workers could cash their paychecks at any bank in the city, even if the bank was not the worker's own. About four million such checks were cashed last year aloneat a cost to the city of 25 cents a check. Mr. Irizarry said that the city had won a concession from the civil service unions accepting the new regulation, saving the city the million dollars a year. He said that the employees would soon receive a circular with the information and effective date of the change and that they would have to go to banks where they have accounts to cash their salary checks.

title: Scaloppine Aphrodite
description: 1 pound veal scaloppine, about eight ounces

title: 25C FARE FOR PUPILS APPROVED BY M.T.A.
description: Bowing to pressure from Mayor Beame and a group of legislators, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday granted halffare privileges for 113,500 pupils who since last month had been paying the full 50cent fare for trips on subways and buses to and from school.

title: Tenneco 3dQuarter Net Up 6.2% On a 12% Advance in Revenues
description: Tenneco Inc., the widely diversified company operating in nine separate fields, reported yesterday a thirdquarter profit increase of 6.2 percent on a 12 percent revenue gain. The results reflected an improvement over the second quarter.

title: World News Briefs
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 26 (Reuters)Prime Minister John Vorster said in an interview published here today that he had forbidden Arnaud de Borchgrave, a senior editor of Newsweek, to visit South Africa.

description: New York City and the state moved quickly yesterday to rake advantage of a Federal pumppriming program that could pour $232.9 million of money from Washington into construction projects that have been stalled or abandoned in the fiscal crises of the last two years.

title: WILLMM KAUFMAN, 80, LED BUILDING CONCERN
description: William Kaufman, founder of the William Kaufman Organization and head of one of the major real estate and building families that helped reshape the city's skyline in the postwar period, died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. He was 80 years old and lived in Great Neck L.I.

title: Carter Cancels a Visit to Jersey; Fear of Tax Protest Seen in Move
description: Jimmy Carter's campaign staff has blamed scheduling problems for the decision to cancel a planned visit to New Jersey Friday, but political leaders in both parties say they believe Mr. Carter watns to avoid a possible confrontation with antiincome tax demonstrators who are already calling for the defeat of Governor Byrne and the Democratic state legislators next year.

title: Cocoa Futures Climb 2c a Pound
description: Cocoa futures, still displaying strength on speculative buying, rose to their previous record high price of $1.28 2/10 yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange and then fell back to close at $1.26 85/100 in terms of the December delivery, up 2 cents a pound from Monday. The record price was first reached last Friday.

title: Law is Sought to Require 2 Exits In SecondFloor Gathering Places
description: Buildings Commissioner Jeremiah T. Walsh said yesterday that New York City was considering a measure that would require two means of exiteither two enclosed stairways or a stairway and fire escapefor all public gathering places above a street floor.

title: Technology
description: Scientists seek new ways to protect developing nations with rapidly expanding populations from the ravages of insect plagues on their grain crops. Page 63.

title: Teamsters Pension Fund Board Revamped as 11 Trustees Resign
description: The teamsters union's major pension fund, which has been charged with improper activities for 20 years and under investigation by the Federal Government, announced yesterday the resignation of 11 trustees as part of a major reorganization of its board of trustees.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Hunting For Woodcock a Lesson in Futility
description: ROSCOE. N.Y,  Most hunters or anglers who stop in Roscoe will visit. Doug and Anna Mae Bury's Antrim Lodge, not only because of the good food and warm welcome, but also because they will invariably find others of their persuasion perched at the bar.

title: Mexico to Float Peso 2d Time in 2 Months
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 26 (AP)The Mexico Government freed the peso to find its own level in international money markets tonight for the second time in nearly two months, hoping to stem a flight of capital from the country.

title: Personal Finance: Mortgages
description: The Administration's graduated mortgage payment plan will be instituted next Monday. Most bankers doubt that the program will provide much immediate help to home buyers. Page 67.

title: Avnet Asks F.T.C. To Back Sale to Wabash
description: Avnet Inc., said that it had requested the Federal Trade Commission to approve, the sale of certain assets of the International Products and Manufacturing Company to Wabash Inc. of Wabash, Ind., under an F. T. C. divestiture order issued three years ago.

title: In Memoriam
description: GOLDMar C. 10 yrs have gone since you left me. Miss you more and more as the years on by. DAVE.

title: Tiger International Seeks Investors Mortgage
description: Tiger International Inc. of Los Angeles, owner of the Flying Tiger air transportation line, said it had signed letter of intent to buy Investors Morgage Group Inc. for cash amounting to no less than $37 million or more than $39 million.

title: McCarthy Ordered Back on Ballot, Moynihan to Liberal Line, as of Now
description: ALBANY, Oct. 26Eugene J, McCarthy, an independent candidate for President, was ordered back on the New York State ballot today by the Appellate Division. And, in another decision that also overturned a lowercourt ruling, the Appellate Division said that Daniel P. Moynihan, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator, was entitled to the Liberal Party line.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority approved a 8108,700 study to try to reduce the number of headon collisions on the southern end of the toll road. The study will he contracted through the Federal Highway Administration to Ultrasystems Inc. of Phoenix, Ariz. The rate of headon collisions caused by vehicles jumping the median divider is higher south of New Brunswick because trucks and other heavy vehicles have a greater chance of crossing the median along the southern 80 miles of the roadway. North of New Brunswick, the turnpike is divided into dual threelane roadways in each direction, with trucks and buses limited to the outside roadways, thus reducing the chance they will vault the dividers between lanes.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for ???

title: CARTER AND FORD AIM AT L. I. TO WIN STATE
description: With President Ford, Vice President Rockefeller and Jimmy Carter campaigning on Long Island during the final week of the Presidential contest, the suburbs there have become a crucial battleground in the fight for New York State's 41 electoral votes.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Two Elderly Men Found Dead; Police Blame Illness and Poverty
description: The fourroom apartment at 651 West 188th Street, in Washington Heights, was littered with wine bottles and rubbish. Two elderly men lay on the living room floor, dead, it appeared, for more than a week. An elderly woman was semiconscious on the floor of her bedroom. There was no evidence of violence.

title: Brownstones Sprucer Now In the Valley in Harlem
description: A major preoccupation of homeowners who live between the crowded avenues above 110th Street in Harlem is with overcoming the stigma of living in the Valley.

title: P.B.A. Head Advises Members to Accept Contract
description: The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has sent a detailed explanation of the proposed agreement with New York City to the union's 18,000 members and has recommended acceptance as the best of available alternatives.

title: Changes Sought in Jersey Law on Adopted Children
description: ATLANTIC CITY. Oct. 26Five women who were adopted as children pleaded today in Superior Court that adopted children, when they grow up, have the right of access to their birth certificates so they can search for their natural parents.

title: Norcross Has a Hard Job Against Williams
description: NEWARK Oct. 26Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. heard himself described from campaign platforms this week as the most popular Senator in Washington, and there are a number of Democratic candidates in next week's elections who hone it's true.

title: Fire Kills Woman, 63, in Home
description: TRENTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)Marian Tracy, a 63yearold switchboard operator at the Trenton Psychiatric Hospital for the last 18 years, was killed today in a fire at her home. Firemen said a spark from a cigarette had ignited a livingroom chair. Mrs. Tracy, who lived alone, was trapped in her bedroom.

title: Her. Majesty Industries Approves G.&W. Offer
description: The hoard of Her Majesty Industries, a children's wear manufacturer in Mauldin, S. C., yesterday approved an offer by Gulf and Western Industries for all of the assets of Her Majesty: on Sept. 28, Gulf and Western announced that it had agreed to buy a 48 percent interest or about 435,500 shares in Her Majesty, from Arthur Magill, chairman of the company for cash and promissory notes.

title: New York's Law On Death Penalty Is Found Invalid
description: A State Supreme Court Justice ruled yesterday that New York State's death penalty law was unconstitutional, in the first legal test of the law since a landmark decision by the United States Supreme Court last summer.

title: New York Food Prices Tumble as Supplies Rise
description: The greatest overall food price decline in the past six months was reported here yesterday by Consumer Affairs Commissioner Elinor Guggenheimer.

title: Dirty Tricks in Dead of Night
description: Florence Silverman was fast asleep in her West Orange home when the jangle of the telephone awakened her and the caller asked whether she intended to vote for Jimmy Carter for President.

title: JIMMY BUFFETT A FLUENT AND FRESH SOUTHERNER
description: Jimmy Buffett, who opened a twonight run at the Bottom Line on Monday, is a countryflavored singersongwriter who has more talent than his rather modest commercial success so far would indicate.

title: Unity of Rhodesian Factions Sought
description: GENEVA, Oct. 26Efforts to unite Rhodesia's factionridden black nationalists were under way here today as Ivor Richard of Britain continued his quest for flexibility in the opposed positions of the white and black delegations to the conference on a transition to black rule.

title: CAIRO MEETING ENDS WITH NO FINAL PACT ON A LEBANON FORCE
description: CAIRO, Oct. 26Arab leaders ended a twoday conference here without final agreement on arrangements for an expanded Arab peacekeeping force for Lehranon. But their closing statements. appeared to imply that Syrian troops already in Lebanon would dominate it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The most astonishing aspect of this Presidential campaign is the fact that a major political party should nominate a candidate for the Presidency whose experience and exposure in foreign policy is virtually zero.

title: U.S. Steel Says 3Month Profit Is Down 17.8%
description: The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday a decline of 17.5 percent in net income for the third quarter.

title: Election Panel Gets Six Complaints
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Complaints that five conservative political groups and a major professional fundraiser for such causes have violated the campaign law have been filed with the Federal Election Commission.

title: Analyzing Joblessness
description: WASHINGTONAt 7.8 percent, the unemployment rate today is almost twice as high as that of 20 years ago. Although the unemployment rate measures fairly well what it intends to measure, intervening events in the last two decades have affected the comparability of the data.

title: About New York
description: Moving to final rest at 65 miles an hour, the last remains are trundledeastward from the city along the Long Island Expressway to Exit 49, where the cortege's headlights beam southward through the fall sunshine to Pinelawn, the great suburban resting place for the urban dead.

title: 12 Earthquakes Jar California
description: FULLERTON, Calif., Oct. 26 (UPI)Twelve minor earthquakes jarred a section of northern Orange County last night and early today. There were no reports of injuries or property damage.

title: Miss Holtzman's Opponent Faces Awesome Task
description: Her campaign button says it all. Liz Holtzman Again! its blue and white slogan proclaimsnot the more precise Reelect Liz Holtzman or the more informative Liz Holtzman for Congress. The button's language underscores a basic political fact of life for any New York City Democrat in Congress, Election Day is not so much a time for reelection as for simple ratification.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CORNUCOPIA Name it  china, pottery, jewelry, folk art, patchwork quilts and American, British and European furniture and moreand the 33d annual Greenwich Village Antiques Show and Sale probably has it, from 35 dealers in six states. The event starts tonight at 7 o'clock with a party benefiting Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street (a block south of Sheridan Square); the tab is a taxdeductible 510.

title: Open Interest
description: (In bushels, 000 omitted)

title: Moderate Price Rise In Oil Held Saudi Aim
description: Alawi Darwish Kayal, Saudi Arabia's Minister of Posts and Telegraph, said yesterday at a news conference in Montreux, Switzerland that his Government would seek a moderate increase in oil prices at the Dec. 15 meeting of the Organization of Petroium Exporting Countires. He declined to provide any figures.

title: ABC Freight Triumphs in Westbury Trot
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 26Taking command from the outset, Arthur Brown's heavily favored ABC Freight scored a fivelength victory in the $64,290 Westbury Trot for 2yearolds at chilly Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: GEORGES CABANIER, FRENCH ADMIRAL,DIES
description: PARIS, Oct. 26Adm. Georges Cabanier, France's most senior naval officer, who fought with the United States Third Fleet in the Pacific during World War II, died today at his home here of an apparent stroke. He was 69 years old.

title: Market Place
description: MCA Inc., the producer of the movie Jaws, started buying Sea World Inc. last August, obtaining 8 percent of the marine park companys shares from institutions through a West Coast broker at 514.96 a share.

title: Other Earnings Results Reported
At Stake in Geneva
description: The only visible basis for hope for the conference Rhodesia that opens tomorrow is the fact that all the white and black leaders invited by Britain have come to Geneva to participate. if their private negotiating positions were as rigid as their public postures they would hardly have bothered to make the long trip north.

title: French Schoolchildren Found To Eat Little and Work Too Much
description: PARIS, Oct. 26French schoolchildren work too hard, sleep too little and do not eat enough breakfast. As a result their attention suffers, they do not learn. as much as they should and too many of them come down with psychosomatic ailments.

title: Notes on People
description: Sectary of State Henry A. Kissinger, not generally known for according excess praise, characterized the late Dean G. Acheson yesterday as the greatest Secretary of State of the 20th century. Mr. Acheson, a Democrat, held the office from 1949 to 53 in the Administration of President Truman. He died in 1971. Mr. Kissinger spoke at the dedication of the State Department's West Auditorium as the Dean Acheson Auditorium.

title: Trinidad Deports 2 Venezuelans Held in Crash of Cuban Airliner
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 26.Two Venezuelans arrested in Trinidad as suspects in the bombing of a Cuban airliner that crashed off Barbados, killing all 73 persons aboard, arrived here today in the custody of the Venezuelan police.

title: Electrical Workers Union Voting By Mail for Its Two Top Offices
description: Members of the International Union of Electrical Workers in the United States and Canada will vote this week and next for their choices for president and secretarytreasurer of the 275,000member union.

title: A Precious Moment Arrives for LuxuryLoving Palates
description: We may have remarked a few hundred times that there is almost no food known to man that, given a purse of sufficient size, cannot be purchased in America in or out of season, be it Australian kangaroo tail, scotch grouse or reindeer from Finland. One rare and notable exception is a delicacy, peculiarly Italian, that will he available in this country for a short period beginning this week. That exception is fresh white truffles, one of the most extraordinary luxuries ever to touch a person's palate.

title: Champion International to Sell Drexel Unit To Dominick International for $53 Million
description: The Champion International Corporation said in Stamford, Conn., yesterday that it would sell its Drexel Heritage Furnishings unit in Drexel, N. C., to the Dominick International Corporation for about $53 million. Dominick International is the parent of Dominick & Dominick, a New York stock brokerage and investment firm. Under terms of the agreement in principle, the sales price of the unit was said to he equal to the net hook value of the assets, and liabilities assumed at the time of closing. Dominick will pay more than $40 million in cash and the balance in preferred stock and subordinated notes to be redeemed within five years.

title: FORT LEE OPPOSING RENTLAW DECISION
description: TRENTON, Oct. 26An attorney for Fort Lee urged the State Supreme Court today to overturn a lowercourt decision invalidating the Bergen County borough's rentcontrol law. He said that invalidation would create havoc with rents in the area.

title: BUCKLEY TV ADS SPUR NEV TOMB STANCE
description: With three new television commercials and endorsements from the city and state Patrolmen's Benevolent Associations, Senator James L. Buckley intensified his campaign yesterday to sustain what he said was momentum that had built up this week.

title: FORD APPROVES RISES IN CERTAIN AIR FARES
description: President Ford approved yesterday a Civil Aeronautics Board decision granting the airlines some increases in winterseason promotional fares on the North Atlantic but rejecting other major ones that the carriers had sought.

title: FAO Schwarz to Open For Sunday Yule Sales
description: FAO Schwarz will be the second Fifth Avenue specialty store to open its doors on Sundays during the coming Christmas shopping season.

title: OIL CONCERNS INVEST IN VARIOUS SOURCES OF ENERGY, U.S. FINDS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Most of the nation's largest oil companies have invested in alternate energy activities such as coal, uranium, geothermal energy and solar energy. according to a study done for the Library of Congress.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)Eight American steel companies asked the International Trade Commission today to investigate charges that Japanese manufacturers of stainless steel pipe were selling their products in the United States below the cost of production.

title: Pound Problems Continue With New Low of $1.59
description: LONDON. Oct. 26 (AP)The British pound slipped to another record low of $1.59 today after steadying briefly as the Government discussed how to recover from yesterday's worst singleday drop in history.

title: Schlesinger Doubts That Peking Will Seek to Heal Rift With Soviet
description: James R. Schlesinger, former Defense Secretary recently returned from a private visit to China, expressed doubt yesterday that Peking's new moderate leadership would seek to heal the schism with the Soviet Union or otherwise alter China's strategic relationship to the United States.

title: Syria and P.L.O. Said to Renew Military Links in South Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 26Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization, whose forces fought a bloody battle in the mountains above Beirut only 10 days ago, were reported today to have resumed some of their previous military cooperation in southern Lebanon.
