description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Oct. 27 (Reuters)Five Turkish workers were burned to death in their beds and two died when they leaped from upperfloor windows after fire broke out in a lodging house here during the night, the police said. They said 23 Turks were injured, two seriously.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Cavaliers, at Cleveland. (TelevisionChannel 9, 8 P.M.)

title: Companies Report Their Sales and Earnings Figures
description: For priods ended Sept. 30 unless otherwise indicated. (N) Indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) American Stock Exchange and (0) over the counter.

title: GIL RAISED INCOME 63% TO $397 MILLION FOR THIRD QUARTER
description: DETROIT, Oct. 27The General Motors Corporation reported today that earned a net income of $397 million, an increase of 63.2 percent, during the third quarter of this year.

title: ExAide of Humphrey Asks Judge To Suspend FourMonth Jail Term
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's former campaign manager has asked a judge to suspend his fourmonth jail term for taking illegal campaign contributions, the Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Protestant Publication Proposes Saturday Be Day of Rest for All
description: Christianity Today, the Protestant evangelical fortnightly published in Washington, has proposed that Saturday be set aside as a day of rest for everybody. Those who choose to join in worship of God on that day could do so, the magazine suggests in Its lead editorial for Nov. 5, while those who do not so choose could spend the time in their own way.

title: DR. JOSEPH H. N. JONES
description: Dr. Joseph H, N. Jones, a retired general practitioner, died Monday at Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 87 years old and lived in Freeport, L.I.

title: Kissinger Assigning Top Adviser To Prevent Stalemate on Rhodesia
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 27Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has ordered his principal African adviser to fly to Geneva to do whatever he can to help the British prevent a breakdown in the negotiations between black and white Rhodesians for a new Rovernment in Rhodesia.

title: Mobil Accused by Mrs. Schaffer Of State Campaign Interference
description: Gloria Schaffer, Connecticut's Secretary of the State and Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, said today that she would complain to the Federal Elections Commission that the Mobil Oil Corporation, through a newspaper advertisment, had illegally supported her opponent.

title: At Rally in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 27 (UPI)President Ford campaigning on the Boardwalk here, told New Jersey voters today to e wary of a candidate who turns his rack on the voters after Election Day.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Voters Overseas Say That Ballots Haven't Arrived
description: PARIS, Oct. 27A number of Americans abroad, most of them New Yorkers are complaining angrily that election boards at home are not responding to their requests for absentee ballots in time for their votes to be counted in the Presidential election.

title: In Tux and Gowns, SomeOutdoorTypes Climb the Walls
description: Some of the men who have climbed to the summit of business and industry rappelled down a marble staircase at the Plaza the other night. But most of them took the elevator.

title: New Bond Issues
description: New Bond Issues

title: Seoul is Said to Allow Companies to Cheat American Army
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27Army investigations have concluded that the South Korean Government has condoned if not controlled a practice of collusive bidding among Korean contractors that is costing United States military units in South Korea about $20 million a year.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: fourth quarter. By that time Erving had pushed the margin to 20 points.

title: GLENN ERVIN TUCKER
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 27 (AP)Glenn Ervin Tucker, a noted Civil War historian, died early today in an Asheville hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: New York City Patronage Jobs Are Still Around but Not to the Extent They Were Before the Fiscal Crisis
description: Patronage, long the lifeblood of New York City's political organizations, has been slowed to a trickle by the city's fiscal straits, but the job faucet still drips occasionally.

title: Daughter Testifies In Friedgood Trial On Hiding of Drugs
description: MINEOLA, L.I, Oct. 27A woman entered Nassau County Court today, paused once to smile at her father, Dr. Charles E. Friedgood and then testified that at her father's request she took two bottles and a hypodermic syringe with a needle from an upstairs filing cabinet and put them in her underwear until after the Nassau County police, who had been searching the Friedgood home for drugs, left the premises.

title: Church to Stay in Senate
description: DENVER, Oct. 27 (UPI)Senator Frank Church, an unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, says that he will not accept a position in a Jimmy Carter Administration if the former Georgia Governor is elected President. I think I can render a better service to both my state and the country by remaining in the Senate, the Idaho Democrat said yesterday. He was here to campaign for Mr. Carter.

title: Confidence Declines
description: Consumer confidence fell sharply in October a Conference Board survey shows. Page 67.

title: British Parties Reject Coalition Idea
description: LONDON, Oct 27A suggestion by Harold Macmillan, a former Conservative Prime Minister, that Britain should have a government of national unity to get it out of its economic mess, has been rejected out of hand by both major political parties.

title: 2 Men, Including ExPoliceman, Indicted in Armed Bank Robbery
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a former New fork City detective, Dennis W. Mulligan, 39 years old, and John Anthony Cerasani, 38, on charges of conspiracy and armed bank robbery.

title: F.C.C. Backs Bid By Buckley to Gain Free Time on PBS
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday upheld the contention of Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, that five public television stations in the state have not provided him with adequate free air time, as he had requested under a provision of the Campaign Communications Reform Act of 1971.

title: U.S. Agency Finds Another Rise In 77 Auto Prices Unwarranted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27A Government agency said today that auto manufacturing costs had risen less than some companies announced and that there was no basis for another increase in prices for 1977 models.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Buckley Defends Campaign Ads; Runs Into New York Carter Rally
description: During a crowded day of campaigning that began in Manhattan at 9 A.M., senator James L. Buckley yesterday defended his new television commercials disparaging his Democratic rival, Daniel Patrick Moynihan. During his travels he crossed Jimmy Carter's trafficcongested trail in midafternoon and he ended late last night at a Queens County Republican rally in Astoria.

title: Body of Florida Girl, 8, is Found
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Oct. 27 (AP) The body of Lisa Lynn Berry, the 8yearold girl whose disappearance led to a fourday search by hundreds of volunteers, has been found in a canal. Authorities said today that she died from a blow to the head. A deputy medical examiner identified the body, found floating last night in a Broward County canal, as that of Lisa.

title: Court of Appeals Rejects McCarthy, Upholds Moynihan
description: ALBANY, Oct, 27In a decision that Democratic leaders say will help Jimmy Carter in the Election Day contest for New York State's 41 electoral votes, the State Court of Appeals today disqualified former United States Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota as an independent Presidential candidate in the state election.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 27 (AP)A flash fire in the National Hotel near Red Square killed a New York businessman and sent hundreds of thinly dressed guests into the freezing streets early today.

title: Opus 65, a Dance to the Loss of Innocence
description: From time to time, the Joffrey Ballet goes on a social history trip. There could be no better tour conductor in this special area of dance than Anna Sokolow, and on Tuesday night at the City Center, the company revived her ballet Opus 65.

title: ORDER ON SCHOOL BUSING IS APPEALED IN KENTUCKY
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct, 27 (AP)Jefferson County officials who contend that a Federal judge went too far in ordering extensive busing to integrate schools in the Louisville area took their case to a higher court yesterday.

title: Paris Collections: Everything Seems to Tie in Nicely
description: PARIS, Oct. 27After the shocker of the return of the mini, the hig fashion news in Paris involves clothes that you wrap and tie yourself into. Even the Missonis have gotten into the act, in a most civilized way of course.

title: MORE POWER URGED FOR MAIL RATE BIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27The Postal Rate Commission, which is assigned to look after the public interest in establishing mail rates and guarding service quality, needs clearer powers to keep the huge deficitridden United States Postal Service in check, according to the General Accpunting Office.

title: Warring on Crime in the First 100 Days
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.In view of the way crime was an issue in the last three Presidential campaigns, it should he a relief that it appears in a more muted form this fall. But. President Ford's promise of an anticrime program in the first 100 days of a new Administration prompts one to ask for an accounting of the last 2,800 days of this law and order Administration.

title: Big Political Scandal Held PossibleStudy Still in Early Stage
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27The sweeping investigation of South Korean political influence here is focusing on the possible involvement of 90 members of Congress and could become a major expos of political corruption, senior Government sources said today:

title: Sonderling's Purchase of WRVR From Church Approved by F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission in a 50 vote, with two commissioners absent, yesterday approved the sale of FM radio station WRVR from the Riverside Church to the Sonderling Broadcast.inr Corporation for $2.3 million.

title: Seoul is Said to Allow Companies to Cheat American Army
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27Army investigations have concluded that the South Korean Government has condoned if not controlled a practice of collusive bidding among Korean contractors that is costing United States military units in South Korea about $20 million a year.

title: Vietnam Accuses Thai Regime And Demands That it Free 800
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 28 (Agence FrancePresse)  Vietnam has warned Thailand to stop what it terms the persecution of Vietnamese citizens and has demanded the release of 800 people reportedly interned in concentration camps.

title: George A. Gottlieb Dies at 73, Long in Real Estate Business
description: George A. Gottlieb, a real estate man in New York City who in 1943 was president of the Smaller Business Men's Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, died yesterday in the Neurological Institute of Columbia Presbyterian Nledical Center here after a lingering illness. His age was 73.

title: FRENCH POLICE HOLDING 7 IN ROBBERY OF CENTURY
description: PARIS, Oct. 27Seven of the men who pulled off the robbery of the century last July at Nice are under arrest at Marseilles. They have confessed. And a part of the $8 million haul they made away with after having tunneled their way into a bank has been recovered.

title: Poll Finds Georgia Backs Carter
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 27 (UPI)According to the Darden Research Corporation, the Democratic Presidential candidate, Jimmy Carter, leads President Ford by nearly 2to1 margin in Georgia. The poll indicated that 59.8 percent of the Georgia voters reached last week would vote for the native son, Mr. Carter, and 30.4 percent for Mr. Ford, and that 9 percent were undecided.

title: MSGR, THOMAS FAHY OF SETON HALL DIES
description: Msgr. Thomas G. Fahy, president of Seton Hall University since 1970 and regarded by many Roman Catholic leaders as one of the church's most forwardlooking educators, died yesterday of a heart attack in his quarters on the universio.. campus. He was 54 years old.

title: Around the Nation
description: DETROIT, Oct. 27Top officials of the United Automobile Workers union announced today that the Chrysler Corporation, the nation's third largest auto maker, had been given until 6 P.M. Nov. 5 to to come to terms with the union on a new threeyear contract or face a strike.

title: EXAIDE SAYS U.S. SOUGHT TO HALT SEOUL'S LOBBYING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP)A former director of the State Department's Korean Affairs Office said today that the department several times pleaded unsuccessfully with the South Korean Government to put an end to activities involving members of Congress.

title: ABC'S QUARTER NET UP BY 93C A SHARE
description: The American Broadcasting Companies, which had a 1975 fourthquarter loss, the first in years, reported yesterday a profit of $17 million, or 95 cents a share, for this year's third quarter.

title: Physician Accused of $135,000 Fraud In Medicaid Cases
description: Dr. Sylvan L. Sacolick, who has been named as one of the physicians who received the most money from Medicaid in New York Stale last year, was indicted yesterday on charges of conducting a doublebilling scheme that allegedly defrauded the Medicaid program of $135,000.

title: Nystrom's Goal Ends PowerPlay Drought
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 28The Islanders took the cure tonight.

title: Israelis Wary But Una!armed by Shifts in Lebanon
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 28Israeli officials are carefully analyzing reports from Lebanon of an improvement in relations between two foes, Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization. as well as reports of a buildup of Palestinian forces in southern Lebanon close to northern.

title: Jonah, Drama of Guilt, At Jewish Theater
description: The Jewish Repertory Theater's second production of its third season will be Jonah, a drama dealing with the collective guilt after World War II that was written in 1947 by Giinter Rutenborn, a former pastor of a small parish near Berlin., Under the title of The Sign of Jonah, the play was presented in 1960 at the Players Theater in the Village.

title: Beyond McCarthy
description: The onagain, off again 10:1 mks of Eugene J. McCarthy in his quest for a Place on New York State's ballot as an independent Presidential candidate appear close to the end of the road. By a vote of 5 to 2, the State Court of Appeals has disqualified the former United States Senator from Minnesota. The ruling, which is being appealed to the United States Supreme Court, was based on real deficiencies in the manner in which McCarthy supporters collected and submitted the petitions required by the election laws.

title: Culinary Olympics: DeEmphasizing the Inedible
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 28I'm not crazy about inedible food, said Bruno H. Elmer at the 14th international Culinary Olympics, which attracted entries from 20 countries and featured, among other things, a category for such inedible food.

title: 12 Murals to Decorate Parsons Blvd. Station
description: Twelve 4 by 4foot murals, painted in acrylic on masonite, have been mounted on railings at the west end of the Parsons Boulevard Station of the E and F lines in Queens as part of an effort by the New York City Transit Authority to improve the appearance of subway stations.

title: Carter Sweep of South is in Doubt As Two States Lean Toward Ford,
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 28Contrary to early assumptions, Jimmy Carter could lose some Southern states in next Tuesday's election. according to political specialists in the region.

title: Carey Expands Ethics Regulation To Over 10,000 State Employees
description: Governor Carey expanded his financialdisclosure and conflictofinterest regulations yesterday to cover more than 10,000 state employees who were exempted from the original regulations he issued 18 months ago.

title: Business Records
description: Thursday, Oct. 28, 1971 Petition filed by:

title: Piano Recital: Weissenberg's Icy Intensity
description: There are people who complain that Alexis Weissenberg is a cold performer, but there is such a thing as icy intensity, and he is its personification among pianists. in a work lit by such cold fire as Liszt's Sonata in B minor, the centerpiece of Mr. Weissenberg's Carnegie Hall recital Wednesday night, the Bulgarianborn virtuoso has few peers.

title: CREDIT PRICES CLOSE WITH NARROW GAINS,
description: The credit markets wavered up and down within narrow limits several times yesterday and closed with small gains, nudged upward at one point when the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company reduced its prime rate and at another point later when the Federal Reserve Board reported a decline in the nation's money supply. However, after each slight gain, prices tended to drift back downward.

title: People and Business
description: John H. Lichtblau, executive director of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, said yesterday that the oil exporting nations could only justify price increase of somewhere between 2.7 and 7.8 percent if they based it on how much prices of things they must import have risen.

title: I.R.A. Aide Slain in Belfast Hospital
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 28 (UPI)Maire Drumm, former vice president of the Provisional Sinn Fein, political wing of the Irish Republican Army Provisionals, was shot to death tonight in her bed at Belfast's Mater Hospital.

title: Antiques
description: IT WAS ALASTAIR STAIR, an astute antiques merchant, who conceived the idea of bringing a very special cultural segment of Milton, Mass., to Manhattan.

title: NEW KOREAN INQUIRY BY U.S. IS DISCLOSED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28Federal authorities said today that they had been investigating a wide range of allegations that Korean intelligence agents and other Koreans had been harassing and coercing Iand violating the civil rights of Korean aliens residing in the United States and of KoreanAmericans.

title: Police in Japan Arrest 2,489 And $12 Million Worth of Drugs
description: TOKYO, Oct. 28 (Reuters)The Japanese police said today that 2,489 people had been arrested and $12 million worth of drugs seized in a coordinated nationwide raid against homes and offices.

title: Geico Lists Net of $5.8 Million, First Profit Since 3d Quarter 74
description: The financially embattled Government Employees Insurance Company reported yesterday its first net profit since the third quarter of 1974. Geico announced net income after taxes of $5.8 million in the period ended Sept. 30 despite an underwriting loss of $7.3 million.

title: Continued Growth in 1977 is Seen By Maier for Aluminum Industry
description: Cornell C. Maier, president of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, told some 250 leaders of the aluminum Industry yesterday that the industry's current condition is, in my opinion, good.

title: A Message From the Next President
description: WASHINGTONFor many weeks, the major issues of this year's Presidential campaign have been obscured by a fog bank of political rhetoric and petty diversions.

title: JERRY BUSH
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 28 (UPI)  Jerry Bush, a former basketball star at St. John's and coach at the University of Nebraska, died of an apparent heart attack yesterday. He was 62 years old.

title: IHILTON GAINS AN ACCORD ON PURCHASING WALDORF
description: Hilton Hotels announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company to buy the WaldorfAstoria Hotel for $35 million.

title: News Summary
description: The sale to China of a computer system with both military and industrial capability has been approved by President Ford. High Administration officials said that, in approving the sale, Mr. Ford was waiving established safeguards on the advice of Secretary of State Kissinger as a gesture to China's new leaders. Some officials had objected to the sale on the ground that the computer can be used to make calculations on n???lear tests. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Bench Gets a Prize and Gives a Warning
description: The Cincinnati Reds began to collect the spoils of their latest victory yesterday when Johnny Bench was honored as the hero of their World Series sweep of the New York Yankees.

title: At the Movies
description: SINCE THE URBANE and eternally unflappable Basil Rathbone has presumably passed on the happy sleuthing ground, the producers of Nicholas Meyer's The SevenPerCent Soluticrna fanciful confection centering on the investigative collaboration between a drugaddicted Sherlock Holmes and a budding shrink named Sigmund Freudhad their work cut out for them. Their challenging chore was to come up with a hero cast in the gruffly virile modern mold, yet one who would not enrage the hordes of Rathbone buffs. The 100 percent successful solution to the problem turned out to be Nicol Williamson, a blissfully unpredictable, jovially scowling Scotsman who is striking the same kind of moody sparks in the film that he ignited on stage in such plays as Inadmissible Evidence, Hamlet, Uncle Vanya and Macbeth.

title: Management: How a Boss Works in Calculated Chaos
description: Businessmen are discovering Henry Mintzberg, a bookish Canadian management theorist who depicts the manager's routineany manager's routine as controlled disorder.

title: A Native Son Returns To Make Jazz History
description: Dexter Gordon, the masterly jazz saxophonist who returned to New York last week from his home in Copenhagen, was rehearsing at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, preparing for an engagement which extends through Sunday evening, He had an audience of three, including his wife Fenja, his young son Benjamin, and his old friend Charles Mingus, the bassist. When Mr. Gordon picked up his horn and filled the small basement club with his huge, commanding sound, Mr. Mingus became so excited that he banged a fist down on his table. You're going to be teaching New York some stuff, he said approvingly. Some lessons.

title: Democrat Calls Some Reduction in 4 Years Almost Inevitable
description: Jimmy Carter raised yesterday the possibility of a tax cut if he is elected President but then indicated it should not be taken as a firm promise.

title: Sales by Chains Gained by 10.1% For September
description: The nation's chain stores chalked up a sales gain of 10.1 percent in September; compared with September 1975, Chain Store Age magazine reported yesterday. Fcr the first nine months of the year, the chains went ahead of the corresponding period of 1975 by 11.1 percent.

title: Dixon's Shift From Racing Gives 76ers a Golden Touch
description: F. Eugene Dixon used to think horse racing was the most pleasant way man with money could spend it.

title: Candace Mossier to Be Buried In Arlington National Cemetery
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 28 (AP)Candace Mossier, who officials say apparently suffocated in a heavily sedated sleep, will be buried tomorrow in Arlington National Cemetery beside the wealthy husband she was acquitted of slaying.

title: French Authority on Volcanoes Loses Post in Guadeloupe Dispute
description: PARIS, Oct. 28 (AP)Haroun Tazieff, an authority on volcanoes, has been dismissed from his post as head of a study institute after a dispute over a Caribbean volcano that was supposed to have exploded with atomic force last summer. but whose eruption was far milder.

title: Japan Series Game Rained Out
description: TOKYO, Oct. 28 (AP)The fourth game of the Japanese baseball World Series, matching the Hankyu Braves and the Yomiuri Giants, was rained out today. The Braves lead the fourofseven series, 30, on the strength or 6.4, 54 and 103 victories. They can wrap it up with a victory tomorrow.

title: Nominees Lift Voices to be Heard in the Land
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28Everyone speaks of the media blitz that is supposedly being waged for the Presidential candidates in the campaign's closing days, but a media blitz is what happens to this country 365 days a year. in the din of the general bombardment, it is not easy for the candidates to be heard.

title: Music: The Fires of London
description: The Fires of London, which gave the first of two concerts at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night (the second is next Wednesday), has never before played in America. But that doesn't mean it isn't wellknown here, since a series of records have attested to its expertise in a rather specialized repertory centered on the music of its founder and director, Peter Maxwell Davies.

title: 4 Tie for Lead at Pensacola on 67's
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 28 (AP)Jerry McGee, admittedly nervous in his role as the defender, fashioned a fourunderpar 67 and shared the firstround lead today with three others in the $125,000 Pensacola open golf tournament.

title: Learning to Read Through Art
description: It you're striding up the ramp at the Guggenheim Museum this weekendmoving familiarly past the stark bays that house those old friends, Hofmann, Albers and Rothkoyou're likely to break stride just as you reach the fifth ramp, where the museum has abruptly changed pace.

title: Stilwell, Part Baritone, Part Tenor, is All Pelleas
description: Richard Stilwell, who will be singing the male lead in Debussy's Pell&as et Melisande with the New York City Opera on Sunday night, has one of those unusual voices perched ambiguously between the baritone and tenor ranees.

title: Futures Prices Rise Sharply for Gold and Cocoa Beans
description: Gold and cocoa beans rose sharply yesterday for widely different reasons.

title: 4 CAR MAKERS TARGET A 13.6% RISE IN OUTPUT
description: DETROIT, Oct. 2SThe domestic auto industry is targeting production of about 803,000 cars next month on its way to a fourthquarter schedule of 2,195,000 units. The fourthquarter total would be up 13.6 percent from last year's 1,932,000. But it would still be 16 percent below the fourthquarter output record of 2,624,000 set in 1965.

title: Cardin Joins Miniskirt Parade
description: PARIS, Oct. 28Pierre Cardin returned to the scene of an earlier triumph last night. He first came to prominence 20 years ago as a couturier with a knack for designing snappy coats and suits for young women. Later, he became known, along with Andre Courreges, as a foremost exponent of the spaceage look. He lent, his name to such diverse products as motor cars and chocolates. He spurred the men's wear revolution with his brassbuttoned blazer and snug Edwardian cut in the 1960's.

title: Seton Hall Game Postponed
description: SOUTH ORANGE, Oct. 28 (UPI)The football game between Seton Hall and St. Peter's, scheduled for Saturday, has been postponed until 1:30 P.M. Sunday because of the death of Msgr. Thomas G. Fahy, Seton Hall president. it will be played at Underhill Field in Maplewood, N. J.

title: The Glow of Carter's Primary Drive Has Faded in His Contest With Ford
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct 28With its imaginative conception, its careful planning and its usually crisp execution, the campaign that brought Jimmy Carter to the platform at Madison Square Garden in July to accept the Democratic Presidential nomination was sometimes called brilliant. Few people, even in his inner circle, seem willing to apply that adjective to the general election campaign that has followed.

title: U.S. CENTER EKED ON LEGION DISEASE
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 28A report prepared for a Congressional subcommittee charges that the Federal Government mishandled its investigation of a mysterious disease in Pennsylvania by failing to give prompt, adequate attention to the possibility of a toxic cause.

title: CourtOrdered Halt In Putt ng Taconite Into Lake is Upheld
description: ST. PAUL, Oct. 28 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit upheld today a July 7, 1977, deadline for the Reserve Mining Company to halt discharges of taconite tailings into Lake Superior. But the court suggested that the deadline might be extended if there were changed circumstances.

title: Clown Princess Of Dance Goes Solo
description: I think the thing that is so lacking now in dance is nerve, that passionate calling, the Red Shoes number. I think von should be like that. I'm like that.

title: Ford Discloses NuclearCurb Plan; Carter Calls it Too Little, Too Late
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  President Ford today formally announced a broad new Government program to prevent nuclear materials intended for peaceful purposes from being used for atomic weapons, and Jimmy Carter, the Democratic nominee for President, charged it was too little and too late.

title: Student Dies in Adirondack Mishap
description: Doug Parker, a student at Middlebury College in Middlebury, Vt., died Wednesday in a mountainclimbing accident in the Adirondacks near Keene Valley, N. Y.  He was IS years old. He was a son of Mrs. David Mackintosh and H. Lawrence Parker. a managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company, investment brokers. He is also survived by two brothers, Richard and Michael, and a sister, Katherine Goldsmith.

title: HARLEM VOTE SOUGHT BY SENATOR BUCKLEY
description: Senator James L. Buckley spent most of yesterday in Harlem hoping to win votes in the wake of expressed coolness of some traditonally Democratic black leaders to his opponent, Daniel P. Moynihan.

title: SOVIET IS REBUFFED BY CHINESE AGAIN
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 28Although China has given no hint since the death of Mao Tsetung that it is ready to improve relations with the Soviet Union, the Russians seem still in a waiting, watching moodsuspending polemics in the press and probing for positive responses from the Chinese leadership.

title: World News Briefs
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Oct. 28 (UPI) A 26yearold Czech railway worker armed with a submachine gun, a pistol and a knife hijacked a Czechoslovakian airliner today and forced the pilot to fly to West Germany.

title: U.S. Aide Said to Reject Seoul Gift
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28A senior South Korean Government official attempted to give $10,000 in cash to an aide to President Richard M. Nixon in 1974, but the gift was rebuffed and the money returned to the South Koreans, senior intelligence and diplomatic sources said tonight.

title: James C. Maloney Dead; Veteran Pilot of Blimps For Goodyear and Navy
description: James C. Maloney, a veteran blimp pilot, died yesterday at his home in Akron, Ohio. after a long illness. He was 58 years old.

title: Lawyers Give Advice Free In WMCA Radio Program
description: If you walked out just to do your thing, and your wife is home and hasn't done anything wrong, chances are you are going to wind up supporting her.  the amount of the support? it depends on the circumstances. Click.

title: Palestinian Units in Lebanon Move Toward Israel
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 28Palestinian forces began to move southward today from two fronts in central Lebanon where they had been fighting the Syrian Army.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DORIC, Horne. Left Bermuda, Oct. 28; due 8 A.M. W. 55th St.

title: The Pop Life
description: DONNA SUMMER'S muchballyhooed appearDance monday night at Roseland or at least as much as this observer stuck around to seewasn't all that wonderful. But it did set one to thinking about the evolution of disco.

title: CHICAGO BANK SETS LOWER PRIME RATE; OTHERS RESIST CUT
description: Downward pressure on interest rates continued yesterday when the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, the nation's seventh largest hank, said it would cut its prime lending rate from 6 percent to 6 percent, effective today.

title: About Real Estate
description: Until a year or so ago there was to have been a yeshiva at 56th Avenue and Cloverdale Boulevard in Bayside. Queens, across the street from Queensborough Community College. Some of the steel was already in place. But the yeshiva changed plans, merged with another yeshiva instead, and sold the 1.4acre Bayside plot to Norman and Eli Bluestone.

title: Reserve Report
description: DAILY AVERAGES In Billions

title: Market Place
description: The Hughes Tool Companythe world's largest manufacturer of oil and gas drilling bits and an investor favorite in an era of feverish exploration for new energy sourcessurprised Wall Street after the close of trading on Wednesday by reporting a sharp drop in earnings in the third quarter.

title: Newark Hotel to Be Demolished
description: NEWARK, Oct. 2RThe 13story Essex House, a major hotel for 50 years and now a vacant and vandalized shell, will be demolished to pave the way for a $13.5 million senior citizens housing rehabilitation project, sources close to Mayor Kenneth A. Gihson disclosed today.

title: The Glow of Carter's Primary Drive Has Faded in His Contest With Ford
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28With its imaginative conception, its careful planning and its usually crisp execution, the campaign that brought Jimmy Carter to the platform at Madison Square Garden in July to accept the Democratic Presidential nomination was sometimes called brilliant. Few people, even in his inner circle, seem willing to apply that adjective to the general election campaign that has followed.

title: ExHead of Navajo Housing Authority and 2 Indicted
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 28The former head of the Navajo Housing Authority and two other men were indicted today by Federal grand jury on charges of misapplication of funds and conspiracy in connection with $15 million earmarked for housing on the largest Indian reservation in the country.

title: U.S. Grants New York Transit Projects $90 Million
description: The Federal Government announced grants of nearly $90 million yesterday for transit projects in the New York City area including an experiment in hovercraft commutation. But it also warned that the city must soon stop using capitalgrant money to meet transit operating deficits.

title: In Geneva Atmosphere, a Heavy Overcast of Old Suspicions
description: GENEVA, Oct. 28  Hours before the white Rhodesian and four black African nationalist delegations trooped into the main council chamber of the Palais des Nations and took separate tables, Ivor Richard, Britain's chief delegate to the United Nations, observed bluntly that the Rhodesia conference here faced some delicate and extraordinarily difficult problems.

title: PRIVATE NURSING HOMES BALK AT MEDICAID RATE
description: The organization that represents 95 private nursing homes in New York City said last night that it would refuse, a of Nov. 10, to accept new Medicaid patients unless the state increased its recently announced reimbursement rates.

title: Celebrating Meier's Pristine White Houses
description: It was only a few years ago that architects of Richard Meier's generationhe was born in 1934were considered the daring new laces on thearchitectural scene, Mr. Meier's pristine white houses began to dot the suburban and oceanside landscapes around New York in the mid1960's, and for all of their allusions to Le Corbusier, they were dramatically fresh forms.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney finds economists in San Francisco optimistic on economic prospects. Page D7.

title: Retail Store Sales Increase 9%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 28  The Department of Commerce reported today that retail store sales last week totaled an estimated $12.74 billion, up about 9 percent from the yearearlier level of $11.71 billion. Department store sales were about $1.33 billion, up about 19 percent from last year's $1.12 billion.

title: Democrat Calls Some Reduction in 4 Years Almost Inevitable
description: Jimmy Carter raised yesterday the possibility of a tax cut if he is elected President but then indicated it should not be taken as a firm promise.

title: In a Real Horse Race, Maybe Turnout Will Go Up
description: The most conventional wisdom of the 1976 election campaign is that voter turnout, which dropped to 55 percent of citizens of voting age in 1972, may fall below 50 percent this year. Partly based on 1972 statistics, partly derived from 1976 polling data and consonant with widespread reports of voter apathy, this assumption may nevertheless be more accepted than warranted.

title: Moynihan Calls Buckley Eccentric, Consistently Uncaring and Haughty
description: Daniel P. Moynihan described Senator James L. Buckley yesterday as an eccentricity that New Yorkers can ill afford in the United States Senate.

title: Sears Acts to Cease Banning Competition In Shopping Centers
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (Reuters)Sears, Roebuck & Company has agreed to end its practice of refusing space in shopping centers to tenants who would offer strong competition, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Striking Pilots Volunteer Service
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 (UPI)Striking Continental Airline pilots are volunteering to fly two flights each week on the airline's Micronesian Islands route because the service is the very lifeline of the South Pacific Islands, pilots said today. A spokesman for the Airline Pilots Association said that pilots had made the decision because of humanitarian reasons since Continental has the only air passenger service to the Micronesian Islands.

title: Clark Pupils Told Government Rules Cause Price Rises
description: CLARK, Oct. 28Representatives of the business community today told 100 high school seniors attending a symposiurn at the Ramada Inn that government regulations had grown to monstrous proportions and were adding millions of dollars to costs that had to be passed on to the consumers.

title: Education Chief Places Priority on Books and Supplies
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 28Fred G. Burke, the State Education Commissioner, said tonight that school budget ceilings would not be raised to accommodate increases in teacher salaries that might be negotiated with school boards.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)The Federal Railroad Administration said today it had selected a consortium of engineering and construction concern.; led by De Lem, Cattier & Company, of Chicago, and the Ralph M. Parsons Company, of Pasadena, Calif., to oversee rebuilding of the Northeast Corridor track between Washington and Boston.

title: Commodity Price Index Declines 1.4 From the WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 194.3 from 195.7 last week.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Thursday: London: Morning fixing $123.50, up $5.65; afternoon fixing SI22.75, uo $4.90.

title: ALFRED WILLOUGHBY; CITIZEN GROUP HEAD
description: Alfred Willoughby, who retired in 1968 as executive director of the National Municipal League, a nonpartisan citizen group seeking better government, died in Fairview Hospital, Great Barrington, Mass., Wednesday after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Peso Rallies on New I.M.F. Credit
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 28The Mexican peso rallied slightly against the dollar today after the International Monetary Fund last night approved a Mexican request for new credit facilities exceeding $960 million.

title: DIEBOLD VENTURE MEETING REJECTS VOTE CHALLENGES
description: he special meeting of stocitholdeers of the Diebold Venture Capital Corporation was finally concluded yesterday after a 15minute session at which all of the challenges to the proposals on the proxy were rejected.

title: Animal Farm Folds at Auction After a Game Fight to Survive in Town
description: SUFFIELD, Conn., Oct. 28The kinkajou went for $85, a pair of ferrets for $115 and two rare black swans for $162.50 each as a public auction that nearly everyone hoped could be avoided was held today to sell the stock of the Grand Game Farm here.

title: Advertising
description: The Bic Pen Corporation, having taken on the Gillette Company in the ball pen and disposable lighter categories, is now challenging the Boston giant in its area of greatest strengthrazors.

title: House Panel Urges a New Agency To Regulate Consumer Matters
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI)A Congressional study today recommended creation of a new agency for consumers, regulating everything from prescription drugs to seat belts.

title: Two U.S. Religious Leaders Assail Soviet Refusal to Admit Delegation
description: Christian and Jewish religious leaders criticized Soviet authorities sharply yesterday for refusing to admit an interreligious delegation to investigate the condition of Soviet Jews and oppressed Christian groups.

title: Iran Returns Defecting Soviet Pilot
description: MOSCOW, Oct 28The Soviet Union announced today that Iran had returned a Soviet pilot who flew a light plane across the border last month in search of political asylum.

title: Ford Now Leading Carter In California 46% to 43%, According to Field Poll
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28President Ford leads Jimmy Carter, 46 to 43 percent, in a California Poll sampling released tonight by Mervin D. Field.

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 28 (AP)  More than five million Americans have received swine flu shots, and the national immunization program is picking up steam despite some lingering fears, Federal, health officials said today.

title: The MoynihanBuckley Race: Breeding Gives Way to Brawling
description: Three weeks ago, Senator James L. Buckley and Daniel P. Moynihan debated for the first time. They differed on many issues but their differences were couched in gentility, humor and cordialitybefitting candidates from Yale News and Harvard who had not come up the hard way in Analysis elective politices. it seemed as though it might be a particularly literate campaign free of the usual rancor. Instead, it has been downhill since that first debate. Instead of Jim and Pat, it has been extremist millionaire, radical right, cruddy, elegant Charlie McCarthy, doubledomed intellectual, liberal golden boy and other pleasantries.

title: S.E.C. Pushes for Efficiency Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25In a major step in its campaign to reduce paperwork and simplify regulation, the Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered more than a dozen industry organizations to submit their own plans on how this should be done and threatened to impose its own solution it they tailed.

title: Publishing: An Album of Hard Times
description: ONE of the big books of St. Martin's Press for the fall is A Vision Shared, a compilation of photographs from the work of eleven photographers of the Farm Security Administration. The book covers the period 19351943 and reflects the Diaghilevlike guidance of Roy Stryker, not a photographer himself, but the motivating force behind the men and women who produced an unparalleled record of our country during those years. Through visual images they conveyed the texture, the artifacts, the life style of predominantly rural Americans, many of whom lived in conditions of squalor difficult to believe. That they were believed was due to the skill, the viewpoint and sustained passion of the people who took these photographs.

title: Raven Hanover Rated A Threat in Messenger
description: WESTBURY, L. I, Oct. 28What a difference a favorable post position and one good race can make.

title: ExHughes Aide Appears In a Court in Los Angeles After Warrant is Issued
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28A bench warrant was issued in Superior Court here today for one of Howard R. Hughes's personal aides, who then quickly appeared in court and was released on his promise to appear for questioning under oath Nov. 8.

title: Music: A Revue of Unheard Tunes
description: For more than a decade, Ben Bagley has been producing an invaluable series of records on which the less familiar songs of leading composers for the musical theater are featured. On Wednesday he brought a sampling of these Revisited albums to the stage at Town Hall as part of the Interludes series, complete with a spoken version of his liner notes in which the line between truth and fantasy is outrageously smudged and backed with slides in which stage designs by Shirley Kaplan were mixed with nudes, bearded ladies, Lois De Fee, the 6foot, 7inch nightclub bouncer and quondam stripper, vintage movie ingenues and other outrageous figments of the photographer's art.

title: Regents Urge New York to Widen Tuition Help at the City University
description: ALBANY, Oct. 28The New York State Board of Regents urged New York City today to provide free undergraduate tuitoday to give tuition assistance to City University students whose families had gross annual incomes of $14.000 or less.

title: A Journeyman Quarterback Passes Up Stop With Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 28Larry Lawrence, journeyman player, turned down his chance today to become a New York Jet quarterback. Instead, he returned to his sailboat on the Panama Canal.

title: Berger Warns City Not to  Maximixe Hospital Admissions
description: The executive director of the New York State Emergency Financial Control Board warned yesterday that the effort by the city's municipal hospitals to fill empty beds with Medicaid patients to maximize its Federal and state reimbursement could make them liable to charges of criminal fraud.

title: Geneva Talks on Rhodesia Open After Chairman Averts a Boycott
description: GENEVA, Oct. 28The Geneva conference on Rhodesia got off to a delayed start today after lastminute negotiations by the British diplomat Ivor Richard averted a possible boycott by two powerful black nationalist groups that are anxious that Britain play a more assertive role in the talks.

title: 2,000 at Wall St. Rally Brave a Chilly Afternoon To Bach Carter Ticket
description: About 2,000 people attended a Wall Street rally yesterday, fidgeting in nearfreezing weather as the Broadway celebrity Linda Hopkins sang a song for the CarterMondale ticket and chanted along with the entertainer Mitch Miller, We want Carter!

title: Hometown Paper Backs Ford
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 28 (UPI)President Ford's hometown newspaper, The Grand Rapids Press, today endorsed Mr. Ford for election in what it said was a very narrow choice over Jimmy Carter.

title: Funds to End YouthGang Violence Termed Misspent
description: The National Urban League, reacting to recent flareups of youthgang violence in major cities, said yesterday that millions of dollars in public money were being misspent through failure to use the expert knowledge of experienced minoritygroup organizations and gang members to combat the rise.

title: Fan Trouble at Pats Game Blamed on Hard Liquor
description: BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP)The owners of Schaefer Stadium, home of the New England Patriots of the National Football league, blame the violence by fans after the PatriotsNew York Jets game on Oct. 18 largely on hard liquor. Twentysix fans were arrested on various charges after the game.

title: Argentines Report 10 Slain
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28 (Reuters)Ten leftist guerrillas were killed today in a gun battle with an Argentine security force in woods at La Plata, 37 miles south of here, according to the police. They said that the guerrillas had opened fire from two cars on approaching troops. No casualties among the security force were reported.

title: City Firemen Hail OnceScorned Chief
description: In 1919, Wesley Williams, one of New York City's first black firemen and eventually its first black battalion chief, walked into his first city firehouse. The other firemen walked out in initial protest, then ostracized him.

title: 2 Japanese Car Makers to Weigh Setting Up Assembly Plants in State
description: TRENTON, Oct. 28Two Japanese car manufacturers, Toyota and Datsun, will explore the possibility of opening assembly plants in New Jersey, Governor Byrne said today at a news conference.

title: And for Hobnobbing With the Candidates
description: IT'S IMPROBABLE. no doubt, but if you should be at the MacArthur Field airport in Islip, L.I., at S o'clock this morning, you can see Senator James L. Buckley talk with some news reporters.

title: NEW KOREAN INQUIRY BY U.S. IS DISCLOSED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28Federal authorities said today that they had been investigating a wide range of allegations that Korean intelligence agents and other Koreans had been harassing and coercing and violating the civil rights of Korean aliens residing in the United States and of KoreanAmericans.

title: Newspapers Split on Use of Endorsements
description: Recently, The Wall Street Journal reprinted an editorial it ran four years ago to explain its dissent from the tradition that every good newspaper formally endorse a Presidential candidate.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: MYSTIC, CONN., is one of those special places where the past has never really died, but rather lives on elbow to elbow with the present. Sometimes the village's history of sailing ships and whaling captains gets lost amid the bustle of 20thcentury life and the hustle of commercial activity. And sometimes, when the light is just right and the air just so, the past takes over for a few moments for those willing to stop and look.

title: Ehrlichman Enters Prison Voluntarily
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28John D. Ehrlichman, one of the Nixon Administration's most powerful advisers, voluntarily entered a Federal prison camp today to serve sentences for his Watergate crimes, even though appeals in both cases are pending.

title: CBS Forsakes Giants, Chooses to Televise CowboysRedskins Game Instead
description: CBS, whicil has been loyal to the Giants and their fans for years, has finally forsaken them. The CBS station here, Channel 2, will not televise the soldout GiantsEagles game in the Medowlands but Dallas at Washington instead beginning at 4 P.M. League rules prevent the station from doing both. The Jets will be in view from Buffalo, Channel 4, 1 P.M. The Monday night game will display one of the best teams in pro football, Baltimore, against Houston, Channel 7, 9 o'clock. Previews of all games follow with wonlost records in parentheses.

title: Pop Music: A Marcovicci Without Guitar
description: Before Andrea Marcovicci gained her current renown playing opposite Woody Allen in The Front she was, among other things, a nightclub singer with a rather folkish outlook who player her own guitar and piano accompaniment. She has picked up that career again at Reno Sweeney where the folk quality has been replaced by a mixture of old standards and contemporary pop songs and her accompaniment is provided by a tightly organized quartet led from the piano by Lewis Friedman.

title: Troubled Children And a Rare Teacher
description: When Mary Stevens walked into her first classroom in Harlem nine years ago, one boy stepped on another's toe, and that child picked up a chair and soon furniture was flying around the room. Mrs. Stevens, shaken, eased back out the door. I went home crying. she said.

title: Plan to Rent Apartments on 42d St. To Theater People Draws Criticism
description: A proposal by the Beame administration to salvage the unrented Manhattan Plaza housing complex on West 42d Street by using Federal subsidies to allow members of the performing arts to rent most of the 1,600 apartments was attacked last night by realty interests and residents of the Clinton neighborhood.

title: Sabine and Hamilton End Talks
description: The Sabine Royalty Corporation said in Dallas yesterday that it had terminated merger negotiations with the Hamilton Brothers Petroleum Corporation. Sabine said that the two companies had been unable to agree on basic terms for a merger.

title: U. S. AGREES TO SELL CHINA A COMPUTER WITH DEFENSE USES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 President Ford, making exceptions to prevailing safeguards and established policy, has approved the sale to China of a computer system capable of being used for military as well as industrial purposes.

title: Reexamining the State of the Union
description: People under intolerable strain from wondering whether to vote for the man with the smile or the man with the steady look  and from noticing which candidate is currently under advice to inhabit which look  can always take this weekend off and go to the movies.

title: Egyptians, in Relatively Free Voting, Elect Assembly
description: CAIRO, Oct. 28A cautious and tentative liberalization of Egyptian political life began formally today as millions of voters elected a parliament in the first relatively free voting in Egypt since the early 1950's during the rule of King Farouk.

title: Pop Music: Diffident Ry Cooder
description: Through his records (the latest is called Chicken Skin Music) and his concerts (he opened a twonight run at the Bottom Line Wednesday), Ry Cooder has established himself as one of our most charming guitarists and musical collectors.

title: RADIO
Hope for Drama On Broadway?
description: This weekend you have your last chance to see a number of Broadway dramas. it is your last chance to see A Texas Trilogy. it is your last chance to see The Runner Stumbles. It is your last chance to see Harold Pinter's staging of The Innocents, starring Claire Bloom. if you do not hurry, it may he your last chance to see the new Czech play Poor Murderer.

title: Democrats Appear to Trail in Vermont Senate and Governor Races
description: MONTPELIER, Vt.As the first snows dust the Green Mountains, Vermont is seeing hardfought political campaigns that are sorely testing its growing, but now divided, Democratic Party.

title: Heroin Smuggler Convicted
description: A 42yearold Bangkok businessman was convicted by a Federal District Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday of trying to smuggle nearly 14 pounds of heroin into this country from Thailand. The drugs were said by Carol Amen, an assistant United States attorney, to have been concealed in a pedestal of a religious object brought here in a freighter from Hong Kong. The businessman, Prasarn Bhongsupatana, faces up to 30 years in prison.

title: Bridge:
description: For knockout players who like to use a swinging bidding style, the automatic redouble is worth considering.

title: A Time for Hobgoblins And Their Parents
description: THE LITTLE DEVILS will be partying and parading this weekend, accompanied by their friends the little monsters, the fairy princesses, the pirates, the skeletons, the space commanders, the gypsies, the wicked witches and the sixmilliondollar men.

title: Ruling on McCarthy Is Stayed for a Day To Allow an Appeal
description: ALBANY, Oct. 28Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel of the State Court of Appeals today delayed an order that had removed Eugene J. McCarthy from the state ballot as an independent candidate for the Presidency.

title: Essex House Will Be Demolished
description: NEWARK, Oct. 28The 13story Essex House, a major hotel for 50 years and now a vacant and vandalized shell, will be demolished to pave the way for a $13.5 million senior citizens housing rehabilitation project, sources close to Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson disclosed today.

title: Judicial Choices: Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Is,
description: Yesterday, we gave our preferences for judicial offices in Manhattan and the Bronx. Today, we cover Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: Berger Warns City Not to Maximize Hospital Admissions
description: The executive director of the New York State Emergency Financial Control Board warned yesterday that the effort by the city's municipal hospitals to fill empty beds with Medicaid patients to maximize its Federal and state reimbursement could make them liable to charges of criminal fraud.

title: Music: Cage's Renga Gives Lift To Festival of Modern Works
description: BOSTON, Oct. 28Contemporary music festivals sometimes are actually contemporary and occasionally contain some music, but they are almost never festive. in fact, circumspect or dour are words that might best describe the goingson at most of these events, which tend to be dominated by a few gray eagles of the composing flock and by solemnly professorial music. it may be John Cage's chief virtue that he acts as an antidote to all this sobriety and academic tailswallowing.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The New York Times/Andrew Sacks

title: CARTER EMPHASIZING MONDALE AS AN ASSET
description: ERIE, Pa., Oct. 28Jimmy Carter has begun an unusual effort to capitalize on the popularity of his running mate, Senator Walter F. Mondale of Minnesota.

title: Spur for Economy Urged
description: Jimmy Carter's chief economic adviser, Lawrence R. Klein, called for stimulus for the economy because has gone downhill so much. Page D7.

title: Simon Warns on Carter, Victory
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28 (UPI)Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said yesterday that the election of Jimmy Carter as President could hasten the country right down the road to state socialism.

title: Variety of Companies Issue Their Earnings Results
description: Variety of Companies Issue Their Earnings Results

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Joseph E. Schnee at 47; Bloomingdale's Executive In Charge of Soft Goods
description: Joseph E. Schnee, executive vice president of Bloomingdale's, died Wednesday at his Hartsdale, N. Y., home alter a long illness. He was 17 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on the aparttheid policies of South Africa.

title: Music: Leonid Kogan With the Philharmonic
description: It was a typical Boulez program a Handel concerto, the Berg Violin Concerto and an elaborate work by Olivier Alessiaen. Mr. Boulez and the New York Philharmonic took on those three works last night in Fisher Hall, with the assistance of Leonid Kogan, soloist in the Berg.

title: The Knot That Rhodesian Negotiators Must Untie
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The tragedy of Rhodesia is that the mere gathering of black nationalists around a conference table in Geneva may prove insufficient to produce a settlement satisfactory to all. The persuasive powers of a distinguished British chairman, the assurances of United States assistance, the support of nowpragmatic South Africans, andshould it be realizedeven the public humbling of a hitherto intransigent Rhodesian white public may all be to no avail.

title: Olin to Increase Chemical Price Of Thermolin 101 by 6c a Pound
description: The Olin Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase its price of Thermolin 101 chlorinated phosphate ester by 6 cents a pound to 91 cents, effective Nov. 15. The new price for truckloadcarload drums (40 drums minimum) will be 96 cents a pound and for shipments less than truck or carloads, 98 cents a pound. The chemical is a flame retardant additive for flexible urethane foam used chiefly in furniture, automotive and construction applications.

title: A School Clerk in Jericho Is Accused of Embezzling $130,000 in Last 11 Years
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 28A payroll clerk of the Jericho School District and her sister were indicted today by a Nassau County grand jury on charges of having embezzled more than 8130,000 from the district in the last 11 years.

title: Nominees Answer Watergate Query
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The responses of President Ford and Jimmy Carter to a questionnaire on proposed Government reform were released today.

title: Cancer Expert Urges New Effort I To Reduce Hazard in Cigarettes
description: WASHLNGTON, Oct. 28The hope of turning the United States quickly into a nonsmoking society is unrealistic, an officer of the National Cancer Institute said today, and therefore more attention should be paid to the development and use of less hazardous cigarettes.

title: Big Board Seat Price Off $3,000
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported the sale of a seat for $60,000 off $3,000 from the previous sale of Oct. 18. At present seats are quoted at $56,000 bid and $68,000 offered.

title: Books of The Times
description: When your husband dies, Amy Henderson discovers, you have to do things you may have forgotten how to manage after 30 years of marriage. You have to form individual relationships with people you knew casually from your safe cover as one half of a couple. After investing most of your life in acting the part of a wife, you are obliged to gamble as a free agent. You must contend with such new problems as pity, officious solicitude and sexual attraction. All at once, you are not a social asset or a pleasure to certain people, but a liability, or a problem. To others, with whom you felt safe, you are now exciting, and must live up to, or down to, their exceptions. Precisely when you are feeling most forlorn and empty, you are expected to respond and give of yourself.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: President Ford should be elected, if only to act as a brake on a spendthrift Congress. Congress spends billions as though they were only millions.

title: Librarian Guilty in Book Thefts
description: LEXINGTON, Va., Oct. 28 (UPI)The head librarian at Virginia Military Institute for the last 11 years has pleaded guilty to stealing 7,500 books from the school library valued at more than $34,000. Judge Paul Holstein in Rockingham County Circuit Court yesterday postponed sentencing of the librarian, Lieut. Col. George Davis pending a background report.

title: TV SPENDING RECORD IS SET BY FORD GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The President Ford Committee has already spent more money on campaign television advertising than has any other national candidate in political history, and the end has not arrived yet.

title: U.S., Canada to Play Off
description: ZURICH, Oct. 28 (AP)The United States and Canada will have to meet in a playoff to decide who advances in the preliminaries of the World Soccer Cup tournament, the International Football Federation said today. Mexico which tied Canada yesterday, has already qualified for one of the two spots in the next round, allotted to North and Central America and the Caribbean. No date has been announced for the United StatesCanada playoff.

title: Moslems in India Accuse Local Officials for Riot In Sterilization Dispute
description: MUZUFFARNAGAR, India, Oct. 28 (AP) Moslem leaders blame overzealous regional authorities and not Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government for a riot against sterilization 10 days ago. The leaders say police gunfire killed 50 to 150 people.

title: Geneva Conference at a Glance
description: PurposeCalled by Britain to work out a temporary biracial government in Rhodesia that would lead to black majority rule in the former British colony within two years.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Tonight is dominated by specials. Last year, the two  hour production celebrating 25 years of Bob Hope on television did very nicely in the ratings for NBC. So tonight at 8, the network is offering another twohour Bob Hope sampler, this one featuring highlights from 26 years of the durable performer's shows. Special guests thanking him for the memories are Lucille Ball, Neil Simon, Don Rickles and Norman Lear.

title: Monet's Reputation Out on Top This Time
description: WHAT TO THINK about Claude Monet is as hot a question as any now generally discussed among people who enjoy French 19thcentury painting. After Monet died in 1926 there was a subsidence during which nobody thought about him very much. There was then an interesting moment after World War 11 at which the late paintings of waterlines were on offer (at what now strikes us as laughably low prices) and found few takers. But how should they have been rated higher, when they werethought of as formless aberrations, all too evocative of the Painter's nearblindness?

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Poor Murderer. Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street. 2460390. Tonight and tomorrow at S. Tomorrow at 2 P.M. Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets at all prices available for all performances.

title: U. S. TRADE DEFICIT GREW LAST MONTH BY $778.9 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)The nation's trade balance slipped deeper into the red in September as imports exceeded exports by $778.9 million, the Commerce Department reported today. The figure, wider than August's deficit of $757.7 million, brought to $3.4 billion the total trade deficit for 1976.

title: African Virus to be Studied in U.S.
description: Federal scientists at the Center for Disease Control in Atlanta expect to receive specimens today from victims of a new disease in Africa to help determine how serious a threat the infection might represent to the world.

title: Palms for the Parlor, Office and Patio
description: Chamaedorea elegans (parlor palm). The dark green feathery leaves of this dwarf palm, which rarely exceeds two feet in height, are a decorator's standard. it is one of the few palms that flower regularly indoorsbut the whole inflorescence looks like little more than a bunch of diminutive green lentils. Parlor palms are usually grown several to a pot for lushness. They like a warm climate (average 75 degrees) and low light.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: United Press International

title: When Irish Bars Are Smiling
description: Booze and iloquence, said Mr. Dooley many years ago, has both passed out iv our public life. Finley Peter Dunne, Mr. Dooley's creator, was writing during Prohibition. Booze has returned, of course, but eloquence, alas, is still in short supply. Except, perhaps, in the Irish bars on weekends.

title: T. H. RobsjohnGibbings is Dead; Designer and Interior Decorator
description: Terence Harold RobsjohnGibbings, a Londonborn interior decorator, furniture designer and author, who had lived in Athens since 1964, died of a heart attack on Oct. 20. He underwent openheart surgery in Dallas a year ago. His age was 71.

title: Events and Openings
description: UP, rfirejed In. Russ Meyer, at neictithorhod theaters. PEOPLE OF THE WIND, directed by Anthony Howarth, at the D. W. Griffith Theater.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: United Press International

title: Ehrlichman Enters Prison Voluntarily
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 28John D. Ehrlichman one of the Nixon Administration's most powerful advisers, voluntarily entered a Federal prison camp today to serve sentences for his Watergate crimes, even though appeals in both cases arl pending.

title: Ruby &hut, 63, is Dead; Said She Was Involved In  Scottsboro Boys Case
description: YAKIMA, Wash., Oct. 28 (UPI)Ruby Schut, who said she was one of two women who made a rape charge in 1931 against the nine Scottsboro Boys in Alabama, is dead. She was 63 years old. She died of natural causes yesterday.

title: Westchester Symphony
description: The Westchester Symphony Orchestra will open its 52d season tomorrow night at the Highland School, White Plains, with a concert featuring three soloists, David BarIllan, piano; Eric Friedman, violin, and Michael Rudiakov, cello. Raffael Adler will conduct the concert, which starts at 8:30 P.M. Tickets can be ordered by telephone: (914) 4724560.

title: Tong Sun Park in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 29Park Tong Sun, the key figure in the unfolding investigation of South Korean influencebuying in Washington, arrived here late last night.

title: Gus Hall, Communist Candidate, Says Goal is Just to Raise Issues
description: Gus Hall chuckled: I tell them that if New York City is not getting Federal attention, you should give the Communist Party a big vote. Then you watch the Federal Government pay attention.

title: VENEZUELA PRESSES CASE AGAINST 6 IN PLANE CRASH
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 28Two special prosecutors have been appointed by Venezuela's Attorney General to prepare charges against six persons arrested here as suspects in the crash of a Cuban airliner off Barbados.

title: New York Elections Unit Reports That It's Ready For Anything on Tuesday
description: The New York City Board of Elections, whose shrunken staff of 272 was flooded by 100,000 mail registration forms that arrived the first week of October, finally caught up with its paper work yesterday and prepared to conduct next Tuesday's election.

title: Narcotics Use Again a Worry At City College
description: City College officials are considering whether to ask the police to come onto the campus to help curb an increase in illegal drug sales that they say has developed since the college completed a drug cleanup last spring.

title: U. S. AGREES TO SELL, CHINA A COMPUTER WITH DEFENSE USES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 President Ford, making exceptions to prevailing safeguards and established policy, has approved the sale to China of a computer system capable of being used for military as well as industrial purposes.

title: Art: Early Photos By Robert Frank
description: BETWEEN an artist's myth and the reality of his life and work, there are inevitably certain discrepancies. The myth seizes on extremes of feeling, whereas the realitymore often than notis a subtler mixture of more variegated emotions and perceptions. And while such myths always have an obvious appeal, they are never sufficient for a complete understanding of either the artist or his work.

title: Ford Vows Effort to T rim Taxes; Carter Hints Cut but Bars Pledge
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 28President Ford, acting as though he was certain of election in his own right next Tuesday, said today that he would make another Federal income tax reduction the Number One priority in the next Ford Administration.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: The New York Times/Wilham E. Sauro

title: WARREN BOWER, TEACHER; WAS HOST OF RADIO SHOW
description: Warren Bower, professor emeritus of English and a former assistant dean of New York University's School of Continuing Education, died Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at the Salmagundi Club, at 45 Fifth A venue.

title: Oil Companies Build Inventories Before Price Increase by OPEC
description: With a price increase by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries almost certain on Jan, 1, the multinational oil companieseager to protect themselves at least temporarilyare scrambling to build up inventories at today's lower prices.

title: OM FILE OF YOUTH IN THE BRONX IS CITED
description: The chairman of the New York State Senate's Committee on Crime yesterday broke the rules of confidentiality on Family Court records to charge angrily that a 19yearold robbery defendant had a long background of juvenile delinquency, including the murder of a 92yearold man.

title: Inside Occult New York
description: This Sunday is Halloween, All Hallows Eve, the ancient Celtic Samhain, when the portals gaped wide between this world and the otherworld, freeing spirits to do mischief; the night, in effect, that all hell broke loose. it is the season when, according to folk legend, unsuspecting mortals were rapt away by demon lovers to a place where seven years pass as swiftly as if they were seven days.

title: The Greta Garbo of the Bar
description: She moved comfortably among European nobility and Presidents of the UMled States. Her clients came from the Social Register, the Algonquin Rpund Table and early Hollywood. Preferring to operate behind the scenes, in the 1930's she was labeled the Greta Garbo of the bar.

title: Troubled Children And a Rare Teacher
description: When Mary Stevens walked into her first, classroom in Harlem nine years ago, one boy stepped on another's toe, and that child picked up a chair and soon furniture was flying around the room. Mrs. Stevens, shaken, eased hack out the door, I went home crying. she said.

title: ANTONINHAYMOND,88, BUILDING DESIGNER
description: Antonin Raymond, an architect who was associated with the late Cass Gilbert and Frank Lloyd Wright, died Monday at St. Mary's Hospital in Langhorne, Pa. lie was 88 years old and a resident of New Hope, Pa.

title: Friendly Enemies
description: OTHER PEOPLE'S TABLES by Corinne Jacker. ??? by Robert Mandel; sett;ng by Linda Carmichael; lighting be Cheryl Thacker; ??? by Pit MeGc.urty; ene Junction stage manager, Stephen James. P.7,sentcd by the Billy Munk Theater, At 302 East ??? Streel.

title: Eight School Districts Weigh Sharing of Their Facilities
description: RIDGEWOOD, Oct. 28 Confronted With a declining student enrollment and increasing educational costs, seven school districts in Bergen County and one in neighboring Passaic County have started exploring the possibility of sharing some of their facilities and courses.

title: Stocks Drop 3.49 Points to 952.63 After Two Big Gaining Sessions
description: Stock prices dropped moderately yesterday after two sessions of brisk advances.

title: Carter Rebuffed on 65 Land Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI)Jimmy Carter made an unsuccessful effort in 1965 to reclaim some Georgia land being held as loan collateral. He was turned down because of suspicions his aim was to raise money for personal reasons, possibly politics, and not to expand his business.

title: Shrine Bowl Sanctioned
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 28 (AP)The National Associaion of Intercollegiate Athletic sanctioned the San Jacinto Shrine Bowl football game today to be played nt Pasadena, Tex., on Dec. 4. The game will match the champions of the Lone Star Conference in Texas and the Akansas Intercollegiate Conference.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday.

title: U.S. Contracts Unit Urged Not to Alter Civil Rights Rules
description: The groups, in a meeting with reporters yesterday, appeared most disturbed by a proposal to raise the number of employees required to he employed by contractors before a Federal contract must be reviewed prior to being awarded.

title: KLEIN, IN SHIFT, ASKS ECONOMIC STIMULUS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 28Lawrence R. Klein, Jimmy Carter's chief economic adviser, said today that the national economy has gone downhill so much in recent weeks that it is evident that the economy needs stimulus.

title: But the Water Jump's a Fake
description: The 93d National Horse Show comes to Madison Square Garden Tuesday. The Westminster Kennel Club was 6yearold pup in 1883 when mounted cops and horsedrawn fire engines first drew crowds to the original Garden between Madison and Fourth Avenues at East 27th Street. that makes the horse show the secondoldest sports competition held without interruption in the city. Unlike some other entertainments in the Garden, such as grudge matches between wrestlers, everything about the show is on the level except the water in the Liverpool Sports jump. That's oilcloth painted blue. The of earthen flooring is the real thing, a mixture of loam and binder's clay that has The Times been rented from and returned to the Consolidated Excavating Company every November for 40 years. What if a horse lands in the water and tears a hole in it? Honey Craven was asked. Four faults, he said.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY. OCTOBER 21,1976

title: Islanders,Resch Stop Blues,52; Knicks Routed by Cavaliers
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Oct. 28  Four games into the National Basketball Association's 31st season, the New York Knicks discovered they were not so perfect after all.

title: The MoynihanBuckley Race: Cordiality Gives Way to Hostility
description: Three weeks ago, Senator James L. Buckley and Daniel P. Moynihan debated for the first time. They differed on many issues but their differences were couched in gentility, humor and cordialitybefitting candidates from Yale and Harvard who had not come up the hard way in elective politics. it seemed as though it might be particularly literate campaign free of the usual rancor. Instead, it has been downhill since that first debate. Instead of Jim and Pat, it has been extremist millionaire, radical right, cruddy, elegant Charlie McCarthy, doubledomed intellectual, liberal golden boy and other pleasantries.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in The Times on Oct. 14 incorrectly stated that the Adolph Coors Company of Golden, Colo., sup ported a Colorado ballot proposal to require deposits on beverage containers. The company advocates Federal legislation to this effect, but opposes the state proposal.

title: SCHOOL BOARD LOSES ARBITRATION ON PACT
description: An arbitrator ruled yesterday that the Board of Education must live up to its contractual commitments for paraprofessional training despite New York's elimination of funds for the program.

title: Abercrombie Offering 10% Price Reductions
description: The Abercrombie & Fitch Company, which filed for voluntary bankruptcy status Aug. 9, is offering charge and other customers a onetime, 10 percent price reduction through the Christmas season.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Beame called on the Federal Government yesterday to assume the cost of operating the Police Department's Narcotics Division and the cost of all other parts of the criminal justice system dealing with drugrelated crime. He called it a national problem.

title: Weekend Gardening: Tropic Transplants
description: Man dwells naturally within the tropics and lives on the fruit of the palm tree. He exists in other parts of the world and there makes shift to feed on corn and flesh, said the 18thcentury Swedish botanist, Linnaeus. His words may seem exaggerated in this age of technology; nevertheless, there is a certain underlying truth to this romanticized view of the palm.

title: Legislative Choices: New York City
description: Although public attention, such as it is, has been directed principally to the national races in this Presidential election year, the choice of a new State Legislature150 Assemblymen and 60 Senatorspresents a challenge and an opportunity that New York voters cannot afford to overlook. in a time of continuing financial crisis, in City Hall and in Albany, the next Legislature could determine the chances of city and state to regain economic and fiscal health.

title: MARGARET E. MORRIS
description: Margaret Edwards Morris, widow of Dudley H. Morris, an artist and former chairman of the art department of the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School, died Wednesday in Princeton (N.J.) Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: F.A.A. Aide is Chided for Acting On Jumbo Jets Before Consulting
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The head of the Federal Aviation Administration chided a subordinate today for not consulting him before extending the deadline for modifying jumbo jet airliners so they could survive the type of pressure loss that led to the DC10 crash near Paris in 1974.

title: Mother Charged in Baby's Death
description: MILTON, Fla., Oct. 28 (AP)Christine Alexander, 27 years old, accused of beating her 3monthold twin sons, was charged with murder after one of the infants died of massive injuries in a hospital yesterday, officials said today. The other child was in critical condition at a Pensacola hospital with a broken leg, a mutilated ear and other injuries, they said.

title: Old Themes, Different America
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28In the 32 years since the Presidential election of 1994, the Republicans have held the White House for 16 years and the Democrats for 16, during which the world has been transformed.
