And if this has been a strange election, it is partly because President Ford and Governor Carter have applied roughly the same old party arguments to a different America and a wholly different community of nations.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: How to Get There
description: Mystic is a straight and simple run of 135 miles from the New York City line on the Connecticut Turnpike (Interstgte 95), a trip that takes between two and a half and three hours by car at the posted 55 mileperhour speed limit. The State Police are vigilant when it comes to speeders, end prudence is advised.

title: Irish Riding Team Takes Jumping Lead
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 28Ireland, which has been an alsoran on the North American indoor fall circuit for almost two decades, took the lead for the international jumper championship today at the Washington International horse show.

title: Meadowlands
description: Meadowlands

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: A child who had been sleeping peacefully just moments before sits straight up in bed and shrieks. He is inconsolable. The parents ask, even implore, what's wrong? But there is no answer. Soon the crying subsides, the child returns to sleep, the night terrors have ended.

title: Sports Today
description: Nies vs. Indiana Pacers, at Nassau Collscum, Uniondale, L.I., 8:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 10, (cable), 8 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, WGBB, 8 P.M.)

title: Film Forum: Jungle Indians
description: The new Film Forum program, which opened yesterday and will play this wekend and next, is composed of two documentaries about primitive South American tribes that face extinction in the near future. Both were produced for Granada Television's Disappearing World series in England.

title: Cosmos Find (Artificial) Grass is Greener in Jersey
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 28Clive Toye. who has directed the soccer fortunes of the Cosmos since their inception in 1971. admired the panoramic view of the football stadium in the Meadowlands today, sighed and said, I won't have to negotiate for a stadium again.

title: Referrals Set in Pharmacy Boycott
description: The Westchester County Executive said yesterday that because of a boycott of Medicaid  reimbursed prescriptions by Westchester pharmacists, a telephone referral service had been set up to insure that Medicaid patients receive their medication.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in The Times on Oct. 14 incorrectly stated that the Adolph Coors Company of Golden, Colo., supported a Colorado ballot proposal to require deposits on bevel te containers. The company advocates Federal legislation to this effect but opposes the state proposal.

title: Ballet: Feld's Gods Amused
description: One of Eliot Feld's most beautiful ballets has always been The Gods Amused, which he created in 1971 for his first company and then included in the first season of his current company. the Eliot Feld Ballet.

title: Brown Recalls 75 Loss In Confronting Harvard
description: The year was 1949, Charles (Rip) Engle was the Bruin coach and Joe Paterno was the team captain. That team went into the Harvard game with a 51, wonlost record. The Bruins beat the Crimson and went on to an 8 1 mark. A year ago Brown hoped to win its first Ivy championship since the league began roundrobin competition in 1956. But Harvard ruined the Bruins, 4526, before 17,000 fans in Brown Stadium, the first sellout there in 40 years. lvy League roundup.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Superior Court judge in Elizabeth entered a $39,000 civil pudgment yesterday against Richard Buggelli, a businessman and Democratic Congressional. candate who is trying to unseat Representative Matthew J. Rinaldo, Republican. Judge Harold Ackerman ordered Mr. Buggelli to pay the money to Gordon and Joanne Palkevich of Montvale, who agreed to sell their janitorial service to Mr. Buggelli several years ago for $60,000. The judge said Mr. Buggelli had failed to carry out the terms of the contract and still owed the couple $39,000.

title: Black Delegates to Rhodesia Talks Find Geneva Style Hard on Purse
description: GENEVA, Oct. 28When black nationalists talk of a British settlement of accounts on Rhodesia, they have in mind more than the transfer of power from whites to blacks. They also worry about $57 rooms and $1.15 cups of coffee at the InterContinental Hotel, where many delegates are staying.

title: Restaurants
description: IN THE FACE OF everrising restaurant prices, it is reassuring to discover that New York still has a number of comfortable and pleasant dining places offering good food and respectable service at prices that seem almost miraculous by today's standards. At the request of many readers who have said, in effect, that the fun of dining out is more than slightly dampened by astronomical checks, this column will periodically be devoted to two or three such budget restaurants.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Art People
description: AVAST GOLDFISH BOWL, harboring 40foot carp, 30foot anemones and other exotic denizens of the deep has materialized at 88 Pine Street, the same office building locale that launched Red Groom's Ruckus New York on its way to uptown fame last year. Dubbed an air aquarium by its creator, Otto Piene, the fishbowl actually comprises the building's glasswindowed lobby space, measuring 6,400 square feet, and its inhabitants are inflatable soft sculptures that swell and deflate in a programmed sequence effected by timed air blowers.

title: 20th Anniversary of 56 Uprising Is Nearly Unnoticed in Hungary
description: BUDAPEST, Oct. 28The 20th anniversary of the Hungarian rebellion, in which more than 20,000 people died, is passing without a murmur, seemingly all but forgotten.

title: Gold Prices Lifted By I.M.F Auction; Pound Sets a Low
description: LONDON, Oct. 28 (AP)Gold bullion prices rose by $4.75 an ounce here today in reaction to higher price levels at the International Monetary Fund's gold auction yesterday.

title: Brooklyn Company, Costs High, Competes by Automation
description: The Ideal Corporation pays its workers an average of $5.63 an hour to make hose clamps and turnindicator flashers for cars. Some of its competitors in the South and Midwest pay $3 to $3.50.

title: BUSINESS LOANS UP BY $106 MILLION
description: Business loans increased $106 million in the week ended Wednesday at major New York City banks. continuing an uptrend that has added $12 billion to the commercial and industrial loan portfolios at these banks in the last nine weeks.

title: Li Hsiennien, Economic Chief, in Prime Minister's Role in Peking
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 28After all the breathtaking changes of the last few weeks in Peking, the pace of events seems to have slowed somewhat, with China's new authorities settling down to the difficult task of realigning party posts and readjusting government policies. Nevertheless, each day still seems to bring some fresh if more oblique clues to developments in the Chinese capital. Analysts here have taken particular note, for example, of the increased role of Li Hsiennien, the Deputy Prime Minister who for many years has been in charge of the economy.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: No, Nero Wolfe was not the only one ever to grow orchids in New York, and starting today the Greater New York Orchid Society will prove it. In one of the nicer things ever to happen at a subway station, the orchid society and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will hold an orchid show in the mezzanine passageway of the Sixth Avenue line's 57th Street Station. The members of the orchid society, all hobbyists, will show hundreds of varieties of orchids and pass out information on how you, too, can grow orchids under lights in your own apartment. The members of the orchid society are doing this as a labor of love, and you can see their orchids today, tomorrow and Sunday. The other nice thing about it is that it's free.

title: Animal Farm Folds at Auction After a Struggle to Survive in Town
description: SUFFIELD, Conn., Oct. 28The kinkajou went for $85, a pair of ferrets for $115 and two rare black swans for $162.50 each as a public auction that nearly everyone hoped could be avoided was held today to sell the stock of the Grand Game Farm here.

title: Notes on People
description: What seems to be Gracie Mansion's first luncheon and midi dansant is scheduled for Nov. 10 in honor of the Bee Gees. The poprock group, formed by the Brothers Gibb (Barry, Robin and Maurice), has promised to give the Police Athletic League the net proceeds of its Dec. 2 concert at Madison Square Garden. Commissioner Arline Wolfe of the city's public affairs department said the description of the event has never been used before, to my knowledge. More than 150 invitations have been issued to the elaborate buffet in a tent overlooking the East River, with dancing to a band yet to be announced. The Gibbs brothers, born in England like Mayor Beame grew up in Brisbane, Australia, and began performing in child hood.

title: Stage: TableHopping With Corinne Jacker
description: IN the last two years, Corinne Jacker has emerged as an extremely versatile dramatist, with the naturalistic Harry Outside and the darkly comic Bits and Pieces as well as John Adams, President, one of the most dramatic episodes on television's The Adams Chronicles.

title: Whiteman's Shadow at Carnegie
description: Three years ago, when Richard Sudhalter, a jazz cornetist and author, was gathering material for a book on Bix Beiderbecke, the great jazz star of Paul Whiteman's orchestra, he went to Williams College and spent several days poring over the Whiteman Collection there. Among other things, the collection contains all the known existing orchestrations of Whiteman's orchestra of the 20's when he was celebrated as the King of Jazz. Mr. Sudhalter found himself fascinatedly exploring these arrangements in far greater depth than his book required.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: Federal Reserve Statement

title: TOP WEEKEND FILMS
description: 11 P.M. (13) Black Orpheus (1959). Marpessa Dawn, Breno Mello. Carnival Rio. Stunning.

title: Judgment Orders Goldman Sachs To Pay Coast Group $600,000
description: The University Hill Foundation, a fund raiser for Loyola University of Los Angeles, yesterday was awarded a judgment of $600,000 plus interest from Goldman Sachs & Company for losses suffered in its 1970 purchases of commercial paper of the Penn Central Transportation Company. Penn Central collapsed in June of 1970 and was later declared bankrupt.

title: Tribal Fate
description: THE LAST OP THE CUIVA, directed and produced by Brian Moser; running time: 65 minutes. A CLEARING IN THE JUNGLE, directed by Charles Nairn; produced by Brian Moser; running time: 3B minutes. Both films distributed by Granada Television International. At the Film Forum, 15 Vandam Street.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: SAN FRANCISCOFrom his observation post on the 40th floor of the Bank of America's handsome headquarters overlooking this city's famed bay, Walter E. Hoadley, one of the West's most widely known economists, must find it difficult to be pessiThe mistic at any time. A recent Economic visit showed that he was anything but gloomy about Scene the nation's economic prospects.

title: Meamorial
description: BISSELLLouis. A memorial service will be held on Nov. 3, 1976 at 11 A.M. at St. James Episcopal Church, 71st St. and Madison Ave., New York City. The family request that Rowers be omitted.

title: Carla Hills Defends H.U.D. Record Against Implications of Vast Fraud
description: PATERSON, Oct. 28Carla A. Hills, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, defended her agency today against any implications of fraud in Federal housing programs.

title: Broadway
description: REX HARRISON will return to Broadway next February, starring with Elizabeth Ashley in Shaw's Caesar and Cleopatra. It will be directed by Noel Willman, and produced by Elliott Martin and Gladys Rackmil, and before it comes here it will play the Kennedy Center in Washington. Mr. Martin had thought he would be producing Monsieur Perrichon's Travels on Broadway with Mr. Harrison this fall, but after seeing it done at the Chichester Festival in England last summer he decided against it. Subsequently, Mr. Martin, who produced Pirandello's Henry IV with Mr. Harrison a few years ago, suggested Caesar and Cleopatra. Mr. Harrison said he had always wanted to do it, but never had. (He did play Caesar in the movie Cleopatra with Elizabeth Taylor, but that was something else.) Mr. Martin, in turn, said it would be Mr. Harrison's greatest role since Henry Higgins. Then the deal was made.

title: I Was a Halloween Gypsy
description: It's not the taste of candy corn and Milky Way bars I remember when I think about the Halloweens of my childhood. It's the taste of lipstick. The year I went trickortreating as a gypsy fortune teller, my mother gave me a gold earring and sprayed Evening in Paris behind my ears and painted my mouth red. All night I kept kissing the back of my hand to make sure the color was still there. I wore a long skirt and a silk bandana and a chain of pop beads. I was surprised when people answered their doors and they all seemed to recognize me.

title: S E. C. SETTLES A CASE WITH C. ARNITOLT SMITH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it had settled a case accusing C. Arnholt Smith, the former California banker, and other persons of trying secretly to merge a company operating New Mexico race tracks into a Califenda corporation.

title: In Aemoriam
description: GETTINGERAnna J. Nine years, dearest mother. Loving thoughts of you today and everyday.

title: News Summary
description: The sale to China of a computer system with both military and industrial capability has been approved by President Ford. High Administration officials said that, in approving the sale, Mr. Ford was waiving established safeguards on the advice of Secretary of Slate Kissinger as a gesture to China's new leaders. Some officials had objected to the sale on the ground that the computer can he used to make calculations on nuclear tests. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: McVay Alters Line, Keeping Archer In
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 2SLike a chess player who has lost seven straight games, John McVay made some moves today with the hope that putting pawns in different positions might make a difference.

title: Market is Resisting New M.A.C. Bonds
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, faced with a requirement to raise cash for New York State's needs next month, said yesterday that lingering market resistance to its securities was forcing it to turn to local banks and statecontrolled funds to absorb most of a new offering of $250 million in bonds.

title: Keystone Ore Favored To Sweep Pace Series
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 29Keystone Ore, the fleet 3yearold colt who has six owners, will seek to become pacing's first triple crown winner since 1970 tomorrow night. It's generally believed he'll do it. The occasion will ne the prestigious $161,290 Messenger, which is to standardbreds what the Belmont Stakes is to thoroughbredsthe final jewel in the threerace series for 3yearolds.

title: Kissinger is Willing To Stay, Aides Say
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Henry A. Kissinger's closest aides say they are virtually certain that if President Ford wins the election Tuesday Mr. Kissinger will agree to remain at least two more years as Secretary of State.

title: Natl Basketball Assn
description: Natl Basketball Assn

title: Springsteen, Cocky and Tireless, Asserts Flamboyant Ebullience
description: The twohour show that Bruce Springsteen offered Thursday night at the Palladiumthe first of six therecould not be called one of his best. it was still good enough to reassert his credentials as about the most exciting, satisfying performer in presentday rockandroil.

title: New Custody Customs: in the Best Interests of the Child
description: Court battles over custody of children are nothing new. But in cases decided in the last year, courts have awarded children to a stepfather over the objection of their mother, who was not considered unfit to grandparets although neither the mother nor father was considered unfit; and, in a case of iliegitimate twins to their father.

title: MONOGRAM ACCUSES ROYAL ON TENDER BID
description: Monogram Industries said yesterday that Industries said yesterday that it had amended the complaint in its lawsuit filed Wednesday in the United States Federal District Court in Los Angeles against Royal Industries, which is making a tender offer to acquire 55 percent of Monogram's Industries common stock. Monogram, with headquarters in Santa Monica, Calif., said the amended complaint alleged that statements made by Royal in news releases and a letter to its shareholders were false and misleading and therefore violated Federal securities laws. Monogram is seeking temporary restraining order and injunctive relief and damages.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up in Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Association of American Railroads reported, today that freight traffic on United States railroads in the latest week totaled an estimated 16.5 billion tonmiles, 0.7 percent above the corresponding week year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 483,540 cars, 1.88 percent below last year. The American trucking Association Inc. reported intercity truck tonnage was 7 percent above last year.

title: Carter Stand on Teacher Strikes Stuns Jersey Boards
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 29Members of the New Jersey School Boards Association said today that they had been shocked by a telegram from Jimmy Carter declaring that teachers had a right to strike.

title: Jacko Heads Field Today For 54th Jersey Hunt Cup
description: FAR HILLS, N. J., Oct. 29Jacko owned, trained and ridden by Russel Jones of Unionville, Pa., heads the field for the 54th running of the New Jersey Hunt Cup tomorrow at the Essex Fox Hounds hunt meeting tomorrow. Richard Stoke's Flying Boxcar and Kinloch, winner of three races this year, are expected to provide the main opposition in the 3mile timber race.

title: Irving M. Cohen, President Of Fifth Ave. Card Shop Chain
description: Irving M. Cohen, president of the Fifth Avenue Card Shop chain, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. He was 54 years old and a resident of New Hyde Park, L. I.

title: Early Pound Gain Cut After Denial Of Report of $10 Billion Loan Bid
description: LONDON, Oct. 29An unsubstantiated report that the British Government was trying to borrow $10 billionperhaps to buy Arab holdings of poundssent the beleaguered pound on its sharpest rise in months today. But the currency slumped again when that rumor, like most others, was disavowed.

title: Personal Finance
description: Mainly because of buyer resistance, some of the nation's biggest mutual fund managers are converting funds under their control to a noload status from a load, or commission, basis. Page 30.

title: Notes on People
description: A new chief for Scotland Yard was named yesterday when David McNee, a Glasgow detective known in the underworld as The Hammer, was appointed to succeed Sir Robert Mark. Mr. McNee, a 51yearold church elde'r and lay preacher, rose from constable in a ganginfested Glasgow slum to head Britain's biggest provincial force. Sir Robert reaches the retirement age of 60 next March. An intellectual and a frequently controversial figure at Scotland Yard, he has been known for his ruthlessness against corruption inside the force and his open contempt for criminal lawyers who win acquittals on technicalities.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Albert C. Jacobs is Dead at 76; Was President of Trinity College
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 29 (AP)Dr. Albert Charles Jacobs, president emeritus of Trinity College here, died today at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 76 years old and since his retirement from Trinity in 1968 lived in Ann Arbor and Chappaquiddic Island, Edgartown, Mass. His survivors include his wife, the former Loretta Field Beal, and three children.

title: PAUL WILLIAMS, REPORTER; WON 1973 PULITZER PRIZE
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 29 (UPI)Paul N. Williams, a journalism professor at Ohio State University who was the winner of a 1973 Pulitzer Prize, died today at his home. He was 54 years old.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1976

title: LowTar Cigarettes Creating a Revolution
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C.Each weekday morning, before he begins his job in the flavor application section of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, 41yearold John Shore puts in a stint as a member of the company's expert smokers panel.

title: Television
PriceFixing Laid To 5 Bag Makers In U.S. Indictment
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 29 (AP)Five manufacturers of paper bags were indicted today on Federal charges of conspiring to fix the prices of bags sold to package a variety of consumer products. The indictment was returned by a grand jury in the District Court in Philadelphia and announced in Washington by the Justice Department.

title: PENNSYLVANIA RACE IS VIEWED AS CLOSE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29The Carter campaign in this state hangs together by a slender thread, Joseph Timilty said Wednesday nightand this morning the thread very nearly broke.

title: News Summary
description: Scathing condemnation of the white Rhodesian Government was expressed by black nationalist leaders, who demanded that Britain take full responsibility for a speedy transfer of power to the black majority. on the second day of the Geneva conference, the Africans charged that the Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith condoned brutal atrocities against prisoners. Mr. Smith called the charges a complete pack of lies. [Page 1, Column. 1]

title: MYSTERIOUS SIGNAL UPSETS AIR WAVES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  A very powerful, mysterious radio signal, apparently emanating from the Soviet Union, has been disrupting communications throughout the world for months, sources on both sides of the Atlantic say.

title: Todd Will Start Tomorrow In Place of Ailing Namath
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct, 29With a mixture of embarrassment and anticipation, Richard Todd, the rookie, learned today that he would start in place of Joe Namath on Sunday against the Bills.

title: Honecker Gets Key Positions
description: BERLIN, Oct. 29 (UPI)  The East German Parliament today unanimously elected Erich Honecker, the Communist leader, as chairman of the Council of State, making him in effect head of state. It also elected Mr. Honecker as chairman of the National Defense Council.

title: KEY CAMPAIGN ISSUE IS CITED BY MOYNIHAN
description: BUFFALO, Oct, 29Daniel P. Moynihan asserted today that the main issue that had developed in his contest with Senator James L. Buckley was their fundamentally different approach to what the Federal Government could and should do to help New York in its time of troubles.

title: Puerto Rican Election in Doubt As Independent Voters Increase
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 29Puerto Ricans, for years accustomed to the rising economic expectations created by Operation Bootstrap, will decide Tuesday whether Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon's administration, which has seen a period of high unemployment and economic recession, is to earn a second fouryear term.

title: Community Gives Brooklyn's Newkirk Plaza a New Lease on Life
description: Rather than accept as inevitable the gradual blight of the inner city, several energetic community and business groups ernharked acme 14 months ago on a selfimprovement project to restore. 68yearold Newkirk Plaza in Brooklyn's North Flatbush, a shopping area that includes a pedestrian mall, stores and a subway station.

title: RHODESIAN BLACKS INSIST THAT BRITAIN DIRECT POWER SHIFT
description: GENEVA, Oct. 29African nationalist leaders today bitterly condemned the Rhodesian Government of Prime Minister Ian a Smith and demanded that Britain assume full responsibility for the rapid transfer of bower to the black majority.

title: Patents: Video Memory is Used In IntrusionDetection System
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 29A new intrusiondetection system has a video memory that records the principal aspects of the area being guarded, sounds an alarm when something unusual happens and reproduces any movements of persons and property, disclosing where an intruder may have hidden.

title: Trade Deficit Rises
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 29 (Reuters)The United States trade deficit on a balanceotpayments basis rose to $2.86 billion, seasonally adjusted, in the third quarter, from $1.29 billion in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Money
description: Telerate money market Index 4.95, down .01 from Thursday, up .02 for week.

title: Kissinger is Willing To Stay, Aides Say
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Henry A. Kissinger's closest aides say they are virtually certain that if President Ford wins the election Tuesday Mr. Kissinger will agree to remain at least two more years as Secretary of State.

title: Auction of U.S. Funds Seen by President
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 29 President Ford accused Jimmy Carter today of bidding for the political support of the nation's schoolteachers with the prospect of Federal tax dollars.

title: JuvenileJustice System in Throes of Change,
description: It has long been the law that the use of bail is to be limited to assuring the presence at trial of a defendant. The defendant is presumed innocent, and in setting bail, a judge is supposed to weigh his character, finances, roots in his commanity, the strength of the evidence against him, the sentence he could receive if convictedand his prior criminal record. But not if the prior crimes were committed when the defendant was lb or younger. Those juvenile records are sealed under the traditional theory that a person under 16 should not be held criminally accountable for his actions and therefore should not be haunted for the rest of his life with the stigma of a criminal record.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: 1111:30, WNYCAM: A Look Ourselves. Youth Attitudes Towards Big Business.

title: Bond Issues, Totaling $225 Million, on Ballot Tuesday
description: TRENTON. Oct. 29Almost lost in the shadow of the Presidential campaign, the 16 House races and the fight over casino gambling in Atlantic City are three bond issues on the New Jersey ballot Tuesday in which the state government is seeking voter permission to borrow $225 million.

title: JUDGE JACOB LUTSKY OF COURT OF CLAIMS
description: Judge Jacob Lutsky of the State Court of Claims, who entered city government nearly 40 years ago and served as a legal aide to four mayors, died yesterday at Lcng Island College Hospital after apparently having suffered a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived at 16201 Powells Cove Boulevard, Beechhurst, Queens.

title: Test Suburbs
description: HEAPSTEAD, LI., Oct. 29Earlier this year, supporters of Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington captured 10 out of 11 Democratic Presidential delegates within the Town of Hempstead, and 17 of 22 delegates in Nassau County. Their efforts did not get their candidate a spot on the ticket, but many of the same workers are now pushing Daniel P. Moynihan's campaign to unseat Senator James L. Buckler.

title: Seoul's Intelligence Agents Harass Korean Community in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29The 70,000member Korean community herethe largest concentration of Koreans outside the Orientis being systematically intimidated by members of the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency, according to community leaders and law enforcement officials.

title: Report Spurs Stock Sales
description: SYDNEY, Oct. 29 (Reuters)Buyers rushed today to snap up Australian uranium shares following the Government commission's cautious goahead for the mining of the country's vast uranium reserves. The scenes at the Sydney Stock Exchange were reminiscent of the time of the Australian mining boom six years ago.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Vibrant Chita Rivera at the Waldorf
description: A year and a half ago when Chita Rivera was in town waiting for the start of rehearsals of Chicago. which were delayed by the illness of Bob Fosse, the director, she took the opportunity to make her New York nightclub debut at the Grand Finale in a lively, fastmoving act written by Fred Ebb (of the team of Kander and Ebb) and staged by Ron Field.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
November Soybean Futures Rise by 19c a Bushel
description: Soybean futures for November delivery jumped 19 cents a, bushel yesterday to close at 56.78 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Ford Group Dismisses Sound Man Working on Film With Nudity in It
description: A sound specialist, who has been taping tatements by President Ford and other persons for commercials in the President's campaign has been dismissed after It was discovered that he was also working on a film, Philosophy of the Bedroom. involving nudity.

title: Senate Rivals
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 29Senator James L. Buckley has campaigned in Westchester County on more than a dozen occasions in the oast few months.

title: Physician Testifies That He Found Bronfman in Good General Health
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 29The doctor who examined Samuel Bronfman 2d on the morning that he was rescued from his alleged abudctors testified at the kidnapping trial today that the 21yearold heir to the Seagram liquor fortune was in good general health at that time.

title: Buyers Play Right Note At Auction
description: A double virginal, a kind of harpsichord devised by Hans Rucker the Younger in 1623, sold for a record price of $65,000 to an anonymous buyer yesterday during an auction of fine musical instruments at Sotheby Parke Bernet, at 980 Madison Avenue. An auction sale of the last important Ruckers instrument in 1969 brought $22,080.

title: PENNSYLVANIA RACE IS VIEWED AS CLOSE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29"The Carter campaign in this that hangs together by a slender thread, Joseph Timilty said Wednesday nightand this morning the thread very nearly broke.

title: Council Panel Wins Refund of an Unapproved Outlay
description: A week ago, the Finance Committee of the New York City Council flexed its muscles. Yesterday, it had the pleasurable experience of knowing that $2.4 million paid by the city without Council sanction for two Board of Higher Educa tion computers had been returned by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Family Doctors Given First Test To Find if Knowledge is Up to Date
description: Some 330 family doctors hunched over examination booklets in meeting rooms at the Essex House Hotel here yesterday, scratching their heads, rubbing their eyes and marking answers in the first mandatory test ever given physicians to see whether they have kept their medical knowledge up to date.

title: F.B.I. Said to Have Inspected List Of Socialist Workers Contributors
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation visited the Office of Federal Elections in 1972 to inspect the financial records of the Socialist Workers Party and review lists of donors to the Trotskyist Party, an election agency official says.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Airlines Speed Modifying of Jets
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it had been notified of a speedup in airline plans for modifying jumbojet airliners to protect them against the effects of sudden loss of pressurization.

title: Sex Among Issues Covered in Regents Book Guidelines
description: ALBANY, Oct. 29 The New York State Board of Regents, in move to encourage development of critical thinking among students, today adopted its first set of guidelines that would help local school districts to select ??? textbooks and library booksincluding material dealing with sex.

title: Balint Vazsonyi Will Play 32 Beethoven Piano Sonatas
description: Why would anyone want to play all 32 Beethoven piano sonatas in public in two lengthy sessions, each lasting 11 hours? Balint Vazsonyi, who is going to do just that tomorrow and Nov. 14 at the 92d Street Y.MY.W.H.A., is neither a crackpot nor a musician trying to draw attention to himself with a gimmick. Early this week he gave a clear, logical reason why he is undertaking to do one of the great cycles in music.

title: Unemployment Drops in New York, Indicating a Weak Recovery Trend
description: A weak recovery trend aided by seasonal factors pushed unemployment down in New York State and New York City last month, the State Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: A Halloween Story
description: A Halloween Story

title: Dave Anderson
description: Bo Schembechler sounded as if he were talking about a wide receiver. He's fast, Bo said, and he's got good hands. But the Michigan coach was talking about Dr. Otto Gago, who performed openheart surgery on him. In the operation, Bo said, they stop your heart from beating, so the doctor's got to be fast. And he needs good hands because you don't want him to drop anything in there. The only thing that Dr. Gago dropped in there was perspective perhaps as important as the arterialbypass surgery itself. Less than six months after his sixhour operation, Bo Schembechler is guiding Michigan toward the Rose Bowl and perhaps the national championship. Bo will be pacing the sideline today when the topranked Wolverines oppose Minnesota in a Big Ten game that ABC will televise to most of the nation. Bo's heart is fine, thank you. And so is his perspective.

title: Bertram D. Coleman, ExBroker, Dies in an Automobile Accident
description: Bertram D. Coleman, a retired stock broker, died Thursday in an automobile accident in Bryn Mawr, Pa, He was 57 years old and a resident of Bryn Mawr.

title: Harlem Up for the Big Game Today, and Tonight
description: They're going to turn the clock back in Harlem todaynot just to standard time and maybe not all the way back to the heyday of Harlem, but at least back to 1973.

title: College Football Today Focuses on Cambridge
description: When Harvard and Brown met in 1975, the Bruins were within reach of their first Ivy League championship since the start of formal roundrobin Ivy competition in 1956. They were denied by Harvard, which won that big game, at Providence, R.I., 4526, by striking quickly and effectively behind Jim Kubacki, the versatile quarterback.

title: Casts Are Replacing Real Thing to Protect Acropolis Statuary From Pollution
description: ATHENS, Oct. 29 Almost 2,500 years after they were erected on the Acropolis of Athens, some of the great arts works of antiquity are being removed for safekeeping and replaced by casts.

title: COMMUNITY CENTER PLANNED IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, Oct. 29Black community leaders of Newark's South Ward, supported by state and local political figures, opened a fundraising campaign tonight for a new Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Community Center that could cost as much as $30 million.

title: Knotty, Sculptural Forms of Grace and Motion
description: What looks like a gigantic creature from another planet descends menacingly down the length of the white brick wall and spreads its braided rubber tentacles across the polished wooden floor

title: REAGAN SHUNS ROLE IN FORD'S CAMPAIGN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29Former Gov. Ronald Reagan has succeeded in running out the election campaign without being drawn into direct, full support of President Ford, to whom he lost the Republican Presidential nomination after a hard fight.

title: Honor Among Officers
description: Bucking the military system has never been a very effective way of bucking for promotion. The latest illustration of that rule is the case of Capt. Arthur Lincoln, the military lawyer and West Point graduate who successfully challenged the Military Academy's handling of its massive cheating scandal that has led to the resignation or expulsion of more than 150 cadets. it has now been learned that Captain Lincoln has since been passed over for a promotion that appears to have been warranted by his record and was transferred from criminal to civil legal duties at the Academy.

title: Events Today
description: Events Today

title: Against McCarthy
description: DENVERSome men would make great Presidents it you could appoint them, it was said of Adlai E. Stevenson, This could apply to Eugene J. McCarthy as well. But we don't appoint Presidents.

title: Dow Rises 12.30 to 964.93 As More Banks Cut Prime
description: Primerate reductions by many or me nation's largest banks pushed the stock market sharply higher yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 12.30 points to 964.93, its high for the day.

title: SouthWest Africa City Remains More German Than Germany
description: SWAKOPMUND, SouthWest Africa 'Heil Hitler! said the black gas station attendant matteroffactly to the department customer, raising his right arm to the traditional height.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR, on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station.

title: Ford Can't Rule Out Further Price Hike; Labor Costs Up 13%
description: DETROIT, Oct. 29The Ford Motor Company said today that its new contract with the United Auto Workers Union would raise labor costs by 13 percent in the first year alone. As a result, Ford said it could not rule out another increase in car prices in the 1977 model year.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
RHODESIAN BLACKS INSIST THAT BRITAIN DIRECT POWER SHIFT
description: GENEVA, Oct. 29African nationalist leaders today bitterly condemned the Rhodesian Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and demanded that Britain assume full responsibility for the rapid transfer of power to the black majority.

title: POLICE WIDENING UNIT TO PROTECT ELDERLY
description: Mayor Beanie announced yesterday that the Police Department's senior citizens robbery unit would be quadrupled in size to a total of 84 police officers. His statement, at a City Hall news conference, followed by only three hours the discovery of the latest elderly victim of an apparent robbery, 82yearold Kathleen King, whose body was found in her apartment at 100 West 93d Street.

title: Patents
description: A new intrusiondetection surveillance system uses a video memory to record the principal aspects of the area being guarded and sounds an alarm when something unusual happens. Page 31.

title: PORTUGAL'S SOCIALISTS SEEK TO EASE DISCORDS
description: LISBON, Oct. 29Portugal's ruling Socialist Party will define its new political line and attempt to resolve serious internal differences at its second national congress meeting here this weekend.

title: Britain's Tough Choice
description: Prime Minister James Callaghan has warned the International Monetary Funtiand the United States and Britain's other principal alliesagainst trying to force us into policies which would be so harmful to the economy that we would go into a downward spiral.

title: POLICE WIDENING UNIT TO PROTECT ELDERLY
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that the Police Department's senior citizens robbery unit would be quadrupled in size to a total of 84 police officers. His statement, at a City Hall news conference, followed by only three hours the discovery of the latest elderly victim of an apparent robbery, 82yearold Kathleen King, whose body was found in her apartment at 100 West 93d Street.

title: Dance: Carol Conway Hypnotizes
description: The slow, deliberate pacing of Carol Conway's choreography begins to become hypnotic toward the end of a long program such as the one she gave with her company Thursday evening at American Theater Laboratory. What started as interest in slight shifts of weight in an unaccented flow of movement ended with a feeling of tedium.

title: Democrats Accuse G.O.P. of Violation In Congress Races
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)The Democratic National Committee asked the Federal Election Commission today to rule on whether the Republican National Committee violated the election law in its distribution of money to about 33 Coneressional candidates.

title: Three Indiana Democrats in Fights To Keen House Seats Won in 1974
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind.Two years ago, in the angry backlash over Watergate, three Democrats ripped up the form book and captured Indiana Congressional seats that had been safely Republican for decades.

title: Sarbanes is Given Edge in Bid to Unseat Senator Beall in Maryland
description: BETHESDA, Md., Oct. 28The Senate race in Maryland this year provides a splendid illustration of how much the national political climate has changed in recent years.

title: Dennis Sullivan, Director, Marries Susan Stratton
description: Susan Stratton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth S. Stratton of Chicago, was married yesterday to Dennis Sullivan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Sullivan of Flushing, Queens.

title: Air Crash Kills Civil Defense Aide
description: JONESBORO, Ga., Oct. 29 (AP)The director of the Clayton County Civil Defense unit was killed, and a county commissioner and commissionerelect were injured early today in the crash of a private plane south of Jonesboro, the authorities said. The Federal Aviation Administration in Atlanta identified the civil defense official as Clayton Christopher. Injured were Commissioner Lindsey Campbell, Commissionerelect Jerry Adams and the pilot of the plane, Earl Buckner of Morrow.

title: Another Tax Cut?
description: Does the nation need a tax cut next year? President Ford, in the final days of the campaign, has said that he would make another Federal income tax cut the number one priority in the next Ford Administration. Governor Carter has refused to commit himself to a tax cut if he is elected, but says it's a possibility.

title: Personal Finance: Funds Switch To NoLoad From a Fee Basis
description: Thanks mainly to buyer resistance, some of the nation's biggest mutual fund managers are hacking away from the sales charges they have been levying on investors for years. Surprisingly, the fund managers seem as pleased with the results as the investors are.

title: Bad News From The Cellar
description: The campaign existed only on television. I could go to the cellar and light the box and, lo, the campaign would be right there. Look, I would say to the cat, who always goes to the cellar with me when I descend for a stiff bout of television, look, there is a man with immensely telegenic teeth in a northern snowstorm, and I'll bet he is running for President on our very own television box.

title: FREON PRICE INCREASE ANNOUNCED BY DU PONT
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company announced yesterday that it was raising bulk container prices of its Freon fluorocarbon refrigerants and propellants, effective Dec. 1. Under the new price schedules, Freon 11 in tank car and tank truck shipments will go up by 2 cents a pound to 40 cents; Freon 12 will rise a like amount to 44 cents a pound, and Freon 114 will be up 3.4 cents to 55 cents pound.

title: Festival In Boston: Gray Music
description: BOSTON, Oct. 29It is possible to wonder, listening to the pieces being played here at the World Music Days festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music, whether better works aren't being written somewhere in the world. Under the clearest. and bluest of New England autumn skies, delegates and visitors to the convention have heard a remarkable amount of gray and murky music. A chamber program yesterday in Jordan Hall of the New England Conservatory of Music, for instance, presented five pieces, all United States premieres, from five countries. One listener found it difficult to believe that these works represented the cream of anything. If such a festival is not serving up cream, what function is it serving?

title: Memorial Services
description: BISSELLLouis. A memorial service Will be held on Nov. 3, 1976 at 11 A.M. at St. James Episcopal Church, 71st St. and Madison Ave., New York City. The family request that flowers be omitted.

title: Puerto Rico's Election
description: While voters in the fifty states arc electing a President Tuesday, Puerto Rico will be choosing a Governor in a contest certain to have an impact on the island's political status. if the voters give the Popular Democratic Party's Rafael Hernandez Colon a second fouryear term, they will be endorsing his plan for continuing and extensively refining Puerto Rico's selfgoverning Commonwealth relationship with the mainland.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times yesterday incorrectly stated that the Ford Administration had authorized the sale to China of a type of a computer system denied to the Soviet Union. The Soviet Union is also getting a similar type of system. A corrective article appears on Page 6.

title: Miss Holladay on Cup Team
description: Terry Holladay, the ninthranked woman tennis player in the United States, was named yesterday to replace the injured Billie Jean King on the United States team that will compete against Britain for the Wighman Cup at London, Nov. 1113. The 20yearold Miss Holladay will be making her first appearance in international tournament.

description: Questions are based on news reported in The Times during the last week.

title: Nassau's OT B Fills The County Coffers Beyond Expectation
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 29Easa Easa, president. of the Nassau DownsOTB, announced today that the county's Offtrack Betting Corporation would provide $6million in revenue to the county for 1976, or $1.4 million more than had been anticipated.

description: Shipping/Mails

title: 14 U.S. TeenAgers Are Rescued From Welsh Peak by Copter
description: CAERNARVON, Wales, Oct. 29 (Reuters)  Fourteen American teenagers were rescued today by helicopter after losing their way on Mount Snowdon and spending a cold, wet night on a ledge near the top.

title: Mrs. Maxine Dickey, 50, Wife Of Poet, Dies in Columbia, S.C.
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 29 (AP)Maxine Dickey, wife of lames Dickey, the poet ant novelist, died at a Columbia hospital yesterday. She was 50 years old.

title: World News Briefs
description: MADRID, Oct. 29 (Reuters)A rally of Spanish rightwing Falangists broke up here today in uproar, quarrels and fist fights when one of the speakers talked of shortcomings in the Franco era.

title: Warmer Weather Thaws Lincoln Tunnel Jams
description: WEEHAWKEN, Oct. 29A warmer sun smiled on rushhour commuters this morning, and for the first time this week official traffic monitors at the Lincoln Tunnel stopped frowning.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 (UPI)The former producer of Breakfast Cheer coffee today filed a $4.6 million antitrust suit in United States District Court against the Procter & Gamble Company, charging Breakfast Cheer was forced off grocery shelves in the Pittsburgh area by illegal, predatory pricing.

title: Democrat Fearful of More Hard Times
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 29Before big, boisterous crowds in three cities today, Jimmy Carter intensified his steady attack on Republican economics, likening them to the preDepression policies of Herbert Hoover and warning of more hard times ahead if President Ford is elected next week.

title: Nigeria's'Indigenization Policy Under Fire
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 29In an effort to wrest control of the economy from foreign hands, Nigeria has embarked upon a steppedup policy of forcing foreignowned companies to sell into Nigerian ownership.

title: FORD MOTOR LINKS 24.5%10 DROP IN PROFIT TO STRIKE BY U.A.W.
description: DETROIT, Oct. 29Citing the deep impact of a 28day strike against it by members of the United Automobile Workers Union, the Ford Motor Company today reported a 24.5 percent decline in its profits for the third quarter of 1975, compared with the like period a year ago.

title: Mrs. Peron Reportedly Moved From Chalet to a Naval Base
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 29 (AP)Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron of Argentina was flown today from the southern mountain retreat where she had been held to a naval base near here, Government sources said.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 (UP)The University of California's nine campuses [lave been ordered to refrain from using racial quotes as criteria for admission to special programs.

title: Heard, Perry Help Suns Conquer Bulls, 95 to 82
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP)Garfield ??? scored 11 of his 23 points in the final quarter and Curtis Perry collected 17 points and 19 rebounds tonight to lead the Phoenix Suns to a 9582 National Basketball Association ??? over the Chicago Bulls.

title: Auction of U.S. Funds Seen by President
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 29 President Ford accused Jimmy Carter today of bidding for the political support of the nation's schoolteachers with the prospect of Federal tax dollars.

title: Landslide Blocks Italian. Railway
description: DOMODOSSOLA, Italy, Oct. 29 (AP)A landslide early today blocked the main railway link between Italy and Switzerland north of here after three consecutive days of heavy rain in northern Italy. The landslide covered both tracks of the line near the village of Varzo, six miles from the Swiss border and near the entrance to the Simplon railway tunnel. Trains were rerouted on long detours, and officials said it might take weeks to clear the line.

title: Indictment of Jersey Teamster Aide Barred by the Statute of Limitatious.
description: A kidnapping indictment against Anthony Provenzano, a New Jersey official of the teamsters union, was dismissed yesterday by a Federal judge in Manhattan.

title: A Rodeo At Joffrey Is Terrific
description: Terrific. That's how Agnes de Mike's Rodeo looked on Thursday night at the City Center when the Joffrey Ballet staged it for the first time. Co see itit is unlike any other Rodeo you have seen.

title: About New York
description: In the ashes of the deadly Puerto Rican Social Club fire last weekend lies a way of life that will not be easily altered by postmortem bureaucracy.

title: Airlines Wain Great Movie War
description: They dueled in the skies in the great booze war, the pianolounge war and the nofrills war. They fought with bagels, overheadrackspace and legroom. Now the airlines are engaged in a whole new struggle: the ereat movie war.

title: A Growing Trend: Listening to Police and Fire Calls
description: SOUTH ORANGE, Oct. 29Bertrand Spiotta, the village president of South Orange, has a radioscanning monitor in his home and in his office. in neighboring Maplewood, Oliver Jackson, who runs a livery service, has his scanner hooked to his home highfidelity system so he can listen in every room. Herbert W. Laycock, a police reservist in Cranford, listens to his town channel and surrounding communities.

title: Demand for Clues and Data Spurs Proliferation of Polls
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Asked in the last debate what had caused the decline in his commanding lead over President Ford in the opinion polls, Jimmy Carter replied that the only poll I've ever followed is the one that is, you know, taken on Election Day.

title: 3 Egyptians Are Killed And Many Are Injured In Election Disturbances
description: CAIRO, Oct. 29 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Mamdouh Salem and three members of his Cabinet have been elected to the People's Assembly, Egypt's parliament, in elections yesterday marred by clashes that took at least three lives and caused many injuries.

title: Maddox Fights for a Losing Cause With. Vigor and a Vaudeville Style
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 29The campaign has not been easy going for Lester G. Maddox; the. Presidential candidate of the American Independent Party, who 10 years ago defeated Jimmy Carter in a Democratic primary and went on to become Governor of Georgia.

title: REV. ALCWYN L. ROBERTS
description: The Rev, Alewyn L. Roberts, former associate secretary of the General Assemby of the United Presbyterian Church, died Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Asheville, N.C., after a long illness.

title: Inquiry Raises Possibility That U.S. Citizens Work Illegally for Seoul
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29A newly dis. closed Justice Department investigatior into organizations and persons connecter with the controversial Rev, Shn Myung Moon has raised the possibility that American citizens are illegally working on behalf of the South Korean Government.

title: DOROTHY E. SMITH FARR
description: Dr. Dorothy E. Smith Farr, former professor in the undergraduate medical program at the University of Pennsylvania, died yesterday at the Princeton, (N.J.) Medical Center. She was 86 years old.

title: PARTY URGED TO OUST 4 ACCUSED CHINESE
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 29A Chinese province called today on the Central Committee of the Communist Party to expel Mao Tsetung's widow, Chiang Ching, and three other senior leftists from the party and deal them the severest Punishment.

title: U.S. Did Not Bar ComputerSystem Sale to Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29An executive of Control Data Corporation said today that his company has received Administration approval to sell computer systems of comparable capability to the Soviet Union and China, and this was confirmed by Administration spokesmen.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A grocer and his friend were shot to death last night in a Brooklyn bodega when they tried to stop a holdup, according to the police. The grocer, John Montalvo, 45 years old, tried to pick up a butcher knife when the lone bandit gunman, who was about 20 years old, entered his store, at 491 Hegeman Avenue, in the East New York section, around $30 P.M. and was shot once in the chest, the police said, When Atanasio Gonzalez, 35, went to his friend's aid, The gunman shot him twice in the head. Both victims had lived at 785 Logan Street. The police said the gunman was interrupted during his robbery attempt by a customer who walked into the store shortly after the gunfire.

title: United States Team Takes Nations Cup
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 29The United States Equestrian Team, which had captured only one of the seven earlier events, won tonight the Nations Cup, the most important test of the Washington International horse show.

title: The Screen: Naive Work About Tribe.
description: In 1925 Merian C. Cooper and Ernest P. Schoedsack (who hit the jackpot eight years later with King Kong) released their wellreceived documentary feature called Grass. which recorded the semiannual migration of the Bakhtiari tribes of Persia (now Iran) between their winter and summer grazing lands.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday. Oct. 29, 1976

title: Westinghouse To Stop Making Color TV Tubes
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the largest independent manufacturer of color television tubes in the United States, announced yesterday that it was going out of that business.

title: Sunday Halloween Protested
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 29 (UPI)Protests have been expressed to a decision by city officials here to hold Halloween trick or treat night on Sunday. Mormon officials have told their church members to have their children make the traditional rounds tomorrow. The police station said it was swamped with calls from residents who wanted information or wanted to complain about the Sunday scheduling.

title: Ford and Carter Buy TV Time On Election Eve for Final Efforts
description: As their final campaign effort on election eve, President Ford and Jimmy Carter have bought consecutive halthours of network television time running throughout the primetime schedule Monday night.

title: Market is Resisting New M.A.C. Bonds
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, faced with a requirement to raise cash for New York State's needs next month, said yesterday that lingering market resistance to its securities was forcing to turn to local banks and statecontrolled funds to absorb most of a new offerine of $250 million in bonds.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A fugitive who was charged two years ago with defrauding more than $8,000 through a New York bank account scheme was arrested in Elizabeth by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The suspect, John Brown, 41 years old, had been living and working in Elizabeth under the name Simon Brooks, according to the F.B.I., which arrested him on the basis of a confidential tip obtained by the bureau's New York office. An F.B.I. spokesman said Mr. Brown was charged in April 1974 with setting up a false payroll account at the Freedom National Bank in New York in the name of Ancorp National Services in Manhattan, a company for which he once worked. After depositing several fraudulent checks in the account, the F.B.I. said, Mr. Brown withdrew $8,000 to $9,000.

title: Prices Received by Farmers Dropped 5% in Month
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)In its last major farm economic report before the Presidential election Tuesday, the Agriculture Department said today that the average prices farmers get for raw products dropped 5 percent between Sept. 15 and Oct. 15.

title: PrimeRate Cut To 61/2% Joined By Many Banks
description: A primerate reduction initiated Thursday became widespread yesterday as major banks across the country pared their key charge for business loans to 6 percent from 6 percent.

title: ADVANCE INDICATOR OF ECONOMY DOWN 2D STRAIGHT MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29A group of economic statistics that sometimes gives accurate warning of an economic downturn declined in September for the second consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A Niaht Battle Mars Lebanon Truce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct.29Lebanon's ceasefire held up today despite overnight clashes between rightwing Christian forces and leftist Moslems in the eastern suburbs of the capital.

title: Capitals Beats Rockies On Meehans Goal, 21
description: DENVER, Oct. 29 (AP)Gerry Meehan scored his second goal of the season in the third period tonight to lift Washington to a 21 victory over Colorado in a National Hockey League game.

title: ADVANCE INDICATOR OF ECONOMY DOWN 29 STRAIGHT MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29A group of economic statistics that sometimes gives accurate warning of an economic downturn declined in September for the second consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today.

description: London: Morning fixing $122.30, down $0.45; afternoon fixing $123.15, up $0.40.

Smith condoned brutal atrocities against prisoners. Mr. Smith called the charges a complete pack of lies. [Page 1, Column. 1.]

description: Players love it as an easy payday. Promotors see it as a chance for a big score. Spectators drool over a cozy weekend with a select group of stars.

title: Bridge:
description: When a declarer goes down in a contract he could easily have made, his partner usually has something to say Sometimes the declarer can successfully defend his line of play in the postmortem, demonstrating that his line was right, but unlucky. Sometimes he must admit error. But sometimes, as in the diagramed deal, the argument remains unsettled.

title: Radio
GOING OUT Guide
description: HIKE & PEDAL Last call this season for three walking tours and one bicycle safari tomorrow, sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. The foot jaunts depart. at 2 P.M., rain or shine, with a $3 tab and no reservations.

title: Tiny Airport is One of Noisiest
description: SHELBYVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 29 (UPI) Mayor H. V. Griffin believed it was some kind of joke when Shelbyville's tiny airport was ranked one of the 100 noisiest in the country.

title: Music: Aeterna Thrives on Skill
description: Musica Aetcrna may he a busy fixturp at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but it also has a thriving if not so lengthy series at Alice Tully Hall. On Wednesday night, it opened its annual season at Tully, and as usual it played to a capacity audience. The popularity of the orchestra is undoubtedly because, in part, of the skillful programming of its conductor, Frederic Waldman, and this initial concert was a case in point.

title: McGee Leads by a Stroke With 70137
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 29 (AP)Jerry McGee overcame two consecutive bogeys, blustery winds and cold weather as he scored a oneunderpar 70 that put him alone at the top after the second round today in the $125,000 Pensacola open golf tournament. His margin was a stroke.

title: Mr. Smith Chops His Way Through the Tangle of Welfare
description: After eight months on the job, J. Henry Smith, the head of the city's Human Resources Administration, is being praised in some quarters as the very model of an efficiency expert and denounced in others as a pussycat in tiger's stripes.

description: Delegates of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association hold the fate of their union, the Police Department and potentially the city itself in their hands next week when they vote on revised contract terms proposed by mediator Michael I. Sovern, dean of the Columbia Law School.

title: Herbert Rothschild, Manufacturer Of Furniture and Art Collector, 84
description: Herbert M. Rothschild, a furniture manufacturer and art collector, died Thursday at his country home. He was 84 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Ceorgia Sarchet Shreve is Wed to Bank Aide
description: Georgia Sarchet Shreve, an account executive at Ogilvy & Mather, the advertising agency, was married last evening to Glenn Hank Greenberg, a portfolio manager and officer in the investment department of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

description: A 34yearold police officer on sick leave shot himself to death yesterday morning as he and his wife were passengers in a cab that was crossing the Brooklyn Bridge.

description: GREVE, Italy, Oct. 26The vendemmia, or harvest, is under way in this land of chianti, and so is the effort to try once again to overcome the image that all French wines are good and all Italian wines are simply cheap.

title: Fire Destroys Japanese Buildings
description: YAMAGATA, Japan, Saturday, Oct. 30 (Reuters)A huge fire raged out of control in nearby Sakata city in northwestern Japan early today, destroying 1,000 buildings, the police said. No serious casualties were reported but thousands of people were left homeless.

title: Books of The Times
description: One reads the news from China as if one were reading a sciencefiction novelDune, say, by Frank Herbert. It's another planet, an entirely different ecology. Fox Butterfield, who reports so ably for this newspaper from Hong Kong, could be in a space capsule at the end of an intergalactic probe. At least his sense of humor is intact.

title: Judge Bars Refunds to U.S. if His Medicaid Abortion Ruling is Reversed
description: A Federal district judge in Brooklyn refused yesterday to include in his order requiring Federal reimbursement for Medicaid oho glans a provision that, if his ruling was overturned, the Government would be allowed to retrieve the money it had advanced.

title: Ervasti Gains Semifinals in Pinehurst Senior Golf

title: Nets Fall to Pacers As Late Rally Fails

Without Julius Erving, the Nets again played to a nearlyempty house at the Nassau Coliseum. They lost to the Indiana Pacers, 9089. The crowd for the secand home game was 4,239.

title: High Court Rejects Appeal by McCarthy To Remain on Ballot
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The United States Supreme Court today unanimously rejected Eugene J. McCarthy's bid to win back his place on the New York State ballot as an independent candidate for President in next Tuesday's election.

title: Nuclear OPEC Leak

title: Philippines Torture
description: San Juanico is a bridge in the Philippines that connects the islands of Leyte and Samar. in Philippine prison parlance, it is also a method of torture: A political prisoner subjected to the San Juanico bridge is forced to lie with his naked body suspended between two beds and is beaten and kicked in the stomach and thighs whenever he sags or falls.

title: INIONDALE CRITICIZES FORD ON WATERGATE
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 29Senator Walter F. Mondale said today that if President Ford and Senator Robert J. Dole, his running mate, had had their way about it, Richard M. Nixon would still be President of the United States.

title: The Screen: Melodrama Twin Bill:'Death Collector,' 'Violent Professionals' Shown
description: "Death Collector," filmed entirely at the other end or the Lincoln Tunnel in New Jersey, is an effective little melodrama about a fast-talking young punk who aspires to get ahead in the local Mafia but hasn't the brains to operate successfully.Seedy is the word for the world through which this punk moves, often with the towers of Manhattan in the distance and as far removed from him as the moon. Ralph De Vito, who wrote and directed the film, displays a good deal of talent for the kind of movie-making in which action (a lot of it very violent) is exposition and the portrait of a character's soul is the physical landscape that surrounds him. Joseph Cortese and Lou Criscuola are exceedingly good as, respectively, the punk and the local don who befriends him."Death Collector" opened yesterday at the Cinerama and other theaters on a double bill with a bad, hollow-sounding, English-dubbed Italian melodrama called "The Violent Professionals." It's about a good cop who feels hamstrung by law-and-order types and a conspiracy to bring down the Italian Government, which in this film apparently represents the law-and-order types. It's very, very mixed up. Old-timer Richard Conte plays a villain, a Fascist who dyes his hair and whose skin has the translucent look of a newly unwrapped mummy.

title: For the Senate: The main event East
description: It's not your usual biennial Senate singalong, with political castrati trilling everhigher promissory notes, In many ways, the New York election campaign between James L. Buckley and Daniel Patrick Moynihan is one of the oddest on record Consider that Vice President Nelson Rockefeller and Senator Jacob lavas, the graying and baldish eminences of the state's Republican Party, have all but said that they would as soon vote for Leonid Brezhnev as Senator Jim, the standardbearer of their own party. Or that Bella Abzug, the sweetheart of the left, who lost by a whisker to Moynihan in the pentagonal Democratic primary, refused until the last two weeks of the campaign to support him. Or that West Side wall posters denounce him as a class enemy and capitalist roader, and that many of the party's black leaders call him a spiritual descendant of Simon Legree.

title: The Autumn of the Patriarch By Galmel Garcia Wirquez Translated from the Spanish by Gregory Rabassa 260 pp New York Harper & Row. $10
description: In 1968 when he began to write this majestic novel, Gabriel Garcia Marquez told an interviewer that the only image he had of It for years was that of an incredibly old man walking through the huge, abandoned rooms of a palace full of animals Some of his friends remember him saying as far back as 1958, when as a newsman he was witnessing the fall of Marcos Perez Jimenez in Venezuela, that he would one day write a book about a dictator. He has since spoken of the Influence of the life of the Venezuelan ??? Juan Vicente Gomez, on this book He himself lived for years under the Rojas Piniila dictatorship in his native Colombia He covered the trial of a Batista butcher in the early days of Castro's Cuban takeover. He lived in Spain during the interminable rattlings of Franco's elusive death, when that country was a hospitable journey's end for deposed Latin dictators.

title: Last Call for A.R.B.A. Medal
description: Today is the final daythe absolute postmark deadlinefor ordering the fifth and last of the annual offerings in the national commemorative medal senes sponsored by the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration. This is the medal (described and Illustrated here at the start of the ordering period Oct 3) that displays the familiar bust of Thomas Jefferson on the obverse. The reverse design symbolically (with a hand, quill pen and scroll) commemorates the signing of the Declaration of Independence. The 1inch medal is available in bronze at $4 and silver at $15; three of each is the perorder maximum Do not send cash. Personal checks are acceptable. They should be made payable to the A.R.B.A. and sent to it at P.O. Box 1976, San Francisco 94101. Orders must be postmarked today (Oct 31) to be accepted.

One NBC official said the network could have done better with grand opera, which would have got the same low ratings but an incalculable amount of lofty praise and pres??? title: What's Doing in THE NORTH CAROLINA PIEDMONT
description: LAND OF CONTRASTS  The Piedmont region of North Carolina, stretching from the western edge of the Atlantic coastal plains to the Blue Ridge Mountains, is a land where old and new coexist. Its glass and steel cities throb to the spirited beat of the new industrial South. In the last hundred years enterprising men like Washington Duke have harnessed the region's economic potential, creating new industries and luring Northern manufacturers south. Charlotte, Durham, Greensboro, High Point, Raleigh and WinstonSalem have become textile, furniture, pharmaceutical, computer and agribusiness centers. The countryside hums to a quieter music, as it has since sturdy pioneers settled there in the 18th century, bringing with them traditions that still survive Its sounds are the potter's wheel, the plow preparing the rich Carolina earth for a new crop of tobacco seedlings and the soft unhurried drawls around the pumps of a backroads gas station.

title: ART MAILBAG
description: To the Editor: It was not only disagreeable, but also puzzling to read Hilton Kramer's opinion in A Great Show on a False Peg (Oct. 10, 1976) that my attempts to suggest visual and emotional continuities between Romantic landscape painting and Abstract Expressionism were sheer hokum. From his own writings, I would have guessed him to be more generous. Concluding an essay on Henry Moore in The Times (April 26, 1970), he could state. Moore is, then, a Romanticand a very English Romantic at that He is the true heir to the great 19thcentury landscape painters. And writing about Helen Frankenthaler (March 2, 1969), he could find affinities between her abstract painting and the early 20thcentury landscapes of Marin. Dove, and O'Keeffe. Apparently he is far more tolerant of his own freewheeling insights into connections between Romantic landscape and modern art than he is of the Museum of Modern Art's demonstration of his point or of my own longterm efforts, in a book and two essays, to trace exactly those arthistorical currents which would support his published apercus.

title: Criminals At Large
description: In PROMISED LAND by Robert B. Parker (Houghton Mif(lin, $7 95) there are indications that the author is beginning to take his creation too seriously. This is the fourth mystery featuring Spenser, the tough private eye from Boston, the ex heavyweight fighter, the gourmet cook, the student of Thoreau. By now Spenser is an amalgam of Lew Archer, Travis McGee and, maybe, Hamlet. He does a lot of talking and philosophizing, this guy does. He tries to probe into people's motivations and minds. There is more navelwatching here than at a convention of gums Parker should not allow things to get out of hand in future books. He has worked out a good formula up to now, one combining plenty of action with tightly constructed plots There is still plenty of action in Promised Land, in which Spenser is hired to track down a missing wife He finds her She gets into big, big trouble with a loan shark and his tough enforcer. So Spenser has to clear things up.

title: If the Girl Next Door Is a Call Girl
description: The absolutely last strawand really, this burned me upwas when one of the call girls do%n the hall woke us up at two in the morning and asked to borrow a bottle of vodkafor my guest, as she put itMy God, continued the woman telling the story, there she was, in a peignoir that must have cost $200, saying, Honey, could I borrow a bottle of vodka, as though she were no different from somebody in a small town going next door and asking to borrow a cup of sugar at two in the afternoon. Only that was two in the morning, and she sure wasn't baking a cake, either.The exasperated woman telling about how it is to live down the hall from an apartment rented to payforplay call girls lives in a highrise apartment building on East 63d Street off Third Avenue. She and her husband, both in their midthirties end successful, prefer that their names not be used here So call them Helen and Morgan, since they happen to be fond of a ceitain Prohibitionera blues singer

Perhaps, too he was merely being honest Oil will not solve mari. of Britain's basic weaknesses as trading nation, nor, in the short term, will it do the one thing Mr. Callaghan would like to accomplish, which is erase Britain's image as a nation which simply cannot sustain a reasonable standard of living and a generous program of social benefits without begging abroad.

title: His dazzling performances are likely to be better remembered than his script for a new world order.
description: Henry A Kissinger will go down in history as a great statesman, but not for the reasons he would relish and not without some black marks against him He would like to be remembered as a Bismarck or a Castlereagh who shaped a new international order, more stable and lust than the one he inherited He is more likely to be thought of as the Don Juan of international diplomacy, romancing and blundering his way through perilous affairs, to win out in the end From the present vantage point, Kissinger seems a flawed strategist but a brilliant tactician, capable of changing and recouping when all appears lost.

title: Horse Fever
description: All suffering horseplayers will relish William Murray's personalized, sometimes spirited account of betting in California. Author of 10 books and an avowed horse degenerate (inveterate bettor), Murray decided to live out his idea of paradise: spend a summer cashing win tickets in Del Mar Race Track near San Diego. But this seemingly festive life soon becomes a huge miasmic depression  Murray cannot understand why his cautious, intelligent choices always lose. Things go so badly that Murray can't even find Vince Edwards, the actor he calls the most consistently wrongheaded of bettors, for a clue on the one horse not to bet. Earlier, the author had ended a losing streak after hearing Edwards champion the same horse that he had bethe sold his ticket and bet another horse that won.

How ever, he won't be leaving St Peter's Church; at the request of the members of the church he has served long, Canon Boyd, with the consent of his bishop, will remain at St Peter's as Rector Emeritus

title: Sea Grapes By Derek Walcott. 84 pp. New York Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $895
description: Derek Walcott is a poet of great verbal resources and skills engaged in a complex struggle to render his native Caribbean culture, the new world, first successor to Eden For the past 28 years, as a poet and playwright, he has continu ally returned to the themes of that new world, locked in an ancient war between obsession and responsibility, and It is one of the touchstones of his gift that he has remained attentive to the diversity and reality of the West Indies without surrendenng its symbolic resonances and possibilities. Now in his sixth book of poems. Sea Grapes, we see him returning to his first concerns but with a new intensity, a deep, wellsharpened focus.

title: The Presidential Candidates Stand Apart on the Political Spectrum
description: WASHINGTONThe rhetoric of the Presidential campaign this year and the attention paid to style and personality have obscured the disagreements between the candidates on matters of substance. But President Ford and Jimmy Carter are not like Twiddledum and Twiddledee. There are fundamental differences between the two men on the issues that are likely to be paramount in the next four years Here is a checklist of same of them Unemployment and inflation The President believes that inflation is a more immediate national problem than is unemployment He has been willing to accept a relatively high national rate of unemployment to keep down the rate of inflation He opposes most efforts toward Governmentcreated jobs, believing that instead the Government should promote jobs in private enterprise through incentives to businesses.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A:LANTANA (OCT. ID) J.K., Millbrook, N.Y. asked how to winter over her Ian tana, a tender plant that i not winterhardy in this area Mrs. Ruth King, a Connecticut gardener, suggests, Before frost, I take my plants indoors and prune them severely, right down to the hard wood. The skeletal remains, still in their pots, are stored in our attic (or use a cool cellar) where the temperature remains between 40 and 50 degrees. Water the plants every two weeks, just enough to keep the wood from drying up. In early March, place the plants in a warm room near a sunny window. Increase watering. When budding and branching starts, prune plants back bard, almost to the crown since Lantana flowers only on new growth. Repot when budding starts again. I use a mixture of loam and coarse builder's sand enriched with bonemeal. Pinch back plants to keep them shapely and mounded. Put the plants outdoors after all danger of frost is past and feed every few weeks The method also works well for fuchsia.

title: Photographing the Birth Of Your Own Celebrity
description: The time is 5:30 P.M. on June 28, 1976. The scene is the labor room of of New York Hospital's ??? In division and I'm experiencing some of the most intense feelings of my life. My wife, Monique, is now approaching the final stage of her ninenour labor, and in accordance with natural childbirth methods, I am assisting her. My Nikon, three lenses, filters, four rolls of film and all sorts of related photographic equipment lie beside her bed. I'm wondering why in the world I've taken all of this along. I've been too involved in helping her with her breathing exercises to take any picturesand anyway, who Wants to photograph one's wife as she tries to cope with pain?
